front.head: Henry Silver’s Punch Diary
Transcribed and annotated by Patrick Leary

div.head: A note to participants in the Pictorial Punch Study Day, British Library, Nov. 7, 2025
div.p: Thank you for downloading this draft of my edition of Henry Silver’s “diary” (as he called it) of Punch table-talk. To my knowledge this is the only full and reliable transcription of this remarkable document, the original manuscript of which is part of the British Library’s wonderful Punch Archive. I have added links to open access versions of cartoons and articles alluded to in the diary in order to make them easy to consult as you read, a convenience that I think is particularly useful when comparing the discussion of the weekly “Large Cut” cartoon with the actual cartoon that was published in the magazine.

An introduction and various appendices are in preparation, but in the meantime I would be grateful for any questions, comments, or corrections. Please send these to me at pleary@gmail.com . For background to the diary you may wish to consult my book, The Punch Brotherhood: Table Talk and Print Culture in Mid-Victorian London (British Library, 2010).
Please feel free to quote from this document so long as you give the citation. The edition should be cited in this way:
Entry for [date of entry], Henry Silver’s Punch Diary, Patrick Leary, ed., forthcoming, 2026, accessed at http://victorianresearch.org/silver diary leary edition.pdf [date of access]
Please note that this edition is © Patrick Leary 2025.
I hope you will enjoy this fascinating document.
Best wishes,
Patrick
Henry Silver’s Punch Diary
Transcribed and annotated by Patrick Leary

[Quarter-bound in red leather with blue marbled endpapers. Binding is covered with a wrapper consisting of two layers of paper – the inner is tan, the outer is dark brown. Both very tattered. On the cover is written, in Silver’s hand, “Henry Silver’s Diary.”
[On the inside, blank side of the marbled endpaper, at the top, in brownish ink]
Henry Silver – his book.
[in black ink] Formerly of Argyll Square, W.C.
Then of 6, The Terrace Kensington
[in left margin] {Where John Leech lived 1862-1864: o b. Oct. 29}
 [drawing of pointing finger] January 1867 to September 1893
Since of 11, Prince's Gardens, S.W.
[brown ink]

p.hi: Forsan et haec olim menisse juvabit

note.p: Constance Smith's translation, from Virgil, Aneid I, 203: “One day perhaps it will please us to remember even this.”

div.head: [Silver's own introduction to the diary, written in 1908.]
div.p: The first article I wrote for Mr. Punch was sent without my signature when I was in my twentieth year. It appeared in February 1848 under the heading of “Obituary,” – Vol. 14 p. 47 – and recorded, with some humour, the death, at the ripe age of eighty-five, of a Big Elephant in Wombwell's travelling Menagerie, then staying at Norwich, where I was a law student. Not long afterwards I became a fairly regular contributor, and for several years received a guinea a column – the usual fee then to “outsiders” – the column then containing over 1000 words, and not 800 as it has done in the Twentieth Century. And then quite suddenly, and at a short interval, Mr. Punch lost two efficient members of his Staff. Gilbert a Beckett, who had written for the First Number – dated Saturday, the Seventeenth of July 1841 – wrote also for the Number dated Saturday August Thirty 1856, the day on which he died. And his death was quickly followed by that of Douglas Jerrold, in the following month of June. And so – ab illo quantum dispar! [how unlike him] – I was asked to join “The Table” in his place.

The first Dinner I went to was held at the “Star and Garter,” Richmond, on the last Saturday of August 'Fifty Seven. “Covers drawn at Six Sharp - Morning Toggery” – wrote Mark Lemon, in his brief note of invitation. We dined in a big room, at the back of the hotel, and the Senior of the Proprietors, Mr. William Bradbury presided at the feast. Sitting on his right, I had a good view of the river, which was really then worth looking at: for the Silver Thames was brightly shining beneath the golden sunset, and there were then no boatsheds or big chimneys to uglify the landscape.

On my right sat Mr. Peter Rackham, an old friend of the Firm: who, with Sir Joseph Paxton, enjoyed the frequent privilege of dining with the Punch folk. Facing Mr. Bradbury sat his cheery partner, “Pater” Evans, with Tom Taylor on his right hand, and John Tenniel on his left: and they, with Shirley Brooks and Horace Mayhew, made up “the Octave” – as it might be called now, though I fancy in the 'Fifties the word was only used in the Johnsonian sense. ...Thackeray, Leech, and the “Professor” Percival Leigh were all away from home.

We had doubtless a good dinner, and no doubt I quite enjoyed it: for I was young enough to look on a good dinner as a noteworthy event, while a good appetite came naturally more than once a day. I seem vaguely to remember that the Elders, between whom I was sitting, seemed just a little envious of the ease whereby I ate the entrées they declined, and yet, like Goldsmith's Gourmand, “kept a corner” for the dainty little “Maids of Honour” that were notable among the sweets of Richmond Hill.
“Maids of honour” tarts, puff pastry shells filled with sweetened cheese curds or jam, have long been associated with the borough of Richmond. Tradition dates their origin to the court of Henry VIII at Richmond Palace, and commercial production was begun as early as the 18th century. The quoted reference is to Oliver Goldsmith's verses to Lord Clare, “The Haunch of Venison,” in which the dinner-guests vow to “keep a corner” for the venison pasty.

I recollect, moreover, that when dessert was on the table, “Pater” achieved the perilous feat of bowling a big pineapple at his partner, who had asked him for a slice of it. And I feel pretty sure that not a single wineglass was broken in the transit. Then cigars were lighted – cigarettes were things despised then, and even fast young ladies carried a cigar case, as Leech showed in this week's Number [Punch 33 (29 August 1857): 92] ... What we chiefly talked about is now a “blank in faithless memory void.”
From Walter Scott, “The Lay of the Last Minstrel” (1805), line 77. The full lines, which close the poem's introduction, are: “Each blank, in faithless memory void, The poet's glowing thought supplied, And while his harp responsive rung, 'Twas thus the Latest Minstrel sung.” Silver used the phrase in his note for February 21, 1859, below. But I remember that Shirley Brooks made pretence of a Debate on the Cartoon, “Just to give the New Fellow some notion how we do it.” So he proposed the parody of Millais' picture, which appeared next Wednesday [Punch, 33 (5 September 1857): 99, '“The Order of Release”: With Mr. Punch's Apologies to Mr. Millais'].
Parliament was prorogued (that is, adjourned) on August 27, 1857, until November. Parliament was sitting late this Session and was yesterday prorogued: and both Palmerston and Punch were glad to be relieved by the “Order of Release.”
Silver's footnote: “The famous Cartoon of “the British Lion's Vengeance on the Bengal Tiger,” which Shirley Brooks suggested, appeared in Punch of August 22. '57 [pp. 76-77] and increased the Circulation.”

And before ten o'clock, on the Hotel Omibius he and I and other Juniors, with the Seniors inside, were taken to the Railway. “And so Home, mighty pleased” – as Mr. Samuel Pepys would say – after a very pleasant Evening.

div.head: 1858. August 4 W[ednesday]. {Night the first at 11 Bouverie St, previously at the Star and Garter, Aug. 1857.}
div.p: Present: Wm. Bradbury (top), H.S. (to his left), Shirley Brooks, John Tenniel, Mark Lemon (bottom) and Peter Rackham.

“We all have our places” says B[radbur]y, turning up the cloth and showing me JL’ s [small drawing of Leech’s signature of a leech in a bottle] cut on the deal, and “W.M.T.” next it. “D.J.”’s on B.’s right, P. Leigh, the Professor, at Southampton and Ponny – alias Horace Mayhew – at Scarborough.

White soup and salmon – champagne out of tumblers –seltzer and cigars. No puddings allowed – “because we don’t care for them” says S.B. in January, when E. wonders we don’t have them. E., like H.S., has a weakness that way.

M.L. jolly and full of fun – takes a paternal interest in T. now J.L. is in Scotland. “My dear Tenniel – now don’t eat too much salmon – think of your big cut – champagne? – here Hayward, champagne to Mr. Tenniel – pray attend to him Hayward and see that he wants nothing. Go fishing my dear T? – not if I know it! There’s a policeman always watching you – sometimes he appears as an organ man sometimes an old beggarwoman – etc. etc. pleasant chaff – tells of his being cross examined: “Are you a Jew?”— No. – “Do you know his handwriting” – Yes – “only seen him write once and yet you swear” – Yes – “What did you see?” “I saw him accept that bill.” Counsel shut up.

Preparations for Big Cut business – inkstand and sheet of paper to M.L. “What is it to be?”– I say “What a nuisance is that ‘Please to remember the Grotto’” – whereat S.B. says “Wouldn’t that do – Cherbourg grotto – John Bull” – don’t see it myself, but M.L. says “Good- Punchy” – And that J.T. sees it next Wednesday proves. [ Punch, 35 (14 August 1858): 67, “Please to Remember the Grotto.”]
Louis Napoleon had intended the invitation as a reassurance to Britain of his peaceful intentions, but its ultimate effect was to alarm British suspicions. For the larger diplomatic and naval context of the visit, see C. I. Hamilton, Anglo-French Naval Rivalry, 1840-1870 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1993); the dust-jacket of this volume features a reproduction of a painting by J. A. Noel of Napoleon III receiving Queen Victoria at Cherbourg on August 4, 1858. See Times article, August 4, 8a, “The Naval Fetes at Cherbourg.” For the custom of children’s street-begging during oyster season with the cry, “remember the grotto,” see Alfred Gosling Bennet, London and Londoners in the Eighteen-fifties and Sixties (London, 1925), 70-71; a rendering of an oyster grotto street scene in the 1850s can be found at Illustrated London News 19 (1 August 1851) 137. See also Percival Leigh’s poem, “Remember the Grotto,” in Punch, 51 (11 August 1866) 58; Leigh returned to the subject years later in a nostalgic vein, “The Gone Grotto,” Punch 69 ( 21 August 1875) 69; attributions to Leigh from the Curran Index. It is likely that Shirley Brooks, a kindly man in such matters, was welcoming the “new boy” to the Table by finding a way to give Silver credit for this Large Cut.

M.L. suggests Log of the Pera
“Log of the Pera,” Punch, 35 (14 August 1858): 64, and (21 August 1858): 74. The Pera was a steamship participating in the fete at Cherbourg, with British M.P.s on board. and Examinations of MP’s and eruption of the Strand -”Will you do it, Silver?” – “too much work about your suggestion of ‘Northward ho’ for big cut. Good notion tho’”

S.B. tells Walter Lacy’s story of the Maids of Honours’ W.C. 3 handles, fellow pulls. No.1 comes a soft hand and wipes – No. 2, douche of o’ de cologne, No. 3 a [illegible
The three or four words crossed out are illegible except for the last, which appears to be “dildo.” Cross-out is in brown ink. Greek word above is marked through in black, with a vertical stroke through each letter.] . .. As we walk along the Strand says M.L. “Charge for all copy now. Hope soon to get you regular salary – but you must let me go my own way.” To Sterry’s to sleep after [or “apres”] [three words crossed out] (for I am living at Croydon now.)

div.head: September 1, [1858] W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: B[radbury] & E[vans](bottom, P.L., S.B., J.T., T.T., M.L., P.R., and H.S.

P.L., the ‘Professor’ back from Southampton – T.T. inveighs against turtle soup – overestimated – says M.L. “I don’t want it every Wednesday but as we’re in the City, it” etc. etc. M.L. jolly always. B. and P.R. and J.T. silentish.

S.B. tells of Irish girl – ‘It’s a lonesome place – ye’ll be afther taking liberties wid me Pat’ – Arrah how would I wid the pig I’ve got – “Sure and wouldn’t ye be putting the pig under my potatee skep ye blaguard!”

Big Cut – my Covey of Puseyites and Punch shooting, misses fire. India the subject – T.T. suggests ‘graceful figure kneeling and giving sceptre to the Queen’ – accepted. [Punch, 35 (11 September 1858): 107, “The Accession of the Queen of India”]
In the aftermath of the suppression of the Sepoy Rebellion, Parliament passed the Government of India Act (21 & 22 Victoria) on August 2, 1858, stripping the East India Company of all administrative responsibility for the country and investing that power in the crown. For the Queen’s attitude to India at this period, see Miles Taylor, “Queen Victoria and India, 1837-61,” Victorian Studies 46:2 (Winter 2004) 264-274 M.L. wants something comic — T.T. thinks this too serious a subject to be treated funnily. M.L. says as a rule funny cuts sell best. S.B. wants cut for his Harem article “after showing a dozen bottoms (‘common objects at sea-side’ – great sale of) needn’t be too nice.”
Leech cartoon showing women in crinolines from behind stooping to pick up shells: Punch, 35 (21 August 1858): 76, “Common Objects at the Sea-Side–Generally Found upon the Rocks at Low Water” S.B. decidedly sensual as well as sensible – Editor of the ‘Lit Gas’ as they name the Gazette.
Brooks had become editor of the venerable Literary Gazette when Bradbury and Evans acquired a part-ownership in 1858. The acquisition was not a success.
I talk of Woodbridge as the place for port – and Mark asks if I knew Dr. Cork there – a pleasant allusion to my bottle stopping.

M.L. says it’s his wife’s birthday. Tells of anecdotes of old George Stephenson, whom he has met at Paxton’s – How when the rival engine came for trial S[tephenson] said to his wife “Eh, she looks a fine engine, Bessie lass – but I’se not afeard of her go.” Said in after years he enjoyed his bit of bread and bacon that day better than all his grand feastings since. Also, story of the butler saying George could drain the pit – which G. did – and years after when meeting the owner, Sir – in Hyde Park, George said “Eh, but here’s an older friend I must shake hands with, first. Here’s my friend Thomas the butler” – Capital hand at story-telling seems M.L. – acts what he says.
George Stephenson (1781-1848), son of a colliery operative in Northumberland, created the first commercial locomotive and railway. His “Rocket” defeated its rivals in a competition in 1829.
{N.B. 1st printed invitation this – received at Deal on Sunday.

div.head: October 21 [1858] Th[ursday]. At the Bedford.
div.p: Present: B & E, M.L. J.L., J.T., S.B., P.L., P.R., W.M.T., & H.S.

Cometh Thackeray after we had sat down, and sitteth opposite me, who am between S.B. and J.T. J.L. apologisette for not recognizing me on stairs and says “Let me call you ‘Silver’ will you?” Pleasant these small amenities. My first meet with Thackeray who does me the &c to take champagne with me. [interlineation in black ink:] {3 Carthusians at Table!! he, Leech and HS.} Makes a cheese devil to wind up with. Talks of Mackay and his liking for Kitawba wine and says his poetry is like it – sparkling but not so creamy as Moore’s champagne or so sound as Scott’s claret.
Journalist and poet Charles Mackay (1814-1889) published the poem “Catawba Wine” in his Collected Songs (London: Routledge, 1859) 284-285. Catawba was an American wine, first made in Ohio by Nicholas Longworth of Cincinnati in 1828. See Paul Lukacs, American Vintage: The Rise of American Wine (New York: Houghton-Mifflin, 2000). S.B. makes some reference to Hoggarty Diamond, where-at T[hackeray] challenges him to champagne and enquires after his health and family’s. T. says JL. has the best beer and claret in London – wishes for a cottage like Macready’s – the walls hung with caricatures and cuts from Punch – there would he end his days. Talking of fertility S.B. says he once wrote 6 songs in a day and @ 3 guineas apiece. Says his children know by heart my ‘Hoop de dooden doo’ parody, of which he quotes ‘At dis, my joke I laugh yup, yup!’
“Hoop De Dooden Doo,” Punch, 35 (5 June 1858): 229; reprinted in , 3 June 1858. p. 3. This was a parody of an American minstrel song. M.L. suggests sentimental song “Why art thou bilious, dearest?” and S.B. oceanic one ‘I gazed upon the dogstar the while you shot the cat.’ S.B. suggests parody on “Willie we have missed you” which I go and do, teste Punch.
“A Song Without Sentiment,” Punch, 35 (6 November 1858): 183.
J.L. tells of marrying for love – not finding bride in bed thinks ‘how considerate!’ when exclaims a shrill voice “Harry can’t catch me!”

Big Cut. Ponny
Silver had originally heard, and written, this name as “Poddy”; it is corrected in darker ink to “Ponny,” which he later realized was the nickname meant. The traditional explanation of this is that Horace Mayhew had been sub-editor, and that this post was also known colloquially as “pony editor,” but I have nowhere else encountered this use of the term, and neither Partridge nor the OED records it. (i.e. H. Mayhew) writes to suggest British officer bullying natives – (after Russell’s Indian letter
William Howard Russell’s letter in the Times for October 20, entitled “The Sahib and the Nigger,” criticized the disdainful treatment of the natives by the younger generation of British officers.). After a bit W.M.T. suggests poor man lecturing the rich – accepted [Punch, 35 (30 October 1858): 177, “One Good Turn Deserves Another”] – reversing the Social Science business, which J.L. thinks all humbug.
A reference to the second annual congress at Liverpool of the National Association for the Promotion of Social Science, which began on October 11. See leaders in the Times on October 13, 15, and 18. P.L. promises to do the ‘pome’. Wish my brains were as easily commandable. – P.L. descants on Swedenborg. Talk of Charterhouse, WMT and J.L. old Carthusians, like H.S. T. says one of first orders he received was ‘come and frig me’. Says “Curious how Charterhouse has eventuated in Punch.” Talks of circumcision there – candle and gob. J.L. says fighting ground was behind bog, where the church now is. In my time it was behind school
On the disappearance of “the old fighting-ground” at Charterhouse see [Andrew Alexander Knox], Once a Week 3 (21 July 1860) 100. – After they all go but J.T., M.L. and P.L., Mark says his religion consists of Lord’s Prayer and duty to neighbour. Walk home with J.T. via Regent Street.

div.head: November 10 [1858] W[ednesday]. At the Bedford.
div.p: Present: B & E, J.L., J.T., S.B., M.L., P.L., H.M., and H. S.
First time of meeting Horace Mayhew. Why they call him Ponny time must unravel – as also why they call P.L. the Professor.

P.L. suggests ‘Reform Works’ – hoarding up – no admittance. Bright and Russell & Co. as boys peeping over. M.L. suggests presenting Life of Wellington to Prince of Wales. W.B. argues with me (sitting between him and H.M.) that the adulteration business at Leeds is too bad to pass unnoticed, and J.L. suggests Death at the pestle, making lozenges.
In Bradford, candy was adulterated by mistake with arsenic instead of plaster of Paris, killing 18 people, most of them children, and making over 180 people ill. See Times, “Wholesale poisoning at Bradford,” November 2 and 5, and three letters to the Times about adulteration on November 10. Accepted. [Punch, 35 (20 November 1858): 207, “The Great Lozenge-Maker”]

Au reste, this is Feb 21, ’59 – and the blanks in faithless memory void I have no pencillings to supply. But I remember as we left that M.L. said “Keep yourself disengaged on Wednesdays, please” which pleasant hint I duly put into a safe cupboard of my memory. M.L. before said he didn’t use my “Burlesque in Bankruptcy” solely because S.B.’s had come in first – whereat S.B. says he’s sorry, and won’t write so early again.
“The Battle of Bankruptcy,” Punch, 35 (1858): 194 M.L. also talks of a ‘capital’ article he has read this morning about “The advantage of having a Bad Temper” which rejoiceth the vanity of the writer to hear.
“On the Advantage of Having a Bad Temper,” Mr Punch's Pocket Book for 1859, 160-163.

Walk via Regent Street with J.T. – thick fog and wet – thick all day. Sunshine at Woodbridge, said Mrs. Thom – and at Brighton, said J.L. Catch a soupçon of Bronkles which I make worse going to C[rystal] P[alace] on Saturday, and on Sunday night I didn’t sleep a wink – Ugh! that night – how Frith’s window rattled and would let in that infernal East wind and no towels would keep it out. Make me think of old times, and fancy myself a gasping asthmatical old gentleman of 80.
December 1. M.L. says ‘Pray join us at Six and then I’ll speak on your vote (as to David Eaton)? But I had eaten my dinner eheu! Thought I might remind him that I had “kept myself disengaged.”

div.head: December 9, Th. 1858. Bouverie St. again.
div.p: Present: E., J.L, J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M. and H.S.

(Sit to E’s right where D.J. cut – as W.B. points out next week – and, henceforth take this seat facing J.L. “These little things are great to little men.”
Ovid, Ars Armatoria, 1,159Rather a slow meet – perhaps because no champagne).

Evans seedy – and Bradbury dittoer. M.L. late – from Scully v. Ingram – says Ingram looked more like a detected pickpocket than a Member of Parliament. Gives history of case, which to me is a mystery. J.L. thinks it ungentlemanly to haggle about estates and pocket £2000 by reselling.
Vincent Scully, M.P for Cork County, brought suit against Herbert Ingram, M.P. for Boston and founder of the Illustrated London News, for misrepresenting himself in a set of transactions concerning the County Hyde estate in Cork County, transactions in which he was acting in concert with Irish M.P. John Sadleir. The jury found for Scully. This was one of a number of trials arising out of the extensive swindles committed by John Sadleir, who committed suicide in 1856. A good contemporary summary of Scully v. Ingram can be found in Spectator (11 December 1858), 1290.

London yacht dinner yesterday, whereat M.L. and S.B., latter as a friend of Arcedeckne’s, proposed his health.
Andrew Arcedeckne (1822-1871), known to his friends as “Archie”, was a Garrick Club chum of Thackeray, who used him as the model for Harry Foker in Pendennis. Some old Admiral proposed ‘the petticoats’ which was amended into ‘The Ladies.’ A. suggested omission of offensive words, proposing The Ladies – without the petticoats.

M.L. says he wrote the first article in Punch, after vainly waiting for D.J. J.L. tells of Gil a Beckett being locked up with a deal table, pen and ink and a gin bottle, when Figaro was short of ‘copy.’

M.L. thinks Cattle Show
The Smithfield Club Cattle Show opened on December 7 and was visited by Prince Albert and the Duke of Coburg. the subject – and I suggest Prize Nation Show – John Bull receiving Gold Medal – sotto voce to H.M. who says it has been done. M.L. thinks a cut of the Queen and P[rince] A[lbert] looking at pigs – “Too fat, Albert, getting too fat!” would be popular at Palace (!) – S.B. suggests Bright pitching into Cobden & Co. – gives satisfaction to the liberal party. (accepted). [Punch, 35 (18 December 1858): 247,”Mr. Bright Offers to Give Satisfaction to the Liberal Party”]
In a speech at Manchester on Deembrer 10, 1858, Bright had been critical of the Liberal Party, represented in the cartoon in the person of the diminutive John Russell. Brooks’s idea may also have been indirectly inspired by a Times review of an anti-Bright pamphlet published by Conservative MP Henry Drummond (1791-1860) that imagines that Bright and Drummond “fairly step into the ring as antagonists”; Times (8 December 1858) 6c. H.S. tells of farmer and busman, which J.L. next week illustrates – I want to go to ..”“All right, old boy, I know Cattle Show!” [ Punch, 35 (18 December 1858): 246] Also of Gun Trick and backwoodsman – “Guess I nearly had you there, old hoss!” whereat S.B. laughs consumedly. Also tells of how Yates served Tom Reed.

M.L. tells of bringing out farce called ‘Punch’ at the Strand – wherein a new parrot introduced one night from knockshop, which instead of saying what he ought began “Show us your cocks.” Also discourses parentally of his son Mark – fearing he may go wrong etc. – confesses to having slept cum puellâ sempinoctè sans kidding. ТλΕΕΤ only. Amusing to hear the grave and sedate Professor holding forth on moral matters. S.B. openly Baudi. Calls a spade a spade. [In margin:] B[radburyl would like a photograph taken of my modesty and compared with my impudence some 500 dinners hence.

NB. In November suggested Bus Nursing cut. Lot of Nurses teaching Busses to fight.
This refers to the “nursing” system whereby omnibuses competed with cabs and one another for fares. Articles protesting the system appear at Punch, 35 (1858): 161, 220, 240. No such cut, large or small, appears.

div.head: December 15, 1858. W[ednesday]. Almanack Dinner.
div.p: Present: B & E, J.L., T.T., W.M.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., & H.S.
Clapping of J.L. on entry – achieved is the glorious work! (and so we have champagne and my second turkey – my first yesterday at L.G. Pancakes for lunch! Christmas feasting beginning!)

Thackeray on sitting says “Aminadab Fishhatter!” to M.L. “Most elaborate riddle” he remembers having seen.
“What Will He Do with Them?” Punch, 35 (18 December 1858): 245, based on Thackeray’s character in The Virginians. Chaffs and mystifies H.M. about his likeness to General Williams – “You were born in 1802 in Nova Scotia – served at – “ and so on. Leech been at Brighton – asks “Any more rows?” Suggests a weekly Column of Fights to come off in the literary circle. Thackeray talks of “Mr. Jakes” and “the Drain.”

Presentation of the Almanack – one apiece. Toast “Success to the Almanack.” 5,000 sent off to America today. Round of Applause No. 2 – “Tickled with a straw” H.M. thinks the funniest — Man with beard like Chorley.
Henry Fothergill Chorley (1808-1872), an influential author and critic, wrote for the Athenaeum for thirty years. For more commentary about Chorley, see Silver’s entry for November 6, 1861. NB.

The Gordian Knot known in the trade as The Gordian Not Yet and The Gordian Perhaps: so christened for its uncertainty of coming out.
Under the pressure of debts, overwork, and family obligations, Shirley Brooks faltered in his serial publication of his novel The Gordian Knot (with illustrations by Tenniel), much to the outrage of his publisher, Richard Bentley. The eighth number appeared in October, and a ninth in December, after which the story was not picked up again until December of 1859. The novel was published in one volume by Bentley at the end of that year, with a preface in which Brooks praised his publisher and took full responsibility for the delay. P.L. tells long story of how he went to Okey’s [?] table turning and came forward as a skeptic and was asked to do the trick with a pretty widow. Talks well does P.L. – albeit somewhat “like a book.”Bland voice. Sala in Queen’s Bench. H.M. dined there with him.
Queen’s Bench Prison in Southwark, which since 1842 had taken over the confinement of bankrupts from Mashalsea and the Fleet. George Augustus Sala (1828-1895), a versatile journalist who figures largely in the diary, was already by this time known as “king of the Bohemians” among his literary companions for his spendthrift and hard-drinking ways. Talk on Bohemians of literature. Thackeray likens his writing to Dickens and water. Learn from H.M. that the article on ‘Bivins’s’ was by young Chas Dickens.
“A Hall of Dazzling Light,” Punch, 35 (11 December 1858): 234-35 Thought it rather a crib from Sala and unworthy of Punch.

Big Cut – won’t do Duke of Beaufort and Aunt Sally. H.M. suggests Sally in our Alley which I tell him I have done.
The Duke of Beaufort had been involved in an altercation at the Brighton races in August. The Duke was playing at Aunt Sally, a game in which a black doll was set up with a pipe in its mouth and the object was to throw a heavy stick in such a way as to knock the pipe out of “Aunt Sally's” mouth without touching the doll itself. A Mr. Weatherly rode his horse between the Duke and the doll, at which point the Duke threw sticks at Weatherly, who confronted him; a policeman was summoned, and the two men sued each other. The jury, at Lord Campbell's direction, found for the Duke in one suit, assessing damages at one farthing, and for Mr. Weatherly in the other suit, assessing damages of £100. The case was widely and gleefully reported in the newspapers: see, for example, “The Duke and Old Aunt Sally,” Lloyd's Weekly, 19 December 1858, p. 5, partly reprinting the extensive coverage in the Daily News, December 14, p. 4. See Silver’s verses, “Aunt Sally,” in Punch, 35 (25 December 1858): 254. Leech don’t like Christmas generally and Xmas parties in particular. The opening of the closets and the feasting of the skeletons would make a cheerful cut, eh? M.L. suggests John Bull catching India under the mistletoe – and this accepted faute de mieux, but John Bright in pegtops cuts it out I find... H.M. en partant asks M.L. whose is that Canzonet Upon Contentment which he pronounces ‘very good – neatly put!’
“A Canzonet upon Contentment: By a Poet with a Decent Balance at the Banker’s,” Punch, 35 (25 December 1858): 252. Pleasant, quiet fellow is Ponny – get on with him better than with S.B.

div.head: December 22, 1858. W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: B & E, Sir Joseph Paxton, J.L., T.T., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., and H.S.

Sir J. “free of the table” B[radbury] says. Sits between us and champagnes with me. Says he has drunk eno’ champagne to wine the road from St. Paul’s to Hammersmith. H.S. C.D. from Clem’s Barrett and Clay – and so couldn’t enjoy the lark pudding etc.

Been looking over Beddington Park, Sir J. has – gives me an opening for my gamekeeper and Suffolk dialect story. Plain spoken man, and drops an H occasionally – but clearly a clear head – and not a bit stuck up.

Tells how he heard that Strahan and Paul were borrowing at 12%, and so warned the Duke not to put money in their bank.
The Duke referred to is the Duke of Devonshire, Sir Joseph Paxton’s patron. Strahan, Paul, and Bates, a venerable English bank, collapsed in 1855. Its liabilities were £750,000, of which £113,625 represented clients' securities that had been misappropriated and sold. All three principals were sentenced to prison. The case was in the news again in 1858 because Robert Makin Bates had appealed for a reduction of his sentence. See Paul Johnson, Making the Market: Victorian Origins of Corporate Capitalism (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2010), 128-131. T.T. asks, changes seats with me for a private confab. Which ended, the Big Cut is disposed of, T.T. suggesting Derby as Mazeppa, Bright & Co. hallooing him on – horse “Reform” – says he has done Bright in verse as John Gilpin.
Mazeppa (1819) is a narrative poem by Lord Byron whose title character is punished by his enemy by being strapped naked to a wild horse. Mazeppa and the Wild Horse of Tartary, a theatrical version written by Henry Milner for Astley's Royal Amphitheatre, opened there in 1831 in a production, staged by manager Andrew Ducrow, that featured live horses; the equestrian drama was revived there in April of 1858. When the drama was revived at Astley's again in 1864, Ada Isaac Menken's appearance in a flesh-colored body-stocking, strapped to the back of a stallion, made it the succès de scandale of the season. The Diverting History of John Gilpin (1782), a comic ballad by William Cowper, tells the story of a draper who rode a runaway horse. The story was based on a real John Gilpin. H.M. suggests “the Reform Waits” – Bright with ophicleide etc. etc. John Bull looking out of window – “Come move on, you men – don’t stand kicking up that row.”
An ophicleide was a brass wind instrument invented in the early 19th century. By the 20th century the ophicleide had largely been superseded by the tuba. H.M. also suggests “The Reform Waits” – which is done in January [Punch, 36 (15 January 1859): 25, “Reform Snap-Dragon” ]
Snap-dragon was a traditional game, often played at Christmas, in which a shallow bowl of brandy was set alight and the players competed to snatch and eat raisins from the bowl without burning mouth or fingers.. “There’s life in the old dog yet” says S.B. – alluding to Ponny’s fecundity. But the British Juryman cuts all out — an afterthought of somebody’s, like Bright in pegtops not brought out by B & E’s champagne [ Punch, 36 (1 January 1859): 5, “The British Juryman Preparing for the Worst”; Punch 35 (25 December 1858): 257, “A Step in Reform: Suggested to Mr. John Bright, while He is About It”]

Then a discussion on the Franchise – Sir J. talking vehemently and T.T. knowingly – SB and P.L. the other chief speakers. Sir J. says Bright’s plan would be most unfair – giving manufacturers much power and taking away from intelligent workmen (who in Coventry are a large clan) all voice in the elections. Either wealth or brains should be the grounds for having a vote, says Tom: and so say we all of us.
Then a talk about France and her progress compared with ours – Sir J. rather gloomy in his forebodings.
Can’t say H.S. cometh out yet as a conversational contributor. But live and learn is proverbial wisdom. And a good listener has some merit.

[pointing finger] Inspected the New Adelphi afterwards with M.L. and J.T. – opens on Monday and is a Shavings Shop now!
Ben Webster had demolished the old Adelphi and built a larger theatre, seating 1400 patrons, which opened as the New Adelphi on December 27, 1858. See Illustrated London News 33 (18 December 1858) 579-580. – Tom Ireland confirmed M.L.’s story of Anderson being shot through the lip with the gun trick. T.I. held the gun while loading.
Scottish magician John Henry Anderson (1814-1874) performed the “gun trick” at the Adelphi on June 26, 1841, when the bullet lodged in his mouth, breaking off a tooth, tearing his lip, and causing profuse bleeding. “Accident at the Adelphi,” Era, 27 June 1841, 11. – Pitt painting – coat plastered with paint – fine idea of perspective at three feet distance! M.L. and the tenpenny nail in gallery stall. M.L. calls P. the bottomless Pitt, personal peculiarity.
Thomas Pitt, scene-painter at the Adelphi and Covent Garden. Pitt was mentioned by drama critic E. L. Blanchard in an article in The Town in 1839: “The little elderly gent seems to drink more than he eats, eat more than he thinks, and talk more than all put together.”Clement Scott and Cecil Howard, eds., The Life and Reminiscences of E. L. Blanchard (London: Hutchinson, 1891), 64.

div.head: December 29, 1858. W[ednesday].
div.p: Invited, but “can’t get away from the birds” Am to dine regularly now I spose. Well – I’ve done something progressive in 1858 – If I’ve not raised my standing, I’ve at least secured my sitting.

div.head: January 5, 1859. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: Present: B. and E., M.L., S.B., H.M., and H.S.

B. with nasal discoloration. M.L. proposes addition to Notes on Noses of ‘the Christmas Nose.’ E. has bad cold, so H.M. calls them the “Infirm of B.&_E.” M.L. says they’ll have to take him in as the dining partner – whereat S.B. christens E. the shining partner and B. the lining partner.
Talk anecdotic and theatrical. S.B. tells of his losing 1/- to Peter Cunningham on the epithet in Ben Jonson’s Epitaph “Here beneath this
sable P.C.
plumed M.L.
marble S.B.

hearse” which he quotes. Good memory, has Shirley. Tells also of his being in the publishing office and seeing small boy come forth tremblingly and the stern voice of Captain Joyce bellowing – “Give that boy three dozen!” (Little Dorrit to wit).
Bradbury and Evans had published Dickens’s Little Dorrit in twenty monthly parts between 1855 and 1857.

M.L. tells of his being the only one in the house at some country theatre, and finding all the actors playing at him. Imitates Harley – his hesitation in putting his name to a subscription list, underlip protruded – Also gives imitation of a country actor playing Corsican Brothers when ½ drunk — “My brother – hic – in Paris – hic – feels at this moment the precisely – hic – same sensations as – hic – myself.” Glorious imitator is Mark. And jollier than ever today – pour amuser les Invalides.

“Just one – one would do it” hints he – and of course we have a couple (between M.L., S.B., and H.S. only – for Ponny don’t take champagne.) S.B. tells of Yankee refusing to let his wife bring their children to see him hung – “What a shame,” says she, “just like you – never let them have any pleasure!” M.L. talks of Hood “cruel” in his fun. Spoke on his deathbed of the power Punch had, and how he feared they were living too fast etc. etc. Tells of actor as lion roaring: “If I was a real lion and you trod on my tail, of course I should roar!”
Big Cut: H.M. suggests the Inexhaustible Broadbrim – Bright bringing out Reform trinkets. But tho’ accepted it isn’t done.

div.head: January 12, 1859, W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: E., M.L., J.L., J.T., T.T., S.B., and H.S.

Talk of Burns his Centenary. 621 poems sent in – awful the thought of facing the rejected 620.
Tom Taylor, Monckton Milnes, and Theodore Martin were judges of the Crystal Palace competition for the best poem to honor the centenary of Burns’s birth. See Times, 5 Jan 1859, 9d. A letter to the Times on 8 January, 9d, suggests naming the top six poems.“We may meet hereafter” says T.T., – “Yes, but let’s hope it won’t be in the land of Burns!” says S.B. Suggests parody: “Read the boo”

Mock turtle, red mullet, turbot, saddle of mutton, and boiled fowl (“Oh, I can’t stand this” says J.L.!) kidneys, ptarmigan – brown flesh, deuced good. And all this after reading of The homes of our Poor in today’s Times!
The Times article, “Our Homeless Poor,” ran on 24 Dec. 1858, 8c, and caused an outpouring of proposals, petitions, and letters, including a long letter published on 12 January. Smart that take-off by S.B. of G.H.M.’s letter – appeared on Saturday.
A Times leader on the “appalling uniformity of our English feasts” (January 3, 1859, p. 6) called forth a long letter to the editor with additional suggestions, from “A Dinner Giver” (January 5, 1859, p. 12). Brooks’s parody of the letter, “English Dinners for Snobs,” Punch, 36 (15 January 1859): 28-29, is signed “G.H.M.” “Shows what your young men can do, Mr. Evans.” Says J.L. “Life is short – let us be as miserable as we can – so Mark, my dear fellow – a glass of wine with you?” – Talk of D. Jerrold – at Margate, Englishman and American expected, former arrives only. Says his wife, “I’m so glad.” – “Twasn’t the Yankee she wanted, but the Doodle” – D. J. to bathing woman: “Your water’s nice enough, but your bottom’s beastly.” To a lady who said man had been “off and on” with her daughter for some months – “Off and on for months – ah then he’ll never marry her.”– To a Muff – “Shouldn’t mind having your brains if I could have your stomach.”

S.B. says Byron said of Southey: “I’d have his head if I could have his face.” Impotent husband spoken of as having taste – “Ask what his wife says – ‘Taste, yes, and nothing but a taste.’ – Talk theatrical: M.L. full of nannygoats: tells of actors rehearsing combat with just their fingers, so, to give him an idea of it. Quotes celebrated passage from a heavy by Shirley – A certain “spangled officer” forgetting himself and saying “What tho’ I wear my golden epaulettes upon my breow!” T.T. tells of old Diddear taking him aside and begging him for the combat to substitute a curse. “Sir – I have piles!” his reason for so asking.
Charles Bannister Diddear (1801-1859). Imitates old Kemble – his speech at farewell dinner at the Garrick – “I look around me – where are the gentleman – where the etc. etc. who once graced the stage. Alas! There are no gentlemen now.” Pleasant this for the actors hearing him.
The Garrick Club gave Charles Kemble (1775-1854) a large dinner at the Albion, attended by over one hundred guests, on January 10, 1837, on the occasion of his retirement from the stage. Taylor retold this anecdote at the April 8,1868 dinner meeting.

Big Cut: J.L. suggests Our Homeless Poor, I sticking up for it against S.B.’s Reform Bill. And M.L. backing me [Punch, 36 (22 January 1859): 34, “The Homeless Poor.” ]. I had thought of a divided picture, poor dinners and rich – Leech detests Blue Coat School. Evans larky “I mean to get drunk tonight” – but doesn’t.

div.head: January 19, 1859. W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: E., J.L.,T.T., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., & H.S.

T.T. reads the Prize Poem which is commended as being above the average of such effusions and as not being written by one who merely got up some enthusiasm for the occasion. Especially nice the lines “which any hand could wound and none could mend Save but the Maker of the Instrument.”
The prize poem of the Burns contest was by Isa Craig, a woman, who received fifty guineas. The poem was read aloud by tragedian Samuel Phelps at a ceremony at the Crystal Palace and printed in the Times for 26 January, 9b. T.T. accepted judgeship (with Theo. Martin and Milnes) simply because he thought it might fall into worse hands. Read 300 through, and of these, a score or so twice at least. Of a 100, a half a dozen lines sufficed: e.g. one beginning, “Grind, old Time, grind away at thy grand old melody, Nature” – And another running somewhat thus –
“Hail Caledonia! land of snuff and cakes – (or something equally complimentary!)
““ Scotland yearns
To celebrate the birthtime of her Burns:
To celebrate the Exciseman, fool, and sot,
The only poet she’s produced, but Scott!”

Fancy Phelps beginning to spout this and being silenced by a chorus of infuriated Scotchmen! Then apologizing and saying this was one of the rejected ones. T.T. eloquent on the causes of B’s popularity – gave expression to certain ideas and phases of mind which are common to most people and generally felt. Everyone can feel [crossed-out word] the martial spirit in ‘Scots wha hae’ – the conjugal love in ‘John Anderson’ – Home affections in ‘The Cotter’s Saturday Night’ etc. Good motto that of No. 2 – “Gaudente terrâ vomere laureato et triumphali oratore.”
“The rejoicing land threw forth a laurelled and triumphant spokesman.” (Constance Smith) T.T. won’t forget “Tis now one hundred years ago.”

Big Cut. T.T. suggests Louis [Napoleon] as Aeolus holding the winds of war – “vastâ sedet Aeolus arce” – sitting on his big a – se. J.L. at dinner suggests parody, “Behold how Brightly breaks the Session” – this is accepted for Cut – (but not done).

Discussion on the Policy of Punch – take the right side and not the Bright side. – J.L. versus C. Dickens Junior for writing about Evans’s and Dinners (not my Dinners).
According to the Curran Index, Charles Dickens, Jr., wrote 14 pieces for Punch between October 1858 and February 1859, including two specifically about dinners. “Evans’s” refers to Evans Music-and-Supper Rooms at 43 King Street, Covent Garden, a popular dining room celebrated by Thackeray in The Newcomes as The Cave of Harmony. “My Dinners” probably refers to Silver’s Punch series about dinners, perhaps “Dinner Time Part II,” 15 January 1859, p. 22. – M.L. says must have variety, if even inferiority. C.D. Jr. in Baring’s house and progressing favorably, E. says, defendingly (as a probable father-in-law).
Frederick Evans’ daughter, Bessie, was engaged to Charles Dickens, Jr. They married against his father’s wishes in November 1861. Dickens, Sr. did not attend the ceremony. Tells that C.D. Senior has withdrawn his son’s name from Garrick proposal list because he wrote that bit in Punch against the Lounger, Yates and Baronets. Wheels within Wheels. J.L. calls him a cocky young fellow and thinks he would not be comfortable among his seniors at the Garrick. (Echoing my own thoughts about H.S. in that position.) J.L. then applauds Saturday Review for cutting up Jerrold – thinks he was “mean and close-fisted.”
Review of Life and Remains of Douglas Jerrold, by his son, Blanchard Jerrold (London: W Kent & Co, 1859), Saturday Review, January 15, 1859: 74-75. The author denounced Jerrold for “systematically attacking and deriding every institution of his country; Merle Bevington (The Saturday Review, 1858-1868, 1941) attributed this review, on unspecified grounds, to James Fitzjames Stephen (1829-1894).M.L. defends him and in parting says to me, “I don’t like to hear him ill-spoken of – he was always kind to young men especially and gave them a helping hand.” J.L. against his radicalism and low breeding – clearly J.L. inclines to the Clubbish view of things. Query if not a worshipper of No. 1. I don’t think insight into literary circles improves one’s opinion of literary men. I did so at first sight – but – Here I’m beginning to find everybody thinking doubtfully of everybody. J.L.’s antipathy to Forster I don’t know the depths of. Talks of him wearing Kean’s trowsers. And S.B. makes an imaginary biographist say, “Here we find our hero strutting in borrowed plumes etc.” Again, on dit, that Dickens has cut B. and E., and t’other day passed M.L. his oldest friend without recognising him. – Again, Frank Stone is ill treating his wife, by whom he had several children before marriage and ought therefore says Evans to have been more than commonly kind to her.
Artist and illustrator Frank Stone (1800-1859), neighbor and close companion of Dickens. The 1851 census shows Frank and Elizabeth Stone with four children: Ellen (15), Arthur (13), Marcus (10), and Lilian (6). Parish records indicate the couple having married on April 14, 1852. Frank and Elizabeth Stone were estranged at the time of Frank's sudden death in November of 1859. Five years later, rumors of ill-treatment of his widow by their third son, illustrator Marcus Stone, briefly delayed the latter’s election to the Garrick Club. See entry and note for March 30, 1864.

To change the talk – and one beauty of the Knights of our Round Table is that their conversation is continually changing – let me tell of Leech’s story of the man and his wife – she reproaching him for his dissipation and extravagance, “Suppose you die now. What will become of me?” – He replies, “My love, for God’s sake, let’s take a more cheerful view of things – Now suppose you die, let us say.”
This joke can be found in Jane Austen, Sense and Sensibility, in the dialogue between Mr. and Mrs. Bennett.
T.T. contends if you extend suffrage you will lower the tone of Parliament and damage its efficiency.

T.T. defends Imperial Government on the ground of Economy – look at St Pancras or any other parish: rates always higher than taxes: Now if Bright’s bill passed it would assimilate Imperial Government to Parochial – there would be an infusion of the demagogic element which in time would oust the gentlemanly and educated – and the last state of the House would be worse than the first.
Bright’s bill is described in the Times for 18 Jan 1859, 10a. The Times leader of the same date (6b) is skeptical, but concludes that the bill deserves careful consideration. House always listens to lowerclass [inserted in place of crossed-through “poorer”] members if well informed. S.B. recollects Brotherton getting up on Factory Question and saying he was 10 years a factory boy – and there was a dead silence.
Joseph Brotheron (1783-1857), became the first M.P. for Salford after the 1832 Reform Bill, and was re-elected five times.

div.head: January 26 [crossed out: “27, Th”], 1859. W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: E., J.L., Thackeray, J .T., S.B., P.L., T.T., & H.S.

Mark unwell at Crawley, so S.B. takes the Vice Chair and editorial inkstand. W.M.T. receives and corrects “Virginians” proof – which he says will inform me of the name of the headmaster at Charterhouse a 100 years ago. Dr. Crucius to wit – Rosy Crucius?
Dr. Eberhard Lewis Crusius (1701-1775) was headmaster of Charterhouse from 1748 to 1767. He is referred to in Thackeray’s historical novel as headmaster of “the Chartreux.” asks P.L. Owns to having been flogged – “hurt like h-ll” – I tell of our potatoe [sic] pelting Old Mother Whatwashername and of the swishing some score of us got for us: 8 cuts I had, but mild ones – from Phillott – drew blood but didn’t hurt half so much as that brute Tasker’s caning did – for knocking Wms’ toast off.
Henry Wright Phillott (1816-1896) was assistant master at Charterhouse during Silver’s time there. “Tasker” was school slang for “headmaster,” who at that time was Augustus Page Saunders (1801-1878). J.L. says there was a swimming bath in Rutland Place. W.M.T. all the brighter for using lemons lately. T.T. tells of Formes’ “I sall [sic] sing you some-ting obscene” – meaning “comic” – ladies all on tip-toe, “waiting [crossed-out illeg. word] to hear when the ravishing would begin.”
Possibly Karl Formes (1815-1889), a German opera singer who performed frequently in London between 1850 and 1857.

Big Cut: T.T. suggests, from correspondent, Pam’s dinner to the 40 Whigs (Thieves) “Is it time?” – Also Sardinian Marriage – L[ouis] N[apoleon] as . .. Hymen, black and threatening. S.B. suggests Bright on throne opening Parliament. T.T. cries shame on J.L. for shirking the “Behold how Brightly” cut – Bright rising as Sun at back – loaves and fisherman as chorus – Leg of mutton and greasy pole so simple, says L[eech]. T.T. suggests, if Reform’s the subject, The Rival Billstickers – Bright sticking up his bill and Derby and Dizzy pulling it down and pasting theirs over it. Also, Bright and British Constitution – Take away that Bauble! Chosen. T.T. quick and fertile. [Punch 36 (5 February 1859) 55, “The Quaker and the Bauble.”]

J.L. still against Jerrold. W.M.T. says he talked treason at this table and M.L. charged him with it and for once made him blush. Was about setting up “The Pen,” a rival to Punch while he drew his salary and dined and did no work. At same time was writing Dickens his disapproval of Punch. Evans says they debated whether his salary should continue and resolved it should – altho’ he did no work.
“Writing Dickens his disapproval of Punch” refers to a letter written in the fall of 1846 that had just been published for the first time in Blanchard Jerrold's Life and Remains of his father (London: W. Kent, 1859). In it, Douglas Jerrold wrote, “I am convinced that the world will get tired (at least I hope so) of this eternal guffaw at all things. After all, life has something serious in it. It cannot all be a comic history of humanity. Some men would, I believe, write the Comic Sermon on the Mount. ...Surely the world will be sick of this blasphemy. I can only say for myself, at times I am ashamed of my literary companionship and its perpetrators” (259). The recollection by Evans that Jerrold was starting a comic magazine called “The Pen” at the same time, and that he “did no work,” are both mistaken. The effort to start such a magazine came three years later, while the Punch contributors ledgers show that Jerrold continued to contribute steadily to Punch throughout the last twelve years of his life. For a helpful discussion of this passage in the diary and of Jerrold's relationships with his Punch colleagues more generally, see Michael Slater, Douglas Jerrold 1803-1857 (London: Duckworth, 2002), 119-140, 177-180, 217-218.
Says S.B., “Horace Mayhew’s always crying ‘Connu’ when anyone says anything. If told the world was made he’d have said, ‘My brother invented it first.’”

Send telegram to Bradbury at Brighton, “We have just drunk your health and hope to see you among us soon again.” E. says B. has worked up from being a printer’s boy – has printed at case – and his great taste has much improved the style of printing. Apropos of Frank Stone, E. talks of the duty of husbands to make their wives happy: and of masters to make servants happy. Says Mrs. Dickens is happy and has a right to be so. J.L. tells of Dutchman sh- overboard with drawers on and dropping watch – “Shite and no flop!” – “flop and no shite!”
S.B. quotes The lady prefers Capt. Tucker
To Mr. Commissioner Grant –

as a model of neatness of reasoning.
The entire verse is quoted in a letter from George Augustus Sala to Edmund Yates , 22 March 1878: “The Lady preferr’d Captain Tucker / To Mr. Commissioner Grant / Because Captain Tucker can – her / And Mr. Commissioner can’t.” This refers to a case involving Henry S. George Tucker (1771-1851), tried for rape in India in 1806. Judy McKenzie, ed., The Letters of George Augustus Sala to Edmund Yates (Queensland, 1993), pp. 214-215.

div.head: February 2, 1859. W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: E., J.T., S.B., P.L., & H.S.
Tenniel’s first appearance in a black choker! Glad to see it, says J.L. next week.
Posters from Glasgow stuck up by S.B.: “Burns Centenary – Satan’s Revival” “Burns Celebration – Scotland’s Humiliation,” with text from Jeremiah appended.

Big Cut: Nothing better than T.T.’s suggestion last week, The Torch of Hymen – with allegorical smoke. [Punch 36 (12 February 1859) 645, “The Torch of Hymen”] P.L. agrees with H.S. that we should preach against England lending the sinews of war. John Bull buttoning up his pockets and saying “fight away if you like – but don’t come to me to be surety for the stakes.”
See Times leader of this date, 8b-c, denouncing the private Austrian loan as making war between Piedmont and Austria more likely. The form of the Big Cut was provided by the marriage of Princess Clotilde Maria Teresa Luise of Savoy to Prince Jerome Napoleon, cousin of Louis Napoleon. The Times reprinted some verses of Punch on the marriage in its issue for 3 Feb, 8e. S.B. writes off to Egg hint for picture – Dr. Johnson in his night rambles putting pennies in the beggar boys’ hands, as they lay asleep on doorsteps. Touching story of his carrying drunken girl home and having her attended to.

Poets discussed: chief charm of poetry is its suggestiveness – horrors should not be described but hinted – e.g. Scott, “Here an arm, there a leg” – (What lines were those S.B. quoted? Capital memory has S.B.) more terrible in its indistinctness than the cut and dried terrors of inferior writers. Poetry suggests pictures to the mind: something more than music – the sound pleases and the thought remains. E. loves country – and loves walks better than rides. Thinks Tennyson’s Lotos Eaters not enviable – Loves his work as the producer of his pleasure. But it should ‘be worthy work’ as Goethe calls it, says P.L. Says H.S., I like work too – when it’s done.

E. for my especial benefit recounts the details of the split with Dickens.
For an account of this split, see Patrick Leary, The Punch Brotherhood (London: British Library, 2010), 82-92, 164-168. How D. quarreled with Punch for not inserting his letter. John Forster the go between and B&E refused to kootoo. Forster advised D. not to print that letter – but Delane of The Times said “Do.” – D. asked M.L. to name trustee for Mrs. D., E. refused at first but D. said he should like no one better and then E. consented. Wanted Joyce to be discharged offhand for having talked about Mrs. D. — E. believes Yates said this to D., proved to be a lie and D. had to retract. (Joyce was once B&E’s master!!)
Felix Joyce, to whom Bradbury had once been apprenticed, had for many years served the firm as manager. See Dickens to F. M. Evans, 8 June 1858 (Dickens, Letters, 8:580-581) for Dickens’s acknowledgement that there was no evidence for his suspicions that Joyce had gossiped about the separation.P.L. says he expects ere long to hear that D. has proclaimed himself to be God Al-mighty. Thinks himself a god now – Says S.B. If he is we are Atheists, for we don’t believe in him. E. says C.D. Junior must soon choose between his father and him, Evans. D. wrote the other day to deplore his son’s connection with Punch and Bessie Evans.

div.head: February 10, 1859. Th[ursday].
div.p:
Present: E., J.L., W.M.T., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., & H.S.
In his old age, Silver provided Shirley Brooks’s biographer, George Somes Layard, a bowdlerized and embellished version of this entry. See G. S. Layard, A Great ‘Punch’ Editor: Being the Life, Letters, and Diaries of Shirley Brooks, (London: Pitman & Sons, 1907), 165.
Mark redivivus but in low spirits still. Thackeray CD – drinks seltzer and beer – “excuse me for being so fractious, Evans.”

Charade last night. J.L. and S.B. thereat – latter writing it as the Professor wouldn’t. “Tic e tic e tic” – an air the P. wouldn’t write the words to. Illustrated his state of brain by a medical simile: If you take a dose of salts you may force out an excrement but it won’t be healthy or natural. So the forced products of the brain are unpleasant etc.

Carlyle’s Frederick the Great discussed – ‘waste of labour’ the general verdict, spite of what Tom Taylor said t’other night about its being translated into German and selling 10,000 copies there. E. says he felt neither wiser nor better for having read it.

S.B. wonders if reading books which one hasn’t time to read on earth will form one of the joys of Paradise.
The reworked material that Silver gave to Brooks's biographer, G. S. Layard provides a more extended version of this remark: “‘One day,’ Mr. Silver tells me, ‘he said he wondered whether among the joys awaiting us in Paradise there would be found time for the leisurely perusal of good literature, unread in our hard-working and overcrowded days on earth. Leigh pressed him for the list of volumes he would choose. But Shirley protested that it was not possible to prepare off-hand a catalogue for the immortal library. He was clearly of opinion that not more than three English novelists (himself of course not among them) should be included. Of one thing, however, he felt certain, and that was, that no little of the current literature of the day (save the mark!) would be forced as a torture on the denizens of “the other place”!’ A Great ‘Punch’ Editor: Being the Life, Letters, and Diaries of Shirley Brooks, (London: Pitman & Sons), 199. Says W.M.T. a man who produces cannot hope to read much – describes German pianist who threw his best cigars on the fire saying “Ah – we pays duppence for a zigar like zis at Brussels.” Wants T. to write him 2 songs and promised to “dedigate” them to T.- d-n him!

Big Cut: What’ll you take for that are Cuba? – Yankee to Spain – No Professor – not a popular cut.
This refers to the bill pending in the U.S. Congress to appropriate $30 million for the purchase of Cuba. See the jocular leader on the subject in the Times for 10 February, 6c. S.B. suggests Diz with Telescope which J.T. initializes: Evans says Navy first, Reform afterwards – two Jack Tars discoorsing: J.L. suggests French Porcupine, which everyone sees the fun of [Punch, 36 (19 February 1859): 75, “The French Porcupine”]. “You’ve hit it now” says S.B. (NB. J.L. meets J.T. to hunt – at 1:45 Gt. Northern tomorrow – knocks off the cut in a couple of hours after breakfast.)

Jaw on the necessity of woman – brightens the body and clarifies the wits – “Who loves not wine, woman and song He lives a fool his whole life long” says S.B. quoting Martin Luther. It’s a natural necessity, admits P.L., but may be combatted by physic – (that’s unnatural says Thackeray) – same as the Monks did. P.L. contends it’s one’s duty to subdue flesh and cultivate the mental over the sensual: You lose the taste for lust if you think of better things. S.B. and E. and Thackeray chorus “But we don’t want better things.” Says Thackeray to me, “I admire you for it – the way you sit in becoming silence.” S.B. says, O you should join the ladies! Where are they, says H.S. – who has stretched a point by saying he does not remember George the IV. Born ‘28.

div.head: February 17, 1859. Th[ursday].
div.p: Present: E., J.L., T.T., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., & H.S.

T.T. fights S.B. Burns and anti-Burns, says T. Burns, like Shakespeare, wrote for all men and for all time. Says B., he only wrote of 3 things which may be for all time but are not for all men: to wit, lust, drink and blasphemy. Says T., Either you’ve not read Burns or you’ve no soul for {you don’t understand} poetry – and as I cannot believe the latter of you, I am forced to think the former. Answers B. I’ve read more of him than most men and I don’t think such lines as those beginning, “The fowl’s dung o’er your father’s pate” have very much of poetry, or do much credit to your pure poet, Tom – J.L. interposes, Calm yourself, my dear Taylor – etc. Very funny is J.L. in such interpositions.

Talk of Chelmsford’s last – the Higgins job.
See leading article in the Times for February 17, 1859, p. 7. The Lord Chancellor’s son-in-law, William Francis Higgins, was obliged to resign as Master of Lunacy and various other sinecures for being unqualified. T. thinks it a grave matter, and worthy of a great cut. But H.S. and the rest think it not widely known enough. J.L. suggests, “Row of Ministers doing their jobs” as being an agreeable subject. Shows what we should come to if it were not for the press, says E.

For Big Cut, T. suggests Dizzy coming to Papa Bull – “please I want a new boat”, and amends it to Bull going to Pakington, boatbuilder (approved) [ Punch, 36 (26 February 1859): 85, “Naval Reform” ]. Somebody suggests Bull asking for “more fleets” as Swell fellow for “more gigs”.
See Times leader for February 15, 1859 re: Disraeli’s announcement that the Navy will be reconstructed under the direction of Sir John Pakington.

Hear that “Owen Meredith” is a nom de plume for Bulwer, Jr. And rumour says that Bulwer Senior being asked to approve his son’s poems in MS. struck out dozens of allusions to unhappy childhood. T.T. hates B. as a writer – thinks him a vain charlatan and no genius

T.T. tells of foreign swell shooting at Windsor, and after being enjoined to spare the hens blowing one to bits, and being horrified—”Mein Gott, it is one bitch!” Also of foreigner in taking a fence being thrown twice over horse’s head and believing that to be the correct way of leaping, saying, “I sall leap no more.” J.L. also tells of Count – “Fox stole away.” – “Ah – den I spose we must go home!”

Spar No. 2 between J.L. and M.L. – J. saying he wants portraits, has only 7. M. thinks he might look out for them himself. J. says he hasn’t time, hates politics, and never thinks of them when walking out. Detests big cutting. Mind employed on picking up ideas.— P.L. speaking “ex cathedrâ” he says, disputes my Dr. Garrod statement that pox has come out in 3rd generation, passing over the 2nd.
Dr. Alfred Baring Garrod (1819-1907), had been elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1858, and was later celebrated for his theories on the origin and treatment of gout and mental illness with lithium. Talking of phrenology, says that Palmer and Mrs. Manning had similarly formed heads.
Murderers Dr. William Palmer (executed 1856) and Maria Manning (executed 1849). Engaging accounts of their stories can be found in Richard D. Altick, Victorian Studies in Scarlet (1970), and Judith Flanders, The Invention of Murder (2012).

div.head: February 23, 1859. W[ednesday].
div.p: Present: E., J.L., J.T., M.L. S.B., H.M., and H.S.

Says J.L., “Glad you gave the Illustrated Times that wipe.” – Burgos to wit, whereat H.S. pleased at such kudos expatiates {“These little things are great to little men”}
Punch, 36 (26 February 1859) 88, “Critical Intelligence,” makes fun of the writer in the Illustrated Times (February 5, 1859, 91) for thinking that “Burgos,” the Spanish town depicted in a painting, was the name of the artist. The remark appeared in the column “The Lounger at the Clubs,” written at this period by Edmund Yates. Per Constance Smith, the “these little things” quote is from Ovid, Ars Armatoria.
E. at Olympic on Monday (H.S. saw him there) and calls it a disgrace to British critics to have allowed such bosh as Mazeppa to keep the stage.

P.L. at Vocal Assn. Undress Concert last night (not sorry H.S. wasn’t recognized) – Very mild, except Mademoiselle Leanass, or Linas. Whom H.S. admired too.
The Times ran a favorable notice of the dress concert of the Vocal Association, an amateur group, at St. James’s Hall (10 February 1859, 10c).

Greek seldom quoted in the House, says S.B. Thinks country gentlemen like to hear quotations – reminds them of their youth ... P.L. produceth new toy, gutta percha bladder which squeaketh like a baby and delighteth Evans.

J.L. thinks the petty British shopkeeper the meanest creature in creation. Advantage of high birth is that a man [crossed out: “gets to”] has no need to cringe – can look men in the face, and has no fawning. Therefore pleasanter. Ponny walks into Aristocracy. Says Reform is wanted. P.L. says, “Doubtful, no need to excite the country – wait till they ask for it.” S.B. says, But Government ought to legislate in advance, and not wait till Acts are clamoured for. So says H.S., quoting father’s favourite (Huskisson’s) example, how he legislated against the wishes of the persons whom he benefited.
William Huskisson (1770-1830), statesman and M.P., latterly for Liverpool. Despite a distinguished and influential career in politics, he is most often remembered today for having been the first casualty of the railway age. He was killed after being struck by George Stephenson's Rocket during its maiden run on the opening day (15 September 1830) of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway. Saw farther ahead than they did. And so a statesman ought to do. Should lead, not follow.

Large Cut long in coming to life. M.L. suggests Post Office – new regulation about compulsory prepayment. S.B. defends this as facilitating delivery. P.L. and M.L. say,- “But the poor would suffer.”
The Postmaster General had announced in January that as of Febrary 10 all inland mail would require prepayment. A Times leader of 19 February (9d) objected to the new rule, as did many letters to the editor. Rowland Hill, secretary to the Post Office, announced on February 25 that the rule had been withdrawn. J.L. thinks the poor don’t want to write letters. – Precious aristocratic we’re getting, says H.M. — S.B. suggests Balance of Power: John Bull’s foot in scale outweighing arms heaped on by Austria and France. H.M. suggests Giant France backing up Dwarf Sardinia. Go in and win, my little man. I’ll see fair for you. P.L. and H.S. think that England refusing loan would do. J. Bull with money bags and France and Austria coming to borrow – “The real peacemaker,” H.S. Says Evans, but John Bull don’t find the loan, it’s the Jews. The Jews govern the world.” J.L. thinks we don’t half pitch into the Jews. “Then,” says H.S., “let’s turn over a new leaf.” J.L. then recollects that he has an invitation to a Jew’s place to hunt. Says S.B., private arrangements must not interfere with public duties. Men who sit down at this Table must not remember they have friends. “Leave friends behind, all ye who enter here” should be the Inscription H.S.
Pope upheld in chair by France and Austria, fighting – H.M.

Louis Nap. on powder barrel, smoking the pipe of peace, S.B. Good, says H.S. L.N. blowing up the funds. John Bull bulling them, S.B. L.N. bearing them, M.L. But people don’t know Stockexchangeisms, says P.L.

At length J.L. reverts to what he said last week – “Keep your powder dry.” John Bull saying it to whom? P.L. says Queen saying it to Derby – No, says J.L., Queen saying it to Bull as her butler in the storeroom. Good, says M.L. “We’ll keep this dry” a good title, says S.B. [ Punch, 36 (5 March 1859): 95, “The Queen in Her Store-Room”]

Forgot to tell Palmerston’s Epitaph as quoted by T.T. last week – “Siste Viatrix. Here lies all that was loveable of Palmerston, Lord Cupid: Whose opinion it was that no gentleman should remain ½ hour in company with a lady without trying to seduce her.” The Professor lectures on phrenology. Says he would not knowingly hire a servant with a bad head. Does not believe in the localisation of organs – but in general development. A good head betokens a good brain: a cramped head indicates a contracted one. Peculiar developments incline to special acts, but may be neutralised. The Professor talks like a book.

The others clear away and we 4 righthandsiders are left. S.B. proposes some more claret and the Professor breathes a sweet consenting No to it. Then tells of Irishman at a hospital where he (the P.) was studying (was it Bartlemy’s or Guy’s) on being bled in the arm and feeling faint, said, “I’m thinking, Sir, this would be a mighty asy way of cutting one’s throat.” H.S. caps this Bull with that of the Old ‘Un – “Vad ye like, Sir, to be called at 5 or 9?”

Merrier meeting than we’ve had of late. Walk away with H.M. to his snuggery, 38 Regent Street – Regent Chambers to wit. S.B. fills his pockets for his “brats”, explaining that the Proprietors have to pay for the dessert whether eaten or not. So H.S. walketh away with more than his usual one cigar. Shall get a boxfull in time and shall christen it The Punch Box. A contributor has his perquisites, even as a maid of all work.

div.head: March 2, 1859. W[ednesday].
div.p:
Present: E., J.L., T.T., H.S. (place to W.M.T.), J.T., M.L., P.L.., S.B., H.M., and W.M.T.
Over 35 years later, Silver provided to Marion Spielmann an extraordinary re-imagined version of this entry, re-dated as March 7, 1859, expanded from memory and edited for propriety, for Spielmann’s history of the magazine, described as “an extract from Mr. Silver’s Diary” and titled (by Silver) “A Night at the Round Table”; M. H. Spielmann, The History of “Punch” (1895) 68-73.

Turbot and haunch of venison. What a good dinner, says Tenniel. Tantalising to Tom T. to sit and eat naught – going to dine elsewhere, and Thackeray leaves at 9 to go to a “tea-fight” at the Bishop of London’s. T.T. comes merely “to hear what you fellows say about the Reform Bill” – which Diz brought in on Monday. Begins discussing it at once. H.M. condemns it: does nothing for the working man. T.T. thinks people look to Punch and that Punch should take a decided course. P.L. and M.L. think we should stand by, and see how the stream runs first. All agree that Walpole acted as a man of honour in resigning; not being a rich man, his pension would not have come amiss to him.
Spenser Horatio Walpole (1806-1898), Home Secretary, resigned over disagreements with the reform bill introduced by Lord Derby, explaining his reasons to the House of Commons on March 1. Question if Ponny’s idol, Bright, would have done so. S.B. asks why Lord Overstone is like copper: because he’s a Lloyd with Tin.
A wealthy and influential banker and former MP, Samuel Jones-Lloyd (1796-1883) was raised to the peerage as the 1st Baron Overstone in 1850. His father, originally a minister, founded Lloyd Jones & Co. Bank, which was later incorporated with the London and Westminster. “Tin” was 19th-century slang for money. Also, If you put your head between your legs, what planet would you see? Uranus. Whereat W.M.T. laughs consumedly and S.B. says he put it in the Almanack and chaffs Mark thereanent.
This joke does not appear in the Punch Almanac for 1859. W.M.T. talks of a Miss Peawell, and of his being inclined to say to her – My dear Miss Peawell – I wish I could.
Thackeray long suffered from a painful urethral stricture, possibly the result of an early venereal infection. In his old age, artist Charles Keene, writing of his own “plumbing disrepair,” recalled: “I often now think of poor Thackeray how he used to groan when he retired behind the screen by the Old Punch Table!” Keene to Francis Burnand, undated but probably ca. 1889 (Keene mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University). Says to me, “I went to Charterhouse the other day. Hadn’t seen school come out since I left. Saw one little fellow with his hands behind him and a tear upon his cheek, and 2 little cronies with their arms round his neck – and I knew what had happened and how they’d take him to the bog and make him show his cuts. Talking of cuts, how about the Large One?”

Thackeray suggests, lawyer, doctor and schoolmaster, brought up as prize boys and Diz presenting them with votes. H.S. thinks of Diz launching Reform ship, lopsided: query “Will it Swim?” – M.L. hints, Dizzy joining hands of artisan and yeoman: giving each a vote. Thackeray suggests working man coming among gentlemen and saying, “What have you done for me?” P.L. thinks the situation would be shown by poking up the British Lion” not yet roused: and then if he gets roused we can have another cut of him with his tail and monkey up, says S.B. Idea gradually approved [ Punch, 36 (1859): 105, “Who Will Rowse Him?”]. J.L. wants to know if Ponny would prefer a good old fashioned cut of the starving virtuous British Workman, with Death in the background – wife and children dying, while the B. W. refuses work till he can have his rights.

Splendid mill between Ponny Mayhew, or the Regent St. Pet, and Pater Evans and John Leech, the Aristocratic Stunners. Ponny lets fly by saying Punch is standing still – used to take the lead, but now fears to do so. Avançons! Evans returns, “But times are altered, my dear Ponny, and Punch alters with the times. Strong language has done its work and there’s now no need of it. Nobody talks now about the trampled working man and the Dignity of Labour. Poor not crushed now as they were 15 years ago.”
For the larger political context of these changes, see Miles Taylor, The Decline of British Radicalism, 1847-1860 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1995). Says Leech, “I’m a man of extremely simple tastes. Give me my claret and my hunter and I ask not for more.” Apropos this of Bohemianism which Ponny cracks up. “Charley Kenny [sic] lives on £5 a week: and is a d—d clever fellow,” says Ponny. “His own fault, then, he don’t earn more,” says E. “Never was a time when penmanship more at a premium.”
Miscellaneous journalist and author Charles Lamb Kenney (1821-1881) at one time had connections to several Punch staffers, having collaborated on burlesques and farces with Albert Smith, Tom Taylor, and Shirley Brooks. In 1859 he was on the staff of the Standard. (DNB) Ponny cracks up Robert Brough – another d—d clever fellow: cleverer than any man at this table. “What has he done,” says Leech. “Tell you what he don’t do,” says S.B., “he don’t wash much, if he writes much.” Quotes dictum of Mrs. Watts Phillips – “Wash his hands! – he ought to boil them! Should have them scraped, like horse-radish.” “Would do for the Stinking Tosh Club,” says J.L. “Ah,” says Ponny, “You never admit the talent of anyone but yourself, Leech. Nil admirire is your motto.” Nil what?” says Leech., “I don’t admire Brough because I don’t know what he’s done. He’s a d—d clever fellow, no doubt, but what has he done to prove it?”
Robert Barnabas Brough (1828-1860), versatile writer for periodicals, novelist, and burlesque writer, had been associated, with his brother William, with such rivals to Punch as Man in the Moon and Puppet Show. At this time he was working with Sala on the Welcome Guest. Known for his Bohemian tastes, radical politics, and amiable personality, he was the principal founder of the Savage Club. Brough and his brother were both related to Mark Lemon by marriage, each having having married a cousin of Lemon’s wife, Nelly, whose maiden name was Romer. See the thoughtful 2012 essay by Cynthia Dereli, “Robert Barnabas Brough: a republican writer of the mid-nineteenth century.” “There’s Sala, too,” says Ponny – “another d—d clever fellow.” Says Evans, “If Mr. Sala had been a gentleman, he should have had a seat at the Punch table.” Well, I envy these Bohemians,” says Ponny. “Wish I were one of them.”“Don’t kick me,” says S.B., for Ponny’s getting excited. Talks politics again and cries out, “Avançons!” and “excusez moi” and spouts French till J.L. says, “There, don’t talk like a lady’s maid. Why can’t you speak English.” Says S.B., “Chacun a son gout, if you come to speaking French, take that.” H.M. quotes dictum of Brough, that Planché would frig himself in white kid gloves, as a proof of his d—d cleverness. Every man his own woman says H.S. (to himself).
[on otherwise blank page.]
And now both in metaphor and in literalness the chronicler of ye Round Table will turn over a New Leaf.

div.head: January 18, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., J.T., E., P.L., H.M., and T.T.
First appearance of H.S. since December 7 – so “Welcome little Stranger!” saith Mark. And all the rest (H.M. excepted) take friendly notice of his presence.

[Crossed out: “Talk of Grey’s.] M.L. suggests the Book of Costumes, and that incident and anecdote be in it.
Punch, 37 (4 February 1860): 45. “Punch’s Book of British Costumes,” Silver's only series for the magazine, ran for 44 weeks but was not reprinted in volume form. Tells of Rarey’s lecture to 3 or 4,000 cabmen and busmen – come in their own cabs? Very orderly and very smelly.
On January 12, at Allen’s Riding School in Seymour Street, celebrated American horse trainer John Solomon Rarey (1827-1866) gave a demonstration of his skills to an audience of 3000 cabmen and omnibus drivers on behalf of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. A cabman at the gathering was arrested for stealing the coat of Mark Lemon, Jr.; Morning Herald (14 January 1860) 8. Arrival of The Benicia B’hoy – M.L. with Tom Sayers in first class – “bust my b-breeches” “b—y hot ain’t it Sir” – ‘fancy’ first class talk – imagine a bishop the addressed party “I say, old cock, just pull down that bl— window will yer?” Tom fidgety, and pulling gold watch out etc etc. T.T. used to go to fights, agrees that pugilists are blackguards. – P.L. been at Southampton, playing Skittles – alley hung with Muses (portraits of). H.M. says inscription should be “Descend ye Nine.”

T.T. been drilling – teaches promptness in obeying word. Query, if Englishman’s self-reliance and independence doesn’t account for their slowness herein? Tells of Alec Reed being disgusted by Tom Sayer’s boots inscribed “Champion of England.” If he were champion he’d wear a suit of black – (in mourning for his defeated foes?) Tom’s boots unprofessional he thought.
Legendary prize-fighter Alec Reed (1800-1877), known as “the Chelsea Snob,” had come to prominence in the 1820s and remained a part of the boxing scene for decades, staging demonstrations and giving lessons.
J.L. tells of Swell saying “Vember” and “zelle” for his account of sporting in Algeria.

M.L. tells grim tale of a whist playing on a communion table in Lincolnshire. One of the 4 dies and is stuck up as a dummy. H.S. talking of that Pakefield man swimming for 9 hours. T.T. corroborates it – and tells of a crew being exposed to hot tropical sun in open boat till their flesh looked like roast pork, all brown and cracked and scored.
In a ceremony on 28 December 1859, the Royal National Lifeboat Association awarded medals to the lifeboat crews of Lowestoft and Pakefield for their services during the November gales off the Suffolk coast. H.M. asked by the Mons. [?] for a notice “Blaguez mois, donc, mon ami.”
Cornhill Magazine sold 80,000 the first number — dinner of turtle was given on Saturday.

T.T. tells of Celeste paying £50 for the looking glass in Christmas piece. Drury velvet curtain of Macready cut up by Bunn for dresses. All properties must be left. T.T. swindled by Laura Keene – substituting one agreement for another. Says Americans think there’s no wrong in being ‘sharp’
Laura Keene (1826-1873) was British, but made her name in America as actress and theatre manager. She began producing Tom Taylor’s plays in 1857.
