His “Our American Cousin” was bought by Keene and made its debut at Laura Keene’s Theatre in New York in 1858; her company was performing the play at Ford’s Theatre in Washington when Abraham Lincoln was assassinated on the night of April 14, 1865. Taylor’s sour view of Keene may reflect the fact that he did not participate in the profits from “Our American Cousin,” which, with the help of E. A. Sothern’s improvisations as Lord Dundreary, enjoyed great success for years. – Bad government where the unschooled 100 govern the 10 scholars – and those who don’t pay the taxes have the spending of them. A Kakistoquacy P.L. calls it. Aristophanes, an oklokracy—mob law. The Irish a strong party there and the worst of the kakistocrats. Odd that in a republic men should sink to the radical extreme of calling themselves Democrats.

H.M. tells of some young Swells’ club where fellows boasting of their long descents – when Lucifer fell from Heaven – that was the longest descent. “Devil sh-t one flying” said a Yankee in Mark’s hearing. Haymarket the Gaymarket.

L.C. Archbishop Dixon’s “Robber” taking his hand from Vicar’s throat – down comes the Pope, J.L. Cobden teaching Napoleon to spell freetrader, T.T. [ Punch, 36 (28 January 1860): 37, “Dame Cobden's New Pupil”].
J.L. thinks girls injure themselves by not blowing noses because the sound is vulgar. I tell of list in pot.

div.head: January 25, 1860. W[ednesday] No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T. and Sir Joseph [Paxton]. Champagne.

Death of Cap. Harrison on Saturday. Big ship kills everyone connected with her.
The Great Eastern. See obit, Times 23 January 1860, 10.

J.L. with Speaker’s Secretary at opening of Parliament yesterday. M.P.’s rush as bad as boxing night. Splendid sight when the 400 bosoms uncover — like the best of pageant scenes in Shakespeare, says S.B. – You see the British Constitution. Miss Seymour, says J.L., the daughter of the Queen of Beauty at the Tournament, hath a face such as all the artists that ever have painted their imaginings of beauty could not have come near to.
Jane Georgiana Seymour (1809-1884) was the “Queen of Beauty” at the Eglinton Tournament, a medieval-style tournament held by the Earl of Eglinton in Scotland in1839. She was the wife of Edward Seymour, later the 12th Duke of Somerset. Leech refers to one of their two their daughters: Lady Jane Hermione Seymour (1832-1909), who married Sir Frederick Ulric Graham in 1852, or, more probably, Lady Ulrica Frederica Jane Seymour (1833-1916), who married Lord Henry Frederick Thynne in 1858, who first entered Parliament in 1859 as member for South Wiltshire. S.B. has seen the sight 10 times and thinks it the finest possible. [small print, in margin] S.B. hopes J.L. won’t get aristocratic in his girls’ noses, and give up drawing cuddleable girls.

S.B. gives me a gratulatory handshake (was at Boulogne last week) and asks if I got the ballads for bedlamites – I tell him of T.G.R.’s at once pronouncing the music to be Mudie’s – a brother of the Library.
“T.G.R.” is theater impresario Thomas German Reed (1817-1888), with whom Taylor, Lemon, and Brooks had all worked closely, and about whom they liked to complain. Yet Brooks, at least, knew and liked German Reed and his wife Priscilla (1818-1895) socially; Brooks's diary for January 6, 1864, notes that he spent “a very jolly evening” with the Reeds, along with Silver. “Ballads for Bedlamites” appeared in Punch 38 (5 November 1859): 184. Charles Edward Mudie (1818-1890) was founder and proprietor of Mudies’ Select Circulating Library, a vastly influential commercial lending library that shaped Victorian publishing practices for decades.

Sir J[oseph] says his Coventry Constituents don’t mind giving the French the advantage of 18 months in the free trading, but they want the treaty to be definite.
Commercial treaty with France debated in January and February, goes into effect in March. The Times inveighed against its provisions.

L.C. Cobden tying L[ouis] N[apoleon] and Britannia with true lover’s knot. M.L. and T.T. (accepted) [ Punch, 38 (4 February 1860): 48, “The True Lovers' Knot”]. Pam flooring Diz for his opening speech: first blood for Pam. T.T., Diz as bird perched on Telegraph and Pam as boy (with horse pistol, H.S.). J.L. (accepted) [ Punch, 38 (4 February 1860): 49, “Pam and the Jackdaw”].

M.L. shows “Elastic Engravings” [illegible cross-out] and E. explains the india rubber process plainly and concisely as he generally speaks. This after all have gone but P.L., S.B. and Lucas. E. gives P.L. Encyclopaedia, “thank you, Pater, I don’t deserve such a magnificent present.” M.L. writes “ Argent” on scrap, but before E. gets it, E. says ditto to H.S. Worth £7 says Lucas. “Can’t read it, Mark” says E. “You’ve answered it, says M. “Kindness on both sides” says S.B. “Hope I shall make good use of it” says S.
Almost certainly the five-volume edition of Charles Knight's The English Cyclopaedia: A New Dictionary of Universal Knowledge, published by Bradbury and Evans in beginning in 1855.

Pater “could tell a tale about the getting up of a Daily Paper” – the day when Henry Wills marriage [sic] the most wretched in E’s life – discussing with Bradbury and Paxton as to whether price should be dropped to 3d – ought to have gone to wedding and then the fatal error would have been avoided.
At the urging of Paxton the firm had agreed in 1845 to back and publish a new morning newspaper, the Daily News, as a Liberal rival to the powerful Times, making an initial investment of £22,500, setting up extensive offices in Whitefriars, and engaging a large staff. The venture proved catastrophically expensive: Dickens, engaged as editor, left after a few weeks, a lowering of the price to 2s 6d proved a disastrous experiment, and Bradbury and Evans, along with other investors, lost tens of thousands of pounds. W. H. Wills (1810-1880), an early contributor to Punch and later editor of Household Words, was married on April 23, 1846, to Janet Chambers (1812-1892), the youngest sister of publishers Robert and William Chambers of Edinburgh. Moral: “Never neglect pleasure for business,” M.L. M.L. tells that at that wedding Jerrold “blessed you my children – go and make your Wills” and how D.J. taking Camilla Toulmin (Toolman) in to breakfast was accosted with “Pray what’s [crossed out, illegible] your opinion of Capital Punishment?”
Camilla Toulmin (1812-1895), later also known as Mrs. Newton Crosland, writer and editor. Toulmin was a friend of Jerrold’s and tells several anecdotes of him in her memoir, Landmarks of a Literary Life, 1820-1892 (New York: Scribners, 1893). Says S.B., “should have answered that when a man committeth matrimony, ma’am, he ought to be well-hung.”

T.T. tells of child asking to “wear my drum when I say my prayers, and I’ll promise not to think of it.” T.T.’s baby at Tunbridge – a sad blank is a silent nursery. Pater’s great wish is to be a grandfather. M.L. says filing the fetters a good effect in The Dead Heart.
The Dead Heart: a story of the French Revolution (1859), a play by Watts Phillips, played at the Adelphi with Ben Webster in the lead, beginning November 10, and ran for 80 performances. Henry Irving revived it at the Lyceum in 1889 for the centenary of the French Revolution. Agrees with John in saying guillotine’s anticlimax.

Talking of Scotch Jews, Mr. McLevy
Probably James McLevy (1796-1875), Edinburgh detective and popular author. – J.L. –Wants S.B. to give a name to the Artists’ Riflecorps that shall include authors – “Painters and Paper Stainers”, M. L.

[Crossed out, “Tales of”] Ages of authors in Once a Week
“Ages of Some Living English Writers,” Once a Week (14 January 1860), 53.– Billy Russell (and others) complaining. S.B. writes in reply that “The Editor of Once A Week is surprised at the liberty which the Editor of so young a journal as The Army Gazette has taken in questioning the accuracy of an established print: and in reply begs to state 1st: That Irishmen are not to be believed – 2nd that if Mr. R. is as young as he pretends he ought to be ashamed of himself for having done so much. 3rd, that Mr. R. can’t possibly remember his own birth and therefore the writer of the notice being an older man is better able to say when Mr. R.was born than Mr. R. himself.”
Talking of artists making their pretty servants sit as models, S.B. fancies indignant wife saying “You may say you only make her sit, but I know she makes you stand.”
Evans tells M.L. Once a Week must be remodelled – large cuts.
M.L. says they’ve decided to have Indoor Amusements once a month. M.L. tells of stockbroker being adjudged 2/6 per week, saluted by his friends with “Pa to an eighth.”
A pleasant meet. Wind up with a game of bowls with Lucas. Only score 97.

div.head: February 1, 1860. W[ednesday. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T.

J.L. tells of treating his little girls to a shillingsworth of Punch – doorsteps and pavement instantly crammed – where do the children come from? Funny the way Punch looks round the corner when clown knocks him on the head. Clown an innovation. Punch on horseback – “a be-eauty!” red wafered steed. I never saw him mounted – how he gets his fall, and so gets ill – M.L. and J.L. both imitate the squeak – Long talk about origin of Punch. T.T. doubts if he didn’t come from Italy earlier than the Puppets mentioned in Spectator.

J.L. in quod – Jew boy having a holiday, being treated to see a Shentleman arrested! Like Dickens’ Undertakers children playing at funerals. Leech’s playing at going to church. J.L. when in quod used to get P.L. to sell lithographic caricatures for him. Used to kiss female prisoners through the bars.
The story of Leech’s two weeks in a sponging house is told in W. P. Frith’s biography (John Leech, His Life and Work [1891], Vol. 1, pp. 92-93), quoting a memoir by Percival Leigh. Leigh highlights the Jewish element of the story.
Talk of old gent getting out of ELR Express and taking a fly to save time.

Leigh tells of his nephew, boy of 7, saying “Hallo old cock” to him – beginning to take notice, say I. J.L. suggests Portrait of Lady who faints at the melodrama – with bottled stout and oysters. Gentleman who’s hired to laugh, miserable wretch.

L.C. J.L. suggests “Next Invasion” of French wines – accepted [Punch, 38 (11 February 1860): 59, “The Next Invasion”].
Regarding rumors of a reduction in duties on French wines, see the Times for February 1, 1860, p. 10.

div.head: February 8, 1860. W[ednesday].No. 11. (Champagne)
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.M., J.T., Charles Keene (his debut), M.L., E., P.L., S.B., H.S., T.T., Sir J. Paxton.

M.L. very jolly – chaffs H.S. for being spoony (C.K. authority), sends him Valentine [drawing of heart with arrow through it]. Puts on airs as Editor, cuts off Shirley’s wine, and frowns majestically when we rebel – asks Paxton to champagne – “fawning on aristocracy” “putting himself on a level with them.” Imitates actor – “You come from Venice?” “And her king, Bearing a message both from him and that.”“And thus o’erthrow your argument and self.”

Talk of Income tax attack – request to B. and E. to furnish names of Punch writers. T.T. says we’re not your “servants” nor in your “employ.”
See Tom Taylor piece in Punch, 38 (1860): 71, “A Cool Question and a Courteous Answer.”Paxton always “has a row with them.” General sentiment – Down with the Tax!

Paxton says people dissatisfied with Treaty and should resent Louis [Napoleon]’s grab at Savoy. Throws us sop, and then makes his grab. His Uncle went to work openly. We’d better fight than be diddled.

L.C. (Show Keene how we project the Great Cut). Expensive connection, our French friend – John Bull with roomful of Armstrong guns, etc., cannot afford to keep friends and chum[?] with you. Cost me 30 millions – P.L. and M.L. “Yes, I’ll shake hands, but excuse the rifle!” T.T. – Sop for Cerberus. Approved [Punch, 38 (18 February 1860): 69, “A
Sop for Cerberus”].
Bradbury tells of Quakeress sitting on knee in ’bus – “friend I fear I’ve given thee a stiff member.”
Very jolly evening. P.L. imitating old fish poacher with paralysis – catching fish for Bishop out of his own garden – caught in stream — “Throw half a crown over to us.”
“Ici on parle Français” – Inscription over Gates of Hell. Compliment to the Universality of the French language, says Taylor. Insult to the Nation if you print it, says H.M.

S.B. suggests that B. and E. should put a lot of money in a box and let us take it as we want. Thereby avoid Income tax. Write that Palmerston & Co. write for Punch. What’s Vindex’s address, and the Constant Reader’s etc. They “write for” the Times. Evans says the Collector for Bouverie Street is a greengrocer. Beast! says Shirley – comes out swelly on Sundays now, since his Tax appointment – Beast!

J.L. proposes cut of Punch knocking Bryan King’s and small boy’s heads together – apropos of the St. George’s in the Yeast ferment.
See reports in the Times in January and February 1860 of anti-Ritualist riots at St George’s in the East, in Cannon Street near the Garrick Theatre. Brian King was the rector. Taylor indignant, ‘cause M.L. hasn’t used his Savoy Cabbage joke. Funny to see others as anxious as oneself for the insertion of their articles.

div.head: February 15, 1860. W[ednesdayl] No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., T.T., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., S.B., Lucas (late), H.M., W.M.T., & Hole. Champ.
[Silver’s later note at top of the page: “Canon S. Reynolds Hole ... dines at 6. The Terrace, March 30, 1886.”]

Reverence for his Reverence. Shirley tells of sailor in bus and Christian[?] conductor, in a confidential whisper. Hole a big manly
In the mss., the phrase “big manly” is inserted above the line in black ink, suggesting that Silver added it at a later time. cleanshaven [word crossed out in black ink, illegible] young parson, of the Muscular Christianity order. Good at cricket and across country. Wrote the “Little Tour in Ireland.” Ergo, has some fun in him – proves it too by his performance with a wet cork on a bottle. The Cork Robin, Mark calls it.
T.T. tells of drunken sailor “I’m one of that sort” – a specimen of the genus. Thackeray going to Geographical, and after that to Cockburn’s, the Chief Justice.

L.C. J.L. suggests Punch with Gladstone on his knee and Dizzy threatening at door – “Never mind, my boy, I’ll see you’ve fair play.” T.T. suggests J Bull taking his pill of Income tax from Gladstone, the regular practitioner in preference to that Jew quack. Approved. [Punch, 38 (25 February 1860): 79, “The Gladstone Pill”] (S.B. savage next week at Diz being left out – J.L. wouldn’t do him.)

A jolly evening but nothing to record. Save slight spar between H.M. and Bradbury, who claims the right of inviting guests. Only Paxton and Peter introduced. H.M. had said that Tom Sayers wanted to come. M.L. says J.L.’s first cut sent Punch down 10,000 – the 4th or 5th number it was, and the cut was late, and the publication deferred a day. Q.E.D. (Gil à B[eckett] never missed a week in article.) Circulation then 22,000.

Pipe with C.K. at the Old Un’s to finish with. To Drury with T.G.R. today. J.L. begs me to pitch into Flexmore and the French school of clowning.
See “A Good Old Comic Clown Wanted,” Punch, 38 (1860): 94. Richard Flexmore (1824-1860) was a well-known British pantomimist. Flexmore died the following August. Drury full of boys’ schools and the row they made when any one got whacked on the stage!Nothing like your good substantial jokes for the English palate. Thackeray tells of his asking Sloman to dine with him and feeling hurt at the great man’s refusal on the plea of a previous engagement.
Jewish composer, singer, and “improvisatore” Charles Sloman performed at the Cider Cellars, a popular supper club in Maiden Lane near the stage door of the Adelphi Theatre. He appears as “little Nadab” in Thackeray’s The Newcomes. This was when T. used to come up to the Bedford from Cambridge – no such champagne since! Received £50 for a lecture at Liverpool and bought 10 dozen of port with it. Laid in 200 dozen of claret last year at £5.

div.head: February 23, Th[ursday], 1860. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., & H.M. (T.T. at Haymarket; 1st night of Overland Mail.)

Talk of “the Savages” their burlesque on the 7th prox. – 40 Thieves by Amateurs – i.e., not real pickpockets.
The amateur performance by the Savage Club at the Lyceum Theatre, attended by the Queen and the Prince Consort, included in the cast such Bohemian writers as Albert Smith and William and Robert Brough. The performance was reviewed in the Times, March 8, 1860, 10. Won’t want dressing for their parts, says Leech. He sorry that their Mark and Dickens lot set the fashion for authors to act. J.L. bad at “study” says M.L., never perfect in words. –J.L. presents H.M. with a nut for his good joke about “publican(s)port” in this week’s number.
“Publican’s Port,” Punch, 38 (25 February 1860): 84. S.B. asks who did the Cooke puff – and M.L. points to H.S., who defends it on the ground that C[ooke] is retiring and therefore Punch can’t be accused of unworthy motives for puffing him. Punch’s policy being never to puff.
William Cooke had managed of Astley’s Theatre since 1853. Silver’s piece is “Left His Place-A Good English Cooke,” Punch, 38 (25 February 1860), 77.
Talking of writing S.B. begins to think, he says, when he takes up pen – and not before. P.L. slow at composition like H.S. and wants to let subject simmer in his head first.

L.C. S.B. cuts up rough, says last 2 cuts have been against the budget, M.L. says No. S.B. holds tongue and won’t suggest. J.L. proposes Coalheaver shooting coals down L[ouis] N[apoleon]’s cellar and sneering at a glass of claret handed him. H.S. suggests change of public into café. H.M., L.N. and John Bull sitting after dinner “Come you just pass the claret and I’ll [crossed out, “put some more coals”] make up a good fire for you.” [ Punch, 38 (10 March 1860): 101, “An Uncommon Civil War” ] John Bull enlarging his business premises, P.L.
Objections had been raised to the export of coal to France on the grounds that it might assist France’s navy in making war against Britain (Times, February 17, 1860, 10,). Invasion of the Franc (Income tax 10d), H.M.

Leave them to settle — C.K. and H.S. cut to Leslie’s where are the Stew and Dancer. Called on Mrs. Grimwood before dinner. Sarah Garrett a clippère. Don’t wonder G Gissing being knocked into a heap at sight of her as bridesmaid. When will she be bride?

div.head: February 29, W[ednesday]. No. 11. 1860.
div.p: Present: B., H. S., C.K., J.T., S.B., E., H.M., and Lucas.

Lucas tells good classical joke of S.B.’s, on seeing big looking glass put up in Lucas’ chambers – “neque ilium invideo mirror magis.”
Per Constance Smith, this is from Virgil, Eclogue I,11, “As for me, I feel no envy. Rather, I marvel.” S.B. says he calls on L[ucas] who talks Latin to him, then he goes down to E. Walford who talks Greek to him. S. B. hears half quotation and then says, But you know how Homer ends it – and then E.W. finishes it.
Edward Walford (1823-1897), writer and editor, was educated at Charterhouse and Oxford, where in 1843 he won the Chancellor’s Prize for Latin verse. Walford was assistant editor of Once a Week from 1859 to 1865, when he succeeded Samuel Lucas as editor, and edited Gentleman’s Magazine from 1865 to 1868. Query: Is this Charterhouse E.W.? The fellow who caned me for running tick at Tolfree’s and got half boiled by some of the gownboys.
Tolfree’s was a confectioner who acted as “tuckman” to the students of Charterhouse School, supplying sweets, frequently on credit. E. P. Eardley Wilmot and E. C. Streatfield, Charterhouse Old and New, (London: John C. Nimmo, 1895), p. 135. From his classicality I fancy it is. Clipper at verses he was. Rather smutty talk at dinner. S.B. and L[ucas] the chief offenders. Latter says the way to procreate is to place the female on a fishmonger’s slab. Tells of grooms dowsing mares with cold water. Fancy an old hunting man trying it on wife. Bull banged with nettles. L[ucas] asks me to do Cricket article, I telling him of our Ipswich Jacksonism.

L.C. S.B. vice Mark – leave you to suggest. Shan’t go through the form of taking cab to Tenniel. H.M., fight between Gladstone and the Venetia Boy— E. says J.L. will do coalheaver giving Empress black diamonds, S.B. suggests his smacking lips at claret, saying “If I exports my coals I imports my claret” – “hope mine will warm him more than his does me.” H.M. suggests Paris after the Coal Import – all grimy and smoky. Have a double No. triumph over Mark – Russell shoving Gladstone aside – “my turn now” – S.B. But P.L. improves on it – Russell as Newsvendor – “Second Edition” of his Reform Bill. Diz as lazy flunkey [ Punch, 38 (10 March 1860): 100, “The Old News Boy” ; 101, “An Uncommonly Civil War”]. J[ohn] B[ull] with his hand out to buy it. Anything else says Tenniel! Frenchified Coalheaver from drinking claret, H.S.

Bradbury tells of his time at Malta, and how the officers idled and how he funked for his boy, who had begged for a Commission and how he breakfasted on 100-gun ship and saw them exercise the guns – tremendous impression of Power it gave him. This S.B. confirms. Tells of Spithead Review, one minute ships all clear, the next, all in wool. Jolly talk – H.S. taking part – glad C.K. came – makes one feel more = one’s companions. – S.B. speaks of H.S.’s clown article, fancying it Tom T’s – thinks the pitch into Flexmore hardly strong enough. H.S. defends on ground that whenever he has pitched into an actor the pitch has been cut out. Call M.P.’s humbugs as you will, but mind your eye with other people. P.L. approved article which reproduced his own feelings.

Look in with C.K. on the Old Un. And look over Chappell’s Old Ballads.
Possibly William Chappell, Popular Music of the Olden Time: A Collection of Ancient Songs, Ballads and Dance Tunes. 2 Vols. London: Chappell & Co., 1855-1859. C.K. hot to have rifle regiments sing part-songs to march to.

Tell of telegraphing to M.L. – row at dinner, circulation down 10,000 – salaries reduced, etc. etc. Up came M.L. from Boston Election – never seen savage but then.
This was the Boston by-election of 1856, in which Illustrated London News proprietor Herbert Ingram stood successfully for Parliament in the Liberal interest. Mark Lemon and Douglas Jerrold both campaigned for him.

S.B. quotes [Tom] Hood, letter from Rome – “heard the Poop – troops manuring all over the ground” and Gillray would have done fellow on W.C., bit of cheap paper - as a Large Cut on the Budget. – M L. at Adelphi savage at Wright’s saying “Mary, bring me some paper” – sang out to him “And string.”Says Albert Smith was gammoned that the Legioners of Honour were marked with red ribbon as b—rs, to be known by police.

div.head: March 7, W[ednesday]. 1860.
div.p: Absent ... Grant’s birthday dinner ... Volunteer Levée and Ball. Amateur Forty Thieves.

div.head: March 14, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., C.K., J.T., E., M.L., P.L., T.T., H. I., & H.S.

Captain Tom Taylor cometh late from drill – “basking in the sunny smiles of Royalty last week” says E. Talk of Volunteers
Amid rising tensions between Britain and France, and after a concerted press campaign led by the Times, the Secretary for War organized a Volunteer Force of part-time citizen soldiers in the spring of 1859, tasked with the nation’s defence in case of a French invasion. Queen Victoria and Prince Albert were enthusiastic supporters. – he thinks drill quickens men in mind as well as body. Hopes there’ll be no more balls – muffs like Holloway do mischief. C.K. tells of Dowse, stepping forward as a musical man to get up band committee. Also of fellow who when threatened by his captain said, “If you do I’ll raise your rent!”J.L. says the regulars blamed the Volunteers for lighting their cigars when coming from Levee. Regulars never smoke in uniform except on the march.

T.T. preparing Leslie’s life – kind-hearted man.
Painter Charles Robert Leslie (1794-1859). Taylor edited his Autobiographical Recollections with selections from his correspondence (London: John Murray, 1860), which was reviewed in a two-part article in the Times, September 29 (p. 10) and October 10 (10). Taylor also finished Leslie's biography of Sir Joshua Reynolds (1865). Defends Rogers against Leech, who calls him a humbug – says he helped men on etc., which Evans confirms by saying he got Moxon to publish for him. M[oxon] having sent him some verses and R[ogers] asked him to breakfast and was his friend ever after. T.T. says he dined with R. and old Maltby once – petit diner et pas d’erreur – 3 smelts for fish, and all on such a scale as M.L. calls “scaly.” M.L. didn’t like R. for sending Lockhart all the letters written by Scott when he quarreled with Lockhart. T.T. says R. knew his man and L. being thickskinned wouldn’t feel it as M.L. would. Leech was with R. and Maltby at Broadstairs – describes old M. getting jolly when R. went out for a day.
William Maltby (1763-1854), a close friend of poet Samuel Rogers, was librarian of the London Institution. T.T. imitates R.’s toothless voice saying “I’m an old man and have a small voice and if I didn’t say ill-natured things sometimes, I shouldn’t be listened to.”
Taylor repeats this anecdote at the meetings for February 17, 1864 and March 16, 1870. Also tells of R. telling M. that some lady actually asked if his name was Rogers. Well, and was it? says Maltby – obliviously repeating the offense.

L.C. T.T. suggests Lord John [Russell] and his Six Pounder – à la Whitworth Gun trial – says the effect of the Reform Bill will be to swamp the intelligent voters [Punch, 38 (24 March 1860): 120, “The New Russell Six-Pounder” ].
The trials at Southport of the breech-loading Whitworth Cannon, one of a number of guns designed by inventor William Whitworth, drew widespread press attention in the Times and elsewhere; see for example “Whitworth Cannon,” Saturday Review 9 (3 March 1860) 270-272. Ultimately the British Army declined to purchase the guns, some of which were later supplied to the Confederate Army. H.M. only dissentient from the proposition that the Workingman not fit to govern. P.L. calls his the Governing Class now. Good men will be ousted by blatant mob orators. – Talk of budget, H.M. calls Gladstone a rhetorical humbug, over praised for mere words. All dissent – only blot of budget the inequality of Income tax – E. proposes House Tax instead – direct and certain.

Jaw about the “Waygoose” of the Printers – which E. condemns and B. upholds. Hopes the Punchites will be present.
In the printing trade, the “waygoose” (or more usually “wayzgoose”) was the traditional annual feast sponsored by the proprietors and intended to bring masters and men together socially. The Bradbury Papers at Yale’s Beinecke Library include a letter written by William Bradbury to his employees on the occasion of the Wayzgoose of 1868 (box 1, folder 5). Jaw against M.L. for saying that workmen have a right to combine in certain cases. E. instances man not worth 33/- but willing to come for 30/-. Must have free trade in labour before the Employers and Employed will come together. Slow worker more expensive than fast, burns gas doubly etc. etc. Hot jaw. – B. goes to sleep and awakes drunky.
M.L. don’t like my Indoor business – will use it for Punch instead. Walk away with H.M. who says “Never saw B. so before! (Oh!).

T.T. away early to University College and H.S. declines accompanying him. – T.T. says Miss P. Horton was his early stage love – not improved by connection with T.G.R., of whom Charley Kenney said “Your German Reed’s not worth an English rush.”
Priscilla Reed, née Horton (1818-1895), was married to impresario Thomas German Reed. Charles Lamb Kenney (1821-1861) was a dramatist, journalist, and wit. The Reeds ran the Gallery of Illustration in Regent Street, which featured “entertainments” of songs and sketches, and had been instrumental in Shirley Brooks’s early career. That the Punch circle continued to maintain friendly relations with the Reeds despite these and later expressions of distaste is shown by T. G. Reed’s bringing a collection of sketches to show Mark Lemon that had been made by Linley Sambourne, a friend of Reed’s son, Alfred. This gesture led to Sambourne’s engagement to draw for Punch in 1867; see Sambourne letter to Spielmann, 25 August 1907 (British Library).J.L. calls him a Shnob – and T.T. confirms it – saying he called lately to ask him to do an Entertainment which T.T. declined. H.S. keeps his ears open and his mouth shut. And goeth to bed wishing he had T.T.’s brains inside his head instead of those wherewith Nature hath endowed him. “Make me a wiser and a better man” is his nightly aspiration. Query: Should not the latter adjective come first. And query if wisdom be essential to happiness. Fools seem often to enjoy themselves more than wise men. Don’t think so much of consequences. Well – well. Act well your part, there all the honour lies. And don’t be covetous or envious – There are skeletons in all houses, and one knows the anatomy of one’s own. Better to bear the evil one has etc. etc. etc.

div.head: March 21, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S. (his seat henceforth), C.K., J.T., S.B., P.L., T.T., & H.M.

Captain Taylor marcheth in from drill in uniform – grey, with silver clasp on crossbelt, about as big as a coffin plate. Whistle attached by chain long enough for dog chain (N.B., And this is what they call a quiet uniform.)
J.L. also been at drill – proposes that our meet should be henceforth called The Mess.

S.B. tells of his lecturing at Leicester on the House of C[ommons] – surprised to find what small jokes set folks laughing: the broader the better: don’t wonder at actors gagging – speaks also of Thackeray’s mistake in article about Macaulay “lay profane hand on the αιδσια,” the pudenda; men who “think in Greek” have been puzzled by the phrase.
Harriet Martineau had written a harshly critical obituary of Thomas Babington Macaulay for the Daily News (31 December 1859, p. 5), later reprinted in her Biographical Sketches [London: Macmillan, 1869] and reproduced online here, in which she had declared that for all Macaulay’s brilliance “the one thing wanting is heart.” In reply, Thackeray wrote in the second number of the Cornhill for February 1860 (“Nil Nisi Bonum,” p. 134) that “The critic who said that Lord Macaulay had no heart could not know him. Press writers should read a man well, and all over, and again, and hesitate, at least, before they speak of those aidoia.” Thackeray was under the mistaken impression that the Greek word meant privacies, when in fact it referred to female private parts. The incident was still being talked about the following week (see entry for March 29, 1860). See Iain Crawford’s discussion of this exchange in his “Harriet Martineau: Women, Work and Mid-Victorian Journalism” in Joanne Shattock, ed., Journalism and the Periodical Press in Nineteenth-Century Britain (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2017) 317-327.

L.C. T.T. suggests L[ouis] N[apoleon] as Savoyard “Il n’y a qu’un Savoyard de plus” (H.S. don’t catch the quotation) – S.B. reads note from Mark suggesting L.N. stealing cabbages and Punch stopping him “Bock agin!” – or, L.N. break- into cabbage garden and Bull not interfering “No business of mine” – etc. etc. So that Evans says M.L. has been planting out his cabbages. The Editor’s suggestions being duly heard and shelved, T.T. takes up Reform question – fires away at Lord John – proposes Jack Cade finding man with inkhorn and refusing him a vote. H.S. sotto voce suggests parody of Wilkie’s picture of The Savoyard and White Mice – L.N. as Beadle taking them away. Bull standing by etc., of course it won’t do because of the figures – which C.K. don’t seem to see yet.

T.T. blows J.L. up for not caring to vote – all Lord J[ohn]’s six pounders will vote and swamp the gentlemen, who surrendering their power will find taxes doubled. Verdict – And serve ‘em right. A Parliament of Coxes would soon throw all the paying on the richer classes: and retain to themselves the spending. P.L. wishes the Bill at the devil, but thinks that what M.L. said last week is true. That Punch mustn’t go flat against it. H.M. says he is in a minority and therefore shall sit silent, accuses Punch of turning Tory. [at bottom of page, to insert] T.T. suggests “The Disappointed Godfather” – Mr. Bull proposing health of Lord J[ohn]’s baby and hoping it won’t turn out to be too much for him when it grows up. [back in text] S.B. suggests perambulator; accepted. [Punch, 38 (31 March 1860): 131, “An Uphill Job”]
T.T. tells of his dreaming of operation for stone – big ones got out of him and at last one with a label, puzzling the doctors... All through his wife sticking her knees into his back.
J.L. tells of vulgar fellow getting into society and saying to his girlish whist partner “If you do that again I must pinchyourlittlebottommiss, indeed I must!” C.K. and H.S. laugh consumedly.

P.L. C.K., and H.S. talk of Gluck and Mozart – P.L. says a man of genius can write a pretty taking air if he chooses, and when he does he beats the popular composer. Instances Don Juan – whereof the Statue Music is “Terribly suggestive.” ... Took his small boy nephew to Philharmonic t’other night – whereat Leech cries Shame! But P.L. says the boy enjoyed the Symphonies – didn’t care for the ballads so much. P.L. asked which he preferred – this or Mr. Merriman, and nephew wisely says “O, Mr. Merriman!”
Evans says he once produced books to prove Punch was a loss. (Income Tax).

div.head: March 29, 1860. Th[ursday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., S.B., P.L., and Lucas.

J.L. tells of children playing at Pa and Ma – morning after coming home from club, too much claret. Thackeray not been seen since his αιδσια slip – no getting out of it, says Lucas, mistook it for private secrecies and thoughts. J.L. suggests that as it was Miss Martineau he was cutting up he used the Greek that she might enquire what it meant.
See note for entry for March 21, 1860.

Leigh tells of his nephew, aetat. 7, and how he wouldn’t spell ορμς-[?] made a piece of work about it. Says he liked Pastoral Symphony (?). S.B. “speaks as the father of many children, legitimate and illegitimate, and hopes P.L. won’t make boy precocious.” P.L. goes to church now for boy’s sake – Bravo Leigh! cry we. Queer state of religion says Leech, when a man’s applauded for going to church.

H.S. tells of rifle private to commanding officer “If you do I’ll raise your rent.” Also of the dog “cow’s among cabbages I’m thinking”: every now and then have sporting talk with J.L. — learn that Joyce’s brother is the waterproof capmaker
The “Joyce” referred to here is Felix Joyce, manager of Bradbury and Evans’s printing business. His brother, Frederick Joyce, was a pioneer in the manufacture of percussion caps for muzzle-loading rifles. Advertisements for “Joyce’s Waterproof Anti-corrosive Percussion Caps” appear in many mid-Victorian newspapers. Joyce’s company, begun in 1820, was absorbed by Alfred Nobel’s in 1908.– tell of very wet day at Charsfield and shooting Wm. Moore’s wideawake (one of my stock stories this, polished up a bit). P.L. says there are snipes on Barnes Common by the Terrace.

L.C. Lucas says cut has been done about “planted Savoy cabbage look to Brussels sprouts now,” else it would do says S.B. S.B. suggests Queen saying to Pam “Well we can’t refuse to see him (L[ouis] N[apoleon]) but look to your spoons.”P.L. says Punch should back Lord John for his defiant speech on Monday – which the Times of course construed into saying the alliance was at end. H.S. suggests British Bantam versus the Gallic Cock... Distressed Publican, J.L. suggests – fat and jolly looking. France as coquette, John Bull disgusted – can’t keep to her, she goes with anyone, S.B. – J.L. says, how would it do to make Pope and L.N. bringing their own rags. Omnes, Now you’ve hit it. Grand cut, says Bradbury. [At bottom, insert:] S.B. says good, but not popular, people can’t put 2 ideas together, as this cut requires. [Punch 38 (7 April 1860): 141, “A Glimpse of the Future”]. J.L. suggests Raggedy Oh! song go with it, but S.B. thinks P.L.’s pithy lines better.
“Rags” refers to the paper industry, concerned about a shortage, having asked Parliament to restrict paper imports; see Times leader, 27 March 1860, p.

J.L. praises Millais’ Black Brunswicker – query, were they so brave tho’, S.B.
The Black Brunswicker had made its first appearance at the Royal Academy exhibition in May, 1860. [Augustus] Egg stale and conventional – contrast our 2 or 3 pictures a year to Old Masters 20 or 50. Turner exception – and perhaps Landseer. No idea of working to time, says Leech. Perhaps they want the pressure says H.S. – T.T. put Bowrings’ loss of false teeth incident into his Overland Route, having pumped Bowring for details – “dangerous fellow is Tom” says Leech. Talk of how they sold M.L. at Paris by sending cut of fellow on W.C. using Punch — “ha! ha! cured in an instant!”J.L. tells of Sir Chas. Taylor at Volunteer Ball, “ha! so there are your middle classes – now ain’t they demnd ugly!” – Also of Swell at Garrick – shuddering at offer of chop and steak – “bwing me a grilled mackwel bone and some clawet.”

J.L. asks H.S. to come and dine on Sunday and see 2 unbroken colts of his – but don’t let me keep you from going out of town. H.S. had just been ½ pledging himself to Old Grant, but – human nature’s human nature. Jolly meet this – and jolly finale. Jolly change of day too – at No. 8 L.G. yesterday.

div.head: April 4, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 1.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B., H.M., and T.T.
M.L. been steamed, bad cold still – afraid of vapour bath blowing one up, says S.
E. don’t remember promise of Cyclopaedia to P.L. and H.S. Reminded by S.B. and M.L.
Letter from Duncan – Biddy married to Red John (Shan Ruach) and “wants no crinoline I can tell you.” Perhaps ... Black John (Leech) be thanked ( S.B.)
Trowel to Horace – from Levi of Sheffield for laying stone of drinking fountain – brought by Matthews, Mayor of Leeds. Fun about the Jew’s name. S.B. reads the inscription through his nose.

Rifleman who shot the dog on Wandsworth Common found out – ballad. Plead drunkenness, says S.B. “And ‘cos last night I shot the cat, This morn I shot the dog.”
The author of a letter to the Times wrote of witnessing a rifleman shooting his sister’s dog and running away (Times, 22 March 1860, 12). A question about the matter was raised in Parliament (Hansard, HC Deb 29 March 1860 vol 157 cc1495-6). At Punch, 38 (28 April 1860): 176, the magazine ran a social cut of three street boys taunting a man in Volunteer uniform with the question, “Who shot the dog?” The annotated 1895 anniversary set of the magazine notes that the cut “caused unintentional annoyance to his [Mr. Punch’s] friends the Volunteers, as the boys of London adopted the inquiry of ‘Who shot the dog?’ as a street-cry.” ... P.L. says of stupid ass who stutters, watching lovers kissing, and saying “Come out of the moonlight” – then telling his sister to say that to them ... “Can’t see the use of kissing – bad enough to have to kiss one’s own relations.”P.L. very funny in stories.
Talking of charge of b—, disease query[?] says P.L., if not called Gomorrhaea. Charge founded on fellow saying “Visit So and So! Suppose you took your corks with you.”
T.T. says Miss Sedgwick stupid as an owl – like the Fotheringay.

L.C. Don Quixote brewer tilting at French wineskins, M.L. – Teetotaller arm in arm with swell brewer and small publican, common cause, S.B. Pump and beer barrel charging claret bottle, T.T. – Set to between Gladstone and the Beernicia (Pot) Boy,J.L. – Reform Baby and Doctors – “May get through, but will want careful watching/nursing,” T.T. – Publican on beer barrel trying to roll it up board, J.L. – Earl King Derby and the Reform Child, T.T. – Pious Public and immoral pastrycooks (J.L.) [ Punch, 38 (14 April 1860): 151, “The Pious Public-House” and, 152, “The Profligate Pastry-Cook's”]. Omnes applaudiunt.

div.head: April 11, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T. and Thackeray.

Talk of Macready marrying – girl of 23.
Actor William Charles Macready's first wife, Catherine, had died in 1852. On April 3, 1860, at the age of sixty-seven, he married Cecile Louise Frederica Spencer (1827–1908), who was 33, not 23, years old. The two had a son, Cecil Frederick Nevil Macready, in 1862. Ode to St. Cecilia “Ascend ye Nine” (times),S.B. – “Once more unto the breach,” E. (and H.S.) M.L. gives a love passage a la Mac[ready], with the pumping and nasal accent etc. Thackeray’s girls twitting him about it. – Has taken house Kensington Gore ≠ Eggs. Means to run over to Paris for a day or two, having done No. 5. “Take a tour on the Incontinent.” Used to have ex-governess there – gave her a Napn, and one for herself.
S.B. tells of his Viennese experience – waiter suggesting she should come and dine with him comfortably. Mill on the Floss dreary and immoral. Evans bid for it. ... S.B. says he’s well out of it.
Man mistaken for husband, going to bed with woman – not rape, Counsel. T.T. says so.

Thackeray gives kudos to Gryll Grange, by Peacock (of Head long Hall). “Written by a gentleman.” (Joe and the Old Un swear by H.H. and at W.M.T.).
Gryll Grange, by Thomas Love Peacock (1785-1866), was serialized in Fraser's Magazine between April 1860 and December 1860, as “by the author of Headlong Hall.” It was published in book form the following year by Parker, Son, and Bourn.

Mrs. Keeley said she didn’t care for f—. No, says S.B., because she can’t do it publicly. Applause is all she cares for – Mrs. Wigan a beast, talks about “our set” – laments that T.T. was not in good society!
See Clement Scott, Drama of Yesterday and Today (1899), p. 260, where he notes Mrs. Wigan’s “aristocratic affectations.” Joke of Douglas’s – Mrs. W. at a charade telling Georgina Hogarth not to put extract of millefleurs on her head – “has turned mine quite grey.” “Wasn’t it extract of Time?” said J. – Thackeray imitates Yankee prospecting in Wales for a railway and going up to a table in hotel – “Smiles, my name is Smiles – I come from — and I’m agoing” etc. Also imitates parson – à la Spurgeon somewhat. Would like to have 4 sheets a year to write, and would write such letters to ladies. M.L. tells us youngsters how he earned £50 in a night for a farce.

L.C. Between the Bulls.
The Pope had issued a bull excommunicating those who would annex Savoy to France. See Times April 3, 1860, p. 5, and leader of April 7, 1860, p. 7. L[ouis] N[apoleon] between J. Bull and the Pope’s – perplexed, T.T. Pio Mumbo Jumbo Nono [Punch, 38 (21 April 1860): 163, “Mumbo Jumbo”]. Ghost of Bull, M.L. – S.B. asks why M.L. don’t do it himself always, instead of getting us to do it. (When will H.S. be included in the Us?) ... Beastly cold tonight he has – gathering violets for Mrs. Leech (for which J.L. thanks publicly on entry) – and so has J.L. and J.T. J.L. speaks through his nose to Bark Lebol. Good Friday and Saturday were summer and yesterday and Monday were like Christmas, hail and snow and frost.

Thackeray writes inscription in Virginians to Peter Rackham difft. opinions about The Virginians etc. “Accept the book dear [crossed out: “friend”] R./ and if you find it Pleasant to read I hope you’ll bind it.”
The entire inscription is given in a 1900 Rosenbach & Co. catalogue offering this presentation copy of The Virginians for sale:
“In the U. States and in the Queen’s dominions
All people have a right to their opinions,
And many don’t much relish
The Virginians.
Peruse my book, dear R.! and if you find it
A little to your taste, I hope you’ll bind it.
Peter Rackham, Esq’re with the best regards of
The Author.”
Catalogue of a remarkable collection of rare and choice books, manuscripts, and autograph letters : comprising first editions, presentation copies, illuminated manuscripts, English literature, American historical documents, musical scores, literary relics : Offered for sale by the Rosenbach Company (Philadelphia: Rosenbach, 1900) 113. Thackeray had earlier given Rackham a presentation copy of Pendennis; Peter Shillingsburg, Pegasus in Harness: Victorian Publishing and W. M. Thackeray (Charlottesville: U. of Virginia Press, 1992), 188-189.

div.head: April 19, 1860. Th[ursday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., Lucas (late), J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., and H.M.

Talk of the Fight
In what would later come to be seen as the first world boxing championship, British champion Tom Sayers and American champion John C. Heenan (also known as “The Benicia Boy,” from a town in California) fought at Farnborough in Hampshire on Tuesday, 17 April 1860. After a long battle in which both men suffered – Sayers could not use his right arm, while Heenan’s face was badly swollen – the crowd surged into the ring and the police intervened, leading the referee to call the fight a draw. Public interest was intense, and press coverage extensive. first of course – S.B. doubts if Heenan had fair play and M.L. says he’s sorry to hear an Englishman say so, and especially at this table. Woods did the Times account – also, that of the Great Eastern blow up.
Nicholas Augustus Woods (1830-1880), journalist, had been the Crimean War correspondent of the Morning Herald, and was afterward renowned for his descriptive reporting for the Times, the Pall Mall Gazette, and other papers. See G. A. Sala, The Life and Adventures of George Augustus Sala, written by Himself, (New York: Charles Scribners & Sons, 1895) v. 2, 160. The book Woods wrote about accompanying the Prince of Wales on the prince’s trip to the U.S. and Canada as the Times’s special correspondent had just been published by Bradbury & Evans. J.L. at the Market Harbro’ Steeplechase, splendid! says ladies all talking of Sayers, so he drew in Album portrait of him “coming up Smiling.” Children playing at prize fights – “You be Tom Sayers and I’ll be the B.B.! ... T.T. engages to do the fight – might, if he were writing on t’other side of the water begin with the Arma vircum [?]:
Arms and fists too I sing, the hero from Troy (County, U.S.)
Who fought like a Trojan, th’ Benicia Boy.

Well, certainly for pluck and endurance the battle was nearly a drawn one, but considering the long odds Tom fought against, and having but one arm to fight with, I think we should consider him the best man. Heenan lost his temper at last and Tom never did. A lucky tap would have done the business, so although he’d been knocked down 20 times we mustn’t think him beaten... Of course the penny papers come the moral dodge and are virtuously indignant. But where’s your educated gentleman of sufficient self control to go without wine, women and tobacco for 3 months as these “ruffianly brutes” do. And these mind, are their only pleasures.

J.L. tells of swell asking what the new scent was at the Volunteer Ball. “Ah, believe it’s Esprit de corps,” returned another. M.L. tells of man dreaming he saw 8 & 8 on each cheek of his wife’s – so asked for 88 Lottery ticket, but forgot the “0” in the middle — prize 808. Also of man giving toast to actress – “Place from which we came” And here’s the messenger who would fetch us, said she. “Something else to offer him besides an aperture in her person” says P.L. apropos of a rich wife.

Braggart calling himself a Prince – Well, said somebody, he’s not far out, b’lieve his mother had a sovereign when she begat him. After these inanities we drink Bon Voyage to Horace who goes to Nova Scotia tomorrow (weeps at parting says S.B. next week) and also to Lucas, who goes to Vienna – setting me down tho’ at the Opera first, where I see Borghi Mario in Otello and don’t think much of her.

div.head: April 25, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champ. 1st Whitebait.
div.p: Present: B., J.L. (going to dine at Longman’s), C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., and H.S.

S.B. gives motto for a bad wine merchant – Trinculo. “I’ll give him to drink of this bottle, And if he have not tasted wine before he’ll say its good stuff” – or something to that effect. S.B. has a marvellous memory, which is more than H.S. has. H.S. moreover has a beastly cold, and is sore as to his eyes, and it’s as much as he can do to enjoy whitebait and mock-turtle, turbot and champagne, without trying to remember Shakespeare quotations.

Apropos of the Shakespeare birthday dinners (S.B. presiding at Our Club on [crossed out: “Friday”] Saturday and Billy Russell at the Albion on Monday – and sending over to Thackeray for a Shakespeare and nearly going to sleep and taking his Bible instead). M.L. gets up and spouts à la after dinner swell – proposing the health of Mr. Evans as the publisher of Kean’s Edition. Not bad. Talk about Shakespeare. Some one contends that the world would not have been what it is, but for him. S.B. says Bosh, people would have quoted Ben Jonson. English writers quote nobody but Shakespeare (except Douglas Jerrold says Mark), for the reason that Sh. is so intensely quotable. Moliere is much quoted in France – but not so extensively, not so exclusively. Queen Eliz. R., Evans thinks, also greatly influenced posterity.

Talk of the Union Bank frauds discovered on Monday – only £263,000! A mere fleabite.
See the Times for April 24 and 25, 1860, for the story of the embezzlement of the Union Bank of London by chief cashier William George Pullinger, a 16-year employee. Pullinger lost the entire sum in speculation. A Times leader on the subject appeared on April 27, p. 8. And these are your men of business are they! Union is Weakness saith S.B. (and H.S. wisheth he had sold out as he had thought of – fall from 30% to 22½).
Who was it said “M[aiden]heads are like birds: when fledged they fly away.” M.L. repeats.
L.C. Lord Janus Russell – S.B. [ Punch, 38 (5 May 1860): 183, “The Reform Janus”]. Soon settled ... H.S.

div.head: May 2, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L. and S.B.

How much pleasanter it is when the other fellows are away! says S.B. M.L. very jolly and begins to talk smut. Story of knock under the table toast – wife told it’s the Church and says “Ah you may touch the Ch. Long time since you’ve been there!”“When you were born your mother gave birth to a boy and a t-d and the boy died.” – Man asked by Lady why he didn’t marry. “F... fact is your ladyship I can’t f—f. I don’t mean what your ladyship means – I can’t find a girl suitable.” … Woman jawing man, “Why your wife’s jealous of the cat.” The Sussex/Salisbury (?) Arms reopened to the sound of a brass band (almost as bad as the Ginshop opposite No. 20 which the other day was inaugurated to the Hallelujah Chorus!) Evans sends for Police and the trombone is stopped, and the snowstorm of small handbills also. S.B. says t’other night he dreamed the place was opened. Hence a talk on dreams. P.L. chiefly – gives de Bathe the name of de Bagnio, from his having had a girl on the colours of the regiment at the Tower – 1st time of mounting guard, usual ceremony, abolished 5 or 6 years since.
Henry Percival de Bathe (1823-1907), later 4th Baronet, was a colonel of the Scots Guards who had served in the Crimea. He was well known to the Punch circle through his membership in the Garrick Club. P.L. gives kudos to my “catarrh article” and S.B. to my District Telegraph one.
Silver’s article about “catarrh” has not been traced; his article about a District Telegraph appears at Punch 38 (5 May 1860) 181: “A Lady’s Letter”. Silver’s as good as gold, says M.L. S.B. jaws Evans for being Unitarian and wishing to abolish Church rates.

div.head: May 9, 1860. W[ednesday] No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B., and Sir J Paxton. Champ[agne]

Talk of Ingram going into wrong lobby last night on The Paper Bill – the member with the Noes. P[axton] explains how votes are taken, members counted at door and names taken at desk and so checked. Ingram sneaked and didn’t go to desk. House roared at him before Speaker – so ludicrous.
Ingram had campaigned for the repeal of the paper duty, making it all the more embarrassing that he voted with the minority by mistake (Annual Register for the Year 1860 [London: Rivington, 1861], 75). M.L. tells of Boston man asking him to beg Mr. I. not to scratch his a— so when he speaks.

Settle L.C. at dinner. Leech suggesting Punch at Palmerston’s. “I’ll make Lady P. so handsome that she must ask me to her Soirées.”
The evening parties and dinners hosted by Lady Palmerston, both in London and at the Palmerstons’ Hampshire estate, Broadlands, were legendary. She was “the premiere poltical hostess in London” for twenty-five years (K. D. Reynolds, “Emily Mary Temple (née Lamb), Viscountess Palmerston (1787-1869),” Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, 2004. S.B. had thought of parallel, Grub Street a 100 years ago receiving bribe of £5 to write up Government. Well, in future be it known that Gentlemen of the Press are fit for the best Society [ Punch, 38 (19 May 1860): 203, “Pam’s Grateful Recognition of the Press, or Fourth Estate”].
The cut refers to Lord Palmerston's jocular remarks, reported in the Times for May 8, 1860, 7a, about his having socialized with John Delane of the Times, in the course of denying that he had had any influence on what was published in the paper. This was in reply to an attack on Palmerston and on John Walter, M.P. and proprietor of the Times, by Edward Horsman, M.P. for Stroud, during a debate on the reform bill. See Brooks's account of the debate in “Punch’s Essence of Parliament,” Punch 38 (19 May 1860): 202.

After dinner (first time of eating ruff, very nice), Paxton talks of Army blunders. May a slack work [month] for farming and militia should be embodied then, but their officers are in town there, and so the country’s injured. No preparations for billeting troops should a war come. Government don’t know if guns can go on railways – should do as French and drill soldiers to enter trains. Detachments should be moved with their officers – bad to separate them from their men.

Anent the paper question – new materials not used because they’d need new machines. Take the duty off and there’d be lots of new substances. P[axton] believes dung even will be serviceable – rhubarb made into champagne and its refuse into paper – bane and antidote. Soon indeed the poorer classes will be able to wipe their —- sings Shirley. P. says the House listens to him when he speaks. Reads us his Committee List for embanking Thames – grand if it be practicable.

B. proposes P’s health and P. in reply says it was 34 years ago this day he first went to Chatsworth – reached it by a rival coach at 4 a.m., recollects helping to put horses to – instead of going to bed walked round grounds and so set men to work at 6 – being young this gave him authority which he wanted.
On Paxton’s first morning at the Duke of Devonshire’s, see F. Leveson Gower, Bygone Years (London: John Murray, 1905), p. 41: “He inspected the garden and saw all the gardeners, instructing them as to their respective duties, and he fell in love with the housekeeper’s niece, whom he subsequently married.” Gower was the Duke’s nephew.

Says he lived a life in that 3 minutes’ speech of Bradbury’s. Concludes by drawing a bill on us which we must accept – namely to spend a week with him in August when Parliament is up. Omnes, hurrah! Evans asks if it wasn’t that morning he first saw Lady P. and he says yes, and without a good wife a man can’t well succeed. There’s a hint for H.S. Jolly evening – M.L., J.T., & H.S. last sitters – M.L. promises me Fairholt, and begs me to do the going about department and always pay my way and apply to him for cash. Dine at C[rystal] P[alace] and report.
Glad I noticed the Elijah business and wished I said a word of Big Bowley sitting perched up by the tenors and drinking sherry with his satellites.

div.head: May 16, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., P.L., S.B., & T.T.
(H.S. from Wood[bridg]e today and down again tomorrow – May 4 at C[rystal] P[alace] the first day of summer, but cold since.)

S.B. suggests Opera – La donna del largo al factotum. Talk of Hatch getting verdict against Elizabeth Plummer for perjury. J.L. thinks no man would admit his daughter of 10 years old to bed with him, still less a strange child.
Henry John Hatch (1818-1895) had been convicted for indecent assault against 11-year-old Mary Eugenia Plummer, a pupil, and sentenced to four years at hard labour in Newgate Prison. His supporters circulated evidence that had not appeared at trial, and persuaded eleven of the twelve jurors to sign a declaration that they would not have convicted him had they been shown this evidence. The Home Secretary agreed to consider a petition for his release if an action for perjury could be brought; supporters raised funds for such a suit, and the Plummer girl went on trial on May 15, 1860. After five days she was convicted and sentenced to three weeks imprisonment to be followed by placement in reformatory school, or in the care of a suitable governess. Hatch was released and later received a pardon. Press coverage was extensive, including accounts in the Times on May 10-12, 14, 16, and June 4. Leech's comment refers to testimony from Hatch's trial, that he and his wife had allowed Mary Eugenia and her younger sister to come into his and his wife's bed to sleep. The subject crops up again at the dinner for October 12, 1864. Pullinger 20 years imprisoned.
William George Pullinger, chief cashier at Union Bank of London, pled guilty to embezzlement of £263,000 between 1855 and 1860. E. Thinks him happier now than he has been for 5 years.
Thackeray calls Anderson “Macready & Onions.”

Punch made by E. & M.L. T.T. gets jolly thereon – talks like a dozen, and votes for going to Derby on a hearse. Or in a van with a trombone. Capital advertisements, for Punch. M.L. writes for trap – £6 a horse says J.L.

Talk of Hunt’s Christ in Temple. T.T. says Christ’s belt is painted to perfection but such perfection only leads up to imperfection – the flesh and blood climax of the picture is the weakest part of it. Must sacrifice to “fetch up.” H.S. agrees – if you can’t paint living flesh truly it is an untruth to paint accessories so that they become the prominent features. C.K. denies this. Says you should paint truly what you can and not sacrifice for the sake of bringing up the main points. S.B. says, What would most strike a stranger on entering, not Christ, but the Temple. So Hunt was right to paint the Temple prominent.
William Holman Hunt’s Finding of the Saviour in the Temple was exhibited at the Royal Academy in May of 1860.

T.T. loves landscapes and anything natural. Whistler a good colourist: vide Times tomorrow, says T.T. H.S. wishes he could speak thus prophetically. T.T. tells of contemplative spectator of Rifle Corps – “They must be a goin’ to shoot all the dogs in London!”
See first note to entry for April 4, 1860.

div.head: May 23, 1860. The Derby.
div.p: H.S. goes with the 2 Friths per fly and dines with them at 7 after a jolly day, getting to Croydon at 5. First bathe on Monday.

div.head: May 31, 1860. Th[ursday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L. and S.B.

Bawdy begins at dinner. What can the waiters think? S.B. settles L.C. by drawing cartoon of the Two Dogs and Bright. M.L. suggests Strike – Punch pointing to starving children and Potter at man’s other elbow, earwigging [ Punch, 38 (9 June 1860): 233, “Bright the Peace-Maker” ]. Also suggests Garibaldi holding Bomba over Etna – a drop of the Crater. E. like H.S. can feel a picture or a poem, but can’t put in words his feeling about it.

Albert Smith died on the Derby Day. Pater savage at his leaving his wife little and his mistress Patty Oliver £1,000. Needn’t have put this in his will.
Albert Smith (1816-1860), comic writer, novelist, and performer, had once been on the staff of Punch. A freind of Leech since their medical school days, he had clashed with Jerrold and Lemon, and after leaving the magazine had begun a rival paper with Angus Bethune Reach, Man in the Moon. Much liked and admired by a younger set of writers, including George Augustus Sala and Edmund Yates, Smith had achieved great success with a theatrical re-enactment of his ascent of Mont Blanc. His will left his wife £3000 on the death of his mother, as well as £500 (not £1000) to “Martha Oliver,” better known as Pattie (1834-1880), at this time the leading actress for comedy and burlesque at the Strand Theatre. In 1866 she became the manager of the New Royalty Theatre, where she produced such plays as Tom Taylor's “The Ticket-of-Leave Man” and had great success starring in Francis Burnand's burlesque, “Black-Eyed Susan.” See the diary entry for September 11, 1867, for Silver's account of her performance in the latter. She married in 1876. S.B. thinks his wife was an aggravating party, and being well off needed not much legacy. No doubt he ½ killed himself by guttling and guzzling. Strong men go on till they suddenly go off, weak ones get headaches as reminders and so live carefully and longer.
H.S. tonight smokes 3 cigars and has a headache tomorrow. A good thing for H.S. Pain is a merciful provision after all.

div.head: June 6, 1860. W[ednesday]. Greyhound, Dulwich
div.p: (after C[rystal] P[alace] Schoolchildren’s Fete – fr. St. Paul’s. Sat behind Mrs. S.B. and her 2 small curley heads and their pretty nurse.)
Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., Thackeray & Lucas!

Vive Vienna! cries Lucas – they’ve eyes of angels and the hearts of doves. Never lose respect by opening their legs, have the air of a princess etc etc etc. A girl who never complains and never gives you any complaint, says S.B. Better lose your heart Lucas than your nose – says J.L. Can’t you do something about them for The Carnal Magazine, says Shirley. Or “From Once a Week to Weenice with Vienna by the way” says Mark. Thackeray tells of his feeling bump on his Penis[?] – - and of his friend doing it “for the honour of England.”
Vienna bread delicious – small rolls and light not spongy. Beer also capital.

S.B. suggest Perseus Garibaldi [ Punch, 38 (16 June 1860): 243, “Garibaldi the Liberator”]. Why doesn’t H.S. suggest something sometimes. C.K. talks of Punch “drawing from the Nood-le” – Haddo the Sitter.

P.L. explains to nephew, asking why the Band of Hope marched with trumpets and trombones blaring, that Teetotallers are persons who act when they are sober just as other people do when they are drunk. J.L. suggests picture of Leigh explaining that he’s not a tee – hic – toller!
C.K. tells L[eech] of a lithograph he saw in New Monthly, fellows smoking etc. and “Jack Leech done it” in the corner. J.L. remembers doing it after supper.

Jolly dinner – very[?]. As clean as I ever saw. Good sign when the cruet stand is clean, says J.L. Dinner 6/-, claret 8/- should have been 5/-, but sum total with lots of good champagne only £7.19. Bus home[?] outside with M.L., J.T., C.K., and J.T. – seltzer and brandy at the Bedford with Mark and E. and S.B. and J.L. ? if at Dulwich only 2 shops of each trade? C.R.[?] clerk says so.

div.head: June 13, 1860. White Hart, Windsor
div.p: Present: E., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., J.L. and S.B. Champagne.
Went down with C.K. by the 2 o’clock. – high wind and new hat – paced 2375 steps from mid-gates to King’s Statue – judging distances. Then to Chapel – and terrace.
M.L. chaffs me about Newbur.[?] again – fancy Silver taking home his bride to that grim ghastly ghoulish hole! – Ah! first catch your bride.

P.L. shows letter his nephew – aetat 7 – wrote: beginning “Hammert (for Hammersmith) Dear Par – crysal palas – funderstome – mushrones etc etc” each sentence disconnected in subject and joined with “And” to preceeding. Nobody can imitate truly such effusions – bad spelling especially defies imitation.

L.C. suggested by M.L. and J.L. [Punch, 38 (23 June 1860): 253, “Lord J. Russell’s ‘Reform’ Scratched” ]. S.B. and E. thinking the word “scratched” would hardly be understood. J.L. thinks the Light Weight debate should be noticed as well as Reform. S.B. suggests the perambulator floored and Punch saying, “There, I told you how it would be!”
Sloomed about with ½ drunk motte till 2 – grentan[?] and E. and Lettie[?] in town.

div.head: June 20, 1860. No dinner.
div.p: B & E at Hastings. (H.S. after dining solus at Bromley’s. Champ.)

div.head: June 28, 1860. Th[ursday] at the Greyhoud, Dulwich (after Orpheonistes.)
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., T.T., S.B., W.M.T., and Lucas.

H.S. from Crystal Palace, T.T. also – latter says 3000 Englishmen in three months could sing as well. H.S. says, not in three years could they – at least not the soldier’s songs, La Retraite and Les Enfants etc. which are the forte of Orpheonistes. The humming accompaniment was the specialty of the Cologne Choir (in the delicate piano and gradual swell perhaps they surpassed the O’s) – the staccato notes, piano and forte, and spirited crescendo are the specialty of the O’s. No English could sing their soldier’s songs with such energy and fire. Distinctness and precision also admirable.
Three thousand amateur choral performers selected from the best choral groups in France, the Orpheonistes, performed several times to enthusiastic crowds at the Crystal Palace in Sydenham in the summer of 1860, under the direction of founder Eugène Delacorte. See the appreciative notice in the Times, June 26, 1860, 12. Paxton, as president of the Crystal Palace Company, organized a dinner for the Orpheonistes at the Crystal Palace, paid for by subscription (Times, June 30, 1860, 9).

J.L. says there’s no music between the Philharmonic and a barrel organ. W.M.T. and H.S. more cosmopolitan – tho’ H.S. agrees that the higher the taste the higher the enjoyment. Handel better than Kücken – but one mustn’t quarrel with one’s custard because it’s not roast beef. —- C.K. likes to join in bad singing better than to hear good. H.S. doesn’t – but admits there’s pleasure in both. – The wretched lodging for the O’s discussed – les abattoirs in the Cattlemarket – straw mattresses nominally, sacks really – and no furniture.

Sir Joseph [Paxton] next Saturday tells me Delaporte to blame for this, and not C[rystal] P[alace] Company. He foresaw the danger and would have provided – vide Times. T.T. tells of Orph. hurried though British Museum. – “Messieurs, il faut courer, si vous voulez voir les ‘sights’ de Londres.” One man wiping his face – “Mais oui – vraiment, c’est une course!” N.B. The O’s as a rule small men, sunbrowned and smooth faced. Query if conscription lessens the race.

Talk of the [Queen’s] Review
The first great parade march of the Volunteers was held in Hyde Park on Sunday, June 23, 1860, and was comprised of some 21,000 soldiers. Commanded by the Duke of Cambridge, they passed in review before the Queen and Prince Consort and the royal family, with Leopold I also in attendance. – all agree it was as fine a sight as they ever saw. That ass H.S. never thought till Thursday of applying for tickets and so saw it as an outsider with T.T. and Sterry, meeting the Misses Keene. Dark green almost black and grey indistinct. The sombre colours made the Queen’s cortege very souspieds and splendid. Say the Queen was moved to tears by it – and had her tea at a window where she could see the troops march past. Soon cleared the park. D. of W. said not 3 men could get 25000 out of Hyde Park leave them alone – voila tout. Mr. Thomas said he left just as “all that hooting and hollering began.” Good gracious! Why that h[ooting] & h[ollering] was “the cheering burst of loyalty and love that struck terror to the hearts of tyrants” – (vide Penny Press passim). Glad to hear from Bowley that he obtained 50 tickets from Sidney Hubert for the Orpheonistes.

There being a paucity of attendants today (C[rystal] P[alace] perhaps – carriages keep passing till 8 thick and fast), H.S. hands things to J.L. and remarks on the folly of Swell parties where few servants are kept, and one’s meat gets cold before one gets one’s vegetables.

L.C. rather slighted – best rest for Queen at Wimbledon, a rifleman, J.L [Punch, 39 (7 July 1860): 5, “Best Rest for the Queen's Rifle”].
Queen Victoria presided over a national rifle competion on Wimbledon Common on July 2, 1860, attended by the royal family, the Prime Minister, Lord Palmerston, and other diginitaries. The Queen's Prize was won by Edward Ross, a Cambridge undergraduate. S.B. cautions P.L. not to surfeit his nephew with sights – says he himself was a pretty boy and interesting, and people liked to have him about with them – and so at 10 or 12 he had seen everything and was a blasé little beast. And when he grew old enough to appreciate things he found no pleasure in them. In the bus going home H.S. tells S.B. of the three Frenchmen who, with all their national gallantry, would not give up their seats in carriage today to the ladies who asked leave to stand, and how H.S. and another Englishman did. But S.B. says ladies have no right to turn gentlemen out – vide Punch. No more they have in general – but in the crush of a railway, there’s an exception.

J.L., Lucas, and H.S. have soda and o de V. at Bedford with M.L., and M.L. afterwards tells H.S. that he [crossed out: “always”] quarreled with Albert Smith – first because he used to show his proofs at The Cheshire Cheese, etc. – get on very well without Sala & Co., and shouldn’t like to dine with them once a week. Punch keeps up by its keeping to the gentlemanly view of things and its being known that Bohemians don’t write for it. (By the way, Bob Brough dies this week – another case of suicide I suppose if the truth was known.)
Robert Barnabas Brough (1828-1860), bohemian journalist, poet, and editor (see note to entry for November 10, 1858). His death was not a suicide, nor was it necessarily hastened by his frenetic style of living, despite moralizing accounts then and since. There is some evidence for Peter Newbolt’s suggestion that the three elder Brough brothers, all of whom died young, may have shared a genetic physical weakness (William Tinsley (1831-1902) ‘Speculative Publisher,’ [Aldershot: Ashgate, 2001], 25). After a debilitating illness of a few months, he died, penniless, on June 26, 1860, leaving a wife and three children. The Savage Club, of which he was founder and president, staged a benefit for them.

Interesting discussion for a Debating Society – Was Shakespeare a b—?” J.L. argues yes – from the Sonnets. H.S. questions if a man with a natural passion could feel and write on the reverse. J.L. replies, Sh. was an universal genius and could feel and write about anything. James the First was a b—. Le roi Elisabeth and La reine Jacques
E. and J.L. prefer brownbessies to black – and girl waiters to men – H.S. concurs (mentally).

div.head: July 5, 1860. Th[ursday]. Star & Garter, Richmond. (Not dined there since August 57! My debut.)
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., T.T., C.K., J.T., M.L., Fred Evans, S.B., W. Bradbury Jr., Thackeray.
(Wimbledon Shooting Week. H.S. lolled in Q. Gardens instead and wrote a leaf from a French music book – which he guessed would not be used.)

Dine down in garden, next to Freemasons, ergo dishes not hot. Ices and whitebait the best part. Waiters hot and redfaced. M.L. suggests that S.B. and Fred as freemasons should go and remonstrate. S.B. says “Are you aware, Mr. Lemon, that you being a freemason Fred and I have power to order you out of the room?” Well says M., you might order me but I shouldn’t go. – S.B. suggests a paragraph, “It is not true that the worst dinner in the world is to be had at the Star & Garter” etc. … Talk of shooting – Swiss rifles stopped by French Customhouse. Says S.B., “the next time they enter Paris they’ll bring their rifles with them.” First Prize for hitting Louis Jester[?] in the heart, says Thackeray. ... Talk of “my dear Forster” says J.L., “don’t see why we should hate him so: he’s not been so very successful.” — Obiter dictum of a Judge of the fair Sex – “Women are very good sort of creatures if you keep them in their places and don’t turn their heads by marrying them and doing things of that sort.”

First No. of The British Lion out to day. All up with Punch!!!
A twopenny comic weekly, the British Lion made its debut with the number for July 7, 1860, published about six numbers, the last of which was dated September 1, 1860.

L.C. John Bull and Britannia at Breakfast – “I must give up my paper if you spend such a lot on that China” (paper duties retained by Lords), M.L. Pam offering up paper duties as a sacrifice to a Chinese Joss, T.T. Ceres, or Britannia, welcoming the Sun and shutting up umbrella. More talk about this fine week than about the Chinese [Punch, 39 (14 July 1860): 14-15, “The Long Lost Sun”].
T.T. describes an Ice pillar on Clays (American’s) dessert table – looked glittering, kept room cool and was cheaper than silver. Query if people think of the Interest they pay in keeping plate.

Yates writing about Thackeray in New York Times – can’t be a gentleman, says J.L.
Yates contrived to have a story insulting to George Smith, a benign version of which he had overheard Anthony Trollope tell, inserted in the New York Times (26 May 1860, 2) as a report of a conversation between Thackeray and George Smith at the latter’s dinner-table. Trollope was mortified, the more so as the appearance of the article, which was excerpted in the Saturday Review, put an end to the glittering dinner parties at which Smith had entertained the Cornhill’s contributors and which had been for Trollope and other writers an important means of literary networking. Thackeray wrote a “Roundabout Paper” on this incident, entitled “On Screens in Dining Rooms,” for the August number (number 6) of the Cornhill, 252-255. Wants kicking. No use using the kid glove style or argument with a Bohemian – must take to the bludgeon to make any impression on such pachydermatous parties.
J.L. tells of visiting Charterhouse. Names on School new to him – not to me. Fights used to be behind bog. “Coach” trees there – climbed to see mail coaches go by.

Roundabout ride home to put T.T. down – left bus at Sloane Street (30/-) – Talk about Cricket with Fred [Evans] – asks me to join the Hampstead which Bromley belongs to. But my cricket ardour is over somehow.— W[illiam] B[radbury] Junr. not a gent. to look at and doesn’t open his lips at dinner. H.S. not the only abashed party.

div.head: July 11, 1860. Th[ursday]. Trafalgar, Greenwich.
div.p: Present: E., H.S., Bradbury! – M.L., S.B., and J.T.

Leech and H.S. dined upstairs yesterday – mistake in invitation note. But who can object to having two fish feeds instead of one. Loch Tay trout the best thing yesterday – but the salmon cutlets were rechauffees and the whole thing ≠ today’s. O that cold salmon and horseradish ice! Imported from Russia by de Bathe, S.B. says. And then the hot spiced Trafalgar salmon to follow! – fish omelette to begin with, not so bad either, i.e. either after the [four words indecipherable], says S.B. The Star and Garter is the place for women – but Greenwich for men. And the best of these fish feeds is that the brown bread is the only substantial stuff one eats. Next morning I was hungrier than usual for my breakfast. M.L. revives his story of how Pater inspected hen turtle who amourously flapped her fins at seeing some one of her family. Evidently longed to give him a scaly embrace. Bold thing in the Punch proprietors to stand such a dinner in the face of No. 2 of The British Lion!

Says S.B. to M.L., “Sadly shirked politics of late – when J.L. proposes anything it’s sure to be adopted.” – Says M.L. firing up — “You sometimes suggest good cuts, Shirley – but you’re too apt to think yours better than anybody’s.” – S.B. wants a Dissenting cut to please the People. Anent their Census they’ve given Lord Pam a decided slap in the face. — L.C postponed: but S.B.’s notion taken [ Punch, 39 (21 July1860): 25, “Dissent in Earnest” ]. Bradbury’s re-entry. Been at Hastings in the quiet. Can’t stand our row.

div.head: July 18, 1860. No dinner.
div.p: Last week’s good enough for two. Eclipse day. Trimmer and Jane come to us.

div.head: July 26, 1860. Th[ursday]. Greyhound, Dulwich.
div.p: Present: B., S.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L. (late, walking from Hammersmith), and C.K.

Nothing particular in the way of talk. Except about the new ride in Kensington Gardens. E. and S.B. sorry to see J.L.’s cut – S.B. thinking it a good opportunity to introduce a bit to please the people.
The new “ride” was a pathway for horseback-riding (Times July 21, 1860, 7). Leech’s cut in Punch (28 July 28, 1860): 34, ridiculed those complaining about the ride. H.S. dissents and approves Cut, Vestry Claptrap, in opposition only.

L.C. M.L. suggests J. Bull arriving loading [crossed out: “blunderbuss”] revolver [Punch, 39 (14 August 1860): 45, “A La Mode Française” ]. H.S. says you don’t load at muzzle. H.S. suggests J[ohn] B[ull] on look out for poacher. M.L. “following your fashion” – Good! Pam’s speech the subject of this.
[pointing finger] Called on Bromley’s Liz [“arrested”? illegible], and he came just as I –

div.head: August 1, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L. E., P.L, S.B., & T.T.

Talk of spirit rapping. J.L. describes his séance with Mrs. Marshall at Knox’s. Could see her sister do the table trick – and on manifesting incredulity was rapped out of the room. – Shall this gentleman go away – yes – yes – Hume floating past window – all bosh – probably a balloon — says H.S., I’d take a dark lanthorn, or have a flying shot with a pistol. “Don’t be so wiolent, Sperrits,” said Mrs. Marshall. Regular Humebug.
Daniel Dunglas Home (1833-1886), pronounced “Hume,” Scottish medium, arrived in England after attaining considerable celebrity in America.

C.K. tells of man being seasick the day before the voyage. (Miss Meadows, of Otley, says the C[rystal] P[alace] makes her feel seasick – perhaps when she looks out on the roof, and sees the mer de glass.) J.L. describes his mishap at Marlow, placidly sketching, and boat gets adrift and capsizes, leaving him on an island helpless.

L.C. The Emperor’s letter the subject. T.T. suggests the “Injured Innocent,” French wolf appealing to dogs not to think so ill of him. Says it’s the first time we’ve seen a stock obbing King. – What’s your title, Lettre de Catch-it, says P.L. The last French letter, says S.B. Some one suggests The French Savage offering the pipe of peace. –

And then talking of Horsman’s interruptions to the debates. “Mr. Horsman’s coach stops the way”. — Why did T.T. snub P.L. so. I don’t remember – but he did. Funny how quietly P.L. talks in his placid voice – “Hear me,” – “will you let me speak” etc. And how T.T. looks through his spectacles, with a choky sort of laugh and says: “B? – What do you think of this? – Louis Napoleon as a wolf” etc. [ Punch, 38 (11 August 1860): 55, “Injured Innocence and His Billet-Doo”].
J.L. can’t smoke a pipe – makes him sick – so does a cigar – cub cup[?].

M.L. gives a description of Bob Romer – putting finger to nose like the Old Un – “Yes – very clever man, said Bob, but talent’s not his forte.” Bus horse down – light a fire under him says some charitable bystander. Who’s that rowing, Bill – Oh, only the Emperor of Rooshia.
