Talk about Bob Brough and Alfred Dickens – arcades ambo. Gin and water on the brain. Why should the truth be hid. If public comes forward and supports their children, are not other drunkards thereby encouraged. Says E., Alfred Dickens had the fatal gift of singing a good song.
Alfred Lamert Dickens (1822-1860), civil engineer, was Charles Dickens’s younger brother. He died of pleurisy in Manchester on July 27.
S.B. suggests Anti-Convivial Songs, My hand it shakes and my head it aches – A bumper of soda so fill fill for me.

div.head: August 8, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B.

M.L. attacked with steria – but came down after dinner. J.L. details his fight with organ fiend last night. Inveterate enemy he is. Of course the populace take the organ’s part always. Mobs have no nerves. And broadcloth generally gets hooted.

L.C. S.B. suggests “the Latest Edition of the Edinbro’ Review” – Queen reviewing Scottish Volunteers
See Times August 8, 1860, p. 9 re: the Queen’s review of 20,000 Volunteers in Holyrood Park, Edinburgh. – or Prince in Canada dancing and calling out figures – Punch clapping him on the back – hulloa young fellow. This is how you make yourself adored, is it?P.L. – the 2 Sick Men, (accepted). S.B. suggests words “course of steel” and J.L. adds “system.” [ Punch, 39 (18 August 1860]: 65, “The Two Sick Men,” in which the Pope says, “They have sent you my French doctor, I see. His course of steel hasn’t done my system much good.”]

Story of younger son (brother having proposed f—ing and foxhunting) saying Can’t afford such luxuries but I’ll give you frigging and fishing. Spirit talk. Name of the Humbug is Home not Hume – Home Sweet Home an obvious parody. T.T. does 4 lines at a breath. J.L. suggests a cut of Punch floating over duchesses, being visibly held up by the hand of the exhibitor. Also, Punch rapping the hands of the rappers – “You’re a spirit rapper eh! Take that – So am I!” Cut of bloated Buttons floating over his his master’s chair. Home originally a buttons in America T.T. says, and was discharged for humbugging, pretending he could move a piano. Married some Russian Swell’s daughter. Houdin’s aerial suspension much more clever – done in daylight.

S.B. describes going up in balloon – no sensation of movement. Earth seems going away from you, terribly shaky bumps when you alight – somebody lit a cigar, and Green raged and raved at him – of course.
Silver clearly used this note to jog his memory in relating Brooks’s account to G. S. Layard (Layard, A Great Punch Editor, p. 55): “'I once went up in a balloon,' Shirley told us, 'and I wasn't a bit funky, but I frankly didn't like it. London seemed to slip away, and the sensation was unpleasant somehow, though I felt no motion. But the bumping on the ground on coming down was beastly. I believe that some of my lower bones would have certainly been broken had not my rotundity acted as a buffer.'“ The ascent was made in Cremorne Gardens in 1847, with Albert Smith and other newspapermen.
J.L. describes the Game of Russian Gossip – each in circle telling same tale to neighbor.

M.L. makes an appeal re P.B. [Pocket Book] last bad (d– bad says Shirley)
Mr Punch’s Pocket Book for 1860 – shorter articles – Silver do us some more ballads for Bedlam says S.B. and quotes a passage. (!)
Punch, 37 (5 November 1859), 184: “Ballads for Bedlamites”
Talk of The Waygoose last Saturday – only one drunk and he spoilt it – capital fun that “leaded matter” or enemies, in the printer’s song.

H.S. agrees to do Essence [of Parliament], during S.B.’s absence.
In a letter to Percival Leigh, Brooks explained why he had chosen Silver (there nicknamed “Argentum”) to substitute for him on the weekly “Essence of Parliament” column: “here was a special reason why Argentum should do it, namely, that he is remunerated by the work, not by salary, and one is only too glad to throw anything to so good a fellow” (quoted in Layard, A Great Punch Editor, 123). H.S. tells of Rev. Hansard at St. George’s – sailor wants baptism certificate – I ain’t a-going to tell you my name. When were you born – What’s that to you – Where do you live? Ax my -

div.head: August 15, 1860. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B.
(late), Lucas, T.T., Paxton.

At dinner talk of Spirit rapping. Paxton stopped a table’s moving by simply putting his foot on it. Lucas tells of a table rising – M.L. thinks by magnets – blasphemy to say man has power over spirits – moreover miracles have never been done without some good and beneficial end – trading on the dearest affections of one’s nature is detestable. Parents put en rapport with their dead children are disarmed and overcome and can’t criticize.

Paxton renews his invitation to Chatsworth – says a carriage shall be ready by Gr. Northern for us — Says his Thames Embankment Scheme is well received – talks of April 10/ [18]48 – passed Kennington Common, and saw how few there were, and so to his brokers and bought stock and made £500. That’s the way to profit by a panic. Mowbray Morris and Delane, splendidly housed near Ascot, teste J.L.

E.T. Smith writing T.T. for a play – “first act to end with a startling effect – second with a greater – third with water, shipwreck, blue fire and hell and Tommy[?].”Tells of E.T. with troupe of Italians at Dublin, they bothered him by their neglect and indispositions etc. till he invited them to breakfast and then took up a knife and challenged them to fight after their own infernal fashion – better have it out than worry him to death by inches. Believes in champagne as the universal settler of contracts and maker of things smooth. J.L. tells of yachting Swell, going to sleep at Regatta, and yawning “aw – is this d— sailing match – aw – ovaw yet?”

L.C. Lucas suggests Gamekeepers at door waiting for Palmerston – T.T. adds let P[almerston] be seen coming out to them. [ Punch, 39 (25 August 1860): 75, “The Political Situation” ]H.S. had thought of P[almerston] as the Political Maid of All Work, arms full of bills which must be carried – “holiday! There’s no chance of a holiday for me yet awhile!”

Punch’s Thousandth Number near at hand. S.B. had thought of letting off some literary fireworks, but subsides into promising to do a Presentation paragraph, The Universe paying their respects (which he doesn’t). E. and J.L. think much puffing would be claptrappy, and mistaken – enemies would say, see how old Punch is getting. M.L. and P.L. and H.S. concur.

Talk of the Kensington Ride – P.L. objects – ride over ploughed fields, but not over flower gardens.
See Times leader, August 8, 1860, p. 7, defending ride. Well drest fools go to stare at one another. Gregariousness a proof of folly. Says his nephew like himself don’t care for games etc. P.L. used to like to see remarkable men better than a match at cricket. We all dissent – mischief and fun are natural to boys. One likes to hear of lads like J.L. sliding downstairs and knocking off their buttons.
[two blank pages follow in mss.]

div.head: October 16, 1861. Wednesday. No. 11.
div.p: Present: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T.
champ.

T T. just back from Homburg [sic]. Says when he reached England he felt among ladies and gentlemen. English far better drest and behaved, as a rule. J.L. chuckles, Wisdom has been crying that in the streets these dozen years. Nobody like the English. Then T.T. tells of Englishman calling landlord an ugly beggar to his face, not thinking he knew English—and next day dined out and was introduced to landlord who spoke English perfectly. Also of Englishman at roulette, “I can’t play while that old hag sits opposite,” and the Russian lady makes a most polite response in perfect English also. These are the exceptions which prove the rule, of course. J.L. applauds T.T.’s article hereanent, and C.K. says “G.U.” of the Times is G. Urving, a laceman of Regent Street. This sketch is a back portrait.

T.T.’s little boy kept sitting up to welcome him (speaks German) – only laughed, and there T.T. saw a likeness to himself. Curious, that story of his being in bath and boy taking hold and saying KoK. Grim[?], says Thackeray.

Talk on marriage. T.T. says its an art to live with your wife happily. Have your own way and let her have hers, says J.L. Give and take. P.L. says men of intellect had best not marry, happier single. All dissent from him. Pater says no man knows complete happiness without marrying. P.L. says wife apt to retrench in claret and not in crinoline. No, No, says Pater, and S.B. says wife would say beer didn’t agree with her, so that husband might afford himself an extra glass. J.L. pities the wife of a “talented” party, and thinks she has far the better sense and judgment. S.B. and T.T. both say their purses better managed now they’re womanaged.

Talk of Dickens’ hunt after a haunted house, don’t believe there’s one in England that’ll bear investigation. Short story in All the Year Round artist painting portrait of daughter long since dead.
[Thomas Heaphy], “Four Stories,” All the Year Round, Volume 5, No. 125 (14 September 1861), 589-593. The story referred to is the first one, pp. 589-590. [illegible – “dreaming man”? ] says T.T. [words crossed out; ileg “such a man”?]

T.T. prefers humour to wit — says there’s always something devilish in wit, humour only good natured. P.L. says wit akin to philosophy — Jerrold and a Beckett instances of both. J.L. laments poor Gil — so full of ready fun.

P.L. says a poet should be above his art — Thackeray a gentleman – (does he mean that gentlemanliness ranks above talent?). T.T. thinks Thackeray the most miserable of men — not only because of his complaint. P.L. thinks he’s like Swift, despises Vanity Fair and despises himself for taking pleasure in it. J.L. tells of his intruding at Wingrove Cooke’s dinner and meeting his foe, Forster, and M.L. tells of his intrusion at dinner, given to Dickens, when Forster says, “Here are our two greatest writers, one extracts good from evil and [the] other finds evil in everything that’s good.”
George Wingrove Cooke (1814-1865), lawyer, historian, and Times special correspondent.
Long jaw about pictures. T.T. says Rubens greatest in animals.

L.C. J.L. suggests Emperor and King of Prussia at the Coverside (dinner) — turned by S.B. and T.T. and J.L. into cut as it appears. [ Punch 41 (26 October 1860): 166, “The Cover-Side at Compiègne”] Somebody thinks of that young man from the country, so the hunting one is to be a half cut. T.T. anxious that the names of the Treaties should be given, and the dates too.
T.T. E. and J.L. go – “Now we’ll have a quiet evening” says Shirley. Been shooting much, Silver? Not fired a gun yet!! Diarrh. etc. etc.

S.B. and P.L. talk of S.B.’s visit to Brodie, one eye left, wife been wheeled upstairs these 9 years, reads all new books to him.
Sir Benjamin Collins Brodie (1783-1862). Surgeon and specialist in bone and joint disease, president of the Royal Society, and sergeant-surgeon to the Queen. S.B. wonders, considering the education of medical men, that so little progress has been made in medical knowledge. P.L. says the real seeking for truth/knowledge dates 200 years back from Harvey’s discovery. Medicine helps nature, that’s all. Nature really works the cure. S.B. compares the doctors of the body with the Drs. of the soul and thinks the latter have progressed the most. P.L. differs. Essays and Reviews a sign that men are anxious for the Truth. And this sign the blundering Bishops do their best to smash.
The publication of Essays and Reviews (London: Parker & Son, 1860), a volume consisting of essays about Christianity by seven well-known Broad Church liberals (all but one of them clergymen) that challenged traditional interpretations, sparked one of the fiercest controversies of the period. Twenty-five Anglican bishops joined the Archbishop of Canterbury in calling for some of the authors to be tried for heresy in an ecclesiastical court. See Josef Altholz, Anatomy of a Controversy: The Debate over “Essays and Reviews, 1860-64” (London: Routledge, 1994).
Very interesting talk. What memories have S.B. and T.T.! And what a muff is H.S.!

div.head: October 23, 1861_. W[ednesday. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B., T.T.

T.T. asks why L.C. altered – he proposed the King and Emperor at Gate or fence marked “Treaties,” E. saying, “Let me show your Majesty a short cut” and K. replying, “Thank you, I think it’s safer going round.”

Talk of Bethell’s coolness – “If you will direct what you call your mind.” T.T. says he could pick up facts from brief while speaking – bullied Junior and then said something pityingly, “Do you know what Noah said to the Devil, Mr. Bethell?” – “No,” he said. Go to H–!, (S.B.) – Bethell’s son a spendthrift and next door to a swindler. S.B. when a lawyer’s clerk recollects hearing B[ethell] say to Clerk, “When my son comes in tell him I am very displeased with him” etc. etc.
Richard Bethell (1800-1873), appointed Lord Chancellor in 1861.

S.B. at a private performance of Othello last night – 3rd Act beautiful – but can’t give the passion full force – drags Desdemona back from door and makes you feel you are assisting at a brutal murder – cuts his throat at end, surely that’s not “smiting.” What he has done with Ryder is more wondrous still – you may speak of Mr. Fechter’s Iago.
J.L tells of a certain Lady Bountiful who supplied such poor soup that the recipients called it a bullock’s head boiled in a pond. (Says Mrs. L[eech] much wishes me to come and see them soon.)

Rubens’ landscapes and animals his best work (T.T.). S.B. says no painter has produced a luscious woman, one carnally desirable – C.K. says Titian has, and J.L., Lely. Talk of Ruskin, writes like a Eunuch, says S.B. More brains than bollocks [in Greek letters]. (J.L.) – impotent ad hunc. Mrs. R[uskin] only, says P.L.
Critic John Ruskin’s marriage to Euphemia (“Effie”) Gray was annulled in 1854 on the grounds of “non-consummation.” The reasons for this remain a matter of speculation. The following year she married artist John Everett Millais, by whom she had eight children. When T.T. goes, J.L. says the Art criticism in The Times too learned – S.B. says a man needn’t paint to criticise painting. J.L., C.K., and J.T. differ from him – say Ruskin can draw well. S.B. says he can criticize music and yet knows nothing of it – quotes a bit of his – “Over the deep abyss of bass there floated a silvery cloud of treble” etc.(Call that criticism! bosh!). T.T. would write a criticism on Chaldee if he were asked – S.B. ranks a caricaturist like HB or Hogarth or J.L. above all painters – stamps the image of his times ineffaceably.
J.L. suggests “The Orleans Boy to the War has gone, In the ranks of Snobs you’ll find him.”

P.L.’s nephew called Mrs. Stocker (Snorter, M.L.) a bugger [in Greek letters]- not only a crime but a blunder. Been telling lies and saying P.L.’s sister complained that the cold meat was cribbed, and so Mrs. S. put her back up, to P.L.’s surprise. Funny to hear how mildly he speaks of such things – nice old fellow – in some things vastly like the Old Un. – Been mushroom hunting, as usual. Tennyson received £2,000 a year from B & E for his copyrights! No wonder he don’t write —. J.L. asks why Athenaeum like Venison, deer at any price. E. heard Jenny [Lind] last night in Elijah, her first reappearance – liked her better than ever – voice, if less powerful, has even more expression.
Internationally famous Swedish opera singer Jenny Lind (1820-1887) was appearing in Exeter Hall in Felix Mendelsohn’s Elija; see Times, October 23, 1861, p. 10. The paper noted that it was her first appearance before the English public since her “farewell” tour in 1856. Such dramatic warmth – prefers her to Malibran.
Maria Felica Malibran, known professionally as Madam Malibran (1808-1836), opera singer, and daughter of Manuel Garcia, a famous Spanish tenor. A mezzo-soprano, she made her first appearance on the London stage in 1826. Says Barham in the “Comfort Ye’ was wondrous – and so said my father.

L.C. Prince of Wales opening Temple Library, S.B. – King Cotton the subject, says T.T. , King Cotton and King Cabbage (Smith O’Brien, who has offered to mediate), “If I can’t separate them, I’m sure you can’t.” – J.L. thinks such a cut would “astonish your subscribers” – 2 dogs fighting, negro dropping bale of cotton on them, S.B. – France and Britannia, 2 girls on riverside, beckoning King (who is bound and can’t come – S.B.) Lion and Mouse, black man nibbling away the net, S.B. But a cotton Lion won’t do, say the artists – besides there’s only one Lion, the British. T.T. then suggests Prometheus, and J.T. puts the title. [ Punch, 41 (1861)176-77, “King Cotton Bound, or The Modern Prometheus” ]
See the Times leader of October 21, 1860, p. 6, anticipating the cotton famine and blaming the North for it, but concluding that Britain should not allow itself to be drawn into the conflict. – directly after which S.B. suggests Othello, Put up your bright swords {Done next week
Fechter was appearing in Othello at the Princess Theatre; see Times October 24, 1861, p. 9.}[Punch, 41 (1861)187, “The Genu-ine Othello” ]. A hard stool, says M.L., but good [illegible word].

div.head: October 30, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: B., J.L., C.K., H.S., M.L., (Fr. Woode, all serene), E., P.L., T.T., Lucas.

T.T. brings [word crossed out] one of Sir Joshua’s Pocket Books – working out his life – names of sitters. T.T. says almost every man of note went and had his portrait taken, so the PB becomes a sort of History. Kitty Fisher often sat to him. Lucas envies the last century for possessing such a face.
Kitty Fisher (?-1767), born Catherine Maria Fischer, famous courtesan, whose portrait was painted by Sir Joshua Reynolds, Nathaniel Hone, and others. T.T. gets up at six and works 3 hours before breakfast, and so can spend evening with wife.

J.L. thinks Mr. Broome’s chrysanthemums one of the amiable weaknesses which should be pitched into.
Samuel Broome (1805-1870) was head gardener of the Inner Temple. For many years he organized an autumn chrysanthemum show at the Temple Gardens; see the admiring review of the 1861 show, which had opened to the public on the previous day, in the Morning Herald for 30 October 1861, p. 3. The show also coincided with the appearance of the fifth edition of Broome’s treatise on the cultivation of chrysanthemums Hates to see blind men begging, looking so resigned and pious.

T.T. thinks everyone has stolen when a boy – stole master’s apples himself. Master’s property fair game, says P.L. Instances Woodham saying to boy whose name was Beef – “Come, little Sirloin, let’s go and purloin.” J.L. denies, and says, God forbid my boy should steal. But it’s not stealing, says T.T. – not malicious theft. H.S. thinks so, too, and feels conscience smitten about Walford’s tarts. ‘Cribbing’ not so bad as stealing. Code of school honour not real virtue. H.S. thrashed the first week at school for telling the truth. Did you see so-and-so – Yes. Down comes a “rabbiter” on his neck as he goes out of school. What did you show up young Snooks for, you young telltale?

T T. tells of Sala leaving lodgings after ordering beefsteak pudding for dinner (Frith) and returning six months after, “Is that pudding boiled yet?” – Left his journal there: written in Italian and French chiefly. – End of nose redder than his cigar. S.B.
In 1859, word quickly spread throughout London of a drunken brawl in which Sala’s nose was split open, creating a fiery, bulbous emblem of Bohemianism that Sala biographer Ralph Strauss would later describe as “like nothing else in the civilized world”; Sala: The Portrait of an Eminent Victorian (London: Constable, 1942), p. 138.

Ornamental last week. J.T. at Zool[ogical] Gardens last Sunday, saw lion and lioness [Greek letters] he catlike biting ears, clawing and noisy – wrinkled face – looked grand – she sulky and savage, and afterwards lay in corner as though ashamed of herself.

T.T. says Jerrold’s plays won’t live because they’ve no human interest or skilful plot – sheer wit won’t do for the stage, denies S.B.’s assertion that the intellectual playgoer is the best judge of a play – apt to be led away by the neatness of the writing, whereas the less educated better appreciate the naturalness of the characters, etc.

div.head: November 6, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., S.B., H.S., C.K., M.L., P.L., H.M., Thackeray, T.T.
(H.S. asthmatic since Sunday – C.K. and H.M. also with colds – that sudden change on Saturday the cause.)

Thackeray asks whence the derivation of Horn for cuckolds. T.T. says the 2 fingers held branching from forehead like ass’s ears, vide Horace. Sed qure. The sign is Continental as well as English. Charivari has cut of servant speaking to stag, seeing horns over paling, and master calling, “I’m here, you fool.”

H.M. tells how Vivier hates Chorley, and would go about saying, “Je demande la tête de Chorley.”
Eugene-Leon Vivier (1817-1900), French horn virtuoso, was very popular in England and well known for his wit and practical jokes. Henry Fothergill Chorley (1808-1872), music critic, wrote chiefly for the Athenaeum and was a close friend of Dickens. – V. invented story of how at C’s death, the worms all resolved not to touch him, but one did and went raving mad directly. C. lives a careful saving life and so can give a good dinner occasionally. – “Shall as soon hear of C’s taking the bass part in a glee,” says P.L., apropos of something. As a sample of rythmical ingenuity, Thackeray quotes this couplet –
“Let some intelligent officer be sent to the front,
“Hardman, step forward, said Sir Hussey Vivian, K.C.B., and bear the battle’s brunt.”
(Shirley remembers this at first hearing: C.K. and S. don’t.)

Boucicault a blackguard – used to act lies as well as tell them. Note from Webster with cheque for £800, “Dn. the fellow, I told him £l000,” – tears cheque up. Alleged son of Dionysius Lardner,
Dionysius Lardner (1793-1859), writer and lecturer on popular scientific subjects. when tutor to Irish family (of five girls) in Dublin. Lord Somebody in Scotland wanted to marry Agnes Robertson, and his family gave her £3000 to be off — B[oucicault] got £15.15 a week as Dram. Writer to Kean, and pretended to be converted from Catholicism by Mrs. K[ean] then ran off with Agnes.
For the story of Bouciault, Robertson, and the Keans, see Richard Fawkes, Dion Boucicault, (London: Quartet Books, 1979), 75-77. Boucicault and Robertson later married, separated, and eventually, in 1880, went through a very public divorce. Great bragger of his property – Came to Webster, “bought that Manor – makes 3 – hate shooting over same ground.” – So M.L. trumps him by saying he has 10 miles of shooting round his house. This stupendous prosperity and villainy is quite delicious, says Thackeray. B[oucicault] in treaty for Lyceum, gave lots of trouble and then wrote Arnold, “I secede, Yours truly.” Asked Fechter to join him “And then we’ll smash up all the other b-ggers.”
P.L. quotes: “And he that will not be merry with my noble friend Lord Chandos,
“Shall have his head cut off with an axe & his a– shoved into a bandbox.”
W.M.T. asks, Whence this latter phrase? (Leaves in pain – had it 30 years he says.)

Sorry [“Surrey”?] farce, says M.L. – Wm. Stickers thieves in the country, – comes to London and sees every hoarding stuck with the awful warning, “Bill Stickers – Beware!” Shan’t ‘ave Maria Lane, says S.B.: another instance. “Commit No Nuisance St.” T.T. quotes – tells of French actor writing to wife and posting letters in private door letter boxes. – Glanders and Snottley, S.B., almost as good as Bilk & Co. ( faci).

T.T. brings Amateur Sketches on wood, too hard. One of them – “Our Dramatic Correspondent in Wales so pleased with scenery that he calls for “Beverley”. Another, Plain middle aged lady saying mad bull ran away from her, says her friend, “I’m not surprised” – not so mad as he seemed. Feeble jokes, hardly up to “Fun” even – which copy of old Punch of year ‘42 still lingers on.

L.C. When thieves fall out etc., India stepping in, T.T. – How to break the blockade. John Bull paying India for cotton bale, S.B. – Opposition Cotton Shops (accepted) S.B. [Punch, 41 (16 November 1861)197: “Over the Way”].
See the Times leader of November 4, 1861, p. 6, which called for cultivating cotton in India. T.T. suggests 3 Emperors sitting on volcanoes. Franco Russian question.

Who would you best like to meet? – Dr. Johnson, says S.B. & P.L. & H.S. Rather a talker than simply a writer. Love that dear old Sir Walter says W.M.T. The honestest of our craft says S.B. W.M.T. thinks Byron a raffish snob. P.L. thinks Sir Walter as good a poet.
T.T. gets up at 6, 3 hours before breakfast – finished Operetta last night for Harrison. H.S. a great screw in such matters ... Colleen Bawn brings £300 a week from Country alone.
C.K. illustrates “Expression” by
[two drawings, one with tail up, one with tail down]
Cheerful pig Melancholy pig

div.head: November 13, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T., Sir J. Paxton. Champagne.

Paxton says the Coventry ribbons used to be sold as French, because on account of the protective duty of 15% the French were thought the best. Hence the trade now suffers. Salus populi suprema lex – with mills working half time our Government will be forced to interfere with America, so thinks T.T. H.S. doesn’t.

J.L. savage that his hunting cut should be re-published by Illustrated News with their d– penny paper. Mr. Leighton wrote cheekily that they had the copyright, and that it wouldn’t injure J.L.’s reputation to have the picture reproduced.
This cut has not been traced. George Cargill Leighton (1826-1895) and his firm, Leighton Brothers, were the printers and publishers of the Illustrated London News from 1858 to 1883. Ann Little Ingram (1812-1896) became proprietor of the paper after the death of her husband, Herbert Ingram, in 1860, and remained in control until passing ownership to her sons in 1871. J.L. differs and asks M.L. to appeal to Mrs. Ingram. Great shame that artist’s drawings should be used for other purpose than originally intended, as in that precious Yelverton trial pamphlet.
The widely reported Yelverton case of 1861 involved the secret marriage by Catholic priest of an Irish Protestant, Major William Charles Yelverton, to Theresa Longworth, an Irish Catholic, a marriage that Yelverton sought to annul in order to have his subsequent marriage to Emily Forbes declared valid. London publisher George William Vickers brought out a lavishly illustrated pamphlet about the case. Pleasant to see “C. Keene” in the pictures to a bawdy book. Nil mirabile in talk. P.L. and M.L. agree that ladies are powerless to make servants dress properly. H.S. differs, quoting sisters. If a servant has a good place, as a rule her love of finery won’t make her relinquish it.

C.K. expects to see the Swiss belt worn by cooks, suggests cut. You put your footman into livery, why not your housemaid? And how much prettier would be a national peasant’s costume – e.g. Dutch, thinks H.S. J.L. hates crinoline, on ladies as well as servants. S.B. don’t – in moderation. When the Prince of Wales marries a pretty ancled [sic] girl, away will go the crinoline.

P.L. declares against the maudlin imitation of crimes, e.g. men confessing imaginary murders. Soldiers shoot their officers because they read in penny papers of others having done so said The Times.
Times leader, November 12, 1861, p. 6 concerned with murders of officers by their men. Monument suicides were stopped by the cage being put up – take away the facility and you’ll reduce the crime. J.L. approves of Drumhead Courtmartial, and instant hanging. But M.L. thinks you should allow time for repentance, and hang before the regiment. H.S. doubts the efficacy of deathbed repentances, or rather that a fortnight is enough for them – a day would as much suffice. The Almighty is just, and would judge according to the guilt and opportunity for repentance.

L.C. J.L. suggests Little Jonathan fighting, ‘cause I want a National Debt like you, Father Bull' [Punch, 41(23 November 1861): 208, “The Wilful Boy.”]. Duke of Cambridge and public dinners – “Sequitur patreur haud ventribus aequis” [written beneath this word, “ilibus (H.S.)] S.B.
Per Constance Smith, the translation, “He follows his father, but not with equal stomach is a play on “ ... non passibus aequis” - but not with equal steps (Virgil).
C.K. calls the maudlin murder confessings, “obtaining notoriety under false pretenses.”

div.head: November 20, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Pocketbook distributed.
div.p: B., J.L.,H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T., Thackeray. Champagne.

L C. T.T. suggests L[ouis] N[apoleon] doing penance in balance sheet [Punch, 41(30 November 1861): 219, “Penance in a Balance-Sheet!”]S.B. would wish notion of L.N. cleaned out, “Now you see I meant no harm to you.” J.L. suggests the beggar L.N. having ridden to the Devil wants to sell his horse – as supplement to cut in ‘53 which Thackeray it seems objected to. Didn’t he leave Punch on the French question partly – Salary the cause, said M.L. Hand of devil outstretched in distance, says S.B. – French Eagle, an ill bird, that Fould its own nest, J.L.— (But Fould is the reformer!) — Dizzy on the high ropes, doing the clerical Trapeze, M.L. – apropos of his Church Speech – W.M.T. indignant at this Jew’s coming forward as the champion of the Christian Church. S.B. speaks up for Diz — says he took his brief firsthand from Tories, instead of working through the law for it – fought his battle bravely, and men of the pen should be proud of him. M.L. and P.L. and B. dissent – “No principle” – no more has any rising lawyer, says S.B. Denounces Peel as betrayer of his party, and lowered popular faith in the Consistency of Statesmen. But he had no money to gain, says M.L., and he resigned directly he had passed the Corn Law Bill, which he only passed because John Russell couldn’t.
Great jaw hereanent. Shirley solus in his views.

T.T. and C.K. to Haymarket to see Lord Dundreary which J.L. laughed at and imitates. T.T. says piece was well constructed as he originally wrote it.
“Our American Cousin” was extensively re-written by Laura Keene and E. A. Sothern to highlight the comedy. (?) Thackeray savage at Edwin James’ reception into the American bar. “And I have only a twopenny ha’penny thunderbolt to hurl at him.”
Edwin James (1812-1882), prominent barrister, was disbarred in 1861 for taking bribes and other offenses, and emigrated to America, where he was admitted to the New York bar.

Thackeray half cut by Miss Dickens at Lord Mayor’s – calling – “Let fathers hate like h – , but why need their children quarrel?” — Can’t excuse Dickens for writing that letter for Yates, which he owns he did.
Edmund Yates (1831-1894), literary journalist and later editor of the World, was expelled from the Garrick Club at the insistence of Thackeray, though supported by Dickens; this led to an estrangement between Dickens and Thackeray that lasted until shortly before the latter's death. See the account of “the Garrick Club affair” in Patrick Leary, The Punch Brotherhood (London: British Library, 2010), 92-109. After Yates's derogatory article about Thackeray had appeared in the fugutive publication Town Talk, Thackeray wrote to him in protest. Yates took Thackeray’s letter to Dickens, showing him also a long, self-justifying reply he had written in which he castigated Thackeray for making fun of public personalities in his Punch parodies of the 1840s. Dickens found the letter “too flippant and too violent,” and helped Yates write instead a cold reply claiming that as Thackeray’s letter had itself been “slanderous and untrue” he could not apologize, and had nothing further to add. Thackeray later learned of Dickens's role from Dickens himself. Yates's letter of 15 June 1858, appears in Gordon Ray, ed., Letters and Private Papers of William Makepeace Thackeray, 91-92. – Calls Cubitt “an old dear,” and says he was pleased with Punch cutting into that Liverpool pennyaliner about him. — Offers £300 to buy Evans’s for the Garrick – “Aw – put me down a £l,000 or 2,” says J.L.

— Didn’t Tennyson hate Elizabeth Browning, asks S.B. Isn’t it natural for rival writers to be enemies? – W.M.T. dissents – calls Tennyson the greatest man of the age – “has thrown the quoit furthest.” S.B. says Vanity Fair ranks higher than anything of Tennyson’s, “Would you change your reputation for his? “Yes.”“I don’t believe you.”Thinks “Lotos Eaters” T[ennyson]’s best. P.L. thinks Tennyson is to Wordsworth what Mendelssohn is to Beethoven: graceful but not sublime. Ranks “Laodamia” first of Wordsworth’s works. Beats Tennyson there on his own ground. — All 3 praise Scott. S.B. and P.L. the most – stirs the blood – but, says Thackeray, I don’t want to have my blood stirred. Like a trumpet call, says S.B. – and if his lines are here and there a little rough and hasty, who cares for good grammar when a hero cries out Up and at ‘em! Bulwer might much improve Scott’s language. Curious felicity of words, says Thackeray. Curiosa felicitas, appends S.B. (Thackeray often talks just as he writes. And I fancy so did Douglas Jerrold – recollect his short pithy epigrams of sentences at the Duke’s funeral.
At the time of the Duke of Wellington’s funeral in November of 1852, Jerrold was the newly appointed editor of Lloyd’s Weekly. His coverage of the funeral vastly expanded the paper’s circulation.) Thackeray thanks God that the world is wide, and that tastes are various, and whatever mental food be offered there are sure to be customers. Tennyson on a level with Milton and Shakespeare, no, Mr. Thackeray, I can’t agree to that. But with S.B., I will call his writing “music in verse.”

S.B. imagines Bradbury Lord Mayor, and gets up as Lord Palmerston to propose his health – a “type” of a good printer etc. etc. — S.B. to Edinbro’ on Saturday to lecture on House of Commons and Horace Walpole.
Bradbury when savage at Chambers’ close competition used to cut down all Scotch thistles with walking stick.
[drawing of pointing hand] Charley Dickens married yesterday after a 14 years’ Engagement! Only 24 now – and Bessie [Evans]. Drink their healths: and success to the Pocketbook.

Intere Seniores decet juvenere silere, thinks H.S.
C. Smith translates as, “Among their elders, juniors should retire and be silent.” Certainly it’s a treat listening to such talk and somehow my voice trembles to join in it. Want the memory of S.B. to be such a good talker – apt with anecdote and illustrative quotation. Seems to have all poetry at his tongue’s tip.

Duke of Cambridge going to reform Woolwich Cadets, Miss Fairbrother beside him and big cigar in mouth, J.L.
See letter in Times, November 20, 1861, p. 7, complaining of conditions at Woolwich, part of a series of letters on the “Woolwich scandals” that followed in the wake of cadet vandalism to protest bad food and new restrictions on leisure time, reported in The Times October 21, 1861.

div.head: November 27, 1861. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., H.M.(!) H.S., Fr. Woode. ce matin.

McShirley greets the bairns and wad suggest J. Bull shaking his fist at Yankees fighting so near his windows (apropos of Southern frigate burning Northern ship in Channel) – but M.L. reads in evening paper account of the insult to our Flag by taking Southern Commoners out of the Trent. Must wait and see – if this be true England will ring with it. J.T. suggests J[ohn] B[ull] as sailor threatening, “I’ll blow your fleet out of the water” [Punch, 41 (7 December 1861): 229, “Look Out for Squalls”].
This was the Trent affair, in which Confederate envoys James Mason and John Slidell were forcibly removed from a Royal Navy ship, the RMS Trent, by a Union vessel, the USS San Jacinto, captained by Charles Wilkes. The account of the affair in the Times for November 28, 1861, opened with the remark, “It requires a strong effort of self-restraint to discuss with coolness the intelligence we publish to-day.” The resulting diplomatic crisis was resolved a few weeks later when U.S. Secretary of State William Seward released the envoys and disavowed Wilkes’s actions.

Discourse on Swedenborgianism by the Professor, showing wherein it is more sensible than our Churchism. J.L. a believer in conscience being a sufficient guide – “If I do wrong I feel ashamed and sorry – and my Conscience tells me that for my own happiness I had best do right.” But says H.S., Conscience is apt to get blunted – and prayer and something more is therefore needful. M.L. hates all churches. H.S. thinks all will be judged according to their Intellect, and opportunities of learning what is Right ... With H.M. to Master Cutler Matthews in Salisbury Square.
William Anthony Matthews (1813-1872), past Master Cutler of Sheffield, and juror at the International Exhibition of 1862. His home was at 46 Salisbury Square. (Journal of the Society of Arts, May 9, 1862, 409.) Sing song and propose Ponny’s health!

div.head: December 4, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S , C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., T. T., Thackeray.

War talk predominates. P.L. throwing cold water on the fire of indignation. Thinks people too prone to fight. A sentimental war, no extension of territory or other tangible reason – as in Russian War – for fighting. Our personal liberties not threatened. M.L. and all dissent. Thackeray says they might as well send over policeman to take Mr. Yancey out of Lady Palmerston’s drawing room.
William Lowndes Yancey (1814-1863), Confederate commissioner. British ships are British Soil – and if we submit, the Yankees will get the notion that British Bottoms are made to be kicked. Thinks the attitude of the Nation after having its a- kicked was nobly forbearant. Put the question to its lawyers, and pending their decision, remained calm. Says the Captain in charge of the Mails on board the Trent for his plucky outspeaking should be made a Post Captain. Has 5,000 dear relations (invested) in the States: but yet I, Makepeace, declare for War. Talked to Cabinet Minister on Monday – “Did you say ‘arse kicked’ to a Cabinet Minister?” – C.K.

L.C. M.L. suggests Bull Run No. 2 – Yankee running away from John Bull, preparing to gore him. J.B., “Look before you leap – do you see the size of my fist?” (H.S. subaud). P.L. protests against an inciting cut – (Where would go our prestige? And if we let them think they’ve licked us, they’ll learn to do so. People don’t enough think that by submission our National spirit may evaporate, and if we become a dependency of France we are subject to conscription and other French nuisances.) At last M.L. suggests “Waiting the Answer” – (applauded and approved. [ Punch, 41 (14 December 1861) 239, “Waiting for an Answer”]. Fighting cut always sends the sale up. This week 2000 above average).
Thackeray remembers his first flogging (not at Charterhouse) – hurt like h–, says Dicken [sic] looked the same in his time as in mine, and is as fresh still.

C.K. tells his story of going to sketch at Lady Pam’s, and Illustrated News fellow Foster (seen Foster? says flunkey to C.K.) at foot of stairs, taking notes of names of guests, saying in a pause “Delightful parties, these!”
Possibly Myles Birket Foster (1825-1899), painter and illustrator, who drew for both ILN and Punch.

Thackeray dined with Keeley at the “Caffres” Saturday week. Seemed like a party out of the Spectator, tried to stand champagne but couldn’t. Tells of his mother in law (?) giving him 6 sous claret, and now drinking wine of his at 7/6 a bottle. His daughters too are terribly matured in their taste. – Thackeray very chatty and jolly ce soir.

T.T. applauds “A Dinner for a Duke”; for which DuMaurier be thanked [Punch, 41 (7 December 1861): 227, caricature of the Duke of Cambridge, accompanying short article by Silver about the Duke’s dinner at Woolwich].

div.head: December 11, 1861. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., P.L., T.T., Thackeray.

Prince Albert ill with fever. “No cause for uneasiness” says the bulletin. “Nobody felt uneasy” says J.L. Who gives good name for the O’Donoghue, the O’Dono-Yahoo. Clubs call him the O’Doodledoo. Thackeray says he’s a mild spoken young man, wants to make himself a somebody, and so takes the road to a dirty reputation. “Expectaroon,” Thackeray calls The Octoroon. J.L. hopes somebody will pitch into Boucicault’s “morality” and impudence – altering last act, and calling it “composed by the public and edited by Mr. B[oucicault].” Would have done cut of Swell, “Aw – do you dance this waltz – aw – then I’ll take your chair,” but M.L. has seen it somewhere. Du M. didn’t tell me he’d told M.L. of it. “Cut off your little enjoyments,” says B., which of course W.M.T. twists into a meaning. J.L. coaling the Waits from his bedroom. Wonder his windows ain’t smashed. J.L. suggests “The Cattle Show at Evans’s” as a puff for Paddy Green.

How happy we were this day 40 years, says W.M.T., breakfast up at Charterhouse. Remembers J.L. at 6½ in his form – Master Bush just like him. Evergreen old Dicken appointed to a living at last – in Cambridgeshire, I think.

L.C. That suggested last week by Thackeray [Punch, 41 (21 December 1861) 249, “A Likely Story”]. General κμδόs for Britannia Waiting. Last week’s advanced 2000 at office, and this is an increase on that! 30,000 the average at 85 – and this about a third of the total sale, says Godfrey Evans.

Thackeray tells of Duke of Newcastle receiving visit from friend of Editor of the New York Herald offering Mrs. Editor as a bedfellow to the Prince – fact! Told Thackeray himself.
James Gordon Bennett (1795-1872), proprietor and editor of the New York Herald. The Herald and its editor were particularly unpopular in Britain at this time, owing to Bennett's vitriolic anglophobia and his urging that the Union annex Canada by force. See Duncan Andrew Campbell, English Public Opinion and the American Civil War (London: Royal Historical Society, 2003) 36-41
J.L. would like £l,000 and a country life – couldn’t do it, says Thackeray. P.L. never had £500 a year in his life!! Then H.S. has as high as the highest salary on PP.

T.T. says his poem suffered by his absence from town – had an extra foot put into a line. Yes, says J.L., leave it to the printers and they’re sure to put their foot in it. — T.T. reads poem by a young imitator of young Bulwer, Swinburn [sic]. First line proves it wouldn’t do for Punch or Cornhill: “I’m not quite right in my innards, Bill.” Several good lines and mixture of highpressure poetry and prosiest commonplace, as in the original: “Is there comfort in Holloway, Bill, and is there consolement in Parr?” – “What’s a poet? a bubble, a toy, a butterfly” etc. etc.
Algernon Charles Swinburne's “Last Words of a Seventh-Rate Poet,” which begins, “Bill, I feel far from quite right—if not further: already the pill / Seems, if I may say so, to bubble inside me,” was a parody of Owen Meredith's “Last Words of a Sensitive Second-Rate Poet.” The latter poem had appeared (under the title, “Last Words”) in the Cornhill for November, 1860 [(vol. 2, no. 11), 513-517]. Swinburne's poem did not appear in print until his Heptalogia of 1880. It seems likely from this passage that he, or someone acting on his behalf, had given Taylor a manuscript copy, perhaps as a possible submission for publication in Punch. A manuscript of the poem (entitled, “A Poet's Last Words. By O.M.”) was noted by T. J. Wise in his bibliography of Swinburne, and dated by him as 1861; my thanks to Terry Meyers for this information.

Dickens made £l0000 by his readings last year. Thackeray cleared about ½ that altogether. — “Leech, you’d better give a reading of the lines under your cuts,” says T.T. — Thackeray tells of his sketch at New Orleans. “Singular inscription in the English language – ‘Slaves for Sale!’”

P.L. applauds critique on Fechter (not thinking it H.S.’s who keeps his silence still). M.L. ditto, as we drive to the Gallery of Illustrations where he’s going to entertain the people with some prattle about London. “Think it a good subject?” – Yes.

J.L. at Lewis’s singing on Saturday – too full of smoke for him. “Looked jolly bored,” says Du Maurier. — That “Armstrong” whose mathematical bit C.K. praised is really Armitage – young lawyer whom Frith knows.
- x – James Gordon Bennett. “Cowhided again!” used to be frequent Sensation heading.

div.head: December 18, 1861. W[ednesday] No. 11. Almanack Dinner. Champagne.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., T.T., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B., H.M., Lucas. Thackeray.

Prince Albert’s death (on Saturday night at 11) the first topic. General regret.X People now begin to feel how much he has had to do and bear. No easy thing to be a Queen’s husband. And wherein can we find fault with him? Negative virtues are commendable in princes. ‘Tis difficult in high places to abstain from committing oneself. Perched on a pinnacle, one’s least fault is observable. – They say Lord Palmerston has felt the sudden loss deeply. And, says T.T., they who had to do with the Prince all speak well of him. If he was fond of money, as some hint, surely his error was on the right side – seeing what precedents of extravagance he had before him. If the patronage of princes be a good thing for art, the nation should give them a purse adequate. It is a disgrace to a people that its rulers should be poor. The Queen is the first Sovereign who has kept out of debt, and confined herself to her Income. – Still the Times was surely wrong in saying the Prince’s loss was the greatestcalamity that could befall us. The Queen’s death would have been greater, or if not (and that is possible) it was hardly loyal to deny it. – J.L. says the Yankees will call our national grief the “Almighty Dolour.” – Neither N nor Ph – as the Woman said, says Shirley, Neither Knave nor Fool.
- Sorry to see you in H-ll. But as you are there, do me a bit of a toast, T.T.

Almanack
The Punch Almanac for 1862, Punch 42 (January 1862) unpaginated, at beginning of volume. produced. J.L. says he received my “Sweep” just as he was puzzled for a corner.
Leech cartoon of chimney sweep, “The Use of Advertisement.” General toasting. B. proposes the Editor, and everybody proposes everybody (H.S. excepto – who would have had to propose the Compositors). “Greatest demand yet,” says B. in giving us the toast, “Success to the Almanack.”

L.C. S.B. suggests Magic Lantern cut – John Bull with Peace and War slides, “Which am I to show?” or, Dissolving View of the States,- M.L. Mason and Slide-ll, J.L. J.L. suggests Lincoln (on the Ark, à la Noah) Peace or War, Eagle or Dove. Accepted [Punch, 41 (28 December 1861): 259, “Columbia's Fix”]. General praise of ‘Britannia Waiting’ which has been generally KUDOed, Mr. Tenniel.
- Show you the coat in which I was pinked. Will he show us the breeches? (S.B. & T.T.)

- S.B. had a good time lecturing. 1,100 at Edinburgh. Applauded for owning himself a Whig-Tory-Radical. “How young you must be at it to recall the horrid incidents of the Saltimbanque career,” says Thackeray.

- Sala £100 from Smith & Elder for a trip to Genoa, says H.M. – “for the Genoawary Number.” Says W.M.T. – gets £2,500 per annum. Says H.M., “How does he spend it?” Married a barmaid – presentable person, says H.M.
Sala married Harriet Hollingsworth, his first wife, in 1859; she died in Melbourne on 31 December 1885 while accompanying him on a visit there.
- Echo of Dickens and Thackeray, says S.B. Has a diarrhoea of words, says P.L. “D – d clever fellow,” – but what has he done?

H.M., P.L., W.M.T. and H.S. left – talk about America. H.M. would submit to insult from blackguard rather than fight him. But a nation can’t, says Thackeray. If one’s a- is kicked, one can’t turn the other cheek.
X Instance the Sporting Butcher at the Mills and Deerfoot Race on Monday – Bless you, think of the Queen – she’s worse off than you.

div.head: December 25th, W[ednesday] being Xmas Day, no dinner.
January 1st [1862]
div.p: H.S. at Church St. (writing to Ipswich Journal about Seckford Charity).

div.head: January 8,1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., S.B., H.M., Thackeray.

Thackeray says, “This is good news, isn’t it?” — “What?” says H.S. “They’ve released Mason & Slidell.” ... Afterwards rather regrets they’ve had no licking — “d—d sh-ts.” Kissing Columbia under mistletoe should be Large Cut, says M.L. No, Columbia kissing John Bull’s bottom under mistletoe (J.L.). Made a dirt pie, now eat it (J.L.). Big lubberly boy knocked down and howling, “Don’t hit me” (S.B.). Britannia putting rod back into pickle (J.L.) – accepted [Punch, 42 (18 January 1862): 25, “Naughty Jonathan”].

S.B. tells of Charivari’s picture of beard erected in 3 stages. Excited at seeing Madame, Quelqun Abit, he went out to dinner, excessit, he drank too much, erupit, he catted, evasit, he said it was the salmon. – My first an imprecation, 2nd an excrement, whole a delicious sweet (W.M.T.). — Where do American apples come from? Anapolis (H.M.). H.M. talks of George Hodder kissed by lady after supper. “Nasty beast, put her tongue in my mouth!”
Henry Mayhew in Germany living on his £300 a year. Yates not to be trusted. Albert Smith left him £400 cancelled it soon before his death.

Talk of M.L.’s debût “About London” on Monday. Very nervous, feared the subject wouldn’t take. Letter from Stanfield, much pleased. Suggests alteration of Lord Mayor’s barge – too big and flat. H.S. said so.

Ponny and George Augustus [Sala] had a row. P kissed G.A.’s maidservant – “She didn’t object.” S.B. danced with Carlotta Grisi once – like waltzing with a whirlwind. Evans’ whiskers off – looks much better bare faced. M.L. abstains from wine and spirits still.

Thackeray and J.L. speak of Charterhouse morality – fresh young innocent voices singing b[aw]dy songs without knowing their intent. Are your apples ripe, are they fit for plucking? How’s your daughter Jane – Is she fit etc.

div.head: January 15, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., S.B., and H.M.
S.B. reads Lord John’s letter to Lyons:

“I told him (McAdams) I could dispense with compliments, if the matter were amicably arranged.” The aristocrat snubbing the snob. Should give Lord J[ohn] kudos for his conduct. J.L. suggests Punch as Admiral applauding Billy Taylor, Lord John also. Yankee hard up sitting on a stump (“stumped up,” says M.L.). The “famous American runner who outran the Constable.” – S.B. would like to compliment the French. L.N. saying to John Bull as policeman “Handn't we better stop this?” “Well, I’ve seen no fighting to speak of yet.” M.L. would wish to get away from Yankeedom —they’ve given up and there’s an end of it. So J.L. suggests a fine Oyster Season. Accepted. “Shelling out.” “Oyster and [illegible, looks like “Terniner”]” says P.L. “A good opening, says H.S. [Punch, 42 (25 January 1862): 35, “Law and Lunacy; or, A Glorious Oyster Season for the Lawyers”]
This refers to the W. F. Windham lunacy inquiry, which lasted 34 days, during which 144 witnesses were called. See Peter McCandless, “Liberty and Lunacy: The Victorians and Wrongful Confinement,” Journal of Social History 11:3 (Spring 1978), 380.

Miss Matthews has album, per H.M., signed, “Silence is golden, but speech has (H) Silver”: E. tells that Bob Orridge before marriage promised to kill a neighbour’s dog that howled and after marriage didn’t. Mem: to get dog killed before you give away your daughter. S.B. reads letter saying when Queen got to Osborne and saw some alterations the Prince had been making to surprise her she was terribly overcome.... Talk of Manning’s execution which J.L. saw, and of Calcraft saying of a hanging, “No Sir – I wasn’t altogether pleased with it.” S.B. reads imaginary paragraph about Mark’s lecture eliciting laughter by his story of a girl at Temple Bar saying to policeman, you may kiss my A, my C’s in the City.
S.B. and H.M. to finish at Matthews’. H.S. taught wisdom by Nov. 27, smokes a pipe with Jim Hughes.

div.head: January 22, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B.

Apropos of the dreadful Hartley Colliery accident (beam breaking), J.L. suggests “Ye Pit and Ye Boxes.” Miners getting coal, and cozy coffee, or dining, room men burning it. But there’s scarcely ground for a parallel – gentlemen are not in fault.
H.S. suggests that a lecturer giving imitations of popular M.P.’s would find it pay

L.C. Nothing at home – so P.L. suggests degeneration of the IOU Indian and J.L. adds the Harleston Stone fleet. Very good. How easy and simple and obvious a notion after it has been suggested. – Take off the dishcover and make a dishcovery, M.L. [Punch, 42 (1 February 1862): 45, “Retrogression (A Very Sad Picture)”].

J.L. tells of Dickens asking Bulwer, who had been talking an acre of dreamy smoky hazy bosh about Sein Loecas etc. if he’d ever personally seen anything preternatural – And Bulwer lifted up his hands and in his thick voice said “Never.”

P.L. been reading In Memoriam — doesn’t admire it like S.B. Calls it smoky, gloomy, cloudy, with a torchlight glare breaking thro’ now and then – but nothing hopeful or Christian. S.B. thinks Mrs. Browning has written one better poem than any one of Tennyson’s. – Talks of Jerrold’s sparkling drama talk. Wife: But cannot the Sword of Justice separate us. Husband: No, nor yet the Sword of Mercy.

div.head: January 29, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T {Mrs. T.T. lost baby, premature.}

Talk of Dilke’s baronetcy — Everyone to be knighted who ever spoke to the Prince, says S.B. J.L. cites Charles Landseer’s tale of his having a bottle of sherry at the Palace, with a curlpaper stuck in it. Says as a rule artists were snubbed by him and treated shabbily. T.T. denies this and sticks up for him – far better informed than most men, tried to act honourably and for the best. No joke being a Queen’s husband and a foreigner to boot. Cool to our Swells because they were haughty and proud to him. S.B. says she must have sorely tried him – obstinate and ignorant — fussed about a bill of fare as she would about a bill of rights. P[rince] A[lbert] came to her in his virginity and kept that purity throughout. P[rince] of W[ales] entered to a woman at the Curragh – Miss Clifford – since at Cambridge. Went in a funk to Lord Granville to know the consequence of a birth. Wanted to know beforehand if he should take his boots off. Plays croquet on Sunday.

S.B. tells of Rossini being sent for to Emperor’s box, apologises for frock coat – no need of etiquette between Sovereigns, says L[ouis] N[apoleon]. But query if such familiarity would do in England. Fancy the pennyaliners crowding to be noticed: “We observed Mr. Buggins in the Royal Box last evening.”

L.C. – L.N. as Cupid, Fould Mercury, teaching him arithmetic (T.T.). Cupid with moustache! says T.T. L.N. at accounts. I’ve thrown away my toys (soldiers) and now I’ll be a good boy and do my sums, T.T. & C.K. S.B. suggests combining French and Yankee (accepted). H.S. suggesting “division.” Who said that, asks S.B. [Punch, 42 (8 February 1862): 55, “Political Arithmetic”]
Pam says his work will be doubled by P[rince] A[lbert]’s death. All agree that Times too buttery.

M.L. should have a brass band to his lectures. Arce[deckne] said to Thackeray, “You must have a Pianner.”
Andrew Arcedeckne (1822-1871), a Garrick Club chum of Thackeray, who used him as the model for Harry Foker in Pendennis. This is the earliest record of an anecdote – usually rendered as “You should have had a pianner!” – which Arcedeckne himself frequently related after Thackeray's death and which appeared in print many years later in works by F. C. Burnand and Edmund Yates.

div.head: February 5, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Lucas, T.T., Thackeray. 13!

Lucas talks of “The Germ” lent him by C.K. Poetry (!) by Millais and the PRBs.
The Germ, a shilling monthly, was founded by Dante Gabriel Rossetti, his brother William, and Holman Hunt as a mouthpiece for the Pre-Raphelite Brotherhood. The first number appeared in January, 1850; the periodical closed after the fourth number in April. “Vivat Vagina” a motto for the Mottes, J.L. – Co somewhere talking of Ct., says W.M.T., “Has nobody a word to say for poor old A. hole?” — “I can do that which may become a man.” W.M.T. P[rince] A[lbert] laid a stone in nearly every town in England and yet kept eno’ to get 9 children. – H.S.
H.M. queries if a deadlock be opened by a skeleton key. J.L. going to a dance tonight at P.L.’s cousin’s. P.L. declines rather – don’t care for pretty girls: and don’t sit up till 3 for anyone.
Splendid pine from Pernambuco per S.B. “Do you recognize your daughter, Silver? “Pinus Silvae filia nobilis” – says Thackeray.

P.L. gets great laughter by his story of the peas, “passed thro’ me” — “best story I’ve heard these four years – how Swift would have enjoyed it,” says Thackeray.
Leigh repeated this story, evidently a favorite, on January 15, 1868, according to Silver’s entry for that date – an entry that, unfortunately, gives no more details than does this one.
L.C. Johnny Russell and Pam showing holiday task “American difficulty” to T.T. M.L. [ Punch, 42 (15 February 1862): 65, “The Holiday Task”]
J.L. amuses by telling how he solemnly reads a leader at breakfast, and his wife looks appalled and attentive. “Hush, Ada! Don’t you hear Papa is reading.”
Thackeray disturbed by organs – thought of a Sensation Roundabout. S.B. wrote a tale of horror and mystery for Ainsworth’s Magazine, the Explanation lost in MS.

div.head: February 12, 1862.
div.p: M.L., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., (bottom); P.L., H.M., T.T.

Talk of Sothern’s Lord Dundreary – even Leech laughed at him! and imitates him well. M.L. amused by his bepuzzlement and then, “Ah, that’s one of things nobody can understand,” “Brother Sam’s 2 years younger than me, then in 2 years time he’ll be as old as I am, and in two years after that he’ll, egad, he’ll be two years older than I am, how can that be?” “Letter written upside down – must be a lunatic to write upside down,” like Chas. Ibbetson, says J.L.
E. A. Sothern’s performance as Lord Dundreary was the main attraction of Tom Taylor’s Our American Cousin, as it had evolved under Laura Keene’s direction. The character’s dress and gestures owed much to Leech’s drawings of urban aristocratic “swells.”
J.L. thinks Julius Caesar good subject for Pantomime – Senate with big Roman noses. Would be funny to have a broad farce in classic dress — Boxsius et Coxsius.

Miss Gilbert clever not only at horsebreaking. M.L. and J.L. supped when she entertained a score of Swells and kept them all alive. Lord Sutherland a brainless ass to have enjoyed so pretty a horsebreaker.
Eliza Ann Gilbert (1835-1863), horse-trainer, was renowned for her horsemanship and for her brilliant conversation. In May of 1861 she was featured in a painting by Landseer entitled The Shrew Tamed which came to be known by the informal name, “The Pretty Horsebreaker. Annie Gilbert came to be thought of, perhaps unfairly, as part of a group of fashionable courtesans that included Catherine Walters (“Skittles”) and Agnes Willoughby. Thanks to Christopher Whittick and Julian Moore for sharing their researches into Gilbert's life. See also the account of her life and talk in Bailey's Magazine of Sports and Pasttimes, 7:321 (February 1864). — H.M. tells of Irishman abroad claiming to have written Barber’s Chair, met D.J. at H.M.’s after, and flattered him so that D.J. said, “That’s the pleasantest Paddy I’ve seen.” –Talk how D.J. barked his nose falling downstairs after Punch dinner, and H.M. put sticking plaster on and took him home and drank champagne till 4.

Talk of poor little Halliday – operation – P.L. discourseth learnedly on fistula. Very clear he is. Thackeray rather suffer than run risks before he’s done his work – sick of life. A good name his, for “Fun” – “Funch” – so close an imitation is it in type, etc. — J.L. hates it because it makes people tired of hunting subjects, etc., and the public don’t discriminate much.
Fun, a penny rival to Punch, first appeared on September 21,1861, under the editorship of H. J. Byron and Tom Hood, and would become Punch’s most serious competitor of the 1860s and early 1870s.

L.C. P.L. suggests Derby and Diz as foot pads stopping Pam. J.L. – as old gossips (good, says M.L.) [Punch, 42 (22 February 1862): 75, “Too Civil by Half”]. Shirley lecturing at Reigate. B. not well and E. engaged.
To New Inn and wrote “Our London Correspondent” for D.E. ([penciled below] David Eaton) “Bolton Examiner.”

div.head: February 19, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., T.T., Thackeray.

J.L. brings sketch by lady of Python hatching Bills. T.T. adds Pam & Dizzy looking on. S.B. and M.L. dissent at first, but accept. J.L. thinking it good, and T.T. backing him [Punch, 42 (1 March 1862): 85, “The Parliamentary Python” ].
Hopeful articles on the python and her eggs appeared in The Times of March 6 (p. 12) and 13 (p. 5), but the issue of 8 April (Times, p. 7) reported the sad news that the eggs had become septic and had to be removed.X

J.L. savage with Sala for telling a lie about J.L.’s sending for “more beer” at Brill’s when his boy was lying ill. “I’ll hand him to posterity if he meddles with me” – “make his friends ashamed of him.” S.B. defends him and says, “He’s said in print lots of kind things of you.” “But I don’t want his praise.” Thackeray thinks he’s getting out of the mire, but he can’t keep from drink yet.

Talk of Bill Jerrold.
William Blanchard Jerrold (1826-1884), journalist, son of Douglas Jerrold. Writes well and looks well, says Thackeray. (don’t agree to the latter.) but his plays have all been d—d. “Yes, he’s a d—d clever fellow,” says W.M.T., now I could never get my plays d—d.” But what has he done, and what has Sala done, says J.L. Oh, a journalist can’t point to his works, says S.B. Yes, Mozley can point to the Times. Mozley has been King of England for years J.L.
Thomas Mozley (1806-1893), Church of England clergyman and man of letters, began writing for the Times in 1844 and wrote leading articles for the paper steadily until 1886 – amounting, by his own estimation, to some 7000 articles. He was close to both the proprietor of the paper, John Walter III, and its editor, John Thadeus Delane. In later life he published a widely admired reminiscence about the Tractarian movement at Oxford with which he had been strongly associated in the 1840s.

Apropos de something, P.L. says, “3 shits in the wind” – and S.B. adds, “Dejeuner à la 4 shits.” Thackeray, too, says some quick things – his jokes come out most spontaneously. – Of D.J. they report how he snubbed Arcedeckne for talking about Shakespeare, “ass kicking dead lion with a silver hoof.” And S.B. quotes his saying to someone who was boasting how a Countess said, “Come in,” to him, – “Perhaps she took you for the waiter.” Whereat says J.T., “Why, I said that. The only joke I ever made.” D.J. always talking, Gil á Beckett chiefly silent: Fancy his widow marrying George Jones! Who’s G.J.? Jones of the Foreign Destitute, or the boy Jones, grown up.
Mary Anne à Beckett, widow of Gilbert Abbott à Beckett, married George Jones on February 15, 1862 at the Holy Trinity Church, Brompton. According to the gossip recorded in the entry for August 12, 1863, the couple soon separated. A mysterious and flamboyant figure, George Jones had been mercilessly satirized by Thackeray and Jerrold twenty years earlier, along with his patron, James Silk Buckingham, and the British and Foreign Institute with which they were both associated. See Richard Altick, Punch: The Lively Youth of a British Institution, 1841-1851 (Columbus: Ohio State University Press, 1997), 639-641.

S.B. speaks of how rosewatery the critics are – and how little the public cares for the puffs they emit. Witness the cracked up Ruy Bias of Glover, which only ran a fortnight. Says the Angel of Midnight is a bad piece – and here’s a chance for Punch to hit out – hard.
Accordingly, Silver attacked “Angel of Midnight” on the grounds of “extreme bad taste” in his “Our Dramatic Correspondent” column, Punch, 42 (1 March 1862): 87. Has been too mealy mouthed by half? Well, M.L. be thanked for it. Has not he subtracted the cayenne, and put in the meal? As we walk home, discuss this with M.L. who says, “I don’t agree with Shirley that Punch should be all pitch in and no praise. But I can’t hurt Webster, nor Robson now, because he’s served me well.” Well, so long as he’s satisfied, I may be content. — T.T. thinks that Du Maurier “not much use to us – drawings too liney” – whatever that may mean. But at least they’re not pur-liney, thinks H.S. M.L. asks me to do a bit about the Miners, who are aggrieved by J.L.’s sketches – and are good customers of Punch.
See “Punch to the Pitman,” Punch, 42 (8 March 1862): 99, headed by a cartoon showing a miner with his small son on his lap, both reading Punch. In Northumbrian dialect, the piece quotes the Athenaeum about the miners’ resentment of Leech’s cartoons showing them as savages. But J.L.’s cuts are at Staffordshire, not Newcastle.

Apropos of Our Dramatic Correspondent, I have to write Boucicault and Harrison this week – see their letters. Emma and Lettie being with me, I’ve used my privileges more than usual. The opera excepted, I hadn't written for anything until last October. But notices are advertisements, and a critic has a right to entrance, and need not feel under obligation for it. (M.L.’s last night, Saturday 22.)
X T.T. suggests Lord Ch. Westbury as Bishop Hatto eaten by the legal rats, for his Land Bill.

div.head: February 26, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., Lucas, and W.M.T.

“What a rum pudding,” says E. “Why’s it like a petticoat,” Says W.M.T. [symbol for “therefore”] “it’s a rumputin’.” S.B. tells of his seance with Foster the rapper, at De Bathe’s rooms.
Charles H. Foster (1838-1888), American medium, came to England in 1861 and over the next year presided at various séances, some of them attended by literary men like Thackeray and Dickens. The Times ran a somewhat credulous account of one of these on March 13, 1862. 8 sat round table, raps sounded in centre. Wrote names, 3, on slips. S.B. an imaginary Mary Cox, and her spirit answered – i.e., F[oster] said the spirit of M[ary] C[ox] is present – papers all in centre of table, but of course he peeped into one or two of them. M.L. shows how to detect names – S.B. says they each wrote a dozen names and thought of one especially and F[oster] tore off that one. M.L. notices that you write the name you thought of more glibly, and guessed it twice out of 3 with S.B. and J.T. – “Margaret” on F[oster]’s arm of course done by chemistry. Looks a humbug, says S.B. And clearly only a conjurer. P.L. jaws about it, as usual: and thinks exposure needful else people will doubt the miracles. S.B. believes there are little spirits about a foot high. As high as a gin bottle, says H.S. – J.L. believes in no rapper who won’t change clothes and turn his sleeves up. – Edwards frightened at the soirée. P.L. after losing wife, dined with J.L. at Star and Garter and coming home frightened old Mrs. Eaton by saying, “She’s gone. My wife has been sitting by me, but she’s stepped out of the carriage.”
M.L. tells of man falling asleep at Church — prayer book dropped – “Come in.”

M.L. dreamt a play once – got up and sketched it and got £100 and a violent cold. Got £30 for the song “Lovely Night” which was in it. C.K. often dreamt Punch sketch, and sometimes they turn up trumps. I’ve done ditto – and dreamt a whole number sometimes. Seen the big cut as plainly as possible. Dreamt last night that I saw Tenniel open Parliament, then we went out snipe shooting. Everyone’s a lunatic in his dreams, says Dickens.

Thackeray talks of how he went to Bristol as a boy with his father the General and his mother with her diamonds and they went gorgeously to the Play. And next time he went he was an actor himself! lecturing on the Georges.

J.L. tells of swell carriage coming to his door and and small printer’s boy rushing to open it! Fancy the disgust of Jeames. – M.L. afterwards tells that D.J. and and W.M.T. quarreled because T. said D.J. ate peas with his knife and therefore was not fit company for him. “Made up,” says J.T. “You see how far it was made up” – T. often saying a sharp word at him still. ( Snob Papers, peas)

L.C. The O’Mannikin (Thackeray christens him) as gorilla – no, as descendant of old Irish King says J.T. – challenging Sir Robert Peel, Pam with whip [Punch, 42 (8 March 1862): 95, “The O'Mannikin”]. Monkey come down from Pope’s organ, thinks H.S., and says S.B.: but this negatived.
On the simianization of the Irish to be found in political cartoons in Punch and other illustrated periodicals during this period, see L. Perry Curtis, Jr., Apes and Angels: The Irishman in Victorian Caricature (Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution Press, 1971; 2nd ed., revised,1996). An impressive overview of the subject can be found in Michael de Nie, The Eternal Paddy: Irish Identity and the British Press, 1798-1882 (Madison: University of Wisconsin press, 2004).

J.L. tells of his and J.T.’s and Lewis’s run with the Cambridgeshire on Friday – fine bright day, long run, fox took to water and the gallant hounds would scarce have got across, but for the men cheering them on. Sun setting at the time.

-X-X- J.L. piteous in his complaints of the organ men. Got up twice t’other night to send them away. “They’re killing me! The only way to get sleep is to get into a train and give the guard half a crown to keep the door locked. Silver laughs and Tenniel laughs – but it’s no joke indeed.”

div.head: March 5, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., Thackeray.

Tom Evans married yesterday at Charing near Ashford. Chas Wilks [sic], surgeon’s, daughter: Not pretty, but pleasant. Sets me thinking of our Irish friend, L.B., the white necked, whose Valentine I answered and with whom I ate my pancake yesterday as by Shrove Tuesday bound. S.B. and M.L. up from Birmingham today, – full of feasting and fancy work. The glass blowing to be seen. W.M.T. looking at “Funch” observes how they copy Leech his early efforts in feminine development. “Tis true tis titty, titty tis tis true.” “Tityre tu patula,” adds H.M.
From Virgil, First Eclogue, which begins, “Tityre, tu patulae”
This is the first trial of the New Ventilator, which seems to clear the smoke away well.

L.C. rather a hardstool – Education Question, S.B. suggests something about refusal of Grant to Ragged Schools. J.L. hates the Yankee word “ragged schools,” brands a boy for life. H.S. thinks national schools should suffice: teach the reputable poor before the disreputable. But houses are more wanted than grammars. No use bettering boys’ brains if you leave their houses like pig styes. —H.M. suggests Pope as the donkey being worshipped for the images and relics he carries. Good, says W.M.T., but won’t be understood. Try spiritualism, says H.M. How? Palmerston flying in the air as the Happy Medium, says J.L. Makes him out a humbug, says H.S. L[ouis] N[apoleon] as medium and Pope in chair: “I could move that old party and his chair when I like.” J.L. Accepted [Punch, 42 (15 March 1862): 105, “The Great French Medium”].

At the Bedford door where we (J.T., M.L., & H.S.) usually part, M.L. says he didn’t use my last drama letter because he hadn't room, says the public would think me finding fault without assigning reasons: and I’ve once or twice lately been sneering at C.G. Fact is, Mr. L[emon], Benedict’s a friend of S.B.’s and you know it.
Sir Julius Benedict (1804-1885), composer. His most popular opera, “The Lily of Killarney,” based on The Colleen Bawn, made its debut at Covent Garden in February, 1862. It’s hard to be savage with such a corrector of the press, cutting out whatever’s cutting. Said Horace the other day, “Your letters are too favorable,” What the public wants are criticisms, not advertisements. Well, is it my fault you don’t get ‘em? And in this same letter about C.G., I pitched into the butterers much more than into Benedict.X

J.L. thinks Mormonism not objectionable in point of the plurality of wives. Says Thackeray, Aha, I dine with you sometimes and can tell your horrid thought, I’ll be your haunting demon, accept this bill, etc., etc. S.B. quotes imaginary police case, about the extortion to ensue.
E. no grandchild yet, will offer a prize for the first. Query: if smoking prevent poking?

Subscriptions coming in so thickly for the [Hartley] Colliers, W.M.T. says people have caught the Colliery Morbus.
The Hartley Colliery disaster in Northumberland on January 16, 1862, killed 204 miners. S.B. quotes from Shabby Genteel Story the saying that somebody spoke so satirically that nobody could understand him. Bless you, Brooks! says Thackeray.
X Letter at No. 1 tomorrow asking me to leave off the letter while Essence goes on.

div.head: March 12, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., (Late) T.T., Thack.

Thackeray leaves the Cornhill! [George] Smith “a noble generous fellow,” says he, – But wished to have a Co-Editor, and not a Sub. Fact is, T. don’t do Editor’s work – which is to read and judge, not to write. S.B. dilates on the difficulty of reading MSS and fairly judging them.
On Thackeray’s reasons for resigning the editorship of the Cornhill, see Gordon Ray, Thackeray: The Age of Wisdom, 1847-1863 (New York: McGraw-Hill, 1958), 320-321, which quotes this passage.

Thackeray has built his house, costing £5000 out of his 2 years’ savings, nearly. P.L. tries to make him hark back, only a slight difference and might be adjusted. – Thackeray says Lucas pitched into him for trying to get the Once a Week artists to work for him. C.K. refused. Thackeray thinks Free Trade is the right policy in literature and art. Man takes his work where he’s best paid for it. Thackeray likes his Lovel the Widower, and [George] Smith don’t.
Lovel the Widower ran in the Cornhill from the first number, January 1860, to June, 1860. Acted it at Kensington t’other night — his daughter Minnie good, and Morgan John O’C. as footman.

Lucas son of Bristol wholesale confectioner – accounts for his love of puddings, M.L. A very honest sterling editor, says E., – always has the interests of his magazine at heart. – M.L. thinks a Magazine should have a regular salaried staff of writers, and room for occasional outsiders. This would secure an evenness of quality. — Don’t want a genius at £3000 a year. A good sensible ready headed man at £500 better.
Owing to a copyediting error by the author, this amount is mis-transcribed as £50 in Leary, Punch Brotherhood, 150. The genius don’t read other articles than his own – or if he finds a good one is apt to be jealous. Thackeray’s name established the success of the Cornhill at first. He says Framley Parsonage did.
Framley Parsonage appeared in the Cornhill between January, 1860, and April, 1861. E. right in preferring Macmillan as a lasting success. Doyle’s Sketches had been mostly done for Smith some years since and called “Views of Party Life” or some such name.

Will a new Mag. be started? S.B. suggests “The Tomahawk,” and as a motto, “We’ll axe our way.”
Five years later, in 1867, the Tomahawk, a twopenny satirical weekly, made its debut as a rival to Punch. The magazine ceased publication in 1870. – The Saturday Reviler fallen off since they left the vinegar trade and took to selling treacle.
John Bright used the phrase “Saturday Reviler” in a speech in Liverpool in December, 1861, in which he referred to the “continual slanders vomited forth weekly” in the Saturday Review. “Financial Reform Soiree at Liverpool,” Morning Post, December 2, 1861, p. 5.

S.B. quotes a hit at Ruskin (in Blackwood’s, I think) where they said he’d make a safe tutor in a ladies’ school. H.S. don’t think it fair hitting a man in his privates. And W.M.T. concurs. Foul blow. S.B. says when Ruskin wrote for the Cornhill, it was chiefly noted for Philip and the Eunuch.
No such article in Blackwood's has been traced. Ruskin's Unto This Last appeared in the Cornhill as four monthly essays from August to November, 1860, and was savagely attacked in the metropolitan press; published in book form in 1862, these essays on political economy would later prove to be vastly influential..

E. mentions case of lady who had her bladder taken out and sewn up. And W.M.T. improvises: There was a poor lady grown sadder, By having disease of the bladder. They put her to bed and sewed it with thread, And then the Chirurgeon had her! – Only fancy the brutal chirurgeon taking a mean advantage of her helplessness.

J.L. and P.L. Prince Albert and his toadies again P.L. thinks him a respectable, well-informed man. T.T. says, you much underrate him. We owe much of our prosperity for these score of years to his good judgment. And his loss is much felt. J.L. suggests view of England covered with Obelisks —obelisk a little spit, or lickspittle. Monolith one stone — whereas P.A.’s great claim was his having two.
M.L. has Exhibition ticket. Shall we? – Ugly building all agree. Regular Guy Fawkes place.

L.C. Education the only question. But how touch it? J.L. suggests Vessel of State becalmed [Punch, 42 (22 March 1862): 115, “A Dead Calm”]. T.T. thinks you might show sterns of both ships, Government and Opposition, Dizzy and Pam leaning over.

M.L. says when he first came to B & E, John Forster ruled the roast – and brought article from Fonblanque which M.L. altered, thinking it libellous. J.F. indignant, brought another on Lord Brougham – worse – M.L. refused it, and Fonblanque wrote no more.
Albany Fonblanque (1793-1872) was the influential proprietor and editor of the Examiner when Lemon came to Punch in 1841. John Forster (1812-1876), drama critic and literary editor for the radical weekly, succeeded him as editor in 1847. As Dickens’s friend and agent, Forster had come to know Bradbury and Evans when they were printers, and then publishers, for the novelist. After Dickens’s split with the firm, Forster represented him in the shuttering and sale of Household Words. J.F. a snob – never at ease among gentlemen, says J.L. Jupiter Tonans. J.L. would like to draw him beside butcher’s block crying, Buy buy! At Newcastle he slunk into far corner of bus and hid himself. Everywhere else had been blatant. M.L. tells the old stories of F’s — “Dickens, look at my legs” — drops coursing down nose – gruel at the wing to clear his voice. D.J.’s “Stop him, he’ll be off to Mrs. Macready,” etc., etc. Thackeray says J.F. cuts him – and he can’t be savage, because it was J.F. who brought Dr. Elliotson to him and saved his life.
While writing Pendennis, Thackeray fell ill with a fever and was treated by Dr. John Eliotson (1791-1868), to whom he dedicated the completed novel. Lady Russell told Thackeray she liked Mr. Forster — and Lord John thought his books very clever.

Pitch into the Exeter Hall narrow exits, says S.B. There’ll be some few hundreds killed there some day. Sound an alarm of fire and it’s all up with the women.
[Henry Silver], Punch, 42 (5 April 1862): 142, “A Hit at Exeter Hall.”
