S.B. says he never wrote an Ode before the one performed last night at the St. James’ Hall by the Wandering Minstrels — Swell amateurs — and took him a whole afternoon. Begins by describing miners at a Siege – and then passes to miners in a Coalpit. Thackeray envies him his ready pen. Says it takes him 2 days to think of a subject for a Roundabout, and one day to write it. Writes best out of his house. – anywhere except at home.

div.head: March 19, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T., WMT.
[In tiny letters to left of initials] (after 1st sight inside Ex. Building in D.E. Beacon only thing fixed, few cases in France. Scaffolding still in Domes.)

Forster the great John mistaken for Foster the Medium! Damnation impudence! J.L. agrees with me that The Times should have slashed the séance, not merely spoken of it chaffingly.
“A Sitting with Mr. Forster,” Times, March 13, 1862, p. 6, and leader March 15, p. 11. See Leech cartoon, “A Spirit Rapping Seance!” Punch, 42 (29 March 1862): 130, featuring “Mr. Foxer (a Medium).” Mrs. Milner Gibson tells her boy to go and play with his dead brother!S.B. says why not let silly women have foolish amusements? But Spiritualism smacks of blasphemy, and may weaken children’s minds, as well as their weak parents’. Besides, if we prosecute gipsies for telling fortunes, why suffer spirit rappers to get a living by pretended intercourse with an unseen world.

L.C. The row in the Lords between Thesiger and Bethel, Lord Chelmsford and Lord Chancellor Westbury. Lord Derby good in saying Bethel is fond of saying savage things in a silvery voice. Shirley gives an imitation: “If your honour were possessed of sufficient power of mind to grasp the knowledge of facts, and then by some unwonted operation of nature were suddenly to be endowed with reasoning enough to draw a sensible conclusion from them.” – T.T. says B[ethel] twice struck in Court – led to two disbarments. Too insolent for the Lords. P.L. thinks all this shows him a great man, nevertheless. – S.B. suggests the Westminster Cockpit. J.L. amends it to Dogfight: Lord Russell saying, “Bite his tail.” [ Punch, 42 (29 March 1862): 125, “Canine at the Westminster Pit”]

M.L. at Huddersfield last night, heard foul tales of Boucicault’s blackguardism in not paying tailors’ debt, etc., now he has the money. At a weekly settlement for The Colleen there was a sixpence to be divided between him and Webster, so Boucicault said, “Then I’ll take a cigar and make all square.”
M.L. says, when any striking piece comes out, notice it at once. So I needn’t stop the letters.
First look inside the Exhibition building today. A Red Sea mark the only thing fixed yet. Only 36 days to the opening – how can it be finished. Scaffolding not out of domes yet.

J.L. asks who did the Pitman’s Plaint and applauds it – as doth P.L. and J.T. and S.B., who says, however, that such things should be seldom done as they only interest a few readers.
“A Plaint by a Pitman,” Punch, 42 (22 March 1862): 113.

div.head: March 26, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: (Fr. Woode ce matin).

George Peabody’s munificence, announced in The Times today. £150,000 – 2 years’ income!
George Peabody, an American merchant active in London for twenty-five years, gave £150,000 for housing for the deserving poor. See Times for March 26, 1862, pp. 9, 11. By George! My first comes out of my second and my whole’s a brick says S.B.
But it won’t do for a cut, M.L. & P.L. Both agree however it must be prominently noticed.

J.L. tells of the 2nd Life Guards at Windsor, almost in mutiny — guest insulted. Oh, say the officers, you should hear how the sentry speaks to us! J.L. proposes servant girl and soldier — “You must have seen a deal of Service to be so proud!” [Punch, 42 (5 April 1862): 136, “A Bit of Household Stuff”]
L.C. S.B. suggests Oberon (Lincoln) and Titania (Virginia) apropos of slave offer. Good! [ Punch, 42 (5 April 1862): 137, “Oberon and Titania”]

M.L. back from Wakefield, bad audience, tells of miner punishing wife – “I just turn my a. to her for 3 nights.” Another buying Shakespeare along with a lot of keepsakes – “When he writes some more, let me have it.”

J.L. proposes Lincoln as Shoeblack to the Nigger, “Clean your books Sar.” Not good. — A very wet day Sunday and has been showery for a week. So S.B. recommends the Soup à la Rain, as being the most seasonable. — Any bad joke that’s made, “Send it to Fun.”

M.L. and S.B. both Freemasons, S.B. a past Master. Agree it has never been of use to them. J.L. very chatty. Asks me to see his little ones on Sunday (but I’m booked for Deal). Who’ve had the hooping cough, mildly. Little girl quick at figures and boy slow. J.L.’s dodge for multiplying by 9 – the 10’s one less than the number, you multiply, and and then add 10, less that number. — Tells of foxhunter taking a horse over a gate he was defied to do – asks in riding home friend to put hat on: “I broke my collar bone at that jump, but I wouldn’t tell those fellows.”
D. Jerrold said of someone lecturing: “Oh, yes, he’ll get through – like a cat through a skylight.”

Said of C. Kean (who was testimonialed on Saturday): “He makes by Eton what his father lost by drinking.” Said of some one eating calf’s tail soup, “Extremes meet.” M.L. tells of his daughter saying, “Let me go into drawing room” to her sister – “I’ve as much parlour blood in me as you.”

div.head: April 2, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., Lucas.

M.L. tells of Boston man robbing London hell and riding pony into haystack where it was covered and concealed... Also of corpse set up by Communion table as dummy for whist. Lucas suggests for a Christmas tale the story of 2 boys, one careful in his eating and the other not, and how they grew up to be good and bad respectively. The one dined as a man should, thoughtfully – the other rushed in the dining room and snatched a hasty steak and so suffered indigestion and lost his temper and his talent, his happiness and health.

C. at his first public dinner on Saturday – the Artists’ Benevolent – Dickens in the chair. Yates said he felt much the same as the sentry on duty at the R[oyal] A[cademy] would feel if called on to return thanks for the R.A. — C.K. thought this a good impromptu, but was disgusted to learn it was fait à loisir. H.M. says Sala used it years ago ... And these are your young wits, says M.L.

L.C. The Ironship Question, clearly, says P.L. Revive that Pocket Book notion of Jack in armour, says M.L. And asks H.S. to do a Dibdin for it [ Punch, 42 (12 April 1862): 147, “The 'British Tar' of the Future”]. S.B. at Brighton finishing his book (what book?)
Shirley Brooks, The Silver Cord: A Story (London, Bradbury and Evans, 1862)., suggests by letter Vulcan chaffing Neptune which is voted good. Also something about Education which I forget, nil mirabile it was. Not easy to make that Education business clear to the public – testing by results is the gist of the New Code.

J.T. at the Gallery of Illustration on Monday when Tom Taylor’s “Family Legend” did not come out — the sun and moon not sufficiently rehearsed. J.T. says Tom Reed acts like an amateur, jerkily, not smoothly like Parry. M.L. amused at the little jealousies of the trio — says Mrs. Reed used to speak too fast, much improved by Macready. – Tells of his boarding Tom’s yacht and hoisting empty bottle as signal to the shore for beer. Also of his sailing a match in white ducks and having to shift ballast and dirtying his breeches. – J.L. and J.T. both can’t come to the Agnew picture dinner on Saturday – hope the portraits won’t go forth as Punch’s selection. – M.L. savage at the whole affair and P.L. fears the men will be called on to make speeches.

div.head: April 9, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champagne.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B. (After 2nd sight at Exhibition – Chem. Domes, clear, place filled!)

S.B. arrives after the fish, from Brighton — rather in a fluster and a bluster. B. blows him up for not coming to the Portrait dinner at Freemason’s on Saturday and S.B. anathematizes Maxwell for the short notice – seems they were hunting Paxton for Chairman. B. says he was all right next day – went to Studios. “Then you must have been very drunk,” says J.T. State of excitement for the testiclemonials, S.B.

B. tells of his glancing under bonnets after his honeymoon and answering wife – “My dear, I was looking to see if I could find a prettier face than yours, and I can’t.” Artful old file! He and Paxton whales for Champagne and crinoline.
J.L. thinks pittites laugh at Lord Dundreary because they like to see Swells ridiculed. Swell chalking shirtfront at Garrick to hide winestain.

J.L. tells of old Parry the huntingman saying of disagreeable parson: “If I were his Bishop I should draft him.” – Spoke of a fat woman as “17 couples and a half.” ... Contempt for Louis Napoleon, “Shouldn’t like to have him as my Whip.”

J.L. savage at the poor being bullied into subscribing for the Prince’s Obelisk: or hobbylisk. W.M.T. got a letter from Somebody at Osborne begging him to subscribe. Sickening!
The Lord Mayor of London, William Cubitt, began a public subscription for a proposed memorial obelisk to the Prince. The obelisk idea was abandoned, and in May 1862 a committee of architects solicited designs for what would eventually become the Albert Memorial, designed by Gilbert Scott.

Talking of the Budget, S.B. says the reduction of the Card Tax from 1/- to 3d. is the only real reduction. J.L. proposes 4 swells at whist in the midst of all club luxuries, thankful for the boon! real blessing.

L.C. S.B. proposes Gladstone making a house of cards. But all agree that the Iron Ships question is the one. So take his Vulcan and Neptune notion of last week, which J.L. modifies into Sea nymphs arming Neptune as John Bull [Punch, 42 (19 April 1862): 157, “Vulcan Arming Neptune”] P.L. proposes shoeing the Sea horses, but negatived. M.L. suggests Brittania in Crinoline — but this repeats last week’s “Jack in Iron.”
J.L. disapproves of Frith’s Derby Day. Not a bit like life. Swell in black cloth trowsers! – Says a man should like horses to paint them.

J.L. likes quartettes stringed – and not Hallelujah repeating choruses. Quotes small boy singing, “My sister Mary coming down the airey Cocked up her leg and showed something ‘airy.” And S.B. adds, “Jim Crow’s Sister had a Saveloy, 9 months after had a little boy.” Juvenile precocity.

M.L. tells of Ingelow at Boston his old [illegible, looks like “Brides” with a small “k” above] given him as fodder.
Possibly painter George Kilgour Ingelow, brother of the poet and novelist Jean Ingelow, and an old friend of Charles Keene. Good subject for a sketch, says J.T. Also of his grandfather attending a singlestick match and, in a sailor combatant, recognizing his brother, Tom, who ran away to sea. Gave him £5 and never saw him again. M.L.’s father stopped by highwayman, and recognised and let go.

div.head: April 17th. [Thursday]. No. 11. 1862.
div.p: H.S. absent — goes to Woodbridge with Transfer for the Doctor.

div.head: April 23, 1862. W[ednesday]. N. 11.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., and T.T.

T.T. stiff in the thighs from his equestrianism on Monday (Easter) at the Brighton Review. Says the faults were all of officers — marched men uphill without breathing.
See cartoon in Punch, 42 (3 May 1862): 182, showing officers at Brighton Review making their exhausted men climb a hill. C.K. tells of young swell looking into first class carriage and saying, “Full of Serjeants and that sort of people.”
J.L. tells of Irish gamekeeper seeing swell gargle his throat, say, “Arrah, he tak the whiskey and then spit out the water.”
M.L.’s daughter married on Tuesday next – her health drunk.

Shakespeare’s birthday — so S.B. and T.T. have a Shakespeare talk. S.B. contending that Shakespeare’s low humour detracts from the sublimity of his Tragedy: e.g., the gravediggers. T.T. says no – if gravediggers spoke like witty gentlemen, it might. But their natural dullness serves as a relief.

S.B. versus Costa for not conducting Bennett. Lauds the article on Boucicault this week – thinks it mine – but it is Horace Mayhew’s.
“A Sensation Police Case,” Punch, 42 (26 April 1862): 170. The Punch ledgers attribute this article to Percival Leigh.
“He spoke, and with a rousing f—, Let Wentworth Dilke be made a Bart.” S.B.
L.C. J.L. suggests Peace on Armstrong Gun [Punch, 42 (3 May 1862): 177, “Peace”]

div.head: May 1, 1862. T[hursday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T. Champagne.

After the opening of the International [Exhibition]. M.L. there. Girls on a day[?] to see the sight. Saw Delane, Dizzy, and John Lawrence together. C.K. says Pam like Old Un in back of head. Pam’s mouth open listen-ing. Saw cur kicked all along procession – and then seek refuge in The Church, by Bp. of London.

T.T. suggests Britannia’s May Day – all nations dancing round her and offering her presents. H.M. “Exhibition of Industry” – our Idle Parliament. – S.B., J.L.’s old picture of man giving wife present after a few years – not so pretty as last. T.T. amends his notion to John Bull bringing present, and after a doubt about the title, “Enquire Within” says P.L. Look inside — it will grow — etc., hardstool rather [ Punch, 42 (10 May 1862): 187, “The May-Day Present”].
All agree in thinking the building ugly – and ≠ 51. But the things good.

Tennyson’s poem (“reasonable rubbish,” says Joe Needham) – curious misprints of Parts for “arts divine” – p. of piano – lucky it wasn’t forte.
Smith note: Tennyson’s “Ode sung at the Opening of the International Exhibition” was published with music by W.S. Bennett on April 12th and printed in the Times, with errors, on April 24th, 1862. (The Poems of Tennyson. Ed. Christopher S. Ricks. London: Longmans, 1969, pp. 1126-27.)

div.head: May 7, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. from Woodbridge today – out of spirits. Scarce spoke at Dinner and went to sleep at the Phil. Concert after. Clock at Exhibition – “The works are in the Hand” (of the Lord) – worked by Kohinoor, says S.B.

J.L. had a fight with organ today, backed by a Jew. “I’ll summon you for a nuisance as sure as your name’s Moses.” – T.T. was offered to do Critique on Thornbury’s Life of Turner for Quarterly, Times and Edinburgh, but declined. Condemns it. Talks of the Palace of Puffs – and the Crowded Nave – suggests International Difficulty, how to clear away the (Knaves) obstructions, e.g. Pope – Austria – etc., amends it to unpacking Pope. Accepted [Punch, 42 (17 May 1862): 197, “An 'International Difficulty' (From Rome)” ]. S.B. suggests the weaver – cotton question. While you M.P.’s talk of me, I starve. Backward state of the foreign Courts (T.T.) – Wondrous how T.T. gets through all his work – has all the Exhibition pictures to do.

div.head: May 7, 14, 21, and 28, 1862.
div.p: [Outlined in black, in a hand-drawn box:]
Hiatus Valde Deplendus.

In memoriam J.S. .... Ob. May 25. S.
Henry Silver’s brother, John Silver, of Woodbridge, died on May 25, 1862. Constance Smith translates the quotation as “A chasm very much to be lamented,” noting that this is “a phrase used often in editions of Greek and Roman classics to indicate a loss due to the ravaging of time.”

div.head: June 5, Th[ursday]. [1862] No. 11.
div.p: B., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T.
A silent handshake of sympathy.

Hot Derby Day yesterday (H.S. at Ex[hibition]) – more fights than ever. Fighting, getting drunk, and throwing stones the chief pleasures, says P.L. – who suggests L.C. apropos of Walpole’s retreat last night on the National Expenditure question. “Please, Sir, it wasn’t me.” [ Punch, 42 (14 June 1862): 237, “Dr. Birch and His Young Friends”]

 [drawing of pointing hand] Leech’s Girlery opened on Monday: toasted in a bumper, “Success to Leech’s Girls.”
See “Mr. Leech’s Sketches in Oil,” Times, June 2, 1862, p. 5, which noted, “Mr. Leech surveys society from the gentleman’s point of view. When Jerrold wrote he took the other side… We trace, too, in his works a prejudice against the Hebrew nation.” The exhibit was held at the Egyptian Hall.

div.head: June 11, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: S.B., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., & H.M.
S.B. tells of Palgrave Simpson getting out of cab a la Frenchman and giving 1/6. – “Hullo, this won’t do, Mossoo.” – “Vat is it – gif him to me – there, that’s your fare (1/-) you d— rascal.”

L.C. P.L. suggests Pope and Japanese Martyrs. M.L.: “The Real Japanese Martyrs,” i.e., Ambassadors – after all their sightseeing.” – S.B.: Yankee and Louis Napoleon. Accepted [Punch, 42 (21 June 1862): 247, “Joanathan's Programme, Or a Bit of Brag”].

J.L. from Brighton – invaded on Whit Monday by Excursionists — all ½ drunk, bathing babies, screaming. P.L. suggests Swell Missionaries to accompany excursions and teach them to enjoy themselves. ... J.L. says, the fresh air don’t agree with them, used as they are to bad.

“Hullo, my 3 translators,” said Archie to Chas. Dance and Simpson and another. “You’re looking very well, all of you,” to smoking room, generally.
“Archie” was the nickname of Andrew Arcedeckne (pronounced “archdeacon”), a Garrick Club mainstay. A small, rotund, eccentric man and a former schoolfellow of Thackeray's, he enjoyed “taking it out of” the great man, whom he addressed as “Thack.” Charles Dance and Palgrave Simpson were also members of the Thackeray circle at the Garrick. See entry for January 22, 1862. A sad little man at heart, says J.L. — And what wretched tales one hears of Actors and their wives.

J.L. (some while since) suggested to J.T., “Pasttimes of Old England,” — or England in the Good Old Times – Paterfamilias laying down a new carpet — i.e. strewing rushes — Going to bed up a windy ladder — cold in head. — Children going to see a Burning of a heretick, etc., etc. A good idea. – J.L.’s Girlery attracts 400 daily.
Leech’s “Sketches in Oil” – enlarged versions of his cartoons, painted over in oils – debuted to great success at the Egyptian Hall in Picadilly in June. The original Times notice was lukewarm, but the more favorable notice in the Times of June 21 was written by Thackeray.

div.head: June 18, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: B., H.S., (Fr. Lowestoft ce matin), C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M.

Quick dinner. Talk of music. S.B. starting it by asking if H.S. going to Roberto tomorrow. P.L. feels refreshed by Beethoven and Mozart – intellectual music. H.M. says Massol the singer [crossed out] a great beast — speech at Halevy dinner. j’ai passé trois heures ce matin avec une dame aristocratique et je la gamarouchai trois temps. Enfin, je suis un peu fatigue.
L.C.: P.L. suggests Pope as fish fag. Accepted [ Punch, 42 (1862): 257, “The Professor of Allocution”]. Billingsgate. C.K. suggests Gampish Latin in her speech.

S.B. tells of swell among the Verbena Villas etc. of St. John’s Wood calling his “Drab hut” – the Motted Grange, a good name says J.T. – I’ve eaten asparagus. What insect does the odour of the P. resemble. The Centipede. S.B. (impromptu).

div.head: June 25, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. absent – at Crystal Palace. Handel Festival – Couldn’t get away from Solomon in all his glory – of music.

div.head: July 2, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., S.B., H.M., & Thackeray.

P.L. at Southampton — in great excitement on Saturday because his “little boy” didn’t come when appointed – had been disappointed too in being prevented going to the Handel Festival.
See Punch, 43 (5 July 1862): 7, “Our (Anything But) Critic at the Handel Festival”
Thackeray threw over Mrs. — to dine with Lord John, and now Lord J. throws him over, and so he comes to peas aller and eats his peas with us.

L.C. rather a [greek letters ?] stool – follow up Thames Embankment says M.L., but J.L. suggests Punch greeting the Princess Alice on her wedding yesterday and S.B. improves by suggesting Mr. P[unch] throwing flowers in her path, “Hope you’ll be ‘at home’ in England.” [Punch, 43 (12 July 1862): 15, “Au Revoir!”] H.M. thinks this mawkish and suggests North and South meeting on the bridge of “Union” which is breaking and, like the goats, one lying down for the other to cross. Also suggests for small cut Boucicault and Webster’s man both taking headers and knocking heads together.

J.L. imitates D. Jerrold at Rose Cottage throwing hair back and sprinkling salt with gusto over gooseberry tart! – Suggests cut of the Exhibition Medal-giving: Sir Wentworth Bilke and Mr. and Mrs. Unfairbairn the f. prize for Blundering – Punch receiving prize is thought too stale. C.K. suggests Prince and Princess on pillion and Punch drinking a stirrup cup to their health.
S.B. not so moved by Handel at C[rystal] P[alace] as at Ex[hibition] Hall or Birmingham. Splendid sight, but music swallowed up by naves which he says should be covered in Punch.

div.head: July 9, 1862. W[ednesday]. Thackeray’s. Palace Green.
div.p: W.M.T., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., E., S.B., H.M.; Jeune homme, ami de la maison, Lucas, T.T.

First dinner at new house. Turtle. H.S. handing plate for second helping. – T. waits for waiter – All Souls fellows see how a novice cuts cherry pie, if he puts stones in his mouth he is considered ineligible. – pickled salmon and turbot cold sirloin and hot venison pastry, ducklings and peas, savoury jelly and sweet. Dry champagne and first chop claret – “Want some more cl’rt,” says E.

Lucas been to Baden, etc. – play in Paris – La semaine à Londres. Frenchmen going to Exhibition in fog, holding each others’ coattails. Exhibition a mixture of bazaar and zoological gardens. Sleep 2 in a bed and pay sovereign apiece. Climax to misery un diner Anglais. Whole house roared at the idea of an English dinner. .. La course at Epsom, jockeys sitting in Duchesses’ laps, and presented with flowers and champagne. – “Will any gentleman oblige me with the French for bl— foreigner?”
– T.T. tells of Millais explaining who the statues were outside the Grosvenor Hotel – street boy adding to the celebrities “Lord Dundreary.”

Spoons! – especially that Dutch one, chain on leg, “in the year 14– I went thus clad.” Thackeray bought it for 4 at the Hague, and saw one like it in the Strand marked £12. .. Gilt, foliaged mirror frame, £30 – very handsome. Fine, large room, [“antique”?] and queer old pictures. Dutch fighting piece – portraits etc., “All made out of the inkstand” – Verily all is not Vanity, Mr. Vanity Fair. There’s something more substantial. Thackeray says when he married he and his wife looked at house by Brunswick Square and found it too dear – £80.

Deus ex machina? Horace, says S.B., and so does H.S. Can’t be The An because the mā is long. We’re thinking of Nec deus intersit.
Constance Smith translates as, “Not even a god would intervene.”

S.B. at Coronership hustings today. Declaration of poll for Dr. Lankester.
Lankester was elected coroner for Middlesex; see Times, July 8, 1862, p. 7. Mob grumbling at delay. “They’re eating sandwiches — why don’t they come to business.” Well, says policeman, “eating sandwiches ain’t bad business.”

M.L. thinks the Pam and Cobden affair the subject for L.C. Cobden squinting into gun and Pam as beadle. S.B. amends to rifle, “Don’t meddle with what you don’t understand.” Thackeray suggests Cobden as monkey — negatived. And finally original notion accepted. Altered afterwards to Sentinel. [ Punch, 43 (19 July 1862): 25, “The Old Sentinel”]
A letter from Shirley Brooks to Percival Leigh mentioning this dinner is one of a series of such letters transcribed by Silver in blank pages of the diary with the explanation, “Lent me by George Somes Layard [Brooks’s biographer] Sep./’06.” Above this letter’s transcription, Silver noted, “Confirming my account of the Dinner at Palace Green, July 9, 1862.” Brooks had written to Leigh: “W.M.T. gave us a very nice dinner, for your comfort be it mentioned: turtle, venison pasty, salmon cold, turbot hot, aspic and all the rest of it: streaming claret and nine fancy weeds. He has fine large rooms. I think we were a little ‘melancholy and gentleman-like’, and we invented a Cut for the disparagement of the vulgarian Cobden, as became Kensington Gardeners.” Thackeray’s new house in Palace Green was near Kensington Gardens.
– Seedy yesterday and today. Turtle sets me all serene —strange but true.

div.head: July 16, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T, M.L., S.B., H.M., T.T., Thackeray. Champ[agne].
S.B. says he finds the girls don’t come to a man so readily after 40. Labuntur anni, the Annies go away from you.

Whistler’s picture called wrongly “The Woman in White.” J.L. suggests to call it “No Name.” (Girl in nightclothes – shown in Berners St.)
Symphony in White, No. I: The White Girl. A review of the Berners Gallery show in the Athenaeum (No. 1809 [28 June 1862] 859) singled out this painting as a “bizarre production.”
Dinner to Gallait the Belgian artist next Friday. Egalité the motto, says Thackeray.

L.C. T.T. proposes “A Strategic Movement.” Yankee General running away. [crossed out] also suggests two swells’ daughters as poulterers apropos of Game Laws – but this has been done. Night poaching and police bill on today. X

M.L. tells of French duellist shooting young Englishman – after 1814 – and Englishman in Greenroom (Capt. Gronow?) hearing story goes – returns in 3 days & says, “I’ve shot that Frenchman.” Thackeray met the Briton in Paris.

C.K. tells of Mark[?] sitting in red tights, and dangling them out of the window to the delight of the street boys. — Vivier in railway pulled out razor and stropped it, glaring at passengers, who of course cleared out... V. blowing bubbles covered the table with them. Old professor called and thought him a marchand des verres de lampe.
Eugene-Leon Vivier (1817-1900), French horn virtuoso, was very popular in England and well known for his wit and practical jokes.

X T.T. proposes Lincoln at the Bar of public opinion – mixing an eye closer – accepted [Punch, 43 (26 July 1862): 35, “The Latest from America”]. M.L. would like to print Tennyson’s Exhibition Ode in Greek. – as The Times has been inserting translations of it. By the way, E. Walford writes to The Star to cut up those Latin lines the Times prints – and E.W. is up in classics as Charterhouse knows.

div.head: July 23, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Coming of Age Dinner to Mr. Punch.
E., J.L., C.K., T., M.B., P.L., S.B., H.M., and T.T.
Turtle soup (≠ Thackeray’s). Salmon–Cutlet, Cold beef, – Pineapple fritter – Cheese –strawberries and cream – cherries, pineapple – Punch, champagne – sherry and claret.
P.L. tells of Guardian the Rev. Ebenezer Jones pursuing a runaway couple – “And mine too.”

E. briefly proposes, “Success to Punch.” – 21 years ago tomorrow was his start. At more length and with good taste and feeling, E. then proposes health to Mark Lemon – dwelling on his constancy and attention to the interests of Punch and on his talent in raising it to its present standing. Punch met with obloquy in its start, as its printer and engraver were those of “The Town” and other ribald comic papers. Ribaldry and dirt were inseparable from comicality until Punch came. No light honour to a man to have kept such a team together as the Punch lot – to have so kindly borne and forborne, and reconciled and bound together men of such diversity of talent and of tastes. – M.L. in reply says he is the only survivor at this table of the original Punch lot: The Punch Club, as they first called themselves. M.L., Henry Mayhew and Stirling Coyne and Landells, the Engraver were the originators and proprietors. Jerrold and Á Beckett came in the second number — Leech in the 3rd or 4th (and the circulation dropped off one half by the day’s delay of his first cut – thro’ fault of Landells the engraver). Leigh joined a little later – and Ponny Mayhew before the 1st volume was ended. Albert Smith was one of the first number team — so was Beaton! A.S. constantly had rows with Jerrold – contending that Punch ought to stick to fun, and never be serious. M.L. and Henry Mayhew did the notices to correspondents — Jerrold’s “Q” papers had a marked success and influence, and his “Caudle [Lectures]” decidedly raised the circulation. The first meetings were held in Vinegar Yard — and rows were generally the order of the night. At first they dined on Saturday and then settled the cut for the next Saturday (Saturday was the publishing day). The new number used at one time to be handed round at the meeting and endless squabbles arose therefrom — every writer finding fault with every article inserted in preference to his own. Now all works smoothly —the machinery is kept oiled by good feeling and good humour – and long may the Foreman have health to see that all goes right!

L.C. – the Lancashire distress. H.M. suggests a Picture of King Cotton with all the misery he reigns over. P.L. would paraphrase Sidney’s “Thy distress is greater than mine.” — the thing is to show the wives and children, says S.B. – Why not have Charity as Britannia stepping in between families and starvation: “Here at last I may interfere.” Call it “Home Intervention,” says M.L. Approved. [ Punch, 43 (2 August 1862): 45, “Home Intervention”]S.B. says he don’t wonder at Webster’s being friendly to M.L. — but M.L. denies having used Punch to puff his friends. (Our Dramatic Correspondent wrote of The Dead Heart this week.)
Punch, 43 (26 July 1862): 33. Benjamin Webster played the lead in a revival of Watts Phillips' The Dead Heart at the Adelphi. Silver's review praises Webster as “among the best of English actors,” but tempers this with the suggestion that other plays offer a greater scope for his talents.

div.head: July 30, 1862. W[ednesday]. Greyhounds. Dulwich.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., Fred Evans [Pater’s son], S.B., Wm. Bradbury, Sir J. Paxton.

Bus doesn’t come – so we walk from Kennington Gate, and have a little cricket. Sir J.P. hot from a Game row – says that all that gamekeepers want is leave to follow a poacher off their land. Battues are the mischief. Regular debate we have. S.B. & J.L. rather siding with the swells, P.L. and Sir J.P. contra. “Liberty of the subject” a bugbear cry, says S.B. P.L. vehement in its defense. M.L. says Punch has ever been guided by common sense, and hence its success. And common sense says that policemen should not be required to act as gamekeepers. J.L. pictures peeler searching under crinoline for hidden hair. H.S. hates poachers as he hates battues – but thinks you can’t put them down by police force. Allow the tenant farmers to shoot and they’ll preserve your game and always save enough for a good day for their landlord. Lords have no business to turn poulterers and ask the county to pay for gamekeeping police.
See Times leader on July 17, 1862, 10, in support of the Night Poaching Prevention Bill, whose second reading on July 16 had provoked heated debate. —Difference of opinion, so M.L. suggests Lincoln coming to Sambo for help, “Always said you was a Man and brother.” [Punch, 43 (2 August 1862): 55, “One Good Turn Deserves Another”]

Jolly dinner — Paddy Green’s afterwards with M.L. and J.L. and F.E. M.L. tells me more en tete a tete about the early struggles of Punch – how he wrote 5 columns a week at first, and only got a guinea or so – and wrote a farce for the Strand called “Punch” — (revived since as “The Star of the Street”) and then another piece for £30 to carry on the paper. D.J. and Gil. à B. received 30/- a week. B. & E. bought it at end of first volume after the Almanack (which was chiefly Grattan’s work) for £300, its debts. And gave M.L. £5 a week after a while to edit it. M.L. refused insertion of an article puffing some railway B[radbury] was interested in, and an article of Fonblanque’s which he thought libellous. Since that row, never has had another. His system is to let each man write what he likes, subject to M.L.’s supervision. “All cleverer fellows than I am,” says he — but is not his judicious editing a talent they can’t show an equal to?

div.head: August 7, 1862.
div.p: E., H.S., J.T., M.L., S.B., H.M.

J.L. at Folkestone. T.T. in Piedmont. P.L. with gout! A martyr to mushrooms. S.B. likes a snug party like this. But says you fellows don’t pitch into each other. Punch dinners getting stupid. That’s because you have all the talk to yourself, says Mark. H.S. descants to E. on the trip of the Elsie and the carrying away of her mast on Tuesday.

L.C. M.L. suggests Pam carrying out his bat. — Says he has cause to hate the Music Halls. Half brother met motte there and married her. M.L.’s mother married again and has given him great trouble. Jolly comfortable dinner. \ after it.

div.head: August 13, 1862. W[ednesday]. Mitre. Hampton Court.
div.p: E., H.S. (from Harwich ce matin), Fred Evans, C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., Wm. Bradbury, S.B., H.M., Lucas.
S.B. triumphant with a barbel [European fish]. Jolly dinner — waiter like Disraeli. M.L. loquacious, apropos of H.S. and the Elsie tells of Tom Reed and Tom Tit.

L.C. Hardishstool. Wm. B. [son] suggests a thing or two, but nothing of mark hit on. H.M.’s idea of Lincoln’s two difficulties accepted. [Punch, 43 (23 August 1862): 77, “Lincoln's Two Difficulties” ]
Sunday School Treat children pass in procession and we demoralize them by showering coppers and greengages in their path. – M.L. again urges the Music Hall nuisance.

div.head: August 28 [1862], Thursday
div.p: L.C. Leech by letter suggests North and South with their eyes blacked not able to come up to time. S.B. amends by their saying “Why don’t the Police interfere?” [ Punch, 43 (13 September 1862): 111, “'Not Up to Time'“].

P.L. motto for garter “Set your affections on things above.” P.L. and H.M. talk away de omnibus rebus et quibus dam alius. After which the 2 latter and H.S. adjourn to Salisbury Square and have a cigar with Ald. Mathews. Ponny calls Sheffield a picture of lead in a frame of gold.

div.head: September 18th, 1862. No. 11. (Sept. 3 & 10 No Dinner – (M.L. & J.L. in France.)
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T. M.L., P.L., S.B., Thackeray.

M.L. and J.L. been to Dieppe, Paris, Bordeaux, and Biarritz – saw a bullfight. 12 francs a head – worth it for the shade – sweltering sun – 6,000 present. Great smell of garlic – elegant matadors just slipping aside from the bull rushes and kissing their hands. Very cruel sport – horses killed by scores, and men too, at times. Empress enjoys it. Very pretty still, plus embonpoint. Girls with walking sticks, and hair powder coming in. Biarritz as Spanish as Boulogne is English. Sand rocks, sand beach, and blue sea. Les chasseurs with spurs. /. Girls take tremendous headers, as at Dieppe. M.L.’s snoring – told chambermaid that J.L. was a somnambulist. White burgundy first rate. French generally uncivil in railway travelling. (H.S. found peasants very civil.) Agree that bathing better conducted there than here.
Master Busby[?] on board the Elsie – fried taters and plum pudding, frock washing etc. S.B. a corn same as H.S. had. We are all toe-martyrs in our time.
Thackeray a bill of £800 from Jackson and Graham for painting alone.
Presentation of Punch knives by Alderman Matthews per S.B. Regular first chop blades and got up regardless of expense. Appropriately follows the Large Cut.

P.L. suggests the Yankee Reign of Terror, a bigger guillotine than the world has ever seen. Thackeray (who has been brimming with bad jokes all dinnertime) says George Washington as Peacemaker, “I was called a Rebel.” J.L. – Northerner looking at weathercock, “South again, hang it!” S.B. Southerner, take up that bill at 90 days. (accepted.) [ Punch, 43 (27 September 1862): 131, “The Overdue Bill” ]
Jolly dinner – enjoyed all the more for my fortnight’s cruise in The Elsie.

div.head: September 24, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., Thackeray.

L.C. J.L. – Suggests, “Back again” – Lincoln [originally “Lincolnback, “back” crossed out] and Southerner. J.T. – Faust and L.N. as Mephist[opheles] accepted. [Punch, 43 (1862): 141, “Faust and Maguerite”]
H.M. tells of his finding Bob Brough drunk in streets and taking him home – filthy state – stunk so that the windows bulged out. Beast! & yet so clever.
Fancy the Professor, faute de W.C., in garden with a cloak and umbrella – buried it darkly at dead of night – interdment.

J.L. says how he hates to see girls kissing puppy dogs – bubby dogs says Thackeray – give them bumbums – sure they \ them. Says Lydia Thompson must be a clipper – squeeze tight after \ —He and wife split a hare – ½ back each yesterday.

M.L. talks of pawnbrokers dining and pledging one another. “Mr. Thackeray and Mr. Leech and the remainder of the Rothschild family,” said by Telegraph to be at Folkestone. __ Jews very nishe peoples – says Thackeray – simple and artless, and speak such exshellent English. – Tells how he saw at Drury Lane a beautiful blonde with luxuriant yellow locks – her name Celeste.
 [drawing of pointing hand] To Princess’s after to Fanny & LB & Germain, “falls like Lucifer!”

div.head: October 1, 1862. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: E., J.L., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., Thackeray.

Talk of officer accused of “expelling ablebodied semen” says S.B. Should be applied to a frigate – H.M. Toad in hole for dinner – not frog in the coal. “The man who would dine on a single rissole deserves I think to be toad in the hole,” (Thackeray). — S.B. telling of a one-eyed attorney of bad character. “One eye soit qui mal y pense,” says Thackeray, who is quick enough at bad jokes.

L.C. Very hardstool. Lots of mild suggestions including Papist Pot and Protestant Kettle, apropos of Belfast – Du Chaillu and Irish Gorillas, S.B. L.N. as Blondin, carrying Pope across — if you’re not quiet I’ll put you down, P.L. suggests Bull as policeman saying, “Move on,” to Pope as fishwoman. P.L. suggests Lord Dundreary as the Hon. Cadogan who got £2400 from Veillard the Contractor: but Thackeray says you asked me to spare Dickens, now spare Cadogan. Sings good song. At last, S.B. having gone, H.S. suggests Pope and Luggage labelled “Temporal Possessions” – accepted. Amended by M.L. [ Punch, 43 (11 October 1862): 151, “Settling the Italian Difficulty”]
Opening of Dramatic College on Monday last. L.B. day.

div.head: October 8, 1862.
div.p: L. H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., H.M., T.T., Thackeray.

Turtle soup again – second time this year at No. 11! But ≠ at Thackeray’s. Chaff about the Telegraph notice of “Mr. Thackeray, Mr. Leech and the rest of the Rothschild family” being among the fashionable vistors at Folkestone.
T.T. has been with wife and child in Northern Italy, sketching, etc. J.T. at Folkestone with J.L., wretchedly cold rainy day yesterday. (H.S. \\\ last night!)

Anent the Jews, J.L. says they are excessively polite to him – but with all their kindness there’s something you don’t like – and with all their riches, there’s something wanting – they seem to feel their position still.

Thackeray says he can’t write Yankeeisms and compliments S.B. who hands over the kudos to H.S. H.M. applauds my Day at Dieppe of last week, thinking M.L. wrote it.
“Day at Dieppe,” Punch, 43 (4 October 1862): 144

S.B. advises us to read “True to the Last” as a specimen of strong writing in novels.
Mrs. Gordon Smythies [Harriette Maria Smythies], True to the Last (London: Hurst and Blackett, 1862). The novel began appearing in the London Journal in the summer of 1861 (34 [13 July 1861] 41) under the title, “The Girl We Leave Behind Us,” concluding on February 1, 1862, before being published as True to the Last in three volumes later that year. (Thanks to Troy Bassett for the London Journal details.) See the dispiriting account of Smythies's career as a novelist in Nigel Cross, The Common Writer (Cambridge; Cambridge University Press, 1985), 188-192.
Discuss the photographs of Miss Walters (Skittles) and others – Miss Gilbert and Lord Sutherland \.

L.C. P.L. suggests the [two words crossed out] Irishman as the “missing link” between man and the gorilla. Subject mooted at British Association at Cambridge this week.
Richard Owen gave a paper at the meeting entitled, “On the Zoological Significance of the Brain and Limb Characters of man, with remarks on the cast of the brain of the gorilla,” arguing that humans belong in a distinct sub-kingdom, and was attacked by T. H. Huxley (Times, October 14, 1862, p. 7). See also the article, “The Missing Link,” by Percival Leigh, with initial letter showing prognathus Irishman with shillelagh (Punch, 43 (18 October 1862): 165. On Punch’s simianization of the Irish, see note to entry for March 5, 1862. Apropos of the Pope and Garibaldi row in Hyde Park last Sunday – but we think this might get the Punch windows broken.
At a mass meeting in Hyde Park, Irish labourers supporting the Pope against Garibaldi rioted, and were put down by 400 police (Times, October 6, 1862, p. 7) So P.L. is to write his notion and J.L. suggests Abe Lincoln’s proclamation anent the blacks – the gambler’s last stake. (accepted) [Punch, 43 (18 October 1862):161, “Abe Lincoln's Last Card; Or, Rouge-et-Noir”]

Thackeray says Mrs. Yates was his boyish love, – talks of old farces, etc., asks what we youngsters on our side of the table admired. H.S. says his first pantomime “The Great Bed of Ware.” Imp[?] through keyhole and coming up the candle.
M.L. says Punch never was so prosperous as now – spite of the plagiary of “Funch” as Thackeray calls Fun. Has always been so – an opposition helps the sale.
C.K. thinks that Punch someday will be drawn with a nimbus — St. Punch.

In the walk to the Bedford, H.S. suggests fancy fair as the Almanack title page – mouths presiding over beek stalls, filled with things in season. M.L. says S.B. rarely suggests a picture, his ideas are full of point, but not picturesque. J.L. on the contrary brings a picture before you with a dozen words. J.L. immensely applauds the Russian hunting bronzes, and so does H.S.  [drawing of pointing hand] M.L. differs with H.S. as to the merits of Mrs. Fowler Jones’ “Sensation Drama” skit which H.S. begged he’d look at.

div.head: October 15, 1862.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., S.B., Lucas, T.T.
H.S. from the Excellent and Winchester today – balloon thence to Harrow in an hour yesterday.

L.C. J.L. suggests Cardinal Wiseman and his lambs – apropos of his touching appeal to the Irish last Saturday to keep out of Hyde Park, exhorting wives to hang round their husbands’ necks, etc. [ Punch, 43 (25 October 1862): 171, “Cardinal Wiseman's Lambs”]

Discuss no end of things from Armstrong guns to body snatchings. P.L. tells of Arnati, the Italian, again “fock-ed up to the troat,” etc. J.L. asks H.S. to Folkstone – and altogether we’ve a pleasant evening. Not having smoked since Sunday, H.S. gets a slight headache tomorrow, but cures it by fasting, and so eats a good dinner at G.A.G.’s.[?] What an interesting memorandum.

div.head: October 22, 1862. W[ednesday].
div.p:
H.S. from Folkestone today, been there with J.L. since Saturday. Gale on Sunday.
See Leech's cartoon, “The Gale,” Punch, 43 (1 November 1862): 180. Execution of Catherine Wilson (for poisoning) on Monday reminds Evans of seeing as many as half a score of bodies hanging, as he used to come to business. Discussion as to whether death deters. S.B. says yes and T.T. too. – M.L. and P.L. and E. no. P.L. says a fortnight’s imprisonment would deter him as much as hanging. M.L. and P.L. and H.S. agree in thinking that the sight of death only brutalizes.

L.C. S.B. suggests Hercules and Omphale [Louis Napoleon &]- Eugenie – accepted. [ Punch, 43 (1 November 1862): 181, “Hercules and Omphale” ]. M.L. again talks to P.L. and H.S. of his rejection of Fonblanque’s libellous articles to the disgust of Forster and affright of B & E. Says H.M. was once Sub Editor but M.L. took the double work to prevent rows. When the Papal Aggression came, M.L. foresaw he’d lose Doyle, and thought the circulation would fall – but it didn’t – and he thinks their firm tone then showed the public Punch was in earnest and was something more than a buffoon.
In 1850 Richard Doyle resigned his position in protest against the magazine’s fierce “no-Popery” campaign of personal invective against Cardinal John Wiseman and Pope Pius IX, waged by Jerrold and Leech in reaction to the attempt to reinstate the Roman Catholic hierarchy in England. This campaign reached a pitch of virulence and open appeal to bigotry unmatched in Punch’s subsequent history. For a deeply informed discussion of the campaign see Altick, Punch: The Lively Youth, 476-492. His place as Editor has always been to avoid dictation – reserving merely the power of correction – thereby has the benefit of a variety of minds, unfettered by his own.
–\\\ après!

div.head: October 29, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S. from Woodbridge ce matin, C.K., M.L., P.L., S.B., Thackeray.

A dull dinner rather – S.B. been to Xn [Exhibition] – great crush going out, yet only 65,000 – quantum mutata ab 1851. And H.S. quantum mutatus! “Don’t seem to care about it” — or anything else. Can understand M.L. saying life is not worth living simply for its pleasures. M.L. holds that duties are worth living for. More happiness in helping others than in living for oneself. S.B. contra. P.L. thinks if he’d £30,000 he’d live to be 90. Thackeray says when he was on his deathbed (as he thought) he was perfectly content and happy. A bit of a sceptic is he – not deterred from wrongdoing by fears of a future state, but by feelings of present disgrace and dishonour. S.B. says futurity alone deters him from crime.

Thackeray talks of Yates as canaille – tells how he slobbered him with praise at starting of Cornhill, and then asked him to admit a poem on Magazines and blowing up, etc. Base, ungentlemanly, mean, etc., etc. S.B. defends Y[ates] – says he was merely acting for Dickens – who never spoke well of Thackeray or anybody else: which M.L. confirms.

… Afterwards M.L. advises C.K. to take a weekly salary – is sure the system has been the making of Punch – keeps men from jealousy – tells how D[ouglas] J[errold] received £300 and 30/- a week for Caudle.

L.C. J.L. and M.L. suggest a Manchester Expectat cut – England expects, every Manchester man to do his duty — S.B. thinks the running away of Otho should be noticed and Thackeray makes rhymes for Otho with – Feel very thotho, etc.
A popular uprising in Greece forced the abdication of King Otho or Otto (1815-1867), who left the country aboard a British warship and returned to his native Bavaria. See Times leaders at October 27, 1862, p. 8 and October 29, 1862, p. 6. A comic dialogue, “Bomba and Otho,” appeared in Punch, 43 (8 November 1862): 190, opposite the Large Cut, and was reprinted in TheTimes for November 8, 1862.L.C. turns out to be Prussia with Bomba and Otho. “Two Frightful Examples” [ Punch, 43 (8 November 1862): 191, “Two Frightful Examples”]
Thackleray tells how Forster was annoyed by his hit at him in Esmond as “Mr. Addison’s man” — C[harles] D[ickens] being Mr. A[ddison].

Flebitis omnidit[?] – he died of fleabites, PL — S.B. tells of Leotard, nothing repulsive in his performance – admires his white skin and firm muscle, no wonder the Duchesses crave — Leotard c’est meilleur que Leojamais.
L.C. S.B. suggests Manchester men at dinner – “They say we ought to do something, – well, let’s pass the claret.”
M.L. wouldn’t have W.M.T.’s religious opinions for all his intellect and wealth.
M.L. thinks that the Punch light style of writing has had great influence on the Times and other leader-writers.

div.head: November 12, 1862 W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., S.B., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L.

S.B. talks of the beastly rabble we saw following the show on Monday and how they knocked women down, etc. Out of such scum come the Garrotters. Juvenile emigration the cure, says M.L. (in Once A Week), but query if the mothers would let you take away their children.
The previous year Lemon had laid out his argument for compulsory juvenile emigration in a highly uncharacteristic essay signed “Barabbas”: “Thieves and Thieves’ Children,” Once a Week, 11 May 1861, 548-550. The attribution, confirmed by the magazine’s conbtributors ledger, can be found in the Curran Index. Pot boils over – no use putting water in – you must take it off. Abolish flogging in the Army and introduce it in the gaols.

Talking of Whitehurst, the solicitor, charged with inciting to b[ugger]y, M.L. pictures his misery in the bottomless pit — and S.B. hearing that W[hitehurst] is agent to the Ballot Society says “acts properly in wishing to place his balls in secret places.”
Wealthy solicitor Edward Capel Whitehurst, Secretary of the Ballot Society, was charged in November 1862 with inciting George Rogers, late of the 5th Dragoon Guards, to commit an unnatural offense, on the basis of letters written by Whitehurst to Rogers to arrange a meeting. George Lewis appeared for the defense. Whitehurst was committed for trial on related charges but the prosecution did not appear and the case was dropped.
S.B. tells of Frenchman exhorted by priest to try and die like a Christain – “Yes, if you and the doctor will stand one on each side of me.”

Anecdotes of Liston — “Show me his ultimatum.” Wife having taken reins, L[iston] comes and facially swears at footlights – conspiracy, barber shaving king – signal dropping of handkerchief out of windows, “Oh, it might hurt somebody.” Roman and son, father puts hand over and strokes son’s face “You might die like a Roman, and at least you might wipe your nose.”
M.L. a jamais vu une femme nude. S.B. “walker”[“wather” in imitation of swell?] – descants on the beauty of bootlacing, etc.
S.B. tells of miner – goose at back, goose shiting then. Ay. [“answering”?] – I’ll shit him tomorrow.
M.L. proposes to sell rejected letters to Fun – quite up to their mark.
L.C. S.B. suggests Louis [Napoleon] proposing to interfere, and Pam says, – Well, you do it – he’s an admirer of you [Punch, 43 (22 November 1862): 211, “One Head Better than Two”].
(Low spirits of late — quinine revives me. L.B. partly the cause. Can’t make my mind up. Pro and con.)

div.head: November 19, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: S.B., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M. champ[agne].
Mrs. Charles Dickens Jr. “comes down” today — an anniversary of wedding. Charley has trumped Bob Orridge and Fred [Evans]. And Pater is a grandpater – which he has been wishing.
Tell of T[homas] G[erman] R[eed]’s robbery of mare and brougham Saturday week – recovered at Bow.
S.B. tells of sailor washing to prevent cl[a]p – “Who’s to get out of bed 27 times a night?”

Pocket Book produced. And artists applauded. P.L. thinks the “fashions” good satire and not glorification of crinoline as J.L. has sometimes shown.
“Some Seaside Fashions for 1863,” Punch’s Pocket Book for 1863.

L.C. S.B. says Manchester and garotte the 2 subjects. J.T. suggests Mr. Bull dressing for an evening party with revolvers and bludgeons. S.B. says you want to hit Sir George Grey for his non-interference and so suggests deputation of garottees. C.K. suggests “Garrotte Sir George – our best friend – no.” [ Punch, 43 (29 November 1862): 221, “The Garotter's Friend”]

div.head: November 26, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B.(migrated to old seat), J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., T.T., Thackeray.

E. tells that Charley Dickens and Willie Br[adbur]y had their first child both the same day, last Friday month – and that exactly 9 months before they were both dining with him, the Grand Pater Q.E.D.

Thackeray says he feels a sort of βΤΟδγή[?] a when he reads his daughter’s “Story of Elizabeth.”
Appearing in The Cornhill between September 1862 and January 1863 She has all my better parts and none of my worse. S.B. admires her pure English and likens her to Minerva from the brain of Jupiter. Thackeray says his feeling is shared by his mother, who says she can’t read his works — “as many others do” he adds, anticipating our kind hint.

Garotting all the go still. M.L. pictures man asking what’s o’clock and being knocked down unanswered. “Just struck one,” says H.S.
This joke appears twice, with DuMaurier cartoons, in Punch, 43 (20 Dec. 1862): 249, “The Song of the Anti-Garrotter,” and 254, “A Practical Application of an Old Pantomime Joke”.

J.L. says Hastings is quite warm and summerlike — hard frost at Woodbridge yesterday. Says his little ones have been reading Gulliver, and said to him, “Papa, we wish you’d get us some Lilliputians for us to keep in a cage.” L.C. S.B. suggests (King) Alfred and the Greek cakes – “Refuses to burn his fingers,” says T.T. [Punch, 43 (6 December 1862): 231, “Alfred Refuses to Burn His Fingers”]

J.L. sleeps at his new house at Kensington first time tonight. After he and P.L. and rest go, Thackeray writes The Lord’s Prayer in the size of a threepenny bit, drawing the crown and 3 in centre. Gives it to M.L. with lines round it – “Dear Friend, I’ve writ this little page When 1 and 50 is my age” etc., etc. In walking away I talk of reading John Wilson’s life (Christopher North) and admire his manliness in turning to work when he lost all his fortune – also his thrashing the tinker, etc., etc. Thackeray dissents – says J.W. did nothing worth record – and the effect on him, Thackeray, was to make him tell his daughters, “Mind – no biography” of himself.

And so he to Paddy Green’s with Horace. Strong, big man like him (must be 6 ft 2) have great advantage in an animal way over us weak puny ones. I’ve felt miserably weak of late, and can’t stand smoke. J.L. and T.T. have both almost given it up. Not a single cut for Almanack done yet.
W.M.T. tells of going to see some Chinese jugglers throwing knives t’other night at Kensington “very nearly struck him in the juggler vein.”
S.B. calls Spurgeon coarse and vulgar (of course) – imagines him addressing congregation – “Are there any harlots present” – And echo answers, “Yes, there are har lots,” W.M.T.

T.T. describes our Ambassador at Pekin receiving a deputation while dressing and mandarin saying, “Before you talk nation[?] pigson[?] you cover your arsee.” What’s arsee says Thackeray – and catches Master Tom as he caught M.L. t’other week by saying, There’s no rhyme for Babbage – Yes Cabbage says M.L. – Sold!
T.T. and his prolific friend “ 2 wets, 2 dries, and a monthly.”

div.head: December 3, 1862. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., S.B., M.L., P.L., T.T., Wm. Russell, (at 9).

S.B. dreamed a Shakespearian illustration — E. knocked on the head and B[radbury] quoting Lady Macbeth, “See how our partner’s rapt!” Has often dreamed a joke for Punch, but rarely woke and found it a good one. M.L. and H.S. say the ditto. M.L. once dreamed the end of a play and made it available. Talk of Garibaldi and the extraction of the bullet – And now they’ve got the bullet out there’ll be no bullet-in.
Giuseppi Garibaldi had been wounded in the ankle during a skirmish in Calabria. A British surgeon, Richard Partridge, was brought in to consult and declared that there was no bullet in the wound. Partridge was proven wrong when Professor August Nélaton of Paris devised a way to probe the wound, and the bullet was found and extracted. The surgery was widely reported; see for example the Sun, 22 November 1862, p. 2.

L.C. H.S. suggests Prize Criminal Show and T.T. amends to Pen of Jebb’s Lambs [ Punch, 43 (13 December 1862): 241, “Sir Joshua Jebb’s Pen of Pet Lambs.”].
Sir Joshua Jebb (1793-1863), Surveyor General of Prisons. A long letter from Jebb had appeared in the Times for November 1, 1862, 6, defending the ticket-of-leave system of probation for convicts. The paper ran a leader in reply (November 2, 1862, 8) referring to the “growing unpopularity of ticket-of-leave men.” Tom Taylor was undoubtedly inspired by this controversy to write one of the most popular of his plays, “The Ticket-of-Leave Man,” which made its debut at the Olympic Theatre in May of the following year.

Billy Russell correcting press – his Diary – difficult to condense – comes and chats for an hour – no end of Yankee anecdotes.
William Howard Russell (1820-1907), who had first achieved prominence for the vivid brilliance of his Times articles from the battlefields of the Crimea, was sent by the paper to cover the civil war in America, which he visited between March 1861 and April 1862. Bradbury and Evans published Russell's book, My Diary North and South, in 1863. Russell also served as the first editor of the Army and Navy Gazette, which Bradbury and Evans had founded in 1860; he remained its editor for forty years. Kentucky officer – “Can’t go with you – my bl[ood]y fool of a Colonel’s put me under arrest — You see one of my bhoys was untidy on parade and so I shot him. – “Yes gentlemen,” says servant, – “here is the Captn’s six-shooter and it was as neat a shot as ever you see.” – Captn., “I’ve written to McClellan and if I don’t hear by tomorrow mornin’ I shall be off and I guess my boys-will follow me!” “But you don’t set a good example for discipline.” – “ Do you want to have a difficulty with me, Sir?” — Says Kentuckians are fine big men. Londoners seemed small after New Yorkers. Pennsylvanians smaller – Boston the “boss” of the Union. Gave £6 for boots in Crimea and 5/- for a pot of marmalade. 4 newspapers in Wisconsin – quite a small place. But the press has small influence – no London press to give a tone to it. If unaminous the press would be overpowering. — Tells of joke against the Dutch that they mistook Turkey Buzzards, the foulest of birds, for ortolans. In India vultures appear instantly there’s carrion – at Lucknow he saw them inside the horses, feasting on the entrails. – Immoralities at the Hills in Tom Taylor’s piece not exaggerated a bit.
P.L. tells of Yankee threat, “I’ll whip you into so many bits that it will puzzle omniscience to find and omnipotence to put them together.”
Russell looks fatter than when I saw him last, lecturing at St. Martin’s Hall. Has a slight Irish accent —Yankeeises very well.
At Pontrilas 4th to 16th, then Waresley, Woodbridge, Glenham and Holser.

div.head: January 7, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., S.B., J.T, M.L., H.S., C.K.

“Here’s Silver cleaning plate,” says S.B. finding H.S. washing. H.S. from Woodbridge ce matin. J.L. into his new house, been taking tonics. (H.S. wants ditto – this last has been a sad year and he has felt strength and spirits fail him — Be sure your sin will find you out.)

L.C. The Bishops v. Excursion trains. M.L. sugggests tearing down railway bill — and H.S. puts the title “The Publican’s Friend.” [ Punch, 44 (17 January 1863): 25, “The Publican's Friend”]J.L. says he thinks fresh air is too strong for poor people! don’t agree with them! – says they get drunk almost before they start – and tire and bully their children. M.L. and H.S. differ with him – the rich can’t judge of the pleasures of the poor – what is joy to Muggins would be death to Leech.

div.head: January 14, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., S.B., M.L., C.K., H.M. (at 9 o’cl)

J.L. says Billy Russell sent him a suggestion – Swell about to marry friend says, “Nonsense, you’ll never get on well with your wife.” “Why not – I’ve always got on well with other people’s wives.” Also story from Higgins – little child asked why it was so affectionate to her aunt, almost more so than to mother “Oh ma, of course I love you best, but then I must be civil to aunt – ’cause she spreads the jam.” Also story of old gourmand stopped by beggar, “Please Sir, I’m so ungry” – “Go to hell, I wish I was.” – S.B. asks for rhymes (which H.S. sends on Friday) – quote Godfrey Morgan’s There was a young fellow at Bicester Who determined to b. his sister So he thought the best plan before he began was to wipe out her ass with a glister.

S.B. at Fechter’s opening of Lyceum on Saturday – next to Forster, who moved away because the great Dickens was with him. – Says Boucicault was found in b. with Mrs. Jordan — and Chas. Mathews summoned to show what the American law was as to wives divorced.
J.L. suggests swell saying, “Aw – I think of committing a petty larceny and being put in prison — understand its the best place going for good grub.”

L.C. Man who won the fight. Abe Lincoln with black eye, etc., J.L. M.L. and S.B. agree that Lincoln’ s proclamation as to slaves being free should be noticed – Abraham Lincoln made a law and a proclamation etc. – Slave reading proclamation and saying, “Yes, Massa, but you beat him first.” [ Punch, 44 (1863): 35, “Scene from the American 'Tempest'“]Southerner with pistol cocked, “Wal, why don’t yer go?” S.B. suggests black as Othello, “Were it my cue to fight I’d do it without your bidding.” Also, Black Caliban, “beat him well and then I’ll beat him too.” (H.S. can’t find the passage.)
Tempest, 3,ii,”Beat him enough: after a little time I’ll beat him too.” J.L. thinks Punch will stultify itself, but S.B. says two years hence we shall be sorry for espousing the side of Cavaliers and Convicts. The Southerners have been in power for the last 20 years – and they it is who have insulted us – bought the New York Herald, etc., etc., etc. Joe Young’s a rabid Northerner – says that Punch has surprised and offended the Americans more than anything else. Punch always as yet in favour of justice and now to pat rebels on the back. But what right had the States to secede from England, eh, Jonathan? And Punch can’t cry bravo to a Bully – or sympathize with an Invader. South fighting for hearth and home and therefore successful.

div.head: January 21, 1863.
div.p: P.L. from Southampton tells of small rustic at School Ex[amine]d by Lady Josselyn as to how Samson slew the Philistines, prompted the school fellow to say “by the jawbone of an ass,” replied “by jobbing ‘em in the — Mum.” – J.L. tells of French novel where the wife is of such superior intellect that she gets her husband with child — foetus inside another, twins, in College of Surgeons. “How’s your poor foetus,” says P.L. – T.T. says Sothern gets £200 a week now. J.L. dined with him the other day and S[othern] said the swells in Punch made him think Lord Dundreary would be popular in England.
Peter Rackham died last week. E. saw him yesterday in his coffin. Some curious mania with maidservant to make the corpse look “beautiful.” T.T. says many a man dies for want of work.

C.K. made a con[undrum]. Why’s a schoolboy after a flogging like a man who gives support to one of the Royal family? ‘Cos he carries the prints of wales on his back. – T.T. quotes, “When does a man become one of the greadrumena? When he doubles his fists.”

L.C. T.T. suggests Lord Derby and cockpit looking at “Finance,” etc. “That cock won’t fight.” J.L. and T.T. suggest Dizzy as Watcher of the Coming Derby lot. [ Punch, 44 (31 January 1863): 45, “Looking Out for the Next ‘Derby’”]

J.L. dining with Dillon in the Albany yesterday sees old letters from McClellan in the Crimea –good ones, too — deploring the war and its evils. T.T. thinks Butler a man of vigour and will come to the front. Fun called for by C.K., as usual. Coarser and worse than usual this week.
J.L. tells of little dog turning up its nose at little bitch while dirty with housecleaning – but when washed on Saturday and looking like a snowball, dog made love to her at once.

div.head: January 27, 1863.
div.p: H.S. at Sargent’s – 10 guns – Summer’s Day. Only bagged a brace!

div.head: February 4, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., Lucas, T.T. Champ[agne].
H.S. hirsutus barbatusque – hullo! says C.K. — and S.B. congratulates. (Last shave Jan. 12, M.)

J.L. tells of Dukes of Northumberland and Argyll travelling and a small snob will talk with them — so when N[orthumberland] gets out, snob admires his trap and hearing his name says, “Ah, he looks like a Duke – fancy his being so haffable to a couple of little beggars like you and me!
Lucas tells of Lady Pam who drinks toast in water saying to Pam who drinks Amontillado, Why your wine’s just the colour of my water! – Yes, my dear – as like as 2 peas.
L.C. Storm Signals – Pam and John as pilots looking out, “See any danger signal?” T.T. The oyster opening of Parliament (tomorrow) – Russell asking “Is it all right.” T.T.

S.B. suggests Pam dressing John for the Juvenile Party, “Mind you behave among the old ladies (House of Lords). – T.T. alters it to Upper School, “Don’t you let the big boys bully you ... S.B. suggests City of London, a handsome woman, saying to Prince of Wales, “I think you might have come to my house for your wedding breakfast. (Queen too long secluded). M.L. and S.B. finally propose Pam backing his Reduction (of Income Tax) against Derbys Division [ Punch, 44 (14 February 1863): 65, “The Spring Meeting”].

P.L. irate against embezzlers, who ruin recklessly, would wish them whipped. S.B., J.L., and T.T., contra – think imprisonment for life a far greater punishment to men like Redpath, brought from luxury to prison fare. Whereas a common ruffian lives almost better in a gaol than he can do out of it.
Glass of champagne to Romer’s health – M.L.’s nephew – on his being Senior Wrangler.
P.L. suggests Derby asking Pam, “How’s your poor feet?” And Pam replying, “Thank you, my supporters are all right.”

Alluding to Frith’s pitch into Carter (Shirtcollar) Hall, Ed[itor] of Art Journal, – it is said he was the original of Pecksniff.
Samuel Carter Hall (1800-1889), the influential founder and longtime editor of the Art Journal, was the model for the unctuous Seth Pecksniff in Martin Chuzzlewit (1844). Douglas Jerrold of Punch began making satirical use of the character early on. See Nancy Aycock Metz, “Dickens, ‘Punch,’ and Pecksniff,” Dickens Journal, vol. 10, no. 1 (March 1993) 6-17. William Powell Frith (1819-1909) was a popular painter, well known for his large, crowded canvases; his “pitch” into Hall has not been traced.

div.head: February 10, 1863. Tuesday. No. 11.
div.p: (M.L. to Newcastle to read his Hearts are Trumps for £30 tomorrow.)
E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K.

S.B. tells of Lord Carlisle taking no guard against burglars, being told by a friend, “If you don’t take care, you’ll soon be the only spoon left in your house.” S.B. suggests when Bass and Allsop die a parody of Scott’s lines:

“Drop upon Allsop’s grave the tear that trickles for his rival’s beer.”S.B. reads his smash into Sala apropos ‘The Naggletons.”Fancy pulling G.A.S.’s nose! ugh, wouldn’t it blister your fingers! (H.S. gave a slight dig into the Gushers apropos of the Duke of Rutland, as he walked home from J.L.’s last Sunday. See, Is Foxhunting Injurious?)
[Henry Silver], Punch, 44 (14 March 1863) 110, “Is Foxhunting Injurious?”
At Tom Cobb’s last Friday he narrates apropos of Colenso -
A Bishop there was of Natal, Who had a Zulu for a pal,
Said the Zulu, Look here, Ain’t this Pentateuch queer?
Which converted my Lord of Natal.

At Arthur Lewis’s on Saturday this is received with great applause. As is Mark’s hymn anent – Buy your bloaters of Huggins. “It may be observed that in so bountifully providing herrings for the food of man, providence, while kind to man, has been rather hard on the herring.”

J.L. objects to these Nursery Rhymes, but S.B. and M.L. say they get so many letters that they are sure people like the nonsense.
Entitled simply “NURSERY RHYMES,” this series of verses, which first appeared on January 3, 1863 (p. 3), took the form popularized by Edward Lear in his Book of Nonsense; each stanza begins “There was a young lady of” followed by the name of a town. All of these that appear in the magazine’s ledgers were written by Shirley Brooks. The series appears to have concluded with “The Last Nursery Rhyme” on March 7.
L.C. Poland or Greece the subject: M.L. suggests John Bull holding back his bulldog and S.B. puts the title, “A Growl for Poland.” [ Punch, 44 (21 February1863): 75, “A Growl for Poland”]

Apropos of the Coming Wedding, Buckstone asks Tenniel to do a design for a Transparency. It is suggested that the Punch staff should pose themselves on the roof of 85 Fleet St. as the Prince and Princess pass it on the 7th. B. & E. as the strong men with an artist in each hand, etc., etc. Shirley says someone has suggested that there be a charity boy on every lamppost
T.C.W. says the P[rince] of W[ales] is a muff at business. Jansen, Cobb’s partner had the selling of Sandringham to him. — “Would be sorry to give him a seat in my office.”

div.head: February 18 [1863]. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: Ash Wednesday. E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K.
Ponny and T.T. supporting Sala at the Dramatic dinner.

L.C. J.L. suggests a marriage “Bless you my children” by Mr. Punch, apropos of the Settlement – (query: “Dowry” the right word for a Prince’s portion?) – amends it to a slap at the Yankees – “better than some United States” [ Punch, 44 (28 February 1863): 85, “The Dowry”]. H.S. would like some allusion to the difference between the present and the last P. of W. – no £600,000 of debts to be cleared off now.

M.L. thinks my touch about “No Cards” has had effect – you see that postscript to half the nuptial notices now. Must be followed up. He says that cards cost him £8 or £9 when his daughter married.
See “No Cards,” Punch, 44 (24 January 1863): 37, for Silver’s article advocating that cards not be sent, repeating an almost identical article from the previous year: “No Cards,” Punch, 42 (4 January 1862) 4.

We drink the health of Mrs. Tom Evans and her baby – a 7 months child. J.L. relates how 9 years ago he and Millais in their hunting boots had to run off for the doctor and nurse for Miss Ada – whose birthday party next Wednesday induces dinner on Tuesday. And thus do small people disturb the national affairs.

J.L. tells how his boy was bothered by his governess to remember the provinces of Ireland – and he, J.L., instructed him to say “Ulster, Munster and I Connaught tell the other.” M.L. last week told how he was holding court as Judge in his school bedroom, and in came the Dominie and took him down with his pillowcase, wig and counterpane gown on to his drawing room and introduced “My Lord” and treated him to wine. Apropos of this, we jawed about flogging which, H.S. contends, never morally hurts a boy – all bosh about saying it degrades him, when the rule of the school is to flog for certain faults.

Great verbal duel between M.L. and P.L. anent Colenso and the like.
John William Colenso (1814-1883), controversial Bishop of Natal from 1853 until his death. See note for entry of March 22, 1865. M.L. contends that leading a Christ-like life will produce more happiness in this life to him who leads it than leading a sensual selfish existence. And herein H.S. agrees. P.L. disbelieves the Story of Jonah and the Mosaic account of the Flood – which he says lives in the legends of the Chinese and other nations. It is a pity the Church of England don’t have the courage to avow that there are certain parts of Scripture which must be read cum grano. All thinking men agree on their belief in God and Christ – but creeds keep them at enmity. Tennyson wisely says “There is more good truth in honest doubt, Believe me than in half the creeds” – but then there must be honest faith as well. St. Athanius never wrote the Athanasian Creed – that was written for a special time and purpose, why should it be perpetuated now? Sweep it away and some few other Excrescences and away would go Dissent, and the Church would be greatly fortified.

Bradbury don’t see the joke of Mokeanna – complained that Punch was lowered by it.
Mokeanna, Francis Cowley Burnand’s parody of romance and sensation novels, began in Punch 44 (21 February 1863):71-72 and concluded four weeks later on 21 March, 115-116. The lurid illustrations by Du Maurier, and others were burlesques of the drawings they had done for the London Journal. This was Burnand’s first contribution to the magazine, and led to an invitation to join the staff. Two small gents overheard by George Reed to say “Ah see how Fun is smashing Punch They’re forced to get the London Journal chaps to help them!” Pity Gilbert didn’t draw a donkey and not a horse.

div.head: February 24 [1863]. No.11. Tuesday.
div.p: Ada Leech’s birthday party tomorrow
E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M. Champ.

J.L. imitates John Parry’s imitation of shortsighted old gentleman eating radishes and not putting salt on plate to dip them into. J.T. very funny on Saturday at J.L’s (where I met S.B. et ux, Frith et ux and Wingrove Cooke
George Wingrove Cooke (1814-1865), Times correspondent, writer on agriculture.) – french horn and duet – and sticking fox’s brush between his legs à la dog’s tail. Ivory handle sticking out in front – J.L. tells how he in his medical student days bled a fair Jewess, and saved her life the doctor said. And how he was thanked and loaded with presents. This, apropos of his Sundays in the City – H.S. having been last Sunday to St. Paul’s, St. Michael’s, St. (King.Wm. Str.), and St. Saviours – and on to Croydon Mr. Byars in the evening! Catechism at St. Michaels

L.C. P.L. and M.L. and S.B. for a Polish cut against Russia. P.L. suggests King of Prussia as the Hangman’s assistant to the Czar – because he has given up Polish refugees etc. But we all think the Marriage is the topic. “Albert can’t catch me.” – “Before and After” – Princess harpooning the Prince-of Wales (Whales) suggests J.L. in fun. Tells of bride belikening her first f- to a flight of sparrows from her a – pleasant picture. “Last Danish invasion,” says H.M. A perfunctory Cut, says P.L. Climbing up Pole with Russian Bear’s Grease, Crown on top -

J.L. S.B. suggest nuptial Car surrounded by groups showing all the world in a mess. Accepted [Punch, 44 (7 March 1863): 96-97, “At Home and Abroad” ]. Greece an empty throne and auctioneer selling it. Pope trampling on liberty, etc. S.B. tells of the Princess’s health being proposed after a lot of toasts and of his saying “A Needless Alexandra ends the Song.” — S.B. savage against Sala for hinting that the Naggletons are drawn from personal experience.
Punch, 44 (14 February 1863): 69. “Mud That Won’t Stick.” See Sala’s essay, “Breakfast in Bed,” Temple Bar, January 1863, 183-184.Says he waited at the Club on the day that his “Mud that won’t Stick” appeared in the hope that Sala would come and quarrel. Now he views S[ala] as a coward and a skunk and having kicked his a. shall be silent in contempt. H.M. says his brother Gus gets £50 for a description (15 cols.) of Wedding in Illustrated Times. M.L. says Burnand wrote Mokeanna. One of the Fun writers he was – a Cambridge man.

div.head: March 4, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L. C.K., H.M., (late) Thackeray. Champ.
J.L. suggests a comic bill of fare to sell old gourmands – Bacon and custard, Syllabubs and greens, Salmon and oystersauce, Calf’s head and currant jelly, etc., etc.

Thackeray applauds the Bonnie Dundee invitation (by Burnand, I suppose) – but J.L. agrees with me that the notion’s not new. Haven’t we done Ballads from Bedlam by the bushel and didn’t G. à Beckett do mock melodramas by the million. Enter Heavy Father in perspective. Fireworks in the bedroom as usual. Barley water and other rejoicings – old as the hills. But a fresh crop of young readers is always coming up

J.L. tells of old dowager at the Drawing Room addressed by street boy – “Here’s another rosebud!” Thackeray versus Swift for his writing to Stella “How’s Tisdell? Do his feet stink still?” A coward’s blow to hit a rival.

L.C. S.B. suggests Bishops as serpents in cave annoyed by Porcupine Colenso. P.L. – a bolstering match by the Bishops – Punch as Master interfering – J.L. Prince and Princess making tea – or walking on seashore in the Honeymoon shine. S.B. adds Neptune greeting them (accepted) [Punch, 44 (14 March 1863): 107, “The Honeymoon” ]. — P.L. savage against the railways – England will soon be a mere dunghill – everything sacrificed to Utilitarianism.

div.head: Prince of Wales his Wedding.
div.p: March 11, 1863. W[ednesdaly. No. 11.
E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., T.T.

Of course our talk is of the Royal Wedding. London won’t recover from its loyalty just yet. Everybody has gone mad about the Marriage. Valetry of Valetries, all is Valetry, says P.L. And cynically talks about the tendency of people now to gregarious rejoicing over trivial affairs – today we marry, tomorrow comes the smallpox maybe. – Ergo be miserable always, say we all. Men who have had most sorrow are generally the first properly to rejoice says T.T. – life has heavy sorrows so be happy when ye may. T.T. in the Chapel yesterday {as were the Reeds and Jenny Lind and big Bowley and Clark, Mark’s man, as drawer of the curtains: Temple and E. in the Courtyard, and H.S. like a muff at the Crystal Palace where there was kiss in the ring and such like dreary festivities – moreover a beastly fog in Bessborough Street that morning and a jam on London Bridge enough to tear one’s coat off. In the streets people wandering purposelessly about and altogether very melancholy merriment. Somehow I never thought of the possibility of entry – but to the bold all things are possible.} A fine sight that throng of rich colours and jewels, and that once fleecy cloud of white in the midst. T.T. tells how the old dowagers emerged from their queer coverings like fairies out of witches. Bridesmaids not pretty he says. Noticed the gleam of sunshine on the Royal pew as the Queen entered. – The one black spot. Something selfish in such sorrow surely. Rumour says she wished the Chapel hung with black and that the Prince said “Then I’d better bring my Bride in a hearse.” T.T. says Pam looked like an old ape – very flattering to us Pam admirers. Agrees with us that the beauty of Alexandra is not merely in her features – looks good and amiable and wishing to please, and as if she had brains and used them. From the photographs one fancied her dark-haired – but Saturday’s sight of her dispelled this notion. I shan’t soon forget the glimpse of that fair face, bowing incessantly so that nearly everyone believed himself personally bowed to. What a sea of waving handkerchiefs and hats and hands she was borne along upon! I’d no idea the British populace had so many white handkerchiefs. They seemed almost to lift the carriage from its wheels and some of their handkerchiefs must almost have been flapped into her face. Wondrous to see that mass that filled all Fleet Street jammed against the houses when divided by the troopers, coming six abreast at last, and how the tide came flap together again when the wedge had passed.

I was between the Misses Lemon with Mrs. Leech at the corner and Mrs. Sothern next behind her and her husband, Lord Dundreary by my side and Shenton pulling the string that made Punch bow his greeting – funny to see the fat old Aldermen and stiff military swells all gradually burst into a broad grin as they passed. And, touched by her mother’s elbow, how smilingly the Princess herself looked up at Punch and what a good view of her the Punchites so obtained. Somewhat of a cross between a beadle and a ballet girl was Mr. Punch, crowned with white roses and well covered with white favours ... I had walked twice to the Mansionhouse that morning, and taken a sight at London Bridge, too — where the pageant must have had a smack of old Rome about it – and along Cheapside, festooned with flags and with every window full and every housetop fringed with faces.
