And I’d passed through St. Paul’s churchyard by the galleries, 20 deep, where Du Maurier and Grove and George Grimwood[?] and some 15,000 others sat. And so to Fleet Street with its charity children of St. Bride’s perched up by the Church and eating buns and singing psalms as if the gingerbeer had got into their heads. And after all was over and the champagne and 120 dozen oysters were consumed, and I’d chatted with Bob Orridge and his wife and Mrs. Charley Dickens in a splendid Indian mantle which made Fanny’s mouth water, and had been introduced to Burnand and Shirley Brooks’ wife’s cousin, a jolly looking fellow from Glasgow, and had given Master Reginald and his brother a jump – I went to Shine St. for umbrellas, and away we 4 trudged home through the slush to Bessborough Street, where were Joe and Wm. who had dined at Kingston to get out of the mob. – So did Leech and Tenniel go a-hunting down at Baldock and said the old master, “You show good taste.” To Lewis’s that night — where every artist was in raptures with the Princess and her beauty. And wherever each had stood every one seemed satisfied and to have enjoyed the sight.

To return to Tuesday — T.T. tells how the Eton boys charged through the Police – and how Lady Pam wandered carriageless about till T.T. and another came to her relief. Strange to see the diamonded duchesses sitting in 3rd class carriages! – But the Illumination sufferings were worse. Ben Head on a bus from 7 o’clock till 4, via back slums to London Bridge and home by Lambeth where all the gas was out. Sterry[?] for 5 hours trying to get from Camberwell over Westminster Bridge — while Miss Loughborough and I followed in the wake of Fanny and the Old Un, with T. and E. at our heels and saw Bond Street and Poole’s and Regent Street and Charing Cross and so home by 11:30 by the Horseguards and Treasury, which was best of all. Plastered with white mud we were, but uncrushed and safe — the only bad squeeze being at the bottom of Bond Street, where we were borne out into Picadilly again by a down coming rush. A cold rain and hail fell just at five and made the slush.
Compare Silver’s description here to the one he wrote for the magazine, “Punch at the Procession,” Punch 44 (21 March 1863) 116. The attribution to Silver, from the ledgers, can be found in the Curran Index.
Well, for L.C. J.L. suggests Pam setting to rights. accepted [Punch, 44 (21 March 1863): 119, “Setting to Rights” ], spite of Evans’ objection that it will come late.

div.head: March 18, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., T.T.

J.L. at foxhunting dinner at Stortford yesterday to present Parry with his portrait. S.B. rather sneers at the speeches which J.L. says he quite enjoyed. Admires Soapy Sponge and “cuss them Seidlitz powders” — just as about to jump.
R. S. Surtees, Mr Sponge's Sporting Tour, published by Bradbury and Evans in 1853, with illustrations by John Leech. Seidlitz powder was a mild laxative, combining sodium bicarbonate and tartaric acid.

Talk anent Spirit rappers again – P.L. would like a crucial test before he would say finally that the thing is all humbug: or Humebug. J.L. met Hume t’other evening at Senior’s and thought him facially an Impostor. Until they’ll do their tricks by daylight there’s no sense in giving them a moment’s thought. Should impanel a jury of conjurors and lawyers.

L.C. Poland: and the Bill to shut up the Publics on a Sunday which was brought in by a swinging majority on first reading! [Punch, 44 (28 March 1863): 130, “Probable Effect of Mr. Somes’s Sunday Closing Bill” ]. For the latter J.L. suggests Lord Dundreary and Hodge – “What shut the Pig and Tinderbox”...”A – r and the Staw and Gawter.”

For Poland – T.T. suggests Billiards, France cannoning off in order to hole Prussia. But it wouldn’t be well understood we think. J.L. suggests Polish woman banging the Bear with a broomstick, for the Russians have been getting the worst of it. M.L. Poland appealing to John Bull/Prussia, “If you can’t help me, don’t help the Bear.” – M.L. Poland firing her fetters – chainshot (accepted) [Punch, 44 (28 March 1863): 131, “Poland’s Chain-Shot”] out of a tree gun, says T.T. but this would imply weakness and almost ridicule – P.L. Bear climbing up pole, Liberty above him cutting at him with a scythe – H.M. Poland shaving the Bear. J.T. & S.B. John Bull as Pecksniff, “You have my sympathy, but I can’t relieve you.” (“Then we come to the ridiculously small sum of 18 pence” — That, said Mr. Pecksniff, would be equally objectionable.)

H.M. applauds the Nuptial Number – “ rises with the occasion,” says Shirley. Tells of his doing the Duke’s funeral for the [Morning] Chronicle, and jotting down notes of sentiment – The pall of the grey morning – Nature and her sables – etc.
Morning Chronicle, 19 November 1852, p. 5. Sala and the reporters were really Gentlemen of the Press in the procession t’other day – nearly pressed to rib breaking in some places. Bellew and others in carriages and saw. Times had 8 or 10 at different places.

S.B. tells of lady addressing her husband, “Too late, too late, you cannot enter now”
From Guinevere’s song in Tennyson’s Idylls of the King.

div.head: March 25, 1863. W[ednesday]. N. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., T.T.

T.T. seeing Sothern t’other night. Next Wednesday his last and 39th night. Acting elaborated after old school. “You don’t act with your legs” said old Farren.
Actor-manager William Farren (1786-1861). Actors nowadays expect a part to act itself.... Ellen Terry very promising debutante he says. Pity Oxenford allows his mouth to be stopped. No one has such power to improve the stage.
John Oxenford (1812-1877), theatre critic for the Times. Oxenford had been an early contributor to Punch in 1842-43.

L.C. J.L. suggests by a written note, – something about the Staleybridge rioters — Pottering – S.B. Charity hands them over to Sister Justice.... S.B. suggests Income tax cut on Gladstone’s speech — Gladstone with hand in Clerk’s pocket – amended to cut as it stands [ Punch, 44 (4 April 1863): 141, “Gladstone Salve–For Tender Consciences” ].
Outram’s funeral today. S.B. and T.T. there. Jaw about Colenso. Why should not the Bible be subjected to revision? Is our knowledge of it not subject to improvement?

div.head: April 1, 1863. [Wednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., Thackeray.

J.L. been staying with Nethercote in Northamptonshire – don’t I just recollect him as an old Carthusian cricketer — short and curly haired and jolly. Went a crack meet of the Pytchley. Nothing like a grass country!
Talk of Sala breakfasting in bed – his red nose and pale face emerging from the sheets. D—d clever fellow repeats Thackeray – but J.L. can’t read him.

Thackeray says he always takes some brandy and soda before breakfast to give him an appetite – talks of using that umbrella instr. for his erectile tissue – erectile disuse it has now fallen into. Better abstain from drink, says E. But I like drink, says T.
J.L. tells of little girl, “Papa, can’t you induce Mamma to have another baby.”
J.T. means to go in for oil painting this year, hates woodwork. Pity Millais sticks to it – but then there’s the filthy lucre.

L.C. American turning of Mississippi to War purposes – flooding country by Vicksburg. Xerxes lashing the waves (P.L.)X – City Police. Gog and Magog as imbecile peelers (H.S.) – in a crowd, wishing for Metropolitans (J.T.) [Punch, 44 (11 April 1863): 151, “The City Police” ]

Thackeray says he writes when he sits down to write – as soon as he gets his nose to the desk, his ideas come. P.L. like H.S. often requires ambulation to assist his inspiration – carries a pencil and jots down as he journeys. Jerrold and Shirley and Tom Tailor like Thackeray work at will.
X Pam his visit to Glasgow etc. – “a little ‘oliday” to him.

Thackeray defends Colenso and denies the Creation in 6 Days – Jonah and sun standing still etc. he views as fables – as does P.L.: on scientific grounds. H.S. cannot see why the Bible should not be revised when correction in justified. If evidence of defects be furnished, surely those defects should be corrected.

div.head: April 7, 1863. Tu[esday]. Bedford.
div.p: M.L., S.B., J.T., H.S., P.L. Champ[agne].
Cosy little dinner. (H.S. from spending Easter at Woodbridge — Good Friday quite hot, pulled to Wilford and flowerised.) S.B. been to Sheffield, armour plate seeing.

M.L. tells of Paxton and how he cut some trees down during lunchtime to clear a view, Duke irate “Where’s Paxton? – “Gone to Doncaster, your Grace.” M.L. at Chatsworth when Victoria Regia first bloomed: in came a gardener at dinnertime and out went they all to see it. Flower cut for the Queen – faded – revived by warm water poured into stalk. – fine sand put to root to imitate the nibbling of fish, didn’t bloom till then.
The giant Victoria Regia lily, brought to Kew from the Amazon and grown by Paxton at Chatsworth from a seedling, soon boasted leaves four feet in diameter. The lily bloomed in 1849 and was featured in the Illustrated London News 15 (17 November 1849) 328. Paxton designed and built the innovative Victoria Regia House for it, which pioneered techniques he would employ in the Cyrstal Palace. For an exhaustive account of the episode, see Margaret Flanders Darby, “Joseph Paxton's Water Lily,” in Michel Conan, Bourgeois and Aristocratic Cultural Encounters, 1550-1850 (Washington, D.C.: Dumbarton Oaks, 2002), 255-283.

L.C. Scotch kittens as described by J.O. yesterday. – After 2 or 3 hints, P.L. suggests Macbeth scene and S.B. agrees to do the verses. [ Punch, 44 (18 April 1863): 161, “The Scotch Witches' Caldron”] Genius Caledonia teaching Britannia rejected. S.B. tells of his boy Reginald saying “I ate it with the greatest re-lish.”

div.head: April 15, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L. P.L., C.K., T.T. Champ.
Mark a grandfather at noon to-day — the Princess Alice of Crawley as Shirley calls her is therefore toasted and her infant heiress.

J.L. tells of his rushing out of bed to silence some volunteers as he thought them, who were playing by a public near – “We’re Foresters, Sir,” said one. “Then why the devil don’t you go and play in the forest” returned L.
C.K. had a wretched cold and cough in his French trip with Stewart. Got to Biarritz tho’ and into Spain. Spanish bread capital.

J.L. tells of Millais painting his new St. Agnes picture with a dark lanthern in the moonlight, and discovering that the painted window did not cast a “bloody light” as Keats and Sir Walter have said it does. No colors at all are cast — only dark and light.

L.C. Gladstone’s budget tomorrow – tea duty reduced and 2d off Income Tax – says T.T. Suggests Pam plastering G[ladstone]’s face after his late tumble, getting him fit for speaking. S.B. suggests Poland – hitting the bear, who holds out “Amnesty” – accepted [Punch, 44 (25 April 1863): 171, “The Amnesty”]. {H.S. to the first New Phil. & hears the Eroica with Davidson and Grove.}
T.T. suggests Russian Bear and Polish bees – bear with sore head. But these have been done.

div.head: April 22, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M.

Talk of Lewis and the swell new house he has taken by Holland Park – had only half an hour to decide – gives £5000 for 26 years: and £30 ground rent. S.B. suggests the possibility of his reading over articles of War and one of his men asking “Any other article?” Makes £8000[?] from his business, J.L. thinks.

S.B. tells of his living in Islington when a boy and filling waterpot in New River and tumbling in – also of boy writing to little girl “the Romans of old were accustomed we’re told before they had paper invented to wipe clean their a – with a tuft of wet grass with which they were jolly contented” And then adding PS, A – what we call bottom.

J.L. tells of Highland piper getting on ’bus and conductor saying, Bl[ood]y nice thing for the knifeboard, ain’t he, Bill? Tells of that Arcedeckne giving a shilling to some street players who were annoying J.L. at the Garrick – a very rude trick. A. seeing Palgrave Simpson, Reade and Dance dining together said, “How are ye, my three translators?” Noblest work of God, said A[rcedeckne]. “An honest lawyer’s the noblest work of the other party.” But wealthy wit is always laughed at.
S.B. and C.K. talk of Bishop Bloomfield’s life and stories – “All we like sheep have gone astray” – in time and tune: “Singers went before and minstrels followed after.”

L.C. Budget – Gladstone as Monk of La Trappe digging his own grave because ‘tis said Oxford won’t stand for his liberality. M.L. – City Police, Mayor & Corporation barricading Temple Bar against the Reformers – fighting Sir G. Grey. M.L. – Budget, John Bull as Hamlet, “For this relief (2d income tax) much thanks.” P.L. – Americans interfering with our ships, don’t rouse the Lion. P.L. & J.L. (accepted). [Punch, 44 (2 May 1863): 181, “’Beware!’” .]
Fire in Johnson’s Court. H.S. to Lydia’s benefit at D.L. with N. Gascoigne.

div.head: April 29, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., S.B., P.L., H.M. champ.
Shirley’s birthday – so we crush a cup to his happy returns. M.L. has neuralgia in his eyes, from overwork at night, says his doctor.

L.C. J.L. suggests American billiards, common game, H.S. adds Time for marker [Punch, 44 (9 May 1863): 191, “The Great ‘Cannon’ Game” ]. Nil mirabile in talk – H.S., fr. Woodbridge, ce matin and to hear Carlotta Patti at New Phil. ce soir.X
P.L. repeats lines he wrote on a TD[?] and which appeared in the Poets’ Corner of a Hants. paper.
L.C. Forgot that M.L. suggests North and South as Viragos quarreling and Britannia pitying.

X The Examiner rightly calls her voice “pleasingly astonishing but not astonishingly pleasing.”
Examiner, Issue 2882 (25 April 1863) 268. Carlotta Patti (1840-1889), elder sister of the better known soprano Adelina Patti, was appearing at the Italian Opera House, Covent Garden, in Mozart’s The Magic Flute.
J.L. describes monkey anxiously examining the sore tip of his tail – (hasn’t H.S. done the ditto?).

div.head: May 6, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M. champ.

A suggestion from Severn of the Privy Council Office to “My dear Leech” as to using an opera glass at the R[oyal] A[cademy]. (Shirley used to write to Mr. Brown as “My dear Wiggins,” because he affectedly spelt his (Shirley’s) name wrong.) Wonderful is the density of outsiders as to what is a joke. Fancy Bridgman of Norwich suggesting a new see for Colenso – Coventry!

Apropos of The Athalie at C[rystal] P[alace] on Mayday (Where H.S. met J.M. & ux[or] and Ida and thought quantum mutatus ab illo rhapsodico of the Handel Festival 1859 but a year of London sadly takes the gush out of one). S.B. talks about Beethoven and regrets that better words are not put to Fidelio. P.L. and H.S. agree as to Beethoven inspiring them with happiness and goodness.

J.L. contends that Millais’ girl in St. Agnes picture is very pretty. Might have brought in a moonbeam as a high light on her head — marvellous that mermaidish appearance given by the seaweedy green dress at her feet. Is it true that moonbeams don’t carry colour? H.S. at R[oyal] A[cademy] opening on Monday – meeting Andrews and a host of artists as usual. J.L. said it was sickening to see Eastlake & Co. stretching their hands out to shake the Prince of Wales’s on Saturday. Melted butter speeches in profusion.
A souperfishial dinner (G.A. a B.).
S.B. quotes hymns written by Dissenters to show what the Church owes them.

L.C. One or two mild suggestions And then M.L. 3 powers saying “humph” to Russian Note [Punch, 44 (16 May 1863): 201, “Russia’s ‘Evasive Answer’” ]. (H.S. see[?] Alexandra and Albert Edward – continually bowing in Rotten Row tomorrow as he Punchises[?].)
(H.M.: 3 powers waging a pen and ink war for Poland.) S.B. Russia pointing to Poland chained, “He’d be quiet if you’d only let him alone.”
C.K. suggests as a practical joke for someone to stick a big pasteboard lion on the Nelson pillar pedestal.

div.head: May 13, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K.

S.B. writes M.L.: “I’ve just received this notion from Shirley – Victor Emmanuel with baby Italy and Dr. John Bull saying, ‘Never mind what old women may cackle vaccinate your child from my daughter Liberty and she’ll grow up strong enough soon.’”X But Evans suggests a Derby subject – and H.S. and C.K. work it up into John Bull winning the World’s Stakes spite of weight of taxes [Punch, 44 (23 May 1863): 211, “The Derby, 1863 –Portrait of the Winner” ].

X S.B. adds imaginary conversation, J.T. objects, Evans says “poor little dear – holy feelings of paternity are not to be made fun of.” J.L. and the rest “Capital – now Mark touch the bell for more claret.”

div.head: May 27, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., W.M.T.

E. repeats his thanks for the rooks (15) which H.S. shot on Monday week at Finchley[?], well[?]. J.L. figures E. tripping down his garden before breakfast with a basket gathering roses – Jacquinetta discovered asleep, awakes, “Ah! My[?] Corydon! Is it a maypole that I see before me?” – W.M.T. — who inter alia discourseth of Frank Stone having married a woman he’d lived with – his history forming the Shabby Genteel Story – “Give me your story,” said W.M.T. to him, and used it. Now his son Marcus it is said has behaved ill to his mother, whom Frank wished not to live with his children, and so Marcus will be pilled at the Garrick, as Lord Coventry hath been.
Stone was not, after all, “pilled” at the Garrick. Brooks was on the Garrick committee, and his diary entry for April 2, 1864 reads: “There had been a set against [Stone], touching certain alleged misusage of his mother, but 3 men said that they had made enquiries, and were satisfied, so he came in unanimously.” (Houghton Library)
E. says he never could find out in what he offended Dickens. And Thackeray says D. cried at The Athenaeum when T. spoke to him anent the quarrel. Dickens always acting – has the vanity of an actor.

Talk of dining at the Bear at Esher. W.M.T. says he told his daughters he wished they’d take the Bear at Esher – Well they did take the Bear to Esher says S.B., since you went and dined there with them.

L.C. P.L. suggests Yankee Conscription – Irishmen used up – must fight their own battles now. – The late Victorious Retreat of Hooker, taking Richmond with a Hook – er (J.L.). Arcades Sambo W.M.T. But the discovery of the Nile by Speke is the great English subject and triumph says S.B. The battle of the Nile has once more been won by England – and so lets have a glorification cut – Britannia and Father Thames and Father Nile. – Picnic at the Nile source, says J.L. Honor est ex Nilo – Father Thames looking at the White Nile – “Ah I wish I were as white as you” P.L. – S.B. accepts [ Punch, 44 (6 June 1863): 233, “Britannia Discovering the Source of the Nile” ].

Talk of Gil. à B[eckett] as a quiet pleasant talker – answering D.J[errold]’s fulminations with a pithy pregnant joke. J.L. used to do battle with D.J. about the People and their rights. Noisy Punch dinners 10 years ago, or more. M.L. tells of his M.L.’s taking Gil to Vauxhall and leaving him in supper box with a brace of bonnets and a bowl of punch and then walking in front of the supper box and saying Oh fie! at him. As they danced a saraband in returning to Gil’s house, appeareth Mrs. Gil at the gate – ! Oh horror! – A detestable unwomanly woman says W.M.T. – denied her second husband Jones conjugal rights! Oh! and has gone to India – to her son-in-law’s delight there.

W.M.T. breakfasting at Gladstone’s t’other day and met Yankee lawyer and said to him “Thanks to your press warning me about investments, I sold out and so escaped the threatened repudiation.” W.M.T. rather fond of talking of his money – and of his want of it. Had to borrow lately he says. Write me some more yellow leaves says Pater. Who proposes to dine at Greenwich next. I like Silver better without his beard, says Thackeray. Silver likes himself best with it says H.S.: for thereby he saves himself 300 surgical operations every year. Monday January 12 was his last day of shaving. Biographers, take note of this.

 [drawing of pointing finger] The Derby last Wednesday. H.S. with Frith and Sanders the blackbearded, home by Fred Evans’ dining with Charley Dickens and Joyce and Harper the Yankee and Leslie the Falallou Singer – drenching cold miserable day – couldn’t get jolly anyhow. \ to finish. McAroni the winner by a short head – beating Lord Clifden.

 [drawing of pointing finger] Thackeray says it takes him 2 or 3 days to plan a paper but when he sits down he writes currente calamo – so did Jerrold, scarcely ever correcting. Dickens corrects and corrects till his copy is a maze of interlineations. S.B. and Sala write very fair copy. P.L. pencils his ideas out walking – as does H.S.

div.head: June 3, 1863. W[ednesday]. Greenwich. Quartermaine’s the Ship.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S. (from Woodbridge), S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., Fred Evans, Wm. Bradbury.

Only 17 courses of fish before the whitebait — filet de soles à l’Alexandra of course. Trout peu et simple, very delicate and nice. No cold salmon and horseradish ice which of course came so well after the curry at the Trafalgar and lives still in my memory. Somehow everyone seemed dull or disputatious. J.L. savage at street noises, driving him to suicide he says. P.L. gets silently drunk, and is propped inside the omnibus and committed to Leech’s cab. Then we adjourn to the Craven for seltzer and H.S. to E.M. for a good \ [Greek word Κςιΰσλιυε] notwithstanding. Scarcely a joke made all dinnertime. J.L. tells of Irishman looking at Greenwich Hospital and saying “It reminds me of me fawther’s stables, bedad!”

L.C. S.B. wants something about the French Elections – Thiers coming in, despite the Government, nearly all the Govt. people defeated. Show how little Louis is liked. But J.L. thinks the Somes Sunday Beer Bill a more public matter, and so suggests a blowing from the beer barrel, which is accepted faute de mieux [ Punch, 44 (13 June 1863): 243, “A Settler for Somes’s Stale Beer Bill” ].
Second reading of a bill to close pubs on Sunday; see Times for June 4, 1863, p. 8.
That water souchy – perch and flounders etc. seems a mild beginning of a feed. For delicate stomachs one would suggest a semolina pudding, an entree of arrowroot and a bowl of pap to follow.

div.head: June 10, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. dines with T & E, at Ben’s Head’s after the Memorial Fete – where he introduced E. to S.B.

div.head: June 17, 1863. W[ednesday]. The Mitre. Hampton Court. First Strawberries.
div.p: E., S.B., Wm. Bradbury, H.S., Fred. Evans, J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., F.C. Burnand (his debut), T.T.

Burnand’s first Punch Dinner – seems more at home than H.S. felt at his. But H.S. was always a modest young gentleman. By Jove these four years of Punch Dinners have aged his feelings rather! What a contentus parvo he was – and now what a blasé beast he sometimes feels. Not altogether used up tho’ – he can still enjoy a dance (teste the Rifle Ball last Friday week, when he booked Miss Frodsham the yacht-lover for four dances following, and had a small flirtation with her on the steps in the Refrigerating Room). Teste also the first Dance party that Fanny gives at Bessboro’ St. next Friday when Emma and Lettie hope to go after hearing Charles Hallé.
Charles Hallé (1819-1893) German conductor who moved to England and founded the Hallé Orchestra in Manchester in 1858.
Talk of Faust at Her Majesty’s which seems a great success. S.B. says why don’t Gounod write the Brocken scene? What a fine thing Gye might make of it upon his splendid stage!

L.C. The buying of Fowke’s Folly. P.L. suggests Pam as Plasterer whitewashing the building à la Madame Rachel “beautiful for ever,” so as to hide defects and uglinesses. T.T. and C.K. contend that the building is not so very hideous — Fowke was stinted in money and so forced to skimp the work. [ Punch, 44 (27 June 1863): 263, “Putting a Good Face on It” .]
Engineer Francis Fowke (1823-1865) designed the International Exhibition building in 1862.Jolly evening – every one seemed as if his bosom lord sat lightly in his Throne. Burnand has the loud laugh that (in his case does not) speak the vacant mind. Neat natty little fellow he is – an Eton boy he was and married a rather pretty actress. – H.S. meets with [Greek transliteration of name that looks like “Loo Watson”], a pleasantly substantial firm bottomed Carlisle party \\\!

div.head: June 24, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., C.K., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., Thackeray.
Leech salmon fishing with Millais: happy fellow! ... Is he?

Talk of the Murdered Milliner, and Mr. Isaacson’s beautiful letter in The Times to-day.
Fred. W. Isaacson, husband of Madame Elise after whom the millinery shop at 170 Regent Street was named. Silver is being sarcastic in calling his letter in the times of this date “beautiful,” as it is rife with misspellings, etc. The death of Mary Ann Walkley, 20, due to apoplexy brought on by overwork in a crowded, ill-ventilated room, is described in “Worked to Death,” Times, June 24, 1863, p. 7. A leader of this same date, p. 11, replies to the Isacson letter and condemns milliners. Madame Elise – the Champs Elysées says W.M.T. S.B. by letter suggests the Milliner’s Black Hole for the Cut – only the ribald might twist it — Skeleton in the Wardrobe, H.M. Thackeray says his daughters always order their dresses a month beforehand – and E. contends that the Mantalinis can’t help the press of business.
Mr. and Madame Mantalini, milliners, are Kate Nickleby’s employers in Dickens’s Nicholas Nickleby. Bosh! M.L. and P.L. and H.S. stick out for the commonsense view – that the Mantalinis overwork their slaves, and wear them up because there’s always a fresh supply of flesh and blood material. Journeyman tailors work at 6d an hour, and won’t work more than 12 hours a day. Milliners keep their girls in the house and work them at 6/- a week, and so get all the work they can out of them. — So we stick up for M.L. and his Ghost in the Workroom – despite Evans,- who maybe overworks the girls who fold up Punch etc.[Punch, 45 (4 July 1863): 5, “The Haunted Lady, Or 'The Ghost' in the Looking-Glass” ]. P.L. suggests Venus attired by the Spectres – not a bad notion, but the other is more apropos. — Thackeray suggests Lady Godiva, going to Court independent of the milliners. Better go without their dress — that’s what you’d like to see, old boy (says he to E.). He also suggests White Slaves, sort of set off to the Negroes. And P.L. hints that going to Court in a hearse instead of a carriage would do but M.L.’s (and F.C.B.’s, n’est-ce pas?) is the best.
M.L. tells of an old Bawd writing “Come and sup, we’re going to tap the Youn un.”
Thackeray tells of Cow sucking herself, and Mrs. Billy Russell saying “How fat she must get!” A beautiful Irish Bull Cow this!

div.head: July 1, 1863. W[ednesday]. The Greyhound, Dulwich.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., W. Bradbury, S.B., J.T., M.L., Burnand, C.K., Fred Evans, H.M., Thackeray.

Skittles – M.L. and H.S. beat C.K. and J.T. –Jolly hot summer’s day, after a showery June. H.M. applauds Bright’s speech last night on the Roebuck and Napoleon interview – quotes Roebuck saying of the Cherbourg visit “I saw him with his perjured lips pollute her hallowed cheek.” This Tearem ambassadorship does for the cut but everyone is too jolly to discuss it very deeply.
Roebuck had proposed recognition of the Confederacy. (See Times 1 July, article p. 8, Times leader p. 11.) Roebuck claimed that Louis Napoleon had told him that the time had come to recognize the Confederacy, whereupon Roebuck proposed joint recognition with France. See the speech by John Bright (Times 1 July p. 10) in which he quotes the earlier Roebuck speech that “he adopted the character of ‘Tear ‘em,’ and was still at his post,” and also quotes Roebuck re: “perjured lips” remark. Burnand says he wonders how Tenniel gets the notion out of such a chaos of talk about it [Punch, 45 (11 July 1863): 15, “'Tear'em' at the Tuileries” ].
J.L. tells of Millais at a swell’s playing alphabet game and saying “I want a P.”
[At the bottom of the following page is a drawing of a hand pointing.]

By the way on Monday the 29 I went to Ely with Shenton and afterwards to the Arundel, where he stuck me up—at last. – Byron a goodish looking fellow, with an interminable flux of ‘puns – Horsley the C[rystal’ P[alace] director is a solicitor at home and a punster abroad – becomes terribly wearying when every word is played upon and twisted inside out. H. went with Dean to Soho Theatre – “Ah yes, that was Dean’ s (s)treat” says B[urnand]. —Left off suit of clothes B[urnand] calls his “leavery.” And so on and so on and so on. H.S. dumb – not quick with his tongue, where others are quicker.

div.head: July 8, 1863. W[ednesdayJ. No. 11
div.p: [At top, titles in black ink, HS handwriting, underlined: JL bad sport salmon fishing. M.L. imitates Celeste. Frith’s Wedding Picture; Prince of Wales; Byron the Burlesque; Warwick at New House.”]
E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., C.K., T.T.
H.S. from Canterbury ce matin – leaving the hops and crops looking splendidly.

J.L. describes salmon tugging fellow to the brink of a fall, and then leaping down and carrying away the line. Had wretched sport – all the fish 9 miles further up – fancy paying £100 a month for it! The Pass of Glencoe a fearfully wild looking place, sure to be a storm there. Newton painted it under difficulties – 5 miles walk, and a lousy cottage.

M.L. imitates Celeste’s melodramatic description of herself on the Mer de Glace – “I walk along – I slip – I hear a cry – I look before me – grand ciel! I see an unfathomable abyss yawning at my feet! It is a crevasse – I shudder and cry Help! – the guides seize me – I am saved!”
Madame Céline Céleste (1815-1882), French actress, managed the Lyceum Theatre in London from 1859 to 1861.— Jerrold used to call her legs a two pronged fork, says Leech. — Who describes Frith’s treatment of the Swellesses who come and sit for the Marriage Picture and say “Oh please be quick with this bother – I was dancing with the Prince till 3, and I really can’t spare time” etc., etc. Frith says “Oh of course I can get a model to do all I want – only if your ladyship would like your face to be known, you must submit to sit to me.”—Then the mamma says, “My dear, attend to Mr. Frith” etc.
T.T. tells of Irish lady saying “Our asparagus is so large its quite ondacent to handle it!”

L.C. Shirley by letter suggests John Bull and Britannia (an original beginning) with map before them, deciding that they’d best stay at home this year, foreign countries so unsettled [Punch, 45 (1863): 25, “Stay-at-Home Travellers”].

J.L. describes his wretchedness at finding plasterers at work outside his window in Scotland t’other day – where he went for quiet! Has had to buy a wheel-wright out of his knocking shop at back of his house – poor fellow, what a martyr he is to street noises.
Asks J.T. and C.K. and myself to a chop on Friday – J.L. thinks Burnand has quite sufficiently a good opinion of himself – yes, I doubt if they’ll fraternise.

div.head: July 15, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., H.M., Thackeray (late).
H.S. from Wimbledon – a hot walk from Wandsworth. E. was at the Camp on Sunday and saw the shoe blacks parade after church, all drest in black—should have been dressed in blacking says J.L.

L.C. – Meade v. Lee – battles of Gettysburg – meanwhile Brazil is the only subject up. J.L. suggests Lord John trying to crack a Brazil nut (how to get out of his exorbitant demands on the Brazil Government about that shipwreck is the question). [Punch, 45 (25 July 1863): 35, “Humble Pie at the Foreign Office” ] M.L. and S.B. amend it in a shower of small talk about everything, including the short stout old gentleman who flogged the girl tied to a ladder in Dean Street, and who of course was Pater, with his specs off to conceal his identity.

J.L. means to do the Swells as Hotel Proprietors and waiters – Swellesses as Chambermaids etc. Mr. Gladstone will provide the wine etc. etc. Good subject says everybody, for every Times contains a new Hotel prospec-tus with a Lord or two in it.

H.M. and M.L. talk of old times – and how Gil à Beckett brought out “The Thief” – a reprint of all the best magazine articles and issued big posters “Stop the Thief!” “Take The Thief!” Another paper he started called “Hell’s News” and purporting to give the Latest Arrivals.
M.L. tells of actress with low dress and gallery Irish wag crying out – “Mrs. Bubbs dear, put the lid on, the dumplings are boiling over.”
Pleasant dinner—W.M.T. cheering up after CDness and inviting us for next week.

div.head: July 22, 1863. W[ednesdax] at Thackeray’s – Palace Green.
div.p: W.M.T., de Leon (Southerner), Beacher (Cousin from Ca-nada: barrister), T.T., S.B., J.T., E., M.L., Burnand, C.K., H.M., H.S., J.L.(right hand of host).
H.S. from Woodbridge per Queen of the Orwell – reached L.B. at 4 with a strong headwind. Stormy showery day for Harwich regatta, where Shenton and Temple are in Fitzgerlad’s new schooner.

De Leon described in Cornhill how he has run the blockade with his wife in a ship full of powder and a shell fell into some wet coffee and didn’t burst. Of course he’s anxious for the South to be recognised, so that the Blockade shall cease. Says all their wine and spirits are sent to Hospitals – for 6 months he never even tasted tea or coffee. So that the Southerners really are put to hardships – even the richest of them.
Edwin De Leon (1818-1891), Confederate diplomat and writer. The article is “How We Broke the Blockade,” Cornhill 6 (October 1862), 471-479.

Beacher shows us a Greenback and some of the postage stamp money which passes current now in the North. — We luxuriate in 2 plates of Painter’s Turtle – a turbot – curried lobster – venison pie – cold beef – tart and jelly bloaters – ice cream after cheese: but the conversation is subdued and not remarkable for brilliance. Thackeray shows us some sketches for The Virginians – and some he took in the South. Niggers pompously saluting one another on their Sunday out – Southerner picking his teeth with a bowie knife etc. – 2 children at Calais at shopdoor piled with P. pots: “The Little Merchant.” —Dined with Todd Heatley the Wine Merchant yesterday and with J.L. tomorrow – when will H.S. do three turtle feasts running! Friday and Monday week tho’ he dined with J.L. and the latter time had turtle under the weeping ash and so he oughtn’t to be envious. Turtle is one of the few things that there’s no mistake about says Leech and H.S. quite agrees with him. But even for turtle the appetite dies out when one gets blasé.
S.B. discovered that H[orace] Mayhew is named in Shakespeare. “The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman. Modo he’s called and Mayhew.”

Burnand has been to Seaford with George Meredith – will be a big place, he prophesies. Beautiful cliffs: close to Beaches. J.L. takes a house at Broadstairs for his family – where Pater and his are. Where will H.S. go? To Ireland, or Dieppe? What a discontented un-decided dog he is: would be ever so much livelier if he had a wife to stir his blood judiciously.

S.B. says that a Mr. Story (a Yankee) met the Punch lot at Thackeray’s (was it not in 1859 that Handel Festival day, when H.M. praised the pretti-ness of Ida, whom he met at the C[rystal] P[alace]with me as her escort?) and wrote that they were not very brilliant in their talk. Tom Taylor says, men who write are resting when they dine, don’t waste their capital. Denies that any man even purposely keeps back a good thing if he thinks of it. Blurts it out at table and prints it afterwards.

Thackeray points to the Gentleman’s Magazine as being “always pleasant reading.” – Tells of his Pear-tree burglary, and his fear of American Share Confiscation, and how he got £100 a piece for the Roundabouts he wrote in consequence.

div.head: July 29, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. l.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B.(debut at No. 11), H.M.

S.B. says that Charles Kean acts as Chaplain aboard the ship that’s taking him to Australia, and J.T. imitates him saying “D-dearly beloved Brethred” and throwing the Kean emphasis on the words, and the nasal tone etc. Wonder if his habit of acting Macbeth makes him find “Amen” stick in his throat. — J.L. tells of small boy reproved by governess for standing to P and saying “Shan’t sit down and P out of my bottom like a girl.”

L.C. Burnand suggests Emancipation of Niggers by hanging, as was done by the New Yorkers. M.L. amends the picture of a hanging nigger by introducing the mob of rowdies pursuing – the word Rowdy the right one, to separate the act from the civilised New Yorkers.
See special report on horrific hangings and burnings during New York City conscription riots, Times, July 28, 1863, p. 12, the writer of which couples the Emancipation Proclamation with hatred for the war and for Negroes by rioters. [Punch, 46 (1 August 1863) 57, “ ‘Rowdy’ Notions of Emancipation”]
— Slaves for want of legislation are not quite like slaves by law – P.L.

Talk of Stella Colas, the Fechter in petticoats whom H.S. goes to see tonight and joins M.L. and F.C.B. in disliking – hoarse throaty gasping frenchy voice – nice figure.
French actess Stella Colas made a sensation that summer as Juliet at the Princess’s Theatre. See Erroll Sherson, London’s Lost Theatres of the Nineteenth Century (London: Ayers, 1925), 153-156. P.L. compares the Nurse’s bawdiness etc. to the gargoyles on some great Gothic building.
 [drawing of pointing hand]: Last Strawberries.

div.head: August 5, 1863. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: —Faust at C[rystal] P[alace] and the “Sea Urchins” at Putney. Charley Dickens winning the £20 cup and S.B. and Pater going there to see. (vide Punch)

div.head: August 12, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., (H.S. from Woodbridge by Queen of O. ce jour: after his birthdayification.)

J.L. has taken his people to Worthing. Where Pater lost a girl of 5 years old, and consequently would not like to stay now. Tells of open air preaching nuisance. Leech finds a nuisance everywhere, poor devil!

L.C. Capture of Nana Sahib – Calcraft singing “O Nana wilt thou gang with me” P.L. – but H.M. & H.S. think the subject not one to be treated jocularly: too many sad memories. —Then we discuss the Mexican question - L[ouis] Nao[oleon] assuming the Emperorship – on saying to his Deputy. You’ve just as much right to it as I had to mine. Elected of the Millions, and the Maximilians (adds Thackeray) – S.B. suggests ghost of old Buony rising, and Nephew saying—See I carry out your plans – extend the Empire etc.—The Lynn Railway accident, running over a cow and upsetting train - railway fiend devouring excursionists (S.B.)
An excursion train on the Lynn and Hunstanton Railway line derailed near King’s Lynn on the night of August 3, killing five people in the third-class carriages (Times, Augst 5, 1863, p. 10). – A Holiday Cut, says J.L., – J.T. works out notion of British Lion bathing [Punch, 46 (22 August 1863): 79, “The British Lion's Holiday” ] – “Still call it Mexico” says Burnand with his loud laugh. Not a bad fellow tho’ – albeit a noisy one. Had a jaw about Romanism with Leigh this day fortnight I hear. And spoke with sense L[eigh] says. Not bigoted like Doyle. – F.C.B. suggests the Donkey Show – but that’s not off yet. Somehow the old Yates row crops up, and Thackeray fires at Horace and says “D – n it, you fellows still seem to think it was because of his attack upon my nose that I fell foul of him. I don’t care a d – n for my nose – but he imputed dishonourable conduct to me – and for that I got him kicked – out of the Garrick.” – With your strength you might have been more generous, says Horace. And Thackeray blazes up – and finally bolts.
The “old Yates row” alludes to the Garrick Club Affair in the summer of 1858. Edmund Yates wrote an unflattering article about Thackeray in the June 12 number of a short-lived magazine called Town Talk, whereupon Thackeray engineered Yates's expulsion from the Garrick for conduct unbecoming a gentleman. Dickens acted as Yates's supporter throughout, causing an estrangement between the two novelists. For the most extensive recent treatment of the Garrick Club Affair, and its connections to the Dickens scandal, see Leary, Punch Brotherhood, 92-99. The allusion here to Yates's description of Thackeray’s broken nose, about which the novelist was known to be sensitive, appears to have become a commonplace shorthand for Yates’s offense even among Thackeray’s champions. One of them, James Hannay, in the course of a flippant attack on Yates in the Pall Mall Gazette in 1865, reminded readers that he had been thrown out of a club “for writing an article on a gentleman’s nose” (Edwards, Dickens’s Young Men, 113), while the short-lived Arrow reviled Yates for having made “facial blemishes a theme for public tattle” (6 August 1864, p. 11). In his memoirs, F. C. Burnand gives a vivid account of Thackeray’s angry reaction at this meeting (“Down came Thackeray’s fist like a sledge-hammer on the arm of the chair,” etc.); Records and Reminiscences (London: Methuen, 1903; 1905), p. 283.

H.M. crosses the room to express to H.S. his regret about the Arundel. First time I’ve heard that they’ve carried out my innate wishes: viz. by pilling. But Shenton should not have stuck me up, without being sure of carrying—as H.M. would have done. I’m not a clubbable man, and don’t much care to be (or I wouldn’t join Prosser & Co. on the First Sept.!).

Anecdotes of Cruikshank and his drunken wife – and how he studied life in Smithfield and came to Mark for another pint of porter ... Also of Gil. [a Beckett] at the Albion, proposing toast “Universal Duchesses” and of his roaring out of his office window “We must have cash!” Mrs. Gil has suppurated from her second, Mr. Jones, says Thackeray – who improvises “Bill Bowline was a sailor true, As ever went below decks, He gave a nosegay to his Sue, Who put it up her podex.”—H.M. offered £50 by Duberg, of the Haymarket, to say a word for him in Punch. H.M. very groggy and silly tonight.

div.head: August 19, 1863. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. at Pontrilas.

div.head: August 26, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. absent — at Pontrilas: i.e. walking over the great Skirrid[?] from Abergavenny. Dined at Wm. Batt’s and slept at Steel’s.

div.head: September 2, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. absent – at Woodbridge. Shot 4½ brace at Isaac Walker’s. 3 brace yesterday at Nathan’s. S. and L. return last night and dine at Church St. today the 2nd, after their Yorkshire and Newcastle Highland tour.

div.head: September 9, 1863. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. to Dieppe last Saturday, the 5th.

div.head: September 16, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. l.
div.p: H.S. at Dieppe.

div.head: September 23, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Dr. – T.T.S., E. and Settie return by the Alexandra. H.S. walks to the forest and Argues, and Saltates at L’Etablissment.

div.head: September 30, 1863. No Dinner.
div.p:
H.S. goeth to Woodbridge (T. diphtheriarized) and dines at T. Grimwood’s with the Ridleys, the Marshalls, Miss Grimwood, Sarah and Mrs. Thorn and Settie who playeth a galop which Mrs. R. calleth a “rhapsody.”
Possibly Thomas Richard Grimwood (1825-1883). (N.B. delirium sets in tomorrow night. H.S. goeth to Gissing at 2:30 a.m.)

div.head: October 7, 14, 21. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Woodbridge playing Sairey Gamp: A Sad Sore time.

div.head: October 28, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: [Bradbury reappeared some time during H.S.’s absence.]
E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., T.T.

H.S.’s first appearance since August 12! From Woodbridge this morning: leaving the Old ‘Un in charge. Flaxman his Lieutenant. Leech staying somewhere in the Midlands the night of the earthquake, in an old country house, big bedroom next him, wakes and goes to door and cries “Who’s there?” to the earthquake. Partridge shooting with Millais who is a good shot. Stout turnips – boys in trees to mark, as they do in Gloucestershire.’ S.B. and Thackeray at Brighton which is crammed. Dickens described earthquake shock “as if a great beast were under the bed.” John Forster is thought to have been the great beast.
The earthquake occurred in the early morning of October 6. Dickens’s description of his experience at Gad’s Hill appears in his letter to the Times, October 8, 1863, p. 8: “It was exactly as if some great beast had been asleep under the bedstead, and were now shaking itself, and trying to rise.”

L.C. Decided last week to be Lincoln holding candle to the Czar: kootooing the Russians of late [Punch, 45 (7 November 1863): 189, “Holding a Candle to the *****: Much the Same Thing” ]. Carrying guts to the bear suggests P.L. But fancy the Placard – “Guts to the Bear—see Punch!”– Something anent Prussia – M.L. suggests “Portrait of the Man who understands the Schleswig question” – giving him an enormously high forehead.
The complexity of this territorial dispute involving the duchies of Schleswig and Holstein was legendary. Lytton Strachey memorably quoted Lord Palmerston as declaring, “Only three people have ever really understood the Schleswig-Holstein business––the Prince Consort, who is dead––a German professor, who has gone mad––and I, who have forgotten all about it.” (Queen Victoria [New York: Harcourt, Brace & Co., 1921] p. 308.) Strachey's version of the quote is the one most commonly reproduced, as it is more graceful than that of his source, Grant Robertson's biography of Bismark (Bismark [New York: Henry Holt, 1919] p. 161); Robertson, however, gives no primary source for this marvelous quotation, which may well be apocryphal.

J.L. suggests King Preposterous for a Burlesque – Bland would have done for it. Thackeray’s names always have pith in them. Dickens’ simply comicality. J.L. regrets that he and Dickens had not worked together in the Green Leaf serial time.

 [drawing of pointing hand] H.S. at Croydon Nov. 3 dreams of dining at the Garrick with Leech and M.L. some Sunday, and J.L. shows new number of Punch with a “Social” cut of his 2 swells fishing in front of house – lines falling through grating into sewer.—Explains that Swell No. 1 is stingy of his fishing and so Swell No. 2 gives him a day. J.L. tells tales of Lords etc. from living at Kensington (so H.S. dreams), and H.S. behaves as silently and bashfully in dreamland as he doth at the Punch Table.

div.head: November 4, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: T.T., H.S., Fred E[vans], S.B., J.T., P.L., F.C.B., Wmi. Bradbury [son], H.M.

T.T. growls at the gluey taste about the dinner – mistake sending made dishes across Fleet Street. Compares these messes with the Vol au Vent of the Hotel de 1’Europe! The College puddings clearly made with tallow instead of butter – ugh! Better have a good soup, a good fish, a good joint and a good cheese – et praeterea nihil – At home T.T. has his cook in to carve behind a screen. Not every cook would do it.

Talk of Bel Demonico, Fechter’s novelty, produced last Saturday. All the critics of course there – including Fred Evans! T.T. complains of the newness of the dresses, as destroying the naturalness of the stage effects. Stupid piece, but so well mounted that it must draw. T.T. dislikes Miss Bateman as Leah – says an artist would say her arms were too short for beauty.

S.B. asks why may a doctor be thought to be a lady. Because if he’s not an Ann-Eliza he must be a Charlat-an. — Says the Bedford waiter always calls it Pea pudding — adds force to the line “Pea pudding in the Pot” says P.L.

Burnand savage at the Temple Bar pitch into him by Andrew Halliday – who really is a would be comic writer he says.
“Comic Literature,” Temple Bar 9 (November 1863) 590-599. The author is especially critical of Punch's hiring of F. C. Burnand (and Silver is clearly sympathetic to that view). The Wellesley Index to Victorian Periodicals tentatively attributed this article to Edmund Yates; based on this reference in the Silver diary, the Curran Index has corrected the entry to give Halliday as author. See the continued discussion of Halliday's article in the entry for November 11. Scottish journalist and dramatist Andrew Halliday Duff (1830-1877) came to London in 1849 and contributed to the Leader, the Morning Chronicle, and the Cornhill, but became most closely associated with Dickens’s All the Year Round. But I agree with A. H. that the sheer nonsense style of writing smacks more of inanity than wit. The T[emple] B[ar] says that a young smart man was wanted for Punch to compete with Fun – but query if Punch has not been lowered by the flood of nonsense this young man has poured in?

Of course we talk of the Palmerston divorce scandal first bruited by The Star – Mrs. Du CaneX of Essex Street to be the She – but nobody believes the tale to be otherwise than trumped up for extortional purposes. So we resolve to speak up for Pam in every indirect way we can.

L.C. The Russian-Yankee Alliance the chief subject says M.L. S.B. says the South has turned out English Consuls, so M.L. suggests J Bull smoking his pipe of peaceful neutrality between the two viragos who assail him with their Billingsgate [Punch, 45 (14 November 1863): 199, “Neutrality” ].
X corrected to O’Kane, a nobody – Dick Watson says she was an old servant at Broadlands, of course, it is a plant.

div.head: November 11, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., Wm. Bradbury. Champ.

Talk about the triple murder in the cab last Saturday—picture the poisoner seeing his wife and children die! Somehow truth is stranger than “sensation” fictions.
Times leaders about the murders, November 7, p. 7 and November 11, p. 8.

Pater feelingly proposes Mark’s health and success to his novel (Wait for the End) – his maiden effort in a new path of penmanship. M.L. replies with tears in his voice – and hopes his friends will pardon him for any discredit the work may bring – it was written to relieve him from a temporary distress and not for any selfish feeling of ambition. A few manly touching words from both speakers – and one feels that they mean what they say.

L.C. Of course the Emperor’s proposal for a Congress. P.L. says L.N. simply carries out Jerrold’s peace notion of referring questions to arbitration – and suggests he should be saying “Well I’ve tried rows and fighting and roguery and I think that after honesty is the best policy.” E. amends this by picturing him as Mephisto pheles speaking – P.L. suggests L[ouis] N[apoleon] pro posing a Select Vestry – himself taking the chair.S.B. amends this to a Union Meeting, as its more than a parish affair. M.L. suggests Emperor saying to his little boy “Put down that drum, and come and see my visitors.”

J.L. cites old joke of drunkard saying “I’ve tried brandy and water and rum and water and gin and water and I can’t get rid of this infernal headache” so L.N. “I’ve tried balls and powder and revolutions etc etc,” Punch as Doctor saying “You’ve no Constitution – what you want is quiet.” P.L. suggests this dialogue and settles the Cut [Punch, 45 (21 November 1863): 209, “Taking the Doctor’s Advice”] X P.L. says the Puseyites writing SS and using Catholic signs and symbols should be condemned for imitating the Catholic trade mark.

Apropos of Peel, S.B. says he should have retired when his opinions changed and not betrayed a noble party. H.M. also against Peel – P.L. and M.L. for him: think it was a patriotic act to save his country from a riot even at the expense of his party.

H.M. takes the chair tomorrow at a farewell dinner to Sala (at the Scotch Stores, Beak Street) on occasion of his going to New York for The Telegraph. M.L. says of course the antiPunchites will make capital of your presence, as showing there’s a split in the Punch camp, and that the Bohemians count you as one of them. H.M. defends himself as being an old friend of George Augustus. J.T. thinks the answer to the “smart young men” who have not been taken on the Punch staff is “Why don’t you start a Punch of your own?” Whenever they have done this they have always failed.
The defensive tone here is clearly a response to the article on “Comic Literature” by Andrew Halliday that had just appeared in Temple Bar 9 (November, 1863):590-599), in which Halliday criticized Punch both for growing stale and for hiring Francis Burnand; the phrase “smart young men” is Halliday’s (591). (See also the comments at the previous week's dinner, November 4.) Brooks, who by then had made up his quarrel with Sala, nevertheless declined an invitation to chair the dinner welcoming him back home from New York, perhaps for the reason Lemon mentions here. He suggested that Yates be asked, but, as this entry shows, Horace Mayhew chaired it instead. (Shirley Brooks diary, 3 December 1864, Houghton Library)

S.B. and H.S. at the Adelphi last night to see Leah – Miss Bateman an exception to the rule that Infant Prodigies grow up into obscurity. The fifth act made me cry and Shirley to bite his tongue to keep from crying too. That long low tender brokenhearted yearning wail over the child is one of the things that stick in one’s memory, when a rotten play like Leah is forgotten. Her line “And you believed that I had taken it” was the first thing that moved me: the scorn that her lover should believe she had been bribed to leave him. The piece itself is insufferably weak – except in one or two stage situations. But that blessing of the married couple and then appeal to Heaven to heal[?] her blessing is as flat a bit of blasphemy as I ever heard upon the boards.
Kate Josephine Bateman (1842-1917), the eldest of eight children of an American family of actors, made a sensation in the title role of Leah the Forsaken at London’s Adelphi Theatre. The play opened on October 1, 1863, and ran for a record 211 nights. See the appreciative review in the Era, October 10, 1863, p. 10.

X C.K. suggests Emperor saying to Empress “My dear we must give a party” – a Peace Party says H.S.S.B. cites Joe Buggins “Louis Napoleon gave a party to which the Kings he did invite, ‘Cos you see ‘twas his ambition To put the Map of Europe right” ... Wm. Brad[bury] suggests something about resorting the King’s boots and shoes.

E. and Wm. Bradbury dined at Guildhall on Monday. – Lord Mayors always have fine show days – this was brilliant – but not even oysters could tempt me to stay with G.G. Gascoyen at the Punch Office.
George Green Gascoyen (1830-1876), surgeon of St Mary’s and the Lock hospitals (British Medical Journal, January 29, 1876, p. 140). Shirley there of course. Glad that Pam was received so well – shows that the Tories have made nothing by their slander. A shameful article that in the Standard – following the Star – and speculating upon the political changes in case of the proved guilt of the “hoary defendant’X. S.B. says somehow the Tories can never get a decent newspaper to back them, and ditto the R. Catholics . .. He chaffs Burnand anent our having got back E. Walford from the R.C. Church. E.W. a clever fool – up in classicality and nothing else.
Edward Walford converted to Roman Catholicism in 1853, became an Anglican again in 1863, and returned to the Catholic faith in 1870. – M.L. tells how Moon when Lord Mayor invited the Garrick Club to dine with him and some 300 members turned up – M.L. thinks some must have come from India on purpose.
XI wonder they didn’t spell the epithet with a W.

div.head: November 18, 1863. W[ednesday] No.11.
div.p: S.B., H.S., J.T., M.L,P.L., C.K., H.M. champ.

H.M. brings Miss Bateman’s photograph from her to Shirley – “Silver should have it too” says M.L. (who lets the cat out of the onewhopays bag thereby). Although she was an infant Prodigy and petted accordingly, she’s a nice simple natural unaffected girl, says H.M.

S.B. mentions that the ship Charles Kean sailed to Australia in was first saluted from Cape Stuart – Stuart, yes, the proper name for a pretender. Pocket Book Dinner this, but no pocketbook visible Joyce obstante. M.L. says the subscription is greater than ever, worth while next year trying to make the book a better one – “No, no” (general chorus) “better not improve it—see how the Family Herald sells, because of its stupidity. Mark, you improved the London Journal by reprinting Waverley Novels in it, and you lost thereby a lot of readers of the necessary kitchen stuff.” S.B. says he always tries to keep his P[ocket] B[ook] wit down to the usual dull level, for fear of being too sparkling.—M.L. says whenever an article stands over, of course you know it is because I think it is too dazzling for the rest of the number.

L.C. S.B. suggests cards, L[ouis] N[apoleon] asking Britannia to play, and saying of Austria & Co., “They’ll play fast enough if you’ll sit down.”—P.L. amends it to “Voulez vous dansez?”S.B. adding of Russia “I should like the Lancers” [ Punch, 45 (28 November 1863): 219, “The Congress Quadrille” ]. S.B. a bit of a snob in parading his bill of fare at Alderman Lush’s feed yesterday.

M.L. gets to his dramatic anecdotage – inter alia, tells of Phil, the stage doorkeeper with his squeaky voice “Tell ye, Mr. B. ain’t come yet – here’s his (bog) [?]!” – also of Charley Field the Detective, with his flabby hand and cool tongue – how he traced Mrs. Manning to a lodging and tapped at door “Only me – Charley Field – so just open the door quietly, Maria.” Eliza Grimwood supposed to have been murdered by Duke of Brunswick – only one clue being a pair of cleaned gloves under her pillow – which Field took and traced, through man in theatre pit to shop in Strand, there lost the scent. M.L. tells also of City porter tracked to public in Smithfield by detective drest as butcher who turned pot boy to find out the gang. Also of visit to Stunning Joe Banks where a couple of gents refused to “garnish” or pay their footing – So at the cry of “Baker!” down came half a stone of flour on their heads.

div.head: November 25, 1863. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. from Woodbridge today and tomorrow shoots at Dropmore with E. Lee.Dines at N. 20 and hears Judas with [?] Gascoigne.

div.head: December 2, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: S.B., H.S., Fred E[vans], J.T., ML, P.L., C.K., Wm. Bradbury, Thackeray

Thackeray calls Col. Crawley Col[onel] of the Lillie’s Killing (Eniskillen) Dragoons,
See note to entry for December 9, 1863, regarding the Colonel Crawley affair. chaffs M.L. about his mistake in “Wait for the End” – making term time at Cambridge in September. Mark says a Cambridge man “read” for him and passed the error ... Afterwards when M.L., J. T., and H.S. alone, he says he “didn’t write for men like Thackeray” — believed he could tell a story – didn’t aim at highflown sentiment or language. H.S. applauds this good feeling in the book ... Says he sketched plot – thought first of a catastrophe and then thinks what would lead up to it: Wrote the book a chapter a day, 38 in all, 2 days a week. Says Pater offered him a price so tempting that in justice to his children he was forced to write. “Weaver” of course is Webster – and “Stella,” Mrs. Mellon.
Ben Webster (1797-1882), actor-manager; Sarah Jane Mellon (1824-1909), née Woolgar, actress, joined Webster’s company at the Adelphi in 1858.I fancied her Mrs. Stirling, and so did Tenniel. Says Mrs. M. used often to come to him and say “I think so and so should have these lines to say – they’ll be more effective so, than if I say them.” Never knew any other actor to do this. “Rupert Melville” he meant for Edmund Kean, who used to attend The “Harp” by Drury Lane, and stand 20 glasses of grog to poorer actors, many of whom drank themselves to death. M.L. used to get £200 for the Illustrated [London News] Xmas Supplement. They became jealous of his influence when Ingram died, and so have declined his service – and he’s too proud to resent it, as Mrs. Ingram, his friend, would do.

L.C. Queen sending toys to Children’s Hospital, says W.M.T. – pretty picture – but not big enough for Large Cut – .. The Congress still the subject, says M.L. Thackeray suggests the Pope and Sultan coming to door, togged out, and Louis N[apoleon] as footman saying “There’s no party tonight, gentlemen – it’s put off.” H.S. suggests, Opening the Answernotes – Empress says, “The Bulls can’t come”Oh, then, says Emperor [Louis Napoleon], we must postpone the party ... H.S. as usual speaks sotto voce and C.K. gets the credit of “the Bulls.” [ Punch, 45 (12 December 1863): 239, “Unavoidably Postponed”] Thackeray says let Johnny Russell come in as Buttons from Mrs. Bull: a haughty page (accepted). His first idea the most Punchy but P.L. objects that the Pope doesn’t actually go – only says he’s willing, if —. S.B. proposes L.N. as Giant Des pair, England as Faithful. M.L. proposes Picture of Pam explaining the Schleswig question to puzzled Mr. Bull. – Bradbury suggests the Earthquake of London – undermined by Railways.

C.K. says there was an anti Claydon Puseyism row at Ipswich lately and the mob had big placards “We won’t give up our Bible” – The thought is too terrible (W.M.T.) Who says it tells a libel (S.B.) – And we won’t go to Rome (H.S.). This to the tune of We won’t go home till morning would make a capital marching chorus for a mob of Anti-Puseyites.
See “The Claydon Church Eccentricities,” Times, November 27, 1863, p. 10, re: the Puseyite innovations by Rev. George Drury of the Church of St. peter, Suffolk. C.K. quotes a riddle which Thackeray made (he says). Why’s a piano like an onion? – Because it’smell-odious. — S.B. suggests a Domestic Opera, di Camera – the usual life of a family and such incidents as paying bills or playing with a baby.

Fancy coming to the Court of the King of the Belchians, says Thackeray! What a tremendous monarch!
The Times of November 10, 1863, p. 9, featured an address by the King of the Belgians at the opening of Chambers, closing with remarks on the success of the Belgian school at the London International Exhibition. — S.B. tells story of a nobleman walking in his garden when an unearthly voice was heard saying to him “A-hole! A-hole! A-hole!”Suck it, said the nobleman, continuing his walk and proving himself equal to the occasion. — A great jaw about Geology versus Moses: P.L. and Thackeray contending for the Six Days – as stated by the actual word of God in the 4th Commandment. M.L. contends that God could have by a miracle made the Earth in 6 days with all the supposed geological [crossed out: “disparities”] proofs of greater antiquity complete in it.
This was the argument advanced in Philip Henry Gosse’s Omphalos (1857). P.L. contends that Parsons assert opinions for facts. “Different men have different opinions, But don’t let them say that apples are inions.”

div.head: December 9, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: J.L., U.S., F[red] E[vans], S.B., J.T., M.L. P.L., C.K. W illiam] B[rad.bury, son], WMT (late – “couldn’t resist the tripe at the Reform Club”).

L.C. The Congress again. P.L. suggests Europa courting the (John) Bull which Shirlez amends to the Bull carrying off Europa – “I say – What d’ye think of the Bull carrying off Europa? – there’s a grand cut for you” – sniffs more suo [Punch, 45 (19 December 1863): 249, “Europa Carried Off by the (John) Bull” ].Other suggestions by P.L. – John Thomas exhibiting his Calves at the Cattle Show by M.L. Europe putting Louis’ pipe of peace out, by J.L. Government rehearsing for the Pantomime Pam as harlequin preparing to jump thro’ the Session “I think I can get through that.”
M.L. says he’s received 1000 jokes upon the Proclamation against Smoking at Windsor to the effect that the only weeds the Queen allows there are widow’s weeds.

J.L. says when Frith attended her Majesty anent his Marriage picture she held commune with him by the medium of her Lady in Waiting. This recalls to mind Prince Albert’s taking his gun from a gentleman in waiting who takes it from his flunkey who takes it from the loader.
Who expects us to be funny? says P.L. – An author exposing his wit after dinner commits an offence equivalent to a man’s exposing his persomn.

Mark says while he was writing his novel there was great talk about it at home, and his little girl after a day of flurry said, “Mamma, I’m so excited I feel just as if I’d been writing a novel.” Same little girl acts the family doctor – feels her aunt’s pulse and then prescribes her a black dose.
J.T. quotes some lines not knowing them to be Shirley’s (I forget the 3 first but they run somehow thus):
Then followed rednosed Albus, and great Squintus with his squint,
And Scipio who sipped his beer with roasted pippins in’t:
Then followed Ritus Titus with a glass of something short,

And Pintus with a pint of ale, and Quartus with a quart.
These lines appeared in the Argus of December 31, 1842, p. 9, in a set of verses entitled “A Lay of Ancient Rome,” a parody of Macaulay. They include the lines, “Then followed Naso with his nose, And Ossa with his wart, And Pintus with a pint of ale, And Quartus with a quart.” Brooks did some of his earliest work for the Argus, of which he became editor in the early 1840s, when it had become the Age and Argus.

Why, here’s Titmarsh! says Leech as Thackeray’s tall square shoulders come from behind the screen. Yes, I couldn’t resist the tripe says T. and then talks of the Steward’s Dinner at the Smiffel on Monday and how old Hale tossed off his pot of porter and then his pint of port and looked as tough and wiry – short stubbly iron grey hair, don’t you remember? – as he did 30 years since. Very good second rate wine says Thackeray. – Elwyn going to resign, or has resigned, from ill health. Nice quiet clever little fellow he was when I was at Downs.

J.L. talks of old days in Powis Place, when he first married and invited Albert Smith and a lot of fellows to breakfast with him one Sunday and forgot to tell Mrs. Leech of it – so when they came, the dinner leg of mutton had to be cut up and broiled.

J.L. “I hate the Working Man - always a nuisance in his amusements – foresters” etc. etc. J.T. says he smoked ½ lb. of tobacco in 2 days while working at the Pocket Book – generally smokes ½ lb. a week.

S.B. says that a subscription is being made for Col. Crawley, so another should be made for the family of Lilley.
Lieutenant-Colonel Thomas Robert Crawley (1818-1880) of the 15th Hussars and the 6th Inniskilling dragoons, based in India, ordered the arrest of John Lilley, the Regimental Sergeant Major, on a charge of speaking disparagingly of the colonel. Lilley died on May 25, 1862, while in confinement, and after a public outcry, Crawley was arraigned before a court martial, charged with manslaughter. He was acquitted December 24, 1863. See Frederic Boase, Modern English Biography (1892) 756. Did I record Thackeray’s joke “the Lillies killing Dragoons”? S.B. says a gipsy foretold the year when he would go a long journey (to Russia etc.) and the year when he would marry, and both came true. Yes says Mark, and so did your prophecy of the Earthquake – Yes, says Shirley, but that prediction was based on mathematical calculation. (J.L. expects me at 72 Marine Parade tomorrow week. N.B. Working at Almanack still.)

div.head: December 16, 1863. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: S.B., W.B.. H.S., H.M., J.T., M.L., P.L, F.C.B., T.T2.
Thackeray (his last visit).

L.C. Delane catching Cobden under the mistletoe and making it up with him.
See the account of the spat between John Thadeus Delane, editor of the Times, and M.P. Richard Cobden in H. R. Fox-Bourne, English Newspapers (1887), vol. 2, pp. 266-268. Cobden exchanged angry letters with Delane—some of which were later published in the Daily News—over a leader by Robert Lowe that attacked Cobden and Bright.

S.B. thinks the raising of Roman Catholic Serjeant Shee is the topic – Ghosts of Pitt and Wellington approving the completion of their work of Catholic Emancipation.
See Times leader of December 16, 1863, p. 8, approving of the first appointment of a Roman Catholic judge since Catholic Emancipation. M.L. amends it to the plum pudding cut which Posterity will see: [Punch, 45 (1863): 259, “Lord Chancellor Punch and the New Judge” ] after a wish by P.L. that something should be done to smash the Invading Railways.

Thackeray pitches into Horace because his £2.2 to the Julian Portch Subscription is entered as coming from Arthur Pendennis: Says he particularly begged his name might not appear – “They’ll be at me again, those d – d pennyaliners.” Horace explains and says the case is really a deserving one, “Very well then, I’ll give you a fiver besides, in my own name” says Thackeray.
Julian Portch (182?-1865), self-taught artist and illustrator, came from a poor background in Manchester. In the mid-1850s he was on the staff of Henry Vizetelly’s Illustrated Times, for which he covered the siege of Sevastopol. Between 1858 and 1861 he contributed miscellaneous work for Punch. According to Kathryn Hughes (Short Life and Long Times of Mrs. Beeton [2006] p. 161), he was hired by Samuel Beeton to design the frontispiece for the Englishwoman’s Domestic Magazine. He also contributed to Boys Own Magazine and illustrated several books. Portch suffered from a kind of paralysis, brought on by illness, beginning in about 1862, and died three years later. The brief account of his life in M. H, Spielmann, The History of “Punch” (1895) 501 is confused, but appears to be the most substantive one extant. The subscription circulated by “a few artist-friends and wood-engravers” is mentioned in an obituary notice in the London Review, October 7, 1865, p. 396, which also notes that he was several years younger than his friend John Leech. Blanchard Jerrold recalled dropping by Horace Mayhew’s with Thackeray to deliver the £5; Philip Collins, ed., Thackeray: Interviews and Recollections, vol. 2 (New York: St. Martin’s, 1983) 358-359. Tells also of one or two fellows who have extracted fivers and tenners from him at his house and at his Clubs and in the streets and in the Parks. In fact his purse is never safe.

Discussion as to Colenso – Thackeray says “We have God’s own word (in his Commandments) that he made the world in six days and yet geologists tell us it took millions of years to make. Quien sabe? – repeating the talk of the 2nd a little .. rather a dull dinner.
At 8 o’clock M.L. receives the last blocks from Leech, and at 7 tomorrow evening the k is in our hands at Brighton.

div.head: December 23, 1863. Wt[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: J.L., H.S. (from Brighton), S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., F.E., F.C.B.

F.C.B. says his idea of Peace is Louis being castrated of 2 cannon balls: then he tells the old story of “How about them Chawings” giving it a Yankee turn, and another old story which H.S. can’t help crying “Connu” to. But H.S. somehow has felt hipped of late – October be thanked.
P.L. quotes the Scotchman and the Widow – “I’m a mon o’ few words, but tak’ a grip o’ that!” M.L. quotes Dr. telling wife “Your liver’s touched” and husband’s saying “Dr. ye flatter me!”

div.head: December 30, 1863. Wednesday-. No dinner.
div.p: Funeral of William Makepeace Thackeray: who died on Christmas Eve not long after we left the Punch Table last week. S. tells me of his sudden death, after breakfast on Saturday – they would not spoil my Xmas Day by letting me hear of it. I never felt a loss so much, except of course those of my relations. And yet I was not privileged to rank myself as more than a casual acquaintance. But his kindliness extended to the smallest of his visitors, and he never snubbed one or ignored one’s presence. What the loss must be to his old chum and schoolfellow Leech, who can pretend to estimate? And what the loss must be to his daughters who owed everything to him in position and in fortune and were ever petted and much thought of, one shrinks from considering. The loss is a national one, but the nation cannot judge how his family and his friends feel it.

div.head: January 5, 1864.T[uesdayI. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Woodbridge and dines with Tom Grimwood, meeting George and his wife, who have had enough of Christmas feasting. Frost set in on New Year’s Day.

div.head: January 13, 1864. W[ednesday] No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., C.K., H.M., W.B.
Dined with Shirley at Balham on Sunday – inaugurative of “the Pyramid” and Mrs. S. asks “Why don’t you come to our Judy suppers?” – “Why don’t you ask me?”

L.C. the New Baby the Subject – if a Prince can be a Subject. Came rather suddenly on Joe’s birthday. Friday (H.S. up that day) just as we had finished the Turkey with Mrs. Vereker’s help. Alexandra watching her husband skate in the afternoon and gives him a son at 9 p.m. [ Punch, 46 (23 January 1864): 35, “What the Nation Hopes Soon to See” ]

S.B. suggests “Denmark’s New Ally,” the baby to wit – M.L Baby pulling Queen’s Widow’s cap off, bringing her out of retirment – modified to Queen showing baby as Posterity will see (N.B. the baby is not the Queen’s tho’ it almost looks as if it were in the Cut). SB. suggests alteration of Adelphi playbill apropos of Wright’s Execution – “Seeing Wright” – Grim Large Cut, A Drop for Wright and a Bottle for Townley – Shame bringing him in mad.
Samuel Wright, bricklayer, was executed January 12, 1864, for the murder of his lover, Maria Green, in the middle of the night after she had awakened and, according to his account, attacked him. It was widely felt that his execution was a miscarriage of justice, the result of his not having had legal counsel prior to entering a plea. The genteel and well-connected George Victor Townley, convicted of stabbing Elizabeth Caroline Goodwin to death after she broke off their engagement, had his death sentence commuted to life imprisonment after questions were raised about his sanity. This commutation, particularly in contrast to Wright's execution, inflamed public opinion, as Townley had never shown any evidence of insanity prior to the murder. Denied confinement in an asylum, he committed suicide in Pentonville in February, 1865 by leaping from a balustrade on the way out of chapel, onto a stone floor twenty-three feet below. The Townley case was widely discussed in the Lancet and other medical journals, as well as in the newspapers.

S.B. tells of the split in the Shakespeare Committee and how Hepworth Dixon got two moral kicks behind for his Thackeray brutality – proposes statue of H.D. holding little statuette of Shakespeare in his hand (done by Burton in Illustrated Times). S.B. tells of a Jew excusing his laxity on ground that he was circumcised with a hammy knife.
See Shirley Brooks diary for January 11, 1864, in which he mentions having heard a variation of this joke at a dinner at the Conservative Club. (Houghton Library) Pater tells of wife separated on ground of mortal danger and tapping at door “I’ve come to be killed, dear.” M.L. tells riddle “First crinoline – Eve carried a little Cain under her figleaf. J.L. says a lady told him of her child saying “Ma, the Bible says Thou shalt not commit adultery, does the baker then break commandment when he adulterates the bread?” J.L. tells of gamekeeper and tame pheasants that won’t rise “Here you come, Jim they don’t’know you so well.”

Apropos of Thackeray, Leech says “Thank God, we shan’t have to go round with the hat” – his daughters will have £1000 a year between them. On Friday next I dine with Leech (to taste the C. pheasant) and he then over a cigar tells me he can’t sleep without dreaming of poor Thackeray, been sleeping alone, so disturbed is he – says the death was instantaneous, but the limbs fearfully contorted – features calm.
See Shirley Brooks letter to Percival Leigh, Christmas Day, 1863, in the Berg Collection, NYPL, recording Leech’s description of Thackeray’s body: “He saw the body, and says that his impression was not that the death had been peaceful, but that there was tetanus – the arms were bent and rigid, and could not be got down, and there was much discoloration.”

div.head: January 20, 1864. W[ednesday] No. 11. champ.
div.p: S.B., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., C.K., W.B., H.M.

Shirley asks “Isn’t it somebody’s birthday, for I want a glass of Champagne. So I fulfill my word to Robert John Burleigh and drink to him on his Coming of Age. (And tomorrow I go to the dance in his honour and see the Cup and Address given by the men and on Friday we – 14 of us, including Emma and the three Doves, plump little dears – drink again at the Rant’s and I forget almost how to laugh – so dull is the evening there.) The Shakespeare Nullification the subject.
See the letter of withdrawal from Hepworth Dixon’s Shakespeare Tercentenary Committee signed by Brooks, Taylor, and others (Times, January 20, 1864, p. 6). An account of the controversy may be found in Richard Foukes, The Shakespeare Tercentenary of 1864 (London: The Society for Theatre Research, 1984). Gillray would do little dogs p—g against the statue – H.M. suggests Shakespeare as Gulliver with Lilliputians overrunning him – somebody else says Dixon whitewashing the Statue J.L. suggests Shakspeare coming to Punch – “Save me from my friends” and then improves on himself by suggesting Shakspeare and the Pigmies. [ Punch, 46 (1864): 45, “Shakspeare and the Pigmies”].

div.head: January 27, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., C.K., F.C.B., W.B., T.T.

H.S. from Woodbridge this morning, and back again on Saturday, after G.A.G.’s hop. (Feb. 3) S.B. asks him how to cook chops, with mushrooms or truffles, and his ignorance proves his absence from the Gallery on Monday when the Pyramid came out.) Apropos of this S.B. says he heard Mrs. Reed sing as Acis – might introduce the song OAcis into the Pyramid says Burnand – have an oasis in the desert.

J.L. applauds J.T. for the Shakespeare cut – against Ha’porth Dixon, who is said to give his Ipse Dixon.
See the reference to this cut, and to another caricature using the joke “Ha’porth Dixon,” in Laura Hain Friswell, James Hain Friswell: A Memoir (1898) pp. 125-126. See also Punch 46 (6 February 1864): 59, “A Good Ha’porth.” T.T. reads a letter from Tupper (anent the ode H.S. wrote on the Baby Prince
Punch, 46 (23 January 1864): 34, “A Welcome to the Baby Prince, By the Poet Laureate T–pp–r”) thinking it either Tom’s or Shirley’s and saying he and his family laughed heartily at the “hundred thousand million times,” – a “very witty little effusion it is” – “And now why cannot we meet oftener, or at least correspond as literary brothers should do.” “I enclose you my Ode, which is not written in snobbishness but real honesty and truth” – Tom mouths it in stage fashion and we laugh.

L.C. Opening of Parliament (Feb. 4). Members trotting out their hobbies, T.T. Looking out the Properties for Parliamentary Pantomime, T.T. (Comic News does this Cut). Public don’t know behind scenes work, says Evans. S.B. suggests Taking Stock and H.S. amends to Dressing the Window: S.B. introducing Pam the Veteran Shopwalker – Loud discussion settling names of goods, C.K. Russian towelling etc. etc. Gladstone putting up placard about Lease – “nailing it up with Tax” says Burnand. [ Punch, 46 (6 February 1864): 55, “Dressing the Window”]
T.T. tells of his little boy dressed in sailor’s clothes – pretty contrast, their rough manly look and his smooth child’s face.
