S.B. reads in Sun a critique on Mackay’s new poems, one of which is belikened to the Dyin,, Christian’s address to his soul – “the dying Heathen’s address to his A—hole” says S.B.

M.L asks what is our opinion as to asking for leave to place a tablet to Thackeray in Westminster Abbey – only his personal friends to subscribe. But surely if a memorial is to be placed there, it should be a National one.

Ponny Mayhew complaining of the Government – being pressed for explanation says his greatest grievance is that he has no vote. But he might buy one. H.S. offers him a couple for £100 – G's cottages to wit . Where in the world could he get such freedom and safety at so small a price as he pays here?

M.L. says the poor can’t improve till they’re better housed – one of the duties of Property to see that its dependants are not kept in Pigstyes. Declares that the Manufacturers whom Bright so spouts for are the hardest Masters of land – only buy it for investment, and screw down their labourers to make it pay.

div.head: February 3, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., P.L., C.K., F.C.B.. W. Bradbury.
H.S. from Seckford St. this morning and so wasn’t at the Pyramid on Monday, Mr. Brooks.

Townley found sane and sentenced anew to Penal Servitude – Mark says he would rather be hanged than die gradually as a felon – fancy the prolonged mental torture!
George Victor Townley (1838-1865), murderer. See above note for January 13, 1864. Yes, but felons generally are not so sensitive – confinement is simply life in idleness to them and without care. Evans and Shirley say hanging deters, and W.B. says he wouldn’t feel safe with his men without the dread of it.
Burnand tells of small schoolboy threatening to tell of Swells smoking on railway and so stopping them and laughing at them when they get to station – “Who’s sold?”

Thackeray anecdotes by pennyaliners – here’s one: sees friend buying an oxide bracelet, “I hope it’s for an ox eyed lady.”—When Thackeray went to Rome someone said they tried to make a Roman of him, “They should have begun with your nose,” said Jerrold.
J.L. tells of his lending a [crossed out: “restive”] horse to an old gentleman – “And what became of him?” asks Burnand. – Oh, he’s in my stable still. “No, I mean the old gentleman.”

L.C. The Schleswig Invasion – S.B. says Britannia and Master Bull. “Let me go, Ma.”—I can’t see those two big bullies pitching into that little fellow.” Leech amends to the cut of JB between the two Princesses – stet – Sometime ago he suggested two Politicians, after dinner “And now letsh talk of Schleshwig Holshtein.” [ Punch, 46 (13 February 1864): 65, “Our Danish Difficulty”] M.L. thinks a cut suggesting improvement of Labourers’ cottages should be done.
February 10, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
Ash Wednesday. E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L.., C.K., H.M., W.B.
Frost again since Friday – skating today, Leech says, and pictures the disgust of a hunting man with a large stud being offered a pair of skates in the Park.

My advertisement about the Kensington shops and their incivilities (which Leech completed – “Man in an elegant attitude at the tallow chandler’s.”) has brought him a heap of letters and a savage leader in the West London Observer – so the cap fits – and I write a song thereanent as I walk home from the dinner – but next week Mark tells me Leech was so bothered that my song must “stand over.”
T.T. – a daughter! Won’t he be a happy father. Has had two mistakes, Leech says.

L.C. S.B. complains of our position in Europe - Britannia having her a— kicked by all the foreign Powers! No, says Leech, Britannia lifting up her petticoats and saying You may kiss my — would be nearer the truth. Then S.B. suggests Louis [Napoleon] and Victor [Emmanuel] looking at map and threatening to extend their frontiers – and when this cut’s accepted he says “I’ve the pleasure of announcing that the Idea is Mr Frederick Evans’s.”
Frederick Moule Evans (1832-1902), Pater Evans’s son. “Fred,” as he was known, had begun attending the dinner meeting in 1863, along with William H. Bradbury’s son. Shirley Brooks was his particular friend on the Punch staff, and Brooks’s announcement here, like his similar notice of Silver, can be seen as a kind of initiation. S.B. proposes as a Title “The Logic of Kings” and amends it to “Nemesis” [ Punch, 46 (30 February 1864): 75, “Nemesis” ]
S.B. tells of girl screaming thro’ the keyhole on acct of 5/-, “My c’s my bread” – “Yes but I’ve well buttered it.”
H.M. tells of the proposed starting of a periodical to be called “The Comic Punch.”

Thackeray wrote small clear hand with seldom a correction – composed slowly – Jerrold a sprawly hand at first – afterwards a small hand also, and without correction, but wrote rapidly. Shirley writes very clear good quick hand, abbreviates a good deal. Dickens writes one day and corrects and recorrects and polishes till his copy is almost illegible. Albert Smith generally wrote in pencil and then copied (as H.S. does in the train) – Sala a small clear copperplate-like hand, no correction. Tom Taylor very sprawly hand and lots of corrections and references to “back.”

div.head: February 10 [sic, actually 17], 1864.W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: 13 to dinner! T.T. sat down last! E., J.L., H.’S., F.E., S.B., J.T.,R.L., P.L., F.C.B., T.T., H.M., W.B., C.K.
H.S. from Sackford Street.

S.B. tells of the supposed epitaph on Bethell after his Judgment on Essays and Reviews. “He deprived disputing Clergymen of the privilege of consigning one another to eternal damnation, and dismissed Hell with costs.”
Richard Bethell, First Baron Westbury (1800-1873). Bethell headed the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which on February 8, 1864, overturned the heresy convictions of two contributors to Essays and Reviews, Rowland Williams and Henry Bristow Wilson. The witticism that Bethell and the council had “dismissed hell with costs” circulated widely at the time as a prospective epitaph for Bethell, attributed to parliamentary barrister Edward Henry Pember (1833-1911); see Notes and Queries 9 (15 October 1921) 316.

L.C. T.T. and S.B.,and C.K. say England is spit upon by the Continent – No, spit at, says P.L. T.T. proposes Louis as Micawber waiting for something to turn up. M.L. suggests Pen and Sword, Britannia saying “If they won’t take this I must use that.” H.M. suggests Lord Russell riding a cockhorse[?] or a Pen – J.L. improves to Johnny making a mess with the ink – emptying ink over Britannia’s. dress says J.T., but J.L.’s approved. M.L. giving the title “The Incomplete Letter Writer” [Punch, 46 (27 February 1864): 85, “John in a Mess”].
After all tho’ what else could England have done? If the Treaty has been broken is she bound to fight to mend it? If so, she will fight – but all in good time.

S.B. belikens Shakespeare to “a sort of Bouccicault – a glorified Bouccicault” – wrote his plays to order like any others of us. S.B. objects to Webster’s cant about “the Poor Player” – actors are not poor and don’t want to be pitied.They’ve less brains for their money than are found in other callings – and haven’t to pay for education etc. etc. as a barrister or doctor has.
M.L. tells of Stage Managers swearing at ballet girls “You d – b – s – I mean, my little dears.”
J.L. tells of small boy declining to polka – “Hunting men seldom dance.”

T.T. – Woman thinks it a bore, man requires it … a propos of Old Watts marrying Ellen Terry – who really loves him. She receives as a Valentine the ashes of her photographs, burnt by an admirer “Bl y fool!” bursts out Shirley.
Taylor had introduced Ellen Terry to G. F. Watts, the 46-year-old painter whom she married in 1864; a year later, he represented her in the negotiations surrounding her separation from Watts, at the same time that he was guiding her sister Kate’s career. Taylor’s correspondence about the separation is in the Bodleian. Ellen would later pay eloquent tribute to Taylor in The Story of My Life (New York: Doubleday, 1909) pp. 68, 121 as “one of the most benign and gentle of men, a good and a loyal friend” who had been more of a father to her than her real father.

div.head: February 17 [sic, actually 24], 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., S.B., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., T.T., Sir J. Paxton.
Shirley and I dine at J.L. s yesterday, meeting the Eddisons and Thorntons (Pearson married Miss E. and her sister revives old memories by telling of “Josselyn” as “Mike” Pearson calls Humfrey.)

Sir Joseph believes the country if polled would declare against a War – T.T. says had we sent our fleet to the Baltic we should have stopped the Schleswig Invasion. It cost some 600 millions to smash Napoleon, but what would England have been if she’d not done it?

L.C. S.B. anent the proposed Conference in London, announced today, suggests Lord Russell as page washing cups and getting ready for the Party – Paxton thinks the defeat of Bernal Osborne and Dizzy on Monday, asking for papers, should be the subject – S.B. suggests Austria and Prussia as the Men in Possession, looking calmly out of window and offering to confer about the legality of their occupancy. H.S. thinks and S.B. says, or have them as burglars surprised by Lord John as policeman. — S.B. next suggests something from Hamlet “You may fret me, but you may not play upon me.” King of Denmark. T.T. suggests John Bull saying “Part them, they are incensed.” Paxton says Do give Palmerston a lift – leg up with gout yet cheerful and confident. So Shirley reverts to the Tory cry for Papers – “Papers, haven’t they the Standard and the Herald – What can they want more?” Applauded as a good Punch cut – [Punch, 46 5 March (1864): 95, “Papers! Papers! Papers!” ]

Burnand applauded also for his Balletgirl letter, evinces close study of the subject.
“Spoken by a Dancer,” Punch, 46 (27 February 1864): 87

T.T. tells of Rogers saying “When I was a young man I had a very weak voice and I found I wasn’t listened to unless I said disagreeable things.” – He said to Ruskin, “Most men are like animals and you are like a Worm, a white ill conditioned Worm.” M.L. suggests that Ruskin should follow up his Stones of Venice by writing on the Stones of Chorley. — Snowing as we leave. End of the frost I hope.

div.head: March 2, 1864 . W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.,W. Bradbury, C.K.

L.C. discussed early. J.L. suggesting Dizzy as little dog barking at Pam on horseback. P.L. applauds and S.B. dissents – suggesting Louis Napoleon as Le Verrier (the Astronomer) looking through telescope in quest of Conspirators who hide in London and mistaking John Bull for an assassin – apropos of the Greco plot this, which everybody believes to have been hatched by the police – in a modified way the cut is accepted, as is the other. [Punch 46 (12 March 1864): 106, “Bark and No Bite” ; 107, “English Assassin Painted by France.”].
The “Greco plot” was an attempt to assassinate Louis Napoleon. Greco, one of four Italian assassins, claimed to be acting under the direction of Mazzini, who was in exile in London. See the Times report of the trial, February 27, 1864, p. 10.

S.B. quotes D. Jerrold’s lines apropos of Albert Smith and his uncle, the Ironmonger of Fleet Street – “My uncle Water Closets makes Malodorous of vapour And I who scribble books for Bogue Of course supply the paper.
David Bogue was a well-known Fleet Street publisher who specialized in comic works, including Punch’s short-lived rival The Man in the Moon (1847-49), edited by Albert Smith and Angus Bethune Reach. Smith’s friend H. Sutherland Edwards mistakenly attributes this “scurrilous epigram” (without actually quoting it) to Father Prout; Edwards, Personal Recollections (London: Cassell, 1900), p. 189. It had evidently, like so many Jerrold stories, made the rounds of the London clubs.Young lady and lavender – “You should smell my drawers.” lst lady “Have you seen Mr. E. Landseer’s 'Bottom'?” 2nd lady, correcting her, “You mean his Ass.” S.B.

The Great Will case decided yesterday as Sir J.Paxton said it should be, declaring the Codicils to be forgeries – by Else, or somebody Else. Nuttall’s wish was to make everyone squabble about his money, and the lawyers certainly have done their best to carry out his wish.
When surveyor George Nuttall of Matlock, Derbyshire, died in 1856, his will left most of his £10,000 estate to his son, John, who died soon thereafter. John Else, a relative by marriage, came forward with three codicils to Nuttall’s will that gave Else the bulk of the real estate. After various highly publicized legal proceedings, the case was appealed to the House of Lords, which determined on a new trial to be heard before the Lord Chief Justice Cockburn. The jury found, and Cockburn ruled, that the codicils were forgeries. See leader on “The Great Matlock Will Case,” in the Times, May 20, 1864.
Ponny at Charles Mathews’ dance at the Egyptian Hall – – Who were the Ladies?

Burnand says the two Webbs at the Princess’s as alike as two Peas. The play is a mere farce – and one gets so puzzled by the Dromios that one rather gets disgusted.
Henry Webb, manager of the Queen’s Theatre in Dublin, and his brother, Charles Webb, toured together as the twin Dromios in A Comedy of Errors. It opened at the Princess’s Theatre in London on February 27, 1864. See the Times review on February 29, 1864, p. 9, which comments upon “the extraordinary resemblance between the brothers Webb.” Leech proposes a sketch of “Mrs. Roseleaf” – in a tailcoat to wit. Applauds it as all must do – best thing Parry ever did.
Welsh actor and musician John Parry (1810-1879) wrote and performed all of the characters in a series of comic sketches that featured the central figure of Mrs. Roseleaf, beginning in 1862 with “Mrs Roseleaf’s Little Evening Party,” for Thomas German Reed’s Gallery of Illustration in Regent Street.

Shirley shows another number of the Photographic Autographic News – with a note from Leech “Yes with pleasure if I can get an ‘oss.’ The thing is dangerous – fancy seeing a photograph of one’s signature to a dishonoured bill!

div.head: March 9. 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.B., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., C.K.

A glass of champagne to drink success to Shirley’s new novel, the first MS being actually in the printer’s hands. “So you fellows mustn’t expect much copy from me till June” says Shirley. When will H.S. write a novel in a couple of months?

J.L. at Meyer de Rothschild’s – “talk of the Arabian Nights entertainments! Their splendour nothing to Smouch’s” – playing the Toy Symphony when he went – wonder if they had a Jew’s harp? Queer to see a parson blowing a penny trumpet and a pretty girl puffing her cheeks out with a whistle in a glass of water. Shirley tells of Walter Lacy saying damn in the greenroom and begging pardon of Mrs. Charles Kean, who answered “Ask pardon of your God, Sir, and Charles” – (greater person named last, says Shirley) – Song thereanent by one King, describing the consternation of the actors – “Erect stood each hair, On Carlotta Leclerq, Heath Bufton and Murray Were all in a flurry, etc. Chorus: And did he say damn in the Greenroom? Yes, by G , he said damn in the Greenroom: Then out let us cast him, Confound him and blast him – The Man who said damn in the greenroom!”
Actor Walter Lacy (1809-1898), known for light comedy, was part of Charles Kean’s company at the Princess’s Theatre for seven years. A slightly different version of this story appeared in print thirty years later in Montagu Williams, Round London: Down East and Up West (London: Macmillan, 1893), 275. Williams recalls the swearer as John Ryder, another member of Kean’s company, and gives the author of the song as “poor Joe Langford, for so many years a favorite at the Garrick Club.” – Shirley has a memory like an elephant’s trunk that can pick up a tonweight or a pin. And his memory is always at command – which mine seldom is. Mine is staircase wit – recollecting on the staircase what you should have said in the drawing room.

Anecdotes of Jerrold: Saying to Mrs. Frank Mathews, pouring tea out of a long spout “You do it like a man.” Lady says “Blank is too fickle to marry Miss – he has been on and off ever so many times.” “Ah,” says J., then depend he’ll never marry her.”
Burnand – Man tired and sweaty, “I’ll sleep like a top.” “Yes,” says friend, “and smell like a bottom.”

Talking of Rowland Hill, Shirley says in the next century perhaps there’ll be no letters written – all correspondence done by telegraph. Leech pictures a Swell saying, “Aw, I nevah write a letter – such a baw writing – I send a telegwam!”—Also pictures Man sending a message to his sweetheart, “Dearest, I love and adore you” etc., etc., and pretty telegraph clerkess saying “There’s a word or two too much, Sir. Perhaps you’d better strike out the “adore”?” Mark suggests the substitution of a \ for “marry” to save a word in a message, “I love you and am ready to marry you.”— Leech tells of Swell saying, “My intentions are Honourable I asshaw you except of course I can’t mawwy you, you know.”

Sir Rowland Hill’s retirement the subject, says Mark – S.B. suggests, “The Modern Cadmus”—motto, “He gave us Letters,” Or why not reproduce the original Penny Envelope, and direct it as a letter of introduction to Posterity.” Leech says he parodied this design of Mulready’s and got only £5 for it – putting as a motto, “Mulled already.” “A man of the right Stamp” and “a man of Letters” rejected as mere puns. “Don’t see why one should be so serious,” says Keene. “Must be graceful, or don’t do it,” M.L. “I am the Eldest Son of good Sir Rowland,” S.B. — “Sir Rowland ‘ill” would represent the real facts, says Leech, make him resting, worn out – “Ease after Letters,” says Ponny, quoting Holywell St., etc. Britannia patting her prize man of Letters, M.L. – “A First Class man in Litterae Humaniores” says Ponny. – Shirley insists that Hill has done more to civilize England than half a dozen Shakespeares. No poor person ever wrote to another till the penny post came. Suggests Hill reclining asleep, and dreaming of the good effects of his work. “Pity he’s not dead,” says Charles Keene – “I mean for the artist’s sake.” Leech suggests Hill smoking and the pictures of his work seen in the fumes. – “How am I to draw Posterity” says Tenniel. ... Charles says, “But if Hill hadn’t invented it, somebody else would.” – “Then we’d better have a Monument to Somebody Else,” says Burnand. Shirley suggests Hill and Cromwell as two great Reformers – One cut off a bad King’s head, the other stuck on a good Queen’s head. – But his dream idea is decided on [ Punch, 46 (19 March 1864): 117, “Sir Rowland le Grand” ]. And Leigh is urged to parody the old ballad, “Sir Rowland to the dark tower came.” ... – Mark asks if I’ve any plan for the Balletgirl fund that I suggested should be raised. A Mrs. Harriette Blakeley says she and Mrs. Lancaster and Mrs. Leech are willing to help. But how?

div.head: March 16, 1864. W[ednesday]. N2. 11.
div.p: H.S., S.B., J.T.., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., W.B., T.T.

Chaff Charles about his encoring a subject of his last week – artist and dealer, used May 5, 1861. Young Dick Hannen told me of it on Sunday when I dined with him at Bromley’s – after a walk round the Zoologicals (thank you, Dr. Schater for sending me that card).

Burnand says Apollo (Maitland, terrestiale nomen) is protected by Marquis of Bute now clever and pleasant face – but somewhat spindle-shanky He thinks Compton very slow and stupid at rehearsal won’t take a part unless it has plenty of good lines in it. Imitates his gruff speaking and tight shutting of his mouth at end of a sentence. T.T. echoes the complaint.
Henry Compton (1805-1877), best known for comic roles in Shakespearean productions.

Leech talks of Herbert who has just finished his House of Lords fresco. Affected Roman Catholic – went to Paris for a week and now speaks broken English. Regretted to Tom Taylor that he had christened his boy “Wycliffe.” Tom said he should christen the next Luther.
John Rogers Herbert, R.A. (1810-1890). Under the influence of childhood friend A. W. Pugin, Herbert converted to Catholicism in 1840. The fresco to which Leech is referring, Moses Bringing Down the Tables of the Law, was begun in 1858 and not completed until March, 1864; it was one of a series of frescoes commissioned for the new Palace of Westminster.
J.L. tells of Scotchman hearing a joke and returning a year after to laugh at it, “I hae ye noo.”

S.B. says Thackeray walking with a ponderous Swell couldn’t get him to talk – until they met a very pretty girl whom T. praised., – Ah, said Swell, I had that girl (five minutes pause) – my aw brother had that girl (another five minutes) Point of fact we aw both had her.

M.L. shows us a photo of Father Ignatius, a young smooth faced priestly looking fellow, posed in a pious posture – shows also a note from Taylor to correct proof of his lines on Bumbledom – contends that he writes legibly – chorus of derision. Like à Beckett, writes “all over the sheet.”

L.C. S.B. suggests Ajax (Pam) throwing his aegis over Teucer (Russell) which is immediately approved [ Punch, 46 (26 March 1864): 127, “Teucer, Assailed by Hector, is Protected by the Shield of Ajax” ] – Evans fearing public won’t understand it.
Shirley Brooks diary, 16 March 1864, “Punch d. and I suggested the cut” (Houghton Library) Pam spoke up like a trump on Monday – when Roebuck attacked Russell said the Government were responsible for all that Russell had done. And refused any kudos unless Russell and the rest shared in it.
Mark begs for earlier copy – and Evans says the circulation now renders it necessary that the number should go to press Saturday night – then we must try and reduce the circulation, says Leech.

H.S. to Strand “Orpheus and Eurydice” with 3 Gascoignes. Last night had a chat with Shepherd at the Surrey after ‘Ashore and Afloat.’ How old is he? Well made up – fresh & hale & hearty. His soft voice reminded me of T. P. Cooke.
Ashore and Afloat, a naval drama by Colin Henry Hazlewood (1823–1875). Thomas Potter Cooke (1786-1864) is best known today as the first actor to portray the monster in Frankenstein. Shirley thinks there should be open voting in Clubs – has seen how ballot is abused. Leech thinks personal objections should not weigh in voting – but bores should be blackballed merely for their boorishness.
 [drawing of pointing hand] Thackeray’s sale begins today.

div.head: March 23, [1864] W[ednesday]. No. 11, 1864.
div.p: H.S. from Seckford St. and dines at Holland Park with Horace and Arthur: who epitomize the Public School Blue Book. Westminster and Charterhouse advised to move into the country, and St. Paul’s to the Regent’s Park. Average education, even in classics, not what it should be at such an expense.
H.S. with J.N. on Good Friday. Sunny till London smoke came down. Drove on to Fasting Down.

div.head: March 30, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L, H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., T.T.

Taylor at the Review near Guilford on Monday despite the cold and wet. Is a Volunteer only from a sense of duty, hates it. C.K. absent on Monday, hates reviews. Did you go on a horse, says Burnand. “No,” says Leech. “No, not what you can call a horse.” ... Clergyman shot and killed by ramrod at this Review.

Talk of man dying in Burnand’s “Rumpelstiltzken” on Monday, H.S. present. Burnand rather prone to prate of his plays. – Blows up Compton. – “Compton you may depend is right,” says Mark. Pretty seashore “scene” he says at Haymarket. Tell of Taylor’s taking actor aside after a first night and saying, “You know you’re a damned ass to play the part so.” Taylor tells of his Canterbury scene in The Wreck Ashore –and how he had prepared a mulberry[?] for his face and had to carry it throughout the scene in his hand – reminds Leech of Liston putting an oyster into the hand of Miss Stevens just before she sang a song – fancy singing a sentimental song with an oyster in your hand!

H.S. at Drury Lane last night to see Henry IV and so was P.L. with his “little boy,” after treating him to 2/6 worth of soup and whitebait and port wine at the Albion. Says Phelps’ Falstaff was like a fat Hamlet too stolid: not rollicking and racy enough. Agrees with H.S. that Miss Wynn’s Welsh talk and song were pretty – and that there was not long enough fighting in the battle, considering the numbers. T.T. carries off C.K. and F.C.B. to see it – after the Great Cut discussion.

L.C. S.B. reads bit from Standard saying Pam is getting too old to be useful. Suggests Mrs. Gamp, “We want a nice young man.” What we wants is Wigour, says T.T. accepted [ Punch, 46 (9 April 1864): 148, “The Idle Gossips” ]. Garibaldi the other cut – his visit to England is to get support and money, in case the war goes on in Denmark, Germany will attack Austria and all Lombardy be up. T.T. suggests Italy handing him to Britannia and saying, “Take care of him.” M.L. adds some thing about Garibaldi’s lame foot, “You’ll soon be able to wear the (Italy) Boot yet, if you keep quiet a bit.” P.L. suggests Garibaldi presented by Punch with the Freedom of his Office – which E. interprets to mean simply putting him on the free list. J.L. rather sneers at G[aribaldi], and M.L. thinks him the greatest man of the age – so unselfish and bravehearted. But weak in head says Shirley: who suggests Punch rowing him ashore or receiving him on landing (à la William III) A Roman Triumph – Punch as Roman welcoming him – Evans adds “This is the Noblest Roman of them all” to which Leech would add, “Next to me.” Civis Romanus sum. Pam receiving him also suggested: but the other the best. P.L. suggested G[aribaldi] glad to breathe British air – the air of Freedom: “Yes, says Leech, make him landing in a good English fog.” [ Punch, 46 (9 April 1864): 149, “This is the Noblest Roman of Them All”] T.T. says his little boy hearing he, at Brighton Review, was “allowed on a horse,” asked whether Phillips was allowed on a cocked hat – which he was wearing. “This seat is intended for five Parsons” – some wag had altered inscription.

Will Marcus Stone get into the Garrick? J.L. defends him from the charge of ill treating his Mother. (Whom Frank Stone kept before he married her). M.L. doubts.
Artist Marcus Stone (1840-1921) was best known in the 1860s as a young illustrator of novels by Dickens (Our Mutual Friend, The Mystery of Edwin Drood) and Trollope ( He Knew He Was Right); by the following decade he had abandoned illustration for a successful career as a painter. Stone was admitted to the Garrick Club. See Shirley Brooks’s diary entry for April 2, 1864: “ ‘G’ committee. Marcus Stone up for today. There had been a set against him, touching certain alleged misusage of his mother, but 3 men said that they had made enquiries, and were satisfied, so he came in unanimously.” (Houghton Library) M.L. always takes a woman’s part – kind old boy – not spoiled by success, as too many clever fellows get to be. He tells Tenniel and me a lot of stories of his hunting exploits – fancy Mark in pink! – how he was stuck upon a big horse that had never before been saddled, and was whisked over a hedge and gate before he knew it – how another day he fell under the horse and was dragged out, day before he was 21 – lay abed a month after that birthday, when he danced with crutches. My garters are blue – said a sister of a friend of his, who “went into the country” soon after – i.e. to the Regent’s Park – £100 the fee.

Tom says Rawlingson the Government Surveyor told him he calculated the Sheffield W.W. flood ran 45 miles an hour and was 15 feet deep. People thought the End of the World was come and jumped out of windows into the flood. Houses halved by it.
The Sheffield flood of March 11, 1864, caused by the failure of the Dale Dyke Dam just before midnight, killed over 250 people. See Times leaders on March 15, p. 11 and March 17, p. 10.

div.head:
April 7, 1864. W[ednesday.]
Perhaps a slip of the pen, as April 7, 1864, was a Thursday. No. 11.
div.p: H.S., F.E., S.B., M.L., P.L., W.B., C.K.
(H.S. from Church Street – his first visit there since October. Lois over, prenuptial visit.)

Stansfield’s resignation has trumped the Tory knaves. His Mazzini intimacy, brought to light by the French Procurer General of course gave them a casus belli.
James Stansfield (1820-1898), M.P. for Halifax, was accused by Disraeli and the Tories of having been in correspondence with members of the Greco conspiracy to assassinate Napoleon III. After surviving a vote of censure, he resigned his seat, but was re-elected the following year. He later served in Gladstone’s cabinet.

P.L. suggests Stansfield doubling his fists, and Derby and Dizzy backing out of it. But we agree the affair will be swamped by the Budget which comes tomorrow. Sugar free says S.B. and no reduction in Income Tax. S.B. suggests the Shakespeare line, “Why strewest thou sugar on this bottled spider?” Income Tax to wit which faute de mieux is accepted [Punch, 46 (10 April 1864): 159, “Goody Gladstone’s Gifts” ] subject to revision on Friday.
See Times leader anticipating budget (April 7, 1864, p. 10), in which the duties on sugar as well as the income tax were reduced. We should have a Punch breakfast after the Budget.

J.L. lets out his hate of pet dogs – all dogs should be shot except sporting dogs, for they don’t howl – Oh, don’t they? Tie up a pointer in a strange place and see. Suggests an article showing various canine nuisances: Carman’s dog, bilious pet dog, – etc. S.B. quotes the Shakespeare motto for the new Garrick W.C. – Floodgate selected – Lady Macbeth, “When all is done, you look but on a stool.” Some one else suggests Macbeth – “I’ve done the deed: dids’t thou not hear a noise?” And S.B. suggests from Merchant of Venice, “My ventures are not on one bottom fixed.”

M.L. applauds Henry IV at Drury – gave him more pleasure than any play for a long while has done. Phelps too hard but good on the whole. (Shirley says Mark can play Falstaff better than anyone.) Montgomery’s Hotspur fiery enough – looks the part well, and the scene with his wife and Glendower is especially good.
Silver favorably reviewed the play, and Walter Montgomery's performance as Hotspur, in his “Our Dramatic Correspondent,” Punch 46 (30 April 1864): 175. M.L. shouts to Leech in the manner of old gentleman – he forgets that E.T. Smith has left the Drury and that Keeley has left the stage.
Then to Princess’s and see the 2 Dromios– certainly the Brothers Webb are wondrously alike. And the play goes better and more glibly than one would think. No pause in it for the Old[?] drop.

div.head: April 11, 1864. Monday. No. 11.
div.p: Garibaldi’s entry into London: warm and sunny day.
E., H.S., W.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., J.L.

Special invitation to consider the Shakespeare Number.
Punch’s Tercentenary Number, 46 (23 April 1864). – Leech somewhat sneers at it: but keeps his sneer to himself, his only suggestion is the joke of representing the Queen as one of the Merry Wives of Windsor. ... H.S. and P.L. both sent in a suggestion or two on Saturday – and both hit on Diz as Shylock apparently. H.S. suggests Pam, Prospero – Russell, Ariel – Spurgeon, Sir Oliver Martext – Garibaldi, Coriolanus, “he’ll to Rome as is the osprey to the fish.” North and South America, the 2 Dromios. J, so alike, Abe Lincoln, the Gravedigger – Bottom & Co. as the Shakespeare Committee, or his Commentators – Tupper the poet Cinca, “tear him for his bad verses” – Lord Grey, Dogberry, “Truly I would not hang a dog against his will.” Roebuck as Bottom, “Let me play the Lion” – Louis Napoleon, Richard III – no says P.L., Julius Caesar,”Why, man, he doth bestride the world like a Colossus... Bernal Osborne, Touchstone. H.S. more up to this than to great cuts generally. – Mark suggests Macbeth with an organ, “Macbeth doth murder sleep” C.K., Shaftsbury, Falconbridge – Burnand, Falstaff, Banting – an idea H.S. had thought of – S.B., Brougham as Snout – Delane, Hamlet saying, “The Times are out of joint.” Mazzini as Lady Macbeth, “Infirm of purpose, don’t give me the daggers” (apropos of the “Dagger theory” Mazzini has been writing about). Burnand, Black, Edinburgh M.P., as Othello, “What tho’ I’m Black”. – And so forth.

Horace describes his visit yesterday to the Hermit of Dickens’ Tom Tiddler’s Ground, whose name is Lucas (brother of Tham, says Shirley) and who lives in his cellar with a blanket round him and hair to his waist, some dozen miles or so from St. Albans. Has £800 a year and sits on a heap of cinders. Copper coloured face, gives silver to Roman Catholics and copper to others who ask him. Plays with children on grass plot – but otherwise never leaves the cellar. General verdict “a nasty lunatic” – but Horace says he’s au courant du jour, reads newspapers etc etc. and talks rationally enough. Keeps a gig umbrella to hold over ladies who come to his grating, when it rains. House large and windows all smashed.
James Lucas (1813-1874), who lived near Stevenage in Hertfordshire; he was locally known as “Mad Lucas.” See Dickens’s story, “Tom Tiddler’s Ground,” in the extra Christmas number of All the Year Round, in 1861, where Lucas appears as “Mr. Mopes.”
Last week, J.L. suggests Mr. Punch’s Gallery of Shakespeare Portraits – Buckstone as Hamlet, etc. Also for Great Cut, John Bull, “Sugar! Mr. Banting says I mustn’t take sugar.”
S.B. apropos of J.T.’s absence quuotes, “And wring from famine the embrace of love.”

H.S. in Pall Mall this afternoon – mob waiting from 2 to 6 nearly before procession came – club swells chucking coppers for a scramble till Police Swell on horse back begged them to desist. Garibaldi colours and feathers in caps etc. etc. Sight from Whitehall wonderful pyramid of people clustered on base of Nelson Column. Statue of King Charles and a lot of carts and buses. Meagre procession – thin line of trades’ society men with flags and banners – no space kept open for them, so they got on as they could, disjointedly – chaffed immensely by wags in the crowd. That’s not him as was hung, is it? – Hullo here’s Calcraft, said of somebody with an axe. Foresters in feathered hats and Robin Hood dresses, rouged faces some had.—Burnand stopped by mob, had to go round by St. James’s Park. S.B. says he doesn’t think a really great man would have stooped to such snobbery as this entry but M.L. and H.S. say Garibaldi couldn’t help it you couldn’t have the Government welcome him – so no soldiers or police could keep the line: and now the populace have brought him in, the Swells will entertain him... Leech, of course, hates the whole thing and sneers at the Working Man as usual.

div.head: April 20, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p:  [drawing of pointing hand] Garibaldi to the City. Punch Lunch. W.B. Senior redivivus. E., J.L., H.S.,. C.K., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., W.B., T.T. [W.B., Junior = W.B. now.]

T.T. says the Real Cause of Garibaldi’s going is that his reception here stirs up the Mazzini men in Italy and embarrasses the Italian Government. Suggests Victor E[mmanuel] crying to Palmerston, “he’s setting my house on fire – for God’s sake put him out.” But that would represent him as a firebrand, says Horace. — T.T. says he was with William Cooper and other Government Swells Monday week to see the General enter, and compromised the Government by throwing tricoloured bouquets to him: “Red, emblem of the blood you’ve shed – white, of the purity of your patriotism – green, of the growing hope we have of your complete success in regenerating Italy.” Certainly I never saw such a scene of enthusiastic welcome as at the Crystal Palace on Saturday. Mario and Guiglini and Madle Vitali shouting out their chorus and stretching out their hands to “Nostro Salvator”; who after bowing gravely and smiling his thanks, at length slowly clapped his hands to recognize his welcomers. (The only drizzling day since he came. We have been having summer Sunshine without interruption.)

F.C.B. as Roman Catholic of course doesn’t applaud him – thinks Jerry Bawldi is becoming a Bore, glad he’s going – as I dare say are the Tories in their hearts tho’ they daren’t say so. Really ridiculous how they try to fasten on the Government some blame for his departure – I believe his health really is the cause of it. No one could go through the Programme before him without having his head turned or at least his hand shaken off. It’s a wondrous fact this welcoming a man alike by Lords and Labourers for the mere reason of his fight for Liberty and his honesty and purity when he had gained his triumph. Garibaldi has nothing to give us but his friendship – yet how we all love him and like to do him homage. In this age of selfseeking scrambles after power and purseworship, it is certainly a grand thing to see a nation for once forget them both, and do honour to poor Honesty.

L.C. The Conference meets today (and adjourns till Monday) and as Shakespeare is now uppermost we must have a Shakespeare cut about it. (By the way, we all give kudos to Tenniel for his Shakespeare Number Picture – which is put on the table.
Punch, 64 (23 April 1864) 6-7: “Tercentenary Triumphal Procession of William Shakeskeare”) P.L. suggests “Pat, pat – a marvellous convenient place (this London) for our Rehearsal.” T.T. the Sonderburg slaughtering and Prussian envoy saying, “Thou cans’t not say I did it.” T.T., Pam and Dizzy quarrelling – “Do you bite your thumb at me Sir?” Also suggests Toby at Conference door sniffing at the ink which flows under it [ Punch, 46 (30 April 1864): 180, “Suspense.” ] Tenniel for Keene’s guidance draws from memory Sir E. Landseer’s bloodhound (which by the bye Miss B. sent to Fanny last month and I hung for her). P.L. suggests Russell as Hamlet saying, “To be or not to be,” as his political future existence hangs on the way he gets through The Conference. But the Toby cut preferred. C.K.’s debut in the Great Cut line, if he does it.*

Subscription begun for Garibaldi – J.L. thinks he should be drawn as a Prize Boy, “There’s a tip for you – only mind, don’t spend it in those nasty fireworks.” (minstrels) – J.L. still nervous about himself – defied by 2 organ men yesterday who called him, “you bly sht,” “you bly bgr” etc. in the choicest Billingsgate. Said if he hadn’t feared excitement he would have knocked them down, the beasts, for he had his children with him.

div.head: April 27, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., W.B.

A note from Shirley to say that on Friday he is 49! “and so Pater must let you have some of what he calls champagne.” – Says he’s full of morphia and misery – I think I’d rather have my small indigestive headaches than have a triennial go of gout.

Leech very wroth with Evans for altering the wrapper from “Mr. Romford’s Hounds” to “Mr. Facey Romford’s Hounds” as it is on titlepage.
Leech had been the illustrator for four of Robert Surtees’s comic novels, Mr. Sponge’s Sporting Tour (1853), Handley Cross (1854), Ask Mama (1858), and Plain or Ringlets? (1860), all published by Bradbury and Evans. As early as 1861 Surtees had been eager to secure Leech as illustrator for Mr. Facey Romford’s Hounds, but Leech’s other commitments caused a long delay, and Surtees died on March 16, 1864. Bradbury & Evans published the book in twelve monthly parts between May 1864 and April 1865. After Leech’s death in October, the illustrations for parts eight through twelve were undertaken by Hablot K. Browne (“Phiz”). The “wrapper” is the folded, decoratively printed colored paper (in this instance reddish brown) enclosing each number. Says he took the pains to trace the letters backwards so that there should be no mistake. Now from being a book fit for a drawing room it is fit only for a sporting public house. M.L. explains after J.L. has gone that Surtees (who’s dead) meant to draw a snob and so purposely used the word “Facey.” Who was that ex-groom who became a Master of a Pack where Dick Watson hunted? It’s this practice that Surtees wished to expose. We all agree that Leech is out of health and should take rest – but Mark thinks he wouldn’t give up his dinner engagements. To get into Society has been the aim of his life, and now he seems to have lost all taste for enjoyment. M.L. and P.L. both say it annoys him to think Punch could go on without him – even for a month. Curious pride this and yet quite natural. He has always been a spoilt child says Mark, lets petty worries master him, and it is sad to think that his great gifts have not made him a more happy man. … J.L. said he went to Charterhouse t’other day to see running matches, jumpings, and other athletic sports. A new thing this.

L.C. S.B. suggests the Order of St. Gibbet for the King of Prussia – which is at once approved.
In capturing the Danish fort town of Dybböl, the Prussians had been guilty of atrocities that were deplored in Times leaders of April 25, p. 10, and April 26, 1864, p. 10. [Punch, 46 (7 May 1864): 191, “The Reward of (De)Merit” ]. Also hopes we wont forget the extinguishing of the National Shakespeare.Committee which did nothing on the 23 rd unless the Oak Planting at Primrose Hill was a deed of their suggestion. Pater says he’d like to publish a book, “What Birds Eat” and asks me to do it. But it would take a man living in the country and having lots of leisure.

Lucas married! “Done for himself” says Leech. Next week Pater says the marriage took place a dozen years ago and was concealed for fear of Lucas’ father, who is now dead. A wrong thing so to treat a wife. Of course her reputation suffers.

Discussion as to whether the Bible should be castrated. M.L. and H.S. No. W.B. and Pater Yes –or, at least, they think such phrases as “He that pisseth against a wall” should be retranslated. Of course, “male” is what is meant. Certainly the age is more delicate in words than any former one we know of – but is it so in thoughts? For myself I like plain blunt Saxon names instead of foreign euphuisms, which are quite as nasty in their meaning tho’ thought nicer in their sound. A girl shrinks instinctively from the one, but sees no harm in the other. And so her mind becomes corrupted.

M.L. applauds Cardwick for saying “God chose the Stage for his greatest genius (Shakespeare).” Why are authors jealous and artists not? asks M.L. Tenniel began Big Cut Friday evening at 6 and finished at 2 a.m. (H.S. to Stratford – the Shakespeare flower Show tomorrow: and thence to Kenilworth.)

div.head: May 4, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11. (First asparagus.)
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E.f S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B.

L.C. P.L. suggests John Bull and his trainer Russell – “he’s ready for the fight.” King of Prussia keeping a butcher’s shop. S.B., Shade of Nelson, “Now I’ll make up to you for Copenhagen.” John Bull as Gulliver capturing the Prussian Fleet (apropos of the Channel Fleet being in the Downs and ready for action). – P.L., England and France, “If your Cock will fight, my Bulldog will.” S.B., J.Bull holding back his dog – showing Austria and Prussia his teeth. Amends it to Bull as Policeman threatening the Burglars, “You’re not on my beat yet, but… [Punch, 46 (14 May 1864): 201, “The Aggravated Policeman” ].

S.B. says the first Number of Our Mutual Friend is a very weak one. Dickens can’t draw a gentleman or a dinner party –Thackeray could.
The first monthly number of Dickens's Our Mutual Friend appeared in May 1864, comprising the first four chapters. Chapters five through seven appeared in the second installment at the beginning of June; see Silver's entry for June 1, with Taylor's and Silver's comments. — Shakespeare and Scott both instances that self abnegation is one of the marks of genius. — J.L. says Millais was a virgin when he married. And Ponny believes Hunt was the same. “The Awakened Conscience” couldn’t seduce him.
J.L. hates boys to go birdnesting. P.L. thinks they do it in the spirit of natural historians.

div.head: May 11,1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., W.B., T.T.

J.L. thinks Wilkie forced and unnatural – his Scotch Hindman’s buffer painted from a London drayman, his colour poor and his treatment niggling. J.T. and T.T. contra. J.L. says the Irish peasant among his master’s “Old Masters” is the most genuine picture in point of humour that has been seen since Hogarth. ... Glad to see old Landseer come out this year as he has done in the Squirrels (pair of Nutcrackers) and the Bears.

T.T. says the “best heads in the Cabinet” (Pam, Russell, and (I think) Gladstone), were for sending a ship to the Adriatic and 10,000 men to the Daneswerk last Autumn and believes this would have prevented the fighting. Venetia is Austria’s fear of course and if Europe had blazed into War, we could not have been blamed for it. Thinks peace very doubtful. If England is to keep the position she must not stand aloof. So surely as the voice of the Tenpound Householder becomes the voice of the country, so surely will her downfall begin. ... M.L. and P.L. differ from this view – hold that we had no right to interfere. Yes, says T.T., we had – as party to the Treaty of ‘52, and it was a good opportunity to show that we dared to act alone – for the odds were neither Prussia nor Austria would have faced us.

L.C. T.T. suggests French cat feigning to be asleep and British bulldog really so, “Let sleeping cats lie” – fable of the cat and mice – Austria and Prussia mice making a row. P.L., Danish. Raven giving the Black Eagles a peck – apropos of the Danish Sea Victory – which the Austrian Admiral gets promoted for!

M.L., Policeman Bull stopping the fight. T.T., Landseer’s 2 bears tearing the Treaty (flag) of 1852. J.L., The 2 Nutcrackers hard at it while John Bull sips his claret—or, Conference all asleep: “What is done by the Conference”—P.L. suggests Conference Bench of Magistrates and either he or Mark hit on the neat phrase “Remanded for a Month,” that being the period of Armistice: dating from tomorrow ... approved ... [Punch, 46 (21 May 1864): 211, “Brutal Assault – Remanded for a Month” ].

J.L. thinks Bass’s Street Music Bill should be helped by a cut of the “Two Barrels” beer and organs. Or, organmen toiling uphill “Excelsior” – better say up a treadmill, says Burnand, who suggests “Removing the Grinder,” John Bull at the Dentist’s – organ extracted. “Oh that dreadful headache – ha!ha! cured in an instant.” Basso relièvo: as Tom Hood called it. Sotto to M.L. and J.L., “I’ve just come from the Mill and so I know I’m clean.” T.T. says his little boy and his friend went out walking with 2 gentlemen and came home and said, Oh, Mamma – such fun – we’ve been drinking out of all the horsetroughs – they didn’t a bit take care of us!”

J.L. tells of Millais’ eldest boy wrapping little brother up in a wet towel, “like Mamma does herself to cure him of a pain in his ’tomach.” – T.T.’s boy’s attempt at drawing a Bird of ‘Sparagus (Paradise). – Burnand imagines an after dinner lecturer talking thickly of the fate of our firsht parents who were casht out of ‘Sparagus!
H.S. leaves early to hear the Pastoral Symphony. Attended Shakespeare School meeting today to hear Dickens — Also T.T., Trollope (his py) and Th. Martin.
J.L. going to Hamburg soon: in better spirits: was funked about himself.

div.head: May 18, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Waresley – 17 to 24 – thermometer 83° in shade 18th. Croquet, billiards.

div.head: May 25, 1864. W[ednesday]. No dinner
div.p: – Derby Day. With Frith and Saunders (Nor bit nor sup. Blair Athol won. Walk to Croydon. Joe Niell.)

div.head: June 1, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.

S.B. looks pale and worn by his Colchian bout.
Possibly a reference to colcichine, an alkaloid drug used to treat gout. These attacks worse than my small headaches. T.T. talker general – disappointed (is that the word for it?) with “Our Mutual Friend” and its whirling absurdities and arseoverheadishness. That dinner party with the Analytical Chemist I tried to read through it and couldn’t. The tea taking scene in No. 2 better – farcical fun in the “I’ll sort your vertebrae” etc. etc.
The first monthly number of Dickens's Our Mutual Friend appeared in May 1864, comprising the first four chapters; see Silver's entry for May 4, with Brooks's comment on the first number. Chapters five through seven appeared in the second installment in June. T.T. criticises Hamlet at the Lyceum – no middle distance possible with the French scenes – so the Ghost is stuck close to the footlights and the other actors have to elbow him almost – destroys effect of the fine opening. Kate Terry a delightful Ophelia. Fechter plays right through without a change of wig or a ruffle as his dress, to denote his assumed insanity. Boy introduced as playing the.lady’s part in the play and absurdly wears the highheeled shoe, chopine, while in his boy’s clothes. But query if this shoe was only worn by women. That Bellua, Bellew, of course suggested this, says P.L. T.T. thinks Fechter a bad fellow.
T.T. tells of his being entrusted with the care of a young Civil Servant to Germany and being asked to keep him from gambling and then Mentor took to play while Telemachus stood by.

P.L. reads prospectus of a proposed Spirit Power Institute for the use of Spiritbelievers. Talking of Landseer and his Lions – J.L. suggests Lion calling on Landseer to know when he may leave off sitting as a model.
“Wash your hands, Mrs. —. “Thanks, no, we availed outselves of the shrubbery,” S.B.

L,C. – P.L. suggests John Bull disturbed by German Band. H.S. amends notion to Europe vice JB. T.T. thinks the cut should be England eating dirt pie. S.B. agrees – but it wouldn’t do for Punch to tell the truth in the matter – suggests John Russell appealed to by Denmark to uphold the Treaty of ‘52 and saying, “I will as high as I can, but I’m a little man you know.” Napoleon patting Russell on his back, “Thanks, you’ve been playing into my hands exactly.” Several other poor suggestions and at last its agreed to postpone the Conference Cut, and S.B. suggests the following up of Gladstone the false start [ Punch, 46 (28 May 1864): 223, “The False Start”] by Out of the Race: apropos of his Preface of explanations to his published speech [ Punch, 46 (11 June 1864): 243, “Out of the Race” ].
H.S. to Olympic afterwards. Ticket of Leave and Sense and Sensation.

div.head: June 8, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E. J.L,., H.S., F.E., J.T., P.L., F.C.B., T.T. First strawberries.

Burnand acting with the ADC’s at Cambridge last week – Prince and Princess there: she so simple and natural, says T.T., contrasts strongly with the stiffstarched ladies of her Court. S.B. at the Oxford Flareup today – Rowland Hill D.C.L’d.
H S. at the Ocean Match at Harwich on Saturday and on Sunday to Lowestoft – And so we play our parts.

Mrs. Nethercote said you entertained her at dinner very much indeed, says J.L.: “She’s a very sensible woman,” says Tom. –Good simile that of Osborne’s Ministers, in their Conference conduct, are like the nuns of La Trappe, while they keep silent they are digging their own graves. T.T. for L.C. suggests half a loaf better than no bread – beggar won’t do tho’, so suggests old soldier and J.T. adds John Russell as Beadle [ Punch, 46 (18 June 1864): 253, “The Beadle and the Dane” ].
H.S. to dance at Ab. Garnett’s, sun shining brightly at 4 o’clock.

div.head: June 15, 1864. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: E., J.L., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M.

Other humorists besides the great H.S. dream of jokes and wake to find them worthless, But P.L. thinks he made an exception t’other night in “There are 2 sides to every question, as the man said when he wiped his a with sandpaper.” J.E. quotes a bit of Jerrold’s dreaming – “Our hero now is grown so tall, His bottom is his head.”

S.B. tells of snob asking Lord Gifford how he pronounced his name – “Hard, Sir, as in b---r.” S.B. also tells of asparagus, “So large Sir I give you my honour my daughter blushed when she handled it.”

J.L. wrote to Gladstone about street music – G. having spoken against Bass’s Bill. The Band in the Park’s a very different thing to a street organ, methinks, Mr. G. J.L. off to Hamburg with Elinore tomorrow – and we all shake him by the hand and wish him Better.

L.C. The Tories have abandoned their threatened attack on the Government, says S.B., who suggests the Old Lion, Pam, surrounded by barking Curs afraid to attack him. Also M.L. suggests Pam going home with (Treasury Salary) dinner – Dizzy says “How nice it smells – can’t we upset him?” S.B. suggests Dizzy afraid to fight him – and C.K. amends to “Next Half” – Mrs. Gamp Standard as the old appleseller egging him on [ Punch, 46 (25 June 1864): 263, “Next Half” ].
M.L. has an offer to go to Cherbourg in Green’s Yacht (1200 tons he says – Walker!)

div.head: June 22, 1864. W[ednesday]. No dinner
div.p: (except to Tenniel & Co. at the Bedford).

div.head: June 29, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., F.E., H.S., C.K., J.T., S.B., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.
Mark “wind bound” at Havre. Leech at Hamburg, disgusted at the gambling women. F.C.B. very cd – so H.S. is not the only usedupfeeling fellow. What is wealth without health!

L.C. Of course the subject is the failure of the Government to keep the Peace. Conference ended on Saturday and on Sunday the fighting began again. The policy of Punch is to ignore the fact that England has been humbled, if fact it be. The Queen, says Shirley, would sooner abdicate than give her sanction to a war with the country of her Albert. “Let her go then,” says Ponny: who of course attacks the Government. P.L. denies that England has been lowered in her position – says the Continental powers all would chuckle to see her fight. France and Russia as much bound by the treaty of ‘52 as we are, but they’ll only fight for their own ends. – S.B. thinks we ought to have struck the blow last autumn, but as we didn’t, we must now deny the obligation. Easy to invent a cut against England – John Bull as Hercules with Denmark as the Caster [?]. “Yes, I said I’d help you, but I’ve changed my mind.” But this won’t do for Punch – so he suggests the 3 old ladies Britannia, France and Russia talking of their poor relation who is in difficulties, and B. saying “You ought to head the subscription list Mrs France, you know she lost her fleet for you and she never was a friend of mine.” – People won’t understand the history, say we – So S.B. suggests the presenting of the bill which H.S. amends to the Promissory Note. [Punch, 47 (9 July 1864): 15, “The Promissory Note”]
See Shirley Brooks's note of this meeting in his diary for June 29, 1864: “Mark L. is weatherbound at Cherbourg, so I have the Cut to see to again. Work. Dinner, sat in ML's chair, and managed the council satisfactorily, getting my own cut accepted. It’s an important week, and old Punch must not go wrong.” (Houghton Library) H.M. proposes Denmark’s house on fire and France and E. quarreling as to who should help to put it out – but the other is accepted. – Peeler “Your son told me I might k– his a.” Mother “He’s asleep now, can’t you call tomorrow.” (H.M.) – J.T. tells us of his drunken cooks and the trouble to gete ‘em out of the hourse. And H.M. tells of his carrying girl downstairs from his rooms and mob gathering etc.,

div.head: July 6, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., W.B., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., C.K., Sir J. Paxton.

Describing the Great Debate on the Danish Question which began on Monday and ends on Friday next with a majority of 18 for Pam (Ben Head and I at Felixstow on Saturday guessing it 20) Sir Joseph says Gladstone was immensely cheered – never heard such a completely smashing reply. Layard turned leaves of blue book down as Diz made his misquotations, and Gladstone got up and spoke without a note.

L.C. H.S. suggests following up the cut of Dizzy afraid to fight by a Cartoon of D. after the fight. S.B. by letter had proposed something anent Denmark but the other is preferred [ Punch, 7 16 July 1864): 25, “The Fight at St. Stephen's Academy” ]
C.K. and F.C.B. say they rather like women to smoke to me its most unwomanly and to M.L. also.

Paxton tells of staying in the country and praising the cuckoo, and his host says, “Bah, that beastly cuckoo wakes me in the morning – as bad as a street band.” Paxton opposed Bass’s bill while it gave the police the power unsolicited to interfere – thought this unconstitutional, and so it is. Supports bill now it’s altered. Turnpikes on North of London abolished on the 30th and Joe Silver rides to Kensington on purpose to hurrah as he passes through toll free. Paxton is for free trade in road traffic as in everything else. P.L. says he has to pay for other people, as he don’t use the road. But he benefits by the road – a good road benefits the neighbourhood and tollkeepers are a needless item in the cost of maintenance.

P.L. expects to see verdure extinct in England, which will become a series of towns with manure heaps intervening. Deplores the annihilation of hawks and kites by gamekeepers. Nonsense, says Sir J., preserving game produces food for hawks, and therefore tends rather to their increase.

He also talks of Chatsworth and the “Twelve Apostles” – 12 big butts of beer.with the Royal Arms upon them – a present from George IV, I think. Formerly everyone asking at the Lodge had a glass of beer gratis. So at St. Cross, says P.L. – but the beer’s so poor that no beggar will drink it.

H.S. to the Horse Show today, Ag. Hall – Duke of Beaufort’s steppers a splendid pair. M.L. has had a pleasant cruise – despite having a sick steward. – Says Cherbourg is a poor place. Yacht “Sappho” 104 (not 1200) tons.

div.head: July 13, 1864 . W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., F.C.B., H.M., W.B.
H.S. from Woodbridge yesterday, Ben Head and the Drapers and little Burleighs – Mirella at Crystal Palace today.

S.B. had a Swarry last night. J.T. and H.M. and FE. and Mrs. Leech and Yates [N.B.],and Frith and Miss Bateman – her father talks of her as his “gifted chyild” – but she is simple and natural and unaffected.

L.C. W.B. suggests Chase as a rat, leaving the sinking Yankee ship… M.L., Chase his kite tumbling, heavy tail of “greenbacks” – Can’t we do something anent the murder of Briggs in railway last Saturday, showing the Directors averse to Improvement.

Rifle Meeting. H.S. suggests something to show Volunteers as a proof that England has not lost her influence, as Dizzy said – Pam making a Bull’s Eye (a John Bull’s Eye, says F.C.B.) and Dizzy knocked down by recoil, M.L. – but this repeats cut of this week say H.S. and J.T. – accepted, nevertheless. [ Punch, 47 (23 July 1864): 35, “The Winner of the Queen's Prize” ] WB having suggested Wimbledon Peace meeting surrounded with other rifle shootings, Russia shooting a Pole and Prussia a Dane and America a Southerner etc. etc.— Der Freischutz, suggests Tenniel, thinking of the picturesque boots – but we can’t hit the mark with it. I suggest this Opera to Burnand for a burlesque – but he can’t work out the last act: don’t know how to kill Caspar “What have you done to Oxenford that he should pitch into your Faust” – F.C.B. don’t know.

M.L. very chatty, and merry – anecdote of actors how Wigan was a street singer at Brighton and his father applauded from the crowd, and how his wife was a circus rider – and then a lump of affectation got Lady Duff Gordon to “receive” for her. She and Mrs. Keeley at rehearsal, “Leo Dear” “Polly Dear”
Alfred Wigan (1814-1878). His wife, Leonora, also an actor, began her performing career as a rope-dancer. Actor and manager Horace Wigan (1816-1885) was Alfred's younger brother. Both Wigans acted in plays by Tom Taylor. – Horace Wigan a bad one says M.L. Tells of C. Matthews’ want of principle and coolness in repudiation never met a man he didn’t try to swindle – in a gentlemanly way, of course. Tells of Jerrold, and his being accused of laughing at his own jokes. “Ah, I know their value” – and of Planché bragging of his “originality” as an adapter, and saying, “There’s my Baronet for instance, he’s of my own creation.” “Yes,” says Jerrold, “and it’s not the only piece in which we’ve seen your Baronet.” – To Mrs. Wigan who said Eau de Cologne had turned her hair grey, he said, “Are you sure it wasn’t Extract of Time?” To a man who wasn’t seasick he said, ‘If I could have your stomach, I’d almost have your brains.”
F.C.B. tells of a baker named Heaven, “Removed by order of the Underground Railway.”

H.M. tells of young Dumas fishing – “How much does he get a line?” Also of French lady to her husband, who is attacking her seducer, “Would you murder the father of your children?” Also of woman saying to her two noisy children “Silence – or I’ll tell both your fathers.”

div.head: July 20, 1864. W[ednesday], No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., F.C.B., H.M., W.B., T.T.
Precious hot yesterday and today. Strawberries get thin in consequence of heat. A Punster would say thinned in consequence of the ‘eat.

The Police deserve a wipe for their remissness in the railway murder case – a description of Mr. Briggs’ watch and chain might have been sent to every jeweller in London on the Sunday night and the German Muller caught on Monday. S.B. for fun suggests “the end of Mr. Briggs” – or a letter from him, says Pater, stating that he is not the Mr. Briggs who has been murdered.

We get a letter from Mr. Briggs’ creator, John Leech, dated Hamburg saying he’s going to Swarlbath or some such place to take mud baths having iron in them – you sit in mud for 24 hours and come out an Ironclad.

L.C. S.B. proposes another cut for Bass as his Street Music Bill has passed the Lords. But the End of Session is the topic and M.L.’s notion of Johnny’s kettle of fish is approved at once, as is his title “Short Commons,” [ Punch, 47 (30 July 1864): 45 ].

T.T. don’t like Patti in Faust – thinks Arlot more intelligent. (H.S. don’t and her voice is thin) Mario walks before her when courting, he says praises her getup at C.G. – colours and grouping admirable – Mario not impassioned enough – and says Rossini complained that he didn’t know his own songs, she so overornamented them. Also says that Gounod has scarcely got anything for Faust from Gye and Mapleson – the laws of copyright should protect such composers.
James Henry Mapleson ((1830-1901), impresario, had secured a 21-year lease of Her Majesty’s Theatre in 1862. The following year saw the debut of Faust, which went on to become one of the most successful opers of the century. Mapelson went into partnership with Frederick Gye (1810-1878), lessor of the Italian Opera House in Covent Garden.

A Moray Minstrels Concert at Wimbledon tonight, to which T.T. goes.
An amateur choral group organized by haberdasher Arthur James Lewis at his home, Moray Lodge, Kensington. Several of the Punch men attended parties there; Charles Keene was especially active in the Minstrels. C.K. there in his glory, of course. M.L. and I look in at the Olympic and see Miss Raynham vice Robson in Masaniello. Poor.
Alice Raynham replaced the late Frederick Robson (1821-1864) in this burlesque of the popular opera. It was not a success. J.T.’s housemaid confined in his dressing room thanks to the military, last Monday, and so his new cook left at once, without warning – pleasant!

M.L. suggests to F.C.B. to do a History of Richardson’s Show, à la Lumley’s History of the Opera – wherein the treaties with Singers are dealt with as matters of National importance.
Benjamin Lumley, Reminiscences of the Opera (London: Hurst and Blackett, 1864). Lumley (1811-1875) had been director of Her Majesty’s Theatre in the 1840s and 1850s; he published this memoir in the summer of 1864.

div.head: July 27, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., (from Yarmouth ce matin), J.T., M.L., F.E.,.S.B.
Champagne cup to the health of Fred’s small nephew – Tom’s baby. And to that of Edith Bradbury, who tomorrow weds one of the Agnews.

L.C. Bass in praesenti – J.T. suggests Punch as Jupiter darting a thunderbolt marked Bass’s bill at the organ grinders. [Punch, 47 (6 August 1864): 55,” Clearing the Streets” ] accepted.
Brewing magnate Michael Thomas Bass (1799-1884), M.P. for Derby, brought in a bill for the regulation of street music in 1864 for which he had gathered the support of thousands, including such prominent men as Dickens, Carlyle, Tennyson, and Babbage. John Leech had for years felt increasingly tormented by organ grinders and other street musicians, a sensitivity that Mark Lemon and others believed hastened his death in October of that year. Details and contexts can be found in plentiful supply in John Picker, Victorian Soundscapes (New York: Oxford University Press, 2003), especially Chapter 2. S.B. having proposed Bass on a barrel in a sort of Roman Triumph: organmen bound like prisoners to his car.
The Government Whitebait dinner was on Saturday, and there are hints that E. and S.B. & Co. hadone also. We Punch crew have not dined out of town once this summer.

Talk about Public Schools with S.B. anent the Edinburgh article – deny that flogging degrades a schoolboy – fagging should be carefully restricted, or the weak boys become sneaks.
“Public Schools,” Edinburgh Review, 120 (July 1864), 147-188, attributed by Wellesley Index to Goldwin Smith (1823-1910), Regius Professor of Modern History at Oxford and prominent educational reformer. Most of the article is taken up with a fierce critique of the role of classical education in the public schools, but includes also an attack on the frequency of flogging and the flaws of the fagging system (183-186). He tells of the seagull swallowing eel and sitting on a stone to prevent its exit. Stanley has looked out a spot in the Abbey for Thackeray.
Shirley Brooks was the prime mover in an effort to persuade Arthur Stanley, Dean of Westminster, to have a memorial to Thackeray placed in Westminster Abbey, and in raising money for it. See, for example, Brooks’s diary for November 30, 1864 (Houghton Library). Ponny at Paris with old Bateman. Leigh at Southampton. Leech at Hamburg, ironplated.

div.head: August 3, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: L.C. Shirley suggests Brigands carousing – M.L. altered to”dividing spoil” [ Punch, 47 (1864): 65, “Brigands Dividing Spoil” ], Prussia & Co. –P.L. says the barley looks well not affected by the drought. W.B. thinks the Bass bill a bit of class legislation – nobody else here does. – “London Dinner Co. Limited” – give us a good dinner to start with: Turtle (too winey) – Salmon – fried eels entrées – calf’s head and leg of mutton – mayonnaise of chicken,.pancakes and ices. And I wake hungry in the morning and ready for Rotterdam, or wherever else it listeth the breeze to blow us. Down in mouth Sunday and am up in spirits today (Thursday, August 9 a.m.).

S.B. says he takes for granted every reader of Punch has read the Times – objects to making quotations from newspapers. Imitate D. Jerrold’s terse style. M.L. and P.L. say Punch should hit low as well as high. And H.S. quotes Joe and Wm. as proofs that men exist who read Punch and not the Times.

div.head: August 10, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 2. 11.
div.p: H.S. at the Hotel Paulez at the Hague. “Groot Concert.”

div.head: August 17, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11,
div.p:
H.S. at Woodbridge, with Horace.
Brooks's notes of the August 17 dinner, from which Silver and Mayhew were absent, appear in his 1864 diary for that date: “D. Punch, and suggested cut of Pam having one of these days to recognize Davis of the South. Leech also suggested a noble one, for which Jackides requires time, the American Juggernaut.” (Houghton Library). These refer to Punch, 47 (27 1864): 85, “Very Probable,” and a double cut, Punch, 47 (3 September 1864): 96-97, “The American Juggernaut.”

div.head: August 24, 1864. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. at Croydon. J.N.’s after Oxford pull, because Betty Lemon weds Senior Wrangler Romer. Of course, we drink their healths next week, and Mark’s. Rothschild of Paris very liberal to his Secretary Romer. “I’m a Romer” the song, very proper for him.

div.head: August 31, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champ.
div.p: (Haven’t dined out of town once this summer.)
H.S ., S.B., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., W.B.
Cold wet day. H.S. shivery over the kitchen fire at No. 20 – aqueous like diarrh. ce matin. Envies the swillers thereof and the eaters of nectarines and other forbidden fruits.

Our rival The Owl is going to publish an Owlbum – the best joke they’ve made. Ponny says the Joke Making Company (Limited) is about to start and crush us. As Henry Mayhew edits, “Prince Hal” is to be the title. “Prince Hallelujah,” says P.L.

Lord Stare’s reply, “No, but my father was”* Shirley thinks the neatest repartee he knows. He tells of poor Thackeray’s pathos after C. had been talked of a good deal, “Will no one say a word for poor old a–!” *Was your mother in Paris after Waterloo?
Shirley thinks Shakespeare was fearfully afraid of The Devil, “The Prince of darkness is a gentleman – Modo he’s called and Mayhew” – never speaks of him uncomplimentarily.
Ponny to Paris with Bateman Senior – and in love with Miss Leah, M.L. says.

L.C. Punch stopping his artist who is trying to run away from Politics. Persigny’s speech about French Liberty the only subject. – M.L. suggests Statue. [ Punch, 47 (10 September 1864): 107, “Liberty à la Persigny” ].
As reported in a Times leader of August 29, 1864, p. 6, Jean Gilbert Victor Fialin, duc de Persigny (1808-1872), gave an address on liberty to the Council-General of the Loire, praising Louis Napoleon as the founder of French liberty and arguing that British institutions were not suitable for France.

P.L. talks of music – only cares for 4 composers: Beethoven, Handel, Haydn and Mozart—and Bach and Mendelssohn adds H.S. Well yes, Bach – and Mendelssohn elegant and graceful, but never grand. Have you heard his Elijah? No, says the old Savage – “Then you’re bigoted and not competent to judge.” P.L. – “I’d take your opinion, Shirley, about music, as soon as I would any man’s.” And Silver’s? – “Yes, but not yours, Mark” whereat we all chaff.

P.L. been reading Browning – likes his Caliban, but hates his little sentimentalisms – wife’s squabbles etc. But life is made up of such trifles, says Shirley. We are not acting tragedies every day. What is Othello but a tragedy founded upon a trivial event. “Why don’t you talk more, Silver,” says Ponny as we walk away. But unlike F.C.B. I’m modest before my betters.

div.head: September 7, 1864. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. might as well have stayed at Carlton Hall.

div.head: September 14, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at G. G. Gascoyens, Stanwick.

div.head: September 21, 1864, No. 11
div.p: W.B. H.S. (from Stanwick today), J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.

S.B. at Whitby with Leech – sends a suggestion, European animals – French tiger monkey – Russian bear, etc., contrasted with British Lion. – An Italian Punch started, and Pope receiving him. But M.L. suggests Sewing Machine – torn America. [Punch, 47 (1 October 1864): 137, “Columbia's Sewing-Machine”] – Talk of Holland – M.L. would like to go.

div.head: September 28, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: B., H.S.(from Woodbridge today), F.E., J.T., M.,P.L., F.C.B., H.M.

Letter from Shirley at Whitby: “There are 99 steps up to the Church, so you may imagine I don’t go very often. Leech and I have begun a crusade against the howling housedogs – and I’ve been writing to the Whitby papers to suggest that people should be asked to show their tax receipts.”
“J’ai jamais vu des couverts,” H.M. quotes with his Parisian accent.

M.L. tells of Tom Cooke’s dressing up as Wallach’s mother and coming to the greenroom and chaffing all the matrons who assembled there to protect their daughters. “Your daughter has your own taste in dress, Ma’am, sure. Was she a lady’s maid thin, before she tuk to play acting?”
Tom Cooke (1782-1848), Irish composer, was closely associated with Drury Lane opera.

L.C. The threatened French evacuation of Rome in 2 years time is the Subject of course, says Shirley, and “I expect you fellows will do a rare strong cut.” Thank you. P.L. suggests Marriage Settlement of Difficulties – Pope and Sardinia united. W.B., “Judgment of Paris.” P.L., Pope evacuating – No Poopery. H.M. comes out strong – for a wonder – and suggests Relieving Guard, which we applaud [ Punch, 47 (8 October 1864): 147, “Relieving Guard at the Vatican” ].
Müller arrived at Liverpool. The Muller and his men. Stab-at Mater, H.M.

div.head: October 5, 1864. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: H S. from Newport today…to Mellon’s & Jullien’s with Henry Thomas tonight.

div.head: October 12, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., J.L., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., H.S. (from Woodbridge), Lucas.
[vertical in black ink along left margin: “The last time I saw John Leech.”]

“Well, Silver, how are you?” asks Leech’s cheery kindly voice, which I haven’t heard since June 15. He went to Hamburg the day following, and has been staying at Whitby since his return. Looks thin and worn but seems in better spirits rather than he was. Talks with delight of the scenery near Whitby and a particular bridge which looks dangerous to cross. Some one speaking of the case of that schoolmaster, Rev. Hatch (was it?) who let little girl come to bed with him and his wife. Leech fires up indignantly – “My dear Leigh” – at any attempt at an excuse for him.
See note to entry for May 16, 1860, about the case of Rev. Henry Hatch.
Leech generally won at Hamburg – but only played for small stakes ... Lucas explains his system to Fred – says he won once by betting on 8, having seen 8 glowworms, or dreamed so.
Shirley’s boy 10 years today so we drink the father’s health.

L.C. Can’t we do a Peace Cut for America? ... Erith explosion (on Oct. 1) the subject most talked about.
The October 1 explosion of two gunpowder magazines in the Erith marshes, Kent, caused widespread damage, shattering windows in the village of Erith several miles distant. See Times October 3, 1864, p. 7. P.L. suggests magazine keeper sitting on powder smoking a pipe and exclaiming, Not safe? – Nonsense. – Done it, says Leech, Aberdeen, in Crimean War.
The cut was by Leech: Punch, 25 (7 December 1853): 249, “Aberdeen Smoking the Pipe of Peace” Good memory for big cuts he has. S.B. suggests blowing up the Government in some way. P.L. and M.L. invent cut as it stands, faute de mieux – Insurance Office and barrel of powder [Punch, 47: 1864): 169, “Questionable Policy” ] Seems a shame they refuse to pay.

Mark says he has seen a prospectus of Henry Mayhew & Co.’s opposition Punch – Joke Co., Limited. Vulgar and abusive – specimen cuts of “The jolly dogs” – “the early birds” – Fancy Portraits of Mr. Boosey and Mr. Tite. .. They complain that the Punch staff is getting old and worn out, but imagine new mines of fun must be found in such young wits as Planché and Sam Lover – Tyrtaeus or Dhirtyass as Lucas says poor Thackeray christened him. The opposition is to be printed in black and red – the only thing that will be read in it. S.B. tells of Hawkins Q.C. being half drunk and beginning his prayer with “Gentlemen of the Jury” and how à Beckett said, “Well, at any rate, it proved he wasn’t a Unitarian.” S.B. anecdotish tonight, tells of Scotch coachman when reins snapped, saying, “I’ll be in hell in five minutes.” – Ah, he’s a modest man, said somebody. Also, of Frederick the Great, “declining to interfere with the intrigues” of a soldier and a sow. Also, talks of Du Maurier and Armstrong whom he met at Whitby.
Tom Armstrong (1832-1911), artist, close friend of George DuMaurier, whom he had known in Paris. H.S. should have gone there, too.
Whitefriars looks itself again! was the general feeling tonight. Ah! who would have thought what a fortnight would bring.

div.head: October 19, 1864. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: H.S. at the Glenham battue – 600 head. Battledore 1622! with Miss Trowell.

div.head: October 26, 1864. No. 11.
div.p:
H.S. at Woodbridge – tempted into shooting by Isaac Walker. J.L.’s last Punch dinner. (H.S. missed Thackeray’s also.)
Shirley Brooks's diary entry for Monday, October 31, 1864: “I re-open the book with a heavy heart. Poor dear John Leech is no more. At the dinner on Wednesday he was present, but complained of illness and pain, and I saw that it was difficult to make him completely grasp the meaning of things that were said to him, without two or three repetitions. He left early, with T. Taylor. On this Saturday, I called at 27 Bouverie Street, and heard from Evans that he was very ill. We went off to the Terrace, Kensington. He was in bed but no one seemed frightened, and there was a child's party, a small one. Mrs. Leech was in tears, but certainly had no reason to apprehend the worst. He would have seen us - we remained 3/4 of an hour or so (his detestable father haranguing us on his own merits, I understand why, now) but an opiate had been given, so it was of course felt that he ought not to be disturbed. Arranged to meet Evans there at 3 next day. At 7 that night all was over… [Oct. 30] We went in, saw him, and Joyce, and the detestable father, and the poor mother, and two of the sisters. And afterwards to the chamber of death. He looked noble in his calm, the hair and whiskers put back, gave up his fine forehead and handsome features - and the eternal stillness gave his face an elevated expression. I looked a long time at my old friend's face. We have known one another many years, and he has been engaged with me in business as well as in pleasure. He was very kind - very good - and is in Heaven, whatever that means. I left Evans and called on [Eneas Sweetland] Dallas, that the Times might have a worthy notice. D. was out but I left word on a card, he came up at night, and I am glad to think that L's memory owes to me the prompt and graceful record that appeared next day. Very sad all the night.”
(Houghton Library)
[with box drawn around text] John Leech obiit Oct. 29, aetat: 46

div.head: November 1, 1864.
div.p:
Special meeting at the Bedford on Tuesday November 1 at 4 o’clock to consider what is to be done. (It is proposed that we should act as Pallbearers ..... and so let Howard, Du Maurier and Armstrong, outsiders, be invited to meet us – well that it be seen that the Staff is strong). M.L., S.B. J.T.,P.L., C.K., F.C.B., assembled when H.S. arrives: T.T. follows shortly. (H.M. absent).
Shirley Brooks notes of this meeting, in his diary entry for November 1, 1864: “To Bedford, where Mark L. had called a meeting of P.P. men, to consider what could be done to strengthen P.P. under the circumstances.
ML TT SB FCB
TT CK HS JT
indeed all but HM. There was little discussion, but all his proposals were received in a good spirit, and the agreements were --
Dinners to be more regularly attended
Everyone to bring a list of topics he thinks worth note
Copy to be earlier
Stress was laid on necessity for smart and careful writing
Dumaurier and Marks to be engaged if possible” (Houghton Library)

M.L. thinks that Dinners have not been looked on as a part of the week’s work so much as they ought to be—begs for better attendance and for more business talk at them – thinks everyone should come with suggestions, both for articles and cuts. Hopes we will back him in protesting against the forwardness of young B&E, which is offensive to him and injurious to the work. ... What artist shall be asked to join us?
