C.K. and J.T. both say Du Maurier and H.S. speaks for him as anxious to join us.... H.S. runs to No. 20 and back to dinner (cod and leg of mutton only). C.K. only leaving. ... Talk of the rehearsal of Tom Taylor’s Hidden Hand last night, which F.C.B. approves. T.T. says you can’t measure an actor by one part – Milter Moss was well drest and an eccentricity – but the man fails me now.—We laugh at Tom’s calling actor aside in quite a friendly way and saying, “My dear fellow, you must be a d – d fool to act so.”—Jerrold had a donkey he used to call George Hodder. M.L. tells how George used to complain, “Why Thackeray and Dickens get their £2,000 a year, and I only my £200 – can’t make it out” – and how Jerrold taught him to write a funny police report and on the strength of its success poor George applied for an increase of salary, and his letter crossed one giving him the sack.
George Hodder (1819-1870), miscellaneous journalist well known to the early Punch staff and onetime private secretary to Thackeray. See note about his memoirs under entry for January 26, 1870. ... Talk of Müller and how rightly he was found guilty on Saturday – and P.L. recites his Alibi Baby on the tree top, When the bolt falls the Müller will drop etc.

May as well do the large cut, says T.T., and S.B. suggests contrast of the Irish Witch and the English Spiritualist – “Which is Witch?” says M.L. “No, Medium and ReMedium,” T.T. [ Punch, 47 (12 November 1864): 199, “Medium and Re-Medium” ].

Then we revert to poor Leech – his voluntas was stronger than his arbitrium, says P.L. – he could deny no one, not excepting himself. M.L. narrates how he would start from a cut to walk up Oxford Street – and laments those dear old days when Leech first married and what a pleasant little unaffected wife he had and how delightful were the little homely banquets of mutton and gin and water to which she welcomed his friends. P.L. tells of the old father calling on him this morning and bowwowing about the article in the Times which implied that family money matters had injured Leech’s health. “You must write and contradict this, Mr. Leigh” “I shall be most happy to do so, Sir, if you will supply me with some facts on which I may refute the statement.” ... Old Leech was keeper of the London Coffee House. And M.L. says he knows that Leech accepted bills for the old man and his daughters for £3000 or so: which swept away the sum he received for his first 100 paintings. While J.L. was in Hamburg, the father called to borrow £50 of old Joyce and then of M.L., and hearing this made J.L. very indignant and angry, and M..L. seeing how agitated he was, said, “Your duty is to work for your wife and children, and not let your mind be harassed, and if buttoning up your pockets leads to a quarrel with your father, I still should advise you to button them up.”
M.L. the first to throw his wreath into the Grave.
C.K., “How J.L. used to trump suggestions, e.g. Juggernaut.”

div.head: November 4, 1864.
div.p: Friday, November 4, instead of going to Woodbridge to keep Temple’s birthday, I go to the Bedford at 10:30 and there find Millais describing the sad scene. Ill in the morning with a spasm.—E. and S.B. called but did not see him. Went to bed at six, another spasm – “If I have another it will kill me” – another came at seven “I’m going,” and so he died. C.K. the only one today not wearing black. – F.C.B. loud in nose blowing in Chapel – snivelling infectious, not affected, God knows. Still sunny autumn day. E.L. joins us with his walking stick nearly at the Grave.

div.head: November 7, 1864. Monday at the Bedford. Champagne.
div.p:
S.B., Du Maurier (his debut), H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.
This dinner marks Du Maurier's first appearance at the Punch Table, yet nothing in this entry suggests the details that Silver later recalled for George Somes Layard’s biography of Shirley Brooks: “The vacancy at the Table caused by Leech's death was taken by George du Maurier, and Mr. Silver tells me that, on his first appearance, he made the Staff a little uncomfortable by referring to his blindness. After complaining that people were for ever calling him “de Maurier,” and expressing the hope that the Punch men would give the devil his “du,” he went on to remind them that he was blind of one eye, and begged them to pardon him if he failed at any time to “ see” a subject that might be suggested for his pencil. “But,” said Shirley, “Tenniel has only one eye left, and it really is the left, for he lost his right while fencing, whilst you have your right eye left. So you see you two fellows have two good eyes between you, and a pair of good eyes are far better than a score of bad ones. In the country of the blind, you know, the one-eyed man is king, and here we're blind as bats—to one another's failings. So I drink to your good health, you two one-eyed royal Majesties.” Layard, A Great Punch Editor, 223. Brooks's own diary entry for the meeting remarks, “D. at Bedford, with all the men except Keene, but not the proprietors. Dumaurier, first time. Many good suggestions made.” (Houghton Library)
H.S. from Woodbridge today after keeping T’s birthday with Tom Reed etc., – feel my brains’fresher than they were a week since. Soon get mossy in the couritry.

Where’s Charles Keene? It is for his Pocketbook cut we mainly meet. Spirits the accepted subject – after a hint or two, DuM. suggests Spiritualists Rehearsing which S.B. improves into throwing a light on them while at their tricks.
Mr Punch’s Pocket Book for 1865 features this cartoon as the fold-out frontispiece.

As to Almanac, J.T. suggests what H.S. had thought – that it would be wise to have the Calendar at head of each page – and F.C.B. suggests that Past and Present games etc. etc’. be the cuts right and left. Much talk ensues and is postponed till Wednesday when each man is to bring 12 designs for cuts.

T.T. for the Large Cut proposes Archbishop of York visited by Sensationalists, Woman in White, etc. etc. against which style of literature he lately spoke. Or else the Southern Slave Arming, “When Black meets Black then Comes the Tug of War,” but this is postponed also. H.S. and J.T. both say this cut was done last year. Talk about J.L. of course and his marvellous invention and fertility – but he made sketches first on paper and then traced on the block – except “Punch’s Fancy Ball” which he drew straight on the wood and finished in 3 hours!
“Mr. Punch’s Fancy Dress Ball,” a double-page engraving, appeared in Punch 12 (9 January 1847) 16-17; a reproduction in the Jubilee Number (18 July 1891) 3 includes identifying captions. —Tenniel draws on the wood at once without a previous paper sketch – charcoal first of course.

M.L. says the Circulation of Punch is now as large as ever – but not larger than it was at the close of the Caudle Papers – these and Jeames’ Diary and the Snobs increased the sale – great cuts seldom do, except the Bengal Tiger, for instance.

S.B., “When I was fighting for my belt I wrote a tale for the Court Journal about a fellow who fell in love with a Castrato.”Du M. talks of French Novels fluently enough. C.K.’s drawing of the French man turning Quaker’s collar down was assigned by one writer just now to Leech – And the public generally are quite ignorant which were his cuts.

The “Advice to Marry – Don’t!” was sent anonymously and never paid for. Dozens claim it as theirs. M.L. once used a short paragraph and was called on by a Scotchman who expected to get £10 for it – and got 10/ — DuM. tells of Whistler and Rosetti’s rage for old china – and how R. once left his guests at dinner and rushed off to buy a piece for fear W. should forestall him, “You’ll find the Spectre Monarch punctual,” says M.L.
Young Mark looks in late for a cigar.

div.head: November 9, 1864 W[ednesday]. at the Bedford.
div.p: S.B., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.

Fine bright day for the Show. I stay in and scribble and get dullbrained. Wish I’d the spirits of Burnand, whose loud laugh does not betray the vacant mind. He suggests an Antediluvian Novel – Loves of the Mammoths – “about this time the World was created.” – Opening of the Garden of Eden. – Extracts from the Newspapers Case of Applestealing – and The Great Sensation Murder and Flight of the Assassin Cain. P.L. and T.T. take the theme up – and M.L. of course says, “Lucky you can’t do it.”

L.C. T.T. suggests the Canada States Amalgamation – somehow – But the Southern Slave Enlistment is the Question. – So he proposes the Road to Freedom, whipping Niggers to the Battlefield – Emancipation by death. Settling the Slave Question by killing off the Slaves. Or else putting slaves in white men’s uniforms as a new way of washing the Blackymoor white—M.L. suggests 2 niggers fighting in the Circus and H.S. adds North and South breathing, resting on their swords, “Abe (Ave) Lincoln, massa, morituri te saluto,” P.L. J.T. suggests the Swedish Wrestlers, 2 blacks – “Statue to Emancipation.” Slaves used to fight for their freedom as a prize – got it with a box on the ear “presenting the freedom in a box” says Horace. Bravo Ponny. T.T., suggests the 2 black cats hung over a line fighting. But no, we stick to the Classical Circus, when suddenly JT says, “Taking the Black Draft” and we all cry, “That’s the Cut”: Classics and Comics: latter wins of course [ Punch, 47 (19 November 1864): 209, “The Black Draft” ]

J.L. regretted he hadn’t studied painting – found his weakness when he began to do his pictures. J.T. lost right eye with foil: Du M. lost left by illness. P.L. discourses forcibly about the Bar and its abuses – apropos of the Berryer banquet last night. S.B. proposes to do the talk of the guests as they come away, “What I like is his modesty,” says Westbury, etc., each admiring him for a quality they don’t themselves possess.
Pierre-Antoine Berryer (1790-1968), French jurist and advocate of freedom of the press, visited England in 1864 as a guest of Lord Brougham, and was fêted at the Middle Temple. The Times, in a lengthy leader marking the occasion (November 8, 1864, p. 8), lauded him as “one of the most illustrious of living Frenchmen.”

P.L. produces a list of Almanack hints for cuts on the Follies of the past year – Donkey Show: Elevation of the Donkey by Education – Congress of Quack Doctors – Atelier of Madam Rachel the face painter, Swells’ Industrial Exhibition etc. etc. (D.M. suggests Lady working in pair of hobnailed boots etc.)

T.T. Tribulations of a Beekeeper – with a bee in his bonnet – Artist of t1he Realistic Nature Sketching School under difficulties, umbrella etc. etc. View of London as it will be – St. Paul’s hidden by posters.
S.B. A Harlequin Novel (?) and one or two hints I forget.

F.C.B. Troubles of a Would Be Benedictine Monk in Winter – cold in head from wet feet etc. Every man his own Telegraph Keeper and Station Master – increase of Town Railways. Telegraph in every closet. H.S. (No list), but on the spur of the moment suggests What Ballooning must come to in scientific high ascent way – lighting cigar at the sun etc. – Improvement of the racehorse – which some fear is deteriorating.

F.C.B. suggests Historical parallels – Scenes in old time and new – but too difficult. Also says he’ll do Mr. Punch his Magic Lanthern – Is doing Allegories for the Pocket Book and is hard up for “Taxes.” S.B. suggests Honesty paying his 6s while Fraud takes a sight at the Chancellor of the Exchequer.
These “allegories” are cartoons that serve as headers for chapters of the Mr Punch’s Pocket Book for 1865. The cartoon for “Taxes” appears on page 42 and features Gladstone as gladiator with his foot on the British Lion, whose leg is shackled with a manacle labelled “taxes.” “Shaving the British Lion” better, says Mark: who calls an allegory an Irish Lane after a fight.
“And if the alley gorey gives you pain;
You’d better just turn down that bloody lane,” P. L.
“Behold the street is full of blood before ye,
Why you may see ‘tis quite an alley gorey,” S.B.
Talk of Morton’s farce fun and how Buckstone pronounces “Barcelonas – thruppence.”

div.head: November 16, 1864. W[ednesday]. The Bedford.
div.p:
S.B., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.
Brooks's entry for this meeting, 16 November, notes the same tensions to which Silver alludes in his note beginning the November 30 meeting: “ D. Punch Bedford. Previously a row touching the invitations, and the non-including young Bradbury. Evans came to Bedford about it. What damned hash all this is when the ship is in rough water and we are all working our best.” (Houghton Library)

Mark inveighs against “the Beautiful Menken” as the blackguard, E.T. Smith, calls her. Shows a pamphlet that biographises her as having translated the Iliad at 12 years old and studied several languages besides becoming a graceful artist and an Editor of a newspaper—all this in addition to her having still further distinguished herself by marrying Jack Heenan who fought Tom Sayers.

L.C. T.T. suggests the Manchester Sewage Question – the Sewage Machine, says H.S. But the Teetotal meeting at the Guildhall is more Punchy – Lord Mayor ’Ale, as the Haldermen doubtless call him, just the man to preside. P.L. suggests the Loving Tea cup [Punch, 47 (26 November 1864): 219, “The Loving (Tea) Cup” ], party of aldermen at the Tea Table: Why not Gog and Magog, says H.S. and repeats M.L. (a little louder) and so gets settled.

M.L. starts a Book today to book the suggestions for Big Cuts etc. Looks tremendously businesslike. Used to scribble on a bit of notepaper. Elegant phrase that of Gibbon’s says Shirley, “Worshippers of the Venus Averta.” No rhyme to your name, is there, Silver? says he – and narrates how poor Thackeray delighted in selling you by saying, “I’ve written a little poem today ‘The mouse lay cozy in her hole and nothing could be snugger, – for the life of me I couldn’t find a rhyme to it.” Victim suggests something obvious and Thackeray says gravely, “Dear me, yes, of course, I never thought of that!”

“Nemo repente fuit Tuppertimus,” says Percival ha! ha! good book that.
Per Constance Smith, this is a parody of Juvenal, “Nemo fuit repente turpissimus,” translated as, “No man ever became wicked all at once.” Jam faeces et saxa volant, adds he, anent some case that deserves the pillory. Shirley suggests a line for for illustration about the Tiger (Buttons) mangling in his lair. Don’t you think proverbs might be illustrated, says D.M., (H.S. to Covent Garden with Wm. Watson to hear Maraniello.)

Next morning call on D.M. and find him with a Punch headache – aha, my boy, you’ll get wiser one day. Shows me drawing of tall boy between two ladies, whereof he has lost the “libretto” as Charles [Keene] calls it. So on the spur of the moment suggest, “People don’t always get married when they get grown up, do they, Miss McKenzie.”

div.head:
November 23, 1864. W[.ednesday]. At the “Hotel Brooks.” 6 Kent Terrace.
Home of Shirley Brooks. Brooks's entry of this date reads: “At 6 the Punch men came, also Mrs Lemon. This was the order of dinner
ML E
Tenniel Dumaurier
Taylor Keene
Leigh Silver
Burnand Horace M
SB Mrs Lemon
All seemed to go very well - some stayed till 12” (Houghton Library)
div.p: Mrs. S.B., Du M. H.S., C.K., H.M., Mrs. Lemon, S.B., F.C.B., P.L., T.T., J.T., M.L. Very Jolly Evening.

“Soles à la Chosen People,” fried and froid – Rowley Powley pudding ... Swiss sweet champagne ... Carlin’s Cigars. Capital collection of authorgraphs and photographs Shirley has. And good dodge that of putting ‘em together. Mrs.Shirley worsted working with great vehemence. Talk of F.C.B.’s Snowdrop on Monday which S.B. praisesC.K. brings “The Ninth Londoniad,” a collection of Puffing Poetry which T.T. recites with great gusto.

L.C. discussed when the ladies leave – The election.of Lincoln the subject, better than the great Medium Indian Durbar Meeting of Native Swells which C.K. don’t think much of, but it shows our sovereignty in the Punjaub, which “our crowned cousins” in Germany should recollect.
An assembly of native princes and nobles (a “durbar”) was convened by Sir John Lawrence, Viceroy of India, at Lahore on October 18 and was reported in the Times for November 22, 1864, p. 8. P.L; suggests Lincoln as the Phoenix and T.T; adds rising out of ashes of Free Press, State Rights etc. [Punch, 47 (3 December 1864): 229, “The Federal Phoenix” ]‘ T.T. declaims against Phelps and Miss Faucit in Macbeth, never saw so brainless and impotent a performance, instead of whispering in the murder scene, speaking in monosyllables, they stand apart ... etc. etc.
Phelps and Faucit appeared in Macbeth at Drury Lane; see Daily News, November 4, 1864, p. 2. M.L. with a cold, does some funny conjuring.

div.head: November 30, 1864. W[ednesday]. The Bedford. M.L.’s birthday. Pocket Book dinner. Champ.
div.p: E., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.

E. absent of late “for political reasons” – (i.e. because of the row with W.B. Jr.?) – later in the evening thanks us all for our exertions to supply the loss we’ve had. Mark Lemon 55 today. So we drink his health, long life to him. And then we drink “Success to the Pocket Book” – whereof Keene’s etching is applauded unâ voce.—Shirley acknowledges his Jumble verses which he says he wrote entirely from memory.
“His Jumble verses” almost certainly refers to the verses in “The Poet of Memory” in Punch’s Pocket Book for 1865, p. 171, which are prefaced by a letter from “Epicurus Rotundus,” a frequent Brooks pseudonym. A wondrous memory is his. Recollects a phrase or fragment of the most trifling writers, e.g. his rhyme to “month” in imitation of Horace – “gave it away to Jones of the onety oneth.”

T.T. says his little boy criticised an illustrated children’s book of drawings – “What would become of them if this really happened so” – showing how unnatural were the designs. – Last week he described boy’s trying the rope trick. Boy makes verses, too and can’t bear to be laughed at. Quite a Precocity.

L.C. Dizzy’s speech at Oxford anent the Church. Shirley suggests D. drest as an angel and looking at himself in the glass – phrase in his speech about a man’s being either ape or angel [ Punch, 47 (10 December 1864): 239, “Dressing for an Oxford Bal Masque” ]. T.T. accepts this after suggesting the Blind leading the Blind – Dizzy teaching the Bishops.
M.L. suggests that John Thomas might visit the Cattle Show, Eh Silver? “The detected Husband,” a domestic drama – Been dining at Greenwich, Sir I smell the asparagus! S.B.

S.B. and Pater chaff Horace (who dined with “George Augustus” [Sala] last night at Rumsey Forster’s and came screwed and noisy and “dear boy” ish today) anent Kate Bateman. “I love the dear girl – and I’d marry her tomorrow – but she wouldn’t have me – I’m not worthy of her.” Nonsense, Ponny – live cleanly – cut the A. Market, and I’ll see what I can do for you, says Shirley. – Leigh doubts whether it be policy to marry a girl used to public praise and petting.
Brooks's entry notes, “Horace very tight, and Miss Bateman his theme all the evening. I undertook to help in his suit, if he would pledge himself to be virtuous for six months.” (Houghton Library)
Last week I walked home in the wet with Du Maurier (and next day walked home from Bealings to W. with cold).
My carriage is waiting for Silver, said Du M. – “And my carriage is waiting for Gold,” says Shirley.

div.head: December 7, 1864. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., Du M., HS., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., W.B.
Where’s the round table? Shirley proposes cutting our names on this oblong mahogany; We all agree that the round one is more sociable.

“Donato is coming” to Covent Garden. Go it ye cripples, for he’s said to be a onelegged man and a dancer. “Mark was right,” says Shirley “in saying Donato should appear at the Hopperer.”
Señor Donato made a sensation when he appeared at Covent Garden in the winter of 1864-65. Originally a ballet dancer in Italy, he took up bullfighting and lost his leg after being gored by a bull. Donato’s stage act consisted of rapid dance movements, his missing leg concealed by a swirling cape, as he played castanets. See the enthusiastic review in Illustrated Times 6 (14 January 1865) 20. Donato died the following June after a brief illness.

Was Shakespeare a B—, Was Socrates? Had an excuse in Xantippe, says M.L. Shirley quotes as proofs “and thou shalt have thy Will!” and “My ventures are not in one bottom”… D.M. a student of the Strand Museum. “This strange and self abuse” (Macbeth). T.T. was humbugging, says M.L., about le bal des Bougres. Yes, he clearly was a humbugger, adds H.S.

L.C. A dull week’s news for us. P.L. suggests Cowper’s Task, to clear Park Lane and see to the sewage and Thames Embankment. M.L., “John Bull dressing his Xmas Window with fat beef – Envious foreigners bystanding.” W.B., “Can’t you do something with the quacks?” And we agree therein [ Punch, 47 (17 December 1864): 249, “A Quack in the Right Place” ]. Pillory, says Shirley, – for pillmongers, adds P.L., and or Desirable Investment in the Stocks – and this is agreed on, notwithstanding D.M.’s “Moral Garotte” and Quack as Spider, web full of fools of patients – empty uniforms etc.
P.L. quotes Leech’s story of old man fishing and keeping snuff and gentles loose in his waistcoat pockets and taking a pinch of the latter by mistake.

D.M., Horace Vernet and + d snuffbox on model platform, “0 it’s only a Snuffbox.” Gil a Beckett tried absinthe once and spat it out saying, “Les absinthes ont toujours tort,” says H.M. Exercise is the best appetiser, says H.S. “Clearly,” says P.L.
Hear 2 Acts of Trovatore at Covent Garden afterwards.

div.head: December 14, 1864. W[ednesday]._No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M. (no d.M.), H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., F.C.B., C.K, H.M., W.B.

M.L. reads a letter from old Bradbury thanking one and all for the Almanack which will go to press tomorrow morning. J.T. been working from 9 to 12 at night for the last 4 days – feared yesterday he was getting blind from his close work. ... We sit till past 11 tonight, i.e., M.L., J.T., duM.,. C.K. & H.S. to alter C.K.’s Pisiculture “Legend” which M.L. had written somehow thus “Mr. Bobbs catches a fine specimen of the Silurus Gladys, or as he calls it, the Silurus Teddingtoniensis.”
“Pisciculture,” Punch’s Almanac for 1865, 48 (January 1865). “Glanis” is a kind of river fish. Amusing to see how particular C.K. is about his “legends”—few Editors would take such pains to please him as Mark does.

M.L. consults me as to getting a Charterhouse nomination for young Leech – whereanent I had been seeing Dr. Currey today and had written to Mrs. Leech. He says J.L. had paid £3000 for his father, and his Estate was now liable for £2000 more. Dallas wrote the Cornhill article – which we applaud.
Eneas Sweetland Dallas (1828-1879), who had, at Brooks’s prompting, written the notice of Leech’s death that appeared in the Times (see note for October 26 entry). “John Leech,” Cornhill Magazine 10 (December 1864), 743-760.

L.C. Shirley objects to an Illustrated Newsy sort of Christmas cut, and proposes Lord Derby sitting at dessert with Homer, after publishing his translation amends this by saying, “Let Dizzy poke his nose in at the door and say, “Now then Derby, you’ve done with that stuff, so perhaps You’ll come and work.” PL objects that the Cut may be mistaken for a spur to the Tories – whom it is not Punch’s aim to move. H.S. says why not have Derby, and Homer spending Christmas together, which P.L. applauds – but S.B. improves into Dizzy as a Homeric Angel appearing to Derby, “Sleepest thou, King of Statesmen” – and then to the Pam and Shaftsbury Cut, as to translating bishops. H.S. says “Let Shaftsbury say, ‘ We only translate bishops’” – which is accepted [Punch, 47 (24 December 1864): 259, “Rival Translators” ].
Edward, Earl of Derby’s blank-verse translation of the Iliad had just appeared from John Murray. This translation would remain a standard text well into the twenbtieth century.
D.M. tells of students drinking champagne at a sou a bottle – “tisane” – “You paid more when you used to tease Ann, Horace,” says Shirley. Yes, adds P.L. if a cour-tes-an.

Harrison lent Buckstone a tenor for “No Song No Supper.” Wish he’d lent me a tenner (S.B.) S.B. suggests new reading for “She strikes upon the Bell” by adding a “y.” Cuneiform inscription, in chalk upon the walls. M.L. amuses us by imitating sneaky little Phil, the property man at Drury, “Only a pint of gin”— “There’s his paper” etc. and D.M. tells tales of Whistler and his vie de Bohème in Paris. And of the nude model fingering her fair friend while the students made hobby horses of their chairs.

div.head: December 21, 1864, No. 11. Champ.
div.p: E., duM., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., W.B., T.T.

Last week we drank success to the Almanack which was published yesterday. And we drank it with special honours several of us with one foot on the table and more Scotico calling “Nish!” Youths outside the office have sold 800 since 3 o’clock yesterday, saith W.B. Looks well. Demand yearly greater.
W.B. shows an appeal from a father enclosing photograph of his five children, “these creatures,” as he calls them – and asking you to choose one to adopt. Cool – dare say will succeed.

Talk of Commodore Nutt and General Tom Thumb and his wife at the Crystal Palace. The General quite double chinned. Used to kiss all the pretty girls, says Paxton: Yes, but he wasn’t under my control then, said his wife: 2 feet high.

L.C. M.L. suggests Mr. and Pam as the 2 Gracchi England’s pride. But we think we’d better simply have a Pantomime cut. H.M. objects that there’s no meaning in.it – but Shirley says he’ll make it clear. D.M. tells of his walking with Armstrong and their sisters in Dusseldorf and being attacked by soldiers who wanted to kiss the girls. It seems that civilians there are always liable to be sabred and that there’s no redress. Thank God I am in England.
Mrs. Reed says it was Sinclair who used to say “Here am I in London – without a penny in my pocket – like Love among the Roses.”

Mark counsels my writing straight to Phipps about getting Leech’s boy into the Charterhouse – which Woodward thinks feasable. I shan’t be easy till it’s done. Very grateful Mrs. L. seems for my poor efforts.
E. asks me to join Shirley and Tenniel at his house on Xmas Eve – but I never spent my Christmas out of Woodbridge except once, and that was when my mother came to me at Norwich.
Haymarket afterwards and saw No Song No Supper for the first time.

Tom Taylor unusually silent today – generally very loquacious. Talks on any topic, from High Art to Low Dutch. More head than heart he has, I fancy. Quick in suggestion, as is Shirley, whose sniff after saying something smart is a thing to remember him by. Amusing to see how he interrupts Old Leigh, whose fancy is less locomotive. And how Old Leigh shakes his head impatiently when he is not listened to. Talks like a book he does: and like a well filled clever book too.

H.S. at Woodbridge (never but once ate his Xmas dinner Out of it) dines with Ben Head and Alfred Diaper and Mr. Flatt and his wife at Seckford Street, after bagging a snipe on Eyke Common .... Tomorrow the 3 Reeds come and on Tuesday we enact “Fourtell” and “Puffit” cum multo applause.

div.head: January 4, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., duM., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T , ML , F C B., C.K.
H.S. from Church St today after a pleasant Christmas – one don’t get a “merry” one nowadays in polite society.

Mark tells anecdotes of Maddox and his stinginess. – “Vant a box? – isn’t the piece a-goin’ to draw? Want a Glory next I s’pose, with fairies and revolving Stars!” Shows goblet, – “There’s a property for you – look how it shines.” M.L. found him in his latter days alone at the Haymarket, “ain’t got a friend to talk to – obliged to come here for amusement” – Poor devil.
J. M. Maddox, manager of Princess’s Theatre. Maddox’s solecisms were often quoted among theatre people; see Clement Scott, Drama of Yesterday and Today, vol. 1 (London: Macmillan, 1899), 222-224.

Says S.B. to H.M., “Before you visit Leah you should go to Rachel and be made ‘beautiful’ for ever”
Mrs. Sarah Rachel Leverson, “Madame Rachel,” sold beauty products out of a shop in Bond Street and published an advertising brochure entitled “Beauty Forever” that gave rise to a popular catch-phrase. See Richard D. Altick, Presence of the Present (Columbus: Ohio State University Press, 1991) 541-45. – Odour of red hair – Ess bouquet, C. bouquet H.S.

L.C. Shirley proposes Louis as the Toreador of the Pope’s Bull – accepted [Punch, 48 (1865): 7, “The Pope’s Mad Bull,” and “The Imperial Bull-Fighter,” p.17].
See the Times article on January 4, p. 10, concerning the Papal Encyclical of December 8 regarding Austria, a subject to which the paper had devoted a leader on December 28, p. 6.“Where are your suggestions you fellows – you promised lists every week.”
See above account of special meeting at the Bedford Hotel on November 1, 1864, in the aftermath of John Leech’s death on October 29, at which Lemon emphasized the importance of every member of the staff bringing Large Cut suggestions to each Wednesday night meeting. England’s nearest approach to Beranger is Dibdin. But we’ve no national People’s Songwriter. Discussion anent this, and the why of it. Burnand’s instance of the jokeless jokes that make audiences laugh — “Knickerbockers yes, and more bocker than knicker!”—

H.M. as we walk away gives a sovereign to poor old fat Charlotte the oyster opener that Jerrold used to cotton to — squeezes my hand in his impressive way as I tell of my efforts for Leech’s boy. “You’ll succeed” he says.

div.head: January 11, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: E. D.M. H.S., F E. S.B J.T. M.L. F.C.B. C.K. H.M. T.T.

Talk about theatres – Brough’s and Byron’s both weak burlesques, says Burnand. Hercules and Omphale a good subject, saith Shirley. Stupid your ending every song and scene with a dance and double shuffle, says Tom to F.C.B. “And you go out of your way for a pun – stops the action – not half enough action in Cupid and Psyche.” Why don’t you give more political allusions says Shirley see how that bit about Denmark took in Snowdrop. B[urnand] denies that he leads up to his puns, but this is doubtful. Planché’s burlesques would be hissed now – not fast enough, he says. But this is doubtfuller. Look at Medea.

L.C. A barren week. Pam’s speech about the need of writing plainly and large – suggests S.B.
In a speech before the Romsey Labourer’s Encouragement Association, reported in the Times for January 5, 1865, p. 7, Palmerston spoke at length about the need to teach children to write large, legible letters. Amended to Britannia bringing Lord John [Russell] to be taught. T.T. would introduce Gladstone and arithmetic, but this would only confuse, we think. Smart boy that Pam spoke of – calculated a day more for Leap Year in his 4 years’ wages [Punch, 48 (21 January 1865): 27, “The Schoolmaster at Home”].

Burnand breakfasts alone with his newspaper and his wife has hers in bed. Forbids children to enter his study – that discipline won’t last, says Shirley. Shirley quotes a bit from Examiner of some 30 years since – censuring Clower[?] for blowing candle out – “And not with his mouth.”

Talk of criticism – M.L. says it should be “I” think and not “we think” or still less “It is.” Two men would differ as to which of two women were the more beautiful. Criticism is a matter of opinion. Go[e]the studied pictures for ten years before he dared to criticise them. D.M. and C.K. object to Tom Taylor’s ex cathedra dicta in the Times. Very unfair that a five minutes’ glance should be taken to condemn a year’s labour. D.M. says Leighton and Rossetti are the best critics he knows.—D.M. very chatty and anecdotical of art. Wrote that little poem, “L’Onglay à Parry,” of which Tom asks the authorship and approves it.
“L’Onglay à Parry,” Punch 48 (January 14, 1865): 14, written in pidgin French, with illustrations by DuMaurier.

Shirley loq: “You know Tennyson, Pater – I wish you’d just go to the Isle of Wight and give him 17 kicks on his backside. He has been castrating his poems – putting “O noble father” for “O silent father of our kings to be,” and altering that pretty little song in The Princess” etc. etc. By the way his lines “The Skipping Rope” have been omitted in all his late editions. Why? T.T. says he has some MS. poems of Tennyson’s, written at Cambridge.

div.head: January 18, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K H.M., , T.T.

The Professor dilates upon the charms of a pretty girl staying with his brother. “If I'd been 20 years younger or 20 years older I should have been spoony on her.” Tells of his dinners with Southampton Swells. E. says he lived there once and remembers abadclap taken there from London. How such stings stick in one.
Horace tells of his quarrel with Bateman anent his brother Juley – big enough to take care of himself, one would think. Fancy marrying Leah with such a father in law.

“The Damp Squibs” a suggested name by Leech for a Convivial Club. “Post Equitem sedet atra Curé”
Per Constance Smith, this is from Horace, but should be “atra cura”: “Behind the horseman sits livid care.” Said of horseman flying from his guilt.], says Du.M. apropos the Brompton Oratorians, which clearly is the subject for the cut, says Mark silencing Burnand [Punch 48 (28 January 1865): 37, “The Brompton Area Sneak”].

Apropos of the Chetwynd case Tom says “How strong little facts tell against a man when marshalled into evidence. I often go into my nursery in my nightshirt and that fact might tell.”
The Chetwynd v. Chetwynd divorce case, in which Blanche Chetwynd accused her husband, Henry, of cruelty and adultery, was reported exhaustively in the Times, beginning December 17, p. 11. The trial ended January 20 with the jury finding in the wife’s favor.

Punch's Pantomime! E. has found some copies of it. “Ponny and I as surviving authors demand an account,” says Mark. How well I remember old skinny legged Payne getting into his carpet bag to hide himself from the Barons – and their unbuttoning their coats and so unbosoming themselves, by words painted on their breasts. Real pantomime, all dumb show. Payne is alive and kicking now and his skinny legs are nightly on the go in Cinderella.
William Henry Schofield Payne (1804-1878), known as the King of Pantomime, and father of the great Victorian clown Harry Payne. Payne appeared as Baron Pumpoline in Drury Lane's Cinderella during the 1864 Christmas season, with his son, Fred, playing Pedro the footman.
“Pater, give us a Child's Party!” says Mark. – “I will, if you'll come in Jackets!”

div.head: January 25, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., S.B., P.L., C.K., H.M.

Dies Albissima! On my return from Woodbridge (without Settie) I find letter from Mrs. Newman and Lord Russell promising the Charterhouse appointment to Bouge Leech! Huzza! – Show Shirley and Pater the Peer's autograph which goes around the Table at Evans' request. (Also find a letter from T. at Clifton saying the Dr. left a Will and an annuity to S. and L. – Whence I infer that all's serene, and on Friday find it is so. Expected a sixth and get a third! ... But Lord R's letter most delights me.)
“S. and L.” refers to Henry’s younger sisters, Sarah and Louise. “T.” is Temple, his brother. The doctor is William Temple, former physician to the Duke of Bedford and Henry’s uncle, who died in Bristol on January 19, 1865, at the age of 85. Dr. Silver left the bulk of his estate of some £250,000 to his nephews and a niece. Thomas Temple Silver died in 1868, leaving an estate of £70,000, almost all of which was left to Henry.
“Horace, ma tear, vill you 'ave shome pork,” says Shirley in Jewish accents.

L.C. H.S. suggests something for Workhouse Surgeons apropos of the Timothy Daly dying of bedsores case.
Timothy Daly, 28, an inmate of the Holborn workhouse, lay in a small, dirty bed in a cramped position in the workhouse infirmary for two weeks suffering from bedsores, without any change of dressings; shortly after friends removed him to a private residence, he died. Articles in the Times, the Spectator, and other papers aroused public opinion and a formal enquiry was instituted that ultimately exonerated the medical officer. See “The Treatment of Timothy Daly,” Lloyd’s Weekly, 15 January 1865, 5. P.L. thinks workhouse children should be taught to be cooks. Public wouldn't want them. Too illbred. But the Bright speech is the subject – Dr. Bright and his poor patient (P.L. and S.B.) [Punch, 48 (4 February 1865): 47, “Dr. Bright and His Patient”].

Talk of Burton's plan for exploring the North Pole, which Shirley approves. Shirley tells of Tom's coming to Garrick too late to fulfill his promise of backing Sullivan, the Composer. – “Pilled, is he? – ah – cold day, isn't it? What d'ye think of Fechter's Macaire?”
Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890), African explorer. Despite this initial setback, composer Arthur Sullivan (1842-1900) was admitted to the Garrick and would be active in the club for the rest of his life. Charles Albert Fecther played the character of Robert Macaire in Adolphe Beau’s “The Roadside Inn” at the Lyceum when he presented the play there on January 21, 1865.

S.B. would like a slice of Siberia for our convicts – sharp floggings instead of long imprisonments. No assaults on Queen since flogging was prescribed. P.L. says that as man develops his higher faculties, he loses taste for the exercise of his lower. Animals have an instinct that limits their breeding – man's reason should supply this. Shirley says, “But men don't reason in bed – poor people have two pleasures, to get children and to get drunk. Rich people have dinners, [word crossed out, “newspapers”?], horses, shooting boxes, sodomy and small talk – but these luxuries are not allowed to the poor. So you can't wonder at their having large families, tho' they have nothing to live on and know that half their sons must either steal or starve.” – An eloquent debate about this.

Then Shirley sets a copy in small writing: “Professor Leigh is one of the most remarkable men of the day, whether we regard his extraordinary memory, his subtle ratiocination, his fluent oratory or his efflorescent wit.” Charles Keene beats us – H.S. second. – Tenniel draws Pam with his left hand.

div.head: January 31, 1865. T[uesday].
div.p: H.S. at Carlton Hall driving partridges.

div.head: February 8, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., J.T., S. B . P.L., F . C .B., C.K., H.M.

D.M. says Sandys has given a dinner to 7 (8 in all), that cost £100. To be consistent he should have paid the bill and then blown his brains out, says Shirley. “What a splendid shot if he had hit 'em!” Perhaps he invited Lords and paid them £10 apiece to come. – F.C.B. explains that a dish of the “oyster of fowls” is as expensive as you'd wish not to order. Of course, it turns out next Wednesday that the dinner cost £20 and not £100.
Frederick Sandys (1829-1904), Pre-Raphaelite painter and illustrator. His work appeared regularly in Once a Week and other magazines.

L.C. P.L. says the Abrogation of Canadian treaties is the subject and after a long talk, Shirley improves on his notion, vide Uncle Sam. (A good ideal, that Uncle Sam, Mr. Tenniel – Eagle's head etc.) [Punch, 48 (18 February 1865): 67, “The Threatening Notice”]
In a letter to Mark Lemon referring to this discussion, Shirley Brooks wrote: “We settled a cut, on the notice which the Congress wishes Lincoln to give us about the lakes &c. He, as attorney, “feels it his duty to say to his client that it may drive Bull to go to Davis.” This is just a hint at possibilities, & don’t commit us. I had to pull at the reins a little, entre nous.” (Kent State Collection, item #24.) D.M. suggests the Sewing Machine, apropos of the Dressmaking Co. Ltd.: girl as the machine; not too much wear and tear under the New Company.
The London Dressmaking Co. Ltd. was created by reformers like Thomas Hughes to encourage healthier working conditions and shorter hours for workers in the dressmaking trades. A meeting of the shareholders, with Hughes in the chair, was reported in the Times for February 7, 1865, p. 9.

S.B. thinks something funny might be made of Bright's indignation at young Lord Amberley pluming himself on being a bird of the same feather. Cocky speech that of Lord A's – his first appearance – at Leeds.
30-year-old John Russell, Viscount Amberley, son of the Prime Minister, spoke at a Reform meeting at Leeds on January 31 in favor of parliamentary reform. See the Times, February 2, 1865, p. 5, and Times leaders on February 3, p. 8., and March 17, p. 9. An account of the speech’s reception can be found in The Amberley Papers, eds. Bertrand and Patricia Russell (2 vols., London, 1937), I, pp. 358-63. Says the Peers are imbecile and have no right to sit hereditarily.
S.B. flares up against the notion of our being worsted in a war with the Yankees. “We should crumple the States like a sheet of paper.” – “Rather a large sheet,” says Horace.

While P.L. and F.C.B. talk theology with E., J.T. and I discuss how to make the most of Leech's sketches.
See Punch 48 (22 April 1865): 157 announcing the collection of Leech's sketches for sale at auction by Christies on the 25th of April. Millais, Arthur Lewis, and Richard Doyle arranged the display of Leech’s sketches at the sale, and the Times carried a lengthy appreciation (perhaps by Tom Taylor) on April 21, p. 10. Millais sanguine – but is he businesslike?

div.head: February 15, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: (H.S. from Woodbridge today.) E_, D.M., H.S. ,F.E.,
S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.

“Where's the Tailor and the Jew?” says Shirley – just before Horace enters. Capital beefsteak pudding – larks etc. ... First bit of salmon (headache en suite). “Who would work if he had £1,000 a year?” asks Shirley. As if money ensured happiness. Bosh! thinks H.S. – reflecting on avuncular expectations realized.

L.C. Slavery abolished by order of New York Senate. Shirley thinks it an event for History – M.L. thinks it humbug.
In a diary entry for this date, Shirley Brooks wrote, referring to the Large Cut discussion, “Stood up for the Federals and their abolition of slavery, but the current feeling in society, just now, is all against them, even to unfairness.” (Morgan Library) “A thought strikes me – let us again emancipate the slaves” says Tenniel. ... Like farmer and the ducks, says H.S.: the slaves not theirs. Malt tax proposed. S.B. suggests The Agricultural Jerry Diddler [Punch, 48 (25 February 1865): 79, “The Agricultural Jeremy Diddler”] (approved).
Jeremy Diddler, a confidence man who borrows but never repays, is a character in James Kenney’s 1803 play, “Raising the Wind,” and remained a popular figure in British culture throughout the century. A deputation of farmers had marched to demand that the Chancellor of the Exchequer repeal the Malt Tax; see Times leader, February 9, 1865, p. 8, and coverage of repeal meetings, January 23, p. 7 and February 20, p. 6.
Paxton commends Punch of late, advises us to write over readers' heads a bit. Circulation keeps up – so let us keep up the tone.

div.head: February 22, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.
Burnand signs himself O Gemini! in declining invitation. Wife with twins!

Tom says Buckstone made £25,000 by the American Cousin and only gave him £150 for the right to play it here.
J. B. Buckstone (1802-1879), actor-manager, who managed the Haymarket Theatre, 1853-76. Buckstone enjoyed a huge success (496 nights) in 1862 with Our American Cousin, which featured E. A. Sothern’s career-making role as Lord Dundreary; the play had made its debut in America in 1858 in a production by Laura Keen, by whom Taylor also claimed to have been swindled (see entry for January 18, 1860). Tom got only £170 for the Ticket of Leave and Emden gave him no Bonus on account of its success.
John Emden managed the Olympic Theatre in partnership with Frederick Robson, where The Ticket-of-Leave Man premiered on March 27, 1863 and ran for over 400 nights; the play, one of the most successful of the nineteenth century, was frequently revived. It brought him £400 from the provinces last year. Shirley condemns and contemns such Managers. Tom says he believes a gentleman manager might do great good to the stage and himself too. Sheridan was dishonest. Garrick succeeded as manager, although he acted – so did Macready, though he sacrificed his interests to his vanity. Contends that managing requires more tact and talent than any business he knows. Also contends that a good pantomimist is greatly to be respected – though his talent is not first class. Instances the Paynes. Shirley despises all actors – Tom doesn't. Pitches into Burnand's Cupid and Psyche as the stupidest and most imbecile burlesque ever written, and “I mean to tell him so.” Vulgarity in lieu of wit.
The punning pantomime Cupid and Psyche, or, Beautiful as a Butterfly, ran at the Olympic during the 1864-65 Christmas season.

L.C. Shirley wants to pat the Yankees on the back for abolishing Slavery – but it’s premature says P.L. who thinks Bull might say, “Well, Jonathan's done it – now's our turn for the slaves here” (milliners etc.) But Shirley quotes a bit of Punch 15 years ago: “Slaves for want of legislation are not quite like Slaves by Law.”
“Seasonable Interference,” Punch (January 22, 1853): 37 M.L. hits the mark, “Street boy – 'Am not I black enough to be cared for?'“ Good, but whom is he speaking to? says Shirley – must have cruiser and slaver in distance, and a missionary giving the Bible to the black. “Telescopic philanthropy,” says H.S. – that's it, says Shirley – Britannia looking through the telescope [Punch, 48 (4 March 1865): 88-89, “Telescopic Philanthropy”]. ... Capital.

Then to Olympic with T.T., M.L., and J.T. – Hidden Hand – and burlesque – which is stupid enough.
The Hidden Hand by Tom Taylor opened at the Olympic in November, 1864, with Horace Wigan in the lead role. “Pray for heaven's sake don't think I am defending them! says the Professor – “only perhaps men think anything will do for boobies who like burlesques, and so they take no pains about 'em.”

 [drawing of pointing hand] Shirley bets Ponny Mayhew a dinner to the Punch men that there will not be a workmen's extension of the franchise before February 22, 1867. Punch men to decide who wins.
Mayhew lost the bet, as noted in Shirley Brooks’s diary for February 20, 1867 (British Library): “Dined P. and gave Horace M. a sealed up bet between us, made two years ago, & marked to be opened 22nd Feb 1867. I had forgotten its subject, but it proved to be his wager (a d. to the P. men) that a Reform bill wd have passed before above date. Therefore, I win, & I leave the matter in his hands, for the present.”

Bill Jerrold gets £500 from Lloyds Newspaper.
William Blanchard Jerrold (1826-1884) succeeded his father as editor of Lloyd’s Weekly in 1857 and served in that role until his death. Shirley would undertake to do three columns of Leaders for it between breakfast and dinner any day and every week. Quick witted he is. Knocks off a Prologue for the Guards as easily as I would a Lunatic Love Song.

div.head: March 1, 1865. W[ednesday]. No . 11. Ash Wednesday. Champ.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., F.C.B., H.M.
Mark again a grandfather and Burnand's wife has had girl twins. So we crush a cup.

Caesar and Boney very much alike – specially Boney. Such is the epitome of Louis Nap's Commentaries on Caesar. The preface appeared in Tuesday's Times. Paris press in extacies of course. Shirley suggests Louis stabbing Caesar with a goosequill at the foot of Statue of Napoleon the Great.' .. Or why not have Louis blowing out a gutta percha Napoleon to the likeness of a Caesar. Difficult to draw says Tenniel. But it’s the situation and is to be tried [Punch, 48 (1 March 1865): 99, “Nullus aut Caesar.”]
A translation by Thomas Wright of Louis Napoleon’s Life of Caesar was reviewed in the Times, March 23, 1865, 7. A series of articles on the French edition appeared on March 1, 2, 6, and 7. H.S. thinks of L.N. as a showman, exhibiting Caesar and Napoleon, “See how like they are.” Evans says, “You can't make Buonaparte a little man, anyhow” – and proceeds to defend him, on account of the times and country that he lived in. Shirley smashes him as a liar and a murderer – “only did one good action – killed a publisher.” Says the verdict of Madame — was that Wellington couldn't talk but f her better than Buonaparte. Hence the conversation groweth smutty and D.M. tells of Ruskin lashing his to a toothbrush, “prixfixe,” says Shirley. – Thinks he married from sentiment.

– 5 at a birth – a revolver cock: “Please sir it took.” .. Friend of artist, “I know who'd give a £1000 to see your picture.”“Who? (flattered). ... Why, Arago! (Arago was blind).
François Jean Dominique Arago (1786-1853), distinguished French scientist and statesman. He went blind in his later years.

Mark pictures a man in street, “Wipe your nose, Sir.” – What for Sir. – “Because I want to pull it!” That's snot polite, says Shirley. – Row between Yates and Hannay, of the Pall Mall Gazette. What do the public care, says Mark. Authors shouldn't blacken authors, says Shirley.
See “The Rival Editors: or Hannay v. Yates,” Huddersfield Chronicle, 25 February 1865, 3.
Blanchard Jerrold's Dining Co. hard up – luxurious furniture etc. “Should spend more on the carving than the gilding,” says Shirley. Sala reformed, says Horace: “He only drinks wine now!” Bravo!
*S.B. suggests ghost of Caesar loq.: “I conquered Britain: You, Napoleon couldn't; and you, Napoleon III; can't.”

div.head: March 8, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champ.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S. (from Woodbridge), S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., T.T

“I spose the Slave driving Brigands will soon throw up the Sponge,” says Shirley – apropos of the fall of Charleston and Wilmington. Nous verrons – He calls snivelling at stage pathos “hydraulic onanism.” ... Talk of de Morny's death.
The Duc de Morny, President of the Legislative Assembly and close supporter of Louis Napoleon, died on Friday, March 10, but Silver has mistakenly put this mention under the meeting for March 8.

L.C. P.L. wants something about the Canada defences – but is snubbed. The Bursting of the Beer Bubble, says H.M., apropos of Kelly's froth last night
Sir Fitzroy Kelly, in a long speech to the House on March 7, presented a petition and a motion for the repeal of the malt tax. Times, March 8, 1865, p. 6. ... Compulsory education, Shirley advocates, à la Louis Nap. Look at those 8 pitmen standing by, while man kills wife.
The Times for March 7, 1865, p. 9, reported on the conviction of Mattthew Atkinson, a Durham pitman, for the murder of his wife, expounding at length upon the shameful failure of several witnesses, all of them fellow pitmen, to stop the beating. Ought they to have votes, or be allowed the management of their children? Education question a bore, argues P.L. But you educate your nephew, says Tom. – “Yes – but I have grievous misgivings if it will do him any good.” (ha! ha!) – Tom suggests John Bull using this phrase apropos of his National Schools.

Finally Shirley and Tom unite in recommending the Sir Charles Wood alarmed by Indian telegrams cut, as it appeareth [Punch, 48 (18 March 1865): 109, “The Tormented Minister”]. P.L. protesting that Canada is the subject, and waving his hands à la Punch with his cudgel, “Rootitooit” squeaks Mark, and we all roar.

div.head: March 15, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S. F.E., S.B., J.T., N.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., T.T.

Du Maurier tells how some 4 years since he sold a great-coat, cost £6, to a Jew for £1 – Jew paid him 19/- and said he'd send 1/-. – 2 years after he met D.M. and asked, “Did you get that shilling?” Pleasant! ...

M.L. tells of friend of his (Hamilton, who married a Princess and meeting Mark said, “Look in if you're passing” – “Where d'ye live? – “Western Coast of Africa!”) and how he sent a Jew to the Edgware Road with some opera cloaks and sold him.

Tom tells that his American Cousin was suggested by the advent of three cousins, father, mother and grownup son, to fellow in Hampshire (Col. -) and they slept all in one bed, and astonished the natives.

L.C. Shirley proposes Rapture of the Nuns at the prospect of being Inspected – (Newdegate).
Charles Newdegate (1816-1887), an actively anti-Catholic M.P., had recently made one of many motions in the House of Commons to establish a select committee to conduct inspections of convents and monasteries. His attacks on these institutions were refuted in print by William Bernard Ullathorne (1806-1889), Bishop of Birmingham. Pleasant Morning Call as a change from the Monks – old abbess disgusted. Or Convent cell according to Newdegate... and according to Ullathorne. But however you put it, says Mark, you suggest prurience. – Better try the Iron Strike. Britannia complaining that her ships can’t be built, or saying to Ironmaster, “If you won't work I must employ Belgium.” [Punch, 48 (25 March 1865): 119, “Vulcan in the Sulks”]. Question between Strike and Stroke, says Shirley, who amends a suggestion of Neptune from Pater, which H.S. had thought of – but as usual did not blurt it out.
Strikes in Staffordshire led to lockouts in Yorkshire, Derbyshire, and the North of England. See Times leader of March 9, 1865, p. 8, and Alan Birch, Economic History of the British Iron and Steel Industry, 1784-1879, (London: Taylor & Francis, 2006) p. 274. Somehow he feels afraid of the sound of his voice, unless he has anything worth hearing to say. Shrinks from the familiar “Tom” and “Mark” and “Shirley” which Burnand has jumped into before him. “Maxima debeter senibus reverentia”
Per C. Smith, from Juvenal, Satires, xiv, 47: “Maxima debetur puero reverential” (We owe the greatest respect to a child.”)... Tom says “I never yet saw a good Cut on Strikes”– of course. Too prosy and practical a subject.
Look in at the Gallery with D.M. First night of “Peculiar Family.”

Horace showeth a new “Comic” – “The Bubble – with which is incorporated The Comic News.” Mark suggests “The Squeak – with which is incorporated The Bubble.” Among the Comicalities the Bubble contains a Comic Case of Rape – old woman of ninety on a boy of 5. Delicious!
According to the Waterloo Directory, The Bubble published only one issue, for March 21, 1865.

Du Maurier wishes for £500 a year to enable him to follow his own fancies in his work – and not to do drudgery: and be obliged to think of Punch when his inclination is to the Sunday Magazine, or vice versâ. H.S. thinks living for mere amusement vastly tiresome. Conscience tortures one for wasting one's time.

div.head: March 22, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E. D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., W.B., H.M.

Lucas starts the Shilling Magazine and so ceases to edit Once a Week. “Let me,” says Mark, “and I'll make it so popular that you'll have to alter it to Twice a Week.”
See the classic study of Lucas’s editorship, William E. Buckler, “Once a Week under Samuel Lucas, 1859-1865,” PMLA 67:7 (Dec., 1952), pp. 924-941

Salmon and ptarmigan – besides Palestine soup and roast beef and pudding – a dinner fit for Jove. L.C. The Colenso decision should be the Cut, says P.L. Westbury knocking the two Bishops’ heads together – or giving them the shells (stale). M.L. suggests simple statement of fact – bishops drawing blanks out of the Chancellor's bag. [ Punch, 48 (1 April 1865): 131, “The Colenso Judgment.”]
John William Colenso (1814-1883), Bishop of Natal from 1853 until his death. A follower of F. D. Maurice, Colenso wrote a series of treatises on the Pentateuch and the Book of Joshua in which he expressed doubts of traditional Anglican theology that had been raised in his mind by his missionary experiences among the Zulus, writings that led to accusations of heresy from the High Church party and attempts on the part of the Bishop of Cape Town to dismiss Colenso from his post. The Privy council ultimately decided that the Bishop of Cape Town had no jurisdiction in the matter. C.K. proposes the East Wind – and the Dust Nuisance. Pater wishes for a Strike Cut, but we'd trouble enough last week with one. Dull debate – principal tongues being absent, Shirley, Tom and Burnand, the chief talkers but B. is not more fertile in his cuts than Keene or myself.
 [drawing of pointing hand] Drury to follow to see a fifty year old Juliet – Helen Faucit to wit – with T. and E.

div.head: March 29, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., W.B., H.M.

Rogeard's “Propos de Labienus” à propos de “Jules César” (by Lewis Napoleon) suggests to P.L. for big cut the serving up an objection on a salver by a flunkey critic. Not strong enough, says Mark, should be critic with a gendarme beside him. H.S. suggests a party of critics “invited” to a supper of handcuffs etc. M.L. thinks the Strike a better subject – and J.T. inclines to Neptune and Britannia being repeated – referring to Arbitration, who's Arbitration in mythology, says H.S. – P.L. suggests Themis for Justice as arbitrator – and we settle thereupon [Punch, 48 (8 April 1865): 141, “Arbitration better than Emigration”]

D.M. was bullied at school for being an Englishman though he was born in Paris and came of French extraction. French boys can't bear pain. Disliked Madame Beatrice in the Stranger: thought her like a Quartier Latin model. H.S. and Ponny agree in thinking her graceful – those little cries of joy when her husband relents are touching. D.M. “hates to see men snivel at such stuff – has no sympathy with an adulteress – husband the next day would think himself a fool to have pardoned her.” Possibly, but an audience doesn't think what will happen after the curtain drops.
H.M. applauds La Joie fait peur – as doth H.S. Says he saw even Forster, the Hon. John Forster, blubbering at it with Leech.

D.J. described how he bathed abroad – you bathe with a man's wife there as modestly as you here would waltz with one. Never felt a prurient sensation in the water with no matter how lovely a Venus might come out of the sea to him.

div.head: April 5, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., S.B.- J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., T.T.

Tom pitches into Percival who owns the scrap anent the Sewerage – “A Nice Job for a Prince.” Tom says the Sewers are the great moral as well as physical advancers of the age, and no one but a fool wd sneer at their being opened (yesterday) by a Prince. Percival replies that he meant no sneer – but thought that opening a watercloset was hardly Prince's work. Moreover he protested against the adoration of things merely material, which is a weakness of the age. It's a mercy the Archbishop wasn't called upon for a Prayer! – Tom is too hot and too venomous: and we rejoice that P. takes it coolly. The proper course would have been for Tom to complain to the Editor privately, for he is responsible for all that appears. D.M. indignant for Leigh's sake. “Shut up – you're in a minority of one, you melancholy Jakes” saith Tom.

We talk of Millais' Roman and Ancient Britoness, which we all admire (Miss Scott Russell was the model D.M. saith). But Tom cuts up the Joan of Arc for wearing armour of the time of Francis the First: a fact which escaped the critical observation of Mr Punch’s Historian of Costume.

L.C. Tom suggests a Thames cut – Father T. clean and shaking the Prince’s hand. – M.L. had previously thought of Thames as a Waterman, which is accepted. [Punch, 48 (15 April 1865): 151, “Father Thames 'Himself' Again”].
Shirley Brooks commented in his diary entry for this date: “Contest as to whether we ought to discuss the published number. M.L. thought not, but any way we did on this occasion, despite protest. But it was all amicable enough, I think.” (Morgan mss.)

div.head: April 12, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: (H.S. from Newport)
E., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., W.B., H.M., T.T. champ.

Champagne to drink the health of Bradbury père – whose birthday is tomorrow. Shirley's smash for Cox in last week's Essence [of Parliament] has evoked a request to know B & E's solicitor. But we think the letter is a hoax: for there in nothing actionable in the paragraph.

S.B. emits some aristocratic nonsense about the vice of poverty – to the effect that all poor people are scamps and scoundrels and degraded beasts. D.M. says it makes his blood boil to hear such bosh. And H.S. agrees with him. Shirley denies that the poor have any feelings but those of an animal. “Leigh can understand what I mean,” says he. And so can H.S., but cannot admire it.

L.C. D.M. suggests the revival of the Costume de 1'Empire as seen now in Paris. France with a low dress and Britannia shocked at it. T.T. suggests the American Gladiators – North as Retiarius and South as Secutor. But we think the time hardly come for such a cut. …T.T. then suggests the Belphegor Russell cut – apropos of Fechter. Which is adopted – he writing the legend, as Charles calls it, propriâ malâ matris. [Punch, 48 (22 April 1865): 163, “Strengthening Bill” referes to Fechter, as Manager, casting his own son in Belphegor the Mountebank at the Lyceum with an analogy to Lord Amberley's appearance at Leeds, with Lord Russell his father.] To the Adelphi with Mark and Tenniel to see “Pan.” Stupid enough.

div.head: April 19, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E.. D.M., H.S., F.E., F.C.B., J.T., M .L. PL, C.K., H.M., W.B.

H.S. from Woodbridge after Settie's wedding visit there. Lovely sunshine of late. We talk of Burnand's burlesques at the Royalty and St. James – Pirithous and Ulysses. He gets more theatrical and slangified the more he succeeds, I think.

L.C. The report of the taking of Richmond in Saturday's Times makes the Gladiator subject a good one we think. All up, says Pater, but we don't agree that the time to ask the “Habet?” question is come yet.
“Habet” (or “Habet, hoc habet!”) was the traditional cry by the crowd at the end of a gladiatorial match, variously translated as “He’s had it” or “He’s down,” in recognition of the victor’s coup de grace.

x x News of Lee's surrender to Grant comes in time for the Habet to be added. [Punch, 48 (29 April 1865): 173, “The American Gladiators – Habet!”].
The Times went to press on Saturday morning, and would have been distributed on Monday, April 24, 1865, although there may have been placards announcing the news on Saturday, the day that Punch, too, went to press; the article about the surrender appears on page 9 of the Times, from reports dated April 10.

div.head: April 26, 1865. No. 11.
div.p: [drawing of pointing hand] Leech's sale yesterday & today & Tomorrow.
Quite summer. Ice pudding & asparagus the first.
E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., W.B., T.T.

This is terrible news! saith Tom on entrance. And we all echo. I could scarce believe the placard outside the Telegraph office at noon today as I walked to Leech's Sale. “President Lincoln Assassinated! Mr. Seward and his son dangerously wounded.” — It could hardly have happened at a more untimely time. Fancy that drunken beast Johnson to be President! What a degradation to America! And what a danger to England from that democratic snob!

Despite Shirley (who is dining in Eaton Square, he takes care to tell) we decide that so great an event cannot be passed over. And T.T. suggests Britannia throwing her wreath on the bier [Punch, 48 (6 May 1865): 183, “Britannia Sympathises with Columbia”] – Mark objects to this but is overruled; suggesting however Britannia comforting Columbia, which title we accept. Tom adds as mourners the black man and the white, and promises some lines. He wrote those in this week upon The Gladiators while travelling from Worcester. H.S. pencils also when he gets his thoughts in train. Tom suggests Lord John cockfighting – young Amberley “this cock won't fight.” There has been a capture of cockfighters lately.

Tom pitches into Whistler – “has no poetry in him.” The aim of poetry is the truthful representation of the beautiful. Whistler chooses ugly faces and does not present them with truth. Prefers mean and grovelling subjects.

Tom tells how in his wild Cambridge days he ate ices for six and did not suffer. And would eat supper for six, or drink liqueurs for six. His stomach must be iron and his brains of steel. O the blessings of a good digestion and a good thick skin!

We compare notes as to our old school games. In one at Tom's North Country school there was a cry of “King's Speech” which he thinks is a corruption of “King's Piece” i.e., Sanctuary: privilege of the Court. Keene tells of a game, “Hammer, chisel and block” – boy propelled, with head into block's stomach.

div.head: May 3, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M. H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W. B.

A week of horrors. News of Lincoln's assassination last Wednesday and that of a Russian attaché in Paris. On Monday news that Admiral Fitzroy, the Clerk of the Weather, had cut his throat (with a cutting East Wind, says Shirley) – cause overwork: a warning to us fellows – and that Prescott the banker had cut his throat also. On horrors head etc. Next Tuesday, we hear that Booth is shot. Shirley protests against Tom Taylor's lines on Lincoln – “Punch has not been blind and shallow,” and even if it had, we ought not to own it. “Would you have written the lines, Leigh?” – “I, no! I should think not, indeed.” Mark contends that the avowal that we have been a bit mistaken, is manly and just: and H.S. agrees with him. Our principal mistrust in Lincoln arose from his saying he would throw over the Slave question if he thereby could maintain the Union: and then afterwards declaring it was Slavery alone that caused the War and alone could finish it. But he was an honest man.

L.C. A Budget Cut – apropos of last Thursday. Income Tax reduced to 4d and tea duty to 6d. Shirley suggests grocer making excuses to a lady why he can't reduce the price: amends this to the Election Budget, accepted. [Punch, 48 (13 May 1865): 193, “The Election Budget.”]
Shirley has a very lordly notion of the aims of Punch – “We don't write for people in cottages – our readers don't think of tea as a necessary of life.”

Somebody suggests Robert le Diable for a burlesque and H.S. suggests a parody of the Nun's Scene – cooks rising from areas and putting heads up through coalholes in pavement at the incantation of a Bobby – “Robert toi que j'aime.”

div.head: May 10, 1865
div.p: Shirley likes Miss Bateman's “Bianca,” but condemns the play. Tom has never seen anything to commend in her acting – hard, stagy and unnatural.

Shirley pitches into Tom anent the Lincoln lines – and Tom says he felt his pen “lamed” by the later acts of Lincoln, and thought that had been too hasty in his judgment. [Punch, 48 (6 May 1865): 182, “Abraham Lincoln: Foully Assassinated, April 14, 1865.”] This Shirley denies and says, “Punch can do no wrong.”
Shirley Brooks, in his diary entry of this date, writes, “Let out my views against some verses on Lincoln in which T.T. had not only made p. eat umbles pie but swallow dish and all. P.L. and J.T. with me.” (Morgan Library)

L.C. Shirley suggests, apropos of Baines on Reform, the Working Man being photographed by various parties – one making him an angel and another a devil: Bob Lowe representing him as a drunkard. Tom amends this to a Portrait Gallery – in preference to Shirley's Workingman showing different photos to his wife ... Tom also suggests Russell's Reform Bill parodying Landseer's horse in Prosperity and Adversity. Mark suggests Workman with a pot of beer on one side and a vote on t'other . . . but the Portraits are accepted [Punch, 48 (1865): 203, “The Working-Man, from the Royal Westminster Exhibition.”]
– Afterwards H.S. to Comus with Clem and the Gascoignes.
May 17, 1865. W[ednesdayl. No. 11. Champ.
E., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., W.B.
Du Maurier was presented with a Son and heir on Saturday, so we baptise the Infant in a bumper of champagne. (And H.S. gets a headache, from its not being Clicquot.)

He tells of the wit of a little French girl in 1848, “Laissez moi, papa” to a blackguard in a blouse – and then explaining to D.M. Senior, “Maintenant tous les messieurs sont mes papas. Et mème les messieurs en blouse.” Both he and Horace declare there's no nature in French children and no modesty in French girls, all shrinking as they pretend to be. Common thing for a French woman to let a young Englishman walk with her daughter, “I can trust you.” Fancy what a state of morals, when the play most fashionable now in Paris represents a wife as in love with her husband and regretting she is not in love with her lover. After she sins and is kicked off, says someone to the husband, “Will she return ever?” And the curtain falls on his “Peut être!” — ugh! the “filthy copulative beasts” as Mark calls them in his disgust.
Shirley tells of the American and his “it's only my claspknife.”

L.C. Debate on the Union Chargeability Bill, which Leigh says is the measure of the Session – no child of mine, says the Squire to the labourer. S.B. and M.L. knock up a cut that will do – but ought to be stronger. And we none of us can hit upon a trenchant title. The Labourer's Walk, says H.S., The Parish Pariah, says H.M. [Punch, 48 (27 May 1865): 213, “Out of the Parish.”] – Burnand suggests the Emperor drest as a Mussulman apropos of his Algerian visit – and Shirley amends it to his frightening Eugenie thereby. But who cares for the Emperor's trip: parodying his Uncle's. Can't get a parallel for the 40 Centuries.

Last week we debated about suicide and Tenniel thinks that hope is a preventive: e.g. in apparently incurable disease a remedy may be invented. Evans says, Fear: and quotes Hamlet —and then Job The Lord hath given and the Lord hath taken away – blessed be the name of the Lord. Du Maurier says before he married he often felt tempted to suicide. And H.S. on a cliff's edge has felt a tingling about his stomach – a devilish impulse to jump over. But this is merely a disordered frame of mind arising from bodily infirmity, such as a blue pill and a black dose will dissipate.

We who remain – M.L., H.M., H.S., and J.T. – the usual lingerers, debate on the degeneracy of the day in respect of filial reverence and girlish modesty and education – i.e. domestic training. To call your father governor and old cock must somewhat lessen respect – and to aim at accomplishments and sneer at home housewifery does not improve a girl or make her fit for what should be the chief aim of her life – to make a happy home.

div.head: May 24, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., W.B.

Whitebait and cyder cup – pickled salmon, soles, chickens, cold lamb and “the London” pudding. A pretty little Birthday dinner. Even puts H.S.'s pecker up, which has been woefully down – at Winchester – the last day or two.

The Derby of course the subject. H.S. suggests Diz trying to mount “British Constitution” or “Church and State” and Pam saying, “Yes that's the horse to win with – but you can't ride him.” M.L. improves to 'Diz as “Correct Card”' [Punch, 48 (3 June 1865): 224, “The Derby Horseshoe Magnet” ; Punch, 48 (3 June 1865): 225, “Dizzy's K'rect Card for the 'Derby'“] His Election bunkum manifesto is a splendid piece of impudence.

Poor old Joyce died on Saturday. He fell down in a fit a few days before in Lincoln's Inn and never spoke again. Godfrey Evans tells me that his habit was to turn a handkerchief about to see if it were his and this he did in his unconsciousness on his deathbed. He was rough – but a goodhearted kind man. I believe he was a master and Bradbury his apprentice. The situations were reversed and B. became his master.

Sam Lucas must be mad. He asked Tom Taylor where he cd get his – photographed. I thought his eyes looked black and wild at Leech's sale – where he introduced his wife to Ponny as the prettiest and most intellectual woman in the world. They say he was mad drunk at the Club on Saturday. Overwork, says Leigh. Disappointment that his wife is not noticed, says Pater.
On the same day, Brooks noted in his diary, “I hear that L[ucas] was wild at the club on Saturday. He looks ill.” Publisher William Tinsley, who had worked closely with Lucas, later recalled that about this time “some peculiar phases of poor Mr. Lucas's mind, which had for some time been visible, began to show themselves in a more serious form” (Random Recollections of an Old Publisher, [London: Simpkin, Marshall, 1900], vol. 1, p. 322. Lucas had also become estranged from Bradbury and Evans, writing increasoingly hostile letters beginning in December of 1864. On May 4, 1865, he wrote of his relationship with B&E as “a connection which I shall ever regard with disgust, and which I do now unceasingly deplore.” The seven letters from Lucas to Bradbury are in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Gen Mss. 210, Box 1, Folder 15.

The talk gets very mournful – Leigh saying men now work too hard and don't spare time enough for exercise – and so their brains wear out. We learn by the Owl that Mrs. Leech has a pension of £100 a year – and I get a letter from her confirming it.

Then the talk gets anecdotical about Mrs. Wigan and Mrs. Glover and Duvernay[?]. But first we have an art jaw apropos of Sandys' drawing to Swinburne's poem in The Shilling Mag. which Lucas[?] cracks up and D.M. and J.T. applaud and M.L. and H.M. and H.S. cannot. But our eyesight is not artistically educated.
Frederick Sandys's illustration appeared with Christina Rossetti's “Amor Mundi” in the April number of the short-lived Shilling Magazine, which was edited by Samuel Lucas. Silver appears to have confused this illustration with the Swinburne poem written to accompany the Sandys painting “Gentle Spring,” which had been included in the Royal Academy exhibition that opened on May 1, 1865. For a discussion of Lucas's relationship to the Punch circle at this time, and his descent into madness, see Leary, Punch Brotherhood, pp. 64-65.

div.head: May 31, 1865. W[ednesday]l.
div.p: The Derby Day – so no dinner, H.S. with T.T. walks home to Croydon after seeing the start. Gladiateur habet!

div.head: June 7, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E. apologizes for no strawberries. Ate the first last Saturday at Beckford Street.
H.S. from Woodbridge by C. today, D.M., H. S. , F. E.. S.B., J.T., M. L. , P.L., C.K., H. M., W.B., F.C.B.

Burnand edits No. 3 of The Glowworm today – and so comes in the middle of the meal.
A four-page daily paper devoted to music hall and general news, the Glowworm lasted from June 5, 1865, to February 13, 1869. The Waterloo Directory lists Arthur William à Beckett as editor, but this entry in Silver newly suggests that Burnand may have functioned in that role, at least for a time. His twins keep him active. And his Windsor Castle at the Strand on Monday was a success.
An opera burlesque, Windsor Castle made its debut at the Strand on June 5, 1865, with music by Frank Musgrave.

L.C. Leigh inveighs bitterly against the tone with which, he says, our press has received “that drunken tailor” [Andrew] Johnson. “The press follows public opinion,” says Mark. “And has its mouth close to the A– of public opinion,” says Leigh. Denies that the South were rebels and denies that the North can charge [Jefferson] Davis with treason. Shirley contrà — debate adjourned. Shirley proposes Political Baby Show apropos of young Gladstone's debut at Chester on Derby Eve. Which is accepted [Punch, 48 (10 June 1865): 235, “Strict Discipline”].
Burnand and Du Maurier talk of education like parents aged 50 and H.S. adds an old bachelor's word.

div.head: June 14, 1865. W[ednesday]. At the Ship, Greenwich.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., Bennett, and T.T. 13.

Capital dinner – crayfish curry and lobster omelette, the two daintiest of the dainties. Excellent moselle cup. Don't know what the Large Cut is to be. Discussion short and sweet while I was out of hearing [Punch, 48 (17 June 1865): 245, “Feeling Their Feet”]. D.M. tells of artists scraping a Titian to see how he worked and finding portrait of George the IV under it. Thinks Mrs. Edmund Yates is a beautiful woman.
Louise Katherine Wilkinson (1830?-1900), whose family was connected to the Wilkinson Sword Company, was renowned for her beauty. Edmund Yates married her in 1853. See the reminiscence by their friend, Jane Ellen Frith Panton, Leaves from a Life (London: Eveleigh Nash, 1908). The references in Silver's diary contradict Panton's assertion that “nobody who ever saw Mrs. Yates could avoid falling in love with her.” (p. 176). Mrs. Yates was the model for the main female figure in A. Solomon's painting, “The Bashful Lover,” an engraving of which appears in The Keepsake for 1855 (London: Bogue, 1855), after p. 254. Don't admire his dollish taste. Lewis had a grand gathering of petticoats on Saturday and some beauties among them.

The dinner I had at Hart's (in 59 was it?) the day after Leech and I dined there, lives still in my memory because I felt hungry after it. I don't feel hungry yet and its now 2 p.m. on Thursday and I've eaten nothing today. Is it age, or what? Remember that cold salmon and horseradish ice – why don't they serve it now?

Tomorrow Mark and Pater attend Paxton's funeral.
Sir Joseph Paxton (1803-1865), garden designer and horticultural writer best known as architect of the Crystal Palace, died on June 8. The Times account of his funeral (June 16, p. 9) mentions Lemon and Evans as among the attendees. One of the few “outsiders” ever to dine at the Punch Table. See Kate Colquhoun, A Thing in Disguise: The Visionary Life of Joseph Paxton (Fourth Estate: 2003). Another diner gone! More fatal overwork! He died last Thursday – only aged 62. His broad shoulders looked as if they would have borne 30 winters more.

div.head: June 21, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Bradbury Redivivus! W.B., H.S., , F.E., SB, J.T., M.L., P.L , F.C.B. Champ.

Three years since Bradbury last dined with us – June 18, 1862! Mark in a few feeling words proposes his health and the old boy touches us with his simple eloquence. Never expected to be with his dear old friends again and thanks God for the health to join them. But what sad gaps since the last dinner he had with us – Thackeray, Leech, Paxton. It will take good men to replace that trio.
T.T. says his little girl, aetat 16 months, on seeing the monkeys said, “Papa.” A child of intelligence clearly.

L.C. Railways and their accidents the subject – but not a funny one. Shirley and Leigh think a cut should be done against the proposed Ry. Factories at Oxford – desecrate and degrade Alma Mater. Minerva should not be soiled by Vulcan. Taylor and Burnand being Cambridge men, of course, don't see that Oxford would be injured; they hope it will be.
Goldwin Smith led the successful opposition to the Great Western Railways’ plans to build workshops in Oxford, for which the Corporation planned to lease Cripley Meadow. See Anthony Howe, “Intellect and civic responsibility: dons and citizens in 19th-century Oxford,” in R. C. Whiting, editor, Oxford: Studies in the History of a University Town since 1800 (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1993), pp. 14-16.
