Apropos of the hot weather (cold enough on board the Elsie on Saturday at Harwich), T.T. suggests Punch saying to Pam, “If you don't dissolve soon, I shall.” [Punch, 48 (1 July1865): 255, “A Propos du Temps”].

Talk of Papa Bateman, “The Colonel” and his curse in Geraldine – whereof Mark funnily gives the plot. “Your Camp [?] of Chobham killed Leigh Murray,” says Horace – the Swells treated him so that dipsomania seized him for a victim. His benefit comes off next Tuesday. Shirley has written a scene for him.
Per the Dictionary of National Biography, a benefit for Murray was given at Drury Lane on June 27 to enable him to move to a warmer climate for his health; the part written by Shirley Brooks was delivered by Murray and his wife. Murray died in 1870.

W.B. has a baby born today – the longest day. Will it be a long fellow? D.M. gone to Brussels to fetch his sister. Tom Taylor's forehead overhangs a rather sunken eye when his specs are off. Small sharp straight nose.

div.head: June 28, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., W.B., J.T. , M.L. , P.L., F.C.B., H.M.

The Handel Parliament. H.S. at the Handel Festival – Selection day. 3 to 5.20: in train 5.25; at No. 11 6.25! A rapid rush after an aural feast. Pitch into mayonnaise of sole, fried salmon, beans and bacon, lamb cutlet and strawberries and cream: smoke 3 cigars and wake next morning brilliant. Nothing like old Handel for clearing one's liver! Have been in better spirits this week than at any time since Easter. Mark and his wife sat with me on Monday. Messiah was a composing draught to him, he says. Horace can't appreciate Handel – poor fellow! thinks his music too dull and lengthy – chorus keep on repeating the same words. Well, anyhow an hour or two with Handel is better than a half hour in the Haymarket.
Shirley has the gout again. He certainly takes pains to get it.

L.C. Shall we take the Large Cut into consideration? says Mark: cigars being alight. F.C.B. suggests the “No Whitebait Dinner.”P.L., faute de mieux, approves but thinks we should back up the Government for the millions they have knocked off in taxes since they came to office. Tenniel suggests Lord John wanting to know why there's no dinner – and M.L. accepts this “Write a dispatch to Quartermaine” [Punch, 48 (8 July 1865): 265, “Business Before Pleasure”].

P.L. says such music as Handel's and Beethoven's and Mozart's and Weber's lifts one's nose from the grindstone and clears one's mind of all the mundane worries that so weary it. Such music seems to be a breath from heaven and a proof that there are higher pleasures there awaiting us than those of this poor sensual clay. He was charmed the other evening with Cherubini's Medea.
Luigi Cherubini (1760-1842) is best remembered for his sensational opera Medea, written in 1797 and based on the play by Euripides. Its first British performance was at Her Majesty’s Theatre on June 6, 1865, with Therese Tietjens in the title role.
Tomorrow with Clem at the Worshipful Co. of the Fishmongers.

div.head: July 4, 1865. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.E., H.M.. W.B.
The Beanfeast or Waygoose at Southend next Saturday – so we dine on Tuesday.

L.C. The Chancellor's resignation, of course, the subject.
The resignation was due to a scandal involving the Leeds Bankruptcy Registry, and followed a vote of censure in the House of Commons. See Times leaders beginning with July 4, 1865, p. 7. We agree not to kick him now he's down – indeed it's questionable if he be much worse than most. See the smash for Chelmsford tonight – swears he never wrote, indeed proves he could not have written the letter Granville produces. Shirley suggests Bacon condoling with Bethel – “The character of this Bacon is a little streaky,” quotes Mark from Gil à Beckett. [Punch, 49 (15 July 1865): 17, “Bacon and Bethell”]. We talk of various subjects – the hot weather included – and when the rest have left, Mark and J.T. and D.M. and I go to the Temple and see a fire in Southwark. Very fine is the glare on the Temple tops and the bright flame leaping high into the clear blue moonlit sky. — Handel exorcised my blue devils. Can eat 3 good dinners running and feel the better for them. Monday C[rystal] P[alace] (to the Swiss Trio), Tuesday Punch – Wednesday Tom Cobb's.

M.L. waxeth warm on the Malthus and Mill notion of Limited Pokeability. Says his children are his chief comforts. And how dare a man say he knows he can't feed more than four. – And the four may all die, and the fifth may be a Shakespeare. S.B. per contra on the Selfishness of Snobs in getting children for the State to maintain.

div.head: July 12, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., (M.L. and S.B. at 9), W.B., C.K., H.M.

Mark and Shirley at Boston canvassing for Parry of the Illustrated News.
Thomas Parry, chairman of the Boston, Sleaford, and Nottingham Railway, assisted Mrs. Ingram in managing the ILN after Herbert Ingram’s death. He ran as a Liberal against incumbent Meaburn Staniland, also a Liberal. See Times June 16, 1865, p. 12. Parry was narrowly elected, but the result was overturned on petition in 1866 and he was unseated in favor of Staniland. By the way, I met Sam Read on Monday: he was in the river “covered with mud and blood” in the Staplehurst accident – escaped unhurt, man killed by his side – nerves unshaken. No time to think – 3 bumps and a smash. Dickens' carriage kept on the line. Sam got £20 for his ducking.
Samuel Read (1815-1883), painter and illustrator, worked for the Illustrated London News. The Staplehurst accident of June 9, 1865, in which the train from Folkestone to London derailed at a viaduct that was under construction, killed ten and injured 49 passengers. The accident is remembered today because Charles Dickens was in one of the first-class carriages (the only first-class carriage not to derail and plunge into the river), accompanied by his mistress, Ellen Ternan, and her mother. Ellen suffered an injury to her arm and side that, according to the researches of Katharine Longley (“A Pardoner’s Tale,” unpublished PhD. Thesis, Senate House Library), troubled her for the rest of her life. The South Eastern Railway company paid out over £70,000 in compensation for victims of the accident.

We tyroes try our brains at the Big Cut but don't do much more than hit on a few titles – “Conservative Reaction,” says Ponny: Liberals coming in everywhere. Pam springing up the stronger for going to the country – like the old Hero and his mother Earth (H.S.) Punch congratulating Pam on his improved looks from his rustication (H.S.). Punch contributors chairing their member Mr. Punch (W.B.). But in come Mark and Shirley and the latter says “Waiting for the Verdict” which we accept. [Punch, 49 (22 July 1865): 27, “Waiting for the Verdict”]

Miss Muloch while at Hampstead nursed a Scotchman so tenderly that, meeting her again, he proposed and got a “Yes” from her. Now they are married and he is to be partner with McMillan. There's a bit of real romance.
George Lillie Craik of Glasgow was a nephew of the famous historian, who was a longtime friend of novelist Dinah Mulock (1826-1887). Sometime in the early 1860s he was severely injured in a railway accident and was nursed back to health by Mulock, eleven years his senior, at her home, “Wildwood,” a cottage near Hampstead. They married on April 29, 1865, in Bath, and moved to Glasgow. In Dinah Mulock Craik (New York: Twain, 1983) Sally Mitchell notes the “wide circulation” of this story. See also Karen Bourrier, Victorian Bestseller: The Life of Dinah Craik (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 2019). A number of newspapers at the time mis-reported that her marriage was to Professor Craik, the groom’s uncle of the same name. As Silver reports, G. L. Craik became a partner with Alexander Macmillan in 1865.

Glad Smith, the Newspaper Monopolist, did not come in for Westminster yesterday – and that Mill did.
Conservative William Henry Smith, who worked with his father in what had become the ubiquitous railway bookstall firm of W. H. Smith, was in 1865 defeated by John Stuart Mill, who entered Parliament as the Liberal member for Westminster. Smith defeated Mill three years later, in 1868. Also glad that Cox is kicked out of Finsbury today.
William Cox, Conservative M.P. of Finsbury since 1857, had threatened to bring an action for libel against Punch; he was defeated by Irish Liberal William McCullagh Torrens, who held the seat until 1885. On dit Smith spends £20000. Last week Shirley suggested Seeing the Animals: or Sunday at the Zoological – lot of pretty women. M.L. had thought of it for the Pocket Book.

div.head: July 19, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at White Hill – the Gillespy picnic. J.G. CD (hieroglyphic)

div.head: July 26, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., J.T., M.L., F.C.B., C.K., W.B.

H.S. from Eastbourne – pulled to Beaches[?] yesterday, and ready for Oxford next Saturday. F.C.B. from Felixstowe and Cromer and Lowestoft – chaffs D.M. about expecting to get to Felixstowe for 1/6- describes funnily the difficulties of reaching Felixstowe etc. etc.

L.C. Shirley who is dining with Frith and going to the Royal Academy Swarry suggests Dizzy the Arithmetician, or Cheap Jack, puzzling the Bumpkins with his election sum – “takes 270 from 320 and what remains of their majority? Pam! ... Or why not show the Tories thanking America and Bright for the “Conservative Reaction” they have caused. M.L. thinks with F.C.B. that the Atlantic Cable should be noticed somehow – the Great Eastern started on Monday – and C.K. suggests Neptune and Mermaids, “Don't swing on that 'ere cable – that's how the last was broke!” – The Lay of the Last Cable, says H.S., and suggests very fat mermaid falling off ... Mermaid in crinoline, eh?
The 1865 the Atlantic Telegraph Expedition ended in failure on July 31 when the cable broke as it was being laid. An attempt the following year at last succceeded. [Punch, 49 (5 August 1865): 47, “A Word to the Mermaids”].

div.head: August 2, 1865 W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., S.B., P.L., W.B., C.K., H.M., F.C.B.

Mark preparing his boy Mark for India – is to join Sherard Osborn on the Peninsula Railway. So we drink to the father and wish his son success. “Mark will be crying all next week,” says Pater. A tender heart he has.

Joyce's man, “Alfred” hanged himself yesterday after eating some toast and taking a cup of tea as usual.
In his diary entry for this date, Shirley Brooks wrote: “At Bouverie St. heard that ‘Alfred’ had yesterday hanged himself. This was a great, sturdy, humble creature, who packed admirably, and whom Joyce used to abuse and be kind to. He loved flowers too. He had a nice wife and 3 or 4 children. Some embezzlement, done by driblets, and amounting to some £4 had been detected, as he must have known it would be, and the clerk had told him that the firm must know it next day. He was depressed at night, but slept well, eat a good breakfast, and then went into the back kitchen, and, I dare say, tied a very safe and adroit knot. I think Joyce's death affected him, as a master's does a dog – and it is suggested that Joyce gave him much beer money, now missed. Poor old Alfred the Packer.” (Morgan Library) “Joyce” was Felix Joyce, B&E’s manager. How could a man breakfast so coolly with such a thought in his head? Shirley thinks a man may kill himself from curiosity – to know what the next world is like. D.M. and S.B. agree that when a man is a confirmed cripple and a bore to himself and everybody he is justified in suicide. F.C.B. and P.L. and J.T. and H.S. and E. and the rest contra. No right to do evil. Murder is taking human life – not simply a fellow creature's. A suicide is a murderer – and a coward. A man must be an atheist and a fool to kill himself. “The fool hath said” etc. How can he tell what good he may do if he keeps alive? What right has he to destroy life which God gives and God alone should take? Shirley says, “But God is too hospitable to turn away an uninvited guest.”

L.C. “We can't illustrate Dr. Pritchard's Execution (for poisoning wife), says P.L.
Dr. Edward William Pritchard (1825-1865) was convicted of murder in the poisoning deaths of his wife and mother-in-law. He was hanged on July 28, 1865, before a crowd estimated at 80,000; this was the last public execution in Glasgow. So what joint is there up? Shirley thinks we should notice the result of the Elections – Dizzy doing a sum showing a majority – (should have been done last week – but then we shouldn't have had the Mermaids and my elegant lines thereanent, which I did when going to Oxford on Friday
“Neptune to the Mermaids,” Punch 49 (5 August 1865): 46.). Diz as Waiter, false reckoning, P.L. Diz as Bobadil, S.B. – Diz as Leporello counting the gains, “In Bucks – 1 in Kidder 1 – In Oxford 1” — P.L. suggests Cattle disease, John Thomas, “My calves ain't diseased I hope.” No, says S.B. they're hay. W.B. suggests “The Rejected Candidates,” group of Cox, Amberley & Co ... F.C.B. suggests Dizzy's Calculating Machine. P.L., the (Diz) Enraged Arithmetician – Punch grinding organ labelled “Press” outside. Amends it to Diz chalking John Bull's door which we accept — and Horace apropos says Jerrold suggested that cut of Russell chalking up “No Popery” [Punch, 49 (12 August 1865): 57, “Dizzy’s Arithmetic”].
This famous Leech cartoon [Punch (22 March 1851) 119 ] is captioned, “This is the boy who chalked up ‘No Popery!’ And then ran away!!!” We talk of our Oxford Pull – and Du Maurier' s Spirits and Transvenalis,” and Tenniel's “Eggs” à posteriori” – and of our drenching at Cookham on Monday. And we talk of Felixstowe – see “London Society” for Burnand's description.
“Where Shall We Go?” London Society, 8 (September 1865), 193-211, where “Flickstow” is Felixstowe. “A Burnand worth two in bush:” (Lee) reflection after 12th tumbler. “Cockney gymnastics,” says H.S., would do and F.C.B. echoes – how to get your muscle up by jumping off omnibus at full speed – getting away from cab without.

Jolly dinner – tho' H.S. has the Wibblewobbles and sticks to chicken and sherry and ODV. Cold on Monday came – just as it did on our trip last year. Says F.C.B., we Catholics want Public Schools opened to us etc. Say S.B. and P.L., you never can be equal to Protestants here while you divide your allegiance between the Pope and the Queen.

div.head: August 9, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.MI., H.S.. F.E., J.T. .L P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.

Burnand only 28 – will be 29 on the 29 November and H.S. yesterday reached the patriarchal age of 37. And maritally has no one to live for but himself. Which is the happier – the overworked or the underworked. How to hit the happy medium. — Tenniel 46! Will H.S. feel as well 9 years hence?

L.C. The Cattle Disease the most important Subject – but we can't make a funny cut of it, twist it how you will. Various small suggestions – H.S. supports poultry farming, Mechi keeps 400 fowls on his 170 acres – but M.L. hits on J. Bull looking at wife's dress, “That's 500 lbs of beef at fifteen pence a pound!”
John Joseph Mechi (1802-1880), entrepreneur, alderman, agricultural reformer, and creator of the model Tiptree Hall Farm in Essex. [Punch, 49 (19 August 1865): 67, “Housekeeping à la Mode, or Food Versus Finery”]

He and Tenniel and F.C.B. with H.S. to Haymarket to see the Hon. Wingfield make a jackass of himself in Ixion.
The Honourable Lewis Strange Wingfield (1842-1891), the son of a viscount, trained for a diplomatic career but chose the theatre instead. He made his stage debut as the goddess Minerva in Burnand’s burlesque, Ixion. Prince and Princess there, so the fools finish with a stave of “God save” etc. Good that Swell's saying of Bulwer apropos of the Literary Guild at Knebworth – “Aw – Bulwer's always having green people – had the Foresters last week!” Fancy Hepworth and the great John Forster on a level with the Foresters!
Atlantic Cable smashed. Neptune notwithstanding. So it is feared at least.

div.head: August 16, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., .DB.
Du Maurier to Felixstowe today. And Fred laid up with gout! Early!

L.C. English fleet at Cherbourg – “Why use shot, if powder keeps them civil?” (S.B.) …Admirals carousing and Peace saying, “May this be the only grape you ever exchange.” (M.L.) — Dialogue between two figureheads as to past and present (C.K.). — “If you are in earnest, why don't you dismantle?” (H.M.) —approved and amended by introducing Punch as sailor (M.L.) – the word “jolly” in the dialogue being delicate for “bloody.” [Punch, 49 (26 August 1865): 77, “The Moral of Cherbourg.”]

S.B. tells of Pitman asking dying friend to order a pair of angel's wings, “And I'll fly you for a sovereign.” Writes letters to friends. More than I do. Tomorrow comes the news of the Great Eastern's arrival.

S.B. quotes Thackeray's, “I'll meet him stern to stern and poop to poop.”
“A New Naval Drama,” Punch, 11 (4 July 1846): 2-3.
The Captain stood at Middlefart:
And his heart did loudly thump,
As he heard the hum of a German bum,
And the boom of a German rump.” (S.B.)

div.head: August 23, 1865. W[ednesday]-. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Ramsay: day of Starvation with Clem and Horace.

div.head: August 30, 1865. W[ednesdaly]. No. 1.
div.p: H.S. at Barmouth, river trip and dine with John and Margaret and Murphy.

div.head: September 5, 1865. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Barmouth – trip to Mrs. George (her beer!) at Tyn y groes [sic] with S. and L. and Aunt HJ and Amelia – thinking we should dine at No. 11 tomorrow. Lucky I got the Dinner Note on my return to chops and duck and apple pudding at 7:30. So did not go to town till Monday.

div.head: September 12, 1865. T[uesday]. No 11 .
div.p: 11. E.. H.S., F.E., J.T. (late from Bognor), M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K.

H.S. 12 hours' journey from Barmouth yesterday. – D.M. at Felixstowe, S.B. and H.M. at Scarbro'. Capital dinner, game soup, red mullet, boiled beef, grouse! plum pie, peaches and grapes. Had a seaside appetite. Day of sandwiches and biscuits yesterday. Talk of Manxland and Wales. Pater and Mark and Ben Webster went to Llangollen together. And met such a nice girl that Pater regretted he didn't pursue her acquaintance and pop the question. Welsh friends inside the coach smashed the Sassenach's hats.

L.C. Mark suggests Mr. Punch unveiling Statue of Queen in her Court Robes to show Queen in mourning – apropos of the latter's trip to Coburg lately to “inaugurate” another Statue to the “Great and Good.” C.K. thinks the widow's weeds should be omitted – but then t’would seem as though the Queen were dead. Nor would it do to have Statue alone, as J.T. suggests. Mark hunts up Winter's Tale and finds a fit line – “'Tis time, descend: be stone no more.” M.L. proposes to leave out last 4 words, but H.S. objects that this would hint at dethronement. So the title is left for tomorrow's considering. [ Punch, 49 (23 September 1865): 117, “Queen Hermione.”] Burnand suggests Englishman asking Prussian “How is the Queen? – You've seen more of her lately than we have.” But this is too social. (H.S. to Stanwick tomorrow. ... Very hot in town last week. 75° today).

div.head: September 20, 1865. W[ednesday] . No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Stanwick. Dines with Murphy today. Sweltering shooting. N.B. Only E., F.E., M.L. and W.B. present.

div.head: September 27, 1865. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: H.S. at Stanwick. Tomorrow to Waresley. Gathering of the Watson tribe. And advent of a thoroughbred filly.

div.head: October 4, 1865. No. 11.
div.p: H. S. at Waresley. Drinks to the New Comer in '34 port as black as her hair is.

div.head: October 11, 1865. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: E. , D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L. , H.M., W.B., T.T.

H.S. from Waresley today. – “Thou shalt not covet thy cousin's house!” nor his cellar, nor his stud. S.B. from Scotland yesterday. H.M. from Scarbro’ today. T.T. from Durham and York. D.M. from Felixstowe last Wednesday.

T.T. tells of Vivier
Eugène Vivier (1821-1900) French horn-player, equally renowned for his practical jokes and powers of mimicry. See the affectionate profile by H. Sutherland Edwards in Musical Times, February 1, 1895, pp. 87-89 as well as Janet Ross’s account of Tom Taylor bringing Vivier to lunch (Ross, The Fourth Generation: Reminiscences [London: Constable, 1912], pp. 33-35). putting on barber's wig and asking to have hair cut – also pretending to be deaf and using a lot of cards to tell his story to a passerby. Also, stopping country man and using signs to express himself, makes him use signs, too. Also, paying at cafés etc. for old gentleman – and saying to shopgirl “Did he call you a —” Also, box of vipers[?] at Custom House – sneezes before official and makes a bell tinkle as he blows his nose. Explains it's natural to him – Also, wire across Place – “N'allez pas au theâtre” to see Tom Thumb.

D.M. wants to see Chang the Giant – admires big men. “If I were 10 feet high, I'd kill 20 prizefighters” à la Bobadil. ... Talks of Balzac and his beastliness. S.B. lets off a lot of smut. What tempts men to talk it so?

L.C. Spain? – Austria? – Who cares for foreign politics in the Vacation? Cattle disease the subject – but can't touch it. P.L. suggests a slap at the Cattle doctors who squabble and can't cure. – T.T. says the Lord Lieut. Wodehouse told him that the Fenians were more formidable than we fancy – if a Fenian ship came, thousands would be up in arms. H.S. thinks the landowners have frightened him. But agrees that the offense is too serious to be laughed at. S.B. suggests John Bull pointing to Sepoy blown from gun, “That's what you'll come to” – or saying to Mother Ireland, “If whipping don't cure your boy, we must try confinement” pointing to prison cell: or saying, “I'll have no row in the nursery – if you can't manage to keep the boys quiet, I must.” M.L. and H.S. & Co. object to identifying the mass of Irish with the movement, as T.T. thinks the case is. Prince of Wales going over as the New Saint Patrick seems a good notion. Fenian reptiles vanishing before him. Suggested last week, but the Merry Swiss Boy and Return of the Tourist thought preferable. — S.B. thinks that the Priests should be commended for condemning Fenianism and P.L. suggests Fenian in the stocks with Priest looking on and saying, “They'd better stay there till they're sober,” [Punch, 49 (7 October 1865): 137, “The Re-United States.”].

N.B. “The London Limited” won't do after Waresley cookery – nor does the claret of No. 11 equal the Waresley '47 port. Oh that smooth silky '46 too! Cream of the Cellar it will be – nay, is. A pint a day since Thursday week I've had and a capital mutton chop to follow at breakfast. Then the Croquet Tournament. N. B. Weighed 10.11 last Thursday at Tenbury.

div.head: October 17, 1865. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., C[harles] Bennett.

H.S. from Woodbridge today – saw old Frost at the Ferry on Saturday after a warm bathe), “that 'ere Mr. Dumorrier is a niceish young chap. He do drawings for the London Journal – hain't you sin 'em?” D.M. lunched at Bob Young's – with Dr. Smith & Co. H.M. showeth the Lancet of July anent the young Spaniard with 2 – “duplices tendens ad sidera penes,” saith Leigh.
D.M. admireth Chang the Giant – 7.8 high and well- proportioned. Only 19.

We make the new French experiment of lighting a small cone, inch high, of some mercurial preparation and out cometh a snakelike substance, twisting about in coils – greyish in colour and clammy to feel – “Pharaoh's Serpents.”

L.C. Seward's demand for compensation of Alabama damage. S.B. suggests Britannia saying to Columbia. Two Widows – wouldn't do. Bennett suggests John clapping finger to his nose. “I wouldn't be mean about money matters – I've had my losses too through your war” ... accepted, C.K. and H.S. protesting that the “set off” is not a fair one. [Punch, 49 (28 October 1865): 167, “The Disputed Account”]

div.head: October 21, 1865. Saturday. The Bedford.
div.p:
 [drawing of pointing hand] Lord Palmerston died on Wednesday last. Shirley his monodist.
Brooks’s obituary poem, “Palmerston,” appeared in Punch, 49 (28 October 1865): 163, inside a black border. Brooks recorded in his diary entry for November 4, 1865, that popular London preacher J.C.M. Bellew told him of having read these lines on Palmerston aloud to a crowd in Bristol and that they were “the best things that were ever in Punch!” (Morgan Library). Perhaps on the strength of this poem, Brooks was commissioned to write a memoir of Palmerston for the Illustrated London News 47 (4 November 1865) 446, for which, according to his diary entry for October 31, he was paid 17 guineas (Morgan Library).
S.B., D.M., H.S., Bennett, J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., T T.

H.S. from Woodbridge ce matin and Acis at the C[rystal] P[alace] – “Grove on a pun sits panting ... to set the Thames on fire.” I reply to his “Thou trusty Pyne I (Harrison) lay thee by.” “That joke would almost do for a burlesque,” saith D.M. “Yes, I think it would do for it,” saith Burnand. Very ready is his tongue – and his brains suggestive: Brings out a packet of notions for cuts—
1. X Competitive Examination for Kings and Queens. Twelfth Night characters – fun marred by old fogy Examiner Cramchild ... Would do politically also.
2. Croquet – “The Rover is free.” Lot of pretty girls, Mr. Punch the Rover. H.S. suggests a wooden legged player croqueting. D.M. suggests lots of old fogies playing.

3. Hunting. Miss Di Dash, “Let's take this fence, Mr. Titmouse – such fun to get away from Papa.” – Tit- mouse funks. M.L. suggests girl riding off with Swell, and father panting after them. Julia: “I couldn't stop him, Papa.”
4. Chamber of Horrors - little boy falls asleep and wakes frightened at Tussaud's.
5. X Underground Railway – tunnelling into wine cellar. C.K. amends into stoker stopping at your cellar to take in coals.
6. Oily City. Sketches of Oily Gammon & Co., Saints. After “Oil City” – letters in Times.
7. Jibbing horse – refusing to pass – “It's only her affectation.”
8. Excursion trains. But S.B. suggests Alpine ascents vulgarised – even the servants go up Mont Blanc now, saith H.S. – And Bennett is doing Cooke's all the world round trip.

9. X Ladies voting. T.T. suggests their fighting and call it, “Mill on Female Suffrage.” T.T. amends to “Vote for Bodger and 9 children.” Bodger a good name, saith F.C.B. “Miscarriage provided for Lady Voters,” S.B.
10. X Ladies College. Sweet girl graduates with golden hair.
11. Oxford Spinsters challenge the Cambridge Donnas: Rowing women.
12. X Lady Doctors – “Affection of the heart – remedy Marriage.” Brave Burnand! “What a brain this young man has,” S.B.
P.L. suggests Vegetarian Lord Mayor's feast: apropos of Cattle disease.
X T.T. suggests Golden Hair Dye – pretty dark girl and and hairdresser. “Make me like her.”
T.T. suggests boy making chemical experiments – ending in a blowup: apropos of Patent Safety Gunpowder.
X T.T. suggests Mermaids staring at Diver's goggle eyes, looking for Atlantic Cable.
T.T. suggests Tumbledown houses. Cheap building.
X accepted. Some other suggestions I forget. Can't read my pencillings under the table. But we agree that we've spent a very profitable evening X. Mark very jolly. D.M. singeth at the piano.

X especially as we settle the Big Cut also. C.K. suggesting Lord John as Butler, I can write a good hand. Altered by Mark to fit Lord J. and Clarendon. [Punch, 49 (4 November 1865): 176, “The New Foreign Secretary” ]

div.head: October 25, 1865. W[ednesday]. No Dinner.
div.p: H.S. to Church Street tomorrow and so misseth Shirley's haunch of venison

div.head: November 1, 1865. W[ednesday]. At the Albion.
div.p: H.S. from Woodbridge & Frimley.

Dinner to the New Firm of Bradbury, Evans & Co.
Shirley Brooks's diary for this date gives the following account: “Whitefriars, and to the Albion, to a dinner given as a sort of inauguration of the new firm, and the introduction of the Agnews. It was what Bunsby would call a howling good dinner. All the staff, the 4 B. & E.'s and 3 Agnews (not T. Taylor, who pleaded illness). I will set the array, as it may not be gathered again in a hurry. B. made a long speech, commending the sons to the friendship of the Punch men. Evans said that the history of B. & E. had begun, continued, and ended in mistakes, but now all was to go right. M. L. spoke very well and with an intention that a non-interference policy must be adhered to. I proposed 'The Ladies,' and Horace replied.
F.M.E.
M.L. Leigh
J. Tenniel Burnand
Thos. Agnew Agnew
S.B. T. T. should have been here
Fred W. Bradbury
Silver Keene
J. H. Agnew Bennett
Du Maurier Horace M
.
Bradbury
After Mark had sung 'Cupid's Garden,' and while du Maurier was on a French song, I left, and dashed home in a hansom, but the bulk of the party stayed late.” [Houghton Library]
B. d.M., John Henry Agnew, H.S., F.E., S.B., Tom Agnew, J.T., M.L. E., P.L., Wm. Agnew, F.C.B., C.K., W.B., Bennett, H.M.
Capital turtle, scented Sauterne, good Mazarine de perdreaux and superlative iced Soufflé. And doth not a dinner like this make amends for leaving old Woodbridge, relations and friends?
“Granville, what d'ye think they're playing at the Haymarket?”“Three weeks after Marriage,” and “Used Up,” (S.B. reporteth).

B. on his legs – seems like old times. Has only dined once with us (last June) since 1862: and oddly enough D.M. was away that once. B. and E. getting old, have put their sons in their stead and taken the Agnews into partnership. So we drink success to B. E. & Co. upstanding and with cheers which Mark leadeth. W.B. and Fred return thanks – and hope the new era will only follow out the old. (No cheques from Smith Payne of late — they pay in cash and bank at Manchester.) Then Mark feelingly proposes the health of B. & E. who have weathered so many storms and brought their ship into harbour successfully at last. Mark has spoken plainly at times anent Punch to its proprietors, and intends to do so still. Men work well together, because they are liberally treated. Thought our loss last year would seriously have affected Punch — but it did not. And no single loss will. Feels proud of his 25 years' old: thinks it has done good. B. endorses this and speaks to the brotherly affection between Mark and B. and E. Says if you want men to serve you well, treat them well, and win their sympathy and esteem (hear! from H.S.). — E. emphatic on the Brotherhood of Punch table. Says he and B. began by making mistakes – went on making mistakes, and have ended with mistakes. Nevertheless the acorn of their business is now a goodly oak. Hope the new firm will profit by the errors of the old. And avoid Daily Newses.
See note under entry for January 25, 1860, about the firm's disastrous investment in the founding of the Daily News.

B. proposes the health of Mark who thanks us with tears in his eyes. Shirley: “Please fill your glasses, gentlemen. and when you have done so, I will continue the oration I have commenced.” ... So proposes the Health of “Nearest and Dearest”: Every man likes to have some one to care for and likes that somebody to be not of his own sex. ... Horace returns thanks humourously. regretting that a husband was not asked to do justice to the toast. ... Then B. goes and cigars come and D.M. sings “Je n'ai que vingt quat' sous”. And H.M. sings Thackeray's “Mahogany Tree.” And W.B. sings “Time is on the Wing.” And J.T. sings “The Spanish Ladies.” And M.L. sings “Cupid's Garden” And H.S. sings “Beautiful Kitty.” And C.K. sings “The 3 Ravens” and Bennett sings “Widow Machree.” And Burnand sings “The Whale,” improving funnily in this fashion: “O 'twas in the Northern seas Where the water it do freeze And the wind it very often blows a ga-ale, We rigged our good ship out And we sailed with hearts so stout All for to go and catch a whale Brave boys! All for to go and catch a whale ... We'd a captain and a mate Who roast pork for supper ate, He preferred a pig with curly tail, And we'd a little cabin boy who to his mother said “Ahoy, I'm going for to catch” etc.

Then our captain says, says he Through my spyglass I can see A shoal of fish ahead There I'll go ba-ail: So bring your cutlasses/magazines and guns and shot Weighing hundreds of puns And we will go etc. And so forth and so forth, we supplying rhymes such as ale–pale, seakale – rail – snail etc. And imaginary shipmates down to the friend of the captain’s who happened to be on board.

Then F.C.B. also singeth a song with no words to speak of to the tune of John Jones was a Farmer – Tolderol, lolderol, lolderol lay. Moral: “Now all you young fellows who're fond of flirtation Never go with a girl who is a ation, Or you'll find out too late she is given to negation. Folderol etc.” So we pass a jolly evening and bear in mind Pater's remark that sociality is the secret of the success of Punch.— Says he owes to his Punch friends some of the happiest days in his life. And so say we all of us...

Mark saith, “My friend, Mr. William Agnew, agrees with me that the Sherry at Bouverie Street is beastly – so in future he will take care of that department. And Mr. Thomas Agnew will edit the cigars – so we may expect improvement therein.” Lustrum is five years, says Shirley. – Leave off the lust and take to the rum, Horace. .. Walk home and thereabout till 1 to avoid dyspepsia.

div.head: November 8, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Pocket books given out. Not published till the 10th.
E., D.M., H.S., F.E. S.B., J. T, M. L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M. champ.
First invitation signed by “B. E. & Co.” received at Woodbridge: whence H.S. today.

L.C. P.L. suggests Gladstone waltzing with Minerva, apropos of his Greek speech at Edinburgh. – But the price of Meat is the subject, says Mark. S.B. suggests Mrs. Blowflies Gorgeous, “Now B. the carriage is at the door. Never mind them customers.” — poor widow etc. too poor to buy as much meat as they want. H.M. suggests Butcher calling on Lady to purchase her horses, which she gives up on account of dearness of meat. But C.K. suggests “The Demon Butcher” – the real Rinderpest. Accepted. [Punch, 49 (18 November 1865): 199, “The Demon Butcher, or the Real Rinderpest.”]

C.K. says the Charivari depicts the Unicorn away from our Queen's arms – sick with the Rinderpest. — C.K., “You go to the Opera with orders, don't you?” F.C.B., “Orders?” – Yes. – You mean in my buttonhole – stars and garters and things. Bravo B. Ten times readier with thy tongue than S.
Apropos of the Yellow Hair mania, D.M. suggests sketch of the Future – all the girls either grey or bald.

div.head: November 15, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Tom Sayers buried today. Cheap press compares him to Duke of Wellington! ! Not like him nasally, anyhow.
E., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B., T.T.

T.T. praises Jefferson for his naturalness in Rip Van Winkle – acted Asa Trenchard and made it, as it should be, the prominent character.
American actor Joseph Jefferson (1829-1905) toured widely in Rip Van Winkle, the role for which he was best known, living long enough to have reprised the role in several silent films. Asa Trenchard played the title role in Tom Taylor’s Our American Cousin; Taylor’s remark here reflects his disapproval of the way in which E. A. Sothern’s elaboration of the role of Lord Dundreary upstaged Jefferson.

Wilkie Collins's “deaf friend” was behind F.C.B. at the Watchcry.
The Watch-Cry, a drama in three acts adapted from the French by Palgrave Simpson, played at the Lyceum beginning November 8, 1865, with Charles Fechter in the lead role as Leone Salviati, a man unable to speak. The magazine ran a parody, Punch 48 (18 November 1865) 196-197, possibly by Arthur Sketchley.

L. C. Shirley writes to suggest Duke of Somerset leaving Admiralty to play Capt. Absolute at the Horse Guards – altered by T.T. into Rehearsing for The Rivals: “Duke of Cambridge – You're to play Capt. A., are you – then I suppose I'm to play Fag!” .. PL. objects to its obscurity.
Brooks, who was obliged by gout to stay at home, noted in his diary, “Also sent a very good cut, but they did not see it – a cut recommended in writing is never adopted, I think.”

T.T. suggests Russell as Cabinet Maker saying to Queen: Your Cabinet will be ready by February ... Old joke, we chorus: and revert to The Rivals. Queen, Mrs. Malaprop, says F.C.B, “with a nice derangement of epitaphs,” adds P.L. – Then T.T. suggests Bright sulky, “None of them ask me!” – amends it to Bright as young Lady Wallflower – accepted with acclamation. Russell asking Goschen – “Won't you join our Set?” J.T. [Punch, 49 (25 November 1865): 209, “The Political Wall-Flower”].
T.T. to Othello at – the City! And H.S. to King John at Drury. Which is the heaviest? ... D.M. funky about his eye. Give up smoke. Mrs. Edmund Yates has dyed her hair yellow! Ground for a divorce.

div.head: November 22, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., T.T., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., W.B., Bennett.

H.S. from Woodbridge this morning – after Glenham “Beauty and the Beast” and Trimley. Shirley clamours for turkey before “all these new fellows” who get the best bits. He amuses us by a scene from a supposed drama of serious interest, “The Virtuous Costermonger” taught by his genteel wife and boy to say “Asparagus” instead of “Yah Sparrergrass!” – “See how the softening influence of Holy Love” etc. S.B. hates domestic dramas, likes to hear ladies and gentlemen talk smart on the stage. Congreve preferable to Porter's knot.

L.C. The Oxford Bread and butter question – P.L., Oliver asking for more.
An appeal from Oxford undergraduates to the Dean of Christ Church for relief from excessive charges was published in the Times (November 11, p. 9) and led to letters and leaders. Dean upset on Butter Slide (P.L.) – used in Fun next week!
“Assault and Buttery: How the Undergraduates Upset the dons on a (Bread and) Butter-Slide,” Fun 2 n.s. (2 December 1865) 115. Dean cutting bread and butter – butcher condoling with him, “These letters in the newspapers about you and me, Sir, is werry low.” P.L. thought of this combination of grievances, but T.T. put it in shape by his “Werry low” and Shirley gives a title, “The Dean and Chopper,” accepted. [Punch, 49 (2 December 1865): 219, “Dean and Chopper”] … We agree that the Jamaica revolt is too revolting. Fun had a pleasant picture this week thereanent. Grim that word looks, “Fun,” atop of such cuts.
See full-page cut in Fun 2 n.s. (18 November 1865): 105 of laughing Jamaican rebel with torch and sword, dead women and children at his feet and homes burning in the background. Horace pulls out papers from his inexhaustible pocket as usual. We agree that the bad spelling is the blot of Artemus Ward. Very quaint is his saying: “The forte of Washington is to have nobody like him at present.”

div.head: November 29, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., 0 .S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B., and Bennett.

Once a Week Christmas No. presented to us. H.S. twice advertised as contributing. Fanny buys a copy therefore. So you see What's in a name!
H. Silver, “Some Christmas Thoughts on Cookery,” Christmas Number of Once a Week (1 December 1865), 72-73.

We drink Lemon's health whose birthday is tomorrow – and Amy, Fred's wife whose birthday is on Friday the 1st, as is Alexandra's – and Wm . B's whose birthday is next Sunday. Shirley takes note of all our birthdays and says he'll stick them in the Almanack next year.

L.C. S.B. suggests Bright furious at Government Enquiry about Voting – “Who vouches for Workingman's fitness?” – “I do.” – “But who vouches for you?” Accepted: but words altered, because of Bright's speech tomorrow – wherein he clamours against Eyre and the Jamaica “murderers” but says he'll support Government. [Punch, 49 (9 December 1865): 229, “John Slow and John Fast”]
Governor Edward John Eyre’s brutal repression of the Morant Bay rebellion in Jamaica in October 1865 polarized Britain’s ruling and literary elites. After a Royal Commission investigation, Eyre was removed from his post and recalled to Britain but the efforts of the Jamaica Committee led by John Stuart Mill failed to secure an indictment of Eyre for murder and abuse of power. There is an extensive scholarly literature about the case, but a good summary can be found in Catherine Hall, “The Economy of Intellectual Prestige: Thomas Carlyle, John Stuart Mill, and the Case of Goveror Eyre,” Cultural Critique 12 (Spring, 1989) 167-196.

Great Debate. M.L. and Bennett stick up for the Working Man. S.B. and P.L. contra. Latter mildly. Says workers are not uncomfortable and don't feel any grievance which a vote would redress. S.B. says the working men have few taxes, if indirect taxation, should have indirect representation.
Shirley Brooks, in a diary entry of this date, notes, “The cut was my suggestion – we had then a long Reform debate, in which Bennett took part, and spoke sensibly against me.”

S.B.'s nightmare – swimming in a sea of butter. Bennett's – having to tie a parcel and cutting string into 100 bits, none of right length. H.M. calls the Haymarket the “terra anonyma.” Bravo! Shirley asks me to dine with him and the Jerrolds and Yates' tomorrow – first time of vivâ voce invitation, in the manner of dear Leech. Fred asks me to Brighton on Friday. And a jolly blow we have. Tenniel comes.

div.head: December 6, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p:
Almanack published 8th. H.S. at Tiptree Hall: to see Louisa Mechi marry Morley Farrow.
William Morley Farrow (1839-1877), novelist, married Louisa Mechi, daughter of John Joseph Mechi, London alderman and agricultural reformer. Tiptree Hall was Mechi's country home and model farm. And to return thanks eloquently “as one of the bridesmaids.”

div.head: December 13, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 1
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., J. Agnew, J.T., M.L., P.L., T.T., H.M., W.B., T. Agnew. champ.

First time the Agnews have dined in my presence at No. 11. So we drink some special dry sherry and have a specially good feed. Hare soup and smelt and goose and woodcock! ... Storks gone to replace Eyre – “See here he comes with Marshall Storks.”
Henry Knight Storks (1811-1874), who had been sent ot investigate the rebellion, was appointed governor on December 12, 1865, and served until July 16, 1866.

L.C. M.L. suggests Exeter Hall maniac hugging a Nigger, and a White Jamaican man saying, “But ain't I a man and a brother, too?” – “The Jamaican Question,” H.S.
The Times leader for December 12 used the phrase “men and brothers” with respect to the Jamaica controversy, warning against “excessive tenderheartness”; the leader for the following day condemned those who would “prejudge” Governor Eyre. [Punch, 49 (23 December 1865): 249, “The Jamaica Question”]

Stage anecdotes. T.T. tells of property man correcting the inscription alphabetically into P.Q.R.S. — Macready manager! Also of his saying to fat page (in Richelieu), “Where do you mean to put that? (his stomach)” also of his swearing at Carpenter, “Draw the curtains (Othello).” Also his entering with candles blown out in Macbeth.

div.head: December 20, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: D.M., H.S., Bennett, S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F. B., H.M., W.B., T.T.
H.S. from Seckford Street today – actually at “'Set Fair”: first dry week since Oct. 7.

L.C. M.L. suggests Punch as clown with red poker, Bright and Dizzy and all running away frightened. T.T. suggests Louis Napoleon saying, “Whom shall I touch up next?” Bennett suggests Bright, in much the same position. T.T. amends to Bright as Clown to Russell holding Reform Baby, – “Allow me to feed it” – big spoon marked Democracy behind back (accepted.) [Punch, 49 (30 December 1865): 259, “Scene from St. Stephen’s Pantomime”]. While the Great Cut is being hatched, Burnand, Du Maurier and Silver make a little cut of their initials on the Punch table. H.S. between W.M.T. and J.L. Burnand where A Beckett sat and D.M. where Leech.- Roman Catholic jaw about Absolution. Forgiving the offence does not imply forgiving the punishment, F.C.B.

Pater thinks with me that wrongdoing is punished in this life. D.. contra: cites instance of a healthy blackguard he knew who seduced his friends' wives and retained their friendship and never was ill. But who can tell if he was happy? D.M. believes in God – and that whatever we do, God will not punish us. A comfortable faith. I believe in Conscience also – and that Conscience in this life is a keen punisher.

Burnand grieves that he has not made £1000 by Ixion which took him a fortnight to write. Intends in future to write only on condition of sharing profits with the manager. – Wants to go to Rome. Will I go?
M.L. drinks our Christmas welfare. As Rip Van Winkle says, “Here's your goot health and your Vamily's. May they live long and prosper!”

Miss Bateman retires from the Stage (at Her Majesty's) on Friday. She has rather proved herself a one-part actress. And so has Sothern whom Burnand denounces as a practical joker – most unscrupulous in tongue. D.M. thinks it harder to write a poem than to paint a picture. But surely there's no comparing them. One mind expresses itself with a pen and another with a brush.

div.head: December 27, 1865. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Church Street – the three Reeds expected come tomorrow. Orridge d. 28th.

div.head: January 3. 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Church Street. Shoot at Cavell's with Horace. “Best day I've had for 15 months.”

div.head: January 10, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. from Winchester – anent Dr. Heale. Dine with the Park Lane four at Ben Head's. Get home just in time to escape the Great Snowstorm which festoons the streets with the telegraph wires and makes the Hansom cabs drive tandem. Sudden come sudden go. All melted before Sunday.

div.head: January 17, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., Bennett, F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., E.B., T.T.
The whole Eleven and 3 Proprietors.

Pleasant to see Silver again, says Ponny .. to whom I talk anent Yankeeland. He says Niagara grows on you the more you stay there. Bright clear water and a cloud of spray. But there's nothing else worth seeing. Cities dull and commonplace, and country ugly.

D.M. tells me of the gas blow-up at his 91 Great Russell Street on Boxing Day.
The gas explosion at the premises of A. P. Pears, perfumer, blew all of the shop windows into the street, knocking down a woman and two men, who were not seriously injured (Pall Mall Gazette, December 27, 1865, p. 6.) Girl dressing in the shop for the Hairdressers' ball - turned on 2 burners and lit one, and left it burning! D.M. and wife dressing on top floor. Bang! Like a 100 pounder and then rattle-smash-crash. “O the children!” … “Dn it! They're all right!” first time he ever swore before his wife. Sister tried to jump from window, but Armstrong held her back. Baby crowing in his arms at the fun as he came downstairs. The nursemaids had run away of course. Lucky no one on the stairs or they'd have been killed. ... On Xmas eve, D.M. was awaked by a row on roof – caught up the poker – saw 2 men looking over the parapet, “We're the police!” Very nearly in his champagning pitched into them. Dutch courage.
Tenniel, Mark and the Professor all growing moustaches! Les trois Moustachequetaires!

Burnand says Greenwood, brother of the Pall Mall Gazette Editor, wrote “A Night in a Workhouse.” ... They'll look out for swells in the Casual Wards now, I reckon. Ugh! that bath of mutton broth! And that blood on the blanket! Had a sodomite taken a maidenhead?
T.T. suggests for the Big Cut: Russell shivering in his rug – “Companions of the Bath” – apropos of the inspection Sir Geo. Grey has been making since the article appeared.

P.L. suggests High price of Meat. But Shirley, “Let's do an English glorification cut about the Bulldog. Punch returning the Captain his Sword.” Plucky fellow, tho' he did lose his ship.
The H.M.S. Bulldog, a sloop commanded by Captain Charles Wake, ran aground in Haiti while in pursuit of insurgents but kept firing and sank the rebel steamer; after abandoning ship, Wake ordered the ship burned, and shortly thereafter it blew up. At a court martial, he was severely reprimanded for running the ship aground, but was supported by public opinion. The Punch cartoon is a reaction to the court martial verdict, following a Times leader of this date (January 17, p. 8). Wake later rose to the rank of vice-admiral. [Punch, 50 (27 January 1866): 37, “Admiral Punch Does Justice to Captain Wake”] John Breahey, I see, was surgeon on board.

I thought D.M.'s “Tom Tit” rather stupid. But perhaps I'm wrong. Anyhow his sketch of the Punch Eleven (and B. & E. the Umpires) is voted a success: though he can't get Tenniel and myself like. My moustache just appears to Mark's left – Leigh underneath looks like Fred Evans.
Punch 50 (20 January 1866), 32“The Iliad, in a Nutshell” says Shirley. D.M. draws “Our Artists” in profile tonight: and Mark begs the sketch. Bennett lefthanded! Usually draws with his left but not always.

div.head: January 24, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., Bennett, F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., W.B., T.T.
Pater's birthday next Monday – we drink “your goot health and your Vamily's. May they live long and prosper”: à la Rip Van Winkle.

I first taste Canvas back duck today. Sent by Agnew. Capital! But I don't perceive the wild celery flavour. Bigger and browner fleshed than our wild ducks. Burnand says Greenwood, brother of the Editor of the Pall Mall Gazette, wrote the “Night in a Workhouse.” Well done, whoever did it. ... Should be the subject, saith P.L. – and after Bennett has proposed Baby and Maximilian deserted by father Napoleon (apropos of the French evacuating Mexico), and S.B. has suggested President [Johnson] saying to Na., “Get out of them there fixin's,” Tom T. proposes Policeman as the New Workhouse Porter, and cadgers saying, “Here's Centralization for you!” which is accepted [Punch, 50 (3 February 1866) 47, “The New Workhouse Porter”].
Frederick Greenwood’s three-part “A Night in a Workhouse” series detailed the writer’s experiences amid the filth of a Lambeth casual ward; signed “The Amateur Casual,” the articles quickly became the talk of the town, and were instantly reprinted in the Times, and shortly thereafter as a pamphlet (“A Night in a Workhouse,” Pall Mall Gazette, 12 January 1866, 9-10; 13 January 1866, 10; 15 January 1866, 9-10). Punch’s cut appeared with Taylor’s accompanying verses, “Bumble’s Counterblast against Centralization,” Punch (3 February 1866) 46; two weeks later this was followed by “Lays of Lambeth,” Punch (17 February 1866) 66. Mr. Bumble, in Dickens’s Oliver Twist, is the cruel and self-important minor official (“beadle”) in charge of the parish workhouse, hence the usefulness of the character for Punch in representing meddling government bureaucracy. J. W. Robertson Scott, The Story of the Pall Mall Gazette (Westport: Greenwood, 1971), 166-171, discusses the series in the context of the newspaper’s history. For an analysis of the “Amateur Casual” articles that is attentive to these allusions to sodomy and their impact on the series’ reception, see Seth Koven, Slumming: Sexual and Social Politics in Victorian London (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2004).

T.T. says that Sodom allusion doubtless is quite true. We talk of the terrible wreck of the London, and G.V. Brooke, the actor, bravely working at the pumps.
The London, a steamer out of Plymouth bound for Melbourne, foundered in the Bay of Biscay on January 11 and sank with 220 passengers. Shakespearean actor Gustavus Vaughn Brooke refused a space in the last lifeboat, choosing instead to help man the pumps. And S.B. reads Paul Bedford's letter proposing a box at Railways for pennies for the guards and porters. We used to tip the coachmen and why not the brave engine drivers who carry us through flood and thunder. ... Actors always write on stilts. “My honoured father brought me to this vast metropolis.” “If you approve of my Idea, – let the collection be called Paul's Pence.” Apropos of the “Casual” and the horrors he hints at, S.B. says “Sailors won't go to the Bottom if they can help it.” ... “Some mischief still for idle hands to do.”

div.head: January 31, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., Bennett, F.E., J.T., S.B., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B., T.T. champ.
Champagne again to drink Evans' health again. But we don't do it.

P.L. tells his stories about the old Italian-French soldier, Arnati, and his niece, Rrrosalie. “I would have taken a leetle wheep and said, “Bishop, will you confirm Rrrosalie? And if the Bishop rrefused to confirm R'solie, I would have a-horse-a-wheeped him in the Sanctuary of Christ.” ... Also of his complaining of boy, “Domned dirty leetle beest, he peesed in my shoe.”

S.B. says he met Ward one year just before Academy opened and Ward said “No – I shan't exhibit this year – I think we ought to give the young fellows a chance. Besides, I haven't a picture ready.” C.K. says Ward so annoyed a man by his loud responses in Church that he got talked to.

T.T. says Landseer insulted him by promising a Swell to bring T.T. to some dinner party. “I can have as much high society as I please – but I don't care for it. And won't enter it through the backstairs or the water closet.” Says L[andseer] is not an educated man and never can understand the feelings of a gentleman.

L.C. S. B. proposes Russell and Gladstone rowing in one boat and Bright saying, “Let me join you.” Horace suggests Bright as Hansom Cabby, “I'll take you quicker than you'd walk.” T.T. amends it to the Cut accepted – Bright as a Crossing Sweeper, “I'll take anything in the Reform way you'll bestow on me.” [Punch, 50 (10 February 1866) 57, “Going Down to the House”] Dance at Ab. Garrett's last night and at Whitaker's tonight.

div.head: February 7, 1866. _W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B.[Bennett], F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., W.B.
(H.S. dancing at J.W. Smith's last night till 3 and none the worse – all the fresher – good as a Turkish bath. To Ridley's tonight – drive to wrong party first!)

L.C. Opening of Parliament by the Queen yesterday – first time since '61. Pater complains of her not reading the speech – but suppose she had broken down? P.L. suggests Mumbo Jumbo – Dizzy and Co. trying to fright the Government by holding up bull's head apropos of the speeches anent the Cattle Plague. But this would seem to indicate that the Plague was all humbug. M.L. suggests Russell as a Nineveh Bull attacked by Opposition – H.S. suggests Political Bullfight – but it isn't the Bull they're fighting. The House is quarrelling over the carcase. So H.S. amends the hint to “While you dispute, I die,” suggesting for a title, “The Political Cow Doctors.” [Punch, 50 (17 February 1866) 69, “The Political Cow-Doctors”] Fred adds “try united action.”
The cut’s sub-caption is, “The Patient: ‘Oh if they’d only leave off quarreling and just try “united action,” it might be the saving of me.” … Rather new for H.S. to suggest a Big Cut.

We talk of the Oscott trial, “Fitzgerald v. Northcote and Stone.” – Fancy calling it “sin” for a boy to drink a glass of beer at a Public! And what a sneak Stone to read a boy's pocketbook! Such schooling may do abroad, but English boys had better turn Protestant than submit to it.
See the Times, February 6, 1866, p. 10, for a long account of the lawsuit brought by David Fitzgerald, the father of a student at Oscott college, a Roman Catholic school in Birmingham, against the principal (the Rev. James Spencer Northcote) and one of the masters (the Rev. W. Stone) of the college, on account of his son’s punishment and ultimate explusion. The case was brought before Chief Justice Coleridge.
“One of the Pall Mall writers spent a night in a Workhouse.” Lady:- “Poor man! Do they pay them so badly as that!”

div.head: February 14, 1866. W[ednesday]_ No.11.
div.p: W.B.,(Junior, that is. Always now.), D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L, P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., Wm. Agnew, C.H. B.

Ash Wednesday. H.S. from Church Street by Parliament today. One's wits get blunted in the country, and one gets too lazy to talk. “Silver hasn't spoken has he?” says Ponny. “Speech is silver – Silence golden,” says the Professor.

L.C. Shirley suggests Ritualist and Claphamite squabbling of the Prayer Book apropos the row about Vest- ments – and Lord Ebury's Society for altering the Rubric. For a title, Mark suggests “The Battle of the Rubricon” – (But there was no Battle) – [Punch, 50 (24 February 1866): 79, “The Battle of the Rubric”].
F.C.B. tells how if you ask for Fun they hand you a “copy” of Punch.
M.L. says the word “humbug” arose from Somebody betting that he'd invent a word that in a week should be in everyone's mouth. So he chalked “humbug” all over the town, and everyone talked of it.

H.M. says James Greenwood got £10 for each of his 3 Workhouse letters, besides a gift of £20 and a half of the profit of the reprint – some £120 or so more. Would you have taken the bath for that? And walked on those cold stones? It might have given him his death.
H.S. received 2 Valentines and sends none. ... M.L. objects to D.M.'s Frenchy notions of modesty.

div.head: February 21, 1866. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: E. , D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., W.B., Tom Agnew.

Tom Agnew says it's his birthday – at least he hasn't had one for six months. Why does Rose call himself Sketchley – because he don't draw, says Mark.
“Arthur Sketchley” was the pseudonym of George Rose (1817-1882), best known for tales and monologues built around “Mrs. Brown,” a character based in part on Dickens’s Sairey Gamp. Horace noisy – produces a lot of newspapers and letters as usual. A note by Shirley, feigning to come from Frank Matthews enclosing a bit of copy anent Hoare, M.P., his maiden speech.
Sir Henry Hoare’s maiden speech cautioned against excessive widening of the franchise. See Times report, February 10, 1866, p. 7. Horace applauds the Fun cut of John Bull and Peabody
“How to Take a Hint,” Fun, February 24, 1866, p. 234, shows George Peabody, philanthropist, presenting John Bull with a building, with Bull saying, “Well, Mr. Peabody, after your splendid donation, don’t you think it’s my turn to do something for the poor?” – shout of dissent – “Don't praise my work any more,” says Tenniel. “O, I wanted to draw you out. That's all,” says Ponny. “Like the man kicked downstairs saying, 'I wanted to see what your boots were like '“ says Shirley – ever quick at a reply.

Shirley tells of actor missing cue – “The memory of the soldier shall live, though his osier-bound grave doth hold him.” – “Though his father was a Hosier.” Might be said of the Bishop of Lincoln – his father was a hosier, says Pater.

Pater says when a schoolboy he met Peter Rackham and Dizzy who was then an articled Clerk in the City. Pater is 62 so Dizzy must be 67. Don't look it. Horace – “I've been a target for you all the evening.” “But then we've been hitting the gold, my dear Horace,” says Shirley very neatly.
Why not have a birthday daily, asks S.B. The Apostle Paul says, “I die daily.” – “If so, he must be born daily.”

L.C. Shirley proposes a semi-Yankee Irish Bull and a Yankee, “We'll try Isolation, i.e., imprisonment if that won't do, then –” “Stamping out the Fenian Pest,” [ Punch, 50 (3 March 1865): 89, “The Fenian Pest”]. (Habeas Corpus Act passed on Saturday – sent to the Queen at Osborne and made law between 12 noon Saturday and 1 on Sunday morning.

“Foreign Cattle,” suggests HS. – St. Patrick and the Fenian Dragon, says F.C.B. Butcher in the background, i.e., Jack Ketch – P.L. – Suspend the Act now, suspend the Fenians soon. H.S. and W.B., Hibernia and Britannia, “Keep the beast from hurting my children” or something of that sort. – S.B. (Accepted, after a protest by Pater against separating Hibernia and Britannia. They are one kingdom).
Shirley tells of man receiving 2 puppies with a note, “Remember me to your Mother and Sister . P.S. They are both bitches.”

Bennett says the song Kay sang in the Casual Ward was (the old one, but I never heard it). And up there came a wild boar, a roaming in the wood, And up there came a wild sow as took it as she stood, And so they went a rootling, a rootling, a rootling, And so they went a rootling by the woodside ... And up there came a man with his b a blowing free ..
H.M. says Sala gets £1250 from the Telegraph for travelling. ... “His ambition is to get on
Punch.”“Wouldn't suit us” says Mark.

div.head: February 28, 1866. W[ednesday].
div.p: D. I., H.S., F.E. , S.B., J.T. , M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C., W.B., H. M.

“Tenniel born today,” inscribed over the fireplace (where Leech's “Punch's Fancy Ball” hangs). So we drink towards him. ... 46 today he is. D.M. will be 31 next Tuesday. M.L. is 56, Fater 63. C.H.B. and H.S. 37. T.T., 48. F.C.B. 29. H.M. the only bald pate among us. Late hours! The new gas, vice old oil, in the ceiling is a great success. Cannibalism – “I feel I wasn't made to be eaten” says D.M. “No – to be drunken” – F.C.B.

L.C. Rumour of Lord Russell's resignation – S.B. depicts him as small boy, either refusing or wishing to “go out” as it may turn out. Mother Britannia. But too doubtful. So we think of Bumbledom anent the Casuals. “A kick in the bum-ble,” S.B. London's Nightmare – a beadle, S.B. accepted. [Punch, 50 (10 March 1866): 101, “London's Nightmare”]. W.B. suggests Mrs. Hercules London cleaning her Augean stable of nuisances. Somebody suggests the Sleeping Beauty. London awaking broom in hand – “The Sweeping Beauty,” says H.S. S.B. suggests London surrounded by scavengers and bea- ules and gas men and van demons, Roused London,” but this must be a double page. “London and the Lilliputians,” says F.E.

We applaud D.M. 's Sir Galahad ballad and picture – a take off of the Rossetti school.
“A Legend of Camelot, Part 1,” Punch, 50 (3 March 1866) 94. Tennyson gone mad style. H.M. don't see it.

Printer's suggestion.”Suspend the habeas corpus, dele habeas,” says S.B. H.M. saith Sala can't come to England because of the Jews. Yet he hath a salary of £1250! Has been paying £60 percent! Why not go and be whitewashed? Something in the background? So this is the result of all the talent of “a damned clever fellow” as Thackeray called him.

div.head: March 7, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., F.E., SB.., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., C.H.B.
Mark says the motto of Cucumber should be “resurgam.” But saith Shirley, “In brandy quies.”

P.L. decries “reliable” – relyuponable it should be. Says all literary men should prevent these Yankee word coinings. Immorality springs from loose verbiage. “Able” is an active termination, not a neuter. “Reliable” is a falsely constructed word. “Trustworthy” a good one. – “That's an argumentum ad Priaper,” saith P.L. “Must draw the Terminus somewhere,” S.B.
S.B. applauds D.M.'s Legend of Camelot – “He smole a bitter smile” etc.

L.C. The Coming Reform Bill of next Monday of course the subject. – P.L. suggests it as a baby – gossips asking, “Is it likely to live?” S.B. adds Russell as nurse with candle [Punch, 50 (17 March 1866): 113, “The Gossips”]. M.L. gives a history of the birth of Punch – he was at the seaside when Henry_Mayhew wrote “come to town here's a man with a notion for a comic newspaper, and he has £2000 to lose.” Mark, Mayhew, Jerrold, Paddy Coyne, Landells and Last the originals – but he forgets who invented the title. “The Panorama” preceded Punch. Mark wrote two pieces for the Strand, “The Silver Thimble” and “Punch” to pay expenses. Sold it to B. and E. for £300 at end of 2nd Volume: its debts. ... First Almanack was written chiefly with Grattan in Fleet Prison. H.M. and P.L. joined in Vol. 2. Jerrold was paid £2 a week, the rest £1. Mark wrote the first article.

div.head: March 14, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., P.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.CB., C.K., WJ.B., HEM., Tom Agnew, T.T. – 14 in all.

Bennett sits by me – with his deaf right ear. No longer a Casual.
Illustrator C. H. Bennett (1828-1867) had joined the Table on June 14, 1865, but ill-health made it impossible for him to continue; his last appearance in the diary is December 12, 1866. He died on April 2, 1867. Shirley Brooks wrote his obituary notice in the magazine; Punch 52 (13 April 1867) 151.
My old Frenchmaster, Brasseur, taught the Prince of Wales and invites him to the Garrick next Monday. Tom Taylor to dine with them. Prince invites his own party.
Shirley heard Gladstone 's Reform speech on Monday – flat. Fine voice. “If I'd such a voice I should be a greater man than Gladstone,” saith he.

T.T opposes the bill as mere extension of the Suffrage, not Reform. Working men in power would revive the political economy of the 15th century, and be ever ready for a sentimental war. Poland and Garibaldi to wit. L.C. P.L. suggests deserting the Reform baby ... or asking Bright to be Godfather. “But I won't stick to it,” . . . S B. says, if we were French we might have Britannia in bed, and Bright saying, “Godfather! Why I'm father!” S.B. then suggests “Frantic Excitement” which we accept [Punch, 50 (24 March 1866): 123, “Reform Bill, 1866. Frantic Excitement”], – tho' H.S. thinks some allusion to the Returns having upset the Bill should be made. T.T. suggests Russell as Morgiana and the 40 small boroughs asking, “Is it time?” for them to be dowsed. P.L. suggests John Bull looking at a tombstone, “I was well – I would be better.” The present system works well – why alter it? – M.L. objects to the Savings Bank franchise, which I had commended. P.L. suggests Bright as Macbeth, “Shake off this drowsy sleep”– trying to waken John Bull.
Buckstone gives a dance at the Haymarket. S.B. pictures the stilted stage talk, and suggests a prompter to remind partners of what to say.

T.T. defends his lines on Whewell.
Taylor’s memorial verses on legendary Cambridge don and Master of Trinity, William Whewell, who had died on March 6, appeared in Punch (50 [17 March 1866): 111 and were reprinted in the Times (March 16, p. 5). He was rough but manly. Saw him knock a townsman clean off his legs in a row. F.C.B. relates how W. was pelted by undergrads, and bore himself bravely, with a brickbat knocking his cap off.
M.L. says at the Crawley Exhibition the Catalogue described the Children of Israel by the waters of Babylon as “Lot and his daughters!” a lot of daughters!

T.T. says at Manchester a picture of Lear and Cordelia got the title of Landseers's “There's life in the old dog yet!” ... Gonorrhae & Cordee–lia, saith D.M. “C. Keene – you're see-king popularity,” W.B. rather a joker of jokes. “I hate overbearing men,” saith Shirley. – “as bad as overbearing women,” – F.C.B.

F.C.B. tells of the toad eating an egg and tumbling from a tree to crack it inside him. T.T. tells of boy boiling magpie's eggs and so killing the bird by its long sitting. Agnew tells of 5 watercolours bought for £70 twenty years ago; and fetched £900 today. S.B. describes sailor's use of paper – finger through, and wiping it. D.M. says, “I use Banknotes.” “You're getting extravagant – you used to use postage stamps” F.C.B. “Presented to my Sovereign – I'd rather a sovereign were presented to me,” P.L.
Drury Pantomime to follow. With the Gascoignes.
March 21, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., W.B., W.Agnew, T.T. = 15.

Tom Taylor dined with the Prince of Wales and Prince Alfred at the Garrick on Monday – 15 in all. Prince named his party. Brasseur my old French master (& his) the nominal host. T.T. supposes they'll (each guest) pay. P. of W. a pleasant laugher. “Sans façon”. Alfred a fine lad – would be noticeable in any company.

L.C. T.T. suggests Reform Pig in a poke. Russell showing his head only. J.Bull declining to buy till he sees the body. “Distribution” .... Or, Russell as waiter calling for “Franchise” – “Redistribution” to follow. ... S.B. amends to Gladstone and Russell as waiters serving Dizzy and Lowe, who complain of “Pudding before Meat” – amendment carried [Punch, 50 (31 March 1866): 135, “Pudding Before Meat”].

We sign our Immortal signatures as the rays of the Punch Sun for Shirley: and we each draw a Punch for Du Maurier – “doom horrier”. S.B. Agnew goes to see Churchyard's Old Cromes which are to be sold next Wednesday.
John Crome (1769-1821), better known as “Old Crome,” a Norwich oil painter and etcher.

(H.S. from Seckford St. ce matin – L[eech]'s 50th Birthday kept – Orpheus at the Haymarket with T. & E. tonight – salmon and headache to follow.) Du Maurier reads a funny bit in French from the “International” describing TomTaylor, having cut his beard off, being not recognized by his wife and “Betsy” till he sits down and dashes off a drama in six acts, when his wife cries, “C'est Tom – p'tit homme” and rushes to his arms. “After all, there's poetry in patrician blood, look at Byron – look at Shelley – look at me!”- Swinburne loquitur,- Swinburne has a marvellous memory and is spasmodic in his actions.

div.head: March 28, 1866. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.L ., T.T.

Felix Whitehurst writes the Paris letter in the Telegraph. Always telling where he dined. Saturday Review pitched into Times Paris correspondent last week for never telling news. S.B. thinks the letters are chiefly written to be read in Paris.
“The Times’ Paris Correspondent,” Saturday Review 21 (24 March 1866) 347-348.

L.C. T.T. suggests the Screw and the Pump – Telegraph Pumping abuse on Non Reformers and Bright & Co. putting on the Screw to get up Excitement. ... Suggests Laying out the Reform Baby before it's dead ... apropos of the St. Pancras Workhouse disclosure.

But M.L. thinks the Fenians and Canada is a fitter subject. So Tom proposes [President] Johnson saying, “Stop the Fenian Rebels! Wal, I guess laws won't do everything look at your Alabama” – Fred suggests Canada as “New Ireland” – or else Old Ireland reformed into New: Fenians extinct etc. – T.T. suggests Canada coming to Johnson drest as policeman, (a poser for Ponny – “What's the good of going to America if you don't know how the police dress?” – S.B.) ... and saying, “Somebody's threatening to break my windows.”- Johnson, “Can't move for threats, Ma'am – wait till there's blows.” T.T. amends this to “Yankee Fireman” which we accept [Punch, 50 (7 April 1866): 145, “The Yankee Fireman.”]. P.L. insists on “Smoke – wait till there' s fire” – but we prefer T.T.'s “Wait till it busts out” ... Rather costive wits tonight. P.L. calls Bright a “malignant beast” – S.B. contends that he has brains and can use them. The House wouldn't listen if he were merely a spouter ... S.B. and P.L. say, Burnand wouldn't write Burlesques to show girls' legs if he were a devout Catholic. ... S.B. recalls how Dizzy on his budget night spoke purposely till one, and then Gladstone, short of time, slashed him to bits.

P.L. defines Woman as “A warm soft substance with a mucuous canal” – but thinks the Exception to this rule a Glorious Creature. Can't conceive without man's help – even mentally – no great female Composer. Wants the patience to write an Epic. Mrs. Yates silly and showy because her husband lets and likes her so to be. A Roue rues his Sin when married. Having deceived, he fears deceit, D.M.

div.head: April 4, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D. M., H. S H – . HB., J. T., S. B., P . L ., CK. . M W.B. T.T.

D.M. drinks a glass of sherry at Lewis's before he sings his serenade – or Sherrynade. Then he drinks a couple of glasses before coming on the stage. “Les deux filles” not so funny as “Les deux aveugles,” The duel by dynometer is funny- and so is the duet, “Je vous dirai” .. “quoi – quoi – quoi – quoi”

L.C. S.B. suggests Carlyle denouncing as a “horrid object” a great orator who does not speak the truth: in his Edinburgh Inauguration speech on Monday.
Carlyle gave this address on April 2nd, on the occasion of his being installed as Rector of Edinburgh University. The Times carried an approving leader about the speech (April 4, 1866, p. 8). Applicable to Bright, saying that the House of Commons has never done a good thing. ... T.T. suggests “the Eve of the Battle” (of the 12th) Russell as Richard III – Bright, “Tis I my Lord – the Hardware Village cock!” ... “Will our friends prove true?” ... But Ponny says this would seem to predict defeat – and we now believe the Bill will pass the Second Reading and be rejected in the Lords. ... P.L. suggests Bright buckling on Russell's armour. T.T. suggests something from “The Robbers” – Austria and Prussia fighting about booty . .. .B. suggests Russell as Tom Thumb – but who's the Glumdalca? Finally we accept Carlyle [Punch, 50 (14 April 1866): 155 “Wisdom and Wind-bag”], T.T. suggesting Bright in background haranguing a mob. ... All applaud Carlyle's speech.
T.T says that local government usually fails ... and he tries to force the Sanitary Act and give parishes great powers, in order that the gentlemen may be forced to act and oust the blatant snobs.

D.M. and H.S. agree in thinking Tennyson will live chiefly by his Songs and minor lays, such as “Ask me no more” – which Grove has nicely analysed in The Shilling Magazine.
“On a Song in ‘The Princess’” by George Grove (1820-1900) appeared in Samuel Lucas’s short-lived Shilling Magazine in February, 1866, pp. 181-184. Grove wrote about “Tears, Idle Tears” in Macmillans the following November. “Break break break” and so forth. H.S. thinks Tennyson commendable especially for his classic rhythm – “faultily faultless, icily regular, splendidly null.” ... “The snowy-banded, dilettante, delicate handed priest intone.”
The first quotation is from The Princess, the second from Maud. D.M. thinks Molière as a poet second only to Shakespeare … “As a dramatist you mean,” says H.S.

S.B. tells how in '51 when Roebuck's book about the old Reform Bill came out, he was on The Chronicle staff and living in Buckingham St.– knocked up when in bed (avec une femme) one night and cut the two volumes and wrote two cols. between ten and 2 a.m.
Brooks misremembers the year, but not the fact that the review appeared the day after the book’s publication. The book was John Arthur Roebuck, History of the Whig Ministry of 1830, to the Passing of the Reform Bill (London: John W. Parker and Son, 1852); the review, which is just over one column in length, appeared as “Mr. Roebuck’s History of the Whigs,” Morning Chronicle, 6 February 1852, p. 6. At a dinner party the following year, Brooks mentioned his “twixt night and day” review to Roebuck himself (Brooks diary, November 6, 1867, British Library).

Buckstone gave a ball on the Haymarket Stage last Thursday, at which, S.B. and his wife and H.M. and F.C.B. and Tom Reed and others danced. “Would you like to go?” said S.B. to D.M. last week – but D.M.'s dancing days are over – only cares for dinners now! Fancy the old fogydom of Thirty! And I love dancing still – at 37.

H.M. saw Burnand's “Yachting Cruise” at the Gallery last night and thought it poor and wanting plot. Ah says S.B., “I told Burnand he little knew how hard it was to write ... for the Reeds. I was bored and bothered out of my life when I wrote for them. Only Parry can act. Mrs. Reed is passeé and limited in her parts, and her husband is an ass. It's the most difficult thing writing for such people and making anything like a connection between the characters. I'd rather write three five act comedies.” ... “I wish you'd write one,” says H.S.

S.B., “I dare say 3,000 people are at this moment listening to Burnand's talk. I don't care for puns and nigger breakdowns.
“Breakdown” glossed by Eric Partirdge as slang circa 1870 meaning “riotous dancing.” In the old days we used to aim at something higher than mere verbal juggling. Burlesquing a situation, or a character is better than making puns. “An upright monarch and a downright fool” I remember told well…and my parody of The Duke's Court letters in 'Robin Hood or Richmond'.”
“Robin Hood or Richmond” appears to be a mistranscription for “Robin Hood and Richard Coeur de Lion, a Burlesque Spectacle in Two Acts” (1846), written by J. H. Stocqueler, Shirley Brooks, and Charles Lamb Kenney. In writing to George Somes Layard, Henry Silver, evidently consulting his diary notes, recalled these remarks of Brooks's this way: “One day at the Punch dinner-table, after the business of the evening was transacted, Shirley said, 'Good legs will carry off bad rhymes, and people chiefly go to look and not to listen. And so players don't take pains to say their words intelligibly, and instead of good burlesques we get bad puns and breakdown dances.' As a sample of stage-writing, he thought the verse 'An upright monarch and a downright fool' was rather a good line of his own, when rightly spoken. And he agreed with me in praising Mrs. Keeley for the clearness of her utterance. Layard, A Great Punch Editor, 192

div.head: April 11, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., Tom Agnew.

Mr. Bradbury's birthday next Friday. M.L. proposes his health. But not in champagne. T.A. tells how he bought Mark's (Toothache or) Gargoyle picture for 300 guineas directly the Academy opened – and sold it at usual profit of 10% within ten minutes. ... His buyer went to Churchyard's sale. Stout fellow – bought several lots – and got invited to spend a week there. Moulton very slow and expatiatory. But £1650 or so realized.

L.C. S.B. suggests Russell between Bright and Punch, Vice and Virtue – “The Choice of Hercules.” Hercules, Lord Russell – for the first time of performance ... as “The sweet Saint that stood at Russell's side.” Re-Distribution of Seats, Chartist saying “I shall take Knowle.” ... F.E. inaudibly suggests Russell keeping back the Seats Bill and or John Bull saying “Why didn't you show me all your bills at once you young scapegrace.” S.B., “Clothes and educates” Fred's child and we accept him – despite the Professor's objection that it is not a logical cut. The Seats bill is not yet before the House. No – and Russell is shown holding it behind his back, [Punch, 50 (21 April 1866): 167, “Business is Business”]. ... The meeting at Lord R[ussell]'s yesterday shows that Government have listened to their Punch, and will not pass their Franchise bill alone. I doubt if they could/have passed a bill, embodying both Franchise and Redistribution: because of course the members who would lose their seats would oppose the bill. ... S.B., “Said to the frog, frig the frug.”

H.S. from Woodbridge today – walk to Ipswich . .. Nevertheless smoke gets into his brain. Tho' he only smokes a pipe. T[homas] A[gnew] finds the Punch Dinners give him a headache. Bad ventilation the chief reason. Sala's books etc. to be sold off tomorrow. Must have muddled away his money. H.M. doubts if Albert Smith satisfied his wife. Intacta sedet genitque. Left her only £l000 and house. M.L. thinks the applause when he acted turned Dickens' head and caused his bad conduct to his wife. Professor Owen foretold a catastrophe, “Dickens has grown so arrogant.”

div.head: April 18, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.

What joints have we up? asks the Professor as usual, apropos the Big Cut.
