Then he praises Mill for his speech in the Malt Tax debate, advocating a reduction of the National Debt, on the ground that a century hence our coalfields will be exhausted – and our prosperity will decay. “A new element in the House – Intellect.”
See Times of April 18, 1866, 6-7, for a report of this speech. Mill recommended Jevons’s The Coal Question on the subject, argued that reducing national debt is a duty to posterity. But not practical, says M.L. – nor Punchy for a Cut. And so proposes [Sir Fitzroy] Kelly as refreshment man in St. Stephen's Theatre bawling out “Porter” and interrupting the Reform performance [Punch, 50 (28 April 1866): 177, “Interrupting the Performance at the Theatre Royal St. Stephen's”]
Sir Fitzroy Kelly moved a resolution in support of repealing the Malt Tax, owing to its burden falling disproportionately upon the working classes, and mentioned in illustrating the economics of brewing that he had himself brewed ale and kept track of the cost. ... Having given notice of motion, he refused to give way to Gladstone. . Professor says Reform is a d-d bore and Kelly is a damnder! And he calls on us to vote with him. ... Ponny protests against the Professor for dogmatising and domineering – H.S. suggests the Reform Bill sticking on the ways à la Northumberland, which was launched yesterday.
The ironclad HMS Northumberland stuck halfway down the slip (“ways”) during her initial launch and could not be shifted owing to her unusual weight. The owners were obliged to wait for the next spring tide before the ship could be dislodged. “No use, without her machinery” – i.e., Distribution of Seats – suggests Fred... But we accept Mark's cut as the best ... despite the growls of the Professor.
H.S. to hear the Italian Symphony, New Phil.

div.head: April 25, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11. First asparagus.
div.p: Summer is ycumen in.
E., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B., T.T.

L.C. S.B. by letter suggests Disraeli fighting Six Gladstones – à la King Richard: apropos of his saying G. has made Six Speeches on Reform, at Liverpool etc. ... Suggests Dizzy and G. as the Gladiators (Arthur Lewis' Swedish Wrestlers, he means), only by Saturday we shall know who wins. T.T. suggests neck and neck – apropos of The Chester Cup – for it’s sure to be a close race. ... P.L. suggests Brittania saying to Russell, “Go – rest and be thankful” – which is equal to saying, “Go and be hanged,” says Ponny. T.T. amends it to Brit[annia] as Nurse coming for Russell – “leave out the corners of his mouth till Saturday, and then turn them up or down as the result indicates,” – accepted, faute de mieux [ Punch, 50 (5 May 1866): 189, “Rest, and Be Very Thankful”].

Burnand goes to Paris on Friday: to see La Famille Benoiton and Le Bas Bleu. Where gets he his railway pass? Guess his wits are quicker than H.S.'s. Chaffs cleverly – gravely saying absurdities as Truths. Laughs at Professor's calling the Maccabees Scotchmen. Tells story of C. Keene and Rumsey Forster (Jenkins) which everybody but Fred knows – “Delightful parties, these.”
Henry Rumsey Forster (1815-1884), reporter for the Morning Post and author of The Pocket Peerage, had been the target of a campaign of ridicule in Punch by Thackeray, who dubbed him “Jenkins” and made fun of the Post’s fawning coverage of the aristocracy. Forster was still active on the Post in the 1860s.

E. revives Leech's story of handsome man and lady thinking aloud. “How I wish he would f – me!” . .. One cigar only – resolve not to have a headache. It's the smoke that does it. Never get headaches elsewhere.
Astley's to follow, with the Gascoynes: Boabdil el Chiro. D.M. and Power as Les Deux Filles at Lewis's next Saturday.

div.head: May 2, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., W.B., Tom Agnew, T.T.

L.C. War seems threatened. Prussia and Austria both arming – and Italy too – and all protesting they don't mean to fight. L.N. the master spirit – pulls the strings, but we've done the marionettes with Lord Brougham as the wirepuller. S.B. suggests Louis and Philippe as the shade of Fagin – “You worthily succeed me, my son.” “Now's your time to get a slice of Bismarck's stolen goods.” ... H.M. suggests scene from “Critic” – Austria and Prussia with their daggers up and Na- poleon as Mr. Puff. – “But he isn't quite the Author” says P.L. .. who suggests “Nemesis” – War following the Rape of Denmark. T.T. suggests the screen scene from “School for Scandal” – “Liberty” disclosed, closeted with L.N. .. but this doesn't hit the fact. P.L. suggests L.N. playing the 3-card trick – which king will he turn up? – also, Louis as Aeolus, holding the winds. Somebody suggests Italy as Marguerite temp- ted by Louis as Mephisto. T.T. suggests L.N. as old gentleman watching two street boys, Austria and P[Russia], about to fight, “You hit me – that's all.” S.B., Louis as the Man in the Iron Mask – amends it Italy half drawing the sword and consulting Louis the Oracle – “whose face should be half hid by the smoke. ... Croat and Prussian threatening in background,” adds T.T. accepted [ Punch, 50 (12 May 1866): 199, “Consulting the Oracle”] – M.L. had proposed Gladstone as Cricketer putting on pads for second Reform innings – bat “Redistribution.”
T.T., “Lust is such a poor thing – so short-lived and so worthless” – S.B., “But the world must be peopled.” (“Bravo” thinks H.S.) Swinburne impotent? therefore bawdy.

div.head: May 9, 1866 W[ednesday]. The Mitre, Hampton Court,
div.p: E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., F. E., H.M., W.B.

First out – but the chestnuts are hardly so. Stroll with S.B. and C.H.B. among them: the latter, “Thanks for the pleasantest half hour” he has had for weeks, while reading Susan Bennett's (“Setty”) letters from Cannes. Good specimens of a nursemaid's handiwork. And education has not taught her to neglect the baby for the sake of scribbling.

L.C. S.B. suggests Dizzy as McDuff saying to Russell, “Thou hast them now, Bill, groupings, franchises, all that the weird Gladstone promised thee.” But the Derby is next week – so P.L. suggests the Emperor as “The Dark Horse” – “Will he Win?” – and H.S. suggests that he be drest as a Jockey – S.B. adds Mr. Punch making up his book and asking Austria, Prussia and Italy as jockeys, “What will he do?” [Punch, 50 (19 May 1866): 211, “The Dark Horse”].

H.M. chaffy in the carriage up – “aggressive” – and H.S. isn't. Non sum qualis eram. Telegraphed to S. & L. to say that I could not start till 1:45 tidal train on Friday. Eborall kindly sent me a pass this morning. Forbes the Chathamite “out of town.”
Somehow don't feel up to the Punch mark quite. Either in wit or wisdom. Feel afraid of stimulating my brains as I used to do – never walk up Regent Street now for a finish. “The
sere & yellow leaf” is coming.
May 15. T. No. 11
May 23. W. No. 11.
May 30. W. No. 11.
June 6. W. No. 11.
June 13. W. No. 11.
H.S. at Paris, Biarritz, Peu, Cauterets, and Ambares. A memorable trip. Never away a month from England till now. Back from Bordeaux in 24 hours June 19 & dance at Ab. Garrett's after the feed 20th.

div.head: June 20, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: E., D.M., H.S, C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., W.B., F.C.B.

S.B. tells of Bernal Osborne at a Wedding Breakfast, “My bosom friend ... and his wife whom I may call still more my bosom friend.” ... bouquet at breast. “It seems to me you wear your figleaf rather too high up!”

“Storming the Barricade” singularly ill-timed, for last night Gladstone said the Government were going to the Queen, anent their defeat on the Rating and Rental. P.L. declaims against the Wicked War between Prussia and Austria, which has been formally declared. And regrets that Italy should forfeit our good wishes by joining Prussia in the fight. We shall have plenty of war cuts though, so let us kudos the Yankees for chivvying the Fenians – repeat the Fireman Cut, say D.M. and S.B. [Punch, 50 (30 June 1866): 273, “Yankee Fireman Keeps His Word”].
Then we blow gas bubbles which explode in the lamp. Bennett the prime blower . . . And we tell a story about everybody and everything – each in rotation beginning at the sign of S.B.

N.B. Special meeting of the Punch Cabinet this day week, anent young W.B. and M.L. and D.M. his charges for the Camelot drawings. £10.10 each – his usual charge for his 2 weekly cuts. .. But the storm is over.

div.head: THE SILVER WEDDING
div.p: The Fiftieth Volume of Punch Flare-up.
June 27, 1866. W[ednesday].

To Slough at 11. H.S. with W.B. just back from Manx- land, and P.L. and Tom Agnew who sticks up for Gladstone in resigning – “more than the Tories would do.” “Why should we not increase the House – and give new members to the new great towns? – P.L. says country don't want reform, and won't have a class Reform bill like this: which would enfranchise the Working Man and not the farm-labourer. “But the manufacturing hands are more intelligent and earn twice the wages of the clodhoppers – and you should give their brains a vote. Don't be dunned into doing what is right.” At Stoke Poges we inspect the churchyard where Gray lies – the old church and its ivy would look better without its new spire and chimneys. Then on to Burnham Beeches – my first visit. And after lamb and lobster and veal and ham pie and salad and.champagne cup, upriseth the Professor and quoteth Bully Bottom, “Pat pat – there is a convenient place for our rehearsal – discourse “most obscenely” – The obscenity may follow later in the evening. Shirley has made many good suggestions but never one so good as this: That the contributors should mark today, at the end of Volume 50, their affection and respect for one who in his tact and skill in government equals our lamented premier (Palmerston) – our dear friend, Mark Lemon. ... And then handeth over a watch and chain, with 11 links, the mystic number of the Punch Staff.
The present was Brooks’s idea. See Brooks to Percival Leigh, June 7, 1866 (transcribed by Silver): “It
would much please dear Mark, I am certain, if we the writers and artists gave him some trifle (pin, ring or
something) on the Silver Wedding. Let us subscribe a pound apiece. If you like, I will see to the small
trouble.” –Mark sitting at the head of the tablecloth, flanked on the right by Pater and on the left by Shirley, covers his eyes for a moment. “It needeth not this, my friends, to assure me of your esteem for me. But I shall ever wear it next my heart. ... You have lightened my labour by your readiness at all times to [crossed out: “do each other’s work”] help me all you can. The Punch Brotherhood has been one of the most extraordinary literary brotherhoods the world has ever seen. We have never had a serious dispute. And in our so working together, proprietors and contributors, lies the secret of our great success. I received a pound a week at first for Editing – but as the success increased my salary increased ... Our brotherhood shows that, irritable as authors may be called, they yet can work together, if joined by real friendship and working for a good end. And Punch has worked for a good end – and done a great good. Shirley's admirable preface is not overpraise. Punch has blotted out The Age and Satirist and other vile publications, which before Punch existed were the only amusing journals of the day. ... Forgive my mother's weakness – I feel more than I can say. I know I have done my duty – but I did not expect this kind acknowledgment from you ... I am sure you will be glad to learn I am a hundred guineas richer than I was this morning. I received them in a letter which I shall value as much as the money it contained. This is Punch's Silver Wedding. I cannot hope to live to see the golden one. But Punch must always prosper if confidence prevails.

Then Shirley handeth Mark the letters we all wrote to testify our gladness at the gift proposed. Bennett heads his with a drawing and so does Du Maurier – who writes the longest note. C.K.'s the shortest – “All right.”“Jackides” proffers “2 lbs. if necessary, or any larger sum.” Burnand says he is at Little Hampton and has just knocked off the Second Act of La Belle Helène. “Ponny” overflows with sympathy. Tom Taylor adds a P.S. which is inter-lined and corrected, as his “copy” always is. Percival Leigh and Henry Silver simply say how glad they are to join, and Shirley has all the notes bound in a small volume and writes one to introduce them to his dear old friend.

Bennett and I (who sit between J.T. and Will Agnew, next whom is Burnand, all on Mark's right hand) drink from the same glass and find the drink is potent. We almost in fact “cup us till our heads go round.”

Then J.T. and F.C.B. have a mock sparring match, “getting away” so cleverly that they almost get out of sight. And C.K. and P.L. go mushroom hunting and find a yellow fungus which turns blue when ex- posed to air inside. Then down comes a little rain and thunder growls and we drive by Dropmore and see the lovely Diodoras and so reach Skindle's at Maiden- head. D.M. and F.C.B. and C.H.B. and H.S. riding together thither and from Slough. F.C.B. amusing us with the drunken old fellows who tried to say “judicious.” “Admiral Codrington was a most seducious man.” No, you don't mean seducious – I know the word you mean ... chorus: “We know the word you mean – [crossed out].” “And you're bound to tell us – bound!” da capo a dozen times ... “It's judicious.”

At Skindle's we shake hands with dear old Bradbury. (Said D.M. at lunch: “Bradbury looks the most uncomfortable man here” – meaning his position on the grass … but I apply it to his position on Punch, after the row about D.M.'s pay and seeing our good feeling towards Mark) ... then some go on the river and get drenched in a thundershower, and I walk with Bennett. And at six we dine. – “You look like a gamekeeper, Silver – so weatherbeaten,” says Tom Taylor – who joins us. Thanks to the Pyrenees, say I: and wonder thinking of their beauties that Tom doesn't know them. At dinner we sit thus:
Evans, P.L., F.C.B., C.K., J.H.Agnew, H.M., T.T., Mark Lemon
F.E. First time of meeting of the Whole Eighteen! W.B.
Wm. Agnew, J.T., S.B., H.B., Tom Agnew, H.S., DM, Bradbury

W.B. proposes Mark's health – hopes new firm will keep the friendships formed by the old one – difficult for young men to feel the sentiments of older ones. Presents a noble silver cup. ... Whereat Mark buries his face in his hands. ... While we get up, and, D.M. duce, give him musical honors with all our hearts and voices. – Mark after recovery speaks out boldly and emphatically that friendship and confidence between all the Punch Men, Editor and contributors and proprietors have been and must be the great cause of Success ... Then he drinks to the two who “made Punch what it is” – who had confidence in it and in him from the first and have handed down that confidence and may it never cease till death.

We drink to B. and E. out of the Cup. And they warmly say their thanks and tell us that their best friends have been the men on Punch. And that Punch has brought them as much pleasure and pride as profit. ... Then Shirley proposes “The New Firm,” and says it has always been his pleasure to work for Punch and he has given it his best work. And so have we all.

W.B. and F.E. and Wm. A. all say their thanks – and the latter adds that his children have been pleased and taught by Punch – “And if ever there's incarnate truth and goodness in the world, it is in little children – and to please them Punch is truth.”

Tom Agnew proposes “the Contributors” and calls on Leigh to respond, as being six weeks the senior of “Ponny” on the staff. But Leigh wanders into talking of an argument he had with the proposer, and so Shirley has to answer for us – in spite of his hoarse voice. “We are, there's no denying it, a Remarkable Lot. There's no mock modesty in me, or real modesty either. But look at us. All come from different spheres of society and bring our experiences thence to be fused in the Punch fire. .... Tom Taylor who mingles with the aristocrats, and Horace who is only known in the back slums of the Haymarket etc. I begin with Horace ... who lives in the most unmitigated profligacy but has the kindest of hearts and in his time has done much good work on Punch. Of Tom Taylor, I need only say that we are all proud to work with him … Charles Keene lives in Baker Street and is connected with the Wax Works, but when not engaged as a showman makes most capital Punch cuts. The Professor lives at Hammersmith and indulges in improper intercourse with very elderly females (Mrs. Snorter!), but is never late with his “copy”, and writes what everyone delights to read. Of John Tenniel I need only say it is our pride to have him illustrate our thoughts. Burnand is half out of the window (like Tom Taylor) and if he were quite out, I could say more about his merits. He is the most successful burlesque writer of the day, and holds nightly in his hand the ears of many thousands. And he writes the most surprising nonsense – and good sense. How he does it, I don't know. I only know that I could not. Mr. Bennett peoples pages with fairies – and is up to all the games of politics – nothing ever escapes his eye and whatever his eye sees his pencil produces. Then I come to Silver who lives nobody knows where – when I wake a nights, to think where Silver lives and what he does when he's not writing is one of the puzzles that perplex me. But he is up in sporting matters and he keeps us well informed in yachting and shooting, and he is a good fellow (which is best of all). Then I come to Du Maurier whose Legend of Camelot is an honour to Punch, – and I hardly know which to praise most, his pencil or his pen. And as to myself, I have given Punch my best work – and I never enjoy working so much as for Punch. I was at Margate fifteen years ago when Mark asked me to join. I began with “Miss Violet” and have rarely let a number pass without an article of mine. I am the connecting link between the old men and the new. And it will ever be my pride and pleasure to be with the men of Punch. After this good speech we drink Shirley's health and Mark testifies to his worth and work. Tom Taylor proposes the Memory of the Contributors and Artists departed – Jerrold, à Beckett, Thackeray and Leech: which we drink upstanding and in Silence.
And then after a song or two we get back by the 11 o'clock train: after a most pleasurable and memorable day.

div.head: July 4, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., C.H.B., H.S., J.T., F.E., C.K., H.M.
Shirley has the gout and Mark is also CD. … Effects of our Silver Wedding.

Austrians getting sewed up by Prussian Needle Gun. P.L. thinks this should be our subject. But M.L. by note suggests Derby finding his old Tory measures too small for him. H.S. adds Dizzy as his Squire. The Rupert of Debate. ... Arming for the fight. Accepted [Punch, 51 (14 July 1866): 17, “Derbye hys Straite Fytte”]. Ponny suggests Derby incubating an addled Ministry. C.K. suggests Derby recruiting Sergeant – Falstaff's ragged regiment. .. The point is that Derby has tried to get a Liberal crew and can't. So Bennett's suggestion of a big suit of Liberal armour in the corner seems good – but Derby can't well say, “I've tried that and it don't fit.” P.L. says a man of sense would shrink from using a friend's wife just as he would shrink from using a friend's toothbrush.
Whacking British Queens!! Then to Adelphi with Farrow and Madame Renouf to see The Fast Family and La Belle Helène.

div.head: July 11, 1866. W[ednesdayl. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., E.+, P.L.7 C.K., H.M., Wm. Agnew, T.T. +deposed.
Champagne cup in Mark's presentation goblet with the many pegs.

Shirley says that Billy Russell and Hosier (or Osier, an officer) write to the Times from the Austrians and Brackenbury from the Prussians. The Battle of Sedowa was another Waterloo.
Also known as the Battle of Königgrätz, the Battle of Sedowa on July 3, 1866, was the decisive battle of the Austro-Prussian War, in which Prussia defeated the Austrian empire. William Howard Russell covered the conflict for the Times. Russell a ready writer truly. No joke writing on a battlefield with the enemy at one's heels.

T.T. doubts the policy of that paragraph about “Mr. John Brown walked on the slopes.” Shirley defends it. Says Sir Edwin Landseer was insulted by the airs of this d – d gillie. Nobody believes the scandal, but it is as well to notice it.
“Court Circular,” Punch 51 (7 July 1866): 4.

L.C. T.T. suggests the Venice Lion of St. Mark ceded to France: “he does not seem to like it” growling .. accepted [Punch, 51 (21 July 1866): 29: “The Lion of St. Mark”]. T.T. suggests also (for C.K.), a cut about the Sisters of Mercy being denied entrance to Sick Ward of Workhouse. “Mercy? – no Mercy here.”
A Times leader of June 22 (p. 8) summarizes the revelations of appalling conditions at workhouse infirmaries. [Punch, 51(21 July 1866): 28: “The Unrecognised Visitor.”] Bravo, T.T. – wish my wits were as quick.

Tom also says that Kate Terry is the only actress who perfectly realises his conception of a character. Places her far above all others – even H. Faucit. Shirley applauds Miss Fortescue of olden time – so graceful and ladylike. But Tom doubts if she had the versatility of Kate. And there's small fear of Kate's being spoilt by success. She played at 4 years old for her mother's benefit, and has too much stage experience to be vain of her success, or covetous of flattery – I go to see her in The Lady of Lyons tonight with Madame Renouf and thoroughly endorse Tom's verdict that she is by far the most natural actress we have.

div.head: July 17, 1866. T[uesday]. At the Rosherville Hotel, Graves end.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., Evans, P.L., C.K., C.H.B., H.M., T.T.
H.S. from Folkestone today and F.E. ditto: after a little yachting. Nautical chaff. Capital dinner. Never tasted curried whitebait before. Very commendable.
T.T. says Millais stands first for dramatic power and faithful representation. He went to Rome last year and so has not exhibited this. Reverence for Old Masters.

L.C. T.T. suggests both cuts as he did last week – Louis Nap. and Bismarck: “Which of us is to be arbiter?” B. with needlegun. “The 2 Dromios”, J.T. [Punch, 51 (28 July 1866): 41: “Rival Arbiters.”] Also suggests cut about the Small Germans fried by Prussia, stirred over with needle gun – or else Giant Russia, gobbling them up. ...Then a propos of Lord Derby's bad Irish law appointments, he suggests, “Irish Justice” (amended by W.B. to “Justice—for Ireland”) [Punch, 51 (28 July 1866): 40, “Justice—for Ireland”] – lame, and deaf as well as blind. Blackburne aetat 85 Chancellor: Napier, deaf, Lord Justice.
See Times leader (July 16, 1866, p. 10) re: old and infirm judges.

Merry journey home. Ponny and Mark and Du Maurier singing comic Italian. At dinner D.M. and C.H.B. discuss morality and the passions of the Beast. Man halfway between an angel and a devil. Few men have the courage to be pure – but at thirty they who have been so clearly have the best of it. Usually are unforgiving of others, though.

T.T. eloquent on the trite theme of Woman and her weakness – which becomes her strength. Man the pursuer and the passionate – Woman the passive: delighting only in that she delighteth him. “We exist through the Vice of the Male and the Virtue of the Female.”

div.head: July 25, 1866. W[ednesday] . No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.

Reform League Meeting prevented in Hyde Park on Monday. D.M. there – railings weighed down by the roughs, panic when the police charged – helmets in a row and truncheons hitting right and left. D.M.’s hansom backed agsint the rails. Soldiers settled the row directly – in Paris they would have increased it.

Of course this is the Subject and we can't amend Mark's suggestion of a Reformer and a Rough – former saying “We don't want that” brickbat. H.M. suggest “Rough and Ready” – “reddy” soldiers, says H.S. [Punch, 51 (4 August 1860): 51: “No Rough-ianism”]. F.C.B. suggests “Bright the Quaker” quaking at the police, but writing to inflame the people. His daughter was married on Monday, but that's no excuse for his letter, inciting the reformers to hold their meeting. Let the question first be legally settled – Have a people a right to meet in public parks?

H.S. to hear Patti in Faust and Crispin e la Couvre in Davison's box. Certainly she has more feeling and natural expressiveness than Lucca, and her articulation is perfect. Mario 58! What a wonder he is! Madame Renouf remembered him, tho' she hadn't heard him for 20 years.

div.head: August 1, 1866. W[ednesday]. The Greyhound, Dulwich.
div.p: W.B., D.M, H.S., C.H.B., F.E, J.T., M.L.,E.,P.L.,C.K., H.M., T.T.
Bus ride a novelty – once a luxury. Recall to Pater my old half crown Sunday sprees to Gravesend and dine at Cobham. Young fellows nowadays would hardly condescend to such meagre bills of fare.
Play bowls with C.K. – and W.B. and F.E.

Shirley by letter suggests “The Unexpected Guests” – Derby & Co. at Greenwich – or getting there by Van. T.T. amends to Whitebait saying, “Who'd have thought of seeing Zou?”'-which we accept [Punch, 51 (11 August 1866): 62, “An Unexpected Treat.—The Whitebait Dinner”]. P.L. suggests bill of fare, Reform pudding etc., “This is what Lord Russell ordered.” “Eating the Enemy's Dinner,” T.T.

Atlantic Cable laid – T.T. suggests Ireland joining hands of England and America, or Neptune saying, “Bless you my children” (accepted) [Punch, 51 (11 August 1866): 63, “For Better or Worse.”]. Another double of cuts from his prolific brain. He says when ill he goes to bed and lies quiet without eating for 48 hours. Brain needs rest.
Apropos of Swinburne's new poems, D.M. quotes Shirley:

“This book of lust and foul desire, A fitting dedication owns, One half I pitch into the fire, The other half to Mrs. Jones.”
Shirley Brooks’s friend William Hardman noted in November 1866 that “It has been Brooks’s great amusement lately to circulate epigrams full of wit and indecency about the poet.” S. M. Ellis, editor, The Hardman Papers (New York: George Doran, 1930) 191-192. Editor Ellis primly omits Hardman’s example of one such epigram, noting that “it is impossible to print.”
Burne Jones (is it? – some Jones I know) the artist, admires Swinburne. A nasty conceited drunken impotent beast, who recites poetry with a St Vitus’ dance.

div.head: August 8, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., F.C.B., J.T. (late from Ramsgate), S.B., P.L., C.K., H.M. T.T.

“Anybody's birthday?” asks Shirley, when the champagne comes:“Yes, mine” – so they drink to my good health Pater in claret as well. My last bachelor birthday, I hope. Oxtail, salmon (sans sauce) hashed venison, fowl and London pudding – peas, french beans, pine and apricot, my simple birthday fare. With one cigar.
Mormonism should be called morewomanism” says Leigh – Bravo Professor!

L.C. Apropos of Pakington's answer that “there is no naval reserve,” P.L. suggests, “The British Fleet thou cans't not see” from the Critic which we accept, Shirley touching up the notion [Punch, 51 (18 August 1866): 73, “’The Critic’ (Slightly Altered)”]. Pakington the Governor. “Navy with a K.”“Non est in ventis” – “A Sail without Reserve” – but we accept T.T.'s “The fleet of the future.”

Somebody was hung twice – rope broken – H.M. suggests the second hanging was done by the Recorder. D.M. says all his handsome models say of H.M., “C'est mon pere.” – We picture him as the father of the models – grouped to show him their backsides stamped with strawberry leaves. “Bless ye, my children!” “Paddle your own canoe,” Burnand has joined the Canoe Club.

div.head: August 15, 1866. W[ednesday No.l 11.)
div.p: H.S. au Chateau du Tillac.

div.head: August 22, 1866,
div.p: “ “ ) “Ne faites trop la cour.”

div.head: August 29, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., J.T., S.B., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.
H.S. from Ambarès in 24 hours – arriving last night at 7. Went there on the wings of love in 22 hours: 10 to Paris, 10 thence to Ambarès, arriving at 6.45 a.m., August 11.
D.M. at Boulogne! M.L., also…or at Paris. Last week they telegraphed to him from the Punch Table and alarmed the Hotel and “the Oblongites.”

T.T. tells how his old college chum Lang scurvily treated him apropos of “Plot and Passion” – L. mentioned anecdote of Fouché, employing women spies - afterwards T.T. wrote the play on this slight peg for Wigan – Lang wrote one for Webster, who returned it unread – and Wigan preferred Taylor's, said L's was unactable. Then Tom gave him half proceeds of his, T's play and inserted one phrase from Lang's, “Why don't she cheat?” Yet Lang afterwards claimed the authorship.
Australian-born John Lang (1816-1864) attended Trinity College in the late 1830s. Later moving to India, he published the newspaper The Mofussilite. Taylor’s claim of virtually sole authorship of “Plot and Passion” (1853) formed part of a wide-ranging attack on Taylor in the Athenaeum in 1871 by Thomas Purnell, who wrote under the pseudonym “Q”, attacks that derided Taylor for his borrowings from the French. See Athenaeum (22 April 1871) 505 and Taylor’s reply regarding Lang at Athenaeum (13 May 1871) 601. These were published in book form as Dramatists of the Present Day (London: Chapman and Hall, 1871). Henry Fouché, Napoleon’s minister of police, was the main villain of the play. Alfred Wigan managed the Olympic Theatre when “Plot and Passion” made its debut there in 1853. Lang published the story as a novel in 1859.

Also tells how he wrote Peg Woffington (Masks and Faces) on a hint from Charles Reade who wrote only one scene – the picture one – admittedly the best, however – then took Tom's scenes for a novel, and never gave a thank'ee for them. So much for literary honesty.
S.B. calls Charles Mackay “the Scotchman that stinks” – challenges a closer title.

L.C. Bright’s speech at Birmingham – T.T. suggests Frankenstein Bright frightened by Shadow of Manhood Suffrage – amends it by adding extract from his speech “I am not afraid of Manhood Suffrage.” – H.M. objects, of course – says “in ten years you’ll think with him” – “Blast me if I shall,” says T! rather unparliamentarily. Somebody suggests “the Workingman King of the future” T.T. suggests Respectability turned out of its gig – apropos of the Bribery Commissions. Totnes and Yarmouth and Lancaster should be disenfranchised. But we prefer the Brummagen Frankenstein, as Shirley names it.
See letter to Mark Lemon from Shirley Brooks of September 4, 1866. Lemon was away, and Brooks explained what had happened at the dinner meeting: “We have been very lucky in a big cut, Tenniel has done a tremendous brute (not a working man, I opposed this) as Manhood Suffrage, and Bright is Frankenstein cutting away frightened. As the rabble are burning effigies on gallowses, and ‘wishing they could serve the originals so, in the flesh,’ I imagine that we must go in for law and order rather strong.” (Author’s collection.) [Punch, 51 (8 September 1866): 103, “The Brummagem Frankenstein”].
Ponny chaffs Pater about his Pollakey – proceedings – pretends that Pater is a spy. “And he looks so beastly benevolent” says H.S., a phrase that pleases Ponny.
Actually Bennett smokes a cigar!
J.T. says he would have preferred D.M. and myself to Vertue[?] and Maxwell for the pull from Oxford – “3 Glorious Days” Saturday week et seq.
Quite a pleasant evening. “And would even a life / with my love make amends / For losing such dinners with / jolly old friends.
But my brains have been sadly blunt of late. Cupid deadens the wits, I think.

div.head: September 5, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., C.H.B., F.E., J.T., S.B., T.T. C.K., F.C.B., H. M.
H.S. driven to town by stress of weather: gasping at Stanwick for a couple of nights.

L.C. – apropos of the Bribery Commissions S.B. suggests (only we can't do it: which T.T. don't see) Pharisee Candidate and Publican ... MP's pay their thousands, and don't ask how they're spent, and then fancy them- selves innocent. “But we mustn't have altar pieces,” says Shirley. – “No, let me alter pieces,” says Burnand – who is as laughing and lively as usual. Wonderful spirits he has. ... M.L. suggests Fenian picnic disturbed by Canada cannonball. We've just been sending some shot over there. T.T. suggests the Pope as Robinson Crusoe launching the Bark of St. Peter on the Unknown Sea – L.N. withdrawing his troops – “But the Bark represents the Spiritual Power, and you wouldn't hit at that,” says Burnand. After B. goes however, we settle on initial to Tom's poem (which Shirley begs may be serious and in stately metre – as in the old days; Tom and he can knock off a poem in an hour or two) on a suggestion from Bennett of the Pope as a Turnip propped up by a musket, L.N. knocking away the prop. .. T.T. suggests Father Thames saying to M.P., “Your hands are as dirty as mine” … accepted, Shirley and H.S. giving the title, “Bribery and Corruption” [ Punch, 51 (15 September 1866): 113, “Bribery and Corruption”].
T.T. says at Cambridge, Tennyson was often quoting (from Shakespeare) these lines:
“O, the absurdity of wretched fools” (query, Shakespeare's?).

“You filthy knave, know you no reverence?”
“O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools!” (Measure for Measure, Act 5, Scene i); “You beastly knave, know you no reverence?” (King Lear, Act. II, Scene i).

div.head: September 12, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., H.M., H.S., C.H.B. J.T., M.L., E., P.L., F.C.B.
M.L. jolly after his Paris trip. Disgusted with the nudities of the French stage.

L.C. After one or two mild hints, we decide on a sporting subject and H.S., apropos of the Snider rifle suggests Punch as Head Keeper handing John Bull a breechloader in the gun room. M.L. amends to J.B. loading old muzzleloader: which we accept – reserving Pater's suggestion of Mars saying to Vulcan, “You'll destroy my business by your inventions.” [ Punch, 51 (29 September 1866): 133].
The British army converted its rifles to a breechloader design by American inventor Jacob Snider, then delayed paying him, although he was in want. Snider died the following month. See Times leaders October 18, 27, and 30, 1866. The Snider-Enfield remained the standard British Army rifle until 1871, and the standard rifle of the Army in India until the end of the century. P.L. had suggested American Eagle and Russian Bear fraternising. Russia seems threatening [Punch, 51 (22 September 1866): 123: “Sport in Earnest”].

F.C.B. contends that all miracles should be credited – including St. Januarius' blood – if one credits the tremendous miracle of God being born a little child. P.L. sneers at Januarius & Co. – never interfere when wanted. “But, Sir, how dare you dictate to a Saint?” says F.C.B. who argues with much humour and some force. Pater and H.M. are Unitarians. M.L. and J.T. not so – but don't accept the Athanasian Creed. Nobody does. Burnand says only they are damned who wilfully neglect the means of salvation. The creed applies to those in the Church only: not outsiders. P.L. talks about “Invincible Ignorance” and “Mortal Sins.”

div.head: September 19, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. in Church St., Woodbridge. To Bawdsey in the Helen with H. Thomas.

div.head: September 26, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M. , H.S., C.H.B, F.E., J.T., M.L., E.,P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.

L.C. T.T. suggests L. Napoleon and Bismarck and the Pope as the three Witches in Macbeth – amends it to the Three European Fates, each with a Fate – shadowy Clotho or Lachesis – behind him, ready to sever his thread of life: all three being now in ill health. Good – but too dismal for holiday time. ... Then he suggests a cut on the Primer squabble – boy puzzled by new grammar – ass in præsenti, idiot in futuro. Finally suggests Electioneering “Knockout” which we accept [Punch, 51 (6 October 1866): 143, An Electioneering ‘Knock-Out’”]. – tho' tis not really a knock out, but an auction.

D.M. had a touch of English cholera at Boulogne. 3000 visitors left in one day. How familiar seems his “Mark” and “Shirley” and “Ponny” – moi, que je suis modeste! D.M. and T.T. to Olympic to see T.T.'s dress rehearsal of “The Whiteboy,” written 20 years ago. H.S. followeth for a couple of acts – precious stupid – but H.S. is down in the mouth.

div.head: October 3, 1866. W[ednesday] No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., C.H.B., H S., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., F.C.B.
H.S. from Stanwick – 3 nights by the kitchen fire. This damp weather is dampnation.

L.C. “A shilling to the gentleman who will invent the Large Cut,” says Mark. Several abortions – at length J.T. revives Taylor's hint as to the New Primer. P.L. suggests the Doctors squabbling – F.E. amends to two Eton boys in front of the Squabblers, one replying, “O hang the Primer, – who's to be Captain of the Eight?” P.L. thinks we should try and hit the blot, and not care for the boyish view of the question – suggests the “Bewildered Schoolboy” – E. amends to the bewildered Schoolmaster, which we accept. H.S. had suggested the two Doctors (old and new grammar) prescribing for sick boy – sick of grammar. F.C.B. adds title: “The Schoolmaster Abroad”.
Benjamin Hall Kennedy’s Public School Latin Primer, published by Longmans in August, came under fierce criticism, including a letter to the Times from Robert Lowe complaining that it was much too difficult for young boys (October 31, 1866, p. 10). The Hall Kennedy primer remained a fixture of classical education in the British public schools into the 20th century. [Punch, 51 (13 October 1866): 153, “The Schoolmaster (All) Abroad”].

E. and P.L. and H.S. agree as to Beethoven being the best mental refresher. M.L. can relish Handel but not Beethoven: F.C.B. is sent to sleep by him. Saith P.L., “Swinburne sacrifices Prosody to Syntax” – saith D.M., “he's a Prosodomite.”
Du Maurier parodied Swinburne’s “Ballad of Burdens” as “Ballad of Blunders” in Punch 51 (December 1, 1866) 227). Swinburne would later write to tell Du Maurier how much he had enjoyed it. See Daphne du Maurier, The Young George du Maurier (1952), 299.

P.L. recounteth of Arnati, “I was alone in the Pope's Library – I mighta have stolen the rarest books – I have repented ever since that I did not do so – but perhaps I shall be rewarded hereafter for it.” We try to talk Latin – and can't find a better word for “yes” than “immo”.

div.head: October 10, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Glencham Hall – charade “Four-sea”: Australian's return and Gipsies – Misses Trowell and Luxmoore.

div.head: October 17, 1866. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., Tom A., S.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., F.C.b., C.K., H.M., T.T.

H.S. in better spirits than he was this day fortnight – thanks to Glencham and a bright day at Bythern yesterday. Motto for a Pawnbroker: “I know that my redeemer liveth” – profanely says D.M. Shirley says his boy said, “Ma, Jack the Giantkiller was stronger than than David – Goliath had but one head, Jack's Giant had three!”

D.M. tells of small boy being asked what Christ said to his parents when, after their long search, they found him in the Temple, “How's your poor feet?” S.B., “I wrote a farce for him.” E., “Was it damned?” S.B., “You'll know some day!”

L.C. The Marriage of the Adriatic and Venice, T.T. (apropos of Austria's Evacuation). S.B. amends to Pope as a blighted being watching King of Italy marching off with Bride Venetia – accepted [Punch, 51 (1866): 173: “Venetia Victrix”]. “Your turn some day, old lady.” S.B. also suggests “The Artful Doge – r” as a title, but it only sounds funny, would not look so, in print. Apropos of Bright's speeches and meetings, S.B. can't understand the force of multiplication – the British workman is a fool – and why are 20,000 fools more worth listening to, or caring for, than one? T.T., “We are a stupid people – more misery and poverty than elsewhere in the world.”
- Child: “Ma – I've caught a flea in the book – I think it's at page 172.” C.H.B.
- Louis Napoleon: – “The Merchant of Venice” – regular sell. S.B.

- S.B. quotes with admiration Ford's lines: “They are the silent griefs that cut the heartstrings: let me die smiling.”
Dramatist John Ford (1586-c. 1637). The quotation is from his tragedy, The Broken Heart (1633).

- Before dinner M.L. and H.S. talk anent Mrs. Leech – who rejected offer from B. E. & Co. of £1000 for copyrights: J.L. £2,000 in their debt. M.L. and H.S. agree in advising her to accept it.
Anne Leech did accept the sum and the agreement, in a deed dated February 16, 1867. See George Wirgman Hemming, ed., Law Reports, Division I. Chancery, Vol 12 (London: Clowes & Son, 1879), 809, cited in the case of Hole v. Bradbury, June 17, 1879. Sale most likely to decrease. Will she let her house? …

And so much for my last bachelor Punch Dinner – a pleasant one enough. After it, to the Princess's with H. Gascoyen to see the quaint French dancers.
Silver married Blanche Renouf on October 27, 1866.

div.head: December 5, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champagne.
div.p: F.E. D.M., H.S., F.C.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., C.K., H.M., S.B.

F.E. the first to shake my hand and then a general hand-shaking and chorus, “I congratulate you, Silver” – the Silver Wedding. “Worth while marrying in France to eat a wedding breakfast. How you would have relished the Cèpes, Professor!”
“Let Silver enjoy a little English – don't speak French, Shirley,” says M.L.

So they all drink our healths in tumblers of champagne – when enters F.C.B. ignorant and doesn't see the joke when Ponny says, “Don't you see Silver?” But what's a wedding to a writer of burlesques: a poor joke at best. “À outrance” right, says D.M. But Froissart writes “à l'outrance” (Blanche confirms D.M.) F.E. gets up and stumbles through a speech to drink our healths in Claret – all upstanding and cheering in the true good British style, which to my ears sounds far heartier than the glass-clinking of the French folk. I thank them, and hope that “Sooner or Later” I may show them my wife.

L.C. Apropos of the Reform March thro’ Pall Mall on Monday (200,000 expected, and 20,000 present – M. de Somerville said “a meellion would marrch with Mr. Braight”) – P.L. suggests Derby as omnibus cad telling rough looking would be voters that there's no room inside. S.B. amends to Derby pointing to Sot: “Is that your friend for Manhood Suffrage?” And M.L. amends by substituting Punch for Derby – which we accept [Punch, 51 (15 December 1866): 243, “Manhood Suffrage”]. Then I go to Charing Cross and find my wife (how naturally the word comes to my lips), half buried in the clean warm fine sheets and blankets. “Smoky, but pleasant” kisses. Dear little girl! She is very tired, but wakes up at my advent. “How thick is the air!”

div.head: December 12, 1866. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., C.H.B., S.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., F.C.B., C K., H.M., T.T.
H.S. at Sipington[?] S.B. writes to ask us for the 31st very kindly.
Almanack produced. Writers thank the artists – and D.M. thanks the writers for leaving so much room. Pater relishes D.M.'s gymnastics for ladies.

L.C. French leaving Rome the subject, says T.T., and suggests Pope to Canute and Mrs. Partington, “Did the Sea (of public opinion) go back?” E. suggests Pope reviewing his ragged army. S.B. says Pusey talks of Officers confessing – fancy a swell in the box! T.T. suggests Punch as Confessor and Peto and Givency confessing. ... F.C.B. suggests Pope as Lear – Catholicism, Cordelia. France and Italy, Regan and Goneril. Good from a Romanist point, perhaps. W.B. Late arrival at Cattle Show, a Papal Bull. S. B. Pope to Italy, “Now he's gone (Napoleon), let us talk together, my dear” accepted. [ Punch, 51, (22 December 1866) 253, “Rome. 1866.” ].
Lady writing in red ink, “She means she can't receive you tonight.” S.B. – “Hides her talents in a napkin.”

F.C.B. repeats: – “A blind beggar had a brother who died. Deceased had no brother. What relation was the blind beggar to the deceased?” My brains are leaden – quantum mutatus ab illo Henrico in 1859. Can hardly make a joke now. My heart's in the Midlands with my other heart and my brains are with it.
D.M. tells of little boy of some artist saying to Miss Ionides: “If you are a Greek girl, why are you not naked?”
S.B., I never knew what was meant by “the tyranny of numbers” till I began to write a serial tale. “Sooner or Later” started last month.
C.H.B. and W.B. congratulate me. T.T. doesn't open his lips. More genial at his own table than at Mr. Punch's, says D.M. ... who had a little girl t'other day. Et ego ... ?

P.L. last week talked of one-eyed M.P.'s. D.M. said “Tenniel and I agree that one-eyed men are very clever.” Next day both had letters from Professor explaining that he meant no allusion to them .... Tonight he is silent even when Burnand defends the Pope. Then he suddenly says, “Have you heard any good thing in the week?” apropos des bottes – and falls down as he used to do – and is inebriate without having drunk. Dear old boy. Horace helpeth.

div.head: December 17, 1866. No. 11.
div.p: Present: all except Bennett and Keene.

Christmas Day on a Tuesday, so we must go to press on Friday. “Our bloated Editor” (says Jackides) eats heartily of roast pig, which Du Maurier never before tasted. Shades of Elia!
“A Dissertation upon Roast Pig” appears in Charles Lamb’s Essays of Elia.

L. C. M.L. suggests Bright and Lowe under mistletoe – foes must forgive at the festive season. “Letsh shwear 'ternal friendship,” adds J.T. Some- body objects to men kissing – but of course they need only shake hands [Punch, 51 (29 December 1866): 263, “The Festive Season”]. Shirley, when he has suggested something good, throws his knife on the table and says, “There's your cut,” and breathes hard. “I say, what d'ye think of – “ here followeth the suggestion.
P.L. “going to perform avuncular functions.”“Turn pawnbroker?” H.M.
F.C.B. tells of little girl with a shilling offered an eightpenny doll. “No, I want a s'lling one.” Would the salesman swindle her?
Vide Almanack for the birthdays of the Punch men. H.S. to Orpington at 8.30.

div.head: December 26, 1866. W[ednesday].
div.p: Being Boxing Day, a cold collation at four p.m. and a visit to the Forty Thieves at Covent Garden. But H.S. is at Woodbridge. [Punch, 52 (2 February 1867): 46 “Gladiators Preparing for Arena.”]

div.head: January 2, 9, 16. [1867] H.S. at Woodbridge.
div.p: January 23, 1867. H.S. in bed after the thaw ce matin at Grosvenor Hill, Wimbledon.

div.head: January 30, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present all the regulars except Fred, Mark and Frank (Burnand). W.B. in chair, Shirley Vice.
Tom Taylor tells of small boy being told that God is everywhere and saying, “Then how can he move about?” ... Curious metaphysical power.

D.M. tells of Burne-Jones' boy frightening a companion, “If you're good you'll go to Heaven, but if you're naughty you'll go to a still nastier place.” P.L. tells of churchwarden complaining to Bishop of parson's puseyistical reading lessons from his lectern (rectum) ... “Must be in bad odour with his congregation.”
Shirley says music is simply emotional in its influence. Jimmy Davison would howl at this! No one cries at a picture .. nerves directly affected by sound, hence music brings tears (says Tom).
L.C. Tom suggests Derby under the sword of Damocles “Reform” – Dizzy reaching to clutch it. “Fall by it or fight with it.” But the fable is spoiled so.
S.B. Bright “the Piper” whistling to “a pair of Nutcrackers” – Derby and Dizzy cracking the Reform Nut.
S.B., History repeats itself – Johnson, the President impeached, like Chas. I.

S.B., Bright going to the House (meets on Tuesday) and whipping off the dogs, Potter Beales & Co. “I'm going to business now, you dogs; no more use for you.” S.B., Apropos of Workmen's Meeting about Empty Churches .. “Why don't you come to Church?”“Why don't the church come to me?”

S.B., “The Lions at Last” “More things, Horatio!” Northumberland Lion snarling at them: in a separate cut. Which we accept [ Punch, 52 (9 February 1867), 57 “The Lions at Last.” ]
In a diary entry of this date, Shirley Brooks notes, “Mark away, so I took his place & got them to do a non-political cut, about the Nelson Lions, which are to be uncovered this week.” (British Library) The gigantic statues of lions at the base of Nelson’s Column had been commissioned in 1859 from Sir Edwin Landseer, but were delayed for years while the artist worked on other commissions. The delays had long been a standing joke in the capital by the time the statues were finally unveiled in 1867. For Tenniel’s opinion of their merits, see Silver’s entry for February 13, 1867.
Dear Mr. Lemon,

“The Lost Pleiad” has been discovered in London at last, and may be seen daily with the naked eye. My wife says London is Beestly in comparison with Bordeaux, but that I am a bon garçon and we English are not such Brutes as she expected. We go to Mrs. Leech's house next week for a few months, to see how Kensington air suits French lungs, and I hope you will now and then condescend (as Bloated Editor) to come and see your heretofore wandering contributor. Feb. 1, 1867.

div.head: February 6, 1867. _W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., F.E., S.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., W. Agnew, H.M.

Agnew wishes me joy in wedlock. What is the key to it? – A quiet life? Pater does not wonder that my wife feels saddened by the climate. Poor child, this winter with its zero and its lack of sunshine is bien triste after a girlhood in Bordeaux. Le mal du pays affects her a little. … Especially when I am away from her – as for instance today. ... But I have faith and hope she will live to love cet affreux pays. We move from Park House (and tough chicken) to Mrs. Leech's tomorrow.
The Silvers moved into what had been John Leech’s house, No. 6, The Terrace, Kensington. In his diary for April 1, 1867, Shirley Brooks records his first visit to the couple there: “We dined at poor J. Leech’s house, now in the occupation of the newly wed Henry Silver & met his wife for the first time. Much pleased with her. The furniture is Mrs Leech’s, & it was like a theatrical scene—old properties, but a change of actors. Ainsi va la monde. A very good dinner & wine good—Mrs H.S.’s papa is in the line—but he did not give me a weed, which was fiendish.” (British Library)

D.M. was at Norwich with Jekyl the architect some ten years ago, and talks how he charmed the rustics with his midnight songs. And used to drive home semi inebriate and sup chez la mère Sapey. I bethink me of one night after the Election of Peto and a bonfire in the market place, when I turned into a sheetless bed with a sanded floor beneath me. Eheu fugaces! How jolly one felt then with a sixpenny spree!
Queen opened Parliament yesterday – first time since Prince Albert died. And yesterday we buried Uncle James, who would have been ninety in April!

L.C. M.L. suggests Lord Russell sputtering like a spoilt child at having to eat Reform from Derby's spoon. ... H.M. amends to Derby as Squeers [in Dickens' Nicholas Nickleby] giving Reform brimstone and treacle to old Tories like General Peel. .. S.B. alters this to Derby as Schoolmaster making Peel & Co. spell “free extension of the franchise.” . . . awful amount of screw put on to squeeze these words into Queen's speech. S.B. suggests Dizzy as the Asian Mystery, conjuring Peel & Co. into being so liberal. M.L. suggests Russell crying to Derby, “He's taken away my baby!” ...The Lost child. Russell as a Nurse with a perambulator, says H.S., but this is not accepted. M.L.'s is [Punch, 52 (16 February 1867): 67 “Political Kidnapping”]

S.B. Women screw a sixpence from a cabman and give a shilling to a beggar. Beastly honest they are...give them a little money, they are sure to pay your debts, instead of letting tradesmen wait and having a trip out. Apropos of Hepworth Dixon's book on “New America” (too long and too made up) Shirley says a man wants 4 wives at least: an intellectual wife to talk to, a sensual one to kiss, a clever one to cook and one to sew his buttons on. P.L. says woman's intellect supplies the vacancies in man's…quicker instincts but no reasoning. M.L. “I never argue with my wife…I say ‘no’ twice, and then hold my tongue.”
“Hepworth Dixon-ary of the language at Utah” says J.T., after H.S. had thought it.

We look at Ponny's usual French budget of filth… Auvergnat actor pronounces ici in such a way that the king says, “Portez lui les papiers.” – “La Lune” and “Le Journal Amusant” entertain their readers constantly with little “jocks” like this. “Il a gamarouche la contesse, son chapeau sur la tête!!”D.M. quotes this and says he does not fear le Dieu Français .. who is in everybody's mouth. The English are more reverential to their God.

div.head: February 13, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present: Sixteen! J.H. Agnew and Bradbury Senior absent.
A double magnum of champagne from Ponny. But not a magnum bonum.

Three years ago I wished for a wife and No. 6, the Terrace, which I saw to be let, furnished. “Have then thy wish the monarch cried.” Tom Taylor defends his eulogy of the Lions. Owen approves them. Tenniel thinks the treatment weak and the hind quarters too large: a lion looks meager behind. Paws too thick, says H.S. Mane does not mass finely.

“Burnand,” says Tom T., “isn't that man acting at the Soho Culverwell, the quack?” – “I don't know, I'm sure – but he doesn't dress the part.” – “Bravo!” cries Shirley, and placards this “prize mot.” – But I doubt if Burnand knew the pith of it.

L.C. T.T. suggests Diz as the Great Medicine Man – apropos of his windy speech on Monday. We are to proceed by Reform resolutions – which he kept dark till Tuesday's Times. S.B. thinks the Government should be attacked for saying they would not make it a vital question: “Heads I win, tails you lose.” Which we accept – after P.L. has proposed Dizzy dancing a hornpipe in fetters. [Punch, 52 (23 February 1867): 77, “Heads I Win, Tails You Lose”]. Burnand suggests Diz as medicine man dancing hornpipe and crying, “Heads I win” etc. so as to combine all three notions! T.T. savage that his cut is not taken – Diz always proves himself a humbug: can't act straightforwardly. He is the Vivian Grey he described when he was 21.
Shirley Brooks noted in his diary about this meeting, “The fullest possible—everybody & two Agnews, 16 in all. A good fight over the cut, TT very persistent, but I defeated him, and carried mine.” (British Library)

div.head: February 20, 1867. W[ ednesday] No. 11 champ.
div.p: Present: all but old B. and the Agnew Trio.
A Princess born at 6 this morning, so we have champagne. ... Sala gets £40 a week from the Daily Telegraph.
Rembrandt is remarkable for his poetry and invention: saith Taylor the critic.

Ducrow
Andrew Ducrow (1793-1842) was a circus performer who pioneered equestrian acts. For the last fifteen years of his life he was proprietor of Astley’s Amphitheatre. For a profile of Ducrow that includes a story of his complaining that his groom “got the pig” (that is, a roasting-pig), see the extensive profile, “Andrew Ducrow,” All the Year Round, February 3, 1872, 223-229. dixit to M.L.: “If I could hire a man to f— God save the Queen! The public loves novelty.” “There's enough of the dialect, Sir, now bring in the 'orses.” “My groom robs me of the hay and gets the pig given him for buying it.” He was the best circus rider ever known, says Pater.
Shirley wishes Tenniel to modernise the John Bull he draws – and whom Arbuthnot invented.

L.C. the 3 Graces, Diz Juno, Bright Venus (back view), Gladstone Minerva: J.Bull Paris, with the Reform apple, T.T. – Better make them old apple women, slanging one another: E. The Canada Confederation, 4 fine children dancing round Britannia: M.L. – amended by T.T. to Miss Canada, “Dear me, how she's grown!” – Bright, Diz and Gladstone on the brink of Reform, John Bull saying, “Now, then, go in, some of you!” T.T. – Diz wants to wade, not plunge. P.L. – Bank Parlour a doubtful Bill – P.L. – Horse Reform, Diz says “He'll go well when he's warm,” J.T. “No more false starts” H.S. – A Liberal Conversazione (apropos of next Tuesday's meeting) examining the Bill, Russell on tiptoe to look thro’ microscope – S.B. – Knocker tied up, Gladstone and Bright as Nurses outside, Diz at window “The party's suited, my dears, but I'm 'appy to make an arrangement,”- T.T. Diz as Iago, “Demand me nothing: what you know, you know” P.L. “Carry it among you” M.L. . . Bill lying in J.Bull's doorway, S.B. – Improved by P.L. to Reform Engine off the line. accepted [Punch, 52 (2 March 1867): 87, “A Block on the Line”].
Mark says Mrs. L[eech] received her £1000 yesterday. She leaves her house today.

div.head: February 27, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., J.T., S.B., E., P.L., HLM.

“Eve of St. Jackides” placarded in red print over the fireplace – where hangeth the first sketch of “Mr. Punch's Fancy Ball”. So we drink Tenniel's health for tomorrow. How young he looks for 47. Shirley proud of having suggested two of Tenniel's finest Cuts – viz., the Bengal Tiger, and the Gladiators. The latter had some details filled in by T.T.

L.C. T.T. by letter suggests Diz as Auctioneer “try something else – take away that Lot” – apropos of his withdrawing the Reform Resolutions last Mon- day, or as an Old Clo'man: or Pantomime trick of Reform emerging in spangles from the Tory – or Cabinet at Sea, Diz at helm, “We must cut away our top hamper (resolutions) to save the Ship.” Or Diz as the New Medea bringing Reform out of the enchanted cauldron. All this is written in Tom's unreadable scrawl, which Shirley tries to decipher.
S.B. suggests Diz as an actor with 2 prompters – General Peel on one side urging Toryism and a more liberal member of Government on the other.

J.T. suggests Diz about to be attacked by Gladstone & Co. as brigands pretending to be friends and saying melodramatically, “We must dissemble.” H.S. suggests Gladstone & Co. with their daggers drawn behind their backs saying to Derby, “Let us swear eternal friendship”: for of course they mean to turn him out for all their protestation of unwillingness to do so. F.E. suggests Reform as a central figure in some way. S.B., “Yes, make her a pretty girl saying, 'Who will woo me?'“ P.L., “Would you gain the tender creature?” S.B., “Capital Polyphemus, Bright!” the thundering giant roars.” ... But it won't be understood. So let's have Diz and Gladstone as Counsel – “We can settle it in five minutes – if it wasn't for the ‘parties’.” Which we accept – H.S. suggesting the title, “Before the Trial” [ Punch, 52 (9 March 1867): 97, “Before the Trial”].

Next Monday Cranbourne, Peel and Lord Carnavon resign – so Diz perhaps may pass a bill. Shirley first dined with the Punch lot on the first Tuesday in May 1852. I remember meeting him not long after, talking to Mark who introduced me as a fellow worker. “But at the bottom of the tree,” said I, “and Mr. Brooks is at the top.” What a reverence I felt then for the staff, and how proud I was of shaking hands with one of them. The Punch table talk was wittier then than now. Gil à Beckett was a big eater, they say. Like Tom Taylor with his ostrich stomach.

div.head: March 6, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., F.E., J.T., S.B. P.L., C.K.. H.M.
“Feast of St. Kikius” Why is D.M. called Kiki? Shirley tells of Bishop and German governesses who thought our church kind in praying for the governesses – “all women labouring with the child.”

L.C. T.T. in his hieroglyphs suggests (apropos of the 3 deserters) the Ministers at Sea – 'Gladstone coming to throw them a rope: – or Diz and Derby fighting for a policy: or the Ship, “Administration” with at least a dozen figures – charming for Tenniel! How dull suggestions are when by letter! M.L. suggests Derby Dilly nearly upset – Manager Derby at rehearsal and three chief actors throwing up their parts (good, but will be forgotten next week).
Mark Lemon’s suggestions, like Tom Taylor’s, had also been sent by letter. The letter, which is in the Huntington Library, runs as follows:
31 Bedford Street [letterhead’s “27 Bouverie” x’d out]
Wednesday March 6, 1867
Dear Shirley,
I am so much better to-day that I think I risk too much in coming out such a day as this is. I offer the result of my meditation.
The Derby Dilly in a Mess
Derby driving – Disraeli as leader pulling forward – the three jibbing[?]
The Corner[?] of St. Petersberg on four horses – Three restive – one going
Reading a New Piece
The manager of St. Stephens in a Fix – Throwing up their parts. Derby (manager) – Disraeli (author). The three discontents.
The Divided Household – Derby or the Queen
Well if you can’t agree with your fellow servants you must go. The work must be done.
—All very stupid—
Love to the boys
Ever yours,
Mark Lemon
The Irish rising will be too serious a subject for the Cut won’t it?

W.B. Mrs. Gamp (from Dickens' Martin Chuzzlewit) in a fluster. C.K., Diz riding a steeplechase, riding at a big ditch “Reform” with his eyes shut – Gladstone and Bright, “Won't he come a cropper?” …altered by S.B. to Derby telling him, “You must ride to win.” .. S.B. – Diz the Prophète, with the 3 Anabaptists who give him bad advice, and finally destroy him – good – but doesn't quite fit. S.B., Derby jumping through hoop, “Reform,” (old). W.B., 3 rats (Cranbourne, Peel and Lord Carnavon) leaving the ship. S.B. Macbeth, Derby and the 3 witches, “We told you so,” Gladstone as Macduff. C.K.. Derby as Shopkeeper, “Shove in another spoonful, Ben, the inspectors is a watching” (Gladstone and Russell) – Shirley amends this false weight to a false measure – “Froth it up.” – J.T. amends to “Don't froth it up this time,” which we accept, Fred proposing as a title, “The Honest Pot- boy” [Punch, 52, (16 March 1867): 107, “The Honest Potboy”].

D.M. and H.S. are usually mutes when the L.C. is discussed. H.M. tells the old retort to Lord Sandwich, “Mr. Wilkes, shall I see you poxed or hung?” “That depends, my lord, whether I embrace your politics or your mistress.” It would have been stronger, had he said “wife” says the Professor. Poor Phillip (R[oyal] A[cademy]) died last Wednesday – just 50.
John Phillip (1817-1867), painter. Shirley Brooks’s diary entry for February 27, 1867, reads: “John Phillip died this day at 5 o’clock, without suffering. …So goes a brave, good man, one of the few whom I really loved. He was a year or two younger than myself, but he looked 60, & I always regarded him as an elder… There were 3 men of genius in the RA, he, Millais, & Landseer—now there are 2.” (British Library) I remember him at Arthur Lewis's – black skull cap and thoughtful gizzly bearded face. Began life as a cowboy and then a house painter. Shirley describes his Highland lodge in this month's “Sooner or Later.” D.M. says the greatest effect music produces is when a man, far from his country, hears an air he heard at home. In a flash all his boyhood comes to his mind – as men when drowning remember their whole life. C.K. contends that the pleasure of music is in the song not in the singer – cares little for a good voice. Leigh says, “My way of enjoying music is the best – a good dinner, and then a good seat – alone. If you have a chatterer next you, all enjoyment ceases – in the middle of the Requiem you hear, “Gracious, what a frightful headdress!” Charles and I walk home together – precious cold: snows before the morning.

div.head: March 13, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., H.S., H.M., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., W. Agnew, T.T.

Agnew has been viewing poor Phillip's paintings and we discuss his merits – A. ranks him with the four great English masters, – Reynolds, Turner, Landseer and ? – . Tenniel concurs and says “for noble breadth of treatment and grand manner of painting Philip stood alone in English modern art – far above Millais even.- Ponny alludes to Shirley's graphic description of Philip's Highland home in this month's “Sooner or Later,” to which, strangely enough, Shirley himself referred at this table a fortnight since, when Philip was just dying and we knew it not. Agnew says Shirley's brief words on the death, in last week's Punch, went straight to his heart.
“Obiit 27 February 1867,” Punch, 52 (3 March 1867): 95. His wife's madness declared itself before the birth of her first child – who has shown signs of insanity. She having lived apart some while prayed to be taken to his bed, and then broke out in the maddest language. Fancy the scene! And the fear that his children might inherit the insanity! No wonder he looked old at 49.

Ponny ranks Hogarth far above Leech – but Agnew thinks Leech's work will live as long, mainly because they please children and whatever pleases children will live: e.g. Robinson Crusoe and Arabian Nights. M. L. instances, as a proof of Leech' s pathos and power, the Haymarket scene, “How long have you been gay.”
“The Great Social Evil,” Punch, 33 (12 September 1857) 114 Agnew recalls the deathbed of the clown's daughter in “Once a Week”: but thinks L[eech] was not good at illustration generally. I differ. M.L. thinks he never could have been a colourist – had not the patience – his genius was too quick in invention. I think the great difference between him and other Punch artists is that his cuts amuse you in themselves: of course the words beneath enhance their effect, but the drawings can stand alone – and few others can.
Tenniel delights in a circus. And so do we all – perhaps H.S. less than most.

Albert Smith wrote in pencil and then copied for the printer. Stingy beggar, had a lithographed circular refusing charity. Gus Mayhew received one and scourged him at the Fielding – Gus having lectured on Constantinople for him, improvising Turkish and declining any pay.

Mark thinks a farce would be funny, scene laid in Rome B.C. 190 – ancient togas and modern talk. Tell how he wrote – i.e. – translated “Don Caesar” at Paris and sold it there for £100 to Jew Maddox – who at rehearsal tried to jew him out of the proper properties: “There'sh a goblet – shines like gold” – “Suppose you'll want a glory next!” – (a revolving star).
Sothern will play Dundreary at Paris for Knowles, of Manchester, at £350 a week. Tom agrees in ranking him as a one-play actor. And in thinking Kate Terry would please the French.

L.C. Tom suggests Dizzy as the cat and Gladstone as the monkey watching the Reform Chestnuts – amends it to Diz playing Blind Man's Buff – “turn round thrice and see who you'll catch, to help you” – Bright – Gladstone – or old Tory – accepted [Punch, 52 (23 March 1867): 119, “Blind Man's Buff”]: in preference to Shirley's Diz gilding the Reform Pill – and Mark's Diz as Leotard flying to Household Suffrage to cling to – and Burnand's Venus rising from the W.C. – a joke from Nottingham, where he is performing in his Blackeyed Susan.
Home in a snowstorm!!!

div.head: March 20, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Present – all but Bennett – Burnand – and the Agnews.

Tom Taylor says brassiness in actors is a sign of incapacity: e.g. Sothern: Dundreary et praeterea nihil. Yet he makes £8,000 a year and gives monster dinners – which must be monstrous bores. A man with brass has no imagination and therefore cannot act. Since Robson there has been no genius on the English stage. Wigan is the best actor now – and he has left the stage.

L.C. Dual voting might be duel voting, says Tom, if Mill had his way and wives were to vote. In the Reform lull Shirley thinks this question of Women Voters might do for the cut – and we agree to his suggestion of Mill escorting a lady to the poll. Tom thinks we might introduce her disgust at being called a “person” – but this is fitter for an article [Punch, 52 (30 March 1867) 129, “Mill's Logic; or, Franchise for Females” ].
T.T. discourseth on somnia humida ... “a sign of health” says the Professor. Sed query?
What a wintry March! My wife might sue me for breach of promise of sunshine.

Saith Du Maurier, “Why not attend more to the breeding of mankind – select brides and grooms according to their physique.” And Shirley suggests a pretty picture of a thin spare fellow proposing for a thin girl and her father saying, “Pauleana! No, Fatima is the girl you want.” Also he imagines a lover saying, “Dearest. I adore you – but tell me, is there Scrofula in your family.”
D.M. quotes, “Arrête le movement, “Zoë,” la pièce est fausse” ... He has blue devils
because of his eyes. And I because ... But we all have our troubles ... and every one fancies his the worst.
D.M. dreams of loving old women. “Sensuality and decrepitude” says Tom. “Ballet girls G'lisley[?],” M.L.

div.head: March 27, 1867 . W[ ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: B., DI.ML., HI.Sl., Tom Agnew, L. (moved his throne), S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L. , F.C.B., C.K., H.M., T.T.

Burnand has been starring in the provinces as “Captain Crosstree ... is my name.” Enjoys acting – more than I should. Envy him his spirits tho! After the business tonight he amuses us by writing a semi-legible letter on official business to Tom Taylor – who never writes legibly – adding “P.S., On second thought, never mind.” Professor doesn't see the joke at first and tries to make out the gibberish.

L.C. P.L. suggests, apropos of the Reform Muddle “Too many cooks.” Diz on Monday said Government would keep in till a bill was passed. ... Also suggests the Cyclops forging a bill .... hammering into shape a shapeless mass also suggests Bears licking it into shape ... good, but nasty. M.L. suggests Diz looking out of window at lodgers, “Hope to take you in after the 8th (date for Reform Committee). S.B. amends to 3 types of lodgers, the Swell, the Clerk, and the Workman – and P.L. suggests a good title, “The Irrepressible Lodger” [Punch, 52 (6 April 1867): 139, “The ‘Irrepressible Lodger’”].

P.L. defines a Philistine to be one who sacrifices truth and justice to the main chance. A German student word it is, applied to men not of the 'Varsity.' The Times is a Philistine, says S.B. – T.T. dreamt Princess was dead the night her last baby came. Dreams by contraries.

div.head: April 3, 1867. W[ednesday].
div.p:
Intelligence of poor Bennett's death yesterday. So we don't dine.
Prolific and much loved illustrator Charles H. Bennett (1828-1867) had joined Punch in 1865. The Punch staff performed at a benefit at the Adelphi Theatre for his widow and children on May 11.

div.head: April 10, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H. M.

T.T. by hieroglyph suggests Derby and Diz in sledge, throwing “Dual Voting” etc. to the Wolves. A capital subject, says Mark. “Plenty of snow,” says Tenniel, who consents to a double page, “for this once.” [Punch, 52 (20 April 1867): 160-161, “They’re Saved, They’re Saved!”] Then we talk of Bennett's family: 8 children and 1 coming, and no debts. Life too hazardous for insurance. Surely a case for a public appeal. Press private channels also. I guarantee £50 – and every man might surely do the like.
Join B. and E. at the Lyceum. “Blaunche” pleased with Duke's Motto.

div.head: April 17, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M. (late), H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.

Champagne to Tenniel – his “They're Saved!” a great success. Frith has written to congratulate him, and Prince of Wales has sent for a proof. Mark talks of his feeling sure it would be a grand cut – and complains that the Professor called it “mere commonplace record” (!) and C.K. rather snubbed the notion. Tom, the father, regrets Tenniel did not make wolves tearing Gladstone down, and so stopping their chase.

We all consider it Tenniel's grandest cut since The Bengal Tiger. (Shirley tomorrow when we dine with him specifies the upset of Diz's donkey cart, by Pam's Derby Drag, as being very happy.) Mark thinks the sale won't be increased above 2,000 by the cut this week. But such triumphs tell in the long run.

M.L. suggests America's new purchase – from Russia – a lot of ice not worth buying. – A Polar Bear, adds T.T., America's pet. T.T. suggests fancy sketch of the “Compound Householder,” a pot of porter on one side and Temperance League on the other. – But this may stand over. – P.L. suggests Spain eating humble pie, the Tornado question – or Spanish Bobadil ... S.B. amends to Spain John Bullfighting, and T.T. adds the notion of a row of heads, frightened looking over the arena, not daring to fight the Bull. Call it “The Spanish Fly” says Shirley ... or, A Bull they won't fight [Punch, 52 (27 April 1867): 171 “The Bull They Wouldn't Fight”].

D.M. has been to a Jew's wedding, that young cheeky Phillips, son of the tribe of Benjamin, late Lord Mayor, who played billiards with us at Brighton, to Helen Levy of the tribe of Daily Telegraph. The glass broken in due form. Ceremony impressive.

A noisy evening – Pater and I fraternise anent Beethoven, whose Pastoral I heard on Saturday – what a sermon it is! Happy he who can truly relish it! I listen so intently that it actually fatigues me. Odd that Shirley's far higher intellect should be deaf to such music. The highest kind of poetry. P.L. quiet, because he is acquiescent – but contends for Scott's lines in Rokeby about the lance is broke and the turret smoke as being a fine subject for music. No, I say, the thoughts are too numerous. Shirley cites the last lines of Tennyson's Exhibition Ode as being finer for music. But a musician wants a theme only – not words.

div.head: April 24, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. dines in Cadogan Place with Mrs. Nicolls.

div.head: May Day, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.

Champagne to Shirley's birthday – Monday last? And Mark's daughter’s today – Mrs. Martin. He quotes an epigram of his on Charles Mackay's “Under Green Leaves”: A t-d al fresco is his type, methinks Under green leaves Charles Mackay squats and stinks. “Conversation pieces? – pity wh-res were not conversation pieces in my time,” S.B.
Another rival “Judy” starts today. The best joke in it is its disclaimer of any attempt to imitate Punch: being outwardly a close copy.

Apropos of our Bennett performance Shirley wants to introduce some apropos speech such as “Yes I am but a locksmith, and tho' honest have no vote.” P.L. amends to “Brown as these fingers may be, they are unstained by slipping through the thin film of The Morning Star.” A brave army of two, Ponny and I! First rehearsal today – which I did not attend: being one of the Personae Mutae.

Shirley suggests that every dog should wear a stamped collar, as proof that tax is paid. Also that no vote be given to the British workman who uses the word Bloody more than twice a minute when he talks. Whence came this frequent oath? Was it used in Shakespeare's time? Yes, says Tom, “Be bloody, bold, and resolute” [Macbeth, IV,2]. “Bloody bawdy villain!” [Hamlet 11,2].
Tom's boy asked his mother, “Ma, do you know there's a fish here called a bugger – one of the boys today said, 'Here's a bugger under this stone.'“
Tom tells of soldier in Crimea, “Some d–d indecent b–r has been scratching c– upon my pannikin!”
S.B. tells of man complaining that his sister's sweetheart is illiterate – “I've looked through his love letters, and he always spells c– with a k.”

L.C. J.T. suggests something anent the tailor's strike and Tom says, “Yes – Dizzy mending the Constitution and Gladstone saying “I've struck” – which we approve [Punch, 52 (11 May 1867): 193, “The Political Tailors”]. Gladstone's letter t'other day says he virtually gives up the leadership of opposition.

div.head: May 8, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. dineth in Holland Park ... and converseth with Kate Robinson.

div.head: May 15, 1867. W[ednesday]. At Crawley.
div.p: All the regulars present except Burnand ... and Elus W. Agnew. Drive thither on the Brighton coach. Mark on the box. S.B. and D.M. in front: rest behind. Christening of Mark's granddaughter, Miss Martin ... whose papa guides us among the iron pits in the wood. Discover a white blue bell. Anent next week's Derby, T.T. in praise of Dizzy suggests his winning as the Favorite. H.S. objects that the race is not over – and Shirley amends to “Wait till they are weighed,” in adds M.L. [But Punch, 52 (25 May 1867): 215, “The Derby, 1867. Dizzy Wins with ‘Reform Bill’”] In the Sweep I draw Van Amburgh.

div.head: May 22, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: All the regulars: except F.C.B. and T.T.

Snow on the Derby Day! Just before the Prince passed us at Balham – not smoking. Never before a Punch Dinner on the Derby Day! C.K. applauds it – D.M. thinks it a sign we are growing into old fogydom. True.

Hermit wins – the sweep for Professor and me, and we give our sweep to the Bennett fund.
Henry Chaplin, a friend of the Prince of Wales, won the 1867 Derby with his now-legendary thoroughbred, Hermit, against long odds. The race’s outcome ruined Chaplin’s bitter enemy, the Marquis of Hastings, who lost £120,000 as a result.
“Paul and Vagina” says Mark – apropos de quelque chose. Paul Bedford?

L.C. P.L. suggests Dizzy as Mephisto – offering Elixir Vitae of Reform to rejuvenesce John Bull. But Faust came to grief – and John, we hope, won't. He approves Lowe's black prophetic speech of Monday, ... and the same evening Mill spoke up for Woman Votes. Shirley applauds the speech as the best for years. Suggests cut à la Criminal, “I never knew how wretchedly I was used till you told me.”' Accepted. [Punch, 52 (1 June 1867): 225, “The Ladies' Advocate”].
Shirley Brooks’s diary entry of this date notes of this meeting: “For the first time in its life Punch dined in council on the Derby Day. Which shows that we are older, if not wiser. I suggested the cut, on Mill’s fine speech in favour of female voting. Rather a pleasant evening. Home early.” (British Library)
M.L. suggests Mill as Giant killer slaying City Gog and Magog, apropos of his speech for making London one – instead of City and Metropolitan.

P.L. grows eloquent in declaiming against Parliament – how they truckle for place – who will bid the best for popularity – how even the Tories grow Radical – in short echoes Lowe. And begs pardon for vehemence. “No one need fear plainspeaking at the Punch table,” says Shirley.

div.head: May 29, 1867. W[ednesday] . No. 11. champ.
div.p: B., Tom Agnew, H.S., J., J.H.Agnew. F.E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., W. Agnew.
P.L. detaileth how a schoolboy misread a long old-fashioned S. “It is a vulgar error to suppose the hedgehog sucks the cow.” . . . “Has pricks enough to do it,” says Mark.

L.C. P.L. suggests Diz as the Reform Proteus rider throwing waistcoats off. C.K. quotes Spectator's suggestion of Diz, as Sphinx, dragged along by the Country Party Israelites, copy of Poynter's picture “Israel in Egypt” – but the picture's hardly known yet.
“Topics of the Day: Disraeli-Worship,” Spectator 40 (May 25, 1867): 572 And country farmers are not Jews. J.T. thinks something apropos of Burke – who is reprieved – not worth hanging – that's the point – S.B. quotes “I damn such fools! Go, go – you're bit.” Jupiter in Swift's lines
Jonathan Swift’s “The Day of Judgment” appeared in Lord Chesterfield’s Letters to his Son in 1774. ... Amends to John Bull as Mad Doctor – Burke melodramatic – “cut off me head – I'll be a martyr!”
