General Thomas F. Burke, who had been convicted of treason and sentenced to be hanged, was reprieved on May 27, partly as a result of a petition signed by 100 M.P.s.“Cut your head off! pooh! cut off your hair and clap a strait waistcoat on!” [Punch, 52 (8 June 1867): 235, “The Mad-Doctor.”]
Agnews praise Philip's pictures – to be sold on Saturday.
H.S. from Eastbourne today ... warm again. Hottest and coldest May on record.
93 degrees on the 7th and 27° on the 23rd.

div.head: June 5, 1867. W[ednesday]. At the Crystal Palace. cham.
div.p: W.B., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., D.M.

“Fireworks and Feasting” ... but the fireworks postponed till Saturday. ... Capital whitebait. No L.C. discussion. Mark has accepted the Spectator's idea of Diz as the Sphinx. [Punch, 52 (15 June 1867): 246-247, “D'Israel-i in Triumph.”]. Pater apologizes for not calling on Mrs. Silver ... and will dine with her on Tuesday. O the joyous days when one ate salmon and hot pickles! A sign of old fogydom that one is careful how one feeds. I can't stand the jumps from cold to heat and heat to cold this year. Have no appetite and no pluck. Quantum mutatus ab illo
“How changed from him” (C. Smith note). who first dined with the fellows at Richmond that Saturday in '57 and ate of every dish, while Peter Rackham who sat next to me scarce ate any but the whitebait and the mutton. I remember how Pater bowled a melon along the table – and how Bradbury half smoked the cigar I gave him – and how Shirley rehearsed the suggestion of a Big Cut, “The Order of Release” – Pam and the Parliament. And then I went to Croydon and δπμεδ [sic].

div.head: June 12, 1867. W[ednesday]. No.11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B. J.T., FE. P.L. H.M., Tom Agnew, T.T.
Photographed for the Bennett Fund today at one.
LC. Street brigands robbing in front of militia marching (last Monday week – five letters in Times).

H. S suggests Fra Diavolo in London – Agnew thinks the subject of no interest out of London, and that the rise in the funds, 5% in May, is the subject. T.T. suggests John Bull watching the growth of the plant, “Confidence.” Also apropos of the Czar & Co. at Paris, John Bull saying to Louis [Napoleon], “Oblige me with a few Sovereigns.” H.M. suggests Britannia saying, “No change for a Sovereign here” (Queen in perpetuity) ... also Czar knocking at Windsor Castle, “Queen not at home.” ... T.T. amends to, “Is your name Brown – No – ah, then she's not at home!” Fred suggests Louis as M.C. in the European Cotillon at Paris. But we revert to the Street brigands and T.T. suggests the remedy, “Letting the ‘harmless necessary cat’ out of the bag.”
The phrase “harmless, necessary cat” is from Shakespeare’s Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 1. Accepted. [Punch, 52 (22 June 1867): 257, “The Cat Out of the Bag”]. He also suggests Napoleon and Diz as the Two Augurs – the one leading Kings together and the other bringing MP's together. I’ve suggested all the good cuts lately,” T.T.

We talk of the sad position of Ellen Terry ... whom Watts has left with £300 a year. A man of 50 should not marry a girl of 17. Weakness grows to wickedness. T.T. encouraged the match.
Re: Taylor’s role in the Watts-Terry marriage see note to entry for February 17, 1864. ... and Mrs. Prinsep snubbed the wife and the husband like a coward did not defend her. “Kicky” is savage against Snobs in High Life inviting a husband without his wife.

div.head: June 18, 1867. T[uesday]. No. 1.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M.,T T. champ.

Mark and Shirley and Tom and Tenniel dine with the [Royal] Academy tomorrow at the Mansion House. “Kicky” threatens to send a note declining the honour of not being invited. He has been dining out greatly. “Nothing takes it out of you so much,” says Tom. Tom complains of Oxenford's criticism on “The Antipodes” at the Holborn.
Tom Taylor’s The Antipodes, or, the Ups and Downs of Life made its debut at the Holborn Theatre on June 8, 1867, with Ellen Terry in a small role, one of her first returns to the stage after the failure of her marriage. John Oxenford’s review in the Times (June 12, 1867, p. 6) castigated the piece as “an extremely clumsy piece of workmanship,” at whose conclusion “the audience are liberated from a dreary, complicated, uninteresting story, which has made them regret that the word Antipodes is only the title of the play, and does not indicate the place at which it is performed.” These remarks in the diary suggest that Oxenford was reacting to Taylor’s criticism of his reviews as “milk and water,” but an alternative explanation emerged years later, when “Atlas” (Edmund Yates) used his column in The World to quote a letter from Burnand asserting that Oxenford’s review was revenge for a review by Taylor. According to Burnand, Taylor had taken Oxenford’s place as the Times critic during the former’s trip to America earlier in 1867, and had taken the opportunity to severely criticize one of Oxenford’s plays. According to Burnand, on his return Oxenford was “made aware of what happened during his absence; for, mild and indulgent critic usually, on the next prosecution of a ‘new and original’ drama by Mr. Tom Taylor, he wrote a notice in the Times which took the skin off the author, from his nape to his heels.” See “What the World Says,” The World 23 (2 September 1885) 17. (Thanks to Kathryn Ledbetter for supplying information about The World.) I have been unable to trace this Times review of Oxenford by Taylor. Shirley says, “You blamed his rosewater and now he shows he can write vitriol.” Tom thinks a man a wretch who allows personal antipathy to bias criticism. The stage might benefit the country and The Times by honest criticism might benefit the stage. Shirley says it’s human nature to spite a man who injures you, and Oxenford resigned because you spoke of his milk and water style, and said he, “I don't break butterflies upon a wheel.” Besides, no critic can kill a good piece.

L.C. The 3 stools, 3 seats distributed, Diz coming to the ground,- T.T. Professor proposes the Excluded Exhibitions at Paris. Calcraft showing the gallows and the French executioner the guillotine, among the other engines of destruction. “If Swift had suggested it, you would have admired.” – “Rather slow than Swift,” says Shirley ... who suggests University of London, a Swell, refusing to be wedded with that of Durham – a country dowdy – Government having proposed to give the two a member, and decision being for London alone. Professor suggests Diz pitting the labourer against the artisan by his Reform. T.T. amends to Dizzy's novice backed against Bright's Working man. Shirley quotes Napoleon I, “I call in the cottage to balance the mansion.”

P.L. would have Nemesis – Peel appearing to Diz, who is becoming Liberal. Tom thinks something apropos of “Vivian, Robin, Grey came a courting of me.” Shirley suggests Diz's Great Trick Act – throwing off farmer's clothes and appearing as Liberty ... Tenniel adds “On 2 horses, Democracy and Toryism.” Tom adds Bright as Clown – and Gladstone holding £6 franchise Bar, which Diz has leapt over.” This we accept – but then the fertile Tom suggests as more à propos du moment, Diz dancing among the eggs – the seats: accepted [Punch, 52 (29 June 1867): 267, “The Political Egg-Dance”]. Also suggests Diz as Cornelia showing Bright her jewels – two roughs with votes. (Good.) This springs from Du Maurier's mention of Leech's funny pictures in The History of Rome, and England. ... Hear Don Carlos, while B. hears Nillson in Faust.

div.head: June 26, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Crystal Palace Benefit Concert, meets Christine Nillson at Garrett's.

div.head: July 2, 1867. T[uesday]. At the Mitre, Hampton Court.
div.p: H.S. goeth to Orpington: and meets Mrs. Rotheram.

div.head: July 10, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., H.M.- S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., T.T.
Ponny Mayhew's birthday, as he reminds us. So we drink his health.

T.T. applauds Nillson – and wonders at the folly of our English managers in not engaging her cheaply before she became famous. Been singing 3 years in Paris. Yet she has only played in Faust, Marta, Traviata, and Elvira in the Covent Garden[?].

English fools grovel before a lord – and French for a decoration, S.B. D.M. tells of old Levi getting Arthur Clinton to his soirees – “parties attended” might be put on his lordship's card. An extra £5 if called “Arthur.”

L.C. Can't touch on poor Maximilian's execution. T.T. suggests “A Reform Leap in the Dark.” But the Sultan's visit is the subject – never a sultan here since The Crusades. Turks invoke the Deity when they eat meat – and our butchers use an oath when they kill it. Turks bg on their heels – W.C.'s altered at Buckingham Palace. P.L. suggests, – Sultan visiting a Queen, advance in civilisation, acknowledges a woman. “There is but one Principle and Interest is its Profit.” S.B. suggests John Bull, or Punch, receiving him, “Sick Man be hanged! You're looking hearty!” accepted [Punch, 53 (20 July 1867): 25, “The Illustrious Convalescent”]
H.S. to Farrow’s dance.

div.head: July 17, 1867. W[ednesday]. Naval Review ... so no Dinner.
div.p: H.S. and B. on board the “Minion.”

div.head: July 24, 1867. W[ednesday]
div.p: W.B., D.M., F.C.B., E., M.L., S.B., JT., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., Wm.A., H.S., T.T.

H.S. from Sandown today. S.B. on board the Royal Sovereign at the Review. Broadsides sounded like musketry compared with her big guns. Lucas is at Eastbourne half insane poor fellow. Remember how we used to play at American bowls together. His downfall dates from his announcing his marriage, and finding his friends did not receive his wife. On dit

that Oxenford is half mad also – been missing since he slashed into T.T.'s Antipodes. Leicester Buckingham died suddenly rather t'other day.
Leicester Silk Buckingham (1825-1867) playwright, and dramatic and musical critic for the Morning Star. Literary men seem to have hazardous lives.

L.C. S.B.'s old notion of a Leap in the Dark, now the Reform Bill is passed ... amends it to Britannia riding Dizzy at the fence of £6 suffrage, Gladstone shying at it and Bright trying. [Punch, 53 (3 August 1867): 47, “A Leap in the Dark”]
This cut appeared just as the debate in the House of Lords was concluding. On the floor of the Lords on August 6, in almost the last and by far the most dramatic speech of his career, the aged Prime Minister, Lord Derby, picked up the phrase in thanking his colleagues for passing the bill, making a frank admission that the country had now made “a leap in the dark.” In his “Essence of Parliament” column two issues later, noting that August 6 “will be a date of importance in the History of England,” Brooks joked that Derby had used the phrase “by the kind permission of Cartoon Punch, Esq.” Punch 53 (August 17, 1867): 65.
Kate Terry plays Beatrice tonight for her “last Benefit.”

div.head: July 31, 1867. No dinner.
div.p: Return from the Bennett performance last Monday at Manchester. Harold Power the fun of the affair: chaffing Clarke the Glasgie Chiel: Sir Vincent Cotton and other Swells with us yesterday at Mendel's.

div.head: August 7, 1867. W[ednesday]. Maidenhead. Champ.
div.p: All the regulars except Charles Keene.
W.B., J.T., F.E., and H.S. pull from Henley – rains from Medmenham. Cold.
L.C. Shirley suggests Critic cut, “Behold your Votaries” etc., amending this from “When they do agree, their unanimity is wonderful.” [Punch, 53 (17 August 1867): 67 “Puff at St. Stephen's”]

He and Tom and P.L. and H.S. leave by the 9 train, spite of M.L. .. who can smoke any number of cigars. I could never do more than three without a headache. And now rarely take even two. – Tom says he once had Harold Power's bouyant spirits, and gift of fooling. He is grave enough now. “Better to lose such gifts,” he says.
Actor and pianist Harold Power, son of famed Irish actor Tyrone Power, played Box to George Du Maurier’s Cox in the first performance of Burnand’s and Arthur Sullivan’s comic opera, Cox and Box, on May 26, 1866, at Arthur Lewis’s Moray Lodge. The performance was repeated eleven months later at the Adelphi benefit for Charles H. Bennett. Power had come to know Burnand when both worked at the Post Office.
P.L. defends Cobbett – had much of the Wordsworth love of the country – but, says Shirley, he collapsed in Parliament.

div.head: August 14-21, 28 at Mo. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Dieppe from August 13 to September 2.

div.head: September 4, 1867. W[ednesday] . No. 1 . champ.
div.p: W.B., H.S., J.T., M.L., E., H.M.
S.B. in Devon, D.M. at Ramsgate, C.K. in Scotland P.L. at Southampton.

F.E. in Switz .. T.T. nescio quâ. So the covey scatters itself in autumn. Mark has been grandfatherising at Bognor. Looks jolly. Pater goes to Ilfracombe. Has been earthclosetising at Aldershot today. Predicts wonders.

L.C. Mark suggests Kirwee Prize Money delay, official cocked hat asleep on a heap of money and poor wounded soldier starving for it. Also suggests a dog cut – policeman afraid to take up a stray dog: “must prove he has bit some one”: absurd law. This we accept: [Punch, 53 (14 September 1867): 107, “Cave Canem, or Dog(berry) Law”]. H.S. suggesting that P. should be present with Toby, a good dog that has paid the tax. Dignity and Impudence.

Two new opponents started: “Banter” and the “Half-penny Punch.”
Banter, edited by George Augustus Sala, ran from September 2, 1867 until January 6, 1868; The Halfpenny Punch did not last past this debut issue for August 31, 1867 (Waterloo Directory, Series 3). And there exists Fun, Judy and Tomahawk: which latter sold 40,000 of “A Brown Study.”
Drawn by Matt Morgan, “A Brown Study” appeared in Tomahawk (August 10, 1867) 151-152. The cartoon was tinted brown, and depicted Queen Victoria’s trusted Highland servant, John Brown, leaning against an empty throne. For more about Tomahawk, see the NCSE introductory essay and Chris Kent, “The Angry Young Gentlemen of Tomahawk,” in Victorian Journalism: Exotic and Domestic Essays in Honour of P.D. Edwards, Barbara Garlick and Margaret Harris, eds. (Queensland University Press, 1998), 75-94 Is loyalty dead? Are there no boots made to kick a scoundrelly libeller who flings mud at the Queen? This is a material age of comfort and go-easyism when one's own selfish pleasures are satisfied. A little dirty scandal is a small fillip of excitement to a blasé brute.

div.head: September 11, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., H.M., J.T.(late from Eastbourne), M.L.,P. L., F.C.B .

The Ritualistic Commission's report “condensed” into 6 cols. of Times, Times boiled down into 2 of the Pall Mall, and so on: Bell's Life would give it in a couple of inches. Clearly is the subject, and we accept Mark's notion of Mother Church stripping gay vestments of a Puseyite and saying, “There, now you look a man again!” [Punch, 53 (21 September 1867): 117, “A Change for the Better”] – Better than previous idea of wife proposing to wear out his gaudy clothing. P.L. suggests the “Ecclesiastical Toots” – Oh it’s of no consequence. Also “What is the Emperor doing” having his corns cut, or something equally prosaic and unwarlike. P.L. approves the short skirts now in vogue – but girls should not have such gaudy dresses – look like Harlequinas. S.B. writes to suggest a squabble cut – “Who shall give the Reform Dinner?” with Russell in the sulks at being invited to play second fiddle to Beales.

M.L. suggests “the Perplexed Tourist,” Dizzy uncertain which road to follow, Tory, Whig, Radical ... W.B. anxious to have an anti-short-weight cut against Bakers. H.S. suggests: Good Harvest but bad weight. Ceres saying, “No use my sending you fine crops,” M.L. Burnand full of pun and fun as usual. Can't fancy him the father of six! Go to hear his Black-Eyed Susan tonight – its 234th! “P – rrr – etty Seeusan don't say No” encored twice nightly. Miss Oliver gives a shrill roll of the R which is very funny.
According to Clement Scott, Patty Oliver sang the song a dozen times a night to repeated encores, and by the last performance in 1868 was said to have performed it 1,775 times. Scott calls her “one of the most delightful actresses of her time.” Drama of Yesterday and Today, 2: 201-202. But there's far more fun in the acting than the writing. Legs more effective than brains.

div.head: September 18, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Stanwick.

div.head: September 25, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.
We drink the elder Mrs. Bradbury's health. “I'll warrant we'll find an excuse for a glass.”

L.C. settled before hand that Tenniel may have a holiday. Pan Anglican Bishops Washing. T.T. suggests Colenso appearing to the Synod as Old Bogy – frightening the big sleeves [Punch, 53 (5 October 1867): 137, “Pan-Anglican Washing”]. M.L., Shall we have Sala among us? P.L., NO. - chorus, NO. Let Banter have him.
The short-lived Banter (it expired in 1868) featured contributions by both Sala and Matt Morgan. See Sir F. C. Burnand, “Mr. Punch: Some Precursors and Competitors,” Pall Mall Magazine 29 (1903) 394 and M. H. Spielmann, “The Rivals of ‘Punch’,” National Review 25 (March-August 1895) 663.

D.M. reports that in coming from Ramsgate yesterday he only saw one Punch bought, and a dozen Fun's, Tomahawk's and Judy's. Thinks we should do something less gentlemanly than our wont is, so as to please the Snobs. And some Vers de Societé at times, like Lockyer's. Chorus against copying the penny wits, but it behooves us to be on our mettle. At present Punch is not injured by his plagiarists. Write briefly, saith M.L. Fun is largely bought for its stupid double acrostics. The Tomahawk sold 40,000 of its “Brown” beastliness.

div.head: October 2, 1867 W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Glenham Hall after Lowestoft.

div.head: October 9, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. from Church Street today ... dull in wits. Kate Terry born April 21, 1844, says Tom: to be married October 18 – a Friday! A great loss to the stage…and to him. “The only actress I cared to write for.” She made £600 by her month at Manchester: too overcome to speak her farewell. L.C. F.C.B. suggests “the Challenge,” Colenso a Stag Gray swimming home to fight him. P.L., the Ritualists aping Pope, like frog and bull – Pope swearing “Non potestis” [I am not able]. T.T. amends to blowing trumpets but M.L. negatives. E. or M.L. suggest Poor Curate – real Church “difficulties,” with Poor Curate's Anxious Wife asking, “Any help for our difficulties, Dear?” – Resigned Husband, “O No, Love. We Poor Curates are not even mentioned,” reading Resolutions. Accepted. [ Punch, 53 (19 October 1867): 159, “A Pan-Anglican Oversight”] P.L. attributes to Queen's absence the apathy as to the Fenians and Tomahawk scandal. Agrees with Swedenborg that men pass into future state grounded in good or evil ... and so become better or worse, and so are happy or cursed.
T.T. tells how a Backwoods Bishop was found smoking in bed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, who fancied he smelt fire. Suggests a sketch thereof apropos of the Synod.

T.T. has been to see the Passionate Pilgrm – printed 300 years ago, and clean copy – discovered by Mr. Chas. Edmonds in a lumber room.
Charles Edmonds of booksellers Willis & Sotheran had announced on October 4 his discovery, in a disused attic lumber-room of the Isham family’s Lamporth Hall in Northamptonshire, a volume containing a previously unknown copy of Passionate Pilgrim bound in with Venus and Adonis, both printed by William Leake in 1599, along with two other rare tracts. Edmonds concluding by noting that he had the permission of the owner to show the volume “to any gentleman interested in Shakesperian [sic] literature.” The Globe, 4 October 1867, p. 3. The volume is now in the Huntington Library; see Douglas Gordon, “The Book-Collecting Ishams of Northamptonshire and their Bookish Virgina Cousins,” The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, 77:2 (April 1969) 174-179.

div.head: October 16, 1867. W[ednesday]. No 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M.., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.S., T.T.

D. complains of M.L.'s cutting in “Titwillow in Paris.”
This series, written and illustrated by Du Maurier, began on September 28 [Punch, 53 (28 September 1867): 126] with Du Maurier’s half-page illustration; the beginning of the text of the story on page 131 includes a self-caricature of Du Maurier (at right, under the initial letter “A”). The series ran for only three numbers, concluding on October 12. M.L. flares up and says he couldn't see the fun – “silly and imbecile.” But they soon hobnob together. “We haven't for years had so serious a row,” says Tenniel.
No more Moray Minstrelsy – D.M. regrets the marriage for robbing us of a nice actress and some jolly greetings. But I don't wonder Lewis gives them up.

L.C. The Pope is the Question of the Day – Garibaldi-ites invading Papal States – T.T. suggests Italy saying to Mrs. Pope, “Better give up 'the Crown,' and be content with the 'Cross Keys'“ – Garibaldi men coming to take possession of the former – Burnand objects to it as profane. T.T. suggests Bench of Magistrates, King of Sardinia and L. Napoleon etc. refusing Pope a license for the Crown.

Usual church squabble between Burnand and the Professor – Says Shirley, “For the last century the only revolutions have been in R. Catholic countries. The Pope won't take English money for the Irish church, because his grievance pays better – Popery sets people against their Government, and so must be attacked.”

Oliver Wendell Holmes said, “Good Americans, when they die, go to Paris.” “Yes,” says Leigh, “Paris is a corruption of Paradise.” Good! S.B., – “Beati sunt qui in domino moriuntur” – Rabelais? “Catching like the itch is a church squabble: – and cured by sending you to sulfur,” says Shirley.
Good notion for L.C. in Times today. Protestant Clergy in Ireland like cattle on deck – ready to be thrown over when the Ship of State is in danger, (T.T.).

div.head: October 17, 1867. At the Bedford.
div.p: M.L., D.M., H.S., C.K., J.T., S.B., P.L., F.C.B., T.T.

Our first Almanack meeting. M.L. “quite satisfied” with it.
Shirley Brooks diagrammed the seating for this dinner in his diary entry of this date: “Then to Bedford, where we had the usual ‘almanac dinner,’ for suggestions.
ML
TT G du M
FCB HS
PL CK
JT
SB
A good many suggestions were made, & ML declared himself more than satisfied with the night’s harvest.” D.M. agrees to do “borders” à la 1850 by Doyle.
Punch’s Almanac for 1850, p. 1. For Du Maurier’s version of the borders: Punch’s Almanac for 1868, p. 1. “The best Almanack,” says Mark. Subjects of the past year. Congresses of Bishops, Garibaldi Peace folk, etc. etc. Reformers – Fenians. S.B., “Ladies Club” – wives smoking: men at home mending stockings. Fungus-Eater, Experience of: for P.L., finding a Phallus Impudious: query circumcised? “Phalluses of the Faculty,” P.L.

T.T. for this week suggests small cut of Sir Thomas Henry saying, “Take away that Bauble”: Mace the prize-fighter having been arrested.
Prizefighter and Champion of England James Mace, scheduled to defend his title against Ned O’Baldwin on October 15, was arrested the night before for intent to cause a breach of the peace, and bound over by Sir Thomas Henry, the police magistrate. See Times, October 16, 1867, p. 6.
S.B. suggests “No more Guys” ... ladies burning their crinolines. Mark tells how he shot a cat with a pistol. Suggests a series of funny cuts.
T.T. thinks Almanacks have been best when there is a thread running through them – both in writing and drawing. Should be the history of the year in brief – and in fun.

div.head: October 23, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Waresley.
Another Rival ... Toby: first number dated Oct. 23. Judy, Banter, and Tomahawk ... all of this year's birth. Fun the best of the lot. Besides there are the Hornsey Hornet and Echoes of the Clubs.

div.head: October 30, 1867. W[ednesdaly]. No. lL.
div.p: H.S. at Paris – Exposition. Mr. Punch “Medaille d'honneur!”

div.head: November 6, 13, 20; No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Tillac – 3 weeks of sunshine and blue sky – fogs in London. Fenians hung at Manchester on the 23rd.

div.head: November 27, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., E., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., Tom Agnew, T.T –
H.S. left Ambares at 5.20 and reached 6, the Terrace at 6 the following (last) evening.

L.C. T.T. suggests Russell making a bid for Education Reform lead – apropos of his notice of motion – Diz with Reform Baby and Russell with Education baby, “That nasty Jewboy shan't kidnap you away.” – But we've had so many baby cuts.

Apropos of Jacob Bright's return for Manchester, T.T. suggests “The Voice is the Voice of Jacob, but the (show of) hands are the hands of John.”
Genesis 27:22. But Scripture is tabooed. – P.L. apropos of Abyssinian debate suggests John Bull, “Well, fight, since I must – but as cheaply as possible.” Nobody cares for cost, so long as we lick, says Shirley. P.L. suggests ghost of Dr. Johnson, “Sir, the entrance to Happy Valley is doubtless arduous,” and so forth – à la Rasselas.
T.T. says Theodorus asked for some of Beethoven's music and our Government sent him a barrel organ! Hence he began to hate us: for he likes music.

T.T. suggests Grateful Coster thanking Hardy for amending the Street Clearance Act – S.B. adds “Walpole were partial to Inions” and names it “A Civil Deputation.” accepted. [Punch, 53 (7 December 1867): 233, “A Civil Deputation to the Home Office”]

D.M. thinks young Arthur à Beckett should be turned out of the Arts Club for editing The Tomahawk. Squibbed Arthur Lewis' wedding, “Mr. Tame Lionhunter and his friend Mr. Toady” etc. No business to touch on private matters. – We sign our set of Punch to give his wife, late Kate Terry.
Albert Smith left his wife under sign Virgo, on dit. Odd how talk turns that way lately.
Black-eyed Susan's birthday at the Royalty next Friday: one year old. F.C.B. wears a ring in her honour and recites part of her Birthday Ode.

div.head: December 4, 1867. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.
D.M. tells me that Louis Nap's nickname is Badinguet – the name of the soldier he shot at Boulogne.

D.M. and F.C.B. chaff: B., You play Box at Chichester – ah, I heard people were leaving the place. D., I'll alter the words – then they'll come back, etc. etc. H.S. a duffer at chaff. B. a dab: draws from Mark all about his House of Commons scene for his new-old play forthcoming at Olympic. House of Peers, says W.B.

D.M. tells of Swinburne and Menken! queer lech she hath, the Animal. Thinks S[winburne] has written finer poetry than anyone living. I don't. S.B., “Swin. – is stringy.” D.M., “Sorry for that – are you going to have him?” F.C.B. roars. I don't.
F.C.B. – “I can't rehearse on a fish diet – must get a dispensation.” S.B., “Ah, I always thought religion didn't go with hard work.”

L.C. T.T. in hieroglyphs suggests “No Lamps” apropos of Cabman's Strike yesterday – lamps wanted in the House as well as out of it. But M.L. and J.T. think the subject deserves a double cut – no lamps in Workhouses, Farnham e.g. etc.

H.M. suggests the 2 Educationists, Dizzy “had to educate his party” – Russell “knows a party that wants education;” moved resolutions on Monday anent the use of schools – “The Two Dromios” [from Shakespeare's Comedy of Errors], but no action.

P.L. protests against paying for Abyssinian War by 2d income tax – saddling the middle classes. Swell and Workman pointing to Shopkeeper and saying, “He'll have to pay for it.” S.B. and J.T. simultaneously suggest Tuck in your Tuppenny – Theodore taking a back over John Bull [Punch, 53 (14 December 1867): 243, “Tuck in yer Twopenny!”]. Whence came the phrase? Funny cut to look at, however. N.B. Heard Southey as Don G. ce matin, with Titiens, Sinico and Kellogg (Zerlina). ... and next Friday Her Majesty's is burnt! Farewell to the horseshoe and yellow curtains!
Built in 1791, Her Majesty’s Theatre burned down in an hour in 1867.

div.head: December 10, 1867. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T.T.

L.C. Apropos of burning Her Majesty's [Theatre] – Shirley suggests Genius of Music Halls saying, “We can get on without you.” ... But P.L. insists that the French debate on Rome and declaration that France will meddle with Italy is the subject: denounces Thiers as a scoundrel for claiming such a right – long debate – T.T. suggests Italy crying for Rome, and Louis N. saying, “Shan't have it? Shall he, Mr. Bull?” John answers, “If you've decided, why ask me?” – for the Conference is no go. ... S.B. suggests Louis as Protector of Pope, “Shan't bully the old woman - hasn't long to live.” F.C.B., “Most unjust and untrue.” T.T., “Tous les chemins menent a Rome,” Italy goes thither stopped by sentry Louis, “On ne passer pas,”. But we had a similar cut for Kossuth. T.T. calls Garibaldi “a contemptible hero” for his late unwise expedition – like a woman, he can't wait. ... At last Shirley quotes, “The Gaul thundering at the Gates” and Tom instantly says, “Brennus Redivivus – throws his sword into the scale with the Tiara – outweighs Garibaldi and Victor [Emmanuel].” “Brennus Buonaparte,” says S.B. [ Punch, 54 (21 December 1867): 253, “Brennus-Bonaparte, or the Gaul Again in Rome.”].

Then we have the Almanack and give three cheers – “Best we've had for years,” says Mark. C.K. comes out famously – and D.M.'s Punch's Genealogy and Beauty and Beast first chop. His brother stood for the Beast's friend, by the way.

div.head: December 17, 1867. T[uesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., T.T.

The devilish Fenian outrage at Clerkenwell last Friday makes us all savage.
On December 13, 1867, members of the Irish Republican Brotherhood (“Fenians”) attempted to rescue a Fenian prisoner, Ricard O’Sullivan Burke, held at Clerkenwell Prison in London by setting off a bomb that killed twelve civilians and injured over a hundred others. The plan failed, and public feelings ran high against the Fenian movement. Fenianism should be called Fiendianism in future. T.T. says Habeas Corpus should be suspended – but it is a grave responsibility to do so and wait for Act of Indemnity. Man M'Cauley, lecturer at Manchester was arrested for seditious speaking and told the Crown Solicitor he had been chosen for Van attack with Allen and being frightened sought safety in prison.
Mark: Glass of wine together? We used to do so, eh Silver? Ah those were jolly dinners 7 years ago.

S.B. by letter suggests figure of Murder pulling off her mask of Liberty while she fires the fuse: M.L., Dizzy as an Angel, relieving the sufferers – Government having sent £500 directly ... sans red tape. T.T., the Fenians Habeas Corpus, Justice clutching man with fuse. .. But we revert to P.L.'s Guy Fawkes, blowing Fenianism to the winds, for all mercy is at an end now. [ Punch, 53 (28 December 1867): 262, “The Fenian Guy Fawkes”]. M.L. would like to show the savage recklessness of life as injuring the poor working man – to set them against sympathising with the scoundrels'. P.L. thinks Bright's speeches partly the cause .. but Walpole and Hyde Park are more so. T.T. calls Shirley's style (as in “Sooner or Later”) the perfection of persiflage... mere smartness ... no dramatic knowledge. Trollope his opposite, but more effective and natural... all his [S.B.'s] characters talk alike smartly ... can't tell from their talk who is speaking.

div.head: January 8, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., F.E., M.L., C.K., H.M.

No Punch Dinner on Christmas Day or New Year's Day. Shirley quotes from Baker's new book on the Nile Tributaries, how nigger boy was told to kill flies in wineglasses, and he killed them also in p.pots. Shirley finds time to read and write 20 times more than most men: and yet dines out three or four times a week.

L.C. Shirley suggests Derby retorting to Bright's taunt, “Turf morals won't do in politics.” – “No, nor commercial morals either”: apropos of Overend, Pato & Co. According to Lord Westbury's London and Brighton Report, Peter Northold Laurie of the Union Bank has been issuing false accounts as well as other falsifiers. S.B. suggests L. Napoleon as Peace .. and Plenty of Chasspots – Chesspots-au-feu, jokes Horace ...Shirley suggests Church and Dissent as 2 cats, ready to spring on small boy, with “the Conscience Claws” apropos the Education Question.

S.B. suggests Diz preparing to “educate his party” – announcing to them that he “expects his young pupils to return to their duties shortly.” Finally, we revert to the new French Army Bill – increasing term of service and number of men: L.N. saying, “Only my Specials – tu prepare the peace like yours.” Apropos of our Special Constable swearing against Fenians. [Punch, 54 (18 January 1868): 27, “A Peace Movement.(?)”].

div.head: January 15, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champ.
div.p: W.B., H.S., Sketchley, M.L., S.B., J.T., P.E., P.L ., C.K., H.M.

Like coming back from the holidays and finding a new boy – Sketchley. “Not Arthur!” says Charles, with a look of horror. Quick fellow – Americanised beard and shaven face – double eyeglass – brown hair – perhaps 40. Talks of So. Kensington Portraits – Princess Mary knew not Wilkes – but well up in Peerage ... Horace quotes, “Well, Wilkes, d'ye expect to be hung or die of the pox?” “That depends whether I embrace your lordship's politics or mistress.”

H.M. disliked Peel and Palmerston: “as alike as 2 P's,” says Sketchley: “Both in their shells now,” says Shirley. Who was the Swell-fool, or Court-fool, who went to America in Queen Anne's time, and dressed himself in Queen's clothes, when he held a court for her? His portrait was at Kensington last year. Fancy Sketch: Cricket on the Hearth – a maiden over – first innings – S.B.

L.C. Alfred in Australia the subject: little fellow – Tom Thumb and Glundalcar, S.B. “Advance Australia” in a quadrille with him (H.M.) ... “How you've grown!” S.B. Accepted. [Punch, 54 (25 January 1868): 39, “Our Australian Cousin”]. How shall she be drest? ask J.T. O as little as possible S.B. Previously had suggested a Colonist in a court suit too small for him, as type of the Colony. Of course a pet kangaroo with her .. and nuggets for ornaments .. C.K. Sketchley's birthday we pretend. And so take champagne with him. And the Professor tells of the hard peas (“been thro' me”).
For the first telling of this story, and Thackeray’s appreciation of it, see the entry for February 5, 1862. And Ponny does not sing the Marseillaise or Mahogany Tree .. with arm uplifted and quavering voice. Sketchley does not smoke. Must begin with a cigarette. M.L. tells of Watchmaker and lady: “The only thing I can do is to put in a Watchglass ... the Dr. lives upstairs.”
“Where did you find your nice little wife?” saith Mark … who met us at Du Maurier's last night for the first time.

div.head: January 22, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., Sketchley, M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.., Will. Agnew.

“And Ponny is so rude” ... added to C.K.'s polite note of excuse for absence. F.C.B. from a month in Paris – while his sixth or seventh child is born. Takes it coolly. Full of fun – writes mock “important” letter which nobody can read ... like his mock speeches and songs, and riddle, “Why is the Queen of Spain in summer like any body[?] in winter?”“Because she isn't.” ... D.M. draws a mock design for big cut which Professor examines gravely and can't quite see! Poor Old Leigh. Shame to “sell” him. Lots of chaff: Ponny. “I'm going to have a treat when I get home.” Burnand, “Going to wash, eh.” “Get away with you: no.” ... S.B. “Do you object to smoke, ma'am?” “I don't know, sir - no gentleman ever smoked in my presence.”... M.L. “Leech met old gentleman who called it a nasty beastly dirty habit and made L. leave off: then took out snuffbox, and L. stopped him by repeating “nasty beastly dirty habit.”

S.B., £10 off rent at each birth. Died. “Fell a victim to his endeavors to reduce the rent.” Vernon Harcourt is “Historicus” in the Times. Whitehurst the snob who writes from Paris to the Telegraph about his dinners and Countesses. N.B. The Razor – first Number on January 1. Another Rival!

L.C. S.B. thinks Seward's Electioneering revival of the Alabama Claim the Subject. John Bull and Cousin Columbia quarreling – over a toy ship, suggests Sketchley. Britannia pacifying, “You know you love each other.” This we eventually accept .. and have a long hunt for a title: “Exeunt omnes thinking of a title,” says Burnand. – Mark, “Kiss and be friends.” Sketchley, “Make it up.” S.B., “Hoighty Toighty.” Approved. [Punch, 54 (1 February 1868): 51, “Hoity-Toity!!!”] “Highty tighty, my man John, Went to bed with his breeches on: One shoe off and one shoe on: Highty tighty, my man John.” Shirley's memory like an Elephant's Trunk – picks up the biggest and the smallest things. But one might as well be proud of a good digestion as of a good memory.

Mark et uxor dine with us yesterday for first time: and eat Canvas Backs (sent by Dr. Alsop from New York with Venison and Bear!) “Propagation – you mean impropa-gation,” J.T. Bradbury makes awful puns and Du Maurier publishes them. Sketchley walks with me homewards and is glad I like his “Australia and Britannia” article: I thought it was Shirley's. Says he has longed to be one of us. As did I a dozen years ago. How jog trot is Pegasus now! Then I used to fancy myself monstrari digito [worthy to be pointed at] - “That's one of the Punch staff!”

div.head: January 29, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., Tom Agnew, Sketchley, S.B., J.T., M .L.,P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.
Pater's birthday – here's better health to the old boy. D.M. says fellows write to him De Maurier: Give the devil his du.

L.C. S.B. suggests Gretna Green Marriage of Zulu to Macrorie by Bishop Gray of Capetown. T.T. amends it to Tait interfering: “I forbid the banns – she's married already to Colenso.”
W. K. Macrorie of Brasenose College, Oxford, was appointed Bishop of Maritsburg by Robert Gray, Bishop of Cape Town, as an attempt to wrest control of Natal from Bishop Colenso, who retained his title. Macrorie proved a divisive figure. [Punch, 54 (8 February 1868): 61, “The Zulu Bride”]

Mark born in 1809. D.M. now aged 33 – has done more than I'd done in '61. '61, by the way, was my grand climacteric on Punch: earned £374.12.6 first year of regular salary: wrote 137 columns. “Our Dramatic Correspondent” paid me extra. 1860 I wrote 202 columns and received £324.10 – in August and September that year I wrote 5 columns a week, and first tried my hand at The Essence of Parliament. Now I average 1¼ columns only. “Be 80 – reach your Be-ati-tude,” says Horace. “The Savage Orson is endowed with reason,” saith Shirley. ... Speke's disappearance still a topic of talk.
The mysterious London disappearance of Rev. Benjamin Speke (1830-1881), brother of the explorer, in the first week in January excited much comment in the press. Seven weeks later he would be discovered in Cornwall in disguise as a cattle drover. See the mention of his discovery in Silver’s entry for February 26.

Fancy Sketch – “Venus rising from the W.C.,” suggested by Burnand. Good initials Tom Armstrong's [A with T in middle]. D.M. suggests for me [S with H in middle]. D.M. laughs at my story of Frenchman aiming at pheasant running – “Shoot, oh no! I sall wait till he stop!”

div.head: February 5, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., Sketchley, M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.
By hieroglyph Tom Taylor suggests apropos of Leap Year, “The Ladies' Year.”Queen holding drawingrooms and coming into life again. Tenniel don't C it.
S.B. suggests Oliver Cromwell Redivivus proposing to squelch the Irish again. Says P.L. “Endow the Irish Roman Catholic Church & the people will turn Protestants.”

F.E. suggests, apropos of Parliament meeting on 13th, Hibernia saying, “I'm first to be attended to.” And C.K. improves to “Dr. Bull's Waiting Room”, which we accept. [Punch, 54 (15 February 1868 ): 71, “Dr. Bull’s Waiting-Room”] – Sketchley had suggested “The Parliamentary Train stopping at St. Stephens,” boys coming back from the holidays. Last Session of the Unreformed, “Morituri te salutant” [We who are about to die salute you], P.L. – P.L. also suggests that the Fenian disease is only skin deep, so Dr. Bull might prescribe for Hibernia's 'skin complaint.' Yes, saith Shirley, “I've cured Scotland.” Rather a Swift-like suggestion. But Swift would have said Itch outright.
Talk un peu loose: Tom, the Purist, being away. The Impurist he is often. Saw “Babes in Wood” at C[ovent] G[arden] ce matin. “The Seasons” good Transformation - Flora in her boat.

1860 was my best year I think in the Punch way. Wrote History of Costume. ... and a brace of Essences and “A Seaside Study” – The Jew in the Porkpie Hat – vide October 27 - which Shirley applauded, and having to make up the Number, placed the lines appropriately under Leech's cut of “Brighton Jewels.”
“A Sea-Side Study,” Punch 39 (27 October 1860) 164. Silver’s verses, which reference “a Jew in a porkpie hat,” harmonize with the patently antisemitic character of Leech’s “Brighton Jewels” cartoon above. Ah, in August '60, I stayed at Clem's and wrote fluently after my pleasant dinners alone.
Madame Finette in Lyceum “3 Bears” on Monday: Cancan kick – and wriggle of bosom.

div.head: February 12, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., R.F.S. (Sketchley), S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., T.T.
Quotes Shirley of omnivorous memory, “Brave spirits had our fathers, for they damned a pantomime”: from a skit by Oxenford. Fancy d–ing a Pantomime! What Manager would stand it after all his cost?

L.C. Apropos of Times' hint that Lord Derby should retire – causâ podagre. Shirley suggests him as Nestor and Stanley as Antilochus – but is he Nestor? Shirley suggests a situation from the Masked Ball in Hayley's Triumph of Temper which nobody but he and Leigh have read: quotes a lot of it.
William Hayley, The Triumphs of Temper. In Six Cantos (London: Dosley, 1781). Wondrous memory!

T.T. suggests Derby as the old boy of the St. Stephens School getting leaving books given him. Sketchley thinks something should be done apropos of Eton Head Master, presented by Head boy with a birch rod on his appointment.
The new Headmaster at Eton was James John Hornby, who succeeded Edward Balston. The Times, quoting a Pall Mall Gazette report, reported that presentation of a birch rod tied up with blue ribbon was a school tradition (Times, February 8, 1868, p. 9). ... But the Cooperative Stores are a better known subject – Professor loq. “Drat them cooperatives.” – “Co-robber-atives,” says Mark.
The Royal Arsenal Co-operative Society Limited was stablished at Woolwich in 1868. The Times ran a leader on the subject of the Co-operative System on February 11, 1868, p. 6. Anti-Trade Unions, amended by S.B. to “The Real Trade Union” of Tradesmen and Servants: because of percentages [Punch, 54 (22 February 1868): 83, “The Real Trade Union”]. - Saw Jack the Giantkiller at Drury today. Good French Street Scene by children only: L'Empereur review.

div.head: February 19, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S.X, R.F.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M.
X from Seckford St. yesterday.

Burnand in full force – “F— my daughter and got a sonata”: marvellous spirits. Saith Shirley, “Musical men can't talk anything but shop.” “No minds.” Saith D.M., “I think music the highest of the arts - but it must be a great bore to anyone without an ear for it.” — Imitates kind old Charles Keene's wink when telling the point of a story. Tells of his annoyance at a fussy friend who read his letters etc. “I almost felt inclined to say (wink) you be hanged.”
S.B., 'Tis thus the Professor defineth a gal:
A smooth, soft, white thing, with a mucous canal.
M.L. “I don't know who you be, young man, but you've done my bowels a power of good” – after f.
S.B. quotes a cartload from Rabelais – more dirt than wit.

L.C. Cockburn's letter that the Judges can't try Bribery cases. Satire, says P.L. Judges mostly have bribed to get into the House. And now fancy Judicial Ignorance pretending not to know what “Sugar” and the “Man in Moon” mean!
S.B. amends to Cockburn's saying, “Don't bring him before me – our judgments are no joke. Accepted [Punch, 54 (29 February 1868): 93, “Legal Difficulty”]. Judge on circuit shouldn't shirk it, W.B.
Shirley, Burnand and du Maurier the chief talkers: when Tom is absent. Burnand quick at chaff and repartee: But Shirley's tongue has the keenest edge.
We debate as to Madame Finette's Cancan and the Ballet room at the Alhambra, both of which D.M. defends and Mark & Co. attack. No right to make it an attraction, tho' you can't prevent it.

div.head: February 26, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Ash Wednesday.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., R.F.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E.-‘Vice’ (as usual), P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.

Not till '96 will there be five Saturdays in February – and five numbers of Punch. Feast of St. Jackides next Friday: so we drink his health: and J – don't return thanks. Quotes Shirley: When a Moslemite goes to Church he leaves his shoes at the door: Catholic, his understanding”: “his sole,” says Horace. Shirley's emphasis by throwing down a knife as he says “There's your Cut!” Burnand burlesques it by throwing down a handful of knives and forks, with a Shirleyan sniff. ... S.B. tells a good sell. ... Seward to Johnson: “With your right hand – eh? That's an interesting fact .. I use paper.”
L.C. Derby resigned (per son Stanley) yesterday: T.T. by letter suggests presenting Dizzy with the birch ... M.L. applauds as hitting two subjects.

S.B. amends by substituting a Duke for – because Diz has floored the aristocrats: Triumph of Literature. – Leigh objects that the cut doesn't go on all fours: should be the head boy of the Tory School – not typified Aristocracy – who presents the birch. Analogy false else – and simply a time server. – Sketchley seconds amendment – and proposes Diz climbing the greasy pole – top at last – “Merely … a clever quack.” Burnand suggests “Ixion in Heaven.” – Good notion for a parody, any way. But after a fight, the Professor is beaten and Shirley, backed by Mark, sticks to the typical Aristocrat [Punch, 54 (7 March 1868): 103, “The New Head Master”].

S.B., “Leigh, do you believe in a personal God who personally knows and records all you do?” ... P.L. (fences), “As a matter of opinion I believe – but as a dogma, I am not sure. Science inclines to belief in God rather than chance.”
D.M., I believe in God – and that I shall go to Heaven, matter little what I do.
S.B., I believe in God – and that he will weigh good actions against bad: being Just.
M.L., I believe in God – and that he pardons all who humbly do their best to struggle with the weakness of their flesh. I say my prayers – but I don't believe in any Church.

Speke discovered on Monday! in disguise as a drover in Cornwall. Clearly mad. S.B. quotes from Newman: “A dishonest drunken whorish Catholic ... I don't say she is perfect, but she will, if she does her duty to her Church, go to Heaven sooner than a Protestant Saint.” Burnand fences: but he fasts.

div.head: March 4, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., R.F.S., M.L., S.B., Tom Agnew, J.T. , F.E., P.L., H.M., J.H., Agnew.
D.M. writes a funny letter bringing in all our names as reasons for his absence. Tenniel's intemperance, Shirley's profanity and so forth.

Apropos of the German Bandmann in 'Narcisse,' T.T. discourses on the difference between the old and modern stage: We have lost the fine old heroic stately eloquence, but have gained in truthfulness to nature, and in little details which make a perfect picture. Bandmann has the emotion of eloquence at command.
Apropos of the Police Journal and other Sensation Papers, Leigh thinks that an Illustrated Medical Journal would be popular – with secrets divulged.
He also suggests that the Army should be used as Stallions, if not allowed to marry. “Utilise your immorality, as you utilize your manure.”
Rossini's 19th birthday was on February 29. Gustave Doré made a joke at the dinner about “Bonheur – santé: sans thé – not in England!”
T.T. wonders how it is that the purest child lays hold of dirt – his little girl says, “Pa, look at bear rubbing his Popo against the wall.”

L.C. P.L. suggests Gladstone and Diz as rival actors G. sulky. – “Rival Stars,” says Mark, for a title [Punch, 54 (14 March 1868): 115, “Rival Stars”]. – And T.T. suggests “To be or Not to be.” S.B. proposes Diz as Jeremy Diddler instead of General Utility. But the latter is approved.

div.head: March 11, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Champagne to Pater on his return – has had a three months’ bout of it – but seems jolly. He tells that when he was a schoolboy, Disraeli was an articled clerk at Swaine and Stevens', Fredericks Place, Old Jewry, with Pater's brother – who speculated with Diz and lost, like him, nearly all his fortune in the Smash of 1825.

H.M. tells of a Mrs. Grattan, enraged by boxkeeper, saying, “If I were not a lady, I'd kick your B.A.!” We talk of Charles Cole, brother of Sketchley's chief at South Kensington, Henry the Great. D.M. quotes part of some lines C.C. wrote about a railway putter down of windows: At Barnes in Surrey I reside: I am a clerk in town, And whenso'er by rail I ride, I'll have the windows down.
Charles Augustus Cole (1819-1887), Henry Cole’s youngest brother. These verses appear, without attribution to an author, in a note contributed by Frank Rede Fowke (Henry Cole’s son-in-law) to Notes and Queries, 6 (22 July 1876): 62-63, under the title, “The Vow of the Clerk of Barnes.” Fowke claims that they were printed as a broadside by one of the clerk’s fellow passengers and distributed on the train, after which the clerk “was seen no more.” Here is a substantial excerpt:
Although a clerk in town:
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
I may be, have been, sorely tried
By tear, reproach, and frown
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
Let beauty plead and wit deride—
Come wealth with its last 'brown'—
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
Though youth sit flaunting in its pride,
Or age with silver'd crown,
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
Come show and splendour, close allied,
Come neat and russet gown,
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
Let infant cry, or woman chide,
Scream, scratch, or scold, or 'swoun,'
In ev'ry carriage, when I ride,
I’ll have the window down.
…
And though last winter I near died—
I had sciatics in my side—
Hear me! I swear, through time and tide,
Whether I swim or drown,
In ev’ry carriage, when I ride
I’ll have the window down! – Said C.C., “My brother, Sir, put ½ a crown in my mother's hand as his share of my father's funeral expenses!”

Lord Strangford wrote a savage review in the Saturday – afterwards met the authoress and married her.
Percy Smythe, Viscount Strangford (1826-1869), a distinguished philologist, anonymously reviewed Egyptian Sepulchres and Syrian Shrines (Longmans, 1861) by Emily Anne Beaufort (1826–1887) in Saturday Review 12 (3 August 1861): 123-124. The author wrote to complain, and the letter was forwarded to Lord Strangford, initiating a correspondence. The two were married on February 6, 1862. See Merle Mowbray Bevington, The Saturday Review, 1855-1868 (New York: Columbia University Press, 1941), p. 43, and G. Le G. Norgate, ‘Smythe, Percy Ellen Algernon Frederick William Sydney, eighth Viscount Strangford (1825–1869)’, rev. Elizabeth Baigent, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.

Ponny produces “Punch in London” of 1832 illustrated by Cruikshank. Also a new Magazine, “The Mask” which has a drawing of The Times' Staff called Forging A Thunderbolt: Delane Jupiter: Mowbray Morris, Mercury: Jimmy Davison, Apollo (should be Vulcan, being lame), Tom Taylor Cupid (adapted from the French), Dasent Juno: S.G. Osborn Minerva: and so forth.
The Mask made its debut in February, 1868, and published its last number in December. Illustrations were by Alfred Thompson, who co-edited the magazine with Leopold Lewis, and engraved by Horace Harral. The caricature of the Times staff appears on page 43 of the March number, accompanying a satirical article (pp. 42-46). A caricature of Mark Lemon appeared in the April number, accompanying an article about Punch entitiled, “Mark Lemon’s Triumphal Car” (pp. 64-67).

L.C. Tom suggests licking Little bills (bears) into shape. “Young bears with all their troubles before them.” P.L. suggests Diz as Proteus – But how draw him? H.M. suggests Ireland as Our Poor Relation. Then J.T. hits the nail – Diz driving 2 pigs that won't go straight – and T.T. amends by adding some other pigs, Catholic and Protestant Tenant Right and so on. The Irish Pig Driver? – How to Please the Pigs? – R.F.S. [Punch, 54 (21 March 1868): 125, “Dizzy's Difficulty, or Mrs. Erin's Pigs”]. Quantum mutatus! Several to pool – and I dutifully go home!
March 18, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S.
Shirley is the ‘chiel’ among us taking notes of bonmots. Quotes one of his own to a lady who said, “What great heads girls have nowadays!” “You won't say so if you talk to them!”

L.C. The Irish debate – Gladstone pronounces against the Church, last Monday. P.L. suggests Gladstone and Diz as rival doctors – one saying I'm for amputation; t'other for waiting. M.L. adds John Bull as Consulting Physician, “While you dispute, the patient's dying.” This on Fred's suggestion that Ireland should be brought in. But you can't make a pretty picture of a diseased limb or a tumour. – Cutting off the Cork Leg. ... M.L. also suggests Gladstone giving the church notice to quit: And S.B., the rival architects laying out new roads for Irish Government: Diz saying, “Remove that Church!” Why you'll pull down St. Paul's next!” But the Doctors are approved [Punch, 54 (28 March 1868): 137, “Paddy's Bad Tooth, or Doctors Differ”]. W.B. amending to patient with toothache, “The Irish Church Tooth.”
See Silver’s notes for the meeting of 15 February 1860 for a cartoon (“The Political Pill”) that was also conceived as a “rival doctors” cut but was amended by Leech in the final drawing to leave out Disraeli, much to the annoyance of Brooks. The depiction of doctors in British political caricature is brilliantly explored in Roy Porter’s Bodies Politic: Disease, Death and Doctors in Britain, 1650-1900 (Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 2002).

D.M. sticks up for Swinburne as the writer of lovely verses - the weaver of words – the rhymer of rhymes. More musical than Tennyson. But what a brute! Foul of tongue and foul of thought and foul of act. Lives with Menken in impotent filthiness. Must be mad to let his photograph be taken with hers…
Bernard Falk, The Naked Lady (London: Hutchinson & Co., 1934), 236-239. Falk quotes a letter of Swinburne’s of 17 April 1868 denying that the pictures were designedly made public and complaining that “there has been a damned row about the photographs; paper after paper has flung pellets of dirt at me” (239).

Afterwards D.M. talks of Shirley being shut up by Val Prinsep – and says Leighton and Poynter are both better educated. Tom Taylor also – whose father was a servant? No snobbism about him. but S.B. vain and struggling to be a Swell. Tom not so jolly as S.B., nobody says hurrah! when he enters the room: and he never asks us to his house – although before his marriage (went to Derby with his wife the day after!) he said, “Now all you fellows must come and dine with me and see my wife.”
Leech a victim of Swelldom and of a weak wife. Silliest I ever met, saith D.M.

div.head: March 25, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., Tom A., C.K., H.M, Will A., T.T.

W. Agnew's Wedding Day. ... And Du Maurier's move to his new house – 12 Earl's Terrace. A palace after 91 Great Russell Street. Pangs of parting nevertheless. Pater and I talk of novels – praise those of old: Miss Edgeworth, Scott, etc., and hate such sensation stuff as “Cometh Up as a Flower” which I read on Sunday at Croydon: mixture of coarseness, scraps of Scripture, snobbism and sht.
Rhoda Broughton, Cometh Up as a Flower: An Autobiography (London: Bentley, 1867). This title made Broughton’s reputation as a sensation novelist while attracting controversy for its sexual frankness. D.M.'s difficulties in drawing for Foul Play – girl's wardrobe after a boat voyage and stay on a desert island? Cute dodge that of sending intelligence by ducks - but Boucicault devised a cuter dodge – which was not adopted.
The novel Foul Play, by Charles Reade and Dion Boucicault, with illustrations by Du Maurier, was serialized in Once a Week beginning with the number for January 4, 1868, 1-12 and concluding on June 20. Bradbury and Evans subsequently brought it out in three volumes. A stage version made its debut at Holborn Theatre on May 28, 1868. See Bassett, Troy J. “Title: Foul Play.” At the Circulating Library: A Database of Victorian Fiction, 1837—1901, Accessed 5 June 2024. Burnand's Chikkin Hazard gives D.M. a chance to burlesque his own drawings.
See Punch 54 (14 March 1868) 112-113 for the first chapter of Burnand’s parody of Foul Play, entitled Chikkin Hazard, with Du Maurier’s self-parodying illustrations; the series came to an end on June 27, 54: 276.
How to measure the Sun's Altitude? Take him to a Tailor, saith Mark. “See how easily we throw off these trifles!” Shirley books it. Rather have his book than mine.

Lord Strangford, who has a philological wife (and therefore no children, says Kiki) criticizes Tenniel's Dizzy's dialect: “I'd loike to zee yow droive un!” as being a mixture from three counties: Yorks: Somerset: and Suffolk. Tenniel owns to its being adapted from the Stage. But Mark contends it should be a general sort of dialect – as Diz speaks as Premier of England.

Professor applauds the Saturday for pitching into “The Girl of the Period” who dyes and paints and talks slang and only lives for pleasure and fine dresses.
Eliza Lynn Linton’s provocative and wildly popular essay, “The Girl of the Period,” first appeared, unsigned, in Saturday Review 25 (14 March 1868) 339-340. This was the first of what became a series of articles by Linton vitriolically attacking the aspirations, appearance, and behavior of middle-class young women. “The Girl of the Period” created a sensation and was re-issued in a pamphlet form that sold tens of thousands of copies, while the series inspired an almanac and a short-lived monthly magazine. See Merle Mowbray Bevington, The Saturday Review, 1855-1868 (New York: Columbia University Press, 1941) 110-112. Mark and I agree with him, in measure. But do you know such girls? says Shirley. No – not altogether – but the taint soon spreads, and Swellesses are copied. Miss Gascoigne dyes her hair: and Annie R. powders her face. Still they are both nice girls notwithstanding. But certainly a modest mien is rarer than it was. And I prefer delicacy and softness to a bold face and hard manner.

L.C. Gladstone's avowal of Disestablishing the Irish Church the subject still. T.T. revives Diz's speech, “I'm on the side of the Angels” and would have him as the Guardian Angel of the Church confronting G. as the Demon.

H.M. proposes G. as Samson pulling down the pillars of the Church. C.K. proposes Tournament for Place (which perhaps is true), G. and D. on hobby horses – Ireland Queen of Beauty. Shirley suggests, “Thais led the way to light him to his prey.” Bright leading Gladstone. – After a long debate T.T. solves the problem by suggesting Diz as an old hen gathering Irish bishops under wing while G. is the hawk pouncing ... Ponny suggests 2 weathercocks fighting – funny but impossible – but cock fight is a good notion and Mark combines the two ideas: Diz and Glad, two cocks, while mother church gathers little chickens together. Sympathy would go with Diz if Glad. were made the hawk. And clearly the Church is doomed - - [Punch, 54 (4 April 1868): 148-49, “Battle of the Spurs”].
“Spretae injuria chloroformae” says the Professor: but of what?

A snowy walk home! Summer last week. Shirley tells funny story of a Judge summing up a case – Prisoner charged with using the expression B. in reference to his grandmother, a bookcase, a canary, and a bit of anchovy toast. It will be for you to say if it be possible in two at least of these. It is my duty to instruct you that in the others it is not.
Shirley Brooks recorded this anecdote in his own diary on February 14, 1865, a story he heard the evening before at Mr. Justice Shee’s dinner table (Sir William Shee [1804-1868]), told by lawyer and politician Henry James (1828-1911) about Mr. Justice Byles (Sir John Bernard Byles [1804-1884]): “James told a good bit of Byles, charging a jury in a case where a man had called another a b. and had also, in rage, applied the term to his grandmother, a bookcase, a little dog, and an anchovy. “I am bound to tell you, gentlemen, that in two of these cases, the word implied an impossibility.”

div.head: April 1, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., Tom A., H.M., R.F.S.
D.M. protests against F.C.B.'s letters from artists with bad spelling “honyrarium.”
Mrs. Du Maurier's birthday. Kiki affects to be low spirited – Kensington air?

L.C. Irish Church debate this week. S.B. suggests Scotch lassie, as Free Kirk, saying to Irish Church, “Don't fret, look at me, I've done well without help.” But the Free Kirk is dissent – and how represent churches by girls? P.L. thinks Scotch girl should carry a basket of loaves and fishes. S.B. alters to two priests, fat Irish and lean Churchman [Punch, 54 (11 April 1868): 161, “Crumbs of Comfort”]. Prince of Wales' visit: New St. Patrick casting out Fenians, H.S ... who leaves to see Bandmann in Narcisse: good.

P.L. suggests Diz saying to Gladstone, “Woodman spare that Tree, Touch Not a Single Bough” – the bough being the Irish Church. Prosy.
Leigh is quoting the opening lines from the poem “Woodman, Spare That Tree!” by American poet George Pope Morris (1802-1864); first published in 1837, the poem was set to music in 1853 and became a popular song of the same name.

div.head: April 8, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: C.E., S.B., H.S., H.M., M.L., E., P.L., C.K., R.F.S., T.T.

“Show Sunday” the last – Shirley went to 19 Studios in that and the next day. T.T. agrees with us that Millais' Stella is his finest work for some while past. And the glade in his Rosalind – squirrel playing in it: airy distance: “Looks as though you'd knocked a hole in the wall and let the light through,” Leech used to say.

“Young writers not appreciated,” says Shirley, “we've all felt that. Populus me Sibilat at mihi plaudo” ... And I get the cl-p at home, says H.S.: free translation.
C. Smith note: “Ipse domi, simul ac nummos contemplar in arca,” Horace; “The people hiss me; but I console myself at home as soon as I gaze upon the money in my chest.” “What's the good of saying good things if nobody listens to them?” P.L.

T.T. tells of Chas. Kemble at the Garrick dinner to him (whereat Tom was in the chair). “The Greenroom was a school of manners – actors once were gentlemen – But now I look around in vain for them. 'Woe is me to have seen what I have seen, see what I see!'
Hamlet III, i. Pleasant this for the half dozen actors who had risen and sat down one by one as tho' they were shot.
Taylor had told this story at the Table nine years earlier; see Silver’s entry for January 12, 1859.

M.L. tells of John Forster shouting to Kemble (who was deaf) after Talfourd's death, “I saw Lady Talfourd today, and conveyed to her your condolence.” K – “I condole with Lady T., but I have no recollection of having authorised you to say so.”

L.C. Sending in the Pictures – Diz his picture of Ireland, M.L. But the Prince's visit next week is the Subject – New St. Patrick casting out Fenians, H.S. Princess and 4 leaved shamrock, S.B. L.O.V.E. on the leaves. Shorter than writing Justice, Mercy, Prosperity, Conciliation, [Punch, 54 (18 April 1868): 171, “Alexandra's Offering to Erin”].
Tenniel unwell. Very rarely an absentee.

Plant the earthcloset on its native bog: says Tom to Pater, its puffer. “In bed and all by ten” ... Mrs. Landells. To whom said Douglas, “It was not the Yankee you wanted, but the Doodle.” Her husband and American being expected.
Mrs. Frank Matthews pouring tea, long spout, “You do it just like a man!” D.J. “I caught such a large flea,” said Miss – to him. “Well, I spose you drowned it.”
P.L. tells of man tried for unnatural offence with a Sow: brother says, “Can't understand it. Why, there was his wife quite handy.”
You're pegging back, says Mark to E., who says he's only 64. “Crib-age,” H.M.
S.B. tells of wife's objecting to foreign beds – “ornament fell on the small of his back.” P.L. pulls out his notebook for it to send to brother Fred.
Shirley and Horace at Mark Nelson's to see the Oxford win on Saturday: We at Phillips' with Ben Head and Lottie.

div.head: April 15, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p:
Easter Week and so no dinner. H.S. to the Priory to meet Sir Atlantic Cable Canning.
Samuel Canning (1823-1908), knighted 1866.

div.head: April 22, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., J.T., F.E. P.L, F.C.B. ,

Jackides neuralgic. Ponny at Boulogne. Du Maurier low and nervous for his eye. H.S. all serene. Advises to “give up smoke.”Fred is an abstainer now and even Tenniel only smokes one cg. [cigar] a week instead of two. But Kiki's way of inhaling cigarette smoke must be killing.

L.C. P.L. suggests a view of the Irish Balmoral - that should be. Princess trying on boot - feeble: but that's the subject. This Irish Visit should be repeated yearly. So we agree that Tenniel must evolve a Balmoral ... pigs and all. “Don't see it a bit,” says he. But when Mark calls on him tomorrow it will be all right. ... Burnand suggests a view of town, everything like, even to the pigs and gable ends [Punch, 54 (2 May 1868): 193, “The Irish Balmoral, or a Vision of 1869”]. How poor Bennett would have done it! – He also suggests Bright trying on a Court Suit, apropos of his joining the ministry of the future. By his mildness of late, he seems to be bidding for it. – Leotard has returned to the Trapèze, left it for the Bar. And now he comes back to the bar. – M.L. suggests Gladstone extinguishing Irish Church – spire for extinguisher: but the idea is not new.

*** On Friday morning next Davis tells me poor Mrs.Leech is dead. How sudden! When I called on her last Tuesday week she seemed in good spirits and spoke quite cheerfully. [Son] Bouge was just going to the Charterhouse and Ada, grown so tall, went with him. Poor children! Mark has heard that Charles Eaton has badly invested his sister's money and that she had nothing but her house. How well I remember Leech saying when Thackeray died, “Thank God, we shan't have to pass round the hat.” Must we do it now?

div.head: April 29, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Mrs. Leech's funeral.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T.,F.E., P.L., H.M., T.T. champ.

Shirley's birthday and Mark's daughter's (Mrs. Martin) Wedding day.
Alice (“Lally”) Lemon (1842-1923) married Timothy Henry Martin on April 29, 1862. So we talk of ages: Horace invites us to dine with him on July 10, his 50th Birthday. Tom Taylor was born Oct. 18, 1817. Tenniel is 48: looks 40. Professor 54, Sketchley 41.

Shirley: Why is a bald head like heaven? Because there's neither dying nor parting there. Said Lord Derby, Because there’s no Whig there. Ah but, Says Mark, you might say because a Wig is wanted there. Henry Mayhew defined a Whig as a false thing attached to the Crown.

Ponny's Inexhaustible Pocket: produces railway reading lamp and French newspapers by the score. – Shirley rejoices that at Bristol Sam. Morley is “beaten by Miles” as Mark says: distanced in the race to the Poll.
In the Bristol election, Conservative John William Miles appeared to have won by 196 votes, but the results were challenged by his Liberal opponent Samuel Morley, who charged foul play. After a House of
Commons investigation Miles was found guilty of bribery and the results were thrown out. In the general election in December, Morley defeated Miles by over 2000 votes. Morley would remain MP for Bristol until his retirement in 1885.

L.C. Says P.L., We must glorify Napier. Times of Monday announces death of Theodore, and shooting at Prince Alfred. ... S.B. suggests Cambridge amazed at Napier, an Engineer, winning without the help of the Horseguards. T.T. puts it in shape – and would like to add a hint to foreigners who won't believe we don't mean to colonise [Punch, 54 (9 May 1868): 203, “Another Napier !!!”].
At the Battle of Magdala in Abyssinia on April 10, the British force led by Sir Robert Napier defeated the army of the Emperor Theodore (Teworos), who committed suicide when Napier’s troops stormed his mountain citadel on April 15.

div.head: May 6, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at poor Temple's deathbed.

div.head: May 13, 1868. W[ednesday]. The Mitre. Hampton Court.
div.p: H.S. at Woodbridge: Seckford St.

div.head: May 20, 1868. lW[ednesdayl. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Church St., – thermometer 85° in shade yester-
day.

div.head: May 27, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. The Derby Day. Champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., John A. (“Jagnew”), H.S., Tagnew, S.B., J.T., M.L. , P.L., F.C.B., H.M., Wagnew, R.F.S., T.T.

Tom Taylor “What a happy thing we are all here and not at Epsom and not caring who wins!” – Du M. wins the Sweep with “Blue Gown.” The favorite “Lady Elizabeth” nowhere. So the Battle of (Lord) Hastings ends in his defeat.

Yesterday saw the last Public Hanging at Newgate: Barrett the Fenian. L.C. T.T. suggests Dizzy as King Theodore shooting himself with “Dissolution.” But Shirley seizes on Burnand's hint that Eyre's second trial is near, and Mark and P.L. and H.M. agree he should be defended. T.T. has read the evidence of the Commissioners and thinks he exceeded Justice in hanging and flogging long after the rebels were crushed. “I will have no hand in the Cut.” ... H.S. and the Agnews agree.

But Mark carries Shirley's suggestion of Palmerston's Ghost reproaching Disraeli for not defending Eyre. [ Punch, 54 (6 June 1868): 245, “For the Defence”]. Which comes out à propos on the day when the Times announces that the Grand Jury have thrown out the Bill. Says Blackburn, in order to try him you must place yourself in his position, and say what you would have done with a handful of whites frightened by a myriad of blacks.
The third and final prosecution of Edward Thomas Eyre (see note to the entry for November 29, 1865) for high crimes and misdemeanors took place in the Court of Queen’s Bench on June 2-3, 1868, the issue being the constitutionality of martial law, pitting Lord Chief Justice Cockburn against Sir Colin Blackburn. The grand jury again refusedto return an indictment. Both Punch and the Times deplored the Eyre prosecutions. See the report of the case published by Chapman and Hall in 1868.

div.head: June 3, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W . B., D.M., H.S., Tagnew, S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., Wagnew.

D.M. won the Oaks Sweep with Formosa. Double event of Luck. Shirley goes to Henley for Ascot Week: proposes a schoolboy theme for the Arse-cut. C.K. quotes man saying “Barrett's gone to Hell” - Friend doubts ... “Well, you'll see!” W.B. and D.M. chaffed by F.C.B. for their Jokemaking Co. Limited. When W.B. makes a joke, D.M. publishes it to the Table.

D.M. says boys have big bums – F.C.B. doubts – “You had, at any rate,” says Kiki. F.C.B. retorts something about Christopher Columbus – Apropos de quoi? Shirley cuts in with “Christopher would look a long while round this table before he discovered the Continent.” Good!
D.M. shows how a one armed fiddler can pick up a penny – digita quà penis

L.C. W.B. upstairs had suggested Diz as Leotard who has written to say his great fall is an intended one. [ Punch, 54 (13 June 1868): 257, “Political Leotard”].
Benjamin Disraeli’s loss in the general election of 1868 left him as leader of the Opposition until his return to power in 1874. D. falls on “Dissolution.” S.B. puts it in shape. Then the late birds fly to billiards: H.S. walking home in the “Moonbames,” “Where be your spirits now?” Remembered how blithely one played bowls with Lucas at Kilpack's, or strolled home Viâ Regenticâ, and sighed for someone awaiting. O si praeteritos!
Mais esperons. – Burnand married at 23 – so is in no hurry to get home.
Sketchley absent having lost his mother. Eve of Charity Children at St. Paul's. “Little darlings,” says B. (her first visit).

div.head: June 10, 1868. W[ednesday]. No dinner.
div.p: Tomorrow D.M. wins Ascot Sweep with “Blue Gown.” Wins all three Sweeps!

div.head: June 17, 1888. lW[ednesday]. No. 11. H.S. at Handel Festival.
June 24, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Greenwich: the Trafalgar: sitting between pleasant pretty Miss Williams and pleasant Dr. Hamilton. Blanche [Silver] between Murray the Great (who thinks her Scotch!) and Fred Nightingale, who is opposite pretty Kate Hamilton. – Horace's Banquet: 20 in all. Mr. Howard (Commissioner of Woods and Forests) etc. etc.
[Clipping from the Pall Mall Gazette, June 22, 1868, p. 4]:

“THE LATE JOHN LEECH.–We learn with sincere gratitude that Mr. Disraeli has responded to the appeal made to him on behalf of the orphan children of John and Anne Leech, and has caused the pension granted to their late mother to be continued to them. This act of kindness and consideration on the part of the Premier will assuredly be appreciated by all who cherish John Leech's memory and deplore his early death.”
The appeal had been organized by Silver. This paragraph was reprinted in the Times for June 23, 1868, p. 12.

div.head: July 1, 1868. W[ednesday]. Royal Hotel, Purfleet.
div.p: Very pretty view of river.
W.B. H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M.
H.S. basks in the shade atop of chalkpit and scribbles “ Musical Nuisances.” M.L. knocked up by a walk from opposite Greenhithe with Fred and W.B.

Hear that Edmund Yates is trying to pass the Bankruptcy Court. How the shade of Thackeray must chuckle! This comes of having a fine wife (who dyes her hair and paints her cheek) and a brougham and a park hack.
Edmund Yates appeared before the Bankruptcy Court with debts in excess of £7000.

C.K. tells of a workman at the Pictures. “Why, I'm told as the Paint costs as much as £5, let alone the Man's time for laying of it on!” S.B. tells of a father losing his child: “Not speak! Vy, he called his mother a b-r as plain as plain the day afore he died!”

L.C. S.B. suggests one or two things which I forget and finally Bright lifting up Gladstone whose Suspensory Bill has been floored by the Lords, “Wait till my big brother, the Reformed Commons, comes next half!” which is approved [Punch, 55 (11 July 1868): 15, “Athletics at Westminster”]. J.B. suggests Cricket Match, Lords and Commons. “We'll beat you next time.” Last week's suggestion crops up, “Peers bolting door against Reform with a boiled carrot.” Fred suggests John Bull's Holiday Task, considering what to do with Irish Church.

div.head: July 8, 1868. W[ednesday] . No. 11.
div.p: W.B., DM., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., T. Agnew.

L.C. S.B. suggests Napier and Eyre, Contrast: I conquered a king and was made a peer – I saved an island and was almost hanged. ... Amends it to Hero Worship at a shilling a head. Napier at C[rystal] P[alace] today, and again amends it to the three Lions (The Lion Show, M.L.). Prince Alfred at Crystal Palace on Saturday at 5/- [Punch, 55 (18 July 1868): 27, “Great Lion Show, 1868”]. “Walking in the Zoo” a pretty tune, says F.C.B. A vulgar fraction of Zoological Gardens, say I. “Weight for Age – wait,” said Mark last Wednesday.
Arthur Lewis had a daughter on the 6th – “Born with spectacles and grey hair like Tom Taylor's,” says D.M. James Hannay Consul of Brest: Shirley hopes it's a Brest flowing with Milk and Honey.

div.head: July 11, 1868
div.p: [Silver writes, in a more careful hand, his wife’s note to Horace Mayhew on the occasion of his 50th birthday dinner]:

“Mrs. Henry Silver envoi ses sincères felicitations à M. Horace Mayhew au sujet de son cinquantième anniversaire, et espère avec tous ses amis qui dans un demi-siècle il sera encore prêt à présider un second diner en L'honneur d'une autre cinquantaine, faisant ainsi mentir l'opinion générale qui ne nous en accordeordinairement qu'une. Le 10 Juillet 1868.”

“The Pleasure of your Company is most earnestly requested on Saturday July 11th at the Albion Tavern, Aldersgate Street, to meet Mayhew, and wish him joy of his 50th birthday. Dinner at 6 o'clock sharp. Ponny Pays. “
Right H.M. Left
W.B., Jr Shirley
Tagnew Fred Evans
Tenniel Bouquet of Tom Taylor
Japan lilies
Sketchley &c., &c., &c.!! Jagnew
Keene Burnand
Du Maurier Wagnew
Pater Evans Silver
M.L. Professor Leigh

Turtle so hot that it hurts one's palate. But the day is oppressive and everyone seems dull – till the speeches are over. - La Grande Duchesse (seen last night) first topic: “Can't call her a wooden actress, tho' she smacks of the boardy, eh?” ...

M.L. proposes with a quiver in his voice the health of our dear friend Ponny: I'm your oldest friend at the table – we've grown old together in years and iniquity – that is, I’ve done the years, and you the iniquity. You are, next to me, the oldest worker on Punch, and so we accept your invitation. Punch remarkable for its good fellowship” ... etc. etc. Ponny thanks us “for the large compliment we pay him by our coming to drink his poor health. – Except Mr. Bradbury (Senior) all are present – Wishes that Leech, and Gil A Beckett, and Thackeray and Jerrold could also be here.”“They are here in spirit,” shouts Mark.
Ponny proposes Bradbury, père. W.B. thanks us. Mark presents oriental onyx pin to Ponny: “the gift of the Table” (?) – Ponny à la Française kisses the hand of the Presenter and thanks.
Du Maurier sings a song to Ponny, written by Shirley – very good. “Willikins” tune. Keene chanteth – bis – the 3 Ravens.

W.B. proposes Pater – who says Ponny and Mark remember the early struggles of Punch – how we met at the Edinburgh Castle once and debated whether to go on! We paid literature more liberally than had been done – were laughed at by our fellow publishers, but set the fashion of liberality to Authors.
Burnand sings a parody on Voici le Sabre – “Go to the Barber,” ending “Well may the Keel row” which is akin in tune: as is “Draw the Sword, Scotland.”
Professor on Swinburne: who fell down in a fit at the Museum yesterday:
“Youth from the fate of this young bard
This lesson understand:
Take care how you abuse the yard
And how you use the hand.”
Fred sings “Viva la Compagnie” – impromptu by Shirley, bringing in most of us, e.g. “Here's to the writer of horrible books, I hardly need mention his name, Shirley Brooks.”

Tom Taylor emits an impromptu about Pater and his earth closets (Moules) about the earth and 'Evans.
F. M. Evans was related by marriage to Rev. Henry Moule of Dorset, the inventor of the earth closet. Rev.
