Moule had married Evans's older sister, Mary Mullett Evans (1801-1877), in 1824; Evans married Moule's younger sister, Maria Moule (1807-1850), in 1830. Robert L. Patten and Patrick Leary, ‘Evans, Frederick Mullett (1803-1870)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.

Horace proposes “To the Memory of Thackeray, Leech, Jerrold and others.” Says Longfellow especially hopes on return from Italy to shake hands with Punch – i.e. Mark. Give our old Lemon a hearty good squeeze. Shirley proposes Mark's health: one who appreciates a good suggestion and does not snub his writers, “I could mention several faults of his, but do not wish to detain you to a late hour.”

D.M. sings “Dites lui,” and “For all my fancy dwells upon Nancy” etc. etc.
See “Songs of Sixpence,” Punch 56 (10 August 1869) 149 for a parody of the latter. And just as I reach the train the rain begins – after a sultry day. Delightful to get wet!

div.head: July 15, W[ednesday]. Windsor (Johnson's) 1868. champ.
div.p: WI.B. H.S., M.L., S.B., T. J.T., F. E. P.L. H.M., R.F.S., T.T.
See over the private apartments – Many good Canaletti's and VanDyke's. But the views from the windows beat the pictures.
Sweltering hot – 3 goes of beef, and seltzer ad lib for lunch. Envy M.L. his power of cup-ping. (Diarrh. on Monday after gingerbeer at Henley.)
Tom tells how Macready mistook a clown from a neighbour's circus for a young actor who was to play Osric and watched Macready from the wing: “Drest for part! Good heavens!”
S.B. tells of Yankee boaster that he knew everybody: Siamese Twins? – “Ye-es, I think I've met one of them, but I forget exactly which.”

L.C. The Bribery Bill the Subject: M.P.'s making rods for their own backs, P.L. One or two other weak notions, till S.B. proposes a big rat trap and voters smelling the bribe, which they don't yet know how to get at. (Accepted.) [ Punch, 55 (25 June 1868): 39, “The Rats in Council”].
The Parliamentary Elections Act, designed to reduce electoral corruption, passed and received Royal Assent on July 31, 1868.

Discursive discussion as to Napier – whom Tenniel wants to honour. Something anent Rasselas, says Professor. Happy Valley of a Peerage. Cambridge and Pakington on his shoulders reaching up to put Napier's coronet on, T.T.

div.head: July 22, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., F.E., P.L., R.F.S., S.B.
Blazing hot! Yesterday the hottest day I say : to-day, the Times says. 27 frost at Barrows yesterday. (Brooms & Horace with us from Thursday last, when Friths & Barrows dined, blazingly.)
S.B. tells of Swell : “Lie still you - I don't want your help.”

L.C. – “Cut and come again” motto for Punch Dinners, Mark suggests “Clerk of Weather waking up St. Swithin.” Accepted – too hot to argue [Punch, 55 (1 August 1868): 49, “The ‘Clerk of the Weather’ Wakes Up St. Swithin.”]. (Tomorrow East Wind, no sun, quite cool! Patti's farewell – wedded next Wednesday. A small meet, say I. But it won't be a small drink, says Shirley: ha, ha!)

div.head: July 29, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Cool day. Showery!! F.E., D.M., H.S., S.B., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S., T.T. Champ.

Jackides Tenniel, or Grumpy as Shirley now calls him, has the Gout! Shirley tells of Frenchman telegraphing : “Votre belle mère est presque morte - venez demain par le train de plaisir” (excursion train).
Our St. Swithin cut has brought some rain today, apropos!
Adelina Patti and Caux today: Never ad-a-leaner, D.M. French literature – “Paul” purveyor – Paul's Epistles, S.B.

L.C. P.L. suggests Diz as Schoolmaster – breaking up (Parliament dissolved tomorrow.) S.B. adds, “There'll be some new boys next half.” But Charles betters the idea by saying, “Landlady and lodgers” which Shirley snaps at – “Was you wishing to take the apartments when you come from the country?” Diz: “Um – I shall want them a week or two - and then we'll talk about a permanency.” Accepted. [ Punch, 55 (8 August 1868): 59, “Going to the Country”].
Mark and I beat Ponny and Fred 2 games at billiards.

div.head: August 5, 1868. No. 11.
div.p: (What a blase bête is H.S. compared to the H.S. at his first Punch dinner X ten years ago : August 4/58!!
[in black ink] X at No. 11... first Dinner was at Richmond Star & Garter Saturday Aug. 29/57. Blazing! Rain tomorrow.
W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

D.M. expecting his No. 4. So doesn't go away this month. M.L. goes to Barmouth! The Milton discovery: T.T. and R.F.S. think the Epitaph by Milton: S.B. and P.L. don't.
In the Times letter column on July 16, 1868 (10c), Henry Morley announced that he had found, in the library of the British Museum, an unpublished poem by John Milton on a blank page at the end of a copy of Milton’s Early Poems, published in 1645. The poem, titled “An Epitaph,”, “Grumpy, Lumpy, and Bumpy,” Punch 55 (25 July 1868): 42“Poetry or Doggerel?” Punch 55 (1 August 1868): 45 Milton's fame is fixed. But if Paradise Lost were published tomorrow, it would be severely criticised, T.T. – A man who makes bawdy photographs sins against the light, P.L. “Grumpy” Tenniel in a list slipper! Eats toe-martyr soup. Whiting uncoi-witing.
D.M. imitates nervous man making a speech, playing with glasses as tho’ playing at chess. S.B. tells how Wellington scared inventor of ballproof coat: “Tell 2 men to load with ball.”

L.C. Raising of Southern Railway fares
See Times leaders on the increase in second- and third-class railway fares, July 14, 1868 (9c) and August 5, 1868 (6d).: robbing shareholders and now passengers: 2 Wrongs make me right, T.T. Garotters, M.L. The New Dick Turpin, T.T. (accepted). [Punch, 55 (15 August 1868): 70-71, “The Modern Dick Turpin; or, Highwayman & Railwayman”]. P.L. wants a gallows in the background – D.M. thinks Vanity Fair a little Bible. “Rather an Epistle by the Corinthians,” says Shirley . .. Then Fred & I play Mark and W.B., game and game: they win the last by a fluke, we scoring 60 to their 61.

div.head: August 12, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., F.E., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Du Maurier's No. 4 born on Saturday : So we drink to Madlle Mary. And Shirley quotes the old ballad “Last night the Queen had 4 Maries, tonight she'll have but three” ... pathetic the line “And I so soundly sleep!”
Tom says he dreamt his girl fell out of window and he ran for doctor ... and of course couldn't find one. Said the child “Did you go in your nightgown, papa?”

L.C. Mark suggests Diz building a rampart on seashore round Irish Church and Gladstone letting in the Sea ... of Popular Opinion says H.S. Shirley adds English Church on a rock near by and Mrs. Gamp (Standard) saying “Drat the boy, he'll be a washing of our church away next.” Accepted [Punch, 55 (22 August 1868): 81, “The Rising Tide”]. The only 'oss a Cockney can keep his seat upon: the Os sacrum S.B.
Pourquoi est ce que l'evêque ne demeure pas a Lambette? – Parceque ça l'embete. (Du M. inven.)
New words: insinuendos: eloquism: Happy accidents.
New rhymes: There was a young princess called Dagmar, Who s[ai]d I sh[oul]d much like a shagma, So I think if I speaks to the King of the Greeks, He will lend me his tally wagma.
There was a young lady of Glo'ster
Whose relations all thought they had lost her:
Till they found on the grass the print of her -
And the knees of the man who had crost her.
There was an old lady of Putney,
Who was sadly addicted to Glut'ney:
Twas her custom to pass her thumb up her -
And swear that it tasted like Chutney.

div.head: August 19, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., J.T., S.B., C.K., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

H.S. from Shipley today. Leeds Exhibition Friday and Sunday, thanks to Tom T.
The National Exhibition of Works of Art was opened by the Prince of Wales at the New Infirmary in Leeds on May 19. Strawberry girl, little innocent demure eyed : Nelly O'Brien, the sweet-smiling Rembrandt's daughter and Greuze's young girl, semi-draped, smiling up from bed.

T.T. suggests the Rival Showmen, Diz, the British Constitution: Church & State: Gladstone, “See the Contented Irishman – alive within!” – S.B. – the 3 Judges of Hell : Bribery Bill to wit: one of them had no business at the bar, and one has no business on the bench .. . S.B. The New House Workingman tries to enter – “Only gentlemen are rich enough at present.” TT.. suggests Pusey dancing up to Wesley : apropos of his letter : C.K. amends to pretty Puritan : accepted [ Punch, 55 (29 August 1868): 91, “Rejected Addresses”], spite of Fred who wants a holiday cut – Mr. Punch and so forth.
See the Times leader (August 17, 1868, 10e), “Pusey and the Wesleyan Conference,” occasioned by his letter to the Conference asking them to resist Lord Coleridge's bill to abolish University tests.
Actually the parks are green again! a week's rain!

div.head: August 26, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. to Le Havre via S & L. at Milanthorpe Monday
24th: Paris 27 to 30 S. Versailles ... arrive
au Tillac Monday August 31st, 8 a.m. “Moustiquiers.”

div.head: September 2, 1868. W[ednesday]. At the Bedford Hotel.
div.p: H.S. au Tillac, doux hamac, ou les bons cours font tic-tac! - ancle bitten and wibblewobbley. Mais les Balousats sont bons!

div.head: September 9, 16, 23, 30. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. au Tillac.
Vintage begins Sept. 7, ended Oct. 1. La dernière Baste.

div.head: October 7, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. au Tillac CD. ... Albert to Pergueux Oct. 5.
Royan September 28.

div.head: October 14, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S.
H.S. left Ambarès at 5.30 yesterday: waited at Libourne an hour: arrove Paris 5.45, left Paris 7.5 – missed train at Amiens by scampering to Cathedral – but reached town at 4.40 ... Maigré.

Mark's Falstaff began last Monday – will do. We take Louisa to see it next Friday. His shock of sorrow when banished and his crestfallen but manly bearing when sent to the Fleet!!
The Times review of Lemon’s October 12 debut performance at the Gallery of Illustration appeared on14 October 1868, 5a.

How one relishes a glass of beer after seven weeks of Vin Ordinaire! And how strong and luscious sherry tastes! How one smells the London smoke too! Can understand pet's dismay when she first came – 2 years since – poor child! Shall I ever forget that pale innocent loving yearning face in that simple blue capuline which would keep blowing off her head in the pitiless Paris East wind.

L.C. Bishop of Chichester has spoken out against Purchas, the Brighton Ritualist. “We'll have no more smoking (incense) in Church.” P.L. – naughty boy – you'll set the church on fire” - M.L. Burnand adds, “That's what they'd like to do.” Cut accepted [ Punch, 55 (24 October 1868): 175, “The Chichester Extinguisher”]. M.L. also suggests Servants' Hall – Master Bull and his Ministers and their estimates. – Economy in butcher's bills etc. etc. P.L. wants a cut about the Jesuits expelled from Spain.
[Here follows 2 press cuttings:]
“The Prince and Princess of Wales went on Saturday evening (October 17]) to Mr. Mark Lemon's reading of “Falstaff,” at the Gallery of Illustration in Regent Street.”
[written in] (Times, Sep./9/68 Wednesday) On the 7th Sept., HORACE MAYHEW, Esq., of Old Bond Street, to EMILY SARAH, widow of the late HENRY S. FEARON, Esq.]

div.head: October 21, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Glencham. Battue tomorrow: 11 guns. Pet frightened and crying for the poor little
birds ... Pilcher hears of his brother's drowning at Jersey.

div.head: October 28, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. from Glencham. W.B., H.S., M.L., SB., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

I thought Mark was chaffing when last week he joked about Ponny being married and the Haymarket nighthouses being closed in consequence. But – vide suprà. So I drink to him – and his. Never too late to mend.

Shirley asks if the Romans spoke of “meretrix” as “conciliatrix.” Tom Taylor has been staying at Bamboro' Castle in Northumberland – fine site – interesting memories. How well he looks! And how many walnuts he eats! Shirley's remedy for street robberies: Castrate your ruffians after the second offense. 80,000 thieves in the 35 millions here: Logic says Exterminate the nuisance. Mark contends that the State is to blame – no work for man after prison. Children of criminals should be confiscated to the State and compulsorily educated.

T.T. says Durham Cathedral the finest specimen of Norman .. Describes rocks 600 feet on coast where a fisherman once leaped 12 feet across! Sensation scene. D.M. writes, “Although my silence may have funked you all,
You’ll find the Spectre Subject punctual.”

Monte Christo damned at Adelphi – but running still. Fechter's part described a la Joseph in Scripture, “Seven changes of raiment and – no – talent.”
“The Count of Monte Cristo” at the Adelphi, a lavish production nearly five hours long starring Benjamin Webster as Noirtier and Charles Fechter as Edmond Dantès, met a disastrous reception on its opening night of 18 October 1868; the Times the following day noted that “hisses were abundant” (10d). Shortened and revised in response to widespread criticism, the play ran for ninety-six performances, closing in early February. See Alfrida Lee, “The 1868-1869 Season,” in Alfred L. Nelson and Gilbert B. Cross, editors, The Adelphi Theatre 1806-1900: A Calendar of Performances (1998).

L.C. J.T. and P.L. advocate a slash at the Street ruffian - Mayne to blame. T'other night burglars overheard planning, yet it was hard to make police defend. S.B. suggests Dizzy Canute reproving Courtiers – “See, the tide of public opinion is gaining ground against me.” Also: How's the Marker? Diz and Glad. at billiards ... Gladstone, “Coming to his Majority,” ... apropos of Election .. also, parody of the old lines – “Tis time we should part, my dear Sue: For your character's totally lost, And I've not sufficient for two.” Sue, the Irish Church – and the fair speaker the English.
T.T. suggests Diz as the political parrot who “says nothing but thinks the more” – apropos of his silence just now, and Gladstone's speeches.

J.T. reverts to his suggestion of Tournament, Diz and Glad. as Knights. Bright the Squire “accomplishing” the latter – Shirley suggests Diz as Richard Third in the Ghost Scene – but the Professor by a happy thought improves this to Diz, as Gloucester between the English and Irish churches. “See where his Grace stands 'twixt two clergymen.” Accepted. [ Punch, 55 (7 November 1868): 195, “A Political Parallel”].

div.head: November 4, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. H.S. from
div.p: Havant.
W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

L.C. Ulysses Grant chosen President: Ulysses in the hall of the Suitors: Homer, S.B. Police taking up hoops and not garotters: P.L. – But Parliament dissolves on the 11th and S.B. suggests Landlady Britannia “airing the House” for new comers: accepted. [ Punch, 55 (14 November 1868): 205, “Airing the House”].
S.B. tells how Pugin, with Stansfield, called on Wiseman and wrapped t-ds in paper – “his first sign of madness,” says Burnand. “No,” says P.L., “his joining the Roman Church was that.”

div.head: November 7, 1868. Saturday at the Bedford. “Almanack Dinner.” champ.
div.p: F.E., H.M., D.M., H.S., R.F.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., E. C.K., F.C.B., T.T.
Thirteen! At Christmas, Dr. Tait couldn't come – nor Gissing take his seat ... and we were 13 – Been low lately – thinned by my French thin potations: and the cold weather.
T.T. suggests “Compulsory Education” ... Workman ridicules the Ignorance of the Upper Classes.
F.C.B. suggests Amateur Opera. Some fun to be got somehow.
S.B. suggests Girls of the Period: “Are we so very bad?”
T.T. suggests A Voyage to the Honey Moon: and the Strange Sights seen in it.

Haven't seen Pater for a Century – looks blooming: tho' Shirley said he'd lost his Savings.
Evans's disastrous investment in a papermaking company, in partnership with his son and Charles Dickens junior, led to the loss of his savings and an appearance before the bankruptcy court in December 1868, which entailed the further embarrassment of his temporary ouster from the Garrick Club. Robert L. Patten and Patrick Leary, ‘Evans, Frederick Mullett (1803-1870)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004. D.M. cut down to 5 cigarettes a day: resolves to ride daily and live frugally: Frightened by his eye this sum- mer. But we all have our troubles ... even Burnand begins to show gray hairs and he's not more than 9 and 20! Wish I'd his spirits tho' ... Certainly I don't feel so jolly as I did at 8 and 20. One sad thought will sadden an existence.
 [drawing of pointing hand] No Lord Mayor's Party in Fleet St. – so Pettums sees the Big Coach in Whitehall Place for the first time. And thinks it very clumsy.

div.head: November 11, 1868. _W[ednesday]. No dinner
div.p: (Lord Mayor's Show seen for first time chez Horace. “Very clumsy.”)

div.head: November 17, 1868. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., R. F. S.
H.S. eats a dozen oysters – “quite a grotto,” says Mark. So much for a shooting walk at Farnborough with Gas- coyen and Smith: (2 brace birds and a hare: at which
I wiped S's eye).

City election today: Twells, Tory, minority member, kicks out Rothschild. And Smith the newspa- per member kicks out Mill for Westminster. Tenniel has settled the Tournament cut, sequel showing Diz unhorsed by Glad [ Punch, 55, 216-17 for “Before the Tournament” and sequel on Punch, 55, 228-29 “In the Melee”]. D.M. takes to riding of late for health's sake. And only smokes 5 cigarettes a day.

Religious jaw ... Ponny thinks it sufficient to say the Lord's Prayer and trust to an all merciful God to save him, sinner as he is. Gets half maudlin hereat. Mark thinks churches needless. How can one man send another to Heaven? Simple childlike trust in God the only satisfaction. Herein H.S. agrees. Try to do your duty and obey your conscience and have faith in God's mercy. Were we tried by man, who of us would see Heaven? Mill wrong to subscribe to the atheist blasphemous Bradlaugh for his election – but right to say that voters should not too narrowly scrutinise their member's religious faith. “Cui bono?” is the strong point with an atheist. What good to create a world in which so much misery will come? But cui bono such arguments? The world is made and we are alive and instead of guessing why we are, we should try to do our duty to the Being who made us and the beings who are living with us.

 [drawing of pointing finger] Tomorrow for the first time I VOTE ... for Dilke and Hoare v. Freake and Billy Russell.
Standing for Chelsea, Liberal candidates Henry Hoare and Charles W. Dilke defeated Conservatives Charles James Freake and William Howard Russell by a wide margin. Ponny plumped for Mill yesterday. Last Sunday his wife's birthday .. met Shirley et ux. and Ponny's sister et mari. .. Talking of Charity School treats, says Mrs. (44), “I don't mind how many children you give me, 'Orace.” ... “Don't be impatient , my dear.” My pretty little tortichell cat shrinks timidly from the 3 great bouncing pussies.

div.head: November 24, 1868. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Holland Park: Herbert et ux .. Miss Dillon (by H.S.). 13 in all.

div.head: December 2, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., Tagnew, M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., Wagnew, H.M. , R.F.S., T.T.
Birthdays: yesterday Mrs. Fred: Monday, Mark: tomorrow W.B. Mark never better. Falstaff agrees with him. Shirley suggests “Falstaff Married” to Mrs. Page, and henpecked
into thinness. Wagnew gives kudos to Bright – applauds even his speeches on the Russian War. All the world praises him now.

L.C. Shirley suggests Ixion out of Heaven.
A play on Benjamin Disraeli’s early novel, Ixion in Heaven (1833). Obviously accepted [Punch, 55 (12 December 1868): 250-51, “Ixion Out of Heaven”]. Turkey and Greece row not ripe.

div.head: December 9, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., S.B., F.C.B., P.L., M.L., E., C.K., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Pocket Book dinner: published today - A merry meeting. F.C.B. tells how Duke of Cambridge said to Artist of Queen's Wedding: “But I don't see the Duchess.”“Oh, she's sitting behind that pillar.” . . “O, ah, very proper .. all right .. as long as she's there.” Companion picture by P.L.: Stanley the Surgeon, complained of not seeing both sides of a diseased bone, in a drawing.
Bailey's “Eve at the Fountain” (in Exeter St.) supplemented by Adam at the Brunswick.

L.C. M.L. suggests Bright introduced by Gladstone – Landlady Britannia says, “Why, who'd have thought of seeing him here!” accepted. But doesn't appear ... Probably S.B. afterwards suggests Bright dancing with the Princess. [Punch, 55 (19 December 1868): 261, “A ‘Friend’ at the Court”].

div.head: December 16, 1868. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: All but C.K., and T.T. Pater sits to my left. Wagnew sits to the right of W.B.

Almanack dinner. Published tomorrow. J.T. angry because his Rantoone cuts are misplaced, he says.
“A Run with a Rantoone,” Punch’s Almanack for 1869, Punch 56 (1869), p. 10. A “rantoone” was a lever-operated tricycle or velocipede. The joke of Tenniel’s sequence of cuts depends in part upon the time assigned to the incident in each cut, but the placement of the cuts is out of order. H.S. with his right eye shaded…fall asleep at the Priory last night. Numb skull…postage stamp remedy. Apropos, D.M. tells of Yankee with eye on cheek. “What will your wife say?” ... “Shows bull – “What will t'other beggar's wife say?” ... D.M. pokes fun at Ponny about his Hansom ride with him last week. – “Dear clever boy” – chants to the air of the Mahogany Tree: chorus by Burnand who is noisy as ever ... Hustings orator: Mr. Bright – bah! his eye is on the Treasury Bench. – Mob: “Yes, and he'll soon have his a- on it!”

L.C. Shirley suggests Reverdy Johnson kissing Britannia under mistletoe. .. Amends it to J. Bull and Reverdy holding up the mistletoe - accepted. [ Punch, 55 (26 December 1868): 273, “Under the Mistletoe”].
Reverdy Johnson (1796-1876). In 1868 he was appointed ambassador to Great Britain. Wants a new type for John B. – but J.T. objects. S.B. tells of old lady to foxhunter: “I can see the gentleman as well thro' the silk as the buckskin. “

S.B. contends that a man of moderate means should be moderate in his love – 2 children will be better cared for than 12. Pater, Mark and Wagnew contrà: Pater has had 12 – and 8 are living - no right to check Nature... the thirteenth child may be your chief blessing. Love is not lust. Providence sends children. .. Bah, saith Shirley: Men have a fit of the beast, and call it Providence!

div.head: December 22, 1868. T[uesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M,, R.F.S., T.T.

L.C. T.T. suggests Turkey and Greece as appropriate for Christmas – all the fat in the fire. Great Powers putting it out: Austria taking off the Coals – i.e. the Principalities. France, chef, pouring cold water ..Russia standing by, waiting. – But J.T. thinks it only a feeble play on words..must at least have pantomime masks. “Harlequin Poluphlosboio Thalasses, or The Great Mogul of the Boundless Bosphorus,” S.B. [Punch, 55 (2 January 1869): 283, “Turkey and Grease”]. Harlequin King Preposteros – would be fitter.

T.T. savage at English clumsiness. French audience more intelligent – But claque has killed natural applause, and without applause actors cannot act. The thrill – frissonne – of an audience says more than a loud clapping. This apropos of the Gaiety which opened last Monday. The Globe opened a month ago. .. T.T. also suggests Tailors Reseating Ministers. Says Tenniel should have drest Bright in white breeches – wear white at Court Balls.

S.B. chaff with Val Prinsep: – Val – I never can read Punch. Shirley – S'pose you will when you know how. Val – I only read what the artists write under their cuts. Shirley – O well, of course any child can understand what an artist writes.

div.head: December 29, 1868. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Holland Park: with B., S. & L., Cobbs and W. Watson. Lotty CD chez nous – “My bride.”

And so ends the Year at the Round Table. .. Which has been enlarged since I first sat at it – ten years ago. A big slice of a mature lifetime. Are my wits as sharp as when I came first? Certainly my tongue is not that of a ready speaker. Kicky and Burnand are younger at the Board, but have older hands at chaff. Still I remember the talk of Thackeray and Leech, and don't envy their successors’ inferior gift of gab.....
Joshua Thomas dies Dec. 30th.
 [drawing of pointing hand] My first Christmas Day in London: Ben Head and Alfred: Jos. and Lotty: S. & L.: & Sketchley dine with us.

div.head: January 6, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., T.Agnew, M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., H.M., R.F.S.

Professor from Southampton by letter suggests Ritualists doubtful between Pope and Paymaster: recent law decision dead against them. Also suggests Gladstone at his Holiday Task of Disestablishment. – But Shirley hits the nail apropos of the murder of Mr. Baker in Ireland last week – shot in early morning by a tenant, Dwyer, evicted for quarreling with brother etc. Suggests Justice: Gladstone sacrificing Church for her sake and not for murdering peasants. [Punch, 56 (16 January 1869): 16–17, “Justice to Ireland”].
In his diary entry for this date, Shirley Brooks noted: “Smallish meeting. I suggested the cut, a protest that we disfranchise, I mean destroy, the Irish church, for the sake only of justice, not to please the assassins of priests.” The entry for January 12 records: “Tenniel has done my big cut nobly, on double block—'Gladstone Sacrificing the Irish Church to Justice, not to Papists and Assassins.' This cut should make a sensation.” (London Library)

On dit that Strahan & Co. have agreed to pay Tennyson £4000 yearly for his Copyrights.
Interestingly, the amount of this payment has traditionally been given as £5,000, but Silver’s figure of £4,000 turns out to be the correct one, agreeing with that found in the Tennyson-Strahan contract unearthed by Patricia Thomas Srebrnik and in Tennyson’s own diary; see her Alexander Strahan, Victorian Publisher (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1986), 227, n. 42. For the making of the contract, and Bradbury and Evans’s possible role in it as friendly acquaintances of the poet and creditors of the publisher, see Srebrnik, 100-107. Mark has 64 plays on the Dramatic List – and gets £50 yearly by them. But some of his best pieces are locked up with Webster: who first encouraged him as a playwright. Shirley suggests a page of the “of the Period” taken from each English reign. Good.
D.M. asks for “Confiture de groseille.” “Give him some Champagne,” says Mark.

div.head: January 13, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Cham.
div.p: W.B., H.S., Pater, M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., F.C.B* H.M., R.F.S.

Garotter’s letter in the Times today asking brother to “dose the Moll” and “square the block” (gent. who went home with her) shows how murderous such brutes are. Our Unsafe Streets the subject: Sketchley suggests Cat o' Nine Tails as the New Police Commissioner – Sir R. Mayne being dead. But M.L. revives his old pet notion flog the man but save his children – who should be confiscated to the State. But where can you send them. N'importe. So we accept his and Shirley's cut of the Cat on one side and the Emigration Vessel “Rescue” on the other [Punch, 56 (23 January 1869): 28-29, “Prevention Better Than Cure”]. And tomorrow as I walk to town I write 8 lines of the Song of the Street Ruffian, and next day's walk add the rest – 16.
“The Song of the Street Ruffian,” Punch, 56 (23 January 1869): 34. Pater v. Shirley on the vexed question: Should poor people marry? ... D.M. writes, “I can't be with you in the flesh, nor in the fish or fowl.” – “Du Maurier absent – then Ponny may talk French,” says Shirley. New halfpenny journal “The Echo.” Doesn't pay. “Well,” says Shirley, “The Echo may not pay, but Echo always answers.”
Mark will one day tell what he knows of Punch: Squeezing a Lemon – or Records of the Round Table.”
[Pasted in note from Shirley Brooks (note in Silver handwriting, “Shirley Scripsit”) entitled, ‘Ben Jonson to you all.”]

Justice Overdo. Neither do thou lust after that tawny weed, tobacco. Whose complexion is like the Indian’s that vends it. And who can tell if, before the gathering and making up thereof, the alligarta hath not pissed thereon.” Barth. Fair.

div.head: January 20, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.I. , R.F.S. ,T.T.

All the Punch staff present! T.T. been laid up with sore shin – but liked the quiet. Been enjoying Leech's sketches: amazed at their truth as well as humour – and at the slight means used to produce effect. Genius only could command such versatility.

Says he conceived the third Act of “The Overland Route” in a ten minute walk on Wandsworth Common. Sat down at 1 p.m. and wrote currente calamo till 1 a.m. as fast as his wife could copy, and so finished Act. But he says now he always works in the morning – less exhausting – greatest nerve-force at night – and playwriting is exciting and should be done cool. He is never so happy as when hard worked – hard work never killed a man – but badly arranged work, ill timed, may do so.

Apropos of T.W. Robertson's “School,” Burnand christens him, “The Dramatic Trollope.”
“School,” by Tom Robertson (1829-1871) made its debut at the Prince of Wales Theatre in January, 1869. With “Society,” in 1865, also at the Prince of Wales, Robertson had introduced a new naturalism to the English stage that would come to seem revolutionary. For some of the implications of these changes, see George Taylor, Players and Performances in the Victorian Theatre (Manchester: Manchester Univ. Press, 1989), 97-104. Taylor says “Trollope astounds me, makes commonplace life and characters interesting, tho' he has the worst of styles in writing.” Shirley says “He astounds me by his power of work – fancy getting up at 5 and sitting down in a cold room, with grubby hands after lighting your own fire, and then writing about pretty girls and love matches and so forth.”
The reading public would come to know about Anthony Trollope’s habits of work many years later from his posthumously published An Autobiography (Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1883), but these remarks make clear that those habits were already well known enough among some of his fellow writers to be a topic of conversation. See the entry for March 8, 1870, for additional talk about Trollope’s writing habits. Brooks had come to know Trollope at the Garrick Club; “I like him,” he wrote, “after one gets used to his intense manner” (Brooks diary, 11 March 1864 [Houghton Library]). – T.T., “My wife reads all his novels to me.” – “A case for a divorce,” says Shirley. Shirley says, “I'm ashamed to find myself laughing with the Gallery.”

L.C. T.T. suggests “New Brooms” apropos of Admiralty circular about Economy. Old Ministers as housemaids looking on “Devil of a dust: Let's see what comes of it” Apropos of Emperor's Speech, Shirley would parody “Critic:” – “When I behold these armaments – forgive me friend if the conjecture's rash, the State methinks some danger apprehends.”

But Mark thinks the Ritualists, for their squabbling Meeting, deserve a Cut: Suggests Pope as Chambermaid of the Cross Keys, “Light your candles and come with me.” S.B. assists in evolving the picture. And as Tenniel hesitates, T.T. sketches it!!! [ Punch, 56 (30 January 1869): 39, “The Chambermaid of the Vatican”]

D.M. discourseth on Religion! Can't comprehend men going to Church – believes in doing his duty according to his conscience, and leaving God to save him or not as he thinks right. But this substitutes your conscience for God. And your conscience may be warped – an unhappy faith. Think ill health is punishment enough for any sins he may have committed. Don't believe in Hell ... or even Heaven, I think.

div.head: January 27, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E. D.M., H.S., E., J.T., S.B., P.L., F C. B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Today the Lord Mayor commits to trial Overend and Gurney... T.T. suggests Chorus of Financing Company Promoters, “We've got no work to do.”Pater suggests Shade of Sir Thomas Gresham rising to shame the fallen honour of City merchants. .. TT., Overend & Co. sheltering behind Gog and Magog (bailed by Rothschild & Co. folks say). Law daren't sentence such Swells, or down will come half the City firms. . . Interlude of Bribery suggestions,- apropos of enquiries before Judges: Aecus, Minos, & Radamanthus, S.B. ... P.L. says, Overend is a subject too important to be shirked: show them committed with burglars and common thieves. Shirley amends to ruined Shareholder and daughter – hard labour for life. General feeling is that they are served right: but people who rejoice at the trial forget how the credit of England is lowered by it. Still one should pity the ruined more than the destroyers [ Punch, 56 (6 February 1869): 49, “Committed for Trial”]. Edwards' exposé shows how Gurneys fell. Charles Loder's suicide at Woodbridge not an isolated case: in consequence.
The failure of discount bank Overend Gurney in May of 1866 set off a financial panic that caused the collapse of a number of smaller banks. The directors were brought to trial, but acquitted. Charles Loder, 76, a retired grocer in Silver’s hometown of Woodbridge who lost heavily in the failure of Overend & Gurney, had jumped to his death from the parapet of a railway bridge in the spring of 1868. Ipswich Journal, April 25, 1868, 5.

div.head: February 3, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B, J.T., F.E. P.L., C.K., T.Agnew, J.Agnew, R.F.S.

L. Chamberlain writes to Managers on Ballet Indecency. Du M. suggests “the Stalls and the Stage” – which the more nude? (“Judy” does this next week.)
“The Stalls and the Stage,” Judy 4 (10 February 1869) 162-163 Shirley suggests Siamese Twins – 2 churches – T.T. adds Dr. Bright saying “Do them good,” [Punch, 56 (13 February 1869): 59, “Our Siamese Twins”].

(The Twins are to be shown at the Egyptian Hall next Monday.)
Chang and Eng Bunker (1811-1874), who billed themselves as The Siamese Twins.

Mark has been Falstaffing in Scotland with great success. ... Old Keeley died t'other day.
Robert Keeley (1793-1868), comic actor. His daughter Mary married Albert Smith. The following remark again mischaracterizes the provisions of Albert Smith's will (see note to entry for May 31, 1860). Albert Smith left his wife his house and £1000 only!Rest to brother.

div.head: February 10, 1869. No. 11. Ash Wednesday.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R F.S.

Lord Cairns is to lead the Lords vice Malmsbury. So Shirley suggests Granville taking his coat off ... Saurin v. Star the petty persecution Nunnery at Hull trial drags its slow length along and interests people – opportunely shows what Puseyites may come to.
The sensational trail of Saurin v. Star involved a civil suit by a former inmate of the Sisters of Mercy convent at Hull alleging that she had been unfairly expelled “with imputations on her character.” Extensive press reports of the trial inflamed anti-Catholic prejudice with their rare and unflattering accounts of life inside a convent, accounts which, in the words of the opening remarks of the Solicitor-General, showed “what women were capable of when they shut themselves up from their kind” (Times, February 4, 1869, p. 10). The Lord Chief Justice's summing-up took an entire day and occupied five columns in the Times of February 27, 1869 (pp.11-12). The jury found for the plaintiff on the major counts, assessing damages in the amount of £200. The Times commented, “Thus ended this extraordinary case which, while it lasted, caused an excitement quite unprecedented in living memory.” S.B. suggests Lady to daughter: “If you like to scrub floors and be half starved on measly mutton, go to a Convent – and I'll bring out your younger sister.” – Amends it to Ritualist addressing girl against Pomps and Vanities, Social Suicide. P.L. for title suggests “The Logic of Ritualism.” (Somebody afterwards alters to “Two Girls of the Period.”) [ Punch, 56 (20 February 1869): 71, “Two Girls of the Period”]
The title of the cut was a play on E. L. Linton’s popular and controversial essay, “Girl of the Period.” See note to entry for 25 March 1868.

div.head: February 17, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.
Mrs. (Mary) sends her Photo book for Autographs:
M.L.: “I have a passion for the name of Mary.” (Byron)
S.B.: “O that those lips had language!” (Cowper)
J.T.: Let me play the fool. With mirth and laugh-
ter let old wrinkles come.” (Shakespeare [Mer-
chant of Venice I,i])
T.T.: “The ninth part of a man.”
H.M.: “The Prince of Darkness is a Gentleman, Modo
he's called and – Mayhew!” (Shakespeare [King
Lear III,iv])
H.S.: “Silence is golden, but Speech” – has Henry
Silver.

(Ponny and his bride's first dinner chez nous [at our house] last Saturday. Tenniel and DuMaurier last Thursday with Dr. Hamilton.) Parliament met yesterday and everybody was polite to everybody. M.L. suggests Diz offering Gladstone a rose: each hiding a big stick behind him. “Mildness of the Season.” [ Punch, 56 (27 February 1869) 81, “Extraordinary Mildness of the Political Season” ]. Mark and Thackeray both at School at Chiswick. Expensive.

div.head: February 24, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., R.F.S., T.T., (H.S. at Park House, Croydon).

Tenniel's birthday next Sunday – and next Monday Gladstone's Motion for Disestablishment. Transit of Venus in 1882 – Shirley at Geographical on Monday, debate on proposed Expedition – shall be dead then – Hope not, says H.S. Hope so, says S.B.
The paper Brooks heard was subsequently published as J. E. Davis, “On Antarctic Discovery and its connection with the Transit of Venus in 1882,” Journal of the Royal Geographical Society, 39 (1869) 91-95.Who would lose a leg if he thereby secured his family £1,000 a year. Query? P.L. and H.S. agree that one's limbs are worth more than any money. — Except the limbs of the law, says W.B. Shirley's eldest boy ill – overworked. He says the want of money is the root of evil.

L.C. Shirley suggests Gladstone as Verginius, killing Irish Church. “And now my own dear little girl, there is no way but this!” S.B., Gladstone as Macbeth: “I've done the deed – didst thou not hear a noise?”. S.B., Gladstone holding up little Ireland to look at Church emerging from Ugly Endowment Clothing. “That old woman you disliked so! Look at her now” T.T., Bunyan's Pilgrim relieved of burden – Church establishment: Christian. T.T., Ariel released by Prospero Gladstone: “Now to the elements be free and fare thou well.” This an amendment of Shirley's bright figure of Christianity rising from Church's clothing is accepted: [ Punch, 56 (6 March 1869): 91, “End of the 'Tempest” ].
Shirley Brooks’s account of the Large Cut discussion in his diary entry for this date runs: “I urged vehemently that the next cut, which will come when the country will be full of Gladstone’s speech, should be on the church, though we usually wait to let topics soak into the public mind. It was agreed to, but we had much trouble hitting on a theme, so I suggested Protestantism, freed from chains, rising like an angel, or that one in the ‘Hermit’, and delighting Ireland. Leigh d—d Protestantism, but something like my notion was agreed to.” (London Library)

Shirley protests that in Scotland “the elements” would be understood as referring to the Communion. – Shirley made several other suggestions such as Church and Guillotine .. Gladstone as Operator, knife in hand, and John Bull asking, “How did you bear it?” But the operation is not performed yet.

Tenniel has almost given up smoking! Used to smoke an ounce a day. Can eat a better breakfast now. Nearly all our folk smoke less. Tom Taylor has given up cigars and only takes a pipe occasionally. Du Maurier takes 4 cigarettes a day in lieu of 40. H.S. never smokes till after dinner. Only Keene and Mark and Shirley stick to their tobacco. Bob Martineau, the artist, died t'other day. Nice quiet fellow.
Robert Braithwaite Martineau (1826-1869), a painter in the Pre-Raphaelite style, had trained as a lawyer and was later a pupil of Holman Hunt’s. Dennis T. Lanigan, “Robert Braithwaite Martineau, Pre-RaphaeliteAssociate,” Victorian Web, 2022 Remember John's account of Surprise Symphony with tongs and shovels and coal scuttles at Bedford Row. Bob and Henfrey the chief performers. Tom says Field produced more artists than lawyers, Vincent, Al – Tom Cobb, not bad ... “Equity drafts-men” these artist-lawyers, says Shirley, the Gifted – as Burnand calls him.
March 2, 1869. Tue[sday]. No. 11. Cham.
W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., P.L., F.E., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Gladstone on Monday spoke for 3¼ hours. ... 11½ columns of Times: which Pet has read!
“The Established Church, Ireland,” Times 2 March 1869, pp. 6b-8b (13 columns total). Gladstone's speech was soon published in book form by John Murray. Tom Taylor applauds, and can't see how one can pick holes in the measure. Suggests Gladstone like the Coastguard man hanging within a foot of the ground after fearing he'd been hanging over a precipice. – But not a known story.

S.B. suggests (as did the Telegraph today), Shade of Swift claiming invention of the bill [for the Disestablishment of the Irish Church]: “He left the little all he had To build a house for fools or mad: And show by one satiric touch No Nation needed it so much.” [ Punch 56 (13 March 1869): 103, “Swift on a Large Scale”]
Lines from Jonathan Swift, On the Death of Dr. Swift (1731). In his diary for March 2, 1869, Shirley Brooks wrote, “Having had the day altered to suit me, felt bound to suggest the cut, which I did, 'Dean Swift leaving his money to the lunatics, to whom Gladstone gives the money of the Irish Church.'“ (London Library). The mention of Swift’s provisions for the poor in the Telegraph is part of its reporting of Gladstone’s speech, Daily Telegraph, 2 March 1869, 2.

“Let's offend somebody!” saith Jackides. Who apropos of Absinthe, drinks to “Our Absinthe friends.” Alfred de Musset died of it, “by instance,” as Pet saith.
Alfred de Musset (1810-1857), French dramatist, poet, and novelist. He died of heart failure. Mrs. (Engraver) Linton wrote “Girl of Period” in Saturday Review last Summer.
Silver's “Mrs. (Engraver)” refers to Linton's estranged husband, prominent engraver and activist William James Linton (1812-1897), who had left for America in 1866. At this time Eliza Lynn Linton had been for some years a close personal friend of Shirley Brooks. D.M. of H.M.: “Ponny goes home in a penitent fit, And reflects, as he kisses the rod, That his soul will go down to the bottomless pit, While his body lies under the sod.”

Shirley dined at Sothern's on Sunday, next to Kavanagh – the MP without arms or legs, who hunts and drives and shoots and sketches! but don't talk brilliantly.
Arthur MacMorrough Kavanagh (1831-1889), M.P. for County Carlow from 1868 to 1880.

Grenville Murray, “The Roving Englishman” of Household Words, dismissed from F.O. [Foreign Office] now edits the “Queen's Messenger,” a scurrilous anti-Government paper.
See entry for July 20, 1869.
On dit that the Siamese Twins get 1000 visitors a day = £60 : @ 1/- and 2/- a head.

D.M. tells of Indian, “Flying Cloud,” asked by lady if he'd many wives: and why. “Big Indian f– much!” S.B. tells of Indian with lady at Picture Exhibition – stopped at sketch of turkey: lifted wampum – “me got that on a– !” ... Apropos Mrs. Annett next Saturday tells of husband's servant in China taking a third wife .. squabble ensues – master orders peace – scream! “Me hang No 1 wife – that's all.”

div.head: March 10, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., Wagnew, H.M., R.F.S.

The Habitual Criminals Bill is the Subject – H.S. suggests Breaking up of a Thieves' Soirée by Policeman armed with the Bill. M.L. sug. garrotter following old gentleman with felonious intent, police- man arrests him – D.M. improves to burglar collared by peeler and protesting innocence, “Only going to my tea,” adds Jackides. D.M., “Why I've invented the big cut!” – and throws knife on Table, a la Shirley who has the gout [Punch, 56 (20 March 1869): 113 “The Habitual Criminal Cure”]. - F.C.B. inveighs against College Athletes – too much time and money spent on rowing, leaping, etc. – Professor says if boxing be taught, Brasenose College should be changed to Brokenose. An Athletic Tripos should be founded.

Thackeray described Anderson the actor as “Macready and onions.” Also he invented this rhyme to the Countess Guiccioli “Who slepped [sic] with Lord Byron habitually.” She is now for the second time a widow – Madame de Boissy, and has two unpublished cantos of Don Juan, given her by Byron.
Ponny tells of Paxton on his knees to Ponny's landlady after the C[rystal] P[alace] was opened in 1854.
Shirley in bed with the gout. But it saves him from colds and headaches, he says.

div.head: March 17, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p:
Oxford beats Cambridge by 3 lengths. H.S. at “Glorious Smiths” at Chiswick – cold day. Another dines at Cadogan Place – Elsmie (Indian Service) et ux. And Winder, who on Saturday dines chez nous, first time, after Kreutzer: and tells Rogers’ lines on Lord Ward: “Ward has no heart, they say: but I deny it: He has a heart, – and learns his speeches by it!”
William Ward, first Earl of Dudley (1815-1885). Known as Lord Ward from 1835 to 1860. The epigram was by Samuel Rogers.

div.head: March 24, 1869. No. 11. Champ.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.,TT.T.

Tom Taylor's new play “Won by a Head” comes out on Monday – tells of Tom Ward, the Yorkshire jockey, who became prime minster to the Duke of Parma – he, Sebright and Cottrell the only Englishmen who stood by the Duke in 1848. Ward visited Lord Palmerston with his wife, who was a marketwoman at Berlin – spoke French, German, and Italian as well as most – but when he spoke English betrayed his Yorkshire stabling. (N.B. Saw the play next week. Only ran a fortnight).
Tom cites Moses Poet as a genius:
Whenever orders are received, from parties painfully bereaved,
Five minutes' time is all we ask,
To execute the mournful task.
Also a quatrain about his never splitting trowsers, ending:
The trowsers of Moses are so very pliant
They wouldn't give way to the stride of a giant.
D.M. tells of Old Lady seeing the Siamese Twins: “I think the smaller is the older,” and of child to mother, “Look, there's a couple of Siamese dogs.”

Majority for Irish Church bill 118 at 3 this morning: 110 expected. Shirley by letter suggests Diz as the rat deserting the ship – or Gladstone as Oliver Cromwell, “If this won't keep them quiet, we must try a sterner way” But his best suggestion we accept: peasant-murderer to priest, “They're spoiling our game” [ Punch, 56 (3 April 1869): 135 “Disendowment and Disarmament”].
Shirley Brooks was not present or this dinner meeting, but noted in his diary entry for this date: “Discussed cut with ML who went up today. My notion said to have been done before – anyhow, a better one was adopted, that is, one more insulting to the Irish.” (London Library)

div.head: March 31, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., W. Agnew, H.M., R.F.S.
Tomorrow’s Mrs. D.M.'s birthday: So she is toasted: and not buttered.

Easter Monday storm nearly stopped the Dover Review. H.M.S. brig Ferret went ashore. S.B. suggests bringing Volunteer officers to Duke of Cambridge to learn their duty. Accepted [Punch, 56 (10 April 1869): 147 “No Playing at Soldiers”].

div.head: April 7, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. champ.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T. F.E. P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.

The Sunday Question crops up again and after some talk it seems fit that the two Sunday attractions be contrasted: “The two public houses,” I suggest: but Burnand amends to “The Public House or the House for the Public” [“The Sunday Question” Punch, 56 (17 April 1869): 158-59]. P.L. suggests Upset of Orange Woman – Protestant Meetings.

div.head: April 14, 1869. W[ednesday]. No Dinner
div.p: . . In Memoriam William Bradbury: Obiit die Solis Ap. 11. Aged 69.

div.head: April 21, 1869. W[ednesday] . No. 11.
div.p: F.E., H.S., C.K., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

“Nemo repente fuit Tupper rimus,”
Constance Smith note: from Juvenal, “No man ever became wicked all at once.” saith the Professor. T.T. tells how Tupper once invited Leech for a country outing: “Now let's be jolly – have some strawberries and milk!”
Palmerston said the best argument for a man's marrying his wife's sister was that he'd have but one mother-in-law.

The site for the Law Courts is the subject: and T.T. suggests Father Thames inviting Themis “Come build by me and be my love:” Thames with big clean shirtcollars marked “Embankment” [ Punch, 56 (1 May 1869): 179 “Thames to Themis”] Bob Lowe last night smashed the Carey St. scheme.
Shirley Brooks's diary for this date asserts that the cut was his idea: “Dined Punch – pleasant evg. I suggested the cut about law courts.” (London Library)
D.M. is at Crawley – takes a big house just as the cold winds follow the hot week April 8.

div.head: April 28, 1869. W[ednesday]. No, 11
div.p: F.E., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.,T.T. Champ.

Shirley's birthday tomorrow. “Cleverest fellow at the table,” says maudlin Ponny. The National Gallery re-opened on Monday: T.T. praises the unfinished Michael Angelo, Dead Christ homely but pathetic. M.A. rarely painted beauty, but always invested homeliness with grace. Makes you feel the effect he aims at. T.T. savage at the R[oyal] A[academy] for rejecting so many pictures: the Academy is virtually National, has been helped by Government for 100 years and is made a mere monopoly. C.K. says if any pictures are exhibited, all should be. M.L. says a man who has once exhibited should always have the right to show one picture. – R.A. discourteous.

T.T. says the Daily Telegraph has influence wherever there's a fool. Newspapers destroy all originality – men save themselves the trouble of thinking by reading what their paper says. “ Mark the perfect man and behold the upright” quotes Shirley. “Give him an Inchbald and he'll take an El-more,” said Mark of somebody: and for somebody else who aimed at Classicality he invented the title of “Focus and Cullodion” for a photographic landscape.
T.T. thinks men usually are tipsy when they go home mottis – appeals to Ponny who says “Yes” bravely and boldly: and then maudlinizes about next morning's repentance.

C.K.'s cut this week of artist chained to rock referred to Inchbold, T.T. says [Punch, 56 (1 May 1869): 184, “Our Adventurous Artist”]
Possibly a reference to artist John William Inchbold (1830-1888)..

L.C. Professor suggests Diz receiving his rejected picture “Church Bill Amendments” – “They accept your naked figure and reject my drapery,” [Punch, 56 (8 May 1869): 189 “Rejected!”]. Professor says the bill is bosh: “abstract justice can't satisfy the Irish who [are] an eminently concrete people.”

div.head: May 5, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: F.E., H.S., F.C.B.,Tagnew, J.T., M.L.,P.L.,R.F.S., H.M.,Wagnew, S.B.
Charterhouse. Athletic Sports today: my first look at the Old School since I left it – in December 44: teste lapide [witness the stone], left of school door: 4th from foundation: “H. Silver, 1844.”

Mathematical room built on our Classic fighting ground behind School – where Gill and Gibbs fought. Coffin and Cobbold's memorable battle was in Verites Yard. Of this I'm reminded by Sarjeaunt the Short, who's as grey as a badger and I've scarce turned a hair yet – but was he not my fag? And does he not remember the building of the room aforesaid in '45 or '6? Jolly old it makes one feel to hear such an old greybeard call one a contemporary, and find he's your junior?

And there's poor Billy Hale – nigh bent double. Wonder how many of my schoolfellows are as well as I am. Should make a man contented. Saddens one to see Under Green boarded round, half already sold. Verites' Yard absorbed, so as to lengthen the racket court. Same desks, cut to pieces – wonder if my name's on Verites new Longroom table still – with those of the other Mother Catherine Conspirators. Remember how we pelted her with potatoes and some score of us were flogged for it. We see the fatal block – and the horseshoes before the masters' desks. Poynder and old Hale scarce look older than when I left them. [Note in black ink, probably added later]: I dined in Brook Hall in 1865 with Williams and the other 4 masters.
Catherine Smith, Archivist at Charterhouse School, has very helpfully supplied the following notes as an aid to the allusions in this passage (private communication, July 14, 2009):
GIBBS: there were six Gibbs brothers at Charterhouse in the 1830s-40s, the sons of George Henry Gibbs of Aldenham, Hertfordshire, any of whom could be the Gibbs mentioned by Silver.
COFFIN, Edmund, born 10 Dec 1824, 3rd son of Robert Coffin of Broadwater, Sussex. Verites [school house] Jan 1840-May 1843; cricket XI 1842-43. Christ Church Oxford; Demy of Magdalen; BA 1847, MA 1850; deacon 1848, C of E Farleigh, Kent 1850. Entered Church of Rome 1851. Died 26 Jan 1894.
COBBOLD, Edward Augustus, b 9 Jun 1825, 2nd son of Rev Richard , Rector of Wortham Everard, Suffolk. Verites Oct 1838-Aug 1844; cricket XI 1842-44. Trinity Cambridge, BA 1848, MA 1854. Deacon 1849, Priest 1850. Died 31 Dec 1900.
SARGEAUNT. There are 8 Sargeaunts recorded in the Charterhouse Register, but only two whose dates coincide closely with Silver:
James Primatt Sargeaunt, b 22 Feb 1831, 3rd s of Rev John Sargeaunt, Verites Oct 1840-Dec 1844. Queen's scholar of Westminster, Jan 1845-May 1846. Verites June 1846-Aug 1849; cricket XI 1848-49. Jesus Cambridge, BA 1853, MA 1856. War Office. Died 26 April 1900.
William Charles Sargeaunt, b 2 Sept 1829, 2nd s of Rev John Sargeaunt. Verites Oct 1840-Aug 1847, cricket XI 1845-7. Colonial Office.
HALE, William Palmer, b 17 Feb 1824, 1st s of Ven. William Hale, Gownboys Jun 1835-Dec1842, exhibitioner, orator 1842, cricket XI 1842. Christ Church Oxford; Scholar of Trinity Hall Cambridge, BA 1848, MA 1851. Entered Middle Temple 1849, called to Bar 1852. Died 4 Jun 1871.
Under Green was the name of a playing field at Charterhouse - the name was later transferred to one of the playing fields at the Godalming Charterhouse.
The masters that he refers to were:
Frederick POYNDER, b 11 Mar 1816, who had been a pupil at Charterhouse and was then an Assistant Master from 1838-49, Chaplain of Brideswell 1848-58, and Usher and Housemaster of Verites 1858-72. Died 7 Jul 1899.
Archdeacon William Hale HALE, b 12 Sept 1795, also a pupil at Charterhouse, and Master 1842-70.
Williams must be Stephen Frederick WILLIAMS, Assistant Master 1862-65 and a pupil in Verites Oct 1840-Aug 1845.

S.B. at Academy Dinner on Saturday – the first in their Burlington House building – could only hear Gladstone, Archbishop of Canterbury, and Disraeli. Contends that writers have no right to criticise a picture – J.T. agrees – H.S. differs. Why should not painting be criticised as well as stage playing or novelists or poets or other inventors? Beethoven is criticized and so is Joachim: Why not Millais? A man who can't play or sing a note can criticise a singer – why need he practice painting in order to criticise it.

L.C. The subject is Motley vice Reverdy Johnson: Sumner has spoken savagely, demands some fabulous millions for Alabama: S.B. suggests Reverdy giving us sugarplums and Sumner a pill after them. P.L. amends to Yankee offering us a humble pie, and S.B. improves to Johnson saying, “He won't eat that I guess: I've dined a good deal with him” [Punch, 56 (15 May 1869): 201 “Humble Pie(?)”].

div.head: May 12, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., T. Agnew, H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., C.K.

R[oyal] A[cademy] took £50 first hour: and £4500 in first week... Today it's closed for the Queen's Visit. L.C. O'Sullivan the Mad Mayor of Cork has been fraternising with Fenians and letting felons out of gaol. So a Disability Bill is passed, and he resigns. S.B. suggests Gladstone with a birch, “Shan't flog you this time, but .. “ P.L. adds that the bad boy should be horsed on a policeman. But Shirley suggests for title “A block for a traitor” [Punch, 56 (22 May 1869): 211 “The Block for Traitors”] and I draw the Charterhouse flogging block for Tenniel.
In a diary entry for this date, Shirley Brooks wrote, “Punch d. I suggested the form of the cut and title. WHB dined, first time since his father’s death. W and F Agnew there.” (London Library) – Says Sketchley, “the Gifted” – “Diz should stick up for him, as a Cork-asian.”

P.L. says in Literature of the Century two books have stood out as having hit the Public –Faust and Esmeralda: and both for the same reason: interesting seduction. Victor Hugo since then has become stagy and stilted and talks incomprehensible nonsense which his admirers mistake for sublimity. “L'Homme qui Rit” absurdly improbable. (To Chatham yesterday: Mrs. Thomas “Generals”– E. Germain. handshake ~ E. Revd. Minute Gun Speaker).

div.head: May 19, 1869. The Mitre . Hampton Court.
div.p: W.B. D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B. , J.T. , F. E. P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

S.B. proposes Sir Jonathan Falstaff – apropos of Sumner's speech claiming half a million for the Alabama damage. (Mark revives his Falstaff next Monday.) [Punch, 56 (29 May 1869): 223 “Sir Jonathan Falstaff.”] Tempest this afternoon: hail! Cold and showery. Walk to Chestnuts with H.M. et ux. Then write The Sweets of Office Life [Punch, 56 (29 May 1869): 228] and A Shot at the Gun Club [ Punch, 56 (29 May 1869): 225]. Tomorrow we go to Mount Pleasant: where the corncrake nightly warbles! while I smoke in the garden and they play Bézique.

Derby Sweep. I drew “Duke of Beaufort.” (Wagnew wins with the favorite, Pretender. The Drummer, which John Watson bred, comes third: and second for the Grand Prix at Paris, June 6th.) We remember how Du Maurier last year won all three Sweeps!! Derby and Oaks and Ascot Cup.

Rossini's Mass produced today at St. James' Hall. Shirley hears and applauds. D.M. tells how somebody having composed a Mass for Meyerbeer was complimented thus by Rossini thus: C'est très bien ... seulement, c'est vous qui aurait du mourir, et c'est Meyerbeer que aurait du faire la messe!

Shirley excites our curiosity by an altered woodcut of Solomon's Prodigal Son which he presents to Du Maurier, the likeness being perfect: “Papa Punch welcomes his Prodigal Son from the husks and swine of Sussex.”

div.head: May 26, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S H H.M., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., F.C.B., R.F.S., C.K.
(H.S. from Newport yesterday to dine with the Fishmongers – “family dinner” no toasts.)
Lovely Derby Day after a wet night and gloomy morning. I have the honour at Balham of a bow from Alexandra: first time a Princess of Wales has seen the Derby.

D.M. tells of old French writer – after the manner of Les Contes Drolatiques – who describes Italianess with scent in little bladders which she bursts – finally a natural explosion “to remind you of your native land.”

L.C. The French Elections last Sunday and Monday – Triumph of the Reds. The Edifice will crown itself, Sire, if you don't crown it,- P.L. John Bull's teaching Napoleon a lesson, in Magna Charta, M.L. But Burnand hits the nail with “L'homme qui rit”: despite Professor's idea of Frenchman dressing child à l'Anglaise [Punch, 56 (5 June 1869): 233 “L'homme qui rit”].
S.B. tells of Billy Russell's mot on Johnny Dean's marriage: Just like him, if he wanted a ha'porth of milk he'd always go and buy a cow.

div.head: June 2, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: (H.S. from Newport today. Sheep frozen in Suffolk last Friday!)
F.E., T.A., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., W.Agnew, H.M., R.F.S., T.T.
D.M. “in misery” he writes ... wife ill with sore throat and boy with scarlet fever.
Sea bears live in Seaberia – S.B.
Wagnew tells of Yankee: “Wal, when I want painting, guess I'll go to Rome and be done by one of them Old Masters.”
L.C. Will the Peers pass the Church Bill? – P.L. says, “Yes, for they're Ritualists.” Enigmatical professor!

S.B. suggests Granville introducing pretty girl, “Irish Protestantism,” to Peers who try to snub her. T.T. amends to “The Cold Shoulder”: We can't turn her out, but you mustn't expect us to be civil to her,” Accepted [Punch, 56 (12 June 1869): 243 “The Cold Shoulder”].
S.B. suggests Phryne before the Judges: but, of course, we can't do it.

div.head: June 9, 1869. W[ednesday]. Purfleet.
div.p: W.B., H.S., E., Tagnew, J.T., F.E., H.M.(late), P.L., M.L., R.F.S., T.T.

Pater, Jackides, Mark, W.B. and Fred and I go by 2.20 train and walk about the chalk pits – pretty view from the Observatory. For a wonder we have had warm weather since Saturday. Sunday at the Zoo with Carry Watson and Monday at Orpington blazing – 104° in Sun! Tonight the wind veers to the North and cold begins again.

Church Bill in Lords – debate begins next Monday. Shirley suggests scene from Macbeth, long line of New Peers created to pass the Bill. Mark suggests Derby as Sisyphus rolling stone of opposition – also, Derby à la [crossed out: “John Bull”] Garrick between Tragedy and Comedy: a Bishop and a Jockey (he has been writing about 2 year olds lately). But Tom Taylor hits the nail with Derby ramming his head against a Wall – The Bill – Longheads and Wrongheads: amended tomorrow into “The Ram of Derby” [Punch, 56 (19 June 1869): 253]. “It will hurt you more than the Wall.” Salisbury of the Moderate Party.
– Jolly evening.

div.head: June 16, 1869. W[ednesday]. The Bedford. cham.
div.p: W.B., W.Agnew, H.S., D.M., T.T., S.B., J.T., M.L., E., P.L., H.M., C.K., R.F.S.

D.M. thinks of Hampstead – fancies Kensington depressing. Scarlet fever is. – (At Frith's on Monday (our debut) Calderon (like de Tranqueillon) said he thought D.M.'s cuts of late pointed to – “that way madness lies”.
S.B. tells of child catechised by 'father – How many commandments are there? Nine, Papa. No, ten, my child. No, Pa. Ma broke one while you were in Scotland.
D.M. tells of girl – introduced his organ (Judy[?]) No, faith 'twas more like a flute.
T.T. tells of Cambridge groom to friend with baggy breeches. You cod sht bottles without breaking them.

Wagnew applauds the Bishop of St. David's speech last night – good his way of answering the charge of Sacrilege by the story [of] how St. Ambrose sold the holy vessels to ransom Christians. S.B. and T.T. and all applaud the elevated tone of the debate. The Lords are on their mettle and not afraid of constituents and so speak their mind freely. A good answer is this debate to Bright's ill-judged letter to Birmingham accusing the Lords of “unwisdom” and “infatuation.” Subject comes well for our cut: (T.T. first suggests Earthen Pot, Peers, escaping collision with Iron Pot, Commons – “We've just missed you this time.”)

S.B. suggests Bright as groom rebuked by Gladstone, “Your business is in the Kitchen, don't answer the front door.” But Mark and Tom amend to cut we accept,”Pull out of the way with that infatuated old machine” [Punch, 56 (26 June 1869): 263, “Forgetting His Place”].
Wagnew and H.S. exchange groans – both with bad colds from this infernal weather – thermo. 50°!

div.head: June 23, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: B., D.M., H.S., E., M.L , S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L. ,Tagnew, H.M., C.K., R.F.S., T.T.

S.B. inveighs against the lavish praise of Patti and primadonnas in general...says fiddlers are idiots and those who care for music can talk of nothing else. D.M. contrà – “Shirley, you're a musical eunuch – can't enjoy music yourself and think no one else can.”Tom Taylor and H.S. and P.L. also concur in thinking music delightful and mentally improving ...

L.C. Church Bill carried last Friday by 33 in Lords. Mark suggests a Haymaking Cut. Bill carried all but the last cock – the Glebes. T.T. suggests Church as a girl undraped, Lords, “We must make her fit to be seen”, putting on some of her Endowment clothes again. Never too late to amend” ... Lord Penzance recently made Judge of the Divorce Court gave his first vote in Lords for Divorce of the Church, S.B. Church separate maintenance: “Your allowance is mean,” S.B. ... But Sketchley apropos of a suggestion of Professor's “to chronicle the event simply” hits on a good title, “Darby & John” ... and Tom T. makes out the cut “In the Tea-room” [ Punch, 56 (1869): 273, “Darby and John”]. Shirley says Russell should have the honour of the bill rather than Gladstone – for he has fought for it these 20 years.

Professor suggests Hamlet at the Opera – with a drinking song! – as a subject for an article ... and I do it tomorrow after breakfast [Punch, 56 (3 July 1869): 270 “The Opera of Omelette”] – under the Ash.
Schneider's champagne bath – 40 bottles before and 41 after, S.B. Hold my vater, I can't, P.L.

div.head: June 29, 1869. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p:
H.S. at C[rystal] P[alace] with Viceroy, Prince of Wales, Mrs. Annett[?], B., and Horace. Costa concert and fire-works!
This enormous concert, hosted by the Prince of Wales in honour of the Viceroy of Egypt, featured an orchestra of some 4,000 performers conducted by Sir Michael Costa.

div.head: July 7, 1869. W[ednesday]. Sussex Hotel. Tunbridge Wells. cham. cup!
div.p: W.B., D.M., E., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., H.S.

Pleasant ride by coach thro' pretty country. Mark on box; J.T., H.M., S.B., and H.S. next. Near leader falls as tho' shot. “A knife and a saw,” says Professor – heart, burst bloodvessel, no doubt. “Get off the wheel, Mark,” shrieks Shirley, who seems nervous.

Walk to Toad Rock with Professor: “If it were warmer, we should find some fungi.” Pretty made walks for visitors – molehilly wooded country ... Back with D.M., P.L., and R.F.S. Cut settled yesterday. Big Baby bill returned to Commons: “Not my che–ild.” [Punch, 57 (17 July 1869): 17 “The Changeling”].

div.head: July 14, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.
Next Saturday is Punch's birthday, says Shirley. Success to Punch!

L.C. The Emperor's Concessions. P.L. thinks them a mere shadow – bit of cake – don't make a beast of yourself. S.B. improves: L.N. to La France, “You wish to manage your own servants, Ma'am – very well – I hope you'll do it.” T.T. improves to L.N. in gig with his boy driving restiff France, “Easing the Curb.” [Punch, 57 (24 July 1869): 27, “Easing the Curb”] accepted.

Trollope the King of the Philistines, S.B. – The Lord was not in the fire.
1 Kings19, “And after the earthquake a fire;butthe LORDwasnot in the fire: and after the fire a still small voice.” Penny a liner's Bible, H.S. “But the Maker of all individuals was not in the devouring Element”
Shakespeare wrote for all time and not his own: You find less of the characteristics – manners, language, etc. – of his age in Shakespeare than Ben Jonson, T.T.
Miss Bateman made £5000 in 12 weeks tour – £2000 more than the Keans. A manager is a beggar on horseback – everybody toadies him.

Nillson [sic] – hard face as a Northern Fate, T.T. Cold but clever. Her Ophelia is perfect.
Christina Nilsson (1843-1927), Swedish operatic soprano. She played Ophelia in the opera “Hamlet,” by Ambroise Thomas; the London production, “Amleto,” opened at Covent Garden on June 19, 1869.

“But for me, Tom Taylor would have died on a dunghill,” quoth Mrs. Wigan the Wonder to Tom Taylor's wife's mother. “He was to me a husband all but in name” said she to Tom's wife. Delicious creature. M.L. says Jerrold became security for Wigan (£300) to Dramatic Author's Society and this began his involvements. Yet when Wigan prospered he never gave Jerrold a lift or a box.

div.head: July 20, 1869. T[uesday]. Rosherville Hotel. cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., F.C.B., M.L., S.B., H.M., F.E., P.L, H.S., C.K., R.F.S., T.T.
We by boat. NE wind so cold that Tom calls for hot brandy and water on landing – and on Sunday last thermo. was 85° in shade, and I wouldn't go to Henley, 'twas so hot.
“A Happy Day” costs but sixpence – we have a happy quart d'heure, same price. Bears, peacocks, monkeys, and pious poetry scattered about in hideous English taste.

L.C. Tenniel at Manchester – with Prince of Wales – and the Lords debate on Commons rejection of amendments tonight: 120 majority against Ministers! Tom suggests Sibylline Books – worse bargain next Ses- sion: Lords as Tarquin. Also Irish parson, “See what I've saved” out of the fire – one or two other hints – but nothing can be settled. (Eventually Queen Elizabeth and Victoria cut is done [Punch, 57 (31 July 1869): 37 “A Change for the Better”].

Man tells Shirley, shot wood pigeon, crop full of bees! Grenville Murray and Lord Carrington– the topic “Roving Englishmen.”
Robert, Lord Carrington (1843-1928) horsewhipped Eustace Clare Grenville Murray (1824-1883) on the steps of the Conservative Club shortly after midnight on June 22, 1869, in retaliation for the latter’s libel against Carrington's recently deceased father in his “society” paper, The Queen's Messenger. In the article in question – “Our Hereditary Legislators, No. XIV: Bob Coachington, Lord Jarvey,” The Queen’s Messenger 22 (17 June 1869) 237-238 – Grenville Murray had alternately ridiculed and excoriated the elder Carrington as “a harmless lunatic” and a “heartless dog.” Lord Carrington was found guilty of assault but given in effect a suspended sentence in light of the provocation under which he had acted; Grenville Murray, however, was indicted for perjury for denying authorship of the article, and while out on bail fled to France, where he spent the remainder of his life, writing novels and serving as Paris correspondent for the Pall Mall Gazette and the Daily News. “The Roving Englishman” was a pseudonym of Grenville Murray's, under which appeared a series of travel sketches in Household Words, later republished in book form in 1854.

div.head: July 28, 1869. W[ednesday]. Wheatsheaf. Virginia Water. cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., M.L., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.S., H.M., T.T.

Wet morning – but cleared. Mark looks pale and seedy: wants rest. Pretty lake and bigger than I remembered. Forged ruins – mock pillars – “A Temple of Humbug, says Georgy, the bloated.” ...W.B. invents the term “Penny Maligner.”

L.C. Irish Church bill settled by Cairns and Gran- ville suddenly last Tursday. M.L. suggests poor Irishman saying to parson, “I'd like to robbed as badly as you.”T.T. amends to Church as basketwoman, lot of things left still. But Shirley by letter suggests Irish harp re-tuned: T.T. adding, “There's another string wants tuning,” – the Land question namely [57 Punch, (7 August 1869): 49 “The Harp that Once”]. A congregation at tea in tent – with a German band. Ponny, Kicki and I join their train at Clapham, home – “Miss,” calls D.M. out of window, and tries to sing a hymn – Curious how they all sing hymns and nothing else. Better behaved than the Van demons who shouted at us coming from Needham's picnic last Saturday. –

Ponny amuses by picturing himself as a bashful blushing gushing boy of 15. Open legged – “you young fool” – at Ramsgate. 2/-, a pencilcase and handkerchief. Bleeding, “Is this what's longed for? Milk of human kindness. D.M. pictures the Venus de Medici à la Ponny – funny attitude. “Dear clever boy.”

div.head: August 4, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., E., J.T., S.B., P.L., H.M.,M RF.S., T.T.
Mark at Crawley CD. Writes to his “dear boys.”

Swinburne nearly kicked out of Arts Club for drunkenness. Whistler says to Committee: “You accuse him of drunkenness – well, that's his defence.”D.M. talks of Swinburne's article on “L'Homme qui rit” in the Fortnightly: good English. But bad sense and bad judgment, says T.T. Nonsense to crack up a bit of bad art.
Algernon Charles Swinburne, “Victor Hugo: L'Homme qui Rit,” Fortnightly Review, n.s., Vol. 6 (July 1869), 73-81. Swinburne should read the Ode on Eton College, says Leigh. What is there in it? sneers Shirley. Music, says L. ...And magic words, adds Tom. Keats will outlive Swinburne, says Shirley. ... Poe ... only half a poe – t.
T.T. inveighs against cant of sending a soul unprepared to God's judgment. As if God did not make allowance for human weakness .. and judge better than man.

L.C. No Whitebait Dinner!
Shirley Brooks notes in his diary entry for this date, “Dined with Punch—had the chair at first—letter from ML who suggested something which we adopted—about there being no ministerial whitebait this year.” (London Library) T.T. says Ministers are glad to escape a dull party and E3 a head ... Lowe-ves and fishes. Economy the order of the day. Shrimps and tea instead. Will do for cut, Tenniel thinks. – T. would like to do the Stool of Repentance, Gladstone wiping – with his own “Church & State.”

Says Shirley – Let a f and wipe - with the Echo. ... Quaker & mot: But your parts are not private. D.M. who tells of swearing sailor speaking mildly after operation by Riccord (“non mi riccordo,” P.L.)
Dr. Phillippe Riccord was a Parisian expert on venereal disease. Dr. William Acton was at one time his student. ... leaves them under pillow ... Servant swears gruffly she's not seen M. – Capital raconteur is Du Maurier. [ Punch, 57 (14 August 1869): 59, “Mean Time at Greenwich”] – Your birthday next Sunday, Silver: says Shirley .. and my wife's on Friday. Acis produced at Princess's on Monday. “Rolling wave” of Drury in 1842.
The 1869 revival of Handel's opera, Acis and Galatea, at the Princess's Theatre starred Blanche Cole and William Rignold. The sumptuous original production at the Drury Theatre in 1842, which starred William Macready, was famous for the opening scene (following the overture) of the “rolling wave,” showing moonlight playing on a view of the sea as the foamy waves bear the sea nymph Galatea, on a shell, toward the shore. The 1869 production closely followed the original set design by Clarkson Stanfield.

div.head: August 11, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., R.F.S.

Shirley at yesterday's wedding. Frith's secunda to a rich stingy brewer, saith Kicki.
Jane Ellen Frith (1847-1923), the second of painter William Powell Frith's children by his first wife, married James Albert Panton (1841–1921) at All Saint's Church in Kensington on August 10, 1869. Panton, the son of a brewer, was in partnership with his brother in a brewery in Wareham, in Dorset. Jane, who was known as “Sissy,” was a particular favorite of her father's close friend, Shirley Brooks, of whom she wrote a pen portrait in her memoir, Leaves from a Life (London: Eveleigh Nash, 1908) 161-172. H.S. at the dance thereafter in the garden, Calderon, Prinsep, Reed & Co. – I danced with a name-sake (only she spelt her name Silva) from the West Indies, who being challenged to point out my wife, as a French lady, instantly did so. Said she recognized a Frenchy face – had seen such in Paris often. Query? D.M. extols doctors – great nerve combined with great judgement to operate – “I don't know a happy man,” says Shirley. “Jackides looks one.” – “But he isn't,” J.T. But we are all blaze here. Ten years of Punch dining age a man's mind to nil admirari. All is vanity ... except turtle and Lafitte.

A hard stool for the Large Cut. Mark suggests Punch's Reading Party – but that will do for next week when Tenniel goes away [Punch 57 (4 September 1869): 89 “Mr. Punch's Reading Party”]. And we ought to notice somehow the end of the Session – such a Session!

Punch condoles with Bright on having a holiday and no speechifying – “Never mind, t'will soon be over” (S.B.) Gladstone as manager dismissing actors (S.B.) accepted [Punch, 57 (21 August 1869): 69 “'Her Majesty's Servants' – Last Night of the Season”]. – but we can't find suitable characters except Bright as Steady the Quaker. And Childers as Capt. Crosstree. “No starring in the Provinces.”

Ponny screwed, “I'd go to the scaffold for Shirley – cleverest fellow round this table – Du Maurier's the cleverest talker, I'd go to the scaffold for him, too. – And for dear old Mark – and yes, Tenniel, for you, dear boy – And dear Professor.”
But you'd only lose your head, Ponny – a very trifling sacrifice.

Home with D.M. who thinks Writers the vainest of men – always expect attentions. Yet their brains are not better than lawyers' or doctors' – and their talk is quite as shoppy. Shirley contemns men who can't make epigrams. Snobbish. There's a smack of the stage about most writing men.

Tom Taylor to Jersey and Brittany. Shirley to Beaumarin. Bradbury to Bognor. Tenniel to Ashby de la Rouche. Silver to Switzerland viâ Antwerp next Sunday at noon with B[lanche] and Sally and Clem and Owen – who deserts us at Visp on Friday fortnight. We reach Lucerne Thursday noon the 19th – thence on the 23d to Hospenthal (frozen regions ... and a piano!) – Rhone Glacier – Munster Aeggischorn (hold by horse's tail) – St. Nicolas (9 p.m.) – Zermatt Gorner Grat (Matterhorn transparent! – 28th!) – Leukerbad (Wm. and Caroline again) – Gemmi (like Guy Fawkes – chaired) – Holler boys, here's a pair of guys! Frutigen (Asthma) – Interlaken – Scheinegge Platte – Berne – Paris 5:30 a.m. Sept. 11, Sat. .. And to Le Tillac at 8.15 that evening after dining with Clem at Bonnefoy's.

div.head: October 20, 1869. W[ednesday]. The Bedford.
div.p: {Dinners here also August 18, September 22, and October 13. No dinner
October 6.} Precious rough crossing from Boulogne yesterday! And so cold.
W.B., D.M., H.S., H.M. S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

The Big Ship-fire at Bordeaux (Sept. 28) and the Pantin Murders and the Emperor's illness have been the chief Events since I dined... All very jolly. And how one relishes oysters and mullet and sherry and partridge after 9 weeks of foreign fare ... Tom T. agrees with me in liking French breakfasts – but they spoil one's dinner – and they too much resemble it. His wife was so bugbitten in Jersey that they had to fly to France. Kicki is at Hampstead – half frozen. And last week I was basking in the shade with thermo' 85°.

Tom suggests Emperor on a Bicycle (Blondin at C.P. now) accepted [Punch, 57 (30 October 1869): 170-171 “A Perilous Passage”]. Professor would prefer a Church cut at the appointment of Temple (the Essays and Reviews man) to See of Exeter. So proposes Pusey and Shaftesbury, High and Low Church, joining in a duet of opposition “Suoni la Tromba.” Each blowing his own trumpet. – But the bicycle is preferred – the “Two-wheeleries,” says Shirley. Ponny chaffed by Kicky says, “The best fruited trees are always the most pelted at!” Irish Intrigue described by British officer as “Shgg a Shivering Savage in a Shhouse,” S.B.

div.head: October 27, 1869. W[ednesday]. The Bedford.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.
My wedding day...and I don't dine at home! (Walk in Hort[icultural] G[ardens] with B[lanche] ... cold N.E. wind, frost.)
No row in Paris yesterday. Expected ... because Keratry threatened to attend the Chamber, which won't open till November – Emperor silly to postpone reforms.
