L.C. The Temple appointment the subject, say T.T. and P.L. Suggest Triangular Duel . . Pusey, Shaftesbury and McNeil. Pusey has cut his own throat.
In the fall of 1869, Prime Minister W. E. Gladstone appointed Frederick Temple (1820-1902), headmaster of Rugby, as Bishop of Exeter following the death of Henry Philpotts. Gladstonian in politics and tolerantly Broad Church in religion, Temple was a sharp contrast to the rigidly conservative Tory Philpotts. A group consisting of the Earl of Shaftsbury, Edward Pusey, and others, publicly objected to the appointment, to no avail. Layard sent to Madrid to get rid of Ayrton at the Treasury, says Tom – S.B. suggests his Entering on Nineveh (Jhn) Bull . accepted [Punch, 57 (6 November 1869): 181, “Don Layardos in Madrid”].
The appointment of Assyriologist Austen Henry Layard (1817-1894) as ambassador to Spain was widely viewed as a tactic to remove him as first Commissioner of Works, in which post his expansive spending plans had incurred the steady opposition of secretary to the Treasury Acton Smee Ayrton (1816-1886). On Layard’s appointment to Madrid, Ayrton was brought in as his replacement as Commissioner of Works. Tom suggests Gog and Magog welcoming Queen on the Sixth ... opening Blackfriars Bridge and the Viaduct. Would like to see Professor's cut of Pusey and Shaftesbury blowing their own trumpets to effect the fall of the Temple.

Three more Rivals in the field –Punch and Judy, The Period and The Gaiety Gazette. Burnand at Aix la Chapelle ... suffering from Aches and Chapel, says S.B. Bust of Jerrold in plaster cost £10, says Mark. “Not a poor man's Plaster,” says Shirley – “The Foot and Mouth Disease.” Kissing the Pope's Toe, H.M. [ Punch, 57 (2 October 1869): 129, “Non Poss.!”]

Tom says Sir Samuel Baker is a Snob – hard, cold and selfish. Set him down for making fun of a poor traveller at Kartoum [sic]. His wife of low birth but conceals it by her good sense.
Celebrated African explorer Samuel White Baker (1821-1893) met his second wife, Hungarian-born Florence Barbara Maria (1841-1916), in 1859 at a slave auction in Bulgaria, where she was being sold to a local pasha. The two escaped together and became lovers, and she accompanied him on all of his travels, taking an active part in his African expeditions in search of he headwaters of the Nile. Although Samuel and Florence eventually married in London in 1865, Queen Victoria refused to receive the Bakers at court. In 1869 Sir Samuel, accompanied by Lady Baker, led a military expedition to the southern Sudan to suppress the slave trade. Lady Florence Baker’s diary of the expedition was published in 1973.

div.head: November 3, 1869. The Bedford. W[ednesday].
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., R.F.S. J.T., S.B., P.L., C.K., H.M., T.T.

The Professor's birthday – 56. So we rise when he enters and chorus “a jolly good fellow.” Mark has come to grief at Exeter – performing in an unlicensed hall. Tom suggests a cut of Falstaff in prison: “Stone walls do not a prison make”, etc.

We condemn B & E for proceeding against “Punch and Judy” today. Defeated of course.
Bradbury and Evans had applied for an injunction to restrain Samuel Beeton from publishing Punch and Judy, a penny weekly, on the grounds that its similarity to Punch would mislead purchasers, particularly those at railway stations, to mistake one publication for the other. The bill was filed on October 29, after three numbers of Punch and Judy had been published. Sir Richard Malins, Vice Chancellor, refused the motion, commenting that, “I cannot help thinking that the plaintiffs might well have remained satisfied with the reputation of their own periodical and refrained from interfering with the defendant's publication, which possesses only a general similarity in form and the nature of its contents. Law Journal Reports for the Year 1870, (London: Edward Brett Ince, 1870) Vol. 38, pp. 57-59

L.C. The Temple Case should not be passed. Rabid parsons are really quarreling with the Queen: inciting the Chapter against her prerogative. Tom suggests Her Majesty interposing: “You forget, gentlemen, to make a bishop is my business, not yours.” ... Shaftesbury and Pusey as the Lion and Unicorn fighting against the Crown. ... Or each sitting on beam sus- pending the sign of Crown & Mitre, and sawing it through. P.L. suggests Queen saying, “You want to disestablish me.” ... But Tom hits the nail with Conge d'elire..ium. all mad together. ... [ Punch, 57 (13 November 1869): 191 “Conge D'Elire-ium: A Case for the Doctors”].
Congé d’élire is a license from the Crown authorizing the dean and chapter of a cathedral to elect a bishop upon the vacancy of a see – in this instance, the see of Exeter (see note to entry for October 27, 1869.
Tom thinks turtle over-rated, pea soup as good. Turtle worshipped by men without taste for delicate cookery.

div.head: November 10, 1869. W[ednesdayl. The Bedford.
div.p: H.S. at Glenham. Battue. 12 guns. H.S. killed 25 cock pheasants and 2 woodcocks.

div.head: November 17, 1869. W[ednesday]. The Bedford.
div.p: Pocket Book Dinner... Published tomorrow. [black ink above: “Opening of the Punch Dining Hall” “Mark Sixty-us”]
W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L,, S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., Tagnew, T.T., R.F.S.
Fog so thick that in Lincoln's Inn Fields I could barely grope my way. Telegram from Blanche that “carriages can't go out,” so no go to the Coming of Age Ball of Alfred Whitaker.

Ponny chaffed by Jimmy Davison, says “You pelt with scented snowballs.”
James W. Davison (1813-1885) was music critic of the Times from 1849 to 1878. See the vivid portrait of Davison in H. Sutherland Edwards, Personal Recollections (London: Cassell, 1900) 72-75.
Big Cut settled last week: T.T.'s suggestion. Suez Canal opened today, [Punch, 57 (27 November 1869): 212-13 “From the Great Pyramid”].

Shirley remembers that last Friday was B's birthday: and drinks.
William Bradbury was born in Bakewell, Derbyshire, in 1800. A host of Agnews born just now.

Up from the Priory today and down again tomorrow. Bouquets on completing “Commentaries” by Blackstone Broom.
Possibly a reference to Herbert Broom's and Edward Hadley's edition of William Blackstone's Commentaries on the Laws of England (London: William Maxwell and Son, 1869)
 [drawing of pointing finger] Poor little Ronald Cobb dies next Saturday. The first cloud on Clara's “awful happiness.”

div.head: November 24, 1869. W[ednesday]-. The Bedford.
div.p: W.B., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., Wagnew, R.F.S., T.T.

The blackguard Irish Priest Ryan at a meeting t'other day (v. today's Times) said, “Your tenant nowadays, if he can't get his rights, just takes his revolver and tumbles his landlord.” Clearly this is the subject – So P.L. suggests “The Irish Treason Shop” [Punch, 57 (4 December 1869): 223 “The Irish Treason Shop”] which we accept, – S.B. adding Punch saying to Gladstone, “Isn't it time for you to interfere?”
When's a sea-pie (sepoy) not a seapie? When it's an Indian Muttony, W.B.

Discussion on Wants for the Poor: – Wagnew says: Cheap Amusements. Mark – Begin with Gutter children. Bradbury – Reform your Licensing System. Taylor – Good theatres. Shirley – Education. Saxon laws made by workers for their self defence: therefore purse ranks before person. Mark: No drink allowed on the premises after 10 p.m. ... Colonial Reformatories.
In England lads seduced to old haunts – would escape temptation if reformed abroad.
T.T. Yankee definition “Conceited's not the word – G.. Almighty's waistcoat wouldn't fit him!”

div.head: December 1, 1869. W[ednesdayl. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Applause at the new decorations. Big globe lamp – old side bookshelves abolished, etc. Stupendous portrait of Mark. Who yesterday reached sixty and gets drunk (by us) accordingly. Today the Princess of Wales reaches 25 (B. coeval) so we drink her health – “a dear little woman” says Tom. Mrs. Fred's birthday today and W.B.'s next Friday.

Burnand flourishing from his Aix baths ... The Fenian Rossa returned for Parliament! M.P. = “Millbank Penitentiary” says Sketchley – fancy portrait of “The New Member” in his convict dress. Tom suggests Rochefort and Rossa as “The Two Irreconcilables” and Shirley adds Britannia to France, “I don't know how you mean to treat yours – but...” birch rod [Punch, 57 (11 December 1869): 233 “Neighbours in Council”]
In a Tipperrary by-election in 1869, Fenian prisoner Jeremiah O’Donovan Rossa (1831-1915) was elected to Parliament, a result declared invalid. He was released and exiled to the United States the following year. Republican and socialist Henri Rochefort (1831-1913), recently freed from prison for his political writings, was elected to the lower house of the French Parliament in 1869.

T.T. to Buckstone: Not an author's business to puff an actor – should point out defects, not praise. T.T. tells North Country definition – “So mean that he wouldn't let off the reek of his a– on another's man's land if he thought there was management (manure) in it”. Mark says Thackeray got £50 for his Punch article, “The Broad and Narrow Guage [sic]”
[Punch, 10 (1846): 223, “Jeames on the Gauge Question”].. Mark bade him return it .. Sed quaere? .. M.L. and W.B. beat J.T. and H.S. R.F.S. marks.

div.head: December 8, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: Present: All the regulars – except Burnand. (N.B.: Pater ill – since Aug.)

The Oecumenical Council opened today. Tom Taylor suggests Pope sliding ... Dangerous! French Bishops Dupanlop & Co. standing by, declining.
Félix Dupanloup (1802-1878), the Bishop of Orleans, had declared in a published letter on the eve of this, the first Vatican Council, that the publication of the doctrine of the Pope's infallibility would be inopportune and divisive. Dr. Cumming and Shaftesbury on other side – Ritualist venturing ... “Don't go too far.” Hole marked “Infallibility,” S.B. Skeleton of Pope under ice, C.K. Don't complicate, says Mark [Punch, 57 (24 December 1869): 244-45 “Sliding on Thin Ice”].
Laurence Poole, son of R.A., said with a stutter – “He's so languid a S.. S.. well, he co-couldn't pull a nigger off his sister,” D.M.
Poor Ponny afflicted by a stepson who can't live on £4.10/- a week. Ponny lived on 30/- as Sub Editor of Punch and D.M. on 25 francs in Brussels, and H.S. on 30/- for half a score of years!

D.M. says you English pronounce your vowels as though dipthongs – differ from all the world in your Latin. But the French say Ciceron, the Italians Chichero, and the Spaniards Thithero. Professor inclines to Kickero. Mark says the Romans remained long in England, so perhaps we have learnt the true pronunciation. But they conquered France, too.

D.M. says you can put French poems into English ones, but not E. into F. such as Tennyson's “Break, break, [break]” and “One more unfortunate.”
“One more unfortunate” is the beginning of the first stanza of Thomas Hood's “Bridge of Sighs” (1844). Yet “The Curfew Tolls” has been excellently rendered ... which I wonder at.
“The curfew tolls the knell of passing day” is the opening of Thomas Gray's “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard” (1751).
P.L., “Lust the Ultimatum of Love,” W.B., “You mean the Ultima Tooley.” P.L., Paris abounds in luxuries, but is deficient in necessaries.

div.head: December 15, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: Almanack Dinner.
W.B., D.M., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M. H.S. R.F.S.

Almanack published tomorrow – at 4 a.m. “The best we've had for years” says Mark, as usual. D.M.'s Seaside nudities are applauded, and Keene's Scotch waiter, – and Tenniel's own Kurassow joke. C.K.'s rustics capital I think.

L.C. P.L. suggests Dr. Gladstone prescribing for Ireland – “Our composing draught (Church Bill) has not taken effect yet .. We must throw in a little steel and lead.” But we must have a Christmas cut .. so S.B. suggests Pancras guardians serving out pudding ... “Penance in St. Pancras” [Punch, 57 (25 December 1869): 255 “Penance for Pancras Guardians”].

Apropos of the Whole Year's Income Tax to be collected in January, Shirley quotes, “The huge two handed engine at the door stands ready to strike once, and strike no more,”- Milton... Tells old story of parson reading, “A man going to sea (see) his wife desires the prayers of the congregation.” D.M. tells of Beaumont the oculist – charmingly polished and wellbred family – but seem depressed by religion. Busman: of old lady in gaiters: “There's a Guy!” D.M., “That's my mother.” Seedy old man speaks to her Busman: “Is that your father, Sir?” Invented Story.

Tennyson's “Holy Grail” published today. 30,000 sold.
Tennyson's The Holy Grail, and Other Poems was published by Strahan & Co., with a cover date of 1870, appearing in America under the “Fields, Osgood & Co.” imprint of Ticknor & Fields. S.B. applauds the Scenic Mediaevalism.

div.head: December 21, 1869. T[uesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., H.S., F.C.B.,S.B., J.T., M.L., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T T.

T.T. cheerful .. tells of aged motte who pursues him still. ... Macready's hesitating solemn speaking ... “Who is that man in the fantastic garb?” ... My son, Sir, he is to play Osric .. my wife invented the dress.” (Youth had gone out ... and a clown sat in his seat). ... In Australia “half a sheep was flung at my feet ... a bleeding and disgusting object.” Tells of misreadings .. “Her picture .. by Fra Philippo!” ... as if it were an oath. ... “O Lord! Archbishop!” (in surprise) ...
“Women like wine...the better for keeping,” H.M. “Gus and I were living[?] a pair of Anchorites” – “you mean Shakkerites”, says Burnand.

Shirley objects to my Almanack advertisement re “Holy Grail.” Taylor says it derived from Sang Real .. not San Grail. T.T. suggests Bob Lowe as Old Father Christmas tax collector – Year's taxes due January. [ Punch, 57 (1 January 1870): 265, “A New Father Christmas and his 'Happy New Year!'”]. S.B. The utmost that a man can do for his child's advantage in the world will hardly atone for the wrong of having brought him into it. P.L., Idiots are perhaps bred ... as we do our beasts. H.M., I could combine Mark's commonsense – and Tenniel's art – and Shirley's wit, and Burnand's vulgar humour . Virgo provided .. on this table ...I could ... F.C.B.
Sala gets £100 for Wat Tyler and I got £l,500 by Black-Eyed Susan.
P.L., Ponny, you should have been a bishop – your Organ of Veneration is prodigious.

div.head: December 29, 1869. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Cham.
div.p: Present: All the regulars, except C.K., and S.B who has the gout

Queen's Theatre opened Monday, the 20th, with Rousby and wife in “The Fool's Revenge.” Whereof the author writes the criticism in the Times
“The Fool's Revenge,” by Tom Taylor, starred Wybert Rousby in the part of Bertuccio and his wife, Clara Rousby, in that of Fiordilisa, both of them making their London debut. Taylor's review, which appeared in the Times on Dec. 21, 1869, p. 8, opens with a defense of the originality of the play despite its adaptation of the plot from Hugo's Le Roi S'amuse and the opera, Rigoletto, founded on it. (Taylor had been much criticised for his borrowings from French plays.) Praising all the performances, the review concludes, “We are delighted to welcome the exchange at this theatre of the coarser for the more truly dramatic form of sensation...in which the imagination is appealed to instead of the senses.” ... Labouchere M.P., the Lessee a stingy snob-swell. At the funeral of the man whose fortune he inherited he swopped his crape scarf for a friend's silk one, stooping behind a gravestone! Tom nicknames him Jerry Abershaw.
Ponny says Sala writes a leader for the Telegraph in an hour.
Can eat anything, saith Mark, I never have trifled with my stomach. Nor have I, saith Ponny. But you have with other people's: saith Burnand.

“Timothee Trimm” in Le Petit Journal was Leo Lespes, H.M.
Napoleon Léspès achieved an enormous celebrity with his daily front-page column in Le Petit Journal under the pseudonym Timothee Trimm. He was ultimately hired away at double the salary by the government journal, Moniteur.
Mere Vin Ordinaire, says Fred. Yes, a good deal of the Mere in it, F.C.B.
L.C. P.L. suggests Pope hunting [for] the Slipper [of] Infallibility. But T.T. hits the Yankee Nail. Fish out of Water, hooked by Lord Clarendon [Punch, 58 (8 January 1870): 5 “A Fish out o' Water”]
Frost giving tonight. Skating yesterday.

div.head: January 5, 1870. W[ednesday.] No. 11.
div.p: W.B., H.S., M.L., J.T. F.E., H.M. C.K., R.F.S.

Charles Mathews' Benefit at C.G. yesterday. Says Ponny, Mrs. Keeley cried at having so small a part as the Niece in the Critic. How I remembered her comical nasal tones: “I am such a beginner in stage matters.” C.J.M. [Charles James Mathews] is 66 – and looks 40! So slim and well preserved.

L.C. P.L. by letter suggests “Liberty Hall” – Louis Napoleon appointing Ollivier as Minister. But Mark's Runnymede is better. L.N. as King John. W.B. would have a Transformation Scene – and H.S. suggests Liberty for Columbine: L.N. Harlequin: Rochefort as Clown [Punch, 58 (15 January 1870):15, “Magna Charta for France”].
... M.L. been Weddingising today. See Rousby in Fool's Revenge tonight. Good. And his wife smiles like Kate Terry.

div.head: January 12, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., S.B., J.T., M.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Dinner to C.J.M. [Charles James Mathews] on Monday: he in chair: precedent C.J. Fox, M.P. Speeches insolvent. Sala said he copied a piece for C.J.M. for 7/6 and “strange to say the money was paid.”S.B. says M always attended to his bye play. Good actor but not great. Could not disguise himself. Always C.J.M.

Ponny produces Rochefort's “Marseillaise” today's date, giving account of Pierre Buonaparte's killing of Victor Noir on Monday at Neuilly. Untoward – just as New Ministry comes in. ... Beastly rant has the Marseillaise.
While acting as a second for the editor of the Marseillaise after a challenge by Pierre Bonaparte, a cousin of Emperor Napoleon III, there was an altercation between the two men and Bonaparte shot Noir dead. Bonaparte claimed in court that Noir had struck him first, and was acquitted. Noir's funeral procession was the occasion of a mass demonstration against the regime.

L.C. T.T. thought of Ollivier asking for More ... but this is postponed: L.N. a good Bumble ... Ayrton and Haussman (who is dismissed) – “See the result of doing too much .. I'll do too little.” But Shirley thinks Bright's speech yesterday at Birmingham should be noticed. No good legislating for workmen who won't reform themselves. Bright, the Bacchus Breaker (accepted) [Punch, 58 (22 January 1870): 25, “John Bright's New Reform Bill—‘Reform Yourselves!’” ] Shirley adds Bob Lowe saying “But think of the Excise, John!” But this we negative.
S.B., The Ladies' petition against the Inhumanity of Poxhunting (Contagious Disease Act). T.T. suggests for D.M. a wet hunting day as a Subject for the Inhumanity of Foxhunting.
H.M. and D.M. chaff as usual – Used to p- in my corner. Playing at ps. in the Corner[?], S.B.

div.head: January 19, 1870 W[ednesday]. Cham.
div.p: W.B., H.S., M.L., S.B., J.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.

Mrs. Rousby's success in “Twixt Axe and Crown”, produced next Saturday at the Queen's. Discuss Mary and Elizabeth: former priest-ridden, latter gallant-ridden, saith Leigh. Tom thinks Mary pined for love ... and was soured by disappointment. Savage her note 'lawful' in document referring to Elizabeth's possible children.

L.C. Shirley (hand in sling: writes by amanuensis) suggests France marching onward and crushing blackbeetles of Socialism, Rochefort & Co. T.T. amends to Liberty leading her. ... after suggesting France tripping over dead body of Victor Noir .. too grim. [Punch, 58 (29 January 1870): 37, “ONWARD!” ]
T.T. Cabmen's New Cut – triumph of laissez faire. P.L.'s French editor armed with pistol à la Rowdy. T.T., A Row in the Cross Keys, landlady Mrs. Pope.

div.head: January 26, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: All the regulars present: except Mark who has sore throat.

L.C. Tom suggests Bright as Bus Timekeeper at Temple Bar: “Don't be in a hurry with your Education, Forster” checking – new thing for Bright. (Speech at Birmingham, “You can't drive six omnibuses abreast thro' Temple Bar.”) Amends to “Irish Stew” .. accepted [ Punch, 58 (5 February 1870): 47, “The Bill of Fare” ]

Shirley (looks pale and worn .. bad attack this) suggests a cut at the Thorncliffe Colliery rioters ... smashing furniture and women by way of “persuasion.”
The owners of Thorncliffe Colliery, near Barnsley in Yorkshire, had hired local replacements for striking miners. On January 21, 1870, a group of the latter attacked the houses of several of those replacements. Trade Unionists' Reasoning. ... British Public a Brutish Public, says Ponny ... Hodder's Randy Recollections, S.B.
George Hodder (1819-1870), a miscellaneous journalist who had worked as a personal secretary to Thackeray, had just published his rambling autobiography, Memoirs of My Time, including Personal Reminiscences of Eminent Men (London: Tinsley, 1870), which also contained many anecdotes of his friend Douglas Jerrold and other members of the Punch circle. In his diary entry for March 28, 1870, Brooks wrote of the book, “Dined, and in came George Hodder's Memoirs, which were a real blessing – I don't know when I have had such a lot of good laughs as at his platitudes. However, it is very ungrateful, for he writes gushingly of me, owns to a kindness I had forgotten, and prints, as another, a letter I have equally forgotten, but which was only a means of saving his feelings in regard to sundry verses which would not do for Once a Week. Some of the letters which he has printed I think the writers would have preferred his burning. But it is a very harmless, unconscious book, and I hope the reviewers will let him alone.” (Morgan Library) Hodder died the following summer after being thrown from a dray in Richmond Park. (See “Chilperis”, “Hervè” at Lyceum.)

div.head: February 2, 1870. W[ednesday], The Bedford.
div.p: [Above in brown ink: Shirley Ill the Mordaunt Case] Billiards, Roberts v Cook. cham.
M.L. H.S., F.C.B., J.T., F. E., P.L., T.T.

No invitation sent. Shirley seized on Friday. {X Yoller[?] tells me this: and then comes Jackides and learns the venue.} ... heart and leg ... gout and erysipelas. Sir Henry Thompson attends.
Brooks's own comment in his diary for February 27: “To-night I knocked up, and the doctor, Edgar Barker, was sent for. And E. managed to see Sir Henry Thompson, and somehow got him to offer to assist E. Barker, which gave her confidence, and which was therefore well. I think that it was to-night that they saw me, and examined my legs. On the left there were darkish veins. There was talk of erysipelas, but this was soon got over. But I afterwards heard that there was congestion, or rather apprehended congestion, of the liver, and that there was doubt as to whether the doctors would succeed. A nurse was ordered–I have never had one since I was a child. And so I was regularly laid up, with all the sick-room appliances. I had to give up all work, which was most distressing to me, but somehow things shaped themselves, and every one behaved very kindly and considerately.” (Morgan Library) ... Poor Mark sad and semi speechless from cold.

L.C. Burnand suggests Conservative Coach trying New Leader, Salisbury. .. But Cairns leads still. Tom thinks Gladstone's Coming Work the Subject (House meets on Tuesday). Hercules “looking at his labours.” ... the Hydra. “H. and the Hydra, say I [Punch, 58 (12 January 1870): 58-59, “Hercules and the Hydra” ]. From Stanwick yesterday [H.S.]. Burnand suggests The Old Mistresses as a pendant to the Old Masters ... Exhibited at R[oyal] A[cademy] now.

div.head: February 9, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., Tagnew, J.T., F.E., P.L., H.M., R.F.S., T.T.
Shirley pronounced out of danger by Sir H. Thompson. But ..

Tagnew inveighs against the Chelsea clique of artists. Rossetti & Co. – unhealthy mannerists – affected – sell you for £l00 picture £30 worth of frame. Du Maurier defends them: Ranks Millais A1 – then Rossetti, Burne Jones and Albert Moore. Tom Taylor detests Simeon Solomon – his pictures suggest unnatural offences.
D.M. quotes – Madame: Mon Mari est cossu, Monsieur. Pourquoi cette cedille, Madame? Apropos of Burnand's slip – writing cancan: Good his excuse – “Cançan softened down.”

L.C. Session opened mildly last night: T.T. suggests Gladstone and Diz, duel fincing – “with buttons” says Diz smiling – Tenniel amends to Box and Cox. – G[ladstone]: Can you fight? Diz: “No” – G.: “Then come on!” Bravo! – exactly hits it [Punch, 58 (19 February 1870): 69, “William Cox and Benjamin Box”].

Bradbury suggests Billiard Match, apropos of Roberts and Cook .. who play for championship next Friday, 1200 up: Cook wins by 137.
William Cook defeated his former tutor, John Roberts, Senior, in the first World Championship billiards match on February 11, 1870. John Roberts, Junior, challenged Cook two months later and beat him by 478 points. The younger Roberts went on to dominate the game for the next thirty years.

T.T. thinks Richard and Saladin's fight would suit heavy Gladstone and quick dodgy Diz. (Drury Pantomime today [with] B. ... Vokes active…grotesque dancing. Beast as shadow behind Fool! Monkey scene, lots of boys as apes, funny. “Beauty and Beast.”
The Vokes family were a troupe of dancing brothers and sisters, led by Frederick Mortimer Vokes (1846-1888), who dominated the Drury Lane Theatre Pantomime all through the 1870s. Fred Vokes delighted audiences with the extraordinary contortions of his legs. The Vokes family made their debut with E. L. Blanchard's “Beauty and the Beast” in 1869-70.

div.head: February 16, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11.
div.p: H.S. at Grosvenor Hill – Rev. Mr. Mason, Wm., and Barrett and wife .. from Norfolk. Skating.

div.head: February 23, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11. cham.
div.p: W.B., J.T., H.S., M.L., T.T., F.E., P.L., F.C.B., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.

L.C. Tories seeking a Leader in the Lords .. vice Cairns. Ponnx suggests Peers asking Derby to “Follow my Leader” and he replying “Not my little game”: for he declines. But Mark (who has a Falstaff sore throat still) suggests Diz in a basket left at Carlton by Duke of Richmond, “the Deserted” [Punch, 58 (5 March 1870): 91, “Deserted!”] or Dizerted, I suggest. For Diz is the difficulty, Tom says. – Gaiety to follow: Wat Tyler, by Sala – slow.

Prince of Wales in the Divorce Court .. today. Mordaunt v. Mordaunt. Tom inveighs against the press for publishing such details. “Can do no good, and may do great harm.” How every one jumps to bad conclusions. No one believes well of a man .. scandal once afoot never stops. Common for a man to make afternoon calls, even on married women. Cui malo?
Important to History. The Prince sometimes hires a Hansom.

div.head: March 2, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Ash Wednesday.
div.p: [Above, in brown ink, “D.M.’s mother dies.”]
W.B., H.S., M.L., Wagnew, J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.

Wagnew fresh from the Demidoff Donato Sale in Paris. Bonnington's picture 20 in. x 15. – “the finest English painting I ever saw.” The red like “crushed rubies.” (Charles I playing with his children.)
This was the sale of the collection of wealthy art patron and industrialist Anatoly Nikolaievich Demidov, 1st Prince of San Donato, held shortly before he died in Paris in April, 1870. Richard Parkes Bonington (1801-1828), English painter.Wondrous noise in a French auction! And wondrous prices in this.
D.M. in trouble – Mother dead ... Shirley driven out today. Mark can't swallow yet.

L.C. T.T. by letter suggests a cut apropos of the Waterford Election Riots. Bernal Osborne returned...with a broken head well nigh. Gladstone and Bright standing calmly by while the windows are broken. Government supine. ... Tenniel amends to a parody of old story of man – “You've lamed my hunter, you've borrowed my money, you've seduced my wife – a little more and you'll rouse the British Lion.” This applied thro’ Gladstone's mouth as policeman is approved [Punch, 58 (March 1870): 101, “Where's the (Irish) Police?” ]... notwithstanding Sketchley's objection to a threat – “force has proved a failure.” …and W.B.'s idea of a Portrait of Habeas Corpus .. and Ponny's notion of The True Peacemaker: Stepping over the Brook: Queen visiting Ireland: and Leigh's suggestion of Dr. Gladstone prescribing a strait waistcoat: and Wagnew's of putting complaint into the mouth of a honest respectable Irish farmer. But where are you to find one ... as a model? asks the Jolly Old Tory, Keene. Good Joke that of the Advertisement Slip .. “Mrs. Blank of Twins (One insertion only).”

div.head: March 8, 1870. T[uesday] No. 11
div.p: All the Regular Army – except Shirley (who has been out) and Keene.

F.C.B. cites the Eton boy's verses on Guy Fawkes – Guy Vulpes frigidus, calidus, postquàm omnia caepit, Insidiis laqueis, Ipse recepit eum. Guy Fawkes the cold blooded hot headed villain, after taking all precautions With insidious snares, he (the bailiff understood) received him. Sidney Colvill, the art critic of the Pall Mall says O'Neil knows as much of art as an organ grinder of music. Sala does the Art business for the Telegraph.

Tom Taylor gets up at 6, dresses, lights his library fire and works till 9 o'clock breakfast. Less trying than nightwork. Says Trollope's man's wages depend on his making his master get out of bed.
See note to entry for January 19, 1869.

L.C. Mark suggests Mother Ireland and her plaguey boys – landlord, tenant, priest, Fenian, etc., who squabble about the Land Bill. “Agree among yourselves and let your mother be quiet.” T.T. suggests an Irish pig stuck in a gate, “Fixity of Tenure.” Stabat Mater Botherosa, D.M. Tenniel suggests Fenian Caliban, – “This Isle is Mine, by Sycorax my mother.” .. Ireland as Miranda protected by Prospero Gladstone. M.L. objects . but ultimately yields [Punch 58 (19 March 1870): 111, ‘The Irish 'Tempest'”]. Strand w. [ ? ] – Clark' s “Toodles .”

div.head: March 16, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11. Cham.
div.p: W.B., D.M., H.S., M.L., Pater!, J.T., F.E., P.L., C.K., T.T.F, R.F.S., F.C.B.

Pater Redivivus! Glad to see his rosy old cheeks! Has had a bad time of it. Charles Dickens' farewell reading at St. James' Hall last night. Sketchley there. Carol and Pickwick Trial. Burnand once heard Pickwick and thought Dickens seemed the only man in the hall who didn't understand its humour. Sam Weller fell flat. .. So I thought, too: But his reading of Fagin and Sikes was a masterpiece. D.M. calls Simeon Solomon a [Greek letters] – Millais a [Greek letters]… thinks of Summering in Paris, to lower his moral tone. �unable to handle Word object, possibly embedded spreadsheet or equation

Tom Taylor tells of Old Rogers saying “When I first went into Society, I was a small man and had a weak voice, and I found the only way to get listened to was to say something disagreeable.”
Silver records Taylor as having told this anecdote on two earlier occasions, March 14, 1860, and February 17, 1864.

L.C. M.L. thinks Shirley's last week's Education Cut good ... Bishop and Minister and Forster saying to two children, “Subject to conscience clauses, etc. you may learn to read.” Accepted [Punch, 58 (26 March 1870): 121, “The Three R's, or Better Late Than Never”].
Shirley Brooks, still at home and very ill, wrote in his diary under March 8, “M.L. called. I was very bad, but I wrote for him a suggestion for a large cut, on the Education Bill, which I thought good. It was not used for the next number, but was accepted with acclaim, Sketchley said, later, and appeared.” (Morgan Library) Sketchley reminds us that tomorrow is St. Patrick's Day, and the Government bring in their measure for stopping Agrarian Outrages. Professor says, “Children can't be taught the 3 R's, because of the fourth – Religion.” ... Tom says his wife copies for him, the neatest handwriter in the world.
 [pointing finger] Saturday 19th, 9 p.m. B[lanche] (mumpish since Monday) and Bezique in breakfastroom: Eve of Wedding of Cick and Siss. ... And I dream of it and that W.B. attacks and S.B. defends.

div.head: March 23, 1870. W[ednesday]. No. 11. 6. 30.
div.p: F.E., D.M., H.S., F.C.B., Wagnew, J.T., M.L. , P.L., C.K., H.M., R.F.S.
(M.L. “will write” W.B. a daughter ce matin.)

L.C. T.T. by hieroglyphics suggests “Muzzling the Wolves” i.e. Irish Press: by Gladstone's Peace Bill. P.L. “Sedition Mongers Surprised.” G[ladstone] as policeman pouncing on an Editor and his treason printing crew. This we approve . . . but surely the Emperor's letter should be the subject. Mark proposes him handing it to Liberty, “Am I in earnest now?” J.T. adds “Poisson d'Avril?”“Non, parole d'honneur.” [ Punch, 58 (2 April 1870)” 131, “No April-Fooling”]

D.M. imitates Ponny “You dear kind hearted charitable b – ! ““You d – d noble gentlemanly cad!” Fancy Harold Power speaking at a Public Dinner thus! Last Wednesday, Professor un peu “tight” – insisted on Montalembert's death being noticed. ... “Burnand should do it . . or Silver, you are impartial very good article of yours about madmen”
“Madmen and their Murderers,” Punch, 58 (19 March 1870):115
